site_title: How China talked markets out of a run on the yuan
summary: China successfully defended the yuan against a run by signalling to markets what kind of selling it would and would not tolerate, preventing a destabilising slide. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) used "moral suasion" to steer market participants, buying yuan and advising banks to cut US dollar holdings. This approach has chilled the foreign exchange market, crashing trading volumes, but has also stabilized the currency above its 16-year low. Analysts describe the PBOC's strategy as "triage" to stop the yuan from falling too rapidly, and say it has prevented a destabilising yuan slide.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China says it will keep liquidity reasonably ample and guide the reasonable growth of credit.

site_title: Food manufacturers, industrial stocks among winners in 2023
summary: Singapore stocks ended 2023 down 1% on the FTSE ST All-Share Index, with the Straits Times Index closing 0.3% lower. Despite rising interest rates and geopolitical uncertainties, industrial and aviation stocks fared well, with Sembcorp Industries, Keppel Corp, and Singapore Airlines among top performers. Food manufacturers Food Empire and Delfi also rose 78% and 44.5% respectively. In contrast, property players struggled, with the sector expected to rebound in 2024 as interest rates are expected to come off.

images.alt_text: The benchmark index, which measures the performance of Reits in Singapore, gained 9 per cent in December, the best monthly performance since the index’s inception in September 2010.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust buys Vietnam logistics asset for S$26.5 million
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust has acquired a logistics asset in Vietnam, D Project Tan Duc 2, for S$26.5 million. The facility, fully leased for 20 years, is located near Ho Chi Minh City and provides cold storage services to a tenant specializing in frozen and chilled-food transportation. The deal is expected to be accretive to the Reit's distribution per unit and increase aggregate leverage to 38.2% on a pro forma basis.

The change in leadership is part of succession planning, DHLT said. Fujita will be returning to Japan to assume another appointment in Daiwa House Industry Co. – the trust’s sponsor.

site_title: ‘Wonka’ back atop North American box office in a weak film year
summary: Wonka, starring Timothée Chalamet, regained the top spot on the North American box office with an estimated $24 million for the three-day weekend and $31.8 million when including New Year's Day. The film has grossed over $140 million domestically and $244 million globally, marking a strong finish to a weak film year. Industry analyst David A Gross notes that audience tastes are shifting towards more family-friendly stories, with Wonka being a prime example.

images.alt_text: Netflix's movie "Society of the Snow" is also Spain’s official entry for the Oscars, and has made the final shortlists of possible nominees for best international film, best visual effects, best score, and best makeup and hairstyling.

site_title: Parasite actor's death prompts criticism of police, media
summary: South Korean actor Lee Sun-kyun, known for his Oscar-winning role in Parasite, has died under mysterious circumstances, prompting widespread criticism of police and media conduct during his investigation for suspected drug use. Lee's death has sparked public outrage, with many questioning the police's handling of the case and the media's role in fueling malicious coverage. Lee's family and friends have criticized the police for leaking confidential investigation details to the press, while experts have labeled his case a "social murder" due to the severe social ostracism he faced during the investigation.

images.alt_text: South Korean actor Lee Sun Kyun had been under police investigation over his alleged use of marijuana and other psychoactive drugs.
K-pop star G-Dragon arrives at a police station for questioning in Incheon on Nov 6, 2023.

site_title: Indosat Ooredoo Hutchison eyes growth in digital services, home broadband post-merger
summary: Indosat Ooredoo Hutchison (IOH), Indonesia's second-largest telco, aims to leverage its scale and synergies to expand into new growth areas, including fixed home broadband and digital services. Post-merger, IOH's revenue rose 8.5% and its net profit fell 24.4% due to increased financing costs. The company plans to reach 1 million home broadband customers by end-2024 and achieve 20% of its revenue from non-core services by 2026. IOH is also exploring opportunities in Indonesia's rapidly growing digital economy, aiming to transform into a "techco" and develop new digital services.

images.alt_text: Telcom CEO Ririek Adriansyah and chief finance and risk officer Heri Supriadi are also bullish on the company's plans to target higher-value customers.
Data-traffic growth and continued network expansions in Indonesia point to positive growth for telecommunications tower companies

site_title: UK property becoming more affordable at quickest pace in decades
summary: The UK property market is experiencing its longest stretch of improving affordability in over two decades, driven by forecasts of rising wage growth and stagnating or declining house prices. Despite a 1.8% drop in average house prices to £257,443, the outlook for housing affordability is improving, with wages racing ahead and expected to rise by 7.1% in 2023. The continued rise in pay, combined with modestly lower house prices and mortgage rates, may prevent a crash in the UK housing market, with many economists predicting a gradual improvement in affordability over time.

images.alt_text: luxe - Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg.

site_title: Musk is world’s richest person in 2023
summary: Elon Musk recaptured the title of world's richest person in 2023, surpassing French luxury tycoon Bernard Arnault, with a net worth increase of US$95.4 billion. The combined net worth of the 500 richest people surged by US$1.5 trillion, largely driven by the performance of tech stocks. Other notable billionaires include Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, and Miriam Adelson, who saw significant gains in 2023. However, some billionaires, such as Gautam Adani and Carl Icahn, experienced losses due to market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, who is the richest person on the planet with a fortune of US$209 billion, owns 13 per cent of Tesla and derives the majority of his wealth from the auto company.

site_title: Real estate stress is brewing in Asian markets other than China
summary: Asian real estate markets are facing stress, with countries such as South Korea, Indonesia, and Vietnam experiencing declining home prices and increasing debt risks. The International Monetary Fund warns that Australia is vulnerable to higher borrowing costs due to its high variable-rate mortgages. The Bank of Korea's aggressive monetary tightening has triggered a property slump in South Korea, while Indonesia's rate hikes have pressured heavily indebted home builders. Regulatory scrutiny and rising interest rates are causing distress for builders and creditors across the region, with potential restructuring of real estate project financing loans expected in 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An advertising sign for a new housing development area is seen with the Melbourne skyline in the distance May 5, 2009. REUTERS/Mick Tsikas/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s economy grows 1.2% in 2023, but ‘much will depend’ on global tensions in 2024: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.2% in 2023, with growth expected to be 1-3% in 2024, but Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warns that global tensions will continue to weigh on the economy in the coming years. Lee notes that the international environment remains troubled, with underlying tensions between the US and China, the ongoing war in Ukraine, and rising tensions in the South China Sea. Despite these challenges, Lee expresses hope and confidence in Singapore's resilience and ability to adapt to the changing global landscape.

site_title: Why Singapore’s demographic problem is no problem at all
summary: Singapore's aging population, with 15.1% of residents aged 65 or older, is not a problem, contrary to claims by some experts. In fact, the country's aging population is a sign of its economic progress and improved healthcare. With increased life expectancy and productivity, older workers can contribute to the economy, and the government's rising retirement and re-employment age plan will lead to more working-age individuals. Historically, economies have thrived despite aging populations, and Singapore's stock market has shown resilience. Demographic trends should not be used to predict future economic performance, and investors should focus on short-term factors instead.

site_title: S-Reits extend rally in December, climbing 9% in their best-ever monthly performance
summary: Singapore REITs logged their best-ever monthly performance in December, with the i-Edge S-Reit Index gaining 9% in December, the highest monthly gain since its inception in 2010. The rally beat the previous record of 8.6% in April 2020 and extended the 6.7% gains in November. Investors' optimism grew following signs of inflation control and the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance. Top-performing counters included US office Reits and other 11 trusts that posted double-digit gains, with CICT, MPACT, and MINT recording significant net institutional inflows.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB likes Genting Singapore for its growing market share of VIP gamers.
Active capital management has been a priority for Reit managers this year, amid heightened investor attention on gearing levels, with higher interest rates putting pressure on valuations.

site_title: Singapore stocks end last trading day of 2023 in the black; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,240.27 on its last trading day of 2023, up 0.8% or 25.87 points. The top gainer was Jardine Cycle and Carriage, while 17Live was a major loser. The broader market saw a gain of 370 to 202 gainers to losers, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changing hands. Economists caution investors to approach recession predictions for 2024 with caution, citing robust growth in real spending and tight labour market conditions.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng has slumped 14 per cent for the year in a fourth year of declines, while the CSI 300 fell 11 per cent.
Hong Kong and Tokyo opened the last trading session of the year marginally higher, with Japanese bourses clawing back some ground after losing steam to a strengthening yen a day earlier.

site_title: Institutional fund flow leaders in 2023
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

In 2023, the Singapore stock market experienced a net institutional outflow of S$4.1 billion, with Straits Times Index (STI) stocks contributing the majority of the outflow. The banks sector led the outflow, followed by the Reit sector. However, the utilities and consumer cyclicals sectors experienced the most net institutional inflow. Suntec Reit, a diversified Reit, saw a significant net institutional outflow, with 80% of it occurring in the first half of 2023. ComfortDelGro, a global land transport operator, experienced a net institutional inflow, driven by the growth of its taxi and PHV services.

site_title: World prepares to ring in 2024
summary: The world prepares to ring in 2024, marking the end of the hottest year on record. Global issues include a renewed assault by Russia on Ukraine, where defiance and hope prevail, and a series of pivotal elections, including the US presidential poll. The year will also bring a summer Olympics in Paris and a host of other global events. Despite turmoil, many are hopeful for a better year, with some in Russia yearning for an end to the conflict and a return to normal life.

site_title: Brics to grow as Saudi, Iran, UAE, Egypt, Ethiopia join ranks
summary: The Brics group of emerging-market nations is set to double in size, with Saudi Arabia, Iran, the UAE, Ethiopia, and Egypt joining on January 1, according to South Africa's envoy. This brings the total membership to 11, excluding India. The new members will participate in a sherpa meeting in Moscow on January 30. The group, formed in 2001, aims to promote economic growth and cooperation among its members, which have underperformed compared to other emerging markets over the past five years.

images.alt_text: South African delegates sit behind a glass with BRICS logo as the BRICS summit is held in Johannesburg, South Africa August 23, 2023. REUTERS/Alet Pretorius

site_title: 950,000 HDB households to receive U-Save and S&CC rebates in January
summary: Singaporean households living in Housing Board flats will receive rebates in January to offset the hike in goods and services tax, carbon tax, and water prices in 2024. Approximately 950,000 households will receive double their regular U-Save rebates, totaling S$160 over two years. Additionally, eligible households will receive an extra S$20 in S&CC rebates. The rebates are part of the Cost-of-Living Support Package announced by Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in September 2023.

site_title: Investor protection has not improved in Singapore: Mak Yuen Teen
summary: Singapore's investor protection remains low, despite the Singapore Exchange's corporatization in 1999, according to Professor Mak Yuen Teen. Capital market regulation and enforcement tend to favor business interests over investor rights, with regulators not stepping up enforcement actions effectively. Mak Yuen Teen launched a new research center at the National University of Singapore Business School to improve investor protection and corporate governance practices in Singapore, citing a need for better policies and practices. He advocates for a more balanced approach to regulation and enforcement, and greater accountability among company directors.

images.alt_text: One of the most critical activities that companies need to get right is the assessment of what sustainability-related factors are most material for the company.

site_title: Abercrombie’s 300% surge in 2023 beats even sizzling-hot Nvidia
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch's shares surged 300% in 2023, outperforming Nvidia Corp's 240% gain and exceeding its peers in the S&P Retail Select Industry Index. The retailer's strong year is attributed to its pivot towards targeting young millennials and Gen Z shoppers with broader offerings, including work-wear, special-occasion clothing, and active apparel. Analysts have boosted fourth-quarter adjusted earnings-per-share expectations by over 30%, and some predict the company can continue its momentum despite neutral Wall Street sentiment, with a 13% decrease from current shares expected.

images.alt_text: Abercrombie says it will now revamp its inventory by getting rid of casual and athleisure apparel that have fallen out of fashion, and bring in more dressier styles ahead of the key holiday season.

site_title:
Red Sea attacks mean double wages 
for crew of Danish liners
summary: Denmark's shipping industry has agreed to double wages for crew members sailing through the Red Sea due to the recent rebel attacks by Yemen-based Houthis in support of Hamas against Israel. This move aims to compensate for the danger posed by the attacks, which have forced many transport companies to avoid the Red Sea. The US-led task force is trying to bolster security on the key waterway, and Denmark will send a warship to the area to participate in the mission.

images.alt_text: Hapag-Lloyd earlier this month stopped using Red Sea routes and the Suez Canal after Yemen’s Houthi militant group began targeting vessels.

site_title: Swiss National Bank sold US$45 billion of forex in Q3
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) sold US$44.73 billion of foreign currency in the third quarter, the second-largest amount since 2020, as it neared the end of efforts to boost the Swiss franc to curb imported inflation. The sale, worth US$45 billion including a previously unreported US$600 million, was a decrease from the record US$63.2 billion in the second quarter. Chairman Thomas Jordan stated that the SNB is no longer focusing on foreign currency sales, citing the return of inflation to the target range.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Statues are seen on the building of the Swiss National Bank (SNB) in Bern, Switzerland May 20, 2020. Picture taken May 20, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices shed 10% in 2023 as supply, demand concerns weigh
summary: Oil prices shed 10% in 2023 due to concerns about supply and demand. Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate (WTI) contracts closed at their lowest year-end levels since 2020, settling at US$77.04 and US$71.65 per barrel, respectively. Geopolitical turmoil, including the Russia-Ukraine conflict, and OPEC+ supply cuts contributed to the decline. Analysts forecast weak global growth to cap demand in 2024, while ongoing tensions could provide support to prices.

images.alt_text: US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell by US$2.34, or 3.2 per cent, to US$71.77 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Full Monty star Tom Wilkinson dies aged 75
summary: Tom Wilkinson, the British actor known for his roles in "The Full Monty" and "Michael Clayton," died on December 30, 2023, at the age of 75. Wilkinson was a two-time Oscar nominee and won a Golden Globe and Emmy for his portrayal of Benjamin Franklin in the HBO series "John Adams." His death was confirmed by his agent on behalf of his family, who were with him at the time. Tributes poured in from his co-stars, including Robert Carlyle, who called him a "real titan of an actor" and George Clooney, who praised his elegance and talent.

images.alt_text: South Korean actor Lee Sun Kyun had been under police investigation over his alleged use of marijuana and other psychoactive drugs.

site_title: China factory activity contracts more than expected in December
summary: China's factory activity contracted for the third consecutive month in December, with the manufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) declining to 49 from 49.4 in November. Economists had expected a reading of 49.6. A non-manufacturing activity gauge rose to 50.4, while an underlying measure of services activity remained unchanged at 49.3. The decline signals persistent pressure on the economy from sluggish domestic and overseas demand.

images.alt_text: The logo of property developer Sunac is seen outside a residential compound in Beijing, China September 19, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: Singapore’s 2024 tourism performance hinges on return of China travellers
summary: Singapore's 2024 tourism performance is expected to be influenced by the return of Chinese travelers, despite slower economic growth in China and high costs in Singapore. The country's tourism recovery continued in 2023, with 12.37 million arrivals in the first 11 months, but still short of pre-pandemic levels. Analysts predict a continued recovery in 2024, but not to the same heights as 2019, with peak months not matching those of 2019.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending may grow more slowly in 2024 as post-Covid exuberance dies out.
Indonesia is Singapore's top source of visitors in November, followed by China, Malaysia, India and Australia.
The lobby of Pullman Bangkok King Power hosts a co-working space, where guests can relax, socialise, or hold small group meetings.

site_title: In 2024, focus on honing your ‘soft skills’
summary: Leaders are urged to focus on developing "soft skills" in 2024, including reading people, handling difficult situations, and negotiating tricky deals, as a way to improve communication and avoid conflict. The world's increasing noise and chaos make it difficult to have meaningful exchanges, and overly strong views can lead to combative challenges. Soft skills start with reasoning and respecting others' right to life, rather than agreeing to kill them. Developing these skills can lead to happiness and a more harmonious world, but they cannot be taught through procedures; rather, they require understanding and empathy.

The proliferation of AI in our lives and society is bringing up some tough questions about ownership.
Ask sincere questions, check your own biases, have empathy -- some ways to check if your business culture needs improvement.

site_title: India's economic growth sustainable, inflation falling, says government report
summary: India's economy is expected to sustain growth momentum with a forecasted growth rate of 6.5% in FY24, according to the government's monthly economic report. Despite a temporary increase in retail inflation to its quickest pace in three months, core inflation remains low at 4.1%, the lowest in nearly four years. The government attributes growth and stability risks to external factors, with consumption demand and rural demand expected to continue their upward trend.

site_title: This new year, take healthcare benefits seriously when picking your next job
summary: Employers in Singapore are under pressure to provide comprehensive healthcare benefits to attract and retain skilled workers. The government has raised the minimum mandatory health insurance coverage for employers, and companies are responding by offering wider coverage, including mental health services and maternity plans. However, rising healthcare costs pose a challenge, and some experts recommend co-payment to ensure responsible utilization of healthcare benefits. Ultimately, good healthcare coverage can lead to healthier, happier, and more productive employees, making it a key strategy for employers to invest in employee well-being.

site_title: 2023: A year of recovery and optimism
summary: The year 2023 saw the US Federal Reserve successfully curb inflation with high interest rates, achieving a "soft landing" despite global challenges. The global economy remained stable, with manufacturing indicators declining in the second half. Travel and tourism, particularly in China's reopening, helped offset this dip. The Straits Times Index (STI) grew 5.5% in 2023, underperforming major global benchmarks, but Singapore ESG indices outpaced the STI. Looking ahead, the year is expected to be marked by risks but also potential opportunities.

site_title: Former vice-chair of China's banking regulator handed life sentence
summary: A former vice-chairman of China's banking regulator, Cai Esheng, has been sentenced to life imprisonment for accepting 517 million yuan in bribes. The conviction is part of a crackdown on corruption in China's finance sector, which has seen over 4.8 million party officials investigated since 2012. The crackdown is suspected of serving as a tool for sidelining figures seen as opposing Xi Jinping. The sentencing comes amid a wave of corruption cases, including the recent conviction of a former head of China's central bank to over 16 years in prison.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd, Japanese shipping firms continue to re-route from Suez Canal
summary: German shipping company Hapag-Lloyd, along with Japanese firms Mitsui OSK Lines and Nippon Yusen, will continue to divert vessels around the Suez Canal due to security concerns. The decision comes after Yemen's Houthi militant group began targeting vessels. This move follows similar actions taken by other shipping companies, including Maersk, in an effort to minimize disruptions to global trade. Assessments will be made to reassess the situation on January 2.

images.alt_text: A ship crossing the Suez Canal towards the Red Sea on Dec 22. With Houthis targeting vessels in recent weeks, major shipping companies have rerouted their operations.

site_title: US tries to persuade shippers to sail through Red Sea despite Houthi attacks
summary: The US military is attempting to reassure shipping companies that it can provide safe passage through the Red Sea and Suez Canal despite Houthi rebel attacks. The Pentagon is engaging with industry on a daily basis to gauge needs and provide reassurance. However, shipping lines remain cautious, and it may take time for them to feel secure. The US and coalition forces are working to maintain safe passage, but so far, shippers are hesitant to return to the area.

images.alt_text: epa11040943 A ship crosses the Suez Canal towards the Red Sea in Ismailia, Egypt, 22 December 2023. These attacks in recent weeks had prompted major shipping companies to reroute their operations and raised concerns of prolonged disruptions to global trade.  EPA-EFE/MOHAMED HOSSAM

site_title: China's Sichuan Airlines to get US$1.7 billion capital investment from shareholders
summary: China's Sichuan Airlines is set to receive a US$1.69 billion capital investment from its major shareholder, China Southern Airlines. The investment will be made in three instalments, including a cash payment of US$2.34 billion, and will help supplement working capital and reduce financial security risks. China Southern will also transfer an Airbus A330-300 aircraft worth around 485 million yuan. The move aims to "expand the scope of corporate development and enhance the risk resistance capacities of Sichuan Airlines."

site_title: How to be a better CEO in 2024
summary: A complex world with rapidly shifting goal posts requires agile leaders, according to Stefanie Yuen Thio. The past four years have been marked by significant global events, including the COVID-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. To thrive in uncertain times, CEOs must adopt authentic leadership, prioritize adaptability, and break free from traditional leadership structures. Effective leaders must also be willing to challenge conventional wisdom and foster a culture of innovation and growth. By embracing these qualities, CEOs can position their organizations for success in a rapidly changing world.

images.alt_text: Today, CEOs must deal with geopolitical uncertainty, mounting government regulation, high inflation and interest rates, rising populism, cyberattacks and advances in artificial intelligence.

site_title: Four management secrets of Greek orthodox monks
summary: Greek Orthodox monks on the Athos peninsula have developed four effective management secrets: disconnecting to focus, mastering specialisation, exploiting core and distinctive competencies, and being steadfast with objectives. The monks' unplugged lifestyle and prescribed responsibilities allow them to concentrate on their tasks, leading to improved productivity. Specialisation and single-tasking enable them to excel in their roles, while their distinctive competencies, such as spiritual guidance, attract pilgrims and donations. The monasteries' ability to adapt and persevere, even in challenging times, is a testament to their enduring success.

site_title: Sri Lanka inflation quickens for third month as economy rebounds
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation rose 4% in December, a third consecutive month, as the economy rebounds from an unprecedented crisis. The Central Bank of Sri Lanka had expected this outcome, following a pause in interest rate cuts last month. The country's economy expanded for the first time in nearly two years in the July-September quarter, thanks to a $3 billion IMF bailout. This marks a turnaround in Sri Lanka's economic recovery efforts, but inflation remains a concern.

site_title: Former SPH Media executive Patrick Daniel appointed to SBS Transit’s board
summary: SBS Transit appointed Patrick Daniel, former interim CEO of SPH Media Trust, to its board as of January 1, 2024. Daniel was chosen for his independence, qualifications, and experience. The group believes he will bring a balance of skills and knowledge to the board, providing greater diversity. His appointment aims to enhance the board's composition and capabilities.

images.alt_text: Ex-interim CEO Patrick Daniel sets out what SPH Media Trust must do to be successful
Six new directors appointed to board of SPH Media Holdings
Patrick Daniel to be interim CEO of SPH Media Trust; digital media capacity to be enhanced

site_title: US: Stocks end banner year with modest loss in final session
summary: US stocks ended the year with a modest loss, down 0.1% at 37,689.54, in a sharp reversal from the year's trend. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which closed at records the last two days, fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 dipped 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.6%. Despite a strong US economy, market watchers warn that the market's lofty valuation and higher labor costs could pose challenges for further gains.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., October 27, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Signa Development files for insolvency with US$1.3 billion in debts
summary: Signa Development, a division of European property company Signa, has filed for insolvency in a Vienna court with debts of around US$1.28 billion. This follows the announcement by Signa that its development division and Signa Prime would file for insolvency. The company has 39 projects in the works, and another division, Signa Prime Selection, filed for self-administrated restructuring on Thursday. The move is a significant twist in the unraveling of founder Rene Benko's real estate empire.

site_title: China’s fireworks ban sparks fiery debate ahead of Chinese New Year
summary: Chinese lawmakers have weighed in on the debate over fireworks during Chinese New Year, stating that a total ban on pyrotechnics is difficult to implement due to existing air pollution prevention and fire safety regulations. Despite this, some counties have banned fireworks, sparking discussion on the ban. An online poll showed over 80% of respondents support fireworks during the holiday. The ban is seen as ironic by some, given the United Nations' recent adoption of the Spring Festival as an official holiday.

images.alt_text: The logo of property developer Sunac is seen outside a residential compound in Beijing, China September 19, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo
People stand on the Bund as buildings along the Huangpu river are seen shrouded in fog, amid a red alert for heavy fog in Shanghai, China, Dec 29, 2023.

site_title: New wave of phishing SMSes scam 103 victims of S$161,000 in December
summary: The Singapore Police Force reported a new wave of phishing SMSes in December, scamming at least 103 victims of S$161,000. Scammers impersonated banks, attempting to get online banking credentials and OTPs via SMSes with embedded links. Victims who clicked on the links were directed to spoofed bank websites, capturing their credentials. WhatsApp messages were also used, impersonating bank security department officers with forged statements. The police advise the public to download the ScamShield app and set security features for bank accounts and e-wallets to protect themselves from scams.

images.alt_text: Scammers typically use internet calling services to spoof local numbers.
The shared responsibility framework for phishing scams will assign all losses to financial institutions and telecoms companies that fail to discharge their prescribed duties

SPF noted a resurgence of a scam variant that involves the impersonation of registered property agents, where victims were pressured by fake agents into making payments to secure the viewing or rental of properties.

site_title: US dollar sees first yearly loss since 2020
summary: The US dollar is set to end 2023 with its first yearly loss since 2020, as it declined against the euro and a basket of currencies. The dollar's decline accelerated after the US Federal Reserve adopted an unexpectedly dovish tone and forecast 75 basis points in rate reductions for 2024. This move is seen as a response to moderating inflation and slowing US economic growth. The Fed's decision is expected to lead to further dollar declines, with some analysts predicting a significant weakening in anticipation of future rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index is on course for a 2.7 per cent decline this year, snapping two straight years of strong gains.

site_title: Boeing says Chinese airlines resumed operating all 737 MAX planes in 2023
summary: Boeing's 737 MAX planes have resumed operations with Chinese airlines, with nearly 100 planes in service as of the end of 2023. The aircraft returned to service globally in late 2020 after modifications and pilot training, with Chinese airlines resuming flights in January 2023. The move represents a significant boost for Boeing's finances and could mark a reset of its relationship with China, which has been largely frozen out of new orders since 2017.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Boeing 787 Dreamliner airplane is seen in Long Beach, California March 14, 2012. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried will not face a second trial
summary: US prosecutors have decided not to pursue a second trial against Sam Bankman-Fried, who was convicted last month of stealing from FTX customers. Prosecutors cited the "strong public interest" in a prompt resolution and the upcoming March 28, 2024, sentencing, which may include orders of forfeiture and restitution. Most evidence that could be presented at a second trial was already presented during the first trial, according to prosecutors.

images.alt_text: Jurors are expected to begin deliberations on Thursday after prosecutors give a rebuttal argument, meaning Sam Bankman-Fried may learn his fate just shy of one year after FTX filed for bankruptcy.

site_title: World rings in 2024 after war, bots and Barbie
summary: The world welcomed 2024 after a tumultuous 2023 marked by devastating wars, climate crises, and the emergence of human-seeming artificial intelligence. The year saw a record-breaking temperature, with numerous climate-fueled disasters. Notable events include war in the Middle East, particularly in Gaza and Ukraine, and the passing of notable figures such as Tina Turner and Matthew Perry. Pivotal elections are scheduled in 2024, including the US presidential contest and European Parliament elections, which could shape global politics.

images.alt_text: As well as New Year, Big Ben also continued to mark Armistice Day and Remembrance Sunday when the nation remembers its war dead.
In Ukraine, where Russia’s invasion grinds towards its second anniversary, there was defiance and hope in the face of a renewed assault from Moscow.
In an online poll in China this week, over 80 per cent of respondents have expressed support for fireworks during Chinese New Year.

site_title: Nvidia launches new gaming chip for China to comply with US export controls
summary: Nvidia launched the GeForce RTX 4090 D, a modified gaming chip designed for China, to comply with US export controls. The chip, offering improved performance and AI-driven graphics, will be available in January. It is 5% slower than the banned RTX 4090 but costs 350 yuan more. The move follows new export rules unveiled by the Biden administration in October, which blocked sales of certain AI chips to China. Nvidia commands 90% of China's AI chip market, and the US curbs are expected to create opportunities for domestic firms like Huawei.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed NVIDIA logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Huawei expects revenues of more than 700 billion yuan (S$131.1 billion) in 2023.

site_title: Fighting fraud and forgery in commodities trading
summary: Singapore's commodities trading scene has faced numerous scandals, including a $1.5 billion nickel fraud case and a $768 million loss by Trafigura due to worthless cargoes. The industry is undergoing a revamp to restore the country's reputation. Companies like Hin Leong, which posted a $78.2 million profit in 2019, have been marred by troubles, including allegations of wrongdoing. The government's efforts to combat fraud and forgery in commodities trading aim to revitalize the sector and regain Singapore's reputation as a hub for commodities trading.

images.alt_text: The revelation is the latest twist in a case that has shocked the commodity trading world, after Trafigura in February accused Gupta of perpetrating a massive fraud against it.
ExxonMobil has been trying to build out its trading business since 2018 but has faced several hurdles including cost-cutting during the pandemic.
In the new case, US trading house Kataman Metals alleges it paid US$3.3 million for nickel from New Alloys Trading only to discover when it opened the containers that there was no nickel inside.
Plans are underway to transform Jurong Island - the pulse of Singapore's energy and chemicals sector - into a space that operates sustainably and exports sustainable products globally

Shell is targeting spending cuts over the next two years to boost profitability while remaining committed to achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. Those efforts include the review of energy and chemicals assets on Singapore’s Bukom and Jurong islands.

A Sept 2022 file photo of a nickel smelting facility in Konawe, Southeast Sulawesi. Many of the materials critical for the green transition are currently produced in far fewer areas than oil and gas are.
The region’s biggest industry gathering is a staple of the calendar, offering both a handy litmus test of the market’s current mood as well as clues on the outlook.
OK Lim’s health has been deteriorating since the collapse of Hin Leong; he has also said he has depression and anxiety.

site_title: UK consumers to cut back in 2024, adding to recession risk
summary: UK consumers are expected to cut back on spending in 2024, adding to recession risk, as inflation remains steady and 41% of consumers feel less financially secure than in 2022. Card spending increased just 4.1% over 2023, less than half the 10.6% gain a year ago, and households are cutting back on non-essential items. Forecasts suggest the economy will stagnate or contract, with unemployment expected to rise as businesses cut costs. This could worsen Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's economic woes ahead of the next general election.

images.alt_text: epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: China, HK stocks end 2023 as world's worst performers, down over 10%
summary: China and Hong Kong stocks ended 2023 as the world's worst-performing equity markets, with losses exceeding 10%. The Hang Seng slumped 14% for the year, and the CSI 300 fell 11%. This marks a fourth consecutive year of declines for the Hang Seng. Despite the losses, some analysts see opportunities in battered shares due to Beijing's economic stimulus and a rebounding yuan currency.

images.alt_text: The US equity market has continued to defy naysayers.
Hong Kong and Tokyo opened the last trading session of the year marginally higher, with Japanese bourses clawing back some ground after losing steam to a strengthening yen a day earlier.
The benchmark Topix is headed for an annual return of 25 per cent and the Nikkei 225 Stock Average is set to post a 29 per cent rally - the best performance since 2013.

site_title: Terraform, SEC set for crypto trial with Jump Trading in spotlight
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) will go to trial with Terraform Labs in January over allegations that Terraform sold unregistered securities. A judge ruled that the SEC's case must be tried by a jury, with Jump Trading being swept up in the trial as a key trader of Terraform's algorithmic stablecoin TerraUSD. The SEC claims Terraform secretly entered into an arrangement with Jump to prop up TerraUSD before it collapsed, wiping out at least $40 billion in market value. Jump has not been accused of any wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: Binance, the largest crypto exchange, has come under increased pressure from regulators around the world in the past year.

site_title: Everything Wall Street got wrong in 2023
summary: The US equity market defied naysayers in 2023, continuing its upward trend despite predictions of a recession. Wall Street experts, including Morgan Stanley's Mike Wilson, Bank of America's Meghan Swiber, and Goldman Sachs' Kamakshya Trivedi, predicted a decline in US stocks, Treasury bonds, and Chinese stocks. However, the market instead experienced a strong performance, with the S&P 500 Index rising. The consensus view of selling US stocks and buying Treasuries and Chinese stocks proved incorrect, and the market continued to defy expectations.

images.alt_text: A trader watches US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell on a screen during a news conference. Powell has warned that the Fed will continue tightening monetary policy in 2024.

site_title: Indonesia’s Aneka Tambang sells shares of subsidiaries to world’s biggest EV battery company
summary: Indonesian miner Aneka Tambang (Antam) sold shares worth $467.18 million in two subsidiaries to CATL, a unit of China's largest EV battery maker, Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Ltd (CATL). CATL now controls 49% of Sumberdaya Arindo and 60% of Feni Haltim. The sales are part of an agreement to develop an EV ecosystem in Indonesia, including a high-pressure acid leaching plant to process nickel ore into battery materials. This move aims to support Indonesia's goal of producing 600,000 EVs by 2030.

images.alt_text: The most profitable EV batteries to recycle are made of lithium, nickel, cobalt and manganese.

site_title: US dollar set for worst year since 2020
summary: The US dollar is poised for its worst year since 2020, with a Bloomberg gauge down nearly 3% since January. The decline is attributed to market expectations of the Federal Reserve lowering interest rates, which could lead to a sharp loosening of policy. Swaps traders are now factoring in Fed rate cuts of at least 150 basis points, with the first cut potentially coming as soon as March. The dollar's decline contrasts with the pound, which is set for its best year since 2017, and the franc, on pace for its strongest annual performance since 2010.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1 per cent to close at 37,710.10 on Thursday, notching a second straight all-time closing high. The blue-chip index is up almost 14 per cent so far for all of 2023.

Representative Sara McKethan, left, hands a list of employment descriptions to a job seeker during the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Sara McKethan
The Fed has carried out an exceedingly difficult task almost perfectly.
A trader watches US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell on a screen during a news conference. Powell has warned that the Fed will continue tightening monetary policy in 2024.
While businesses say that a lack of experienced and skilled workers remains a trouble spot, the survey results indicate that labour supply is coming into better balance with demand.

site_title: Oscar-tipped Society of the Snow gives voice to the victims of Andes plane crash
summary: A new Netflix movie, "Society of the Snow," tells the true story of the 1972 Andes plane crash that killed 29 people and left 16 survivors. The film, directed by JA Bayona, follows the Uruguayan rugby team as they trek across the freezing mountains to find rescue, facing avalanches, infected wounds, and dire conditions. The movie is also Spain's official entry for the Oscars and has earned nominations for January's Golden Globes and Critics Choice Awards. The survivors, including Canessa, 70, believe the story still holds important messages for future generations.

images.alt_text: Tom Wilkinson, who was born in Leeds to a family of farmers, studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London and racked up more than 130 film and TV credits

site_title: Chinese military purge exposes weakness, could widen
summary: China's military purge of nine senior generals has weakened the People's Liberation Army, exposing deep-rooted corruption that could slow leader Xi Jinping's military modernization drive. The purge, targeting the Rocket Force, a key arm of the PLA, has raised questions over oversight of massive military investments amid geopolitical tensions with the US. Analysts say the purge is a setback for Xi, who aims to build a "world-class" military by 2050, and may lead to a temporary weakening of the Rocket Force, which oversees tactical and nuclear missiles.

images.alt_text: Dong Jun (top) was most recently the People’s Liberation Army Navy chief. He replaces Li Shangfu, who took up the defence minister job in March but had not been seen in public since Aug 25.

site_title: Indian solar panel maker Waaree Energies to raise US$361 million in IPO
summary: Waaree Energies, India's top solar panel maker, filed for a US$361 million initial public offering (IPO) to raise funds for its manufacturing facility and expansion plans. The company aims to boost renewable energy in India, which is targeting a non-fossil fuel energy capacity boost. Waaree plans to use the funds to build a 6-gigawatt manufacturing facility in Odisha and invest up to US$1 billion in a Texas factory. The IPO includes the sale of 3.2 million shares, including 2.7 million by Waaree Sustainable Finance, its largest shareholder.

site_title: UK house prices slide 1.8% in 2023, defying crash forecast
summary: UK house prices ended 2023 with a 1.8% decline from last year, defying predictions of a sharp crash. A shortage of properties on the market and robust demand helped the market hold steady. Prices were unchanged in December, with a 0.2% gain the previous month. This marks a slight increase from economists' forecasted 1.3% drop. Despite falling 4.5% below peak prices in late summer 2022, the market is expected to recover as mortgage costs ease and interest rates are anticipated to decrease in the coming year.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: How China’s property crisis blew up bets that couldn’t lose
summary: China's property sector is experiencing a full-blown crisis, with the Citic fund's failure providing a window into the broader issues. A $1.7 billion fund raised by Citic Trust in 2020 to fund property development projects has recouped only a small fraction of its investment, with three projects on hold or delayed due to financing and sales problems. The crisis has destabilized local governments' budgets and drained China's capital markets, with state-backed developers defaulting on debt and investors restructurering debt to prevent default. China's central government has pledged to "actively and prudently resolve real estate risks."

images.alt_text: The outlook signals the downturn in the property market is far from over, despite the government’s rollout of measures mostly aimed at stoking demand for homes.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How profitable will 2024 be? (Ep 159)
summary: Experts from Endowus, OANDA, and Federated Hermes discuss 2024's market outlook, with interest rates potentially reducing. They advise retail investors to position themselves for growth, focusing on sectors like technology and healthcare. US and global markets are expected to perform well, with a focus on emerging markets. The conversation also touches on the implications of the Fed's recent pause in rate hikes and the potential for gold as a safe-haven investment.

images.alt_text: Gold is the ultimate safe haven because of its history and also its liquidity profile.

The top 10 stocks by market capitalisation account for over 65 per cent of the returns in the S&P 500 in 2023. While these names will benefit from falling interest rates and the widespread adoption of artificial intelligence, investors could seek investment opportunities beyond the mega-caps.

site_title: Vietnam’s 2023 GDP growth slows to 5.05%; trade surplus hits new record
summary: Vietnam's 2023 GDP growth slowed to 5.05% due to weak external demand, falling short of the government's official target of 6.5%. The country's trade surplus reached a record high of $28 billion, driven by strong exports of electronics and smartphones. Industrial production increased 5.8% year-over-year, while services sector growth was 6.82%. Despite a subdued outlook for the manufacturing sector, analysts expect a recovery in 2024 driven by exports and green shoots in the sector. Vietnam's legislature set GDP growth and inflation targets for 2024, aiming for 6-6.5% growth and 4-4.5% inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Vietnamese flag flies atop the State Bank building, near the Vietcombank and Bank for Investment and Development of Vietnam buildings, in central Hanoi, Vietnam November 23, 2017. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
The price of gold in Vietnam has skyrocketed this month, reaching a peak of 80 million dong per ounce on Tuesday.
Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (left) met with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida in Tokyo. Vietnam is hopeful that Japan will provide loans for its infrastructure projects.

site_title: Maersk temporarily halts sailing through Red Sea after attack on its Singapore-flagged ship
summary: A Singapore-flagged Maersk container ship was attacked near Yemen on December 31, prompting the company to halt transits through the Suez Canal for 48 hours. The ship, Maersk Hangzhou, was hit by an unknown object while passing through the Bab al-Mandab Strait en route from Singapore to Egypt. Maersk is working with the US-led multinational security force and authorities to assess the security level and determine the cause of the attack.

images.alt_text: A truck hauling an AP Moller-Maersk A/S container, front, and a truck hauling an Ocean Network Express (ONE) container travel past stacked containers at a shipping terminal in Yokohama, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 18, 2021. Japan’s trade deficit likely expanded in September, driven by slowing exports and a bigger import bill due to higher commodity prices. Japan is scheduled to release trade balance figures on Oct. 20. site_title: PowerPoint parties and the joy of ‘useless’ knowledge
summary: The article discusses the trend of "PowerPoint parties," where individuals give presentations on various topics, often silly or serious, to friends and colleagues. This trend promotes aimless, spontaneous learning and repurposes a tool associated with work into a fun and engaging activity. The concept is rooted in the idea that useless knowledge can be meaningful and enjoyable, as seen in the works of Abraham Flexner, who wrote that many useful inventions originated from useless pursuits. The author encourages readers to consider including "useless" pursuits in their new year's resolutions, embracing the joy of learning for its own sake.

images.alt_text: Sam Wu, a certified water sommelier, pays close attention to the mineral composition of various water brands.

site_title: South Korea pledges support to prevent contagion from a builder’s woes
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok pledged support to prevent contagion from a builder's debt troubles, with a US$66 billion program to stabilize markets if needed. The central bank warned that real estate risks would likely increase next year due to a sluggish market and rising interest rates. Authorities will make efforts to stabilize the financial market and expand measures as needed, amid concerns that debt troubles may spread to other builders and pressure lenders.

images.alt_text: A general view shows under construction work amid residential and commercial buildings on a polluted day in Seoul on November 21, 2023. (Photo by Anthony WALLACE / AFP)

site_title: Climate change makes forecasting harder, says Australia’s Watt
summary: Australia's agriculture minister Murray Watt stated that climate change is making it harder to accurately predict extreme weather events, impacting the country's meteorology department. Watt acknowledged criticisms of the Bureau of Meteorology's failure to provide timely warnings before deadly storms, saying "meteorology is not a perfect science." The country is still recovering from the deadly storms, with thousands without power, and severe heat waves predicted for the north-western regions. Watt expressed openness to improving the Bureau's performance, emphasizing the need for adapting to a changing climate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view shows the central Swiss Alps and the town of Zug, Switzerland March 28, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: US mortgage rates fall to lowest since May, dropping to 6.61%
summary: US mortgage rates fell to 6.61% for a 30-year, fixed loan, the lowest level since May, according to Freddie Mac. This marks a decline from 6.67% last week and a peak of 7.79% in October. Industry watchers expect the steady decline in borrowing costs to fuel demand for home purchases in the coming months. However, listings remain scarce, prices remain out of reach for many Americans, and mortgage rates are more than double where they were in 2022, suggesting a slow and bumpy rebound.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A newly constructed home available for sale is pictured in a new housing development area in Vista, California March 20, 2012. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose at the opening bell on Friday, driven by Wall Street gains. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 7.87 points or 0.2% to 3,222.27, with local banks leading gains. DBS led the charge, up 0.3%, followed by OCBC and UOB. The US market ended on a positive note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a fresh record, while European stocks declined due to weakness in banking and oil majors.

images.alt_text: CMG20231215-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.
Sembcorp Industries is developing a 190-hectare industrial park in Ha Tinh, Vietnam.

site_title:
ECB’s Lagarde says euro gives greater
sovereignty in a turbulent world
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the euro has given Europe greater sovereignty in a turbulent world, marking its 25th anniversary. The currency has helped the region stay self-determined globally, despite rising geopolitical tensions, a climate crisis, and competitiveness challenges. The euro has made life simpler for European citizens, provided stability, and protected growth and jobs amid crises. Despite predictions of the euro's disintegration, the region has welcomed new members, including Croatia, and several countries are still considering adoption, citing the need for collective action.

images.alt_text: British finance minister Jeremy Hunt (L) travelled to Bern to sign the deal with his Swiss counterpart Karin Keller-Sutter.

site_title: Denmark’s Queen Margrethe II announces surprise abdication
summary: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark announced her surprise abdication on January 1, 2024, citing her age and health issues, and will pass the throne to her son Crown Prince Frederik on January 14, 2024. The 83-year-old monarch, Europe's longest-serving monarch, has reigned for 52 years and will be succeeded by her 55-year-old son, who has championed Denmark's efforts to address the climate crisis. The decision marks a significant change in the country's monarchy, with Crown Prince Frederik representing a more modern and liberal approach to the institution.

images.alt_text: Fireworks are seen over the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge during New Year’s Eve celebrations in Sydney, Australia, Jan 1, 2024.

Launched by 11 countries at the start of 1999, the euro stayed an electronic currency for its first three years. The euro area now includes 20 countries, making it the payment method for some 350 million people.

site_title: How Asia can lead the global energy race to net zero
summary: Asia is poised to become the world's leading consumer of energy by 2050, with a significant impact on the global energy transition to net zero. The region's growing economies and increasing energy demands pose significant challenges, including scaling up renewable energy projects, building collective will, and increasing the bankability of projects. Innovative partnerships, such as building an Asean power grid, and financial innovation, like high-quality transition credits, can accelerate the transition. Governments, financial institutions, and industries must work together to create a just transition, with Asia leading the way to a more sustainable future.

images.alt_text: Coal is transported on barges in Samarinda, East Kalimantan in January 11, 2022.

Banks are under pressure to reduce and disclose their financed emissions, which refer to the greenhouse gases generated from activities funded by their lending and investment portfolios.

site_title: US state of Maine blocks Trump from its Republican presidential primary
summary: Maine has blocked Donald Trump from its Republican presidential primary, citing his involvement in the January 2021 US Capitol assault as grounds for disqualification. The ruling, which invokes the US Constitution's 14th Amendment, bars individuals who engage in insurrection from holding public office. This move follows a similar ruling in Colorado, which Trump's campaign has vowed to challenge in the US Supreme Court. Trump's campaign calls the decision an "attempted theft of an election" and accuses President Joe Biden and Democrats of "relying on the force of government institutions to protect their grip on power."

images.alt_text: The high court action comes days after a Colorado court ruled that Trump is constitutionally ineligible to become president again because he engaged in insurrection and incited the Jan 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
Voters give Biden little credit for his stewardship of the economy, polls show.
The Colorado ruling is the first to say that Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election results render him ineligible to run for president again.
Republican presidential candidate and former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at a rally in Durham, New Hampshire, U.S. December 16, 2023. REUTERS/Brian Snyder

Hunter Biden, son of US President Joe Biden, speaks to members of the media outside the US Capitol in Washington, DC, Dec 13, 2023.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 29)
summary: The Economic Ministry of Singapore (EMA) attributes the rise in electricity tariffs for Q1 to an increase in carbon tax. Electricity tariffs are expected to increase by 4.8% to 32.58 Singapore cents kilowatt-hour (KWh) due to a 1% increase in GST. Additionally, 2024 marks the end of a downward trend in corporate tax rates, with a floor being set for the first time in four decades. Geely-owned luxury EV brand Zeekr will start selling in Singapore in 2024, with first deliveries expected in June or July.

site_title: China home sales fall again as policy shifts fail to stem decline
summary: China's home sales plummeted 34.6% in December from a year earlier to 451.3 billion yuan, with major developers' full-year sales 16.5% lower than 2022. Despite policy changes to revive demand, the market remains sluggish, with buyers spooked by price drops, construction delays, and company defaults. China's prolonged housing downturn has weakened the economy and hurt developers struggling to repay debts, with industry giant Country Garden Holdings defaulting on a dollar bond in October.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in Zhengzhou, Henan province, China, on Thursday, Jan. 6, 2023. China is planning to relax restrictions on developer borrowing, dialing back the stringent "three red lines" policy that exacerbated one of the biggest real estate meltdowns in the country’s history. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Five sports events to watch out for in 2024
summary: Key sports events to watch in 2024 include the Paris Summer Olympics (July 26 to August 11), Euro 2024 in Germany (June 14 to July 14), and the Undefeated boxers Tyson Fury and Oleksandr Usyk's heavyweight battle in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on February 17. The Singapore Swimming World Cup will also take place in October, and One Championship will stage a live MMA event in Qatar on March 1.

site_title: Swiss financial watchdog wants to examine clawing back bankers’ bonuses
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator, Finma, is seeking stronger powers to claw back bonuses from bankers, following the collapse of Credit Suisse. Finma chairwoman Marlene Amstad wants to discuss the ability to demand bonuses be repaid, citing the bank's history of incurring losses while paying out high bonuses. Finma has previously demanded stronger powers to oversee lenders, including the ability to issue fines and increase accountability. The regulator's proposals come as part of a broader effort to reform banking regulations and increase transparency in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore says Credit Suisse has since strengthened its internal controls to prevent the recurrence of such misconduct.

site_title: JD.com wins anti-monopoly lawsuit against Alibaba
summary: JD.com wins a lawsuit against Alibaba, with the High People's Court of Beijing ruling that the e-commerce giant abused its market dominance and adopted monopolistic practices known as "choosing one from two". Alibaba was fined 1 billion yuan (S$186 million) for the practices, which caused JD.com severe damage. The ruling is seen as a landmark moment in upholding market fairness and competition order through the rule of law, with JD.com stating it's a fair decision for its resistance against the monopoly.

images.alt_text: JD.com reports net revenue of 247.7 billion yuan (S$46.1 billion) for the third quarter, missing analysts’ average estimate of 249.26 billion yuan.

site_title: 2024 will herald the end of a race to the bottom in corporate tax rates
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has implemented a global minimum corporate tax rate of 15% for multinational companies with annual revenues of over $1.1 billion, starting in 2024. This reform, part of the 2021 "inclusive framework," aims to end the downward spiral in corporate tax rates and increase global revenues by an estimated $220 billion annually. The European Union has led the way in implementing the new rules, with almost all member states set to apply them from the start of 2024, and other countries are expected to follow suit, potentially introducing top-up taxes for companies not adhering to the minimum rate.

images.alt_text: With BEPS Pillar 2, Singapore will need to consolidate its appeal to global MNEs and reframe its investment promotion strategies.

Pillar 2 of BEPS 2.0 introduces a minimum effective tax rate of 15 per cent for multi-national enterprise (MNE) groups with annual group revenues of at least 750 million euros. This will be implemented in Singapore on or after Jan 1, 2025.
The new global tax rules will affect all business groups with annual global revenue of 750 million euros or more, regardless of industry.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens subdued on last day of cheery 2023, rate cuts in view
summary: US stocks opened subdued on the last day of 2023, with the Dow Jones falling 8.47 points (0.02%) to 37,701.63. The S&P 500 opened lower by 0.47 point (0.01%) to 4,782.88, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 4.06 points (0.03%) to 15,099.20. The subdued opening comes as investors await potential interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve in early 2024, contributing to a record-high close for the S&P 500 in 2023.

site_title: Fog, haze in China as New Year travellers brace for potential disruptions
summary: Heavy fog and haze are forecast to shroud areas from northern China to southern Shanghai for over 24 hours, prompting warnings from the Central Meteorological Observatory. Over 600 flights were delayed, and severe fog is expected in parts of northern Hebei, central Henan, and eastern provinces. Residents in affected areas are advised to reduce time outdoors and avoid traveling unless necessary. The weather is due to improve from Saturday evening with a cold wave expected to blow over the country.

site_title: Mums at work: S Korean firm’s pro-parent, office-free policies
summary: Erin Lim, CEO of Konny, a South Korean firm, has pioneered an office-free work policy to support working mothers. Since 2017, the company, which has 55 staff members, 92% of whom are women and most of whom are working parents, has allowed employees to work from home with flexible hours and minimal in-person meetings. This approach has helped Lim balance her career and family life, prioritizing her children's needs. Konny's success has contributed to the company's growth and has sparked a conversation about the need for a more family-friendly work culture in South Korea, where women's workforce participation is low.

images.alt_text: Lucas Mundt’s cubicle. “If I’m going to spend 40 to 50 hours a week there, I wanted it to feel comfortable and relaxing,” he says.

site_title: Britain's Big Ben marks 100 years of New Year 'bongs'
summary: Big Ben, London's iconic clock tower, marks 100 years of its "bongs" being broadcast live across the world to ring in the New Year. The tradition began in 1923 when BBC engineer AG Dryland recorded the strikes. The clock also marks other important events, such as Armistice Day and Remembrance Sunday. Clock mechanic Andrew Strangeway will make final checks to ensure the clock is accurate for New Year's Eve. The clock's timing mechanism is adjusted using old pennies attached to springs, a method unchanged since its completion in 1859.

images.alt_text: Shoppers queue at a fruit and vegetable stall in Bexleyheath, Greater London, UK, on Monday, Dec. 18, 2023. Recession fears may stalk Britain’s economy once again, with the threat of a downgrade this week to previous GDP estimates that had raised hopes that the country may have avoided a contraction. site_title: Singapore office landlords bank on green leases, ESG compliance to woo tenants at higher rents
summary: Singapore office landlords are incorporating green leases and ESG compliance into office leasing contracts to attract tenants willing to pay higher rents. Tenants are prioritizing sustainability features, such as energy efficiency and waste reduction, in their lease agreements. As a result, landlords are seeing a premium of less than 5% or 10% or higher for offices with strong ESG credentials. Green buildings can command higher rents, with a 10-15% premium over surrounding buildings. The cost of upgrading to ESG standards can range from S$800,000 to S$6 million, but long-term savings can be significant, making ESG compliance a key consideration for landlords.

site_title: Needing labour, Israel recruits workers from South Asia
summary: Israel is recruiting workers from India and Sri Lanka to fill labor gaps in the construction, healthcare, and agriculture sectors, amid a shortage of Palestinian workers due to the Hamas-led attack in October. The recruitment is part of agreements between the three countries, which aim to provide workers for existing quotas. Approximately 10,000 Sri Lankan workers are already employed in Israel, and thousands more from India and Sri Lanka are expected to be sent, primarily for construction jobs. The move is intended to address labor shortages, not replace Palestinian workers, according to Israeli officials.

images.alt_text: Israeli volunteers walk with buckets as they arrive for the avocado fruit harvest at a plantation near Kibbutz Erez close to the border with the Gaza Strip in southern Israel on December 20, 2023, amidst a shortage of workers due to the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas. site_title: Drugmakers set to raise US prices on at least 500 drugs in January
summary: US drugmakers including Pfizer, Sanofi, and Takeda Pharmaceutical plan to raise prices on over 500 unique drugs in January, with Pfizer accounting for more than a quarter of the planned hikes. The price increases come amid higher inflation and manufacturing costs, and as the Biden Administration prepares to publish discounted prices for high-cost drugs in September. The pharmaceutical industry is also facing disruptions to supply chains due to the Middle East conflict.

site_title: Singapore: An ideal portfolio diversifier
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) has proven to be a stable investment option in 2023, trading within a narrower 10% range compared to other major indices. This reduced volatility makes it an ideal addition to a diversified portfolio, particularly in a year expected to see increased market uncertainty due to macroeconomic slowdowns and geopolitical tensions. Singapore companies, such as banks and real estate firms, are expected to perform well in 2024, driven by lower interest rates and improved consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: At the COP28 climate summit last week, around 110 countries pledged to treble renewable energy capacity by 2030.
The signs are pointing to an easing of interest rate hikes this year, which could help lift investor sentiment.

site_title: Digital twins can future-proof South-east Asia’s urban development
summary: Digital twins are being touted as a solution to future-proof South-east Asia's urban development, addressing infrastructure gaps and sustainability concerns. The technology, which involves creating a virtual representation of a city or building, can help urban planners identify and solve current and potential problems. By leveraging digital twins, cities can optimize energy consumption, reduce waste, and create more resilient infrastructure. The Asian Development Bank has warned that climate change must be factored into infrastructure design, and digital twins can help achieve this. Governments and industry experts are embracing digital twins as a key innovation in urban planning and construction, with potential to create liveable cities for the future.

site_title: Asia: Stocks open year’s last trading day cautiously
summary: Asian stocks opened cautiously on the last trading day of the year, with Hong Kong and Tokyo marginally higher. The rally is expected to continue as investors anticipate a US Federal Reserve rate cut as early as March, boosting expectations for a strong economic recovery. Despite this, Chinese markets remain weighed by concerns over the country's sluggish economic recovery, while tech sector news provided a positive boost. Asian stocks are on track for their best year since the pandemic, but continue to underperform global peers.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1 per cent to close at 37,710.10 on Thursday, notching a second straight all-time closing high. The blue-chip index is up almost 14 per cent so far for all of 2023.

site_title: DBS gains regulatory approval to up stake in Shenzhen Rural Bank
summary: DBS Group has obtained regulatory approval to increase its stake in Shenzhen Rural Commercial Bank Corporation (SRCB) to 16.69% from 13%. DBS will acquire Shenzhen Huaqiang Asset Management's 383.6 million shares for 5.25 yuan (S$0.98) per share, totaling 2 billion yuan. The transaction is expected to be earnings accretive immediately and has less than a 0.1 percentage point impact on consolidated capital ratios.

images.alt_text: DBS has been keen to expand in Greater China.

site_title: Easier ways to achieve personal finance aims in New Year’s resolutions
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

New Year's resolutions can be difficult to keep up with due to the challenge of forming new habits. However, personal finance goals can be relatively easy to follow through with by automating certain tasks. Creating a separate bank account for expenses and setting up standing instructions can help curb impulse spending. Automating investment plans through regular savings or recurring investments can also help achieve financial goals. Additionally, reviewing financial plans regularly and canceling unused credit cards can also contribute to successful personal finance resolutions. By implementing these strategies, individuals can make progress towards their financial objectives.

site_title: M&A activity expected to pick up in 2024; digital infrastructure, renewables to fuel growth
summary: Market watchers expect a pick-up in merger and acquisition (M&A) activity in 2024, driven by a more stable interest rate environment and potential policy loosening. Digital infrastructure and renewables are expected to drive M&A deal flow, with telecommunications tower companies and data centers being attractive to investors. The Singapore market is poised to feature prominently in the global recovery, with a build-up of physical and capital relocation by global companies and investors. M&A activity may lag for businesses in industrial and manufacturing sectors, which will need to transform themselves into more technology-focused businesses.

images.alt_text: The value of M&A and related transactions is down roughly a quarter this year to US$2.7 trillion going into the holiday period.

site_title: Global shares hit 4-year high, volatile Treasuries flat over 2023
summary: Global shares reached a 4-year high, ending 2023 on a positive note, with the S&P 500 up nearly 25% this year. Volatile US Treasuries are expected to finish the year flat, despite a sharp decline in yields and expectations of central bank rate cuts. Markets are pricing in an 88% chance of the US Federal Reserve starting rate cuts in March, with over 150 basis points of easing expected next year. Chinese markets underperformed, with the Hang Seng Index and China's onshore blue chip index losing over 10% in 2023.

site_title: Geely-owned Chinese luxury EV brand Zeekr rides into Singapore next year
summary: Chinese luxury electric vehicle brand Zeekr, owned by Geely, will enter Singapore's market in 2024 with retail sales starting in the first half of the year. The first deliveries are slated for June or July 2024, with four models initially available: the Zeekr 009, a fully electric large multi-purpose vehicle, and the Zeekr X, a small sport utility vehicle. Zeekr aims to be priced competitively with German luxury brands like BMW and Mercedes-Benz, and its Geely affiliation is expected to provide confidence in the brand's long-term viability.

images.alt_text: Zeekr, which publicly files a prospectus this month to float shares in New York, has aimed to maintain the valuation of US$13 billion.

site_title:
Hong Kong shares plunge to losses 
for 4th straight year
summary: Hong Kong's stock market has plunged for the fourth consecutive year, with the Hang Seng Index finishing 14% lower than its start in 2023. The decline is attributed to economic woes in China, mounting pressure on American investors to sell Chinese stocks, and geopolitical tensions. The city's financial chief, Paul Chan, has blamed "misunderstandings caused by Western political prejudices" for the poor performance, but analysts point to China's weak economy and property crisis as major factors. The losses contrast with the US market's 25% gain in 2023, highlighting the divergent paths of the world's two largest economies.

site_title: Grealish family not harmed in home burglary, says Guardiola
summary: Manchester City midfielder Jack Grealish's home in Cheshire was burgled while his family was present, with thieves making off with £1.27 million worth of jewelry and watches. Fortunately, no family members were harmed. Coach Pep Guardiola expressed relief that "nothing wrong happened where the family was inside." Grealish is expected to be available for Manchester City's next game against Sheffield United despite the incident.

images.alt_text: After clinching the treble of the club’s first ever Champions League, Premier League and FA Cup last season, City also lifted the UEFA Super Cup for the first time in August.

site_title: Gold’s rise expected to gain further momentum
summary: Gold's value is expected to rise in 2024 due to strong consumer spending patterns and moderate rate cuts. Despite a reduced risk of a US recession, the economy may still face uncertainty, potentially leading to a mild recession and a subsequent series of modest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. This could trigger increased investment in precious metals, fueling gold's momentum.

images.alt_text: US gold futures fell 0.2 per cent to US$2,078.70 per ounce.

site_title: South Korea December consumer inflation up weaker-than-expected 3.2%
summary: South Korea's December consumer inflation eased to 3.2% from 3.3% in November, beating market expectations. This marks the second consecutive month of easing inflation, supporting the Bank of Korea's view that price pressure will gradually ease to near its 2% target by the end of 2024. The easing inflation rate is seen as a positive sign for policymakers to pivot to monetary policy easing in the third quarter of next year.

site_title: Huawei expects revenue to rise almost 9% in 2023
summary: Huawei expects to reach a revenue of over 700 billion yuan (S$131.1 billion) in 2023, a 9% increase from last year, despite US sanctions. Rotating chairman Ken Hu attributes the growth to the company's ability to "weather the storm" after years of challenges. This marks a significant recovery from 2020, when revenue declined due to US sanctions. Huawei's diversification efforts, including the use of domestically produced chips, have helped the company navigate the tech stand-off between China and the US.
