summary: India's government has targeted high-profile journalists with Pegasus spyware, according to a joint investigation by Amnesty International and The Washington Post. The Israeli-made software can access phone messages, emails, and track locations. Journalists Siddharth Varadarajan and Anand Mangnale were recently targeted, and Indian media reported that the country's cyber security unit was investigating allegations of phone tapping. This marks the latest case of Pegasus being used to spy on journalists worldwide, raising concerns about unlawful surveillance in India.

site_title: Credit Suisse fined S$3.9 million for misconduct by relationship managers
summary: Credit Suisse has paid a S$3.9 million civil penalty to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for its relationship managers' misconduct, including providing clients with inaccurate post-trade disclosures and charging spreads above agreed rates. The Swiss bank has strengthened its internal controls to prevent recurrence. The misconduct, deemed an offence under the Securities and Futures Act, resulted in clients being charged for 39 over-the-counter bond transactions. MAS Deputy Managing Director Ho Hern Shin emphasized the need for robust governance frameworks and processes to ensure fair and transparent pricing for customers.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse’s push to build a wealth management business in China started to fall apart after it delayed the launch of its locally incorporated bank last year.
UBS says its board of directors had given the green light for the respective parent banks, UBS AG and Credit Suisse AG, to fuse.

In a suit filed on Monday (Dec 4) to the Tokyo District Court, two plaintiffs are demanding around 42.7 million yen in compensation from SBI Securities, alleging it sold the Credit Suisse notes while offering incorrect explanations about them.

site_title: Demand for latest Singapore Savings Bond falls after average returns slide to 3.07%
summary: Demand for Singapore's latest Savings Bond (SSB) fell after the average returns slid to 3.07% for a 10-year period. The SSB's first-year interest rate was 3%. The allotment results showed $867.5 million in applications, exceeding the $853 million allotted. This decline in demand follows a decrease in interest rates, making the bond less attractive to investors.

images.alt_text: The latest tranche of SSBs is offering a first-year interest rate of 3.3 per cent, and a 10-year average return of 3.4 per cent.
The December issuance received a total of S$1.9 billion in applications, exceeding the S$1 billion on offer.

site_title: Gold climbs to three-week high as US rate cut bets firm
summary: Gold prices surged to a three-week high on Thursday, reaching $2,086.66 per ounce, as the US dollar and bond yields hit multi-month lows due to mounting bets of a US interest rate cut as early as March next year. The metal is poised for its best year in three with a 14% gain, boosted by safe-haven inflows and US rate cut expectations. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut bets have firmed, with traders now pricing in an 88% chance of monetary policy easing in March.

site_title: 2024 is shaping up to be a better year to invest in S-Reits
summary: S-Reits, Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts, are showing signs of improvement in 2024 due to a decline in global interest rates. The i-Edge S-Reit index has rebounded from multi-year lows, and the sector is trading at a discount to its historic valuations. Despite this, investors should be cautious as interest rates remain high compared to historic levels, which will still impact distributions per unit and property valuations. Selecting S-Reits with low gearing levels and active hedging strategies can help navigate the sector's recovery.

images.alt_text: John Stewart, CEO of Digital Core Reit's manager, expects the Reit's prospects to be brighter next year after resolving matters relating to a customer bankruptcy.
Active capital management has been a priority for Reit managers this year, amid heightened investor attention on gearing levels, with higher interest rates putting pressure on valuations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, ComfortDelGro, Samudera Shipping, Koda
summary: Seatrium secured a S$400 million refinancing deal with DBS, featuring a three-year committed loan facility with a sustainability-linked conversion option. ComfortDelGro's commissions for cabbies will increase to 7% from 5% starting January 1, 2024. These developments may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: BOJ’s Ueda prepares ground for rate hike with salvo of comments
summary: BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda has signaled the possibility of a rate hike in the spring, with a January increase also considered, amid plans to fuel inflation and reinvigorate growth. Ueda's comments, made in an interview, suggest the central bank may move sooner than expected, citing early annual pay deal figures and expanding economy data. Economists now expect a rate hike by April, with the chances of a January move less than 10%. The BOJ aims to end its negative interest rate experiment, which has been in place since 2016.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, Oct. 31, 2023. The Bank of Japan further loosened its grip on government bond yields while continuing to stick with its negative interest rate in a decision that prompted a retreat in the yen. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

A man walks past an electronic board displaying Japan's 10-year government bonds level, the current Japanese Yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average, outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, October 31, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

A man walks past an electronic board displaying Japan's 10-year government bonds level, the current Japanese Yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average, outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, October 31, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Apple wins watch ban delay in US patent feud
summary: A US federal court suspended a ban on Apple's latest smartwatch models due to patent disputes with health company Masimo. The ban, which was set to take effect on Tuesday, was delayed pending the appeals process. Apple had paused US sales of the affected models, but the court's decision reverses the ban. Apple claims the patent infringement ruling was in error and is appealing the decision.

images.alt_text: The US ITC's order to bar imports and sales of Apple Watches that use patent-infringing technology for reading blood-oxygen levels will take effect on Tuesday.
The negotiations mark one of the earliest examples of how Apple is trying to catch up to rivals in the race to develop generative AI.
Sales will continue at Apple’s international online and in-person stores.

An Apple store in New York, US, on Friday, June 30, 2023. The blowout rally in tech megacaps gained further traction on Friday, with the Nasdaq 100 poised to notch a record first-half of a year and Apple Inc. hitting the $3 trillion milestone. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg via Getty Images
The Vision Pro marks Apple’s first new product category since it began selling smartwatches in 2015.

Apple has known for almost two months that a ban on its smartwatch sales imposed by ITC would take effect Dec 25 unless it persuades the Biden administration to intervene – or works out a settlement with Masimo.

site_title: Singapore shares open Thursday with strong gains; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks opened Thursday with strong gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 20.82 points or 0.7% at 3,191.58. Gainers outnumbered losers 87 to 28, with local banks trading higher. Shares of Seatrium, ThaiBev, DBS, UOB, and OCBC advanced. The global rally continued, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.1%. The pan-European Stoxx 600 also edged up 0.2%.

images.alt_text: Seatrium bags S$400 million in refinancing with sustainability-linked option.

site_title: Goldman, Morgan Stanley expect China’s housing slump to worsen
summary: China's housing slump is expected to worsen in 2024, with 10 investment banks predicting a "double-digit" contraction in real estate fixed-asset investment, according to Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and UBS. This would mark three consecutive years of contractions in property construction, with the sector's role in driving demand for goods and services shrinking to 20% of GDP. The prolonged slump will reduce real GDP growth by one percentage point, with some economists forecasting further government stimulus to stabilize the market.

images.alt_text: The average daily sales of new home units in the city rose nearly 41 per cent, while that of Beijing jumped 122 per cent.
Middle class households are being forced to rethink their money priorities, with some pulling away from investing, or selling assets to free up liquidity.
Revenue from land sales falls 1.5 per cent in November from a year earlier, compared with a 25.4 per cent slump the prior month.

site_title: Inside the record year for India’s US$585 billion mutual funds industry
summary: India's mutual funds industry saw a record surge in assets under management, with a 19% boost in the first 11 months of 2023. Equity funds led the growth, driven by an increase in retail investing. The industry's assets are expected to continue growing, with industry veterans predicting a bigger share of households' financial assets in the years to come. The industry's share of assets was 45% for bank deposits, compared to under 9% in March. The US$585 billion industry is set for a blockbuster year, with BlackRock planning a return.

images.alt_text: Created by Israeli firm NSO Group, Pegasus software can be used to access a phone’s messages and emails, peruse photos, eavesdrop on calls, track locations and even film the owner with the camera.
The Reserve Bank of India said its move is designed to prevent an unstable build up of assets in the country’s financial system.
Global warming has triggered more intense clashes of weather systems in India in recent years, increasing extreme weather events have killed nearly 3,000 people this year.

site_title: Oil drops almost 2% as investors watch Red Sea developments
summary: Oil prices dropped nearly 2% on Wednesday as investors monitored developments in the Red Sea, where shippers are returning despite further attacks. Brent crude futures settled at $79.65 a barrel, down $1.42, and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $74.11, down $1.46. Despite a temporary halt to shipping routes, Danish shipping company Maersk and French company CMA CGM are resuming passage through the Red Sea. The prospect of a prolonged Israeli military campaign in Gaza remains a major market driver.

images.alt_text: AP Moller-Maersk, the world’s second-largest container line, said it was preparing to resume shipping through the Red Sea.
Brent crude futures settled US$2, or 2.5 per cent, higher at US$81.07 a barrel, after rising as much as 3.4 per cent during the session.

site_title: Shipping giant CMA-CGM joins Maersk in Red Sea return
summary: French shipping giant CMA-CGM has resumed transit through the Red Sea, days after Maersk announced its return as part of a US-led naval coalition policing the maritime route against Huthi rebel attacks. The attacks prompted shipping companies to reroute vessels around Africa, but the US-led task force aims to counter the threats. The Red Sea route, carrying 12% of global trade, has seen over 100 drone and missile attacks targeting 10 merchant vessels from more than 35 countries. CMA-CGM's return indicates increased confidence in the safety of the route.

images.alt_text: Maersk says the schedule remains subject to change based on specific contingency plans that may be formed over the coming days.

The world’s top shipping companies, including Maersk and Hapag-Lloyd, stopped using Red Sea routes after Yemen’s Houthi militant group began targeting vessels this month, disrupting global trade through the Suez Canal.

site_title: Asia: Stocks open higher on Fed rate hopes
summary: Asian stocks opened higher on Thursday, with Hong Kong leading gains as investors await the US Federal Reserve's expected rate cut next year. Tokyo edged down due to a strengthening yen, while other Asian markets, including Shanghai, Seoul, and Sydney, rose. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached an all-time high on Wednesday, driven by US inflation slowing, but consumer spending still below healthy levels. Oil markets remain concerned over regional conflicts.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open Thursday with strong gains; STI up 0.7%
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 37,656.52 on Wednesday, topping a record set last week.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to raise taxi commissions for booked rides to 7%
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean transport operator, will increase taxi commissions to 7% from 5% on January 1, 2024, for booked rides. This hike aims to help drivers defray higher operating costs, citing increased technology system maintenance and cashless transaction fees. The company will also waive commissions on fares below S$9 until March 31 and make its existing 10% rental waiver permanent. This move goes against rival ride-hailing companies, which have cut or forgoed commissions.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro intends to fund its accquisition of A2B Australia through existing cash and bank facilities.
Taxi trips are getting more expensive.
ComfortDelGro taxis seen travelling along Sims Avenue on Feb 20, 2023.

site_title: Stable outlook for HDB resale market with 3-5% price growth forecast for 2024
summary: Singapore's HDB resale market is expected to experience moderate price growth of 3-5% in 2024, with a total of 26,500 resale transactions forecasted for the year. This growth is slower than the 10.4% increase in 2022 and 12.7% in 2021. Despite increased competition from new Build-To-Order (BTO) flats, demand for HDB resale flats is expected to remain above the 10-year average due to positive job prospects and income growth.

images.alt_text: The projects in the December 2023 BTO exercise are in Bedok, Bishan, Bukit Merah, Bukit Panjang, Jurong West, Queenstown and Woodlands.
Industry watchers largely expect demand in the HDB resale market to remain muted for December 2023 due to the holiday season.
Larger flat prices such as five-room flats saw 50 per cent gain from 2015 to 2023, says Mogul.sg's chief research officer, Nicholas Mak.

The cap relaxation will apply to four-room and larger HDB flats, living quarters of HDB commercial properties where the living space is at least equivalent to a four-room flat, as well as private residential properties of at least 90 square metres.

site_title: Russia says redirected most oil exports to China, India
summary: Russia has redirected most of its oil exports from Europe to China and India, with China now accounting for 45-50% of Russia's oil exports and India for 40%. The move comes after Western sanctions, including a European Union embargo on Russian oil, were imposed in response to Russia's actions in Ukraine. Russia is also finding new markets for its natural gas exports and expects to earn nearly $130 billion in oil and gas revenues this year, similar to pre-2021 levels.

images.alt_text: A view shows tankers in Nakhodka Bay near the crude oil terminal Kozmino outside the port city of Nakhodka, Russia June 13, 2022. REUTERS/Tatiana Meel
Novatek, a controlling shareholder in the Arctic LNG-2 project, has declared force majeure due to the US sanctions, sources say.

site_title: Japan’s November factory output falls 0.9% m-o-m
summary: Japan's factory output declined 0.9% in November from the previous month, according to the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry. The decline was driven by a 2.5% drop in motor vehicle production, which has underpinned industrial output. Manufacturers surveyed expect seasonally adjusted output to increase 6.0% in December and decline 7.2% in January, clouding the outlook for the export-reliant economy.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, Oct. 31, 2023. The Bank of Japan further loosened its grip on government bond yields while continuing to stick with its negative interest rate in a decision that prompted a retreat in the yen. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

A man walks past an electronic board displaying Japan's 10-year government bonds level, the current Japanese Yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average, outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, October 31, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
Toyota's output for November climbed to 926,573 vehicles, while worldwide sales increased 14 per cent from a year earlier when automakers globally were bedevilled by shortages of semiconductors.
At the Dec 18-19 meeting, the Bank of Japan maintained ultra-loose policy settings and made no change to its dovish guidance that pledges to take additional monetary easing steps as needed.

site_title: GM blasts San Francisco in lawsuit over US$108 million tax bill
summary: General Motors (GM) has filed a lawsuit against San Francisco, claiming the city unfairly taxed it $108 million over seven years. GM argues that its self-driving unit, Cruise, is separate from the company and should not be tied to its global revenue, which generated over $3 billion in taxes last year. The company seeks to recover $13 million in interest and penalties. San Francisco's city attorney's office is reviewing the complaint.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Cruise self-driving car, which is owned by General Motors, is seen outside the company’s headquarters in San Francisco, California, U.S., September 26, 2018. REUTERS/Heather Somerville//File Photo
The layoffs are primarily in commercial operations and related corporate functions and come after Cruise fired nine executives on Wednesday, including its chief operating officer.

General Motors' Cruise pulled all its vehicles from testing in the United States to conduct a safety review after an Oct 2 incident in which a woman was struck and dragged by a Cruise vehicle in San Francisco.
Last month, Cruise paused all driverless and supervised car trips in the United States and expanded a safety review of its robotaxis.
GM has struggled to boost its stock price as it dealt this year with the UAW strike, problems at its Cruise self-driving vehicle unit and with the rollout of its new electric vehicles.

site_title: Bitcoin miner Marathon leads crypto stock surge
summary: Bitcoin miner Marathon Digital Holdings' shares have surged significantly, outperforming Bitcoin by over 800% this year, while other crypto stocks like Riot Platforms and Coinbase Global have also seen substantial gains, with MicroStrategy jumping over 350%. The surge is attributed to expectations of increased demand for Bitcoin if the US Securities and Exchange Commission approves a spot Bitcoin ETF, and analysts predict a short squeeze if the rally continues.

images.alt_text: Since bitcoin’s inception in 2009, traditional finance (TradFi) has struggled to understand what it is, what it will be, and whether it is a viable investment asset.

An unwelcome pest is how many financiers and regulators would describe the crypto industry. Criminals use cryptocurrencies to launder money. Terrorists use them to make payments. Hackers demand ransoms in bitcoin.

site_title: Suez Canal reroutes have mixed impact on Singapore SMEs so far
summary: The Suez Canal rerouting due to Red Sea attacks is causing shipping delays and higher costs for imports from Europe to Singapore. Industry estimates vary, with some expecting a 4-5 day delay via the Cape of Good Hope, while others anticipate a two-week delay. Some importers, such as wine distributors Asia Wine Network and Le Vigne Wines & Spirits, have already experienced delays, with costs and cash flow pressures expected to worsen if issues persist. The disruptions highlight the need for supply chain resilience in the face of global uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The international crew of the vehicle carrier Galaxy Leader are being held in Yemen by Houthi rebels.
Brent crude futures settled US$2, or 2.5 per cent, higher at US$81.07 a barrel, after rising as much as 3.4 per cent during the session.

epa11040943 A ship crosses the Suez Canal towards the Red Sea in Ismailia, Egypt, 22 December 2023. On 18 December, the US Department of Defense announced a multinational operation to safeguard trade and to protect ships in the Red Sea, amid the recent escalation in Houthi attacks originating from Yemen, according to a press release from the U.S. Department of Defense. These attacks in recent weeks had prompted major shipping companies to reroute their operations and raised concerns of prolonged disruptions to global trade.  EPA-EFE/MOHAMED HOSSAM

site_title: Europe: Shares kick off last week of 2023 higher
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by optimism around US interest rate cuts as early as March, while shipping companies fell on news of resumption of travel via the Suez Canal. The Stoxx 600 has gained nearly 13% so far this year, with retail and technology sectors performing well. Shipping firms like Maersk and Hapag Lloyd fell due to increased travel through the Suez Canal.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 37,656.52 on Wednesday, topping a record set last week.

site_title: It was a tough year for almost every bank not named JPMorgan
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has dominated the US banking industry in 2023, with its stock soaring 26% and its earnings expected to reach a record $36 billion. The bank's acquisition of First Republic Bank, despite concerns from regulators, has further solidified its position. In contrast, most other major banks have struggled, with dozens of regional lenders collapsing or downsizing due to rising interest rates and unrealized losses. Analysts attribute JPMorgan's success to its size, scale, and ability to absorb failures, with some comparing Jamie Dimon to John D Rockefeller as the best bank executive in the world.

images.alt_text: Ayaz Ebrahim joined JPMAM in 2015 and has over three decades of experience in investments, having held leadership roles in Amundi, HSBC and Deutsche Bank.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the exterior of the JP Morgan Chase & Co. corporate headquarters in New York City May 20, 2015. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo
The bank will continue to provide global custody services in those two markets.
While there have been some departures, a majority of First Republic employees who moved to JPMorgan in July have stayed put.

site_title: Expectations mixed on Singapore’s monetary moves in 2024, even as core inflation is set to cool
summary: Singapore is expected to enter a phase of disinflation in 2024, with core inflation forecast to cool to 3% from 4.1% in 2023. Economists are divided on the central bank's monetary policy, with some expecting a tightening and others a loosening. Sticky inflation factors, such as the one-percentage-point goods and services tax hike and government policy changes, are expected to raise costs and inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is likely to maintain its current monetary settings, with some economists expecting a tightening in the first half of 2024 and a loosening in the second half.

images.alt_text: Economists raise their inflation forecasts for 2024 to 3.4 per cent for headline inflation, up from their previous projection of 3.1 per cent, and 3 per cent for core inflation, up from 2.8 per cent.
Consumer spending may grow more slowly in 2024 as post-Covid exuberance dies out.
Office workers crossing Cecil Street near Bangkok Bank Building in the CBD area, 21 June 2023. population, workers, labour, workforce, manpower, financial district

site_title: Former EU Commission president Jacques Delors dies at 98
summary: Jacques Delors, the former EU Commission president from 1985 to 1995, has died at 98 in his Paris home. Delors, a key figure in the creation of the euro currency, played a significant role in the European bloc's integration during his decade-long tenure. He declined to run for president in 1995, citing a desire for independence, and went on to found think tanks promoting European federalism. Tributes from European leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and European Central Bank chief Christine Lagarde, have praised Delors as a statesman who shaped Europe's integration and will be deeply missed.

images.alt_text:
FILE PHOTO: People walk over London Bridge looking at a view of Tower Bridge in the City of London financial district in London, Britain, October 25, 2023.
REUTERS/ Susannah Ireland/File Photo
Meta has repeatedly stated that it strongly disagrees with the idea that providing access to online platforms to users should be subject to sales tax

epa10858056 European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen during the debate on the ‘state of the European Union’ at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, 13 September 2023. The session runs from 11 till 14 September.  EPA-EFE/JULIEN WARNAND
“The General Court dismisses the action brought by Mr Abramovich, thereby upholding the restrictive measures taken against him,” The EU court says in its ruling.

site_title: Seatrium bags S$400 million in refinancing with sustainability-linked option
summary: Seatrium, a Singapore-based energy and marine solutions group, has secured a S$400 million refinancing deal with DBS, with a three-year committed loan facility including a sustainability-linked conversion option. The deal aims to support Seatrium's environmental, social, and governance goals, including achieving 40% of its net order book from renewables and cleaner solutions by 2026. The refinancing brings Seatrium's total sustainable financing to over S$2 billion, with the group targeting a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030.

images.alt_text: Photo of Southeast Asias first floating and stacked Energy Storage System with maximum storage capacity of 75 megawatt hour MWh to power over 600 fourroom HDB house

site_title: Thailand heads for better year, with or without mega-digital wallet
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow at a slightly faster pace in 2024, with a predicted 3.2% rise in gross domestic product (GDP) driven by increasing tourist arrivals, export growth, and sustained private consumption. However, the implementation of a controversial "digital wallet" scheme, which would provide 10,000 baht to 50 million citizens, poses a risk to fiscal stability and could lead to a 4-5% fiscal deficit. The World Bank predicts the scheme could boost near-term growth by 0.5-1 percentage point but warns of a heavy price, including a 66% public debt-to-GDP ratio.

images.alt_text: An employee counts Thai one-thousand baht banknotes at a bank in Bangkok, Thailand.Photographer: Luke Duggleby/Bloomberg
Thai market sentiment to stay tepid despite encouraging export data: Maybank
Thailand is aiming to convert about a third of its annual production of 2.5 million vehicles into EVs by 2030.
January-to-November exports declined 1.5 per cent from the same period last year.

site_title: Singapore’s F&B groups delay, scrap new outlet openings amid tough conditions
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) sector is experiencing a slowdown, with many operators delaying or scrapping plans for new outlets due to weak sales. Industry players attribute the decline to a combination of factors, including a rise in outbound travel, slower wage growth, and higher business costs. Sales have fallen 14.2% year-on-year for 55 local restaurants and cafes, and some operators expect a 20-30% decline in sales for 2023. Expansion plans have been pushed back to 2025 at the earliest, with some operators scrapping plans altogether.

images.alt_text: Surge in outbound travel, slowing wage growth hurting small retailers’ festive sales
Bittersweet festive season for Singapore’s artisanal chocolatiers
Consumer spending may grow more slowly in 2024 as post-Covid exuberance dies out.
Though more Singapore residents have been heading abroad, restaurants and hotels foresee demand ramping up towards year-end.

site_title: PropertyBT: Chasing restriction-lite HDB resale flats in popular locations (Ep 26)
summary: Resale buyers in Singapore are increasingly seeking "restriction-lite" HDB flats in popular locations, driven by the desire for flexibility in resale. Experts say these flats offer more freedom in resale, compared to Plus and Prime flats, which have stricter restrictions. While top dollar is paid for existing HDB resale homes in choice locations, analysts argue that tighter restrictions may not be excessively burdensome, as they balance the need for resale flexibility with the government's aim to promote home ownership.

images.alt_text: Should Reits be part of investment portfolios of retirees and the young?
Potential buyers of highly sought-after HDB resale flats should be mindful of the risks of paying top dollar for such flats.
Arguably, HDB BTO 5-room flats should be bought mainly by larger households and not two-person households.

site_title: US: Stocks extend rally, lifting Dow to fresh record
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, lifting the Dow to a fresh record, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 0.3% higher at 37,656.52. Major indices have seen significant increases in 2023, driven by a late-year rally as inflation moderates, prompting expectations for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in 2024. Despite concerns over the labor market, some commentators remain bullish, predicting a strong labor market and early Fed interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during morning trading on December 14, 2023, in New York City. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: BOJ to reduce bond-buying amounts in Jan-March quarter
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) announced plans to reduce bond-buying amounts in the January-March quarter, aiming to give more liquidity to the market. The central bank lowered the minimum amounts for bonds between 1 and 10 year maturities and cut the frequency for longer-dated notes. This move follows recent cuts in bond-buying operations as yields fell to multi-month lows, and the BOJ aims to defend its ultra-low rate policy. The BOJ plans to buy between 400 billion yen and 900 billion yen for 5-year and 10-year JGBs.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board displaying Japan's 10-year government bonds level, the current Japanese Yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average, outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, October 31, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
The Topix index and the Nikkei 225 Stock Average have touched 33-year highs and risen more than 20 per cent so far for 2023, beating most equity benchmarks in the rest of Asia.

site_title: Who wants to be a modern CEO?
summary: Modern CEOs face an overwhelming array of challenges, including geopolitical uncertainty, mounting regulation, inflation, and advances in artificial intelligence. With constant scrutiny of their pay and conduct, they must balance the need for authenticity and vulnerability with the pressure to make "right" decisions. As a result, CEO tenure has declined sharply, and boards are often ill-equipped to counsel on navigating these challenges. To succeed, companies should adopt a more distributed leadership structure, spread risk, and prioritize effective risk management and scenario planning.

images.alt_text: Citigroup CEO Jane Fraser is trying to repair the bank’s poor returns by excising layers of management and dismantling regional fiefdoms.  She has been clear that it would be a long and costly job, involving discomfort for investors and employees.
Work is war -- or it can feel that way to certain executives. To meet the moment, they're getting in a cockpit. (Taylor Callery/The New York Times
More than 1,400 chief executives have left their positions so far this year through September, according to a report by executive coaching firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas, Inc.

site_title: Wall St opens muted due to lack of catalysts at year-end
summary: Wall Street opened muted on December 27, with the Dow Jones falling 26.71 points, or 0.07%, to 37,518.62, due to a lack of catalysts to sustain optimism over potential early rate cuts. The S&P 500 opened lower by 1.30 points, or 0.03%, at 4,773.45, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 15.09 points, or 0.10%, to 15,089.66. The absence of strong cues to support market optimism led to a muted start to the year-end trading session.

site_title: Alibaba must face lawsuit in US over counterfeit Squishmallows
summary: A US judge has rejected Alibaba's bid to dismiss a lawsuit alleging the company knowingly sold counterfeit Squishmallows on its online platforms. Kelly Toys, the owner of Squishmallows, plausibly alleged Alibaba contributed to the infringement of its copyrights and trademarks. Despite six lawsuits, Alibaba ignored its own policies and awarded infringing merchants "Gold Supplier" and "Verified" status. The judge found Kelly Toys' allegations plausible, allowing the lawsuit to proceed against Alibaba.

images.alt_text: CEO Eddie Wu appoints six managers to report directly to him from various segments of the core business.
Once the most valuable company in China, Alibaba has fallen behind games and social media leader Tencent Holdings.
Numerous examples of Chinese retailers offering lower-priced alternatives have appeared in response to consumer’s cost-cutting.

site_title: Jane Fraser’s empathy doesn’t mean Citi is soft
summary: Citigroup CEO Jane Fraser is implementing a major restructuring to repair the bank's poor returns, involving significant job cuts and changes to the bureaucracy. The plan, which Fraser has described as a long and costly job, aims to slim down the bank's management and eliminate regional fiefdoms. Despite initial criticism, shareholders have welcomed the hard-nosed decisions, which are expected to take years to bear fruit. Fraser's approach has shifted from a human-centered approach to a more disciplined one, with a focus on cost-cutting and revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Citigroup also has seen a number of senior exits from that business.
Executives hope offering staffers a portion of their annual bonus will coax more of them to leave voluntarily rather than having to rely solely on layoffs for the restructuring.
FILE PHOTO: The logo for Citibank is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Citigroup is widely seen to be among the most amenable financial firms when it comes to flexible work arrangements following the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK residential property market could do better than expected next year: analysts
summary: The UK's residential property market is expected to perform better than anticipated in 2024, with house and apartment prices predicted to decline by 4.7% and 4% respectively. Despite rising mortgage rates, actual prices fell less than expected, with the UK's average residential prices decreasing by 1.2% to £288,000. Analysts attribute this resilience to rising rents, with tenants seeking to break contracts and buy properties. Skilled employees in tech and other sectors are also expected to drive demand, leading to predictions that interest rates may fall to 4% by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: UK households have been under pressure this year from mortgage rates that reached 14-year highs and stubbornly high inflation.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde salutes 'influential' Schaeuble
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde paid tribute to former German finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, calling him "one of the most influential European leaders of his generation." Lagarde praised Schaeuble's commitment to Europe, intellectual rigour, and statesmanship. Schaeuble, who served as finance minister from 2009 to 2017, played a key role in the eurozone debt crisis, advocating for fiscal discipline and balanced budgets. His policies had a significant impact on countries like Greece, which implemented austerity measures and economic reforms to address its debt crisis.

images.alt_text: Wolfgang Schaeuble at the German lower house of Parliament in Oct 24, 2017. He previously pulled the strings of Germany’s policy response to the eurozone crisis, securing support on the right of their conservative bloc for three Greek bailouts.

site_title: China threatens more trade sanctions on Taiwan as election nears
summary: China has threatened to impose further trade sanctions on Taiwan if the ruling party, the Democratic Progressive Party, continues to support independence. This comes as Taiwan prepares for its January 13 presidential and parliamentary elections. China views Taiwan as its own territory and has been trying to force the island to accept Chinese sovereignty claims. The Chinese government has accused Taiwan of violating a trade agreement and has warned that Taiwan's adherence to independence is the "root cause" of the issue, stating that it could lead to war.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese and Taiwanese printed flags are seen in this illustration taken, April 28, 2022. Picture taken April 28, 2022.  REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

epa10560585 Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen delivers a speech during a press conference with U.S. House speaker Kevin McCarthy following a bilateral meeting at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California, USA, 05 April 2023. This meeting takes place amid rising tension between the United States and China, as well as between China and Taiwan.  EPA-EFE/ETIENNE LAURENT

site_title: Swiss climate activists target the rich with new tax proposal
summary: Switzerland's Young Socialists have collected enough signatures for a national vote on a 50% tax on inheritances exceeding $59 million to cover climate change costs, generating around $9.3 billion annually. The proposed tax aims to hold wealthy individuals accountable for climate change costs. However, right-wing lawmaker Thomas Aeschi warns that the tax could scare off rich citizens, citing Norway's experience with wealth taxes. The initiative, which has gathered over 130,000 signatures, will trigger a plebiscite after government and parliament discuss the issue.

images.alt_text: Switzerland is determined to preserve its beautiful natural landscape, epitomised by the majestic Matterhorn mountain.

site_title: US labour market seen cooling in 2024, regional Fed surveys show
summary: US employers expect to hire less in 2024, according to regional Federal Reserve bank surveys, indicating a trend that may limit wage gains and cool inflation pressures. The surveys show labour supply coming into better balance with demand, despite businesses citing a lack of experienced and skilled workers as a trouble spot. Economists forecast an average 80,000 monthly increase in payrolls in the first three months of 2024, about half the pace seen this quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Real estate signs advertise new homes for sale in multiple new developments in York County, South Carolina, U.S., February 29, 2020. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo
Purchases of new single-family homes decrease 12.2 per cent to a 590,000 annual pace last month, a one-year low.

Shoppers along the Magnificent Mile shopping district in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 15, 2023. US retail sales rose in July by more than forecast, suggesting consumers still have the wherewithal to sustain the economic expansion. Photographer: Jamie Kelter Davis/Bloomberg

site_title: Maersk schedules dozens of vessels to travel via Suez Canal
summary: Maersk has scheduled dozens of container vessels to travel via the Suez Canal and the Red Sea in the coming weeks, a move signaling a return to the route after global shipping firms suspended it due to Houthi attacks. The schedule is subject to change based on contingency plans. France's CMA CGM has also increased its vessels traveling through the Suez Canal. German rival Hapag-Lloyd remains cautious, rerouting ships via the Cape of Good Hope.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Containers are seen on the Maersk's Triple-E giant container ship Majestic Maersk, one of the world's largest container ships, as it sails in the Strait of Gibraltar towards the port of Algeciras, Spain January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo
The attacks in the Red Sea are a reminder of the importance of supply chain resilience, say industry watchers.

The world’s top shipping companies, including Maersk and Hapag-Lloyd, stopped using Red Sea routes after Yemen’s Houthi militant group began targeting vessels this month, disrupting global trade through the Suez Canal.

site_title: MicroStrategy’s Bitcoin holdings top US$8 billion with latest purchase
summary: MicroStrategy, a Virginia-based enterprise software maker, has increased its Bitcoin holdings to over $8 billion after acquiring 14,620 Bitcoins for $616 million. The company's total holding now stands at 189,150 Bitcoins, representing about 1% of the total outstanding supply. MicroStrategy's chairman and co-founder Michael Saylor began buying Bitcoin in 2020 as an inflation hedge, and the company's shares have surged over 300% this year, outperforming Bitcoin.

site_title: No major red flags at Koda after funds misappropriation
summary: Koda Ltd, a furniture maker, has completed a phase one review following the misappropriation of funds by a former employee in November 2023. An external consultant found no major red flags after corrective actions were taken, but identified low-risk issues, including the need for a policy on authorized account creations and standardized push notifications within the payment gateway system. Koda has agreed to implement these recommendations, which will be reviewed regularly.

site_title: Collaborative contracting the way forward as BCA seeks to build alliances, streamline processes
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has launched a new digital platform, CoreNet X, to streamline the regulatory approval process for construction projects and enhance collaboration within the built environment industry. The platform aims to reduce the time taken for projects to obtain approval from government agencies by around 20%. Prior to this, separate submissions to different agencies led to potential conflicts between project parties and agencies. The platform's launch is expected to strengthen coordination and reduce bureaucracy in the industry.

images.alt_text: Singapore buildings to have to meet higher standards to be certified green

site_title: Prices of rice surged to a fresh 15-year high
summary: Rice prices surged to a 15-year high, reaching US$659 a ton, driven by strong demand and supply concerns. This marks a 38% increase in prices this year, fueled by India's export restrictions and dry weather threatening production. The price increase could fan inflationary pressures and hike import bills for buyers. Some nations, including Thailand and Indonesia, are building stockpiles amid fears of El Niño's impact on supplies, while others, like the Philippines, are importing rice to meet demand.

site_title: Cytokinetics has record gain as heart drug succeeds in trial
summary: Cytokinetics' experimental heart drug, aficamten, improved exercise capacity and oxygen uptake in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a genetic heart condition, in a closely watched trial. The company reported a record gain of 83% in its shares, with a potential peak sales value of $3 billion by 2035. Cytokinetics plans to submit the drug for clearance in the second half of 2024 and compete with Bristol Myers Squibb's Camzyos, a treatment for obstructive HCM.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Professor Jacob Hanna, a specialist in molecular genetics at Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science, demonstrates his roller culture incubator used to grow synthetic mouse embryos in a lab in the Israeli central city of Rehovot on August 4, 2022. They are not human embryos, but come very close. Artificially created for research purposes, 'embryoids' represent a dazzling scientific revolution, which is now prompting certain health authorities to draw up initial rules. (Photo by AHMAD GHARABLI / AFP)

site_title: The New York Times sues OpenAI, Microsoft over copyright infringement
summary: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft in a US court over copyright infringement, alleging that the companies' AI models used millions of its articles without permission for training. The newspaper is seeking damages and an order to stop using its content and destroy data already harvested. Microsoft, a major investor in OpenAI, implemented the AI powers to its own products after ChatGPT's release. The lawsuit claims that the use of the newspaper's work threatens its ability to provide quality journalism.

site_title: Eiffel Tower closes as staff go on strike
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris was closed on its 100th anniversary of engineer Gustave Eiffel's death due to a strike by staff, protesting the tower's management. The strike, led by the hard-left CGT union, was described by the tower's operator as "headed for disaster." The tower attracts nearly seven million visitors annually, mostly foreigners. Visitors with electronic tickets were advised to check their email for updates.

site_title: US dollar touches five-month low on rate cut hopes in thin market
summary: The US dollar fell to a five-month low on Wednesday, reaching 101.36, amid anticipation of Federal Reserve rate cuts in 2024. Thin year-end trading volumes limited the move. The euro rose to a four-month high, while the Japanese yen weakened 0.1% to 142.55. Markets are pricing in an 85% chance of a rate cut starting in March 2024, driven by cooling inflation and expectations of a "soft landing" for the economy.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board displaying Japan's 10-year government bonds level, the current Japanese Yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average, outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, October 31, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

A man walks past an electronic board displaying Japan's 10-year government bonds level, the current Japanese Yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average, outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, October 31, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Wolfgang Schaeuble, veteran of German politics, dies at 81
summary: Wolfgang Schaeuble, a veteran German politician, has died at 81, ending one of Germany's longest careers. He spent over half a century in politics, serving as a member of parliament since 1972 and as finance minister during the eurozone debt crisis. Schaeuble played a key role in securing support for three Greek bailouts and helped re-unify Germany. Tributes poured in from Chancellor Olaf Scholz, CDU leader Friedrich Merz, and French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire, praising Schaeuble as a sharp thinker, passionate politician, and tireless craftsman of the Germany-France friendship.

images.alt_text:
FILE PHOTO: People walk over London Bridge looking at a view of Tower Bridge in the City of London financial district in London, Britain, October 25, 2023.
REUTERS/ Susannah Ireland/File Photo

site_title: Tesla deliveries to hit record, but fall short of Musk's aspirations
summary: Tesla is expected to deliver a record 1.82 million vehicles globally in 2023, a 37% increase from 2022, with 473,000 units delivered in the fourth quarter. Despite this, deliveries are expected to fall short of CEO Elon Musk's ambitious 2 million annual target. The company's focus on China, where it has lost market share to local competitors, and a price war in the EV market have contributed to slowing sales. Tesla's stock has more than doubled this year, with the company poised to report quarterly deliveries and production early in 2024.

images.alt_text: In China, deliveries of the Model Y accounted for almost 75 per cent of Tesla’s overall sales in the country.
Tesla’s energy generation business is a fast growing revenue stream.

site_title: Indonesian protesters storm shelter, calling for deportation of Rohingya refugees
summary: A large crowd of Indonesian students stormed a convention centre in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, on Wednesday, demanding the deportation of hundreds of Rohingya refugees from Myanmar. The protesters, many wearing green jackets, broke a police cordon and forced the refugees into trucks, leaving them shaken and traumatized. The UNHCR condemned the attack, citing a coordinated online campaign of misinformation and hate speech. The incident is the latest in a series of increasing hostility and rejection faced by Rohingya refugees in Indonesia, who are fleeing persecution in Myanmar.

images.alt_text: Rohingya refugees queue with their belongings at a beach in the Sabang island of Aceh province, Indonesia on Nov 22, 2023, as they are relocated by Indonesian authorities.

site_title: Singapore’s built environment sector on track to hit green targets: BCA chief
summary: Singapore's built environment sector is on track to meet its green targets, with 71% improvement in energy efficiency compared to 2005 levels. The country aims to green 80% of all buildings by 2030 and have 80% of new developments be Super Low Energy (SLE) buildings by the same year. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has set aside S$45 million for a research development program to achieve these targets, and has seen positive results from innovative technologies and retrofitting schemes. Despite challenges, the sector is expected to continue growing, with a focus on adopting technology and attracting young talent.

images.alt_text: BCA expects 60 per cent of construction demand to come from the public sector.

site_title: Swiss finance minister says new rules needed after Credit Suisse crisis
summary: Swiss Finance Minister Karin Keller-Sutter says new banking regulations are needed after the Credit Suisse crisis to protect taxpayers in future banking crises. The government's guarantee of billions of francs in liquidity was put at risk if Credit Suisse had been liquidated. Keller-Sutter believes the government must act to prevent a major bank's collapse from dragging the entire country into economic chaos. She emphasized that the new proposals will address "unpleasant issues" in the spring, aiming to ensure the Swiss economy's stability.

site_title: Shipper Hapag-Lloyd says Red Sea route still too dangerous
summary: Hapag-Lloyd, a major shipping company, will continue to reroute its vessels away from the Red Sea due to ongoing militant attacks, despite a US-led taskforce to protect the key route. The attacks, which have targeted ships handling 12% of global trade, have caused delays and extra costs for shipowners, potentially impacting consumers. The company will maintain its detour via the Cape of Good Hope, adding several thousand miles to its routes, and follows other shipping companies, such as AP Moller-Maersk, which has also chosen to avoid the Red Sea.

site_title: Samudera Shipping acquires 2 ethylene gas vessels for US$12.6 million
summary: Samudera Shipping has acquired two ethylene gas vessels for US$12.6 million. The vessels, Bahamas-flagged and built in 2009 and 2010, will be renamed Sinar Ternate and Sinar Tidore. The acquisition aims to expand Samudera's fleet, sign more charter contracts, and capitalize on Indonesia's growing ethylene market. The vessels will be financed via bank borrowings and internal resources, with shares remaining unchanged at S$0.65.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of Bukom island on Feb 9, 2023. Can use for stories on oil refinery plant, pollution, shell, burn, carbon emissions, gas, environment, climate change, transportation, ship, trains, planes, carbon polluter, carbon footprint, atmosphere.

site_title: Crypto hedge funds gear up for ‘token mania’ after 2023 rebound
summary: Crypto hedge funds are experiencing a rebound after a 2022 decline, with some funds doubling or tripling their value. Pantera Capital's liquid-token fund rose 80% this year, while Chainview Capital doubled after a 18% decline last year. The industry is optimistic about 2024, driven by stabilizing inflation, the Federal Reserve's pivot away from rate hikes, and Bitcoin's halving, which will reduce supply. Fund managers are hiring staff and expecting a "token mania" similar to 2023, with some predicting a 30% return for their funds.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has surged more than 150 per cent this year on optimism that the US Securities and Exchange Commission will soon give their first blessing for an exchange-traded fund that invests directly in the digital asset.

site_title: Adani Energy to spend US$360 million to build Gujarat power transmission line
summary: Adani Energy plans to invest US$360 million in building a 765-kilovolt transmission line in Gujarat, India, to connect a solar and wind energy park with the power grid. The 301 km long transmission line, expected to be commissioned in 24 months, will operate and maintain it for over 35 years. This acquisition is part of India's goal to increase non-fossil fuel power capacity to 500 GW by 2030 and aims to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 2070.

site_title: China metals giant faces protest in Indonesia after fatal blast
summary: China's Tsingshan Holding Group, the world's largest nickel producer, is facing protests in Indonesia after a fatal explosion at its plant on December 24, killing at least 19 people. The workers have demanded better working conditions and compensation for the victims' families. The company's operations have been halted pending a police investigation. The protests, led by about 100 workers, have since dispersed, but the incident highlights concerns over workplace safety and labor rights in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: The strike on the 100th anniversary of the death of engineer Gustave Eiffel, who built the tower, was to protest “the current way it is managed”, the hard-left CGT union said in a statement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 27)
summary: Rental prices for private condominiums in Singapore dropped 1.4% in November, according to flash data from SRX and 99.co. The market is expected to remain soft for the rest of the year before potentially picking up in Q1 2024. The Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme will continue to release sufficient land to meet the demand for industrial space. Meanwhile, a Malaysian proptech startup, LiveIn, raised US$8.3 million to expand its operations in Thailand, Vietnam, and Indonesia.

site_title: Get that champagne feeling on a sparkling wine budget
summary: The price of champagne has increased, making it more expensive than ever. Fortunately, great sparkling wines are now made in various regions, offering alternatives at different price levels. The article highlights 12 exceptional sparkling wines, including Sekt from Germany, cava from Spain, and sparkling Vouvray from France, that can be just as distinctive as champagne. These wines use local grapes, such as riesling and xarello, and are made using the same method as champagne, with a second fermentation producing carbon dioxide. The article suggests that these alternatives can be just as enjoyable and elegant as champagne, without the high price tag.

images.alt_text: A sparkling wine. The price of Champagne has risen, but good alternatives are made all over the wine-producing world Ñ they might taste different but they are superb. Styling by Jenna Tedesco. (Adam Friedlander/The New York Times)

site_title: China to expand domestic demand, ensure speedy recovery
summary: China will focus on expanding domestic demand, stabilizing bulk consumption, and promoting service consumption to ensure a speedy economic recovery and stable growth. The country aims to accelerate reforms, deepen market-oriented reforms, and institutional opening up to boost development. Additionally, China will prioritize high-tech development to overcome technology export blockades and prevent risks in key areas such as real estate, local government debt, and financial institutions. The government will also accelerate breakthroughs in core technologies to achieve scientific and technological self-reliance.

images.alt_text: External demand for Chinese goods has also been weak, with a gauge of export prices hitting the lowest since 2009 in October.

site_title: Japan lifts operational ban on world's biggest nuclear plant
summary: Japan's nuclear power regulator has lifted an operational ban on Tokyo Electric Power Company's (Tepco) Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant, allowing it to work towards gaining local permission to restart. The plant, the world's largest, has been offline since 2012 due to safety breaches and a corrective action order. Tepco aims to bring the plant online to reduce reliance on imported fossil fuels and is seeking consent from local governments. The restart is contingent on improving safety management and regaining community trust.

images.alt_text: The announcement was made at the UN’s COP28 climate summit in Dubai.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend rally on Fed-fuelled rate optimism; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 3,170.76 points, driven by optimism over the Federal Reserve's potential easing of monetary policies. The Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index also gained 1.1% and 1.7%, respectively. Top gainers included Nio, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, while 17Live was the biggest loser. The rally was attributed to moderation in inflation, creating a pathway for central banks to ease off restrictive policies, and higher real rates becoming economically unfavourable.

images.alt_text: Markets in Japan, Australia and Hong Kong all rose, with bourses in the latter two reopening after the Christmas trading break.

site_title: A ski chalet with views of the Matterhorn lists for US$26 million
summary: A luxury ski chalet in the Italian Alps, Chalet La Fenice, is on sale for $26.4 million, making it the most expensive listing in the region. The 13,000-square-foot property features seven bedrooms, a spa with indoor pool, and breathtaking views of the Matterhorn. Owner John Harrison spent "substantial" amounts on renovations, including a controlled explosion to create space, and has used the chalet as both a family home and an exclusive rental property. With a price tag of $94,958 per night, Harrison hopes to attract a high-end buyer looking for a luxurious ski retreat.

images.alt_text: GTC's decision to expand beyond office buildings in places such as Warsaw, Budapest and Belgrade into high-end chalets in the Swiss mountains and mansions dotted along the Greek coast is arguably the most drastic change.

site_title: BOJ's Ueda not in rush to unwind ultra-easy policy: NHK
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda stated he is not in a rush to unwind ultra-easy monetary policy, citing a small risk of inflation exceeding 2% and accelerating. The BOJ's policy-setting meeting is scheduled for January 22-23, and Ueda believes that the bank could gain valuable information from regional branch managers' meeting in mid-January. However, he emphasized the need to keep ultra-loose policy for now, with wages and price outlook to be scrutinized in deciding policy, and a possible interest rate hike in 2024 still uncertain.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, Oct. 31, 2023. The Bank of Japan further loosened its grip on government bond yields while continuing to stick with its negative interest rate in a decision that prompted a retreat in the yen. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: Thailand set to further increase spending in 2025 fiscal year
summary: Thailand plans to increase spending by 3.6 trillion baht in the 2025 fiscal year, resulting in a budget deficit of 713 billion baht. The government projects a 3.6% GDP growth and inflation of 1.5-2.5% in 2025. A public-debt-to-GDP ratio of 63.73% is expected at the end of the year. The budget increase is aimed at supporting economic expansion and stability, despite a slight decrease in the 2024 forecast.

images.alt_text: An employee counts Thai one-thousand baht banknotes at a bank in Bangkok, Thailand.Photographer: Luke Duggleby/Bloomberg
Thai market sentiment to stay tepid despite encouraging export data: Maybank

site_title: Hunt to announce UK budget on March 6 as Tories push for giveaways
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt will announce the country's next budget on March 6, amid pressure from Conservative MPs to deliver further tax cuts. The move aims to boost the party's appeal among voters, trailing the opposition Labour Party in national polls. Hunt's surprise two percentage-point reduction in National Insurance payroll tax in the Autumn Statement last month has fueled speculation about an early election. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak must call a national vote by the end of January 2025, with a spring election likely to occur in May.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt leaves 11 Downing Street on his way to present his Autumn Statement in the House of Commons, in London, Britain, November 22, 2023. REUTERS/Hannah McKay

site_title: Dubai’s red-hot property market is bracing for a slowdown
summary: Dubai's property market is bracing for a slowdown, with many homeowners, including Egyptians Dina Habib and Karim Yusuf, selling their properties to buy a larger one at a lower price. The market has outperformed others globally this year, driven by wealthy investors and liberal visa policies. Despite sharp increases in rents and home prices, some analysts expect prices to moderate, with CBRE's Taimur Khan predicting 5-10% growth next year and a decline of 5-10% in the following 12-18 months. Developers are also adapting, with S&P expecting 40,000 properties to be delivered in 2024.

images.alt_text: The Dubai Investment Fund will house assets worth billions of dollars and invest government money locally and internationally.
The unrelenting appetite for Middle East listings comes even as regional geopolitical tensions are high and as investors fret about high interest rates, volatility and economic growth.

site_title: Year in review: Major headline-grabbing events of 2023
summary: The year 2023 was marked by significant global events, including a record-breaking year for financial markets and a nail-biting year for politics. Notable events included a banking crisis, with Vietnam surprising by Trump's tariff announcement, and a slowdown in China's GDP growth. Other key events included a mid-2026 target for Citigroup's MSCI global equity index, a Thai court's potential clearance of Thaksin's daughter from an ethics case, and the UK economy's shrinkage for the second consecutive month. These events underscored the complexities and challenges facing global markets and politics.

images.alt_text: Looking back at 2022.
Interest rate expectations appear to have fallen since the dovish statements made by US Fed Chair Jerome Powell on Dec 13.
Coming out of 2019's slowdown, companies here have been looking to the upcoming Budget for support - a hope that has intensified as the Covid-19 outbreak threatens to hammer the Singapore economy.

Sri Lankan protesters in 2022, calling for the president to resign over the economic crisis. Sri Lanka has faced long delays in receiving debt relief, because their Chinese creditors refuse to agree to the debt-restructuring terms agreed in the Paris Club.

site_title: Why the world needs its own immune system
summary: The world is facing a pattern of recurring public health crises, such as Ebola, Covid-19, and others, which require a rapid and coordinated response. A global immune system, similar to the human immune system, is needed to detect and neutralize health threats before they cause catastrophic damage. Building such a system requires a sustained commitment to investing in local preparedness, laboratory safety, and public health capacity. The US government, along with the World Health Organization and other partners, has made progress in this area, including launching a partnership with West and Central African countries to build greater readiness for outbreaks. However, much work remains to be done to create a global immune system that can effectively respond to emerging health threats.

images.alt_text: There's an urgent need for greater capacity to create treatments and vaccines in places where they’re often in short supply and last in line for distribution.

A handout photo made available by the World Health Organisation (WHO) on 16 July 2010 shows medical teams prepare to vacinate locals against the Ebola virus outbreak in Mbandaka area, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 10 July 2010.
Experts reckon the toll of endemic Covid might be somewhere from 100,000 to 250,000 deaths every year, just in the United States.

site_title: Outlook for the F&B industry
summary: Singapore's F&B industry faced challenges in 2023, with rising costs, fewer locals dining at home due to travel, and lower-than-expected inbound tourist numbers. Restaurateurs had to tighten their wallets, while food trends and new restaurants, such as Harummanis at Sultan Gate, showcased modern Malay heritage cooking. The industry looks to 2024 with uncertainty, but also opportunities for growth and innovation, as the sector adapts to changing consumer behavior and preferences.

site_title: Iron ore rises on upbeat Chinese industrial data, demand hopes
summary: Iron ore prices rose 0.5% to 985.5 yuan (S$182.3) per metric ton on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange, heading for a second consecutive year of gains. The increase follows robust industrial data and expectations of economic stimulus in China. Industrial profits in November posted double-digit gains, and the government has identified public investment projects to boost the economy. Analysts expect a surge in demand for iron ore in the coming weeks as Chinese steelmakers replenish raw materials for the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday break.

images.alt_text: May iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange is on track to record its best week in five.
The November imports stayed at an elevated level for the fourth consecutive month, above 100 million tonnes for the fifth time so far this year.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,147.31, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street. The market saw 82 gainers for every 27 losers, with Thai Beverage Public Company being the most active counter. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and OCBC rising, while UOB fell. This follows a strong rally in the US, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4% and the S&P 500 adding 0.4%.

images.alt_text: The president of Seatrium's Brazilian unit Martin Cheah is acquitted of all charges related to anti-corruption probe Operation Car Wash. Seatrium was formerly known as Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: GLP Capital Partners sets up 3 billion yuan China income fund
summary: GLP Capital Partners has closed its 3 billion yuan China Income Fund XI, marking the latest onshore income strategy by the alternative asset manager. This brings the total domestic capital raised by GCP in 2023 to over 16 billion yuan. The fund, seeded with four logistics parks from GLP's balance sheet, aims to support long-term real estate investment goals for domestic institutions and insurance companies.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Industrial GLS for H1 2024 launched with 5 confirmed sites, 4 on reserve
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) is launching 13.75 hectares of industrial land across nine sites through the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme for H1 2024. Five sites, totaling 8.29 hectares, are confirmed, while four sites, amounting to 5.46 hectares, are on the reserve list. JTC Corporation will be the sales agent for all sites. Conditions of sale and tender submissions are expected to be available in January 2024.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of National Development announced the ...
Reflection and skyline of Central Business District viewed from the Esplanade on May 25, 2022.
The Marina Gardens Lane site is etched in red in this aerial view of Marina South.

site_title: Uber to deploy Teslas to join Japan’s taxi market: Nikkei
summary: Uber is set to partner with Tesla to enter Japan's taxi market, capitalizing on the government's decision to introduce ridesharing services in parts of the country. Uber plans to initially roll out 30 Tesla Model Ys, increasing to 100 electric cars in 2024. Pricing will be 20% higher than local taxis. This move aligns with Uber's goal to invest $800 million in electric vehicles and become fully electric globally by 2040.

site_title: JGB yields fall as BOJ's summary offers no clue for policy shift
summary: Japanese government bond (JGB) yields fell on December 27 as investors failed to see signs of a shift in the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy from a summary of opinions at its recent meeting. The 10-year JGB yield fell 2.5 basis points to 0.605%, while the 20-year yield fell 2 basis points to 1.350%. Investors remained cautious, suffering a disappointment when they found no clear indication of a policy shift, prompting them to buy bonds.

images.alt_text: Benchmark 10-year JGBs and 20-year bonds would be cut, while liquidity enhancement bills would be increased.

site_title: North-west China cities halt heavy industries to curb pollution
summary: Two cities in northwestern China, Xian and Yinchuan, have halted heavy industries to curb severe pollution. Authorities have issued red alerts for serious pollution until Friday, enforcing measures such as public transportation and flexible work arrangements. Residents are advised to stay indoors and avoid idling vehicles. The pollution is forecast to dissipate with a cold wave arriving Saturday afternoon. China's Central Meteorological Observatory has predicted dense haze for the north and east from Thursday to Saturday.

images.alt_text: China's carbon emissions in the second quarter jumps 10 per cent on last year’s coronavirus-induced lull.

site_title: Parasite actor Lee Sun-kyun found dead
summary: South Korean actor Lee Sun-kyun, known for his Oscar-winning role in Parasite, was found dead inside a vehicle in Seoul's Seongbuk district. He was 48 and under police investigation for alleged use of marijuana and other psychoactive drugs. A note found at the scene suggested he had left a will, and his reputation had suffered after being dropped from projects following the scandal. Lee, a graduate of Korea National University of Arts, was recognized for his performances in various TV dramas and films, including Parasite and My Mister.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on December 23, 2023 shows South Korean actor Lee Sun-kyun arriving at a police station in Incheon for his police questioning over his alleged use of marijuana and other psychoactive drugs. The Busan International Film Festival (BIFF) will run until Oct 13 and feature 209 official entries from 69 countries.
Longtime talent manager Andrew Ooi with actress Celina Jade on the red carpet.

site_title: Tough lessons from China’s fizzled recovery
summary: China's economy failed to recover as expected in 2023, with a modest 5% growth rate and disappointing retail sales, property sector, and consumer prices. The country's former "juggernaut" status has given way to a more modest, yet still significant, role in global commerce. The government's response to Covid-19, including strict containment measures, has eroded the economy's growth potential, with a "systemic" slowdown attributed to the pandemic's impact. With little appetite to dramatically change course in 2024, the world may have to adjust its expectations of China's economic performance.

images.alt_text: Visitors at Yuyuan Garden in Shanghai, China, on Saturday, Dec. 23, 2023. An abrupt surge in foreign buying of Chinese bonds has raised hopes that pessimism about the nation’s assets may be overdone. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippines attracts four bids for main airport’s 170.6 billion pesos upgrade
summary: The Philippines has attracted four bids for the 170.6 billion pesos upgrade of its main international airport, Ninoy Aquino International Airport, which handles 35 million passengers annually. The 15-year concession, extendable by another 10 years, aims to serve 60 million passengers. The upgrade will address chronic flight delays and passenger congestion. The transportation ministry is expected to award the concession in the first quarter of 2024. The project will improve the travel experience for passengers and is part of the country's efforts to attract 7.7 million foreign tourists in 2024.

images.alt_text: The tariff rate for rice will remain at 35 per cent, while import levies on corn will stay at 5 to 15 per cent and 15 to 25 per cent for pork products
The inflation target range remains an appropriate representation of the medium-term goal for price stability, the central bank says.

site_title: Toyota’s global output surges to record in November on strong demand
summary: Toyota's global output surged to a record 926,573 vehicles in November, up 11% from last year, driven by strong demand in Japan and overseas. Worldwide sales increased 14% from the previous year, with domestic sales rising 27% and sales in the US and China increasing by 17% and 15%, respectively. The surge in production and sales comes despite global semiconductor shortages that affected the industry last year. Toyota's strong performance is attributed to robust demand for its vehicles.

site_title: SoftBank surges 7% after getting US$8 billion of T-Mobile stock
summary: SoftBank rose 7% after securing $7.6 billion worth of T-Mobile US stock, part of a deal struck when T-Mobile merged with Sprint in 2020. The investment firm will receive 48.8 million shares for no additional cost. This infusion of stock is expected to improve SoftBank's balance sheet and provide a new pool of capital. The deal follows SoftBank's efforts to raise capital and invest in anticipation of better market conditions in 2024, led by CEO Masayoshi Son's focus on artificial intelligence and autonomous driving.

site_title: Indonesian workers protest after deadly blast at nickel plant
summary: Hundreds of Indonesian workers protested outside a Chinese-funded nickel-processing plant in Central Sulawesi, Indonesia, after an explosion killed at least 18 people and injured dozens more. The workers, who were repairing a furnace, demanded better working conditions, improved health clinics, and required Chinese workers to learn Indonesian. The plant's owner, PT Indonesia Tsingshan Stainless Steel, has given the family of one of the victims compensation, but workers claim it is not enough. The protest highlights concerns over workplace safety and labor conditions in Indonesia's growing nickel industry.

images.alt_text: Sulawesi is a hub for Indonesia’s production of nickel, and Beijing’s growing investment has stoked unrest over working conditions at its facilities.

site_title: Gold holds steady amid muted activity on US Fed rate cut bets
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Wednesday, holding at $2,066.86 per ounce, amid muted trading and expectations of US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in 2024. A weaker US dollar makes gold more attractive for other currency holders, contributing to the metal's 10% gain this year. The FedWatch tool shows an 80% chance of a rate cut by March, which decreases the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, further supporting gold prices.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index fell 0.1 per cent, making gold more attractive for other currency holders, while benchmark US 10-year bond yields edged lower to 3.9 per cent.

site_title: Kanye West apologises for anti-Semitism
summary: US rapper Kanye West has apologized to the Jewish community for anti-Semitic comments, which sparked outrage and led to him being dropped from commercial deals and banned from social media. West, 46, expressed regret for any pain caused and committed to greater sensitivity in the future. His apology comes amid rising concerns over normalization of anti-Semitic discourse in the US, following high-profile outbursts and collaborations with conspiracy theorists and Holocaust deniers.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on February 10, 2020 Kanye West attends the 2020 Vanity Fair Oscar Party following the 92nd annual Oscars at The Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills. - Paris-based fashion house Balenciaga has ended ties with rapper Kanye West following a recent run of controversial statements, including an outburst denounced as anti-Semitic, according to fashion news site WWD.
