site_title: Xi Jinping touts alternative to Western capitalism in speech on Mao Zedong
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has used a speech commemorating Mao Zedong to promote his concept of "Chinese modernisation," an alternative to Western capitalism. Xi described the idea as a "solemn historical responsibility" of the Communist Party, touting its benefits of achieving "common prosperity" and developing peacefully. The move aims to solidify Xi's legacy and create a connection to Mao, despite glossing over the latter's role in China's tumultuous past. Xi has consolidated power to unprecedented levels, sparking concerns about checks and balances.

images.alt_text: Eight of the 10 biggest losers on the MSCI Asia-Pacific gauge this year are from the Chinese consumer or renewables sectors, the other two being Chinese property firms.
Chinese President Xi Jinping’s two-day trip to Vietnam comes just months after his US counterpart Joe Biden’s first jaunt to the South-east Asian nation.
Vietnam is estimated to hold the world’s second-largest deposits of strategic minerals which are at the moment crucial for electric vehicles and wind turbines.

site_title: Malaysian proptech startup LiveIn raises US$8.3 million for regional expansion
summary: Malaysian proptech startup LiveIn has raised US$8.3 million in funding to expand its operations in Thailand and two new markets, Vietnam and Indonesia. The funds will be used to grow its portfolio of properties and hire more staff in these countries. LiveIn's valuation has reached US$26.4 million, according to data platform Alternatives.pe. The company plans to capitalize on the growing demand for affordable long-stay rentals, citing a surge in demand from young people seeking autonomy and quality living spaces.

images.alt_text: IQI and Juwai IQI group CEO Kashif Ansari said the average expectation among property agents in Malaysia indicates a bullish outlook on property values and rental income.

site_title: New World teams with Chinese state firm for Hong Kong property project
summary: New World Development, a Hong Kong-based property developer, has partnered with China Resources Land, a Chinese state-owned firm, to build a residential project in the Northern Metropolis zone. The project will provide approximately 1,800 homes and is part of the city's plan to create four major zones, including high-end professional services and logistics, innovation and technology, commerce and industry, and conservation and tourism. The partnership aims to unlock agricultural land value and reduce New World's investment burden, as the company seeks to trim debt amid declining shares.

images.alt_text: Aoyuan joins a small but growing list Chinese developers – as well as other non-US debtors – to tap Chapter 15 bankruptcy system to more efficiently deal with offshore creditors or handle cross-border assets.
The company’s disclosure further casts doubt on Chinese authorities’ recent vows to support distressed developers and curb an unprecedented wave of defaults.
The move means that three of Henry Cheng’s children now lead a major listed arm of the family’s US$26 billion business.

site_title: Private leasing market slides further in November, HDB rents rebound: SRX, 99.co
summary: The private condominium rental market in Singapore declined for the fourth consecutive month in November, with prices dropping 1.4% from the previous month. In contrast, HDB rental prices rebounded, increasing 0.8% from October. Industry experts expect private rentals to remain soft until Q1 2024, while HDB rents are forecast to increase 9-10% for the full year. This divergence in trends is attributed to increased supply and waning demand in the private market, and the HDB market's affordability and occupancy cap.

images.alt_text: Flash data shows overall resale prices have risen for the fourth straight month.
Industry watchers largely expect demand in the HDB resale market to remain muted for December 2023 due to the holiday season.
For the first time since October 2021, HDB rental prices for October are down from a month prior.

site_title: Major carriers adopt different approaches to sailing through the Red Sea
summary: Major shipping carriers are adopting different approaches to navigating the Red Sea due to ongoing attacks by Yemeni Houthi rebels. CMA CGM plans to gradually increase the number of vessels transiting the Suez Canal, while Mediterranean Shipping Company (MSC) will reroute vessels via the Cape of Good Hope until the Red Sea is deemed safe. Hapag-Lloyd has also decided not to transit the Red Sea, citing the ongoing danger. The attacks have prompted concerns over safety and the potential impact on global trade and supply chains.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$2, or 2.5 per cent, higher at US$81.07 a barrel, after rising as much as 3.4 per cent during the session.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track US gains in ‘Santa Claus rally’
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, tracking US gains in the "Santa Claus rally", with Japan, Australia, and Hong Kong bourses rising after the Christmas trading break. Investors are betting on a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut as early as March, which has driven market activity since last year. The "Santa Claus rally" has historically seen stocks tick higher during the end-of-year holiday period, with the S&P averaging a 1.3% gain since 1969. Market sentiment remains positive, with interest rates and the US dollar index expected to continue to influence investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore bourse, gainers outnumber losers 82 to 27.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.4 per cent to 37,545.33 on Tuesday.

site_title: Some in BOJ called for debate on future exit from easy policy: December meeting summary
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy settings at its Dec 18-19 meeting, with no change to its dovish guidance. Some policymakers called for a deeper debate on a future exit from massive stimulus, citing the need to examine the effects of yield curve control and negative interest rate policy. The timing of normalizing the BOJ's policy is considered "getting closer" due to the increasing likelihood of achieving the 2% inflation target in a sustainable manner. The BOJ will continue to take additional monetary easing steps as needed.

site_title: Tencent, NetEase bounce back after Beijing softens gaming stance
summary: Beijing has signaled a willingness to soften proposed gaming restrictions, reassuring investors. Tencent Holdings and NetEase jumped 3.9% and 14% respectively in their first trading session after the government's move. Investors hope regulators will roll back at least some of the more divisive rules, taking industry feedback over the next month. Tencent remains down about 9% from before the regulations surfaced, while investors recouped just a fraction of Friday's $80 billion rout. The move has revived hopes that Beijing may not target the online content sphere again.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Tencent Games logo is seen on its game on a mobile phone in this illustration picture taken Aug. 3, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China’s BYD set to overtake Tesla as world’s most popular EV maker
summary: China's BYD is poised to surpass Tesla as the world's leading electric vehicle (EV) maker, with analysts predicting BYD will launch its third-generation EVs next year offering advanced technology such as automated-driving capabilities. BYD's growth is attributed to its competitive pricing, government subsidies, and innovative approach to the industry. The company's billionaire founder Wang Chuanfu has successfully navigated the EV market, leveraging China's massive EV production capabilities to challenge Tesla's dominance. BYD's market capitalization is expected to close the gap with Tesla's, with analysts projecting BYD to reach $112 billion in sales by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: BYD already has a bus facility in the country, but is investing in the plant as it seeks to dominate the European EV industry by the end of the decade.

The EU’s probe kicked off in earnest in October with investigations of BYD, SAIC and Geely, bringing the bloc more in line with the US in looking to protect an industry that employs millions of workers.
BYD remains the dominant auto brand in China, having overtaken Volkswagen for the top sales spot this year.

site_title: Hong Kong’s November home prices drop for the 7th month
summary: Hong Kong's home prices dropped 2% in November, marking the 7th consecutive month of decline, with a revised 2.1% fall in October. This follows a 5.6% decrease in the first 11 months of the year. The decline is attributed to weak buying sentiment and a higher interest rate environment.

site_title: Looking ahead: risks aplenty, but there may be opportunity too
summary: Business leaders face risks from ongoing global conflicts in Europe and the Middle East, with the Russian invasion of Ukraine nearing its two-year anniversary. Additionally, the US presidential election, although not directly stated, may impact markets due to former President Trump's influence. However, despite these risks, the article suggests that the prospects for ASEAN countries, such as Indonesia, appear containable, offering potential opportunities for business growth.

site_title: China names foreign exchange veteran as PBOC deputy governor
summary: China's State Council appointed Lu Lei, a 53-year-old foreign exchange veteran, as deputy governor of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), replacing Liu Guoqiang since 2018. Lu's appointment follows an illustrious career spanning the central bank, academia, and a commercial bank. This marks the third new senior official at the PBOC since July and the second this month. Lu's appointment aims to maintain stability at the central bank amidst economic challenges and US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China has cut its key policy rate twice this year but has stood pat since August, relying more on pump priming in money markets to spur economic growth.

For years, Chinese companies have been basing their foreign exchange accounting on the PBOC daily yuan fixing, rather than the prevailing market rate, as recommended by the country’s Ministry of Finance.
The central bank has already geared up support for the economy via massive liquidity infusions, offering lenders a net 800 billion yuan of one-year policy loans in an operation in mid-December.

site_title: Anthropic sees over US$850 million in annualised revenue by 2024-end: report
summary: Anthropic, a generative AI startup backed by Amazon and Alphabet's Google, is projecting $850 million in annualized revenue by the end of 2024, surpassing its previous estimate of $500 million. The company's Claude AI models have gained prominence, rivaling OpenAI's GPT series. Some sources suggest Anthropic could reach $1 billion in annualized revenue next year, or $83 million per month, and is in talks to raise $750 million in a funding round led by Menlo Ventures.

images.alt_text: The music publishers allege Anthropic “profits richly” from its infringement of their repertoires of copyrighted works, achieving a valuation of US$5 billion while paying “nothing” to publishers or their songwriters.

Founded in 2021 by former employees of OpenAI, Anthropic has positioned itself as being especially focused on responsible and safe technology.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit 5-month highs as markets bet on early US easing
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached fresh five-month highs as investors bet on early US rate cuts, boosting risk appetite and commodities. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.6829, while the kiwi dollar reached US$0.6334. The US Federal Reserve's benign inflation report implies an 80% chance of rate cuts starting in March, with 152 basis points of easing expected for 2024. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut rates in June, and the New Zealand Reserve Bank may follow in May, driven by falling interest rates and commodity prices.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index is languishing near a five-month low of 101.42 hit last week, and was last at 101.59.

site_title: China sanctions US firm, two researchers over Xinjiang work
summary: China has sanctioned a US firm, Kharon, and two researchers, Edmund Xu and Nicole Morgret, over work related to Xinjiang, escalating a dispute over allegations of forced labor. The sanctions, announced by China's Foreign Ministry, freeze any assets held by Kharon and bar the individuals from entering China. The move comes after the US sanctioned Chinese officials over human rights abuses in Xinjiang, with China calling the US allegations "false narratives." The sanctions are largely symbolic, as Kharon and the researchers have limited business or property in China.

images.alt_text: Tensions between the world’s two biggest economies have soared in recent years as both sides clashed on issues ranging from human rights to export controls.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, 3Cnergy
summary: Seatrium's former president of its Brazilian unit, Martin Cheah, was acquitted of all charges related to the anti-corruption probe Operation Car Wash. Shares of Seatrium closed up 0.9% following the news. Meanwhile, 3Cnergy's shareholders approved a reverse takeover of hospitality player DTP Infinities, with 3Cnergy to be renamed Prosper Cap.

site_title: India’s crackdown on financial risks puts industry on watch
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has imposed new rules to prevent an unstable build-up of assets in the country's financial system, effectively barring lenders from investing in alternative investment funds (AIFs) that hold stakes in their borrowers. The move has led to a significant impact on the market, with the top seven shadow lenders having invested around $1.35 billion in AIFs. The rules require existing investments to be liquidated in 30 days or provisioned, which may lead to costs and difficulties for fund managers and lenders.

site_title: China’s industrial profits rise though deflation concerns linger
summary: China's industrial profits rose 29.5% in November from a year earlier, driven by government support measures and favourable year-ago comparisons. However, the country's economic growth remains sluggish, with external demand weak and deflation concerns lingering. Consumer prices dropped the steepest in three years, and factory-gate costs accelerated. China's top leaders have indicated they will maintain a pro-growth policy stance, with state-owned banks slashing deposit rates to encourage lending. Despite this, the country's economic growth goal for 2024 is ambitious and faces pressure from deflationary pressures.

site_title: Tesla plans revamp of smash hit Model Y from China plant
summary: Tesla is revamping its best-selling Model Y from its Shanghai plant, with preparations underway for a refreshed version expected to start mass production as early as mid-2024. The updated model will feature significant exterior and interior changes, surpassing the recent October update. The production will be conducted at the second phase of Tesla's Shanghai facility, with a partial upgrade during the New Year holiday. This move comes as Tesla faces intense competition from domestic rivals, including BYD, which is poised to surpass Tesla as the new worldwide leader in fully electric car sales.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s energy generation business is a fast growing revenue stream.
The US electric vehicle manufacturer’s gigafactory in Shanghai is producing at an annual capacity of 1.1 million units.
The long-delayed Cybertruck starts at a price of US$60,990, over 50 per cent more than what CEO Elon Musk had touted in 2019, with a smaller range than originally promised.

site_title: US again extends tariff exemptions on some Chinese products
summary: The US has extended tariff exemptions for 352 Chinese products and 77 Covid-related products until May 31, 2024, following a process established by the US Trade Representative. The exemptions were previously set to expire on December 31, 2023. The move aims to provide economic relief for American businesses, but the US Trade Representative's lack of notice has been criticized by some groups. The extensions follow recent talks between US and Chinese officials, including a summit between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping in November.

site_title: BNP Paribas caught up in French money laundering investigation
summary: French prosecutors have launched an investigation into alleged aggravated money laundering related to transfers made by Cypriot brokerage firm TCR International Limited, which worked with BNP Paribas' custodian unit between 2019 and 2021. The probe focuses on transfers worth hundreds of millions of euros and dollars. The Paris Prosecutor's office confirmed the investigation after the French finance ministry's anti-money laundering unit, TRACFIN, issued an alert in May. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Eight dead, one missing in Australia after severe thunderstorms
summary: Eight people have been killed and one is missing in Australia after severe thunderstorms battered the country's east over the Christmas holidays. The storms brought large hailstones, torrential rains, and strong winds, causing widespread damage and power outages. Authorities have warned of fast-rising rivers and streams that could burst banks, and several regions in the west are fighting fires. The storms come as Australia experiences an El Nino weather phenomenon, which can cause extremes ranging from wildfires to tropical cyclones and prolonged droughts.

site_title: South Korea’s consumers turn less pessimistic as inflation eases
summary: South Korea's consumer survey index increased to 99.5 in December, reversing four months of declines, as inflation eased and exports improved. The 2.3-point rise reversed the previous month's decline and indicated consumers turned less pessimistic. The Bank of Korea kept its key interest rate on hold, citing a hawkish bias despite consumer inflation re-accelerating above 3%. The reading below 100 still indicates more pessimists than optimists, but suggests a shift in consumer sentiment.

site_title: Bets on Xi’s ‘common prosperity’ agenda lead to big losses in 2023
summary: Investors who bet on China's "common prosperity" agenda, which aims to narrow the wealth gap and promote renewable energy, saw significant losses in 2023. Eight of the 10 biggest losers on the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index were from the Chinese consumer or renewables sectors, with stocks like Li Ning and Pylon Technologies plummeting by at least 68%. The Chinese government's regulatory crackdowns, property crisis, and faltering recovery from Covid lockdowns contributed to the losses, highlighting the pitfalls of aligning with a single theme.

site_title: Annual US home prices rise again
summary: US home prices rose 6.3% in October, up from a revised 6.2% in the previous month, indicating continued recovery of the housing market. Annual price growth accelerated in June after a decline since February 2022. Mortgage rates neared 8% in October, a two-decade high, but the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell below 7% in December. The housing market is expected to benefit from softening rates drawing sellers from the sidelines and opening up inventory. The Mid-Atlantic and New England regions experienced the largest gains in October.

images.alt_text: Purchases of new single-family homes decrease 12.2 per cent to a 590,000 annual pace last month, a one-year low.

site_title: Aquaman 2 leads films in a soft Christmas moviegoing weekend
summary: Aquaman 2 led domestic theaters with $38.3 million over the Christmas weekend, despite a slow box office due to a resurgence of Covid-19 cases and increased streaming competition. The film, directed by James Wan, received poor reviews with only 36% of critics recommending it. Warner Bros' films dominated the holiday weekend, with musical remakes Wonka and The Color Purple finishing in second and third place. The film caps a difficult year for Warner Bros' superhero pictures, following disappointing releases like The Flash and Shazam! Fury of the Gods.

images.alt_text: The film is a prequel, with Chalamet (left) as a younger version of Roald Dahl’s famous chocolatier Willy Wonka, a character first played by Gene Wilder and then Johnny Depp.
The process of creating this world, though exhausting and very time consuming – and really the amount of detail is insane – has been incredibly rewarding,” says Rebel Moon's director Zack Snyder.

site_title: Ousted Binance founder CZ’s fortune grew by US$25 billion in 2023
summary: Former Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao's estimated wealth grew by nearly $25 billion in 2023, surpassing the $4.3 billion in fines Binance agreed to pay US authorities. His fortune, currently over $37 billion, is derived from his controlling stake in Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange. Despite facing up to 10 years in prison for US criminal charges, Zhao's wealth is still far from its peak of nearly $97 billion in 2022, and his wealth is now more than five times the size of the fines Binance paid.

images.alt_text: Since bitcoin’s inception in 2009, traditional finance (TradFi) has struggled to understand what it is, what it will be, and whether it is a viable investment asset.
Digital-asset markets still have plenty of detractors who argue cryptocurrencies are fundamentally worthless and a haven for criminals.
Kyle Davies, co-founder of crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital. The claims by Three Arrows’ creditors into the fund’s liquidation remain in excess of US$3 billion, according to Teneo.

site_title: Bitcoin dips below US$42,000 while memecoin rally shows signs of stalling
summary: Bitcoin dropped below US$42,000, its first decline in a week, while the recent rally in memecoins appears to be stalling. The largest cryptocurrency by market value fell 4.3% to US$41,656, with smaller tokens like Solana and Avalanche declining over 10%. Analysts expect potential volatility due to year-end flows, options, and futures expiries, as well as thin liquidity during the holiday season.

images.alt_text: The Bitcoin logo in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023. Bitcoin shrugged off a dip in global stock markets to set another more than 19-month high, a sign of its decoupling from other assets. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Homelessness soars in rural England as living costs hit poor
summary: Homelessness in rural England has surged by 40% in five years, with 24,143 individuals now living on the streets or in makeshift shelters. The crisis is attributed to a combination of factors, including record house prices, welfare payment cuts, and a housing shortage. Charities report that wages have stagnated, and housing costs have risen, exacerbating food poverty. The situation is particularly dire in rural areas, where people are often hidden from view and lack access to support services.

images.alt_text:

REUTERS/ Susannah Ireland/File Photo

epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
The deficit between April and November climbs to £116.4 billion (S$195.7 billion), a rise of 27 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Fixing America’s broken air-traffic control system
summary: The US air-traffic control system is facing a critical shortage of 3,000 air-traffic controllers, leading to flight delays, cancellations, and near-collisions. The staffing shortfall is partly attributed to Congress's failure to provide stable, multi-year funding, which hinders ATC planning and investment in equipment. The FAA is struggling to recruit and train new controllers, and Congressional Republicans' threats to cut appropriations pose a major challenge. A solution proposed by experts is to transfer the ATC system to a non-profit corporation and fund it through user fees, reducing airport congestion and prioritizing commercial airlines over private jets.

images.alt_text: Global flight capacity is projected to grow 3.6 per cent annually between 2019 and 2041, while CO2 emissions will rise – not fall – at a rate of 2.7 per cent, according to Cirium.

A proposal sent earlier this week would require “cash compensation in an amount commensurate with the inconvenience experienced” when a delay or cancellation is due in part or in whole to an issue under the carrier’s control.
Passengers queueing in Heathrow Airport in London. Last week, Heathrow blamed airlines for overambitious flight schedules as it limited passengers to 100,000 a day.

site_title: Shipping firms take first steps towards Red Sea return
summary: Shipping companies including Maersk and Hapag-Lloyd are considering returning to the Red Sea after a US-led maritime security initiative was announced in response to attacks on vessels by Yemen's Houthi militant group. CMA CGM is increasing its vessels in the Suez Canal, while Hapag-Lloyd will decide on Wednesday whether to resume journeys through the Red Sea. The decision comes after the group stopped using Red Sea routes due to the attacks, which disrupted global trade through the Suez Canal.

images.alt_text: An Israeli navy missile boat patrols the Red Sea off the coast of Israel's southern port city of Eliat. The Houthis have vowed to continue their attacks until Israel halts the conflict in Gaza.
Singapore ports have crossed the 3 billion gross tonnage mark as development of Tuas Port pushes ahead.
The international crew of the vehicle carrier Galaxy Leader are being held in Yemen by Houthi rebels.
Maersk was preparing to allow for vessels both eastbound and westbound to resume transit through the Red Sea, under the protection from the multi-national security coalition.

site_title: Los Angeles office building sells at 52% less than 2018 price
summary: A Los Angeles office building, 1640 Sepulveda Blvd, sold for approximately US$44.7 million, 52% less than its 2018 price of US$92.5 million. This is the second real estate acquisition for the joint venture of Harbor Associates and F&F Capital Group in two months. The sale reflects the pressure on LA office buildings due to the rise of remote work and financing challenges caused by soaring interest rates.

images.alt_text: architecture, skyscraper, glass facades

site_title: Oil jumps over 2% amid Red Sea vessel attacks, rate cut hopes
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% amid Red Sea vessel attacks and hopes of interest rate cuts, reaching their highest level this month. Brent crude futures rose 2.5% to $81.07 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 2.7% to $75.57. The attacks on ships in the Red Sea have sparked concerns about shipping disruptions, but supply remains unaffected. Expectations of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve also boosted oil demand, with traders betting on a 25-basis-point cut in March 2024.

images.alt_text: Novatek, a controlling shareholder in the Arctic LNG-2 project, has declared force majeure due to the US sanctions, sources say.
Trade is thin as some markets are still closed for the Boxing Day public holiday.

site_title: Tech revolution unleashed: Emerging trends for strategic transformation
summary: Emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence, are driving transformative change in companies, necessitating restructuring, human capital transformation, and continuous learning. As these technologies propel businesses from one state to another, organizations must adopt a strategic approach to navigate the technological landscape and its trends. Ignoring or delaying involvement with these advancements is not viable, as companies risk falling behind and facing regulatory issues. The transformative potential of technology requires a collaborative effort, fueled by awareness and education, to ensure that technological progress aligns with ethical standards, legal frameworks, and positive societal outcomes.

images.alt_text: AI has the potential to contribute nearly S$1.36 trillion to the Asean economy by 2030.

Developed market companies like Nvidia may have dominated the headlines as the first wave of investment opportunity centres around computing power, but there are secondary role opportunities in the wider tech supply chain for EM businesses.
As societies age, labour is becoming scarcer and better rewarded, especially manual activity that is hard to replace with technology.

There's been a carefully constructed narrative around technology, one of techno-optimism : invent as much as you can, and good things – higher wages, better health, and more opportunity – will follow. Not so.
Within the next two years, 75 per cent of the global workforce will be digital natives.
In an increasingly technology-led world, exceptional soft skills, including in-person networking, critical thinking and problem-solving are increasingly valuable.

site_title: US: Stocks drift higher in post-holiday session
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average advancing 0.4% to 37,545.33, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gaining 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively. The "Santa Claus rally" continued, driven by light trading and positive news flow. The US stock market has been on a tear since October, with the Federal Reserve halting interest rate hikes and leaning towards rate cuts in 2024. However, geopolitical tensions, including US air strikes in Iraq, added to market volatility, with individual stocks such as Manchester United and Apple experiencing fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 19.93 points, or 0.05 per cent, at the open to 37,405.90.

site_title: China approves 26 seed companies for GMO corn and soybeans
summary: China has approved licenses for 26 domestic seed companies to produce and sell genetically modified (GMO) corn and soybean seeds, paving the way for commercial planting in certain provinces. The move aims to reduce China's reliance on imports, which total over 100 million metric tons annually, and boost yields. The approved companies, including Beijing Dabeinong Technology and China National Seed, will distribute and sell GMO grains, potentially significantly lowering future purchases from the US and Brazil. Commercial planting is expected to begin next year, with initial trials showing "outstanding" results.

images.alt_text: China has boosted its domestic soybean production significantly in the last two years by promoting more planting to reduce its reliance on overseas imports.

site_title: Counting on the Chinese consumer
summary: China's equity market has been declining since January due to property market woes and geopolitical risks. However, the domestic consumer is expected to drive growth, benefiting media and entertainment companies. The communication services sector is expected to outperform China's broader equity market, with 56% earnings growth in 2023, compared to 16% for the broader market. This makes the sector an attractive investment opportunity.

images.alt_text: The administration says on Saturday that it will listen to feedback from stakeholders including companies and players to improve the rules.

site_title: The big surprises of 2023 and what it means for 2024
summary: The US economy surprised many economists and investors in 2023, avoiding a recession despite elevated inflation and interest rates. Global equities grew over 20% and long-term interest rates fell, contrary to predictions. The economy expanded at an average rate of 3% while inflation trended lower. Key factors contributing to the surprise include the resolution of supply-driven inflation and the US government's pro-cyclical fiscal policy. In 2024, investors can expect a soft patch rather than a deep recession, with cyclical sectors and emerging markets expected to perform well.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential candidate and former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at a rally in Durham, New Hampshire, U.S. December 16, 2023. REUTERS/Brian Snyder

site_title: Government sustainability reports need to demonstrate greater clarity, better leadership
summary: Singapore's government agencies are releasing annual sustainability reports, but they are underwhelming, omitting key emissions data and providing little actionable information for companies to reduce their carbon footprint. The Land Transport Authority's report, for instance, did not address emissions from its MRT stations and electric bus deployment, while the government-wide sustainability report left out Scope 3 emissions, which are significant in the public sector. To effectively support industries in achieving their national climate goals, government agencies need to provide clearer and more detailed information, including emissions data and policy actions, to drive system transformation towards net zero by 2050.

images.alt_text: Government chief sustainability officer Lim Tuang Liang said the public sector believes that its transparency through reporting will spur agencies to continuously strive to minimise the environmental impact of their operations.
Good disclosures help decision-makers allocate resources, said DPM Heng.
Singapore reduced its emissions to 52.8 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2020, equivalent to 32 per cent below business-as-usual levels, Wong said.
Construction workers building the new Fernvale Community Club.
Singapore ports have crossed the 3 billion gross tonnage mark as development of Tuas Port pushes ahead.

site_title: Let’s talk blockchain, not crypto
summary: CFA Singapore Insights: Blockchain technology, not just crypto, holds significant investment potential. The industry's focus on Bitcoin overlooks the fundamental significance of blockchain itself and its opportunity to revolutionize application sharing, custody, and security. A blockchain-based framework provides a single source of truth, validated by a community, and enables trust without central authorities. This could lead to significant productivity gains and exponential growth in trust. Institutional investors should move beyond Bitcoin and explore the broader realm of blockchain, where validated blockchains can serve as the foundation for secure and trustworthy technology.

images.alt_text: Investors who have attended one of Berkshire Hathaway’s convention and annual meeting weekends may know already of the link between Munger’s passion for bridge and the breadth of Berkshire’s investment holdings.

site_title: Your investment resolutions for 2024
summary: Investors can improve their investment performance by making resolutions for 2024, such as diversifying their portfolios, thinking in a multi-faceted way, and tracking their investment decisions. The author plans to expand his circle of competence by reading about US companies and adopting a multidisciplinary approach to investing, inspired by Charlie Munger's "latticework of mental models." Additionally, he resolves to maintain an investment diary to document his decisions and learn from mistakes, and to grow his dividend stream by selectively adding to existing and new dividend stocks.

images.alt_text: Starbucks serves as a case study of poor capital allocation decisions. Its decisions to grow and “diworsify” despite diminishing returns have been a disservice to shareholders.

site_title: Biden’s objectives in the Middle East: Contain Iran and proxies, and to press Israel to change course
summary: US President Joe Biden's objectives in the Middle East include containing Iran and its proxies, as well as pressuring Israel to change its course. Following the Hamas attack on Israel in October 2023, Biden dispatched aircraft carriers and Marines to the region to deter Iran and its allies, while also pressuring Israel to refrain from attacking Hizbollah sites in Lebanon and to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza. However, the US has refrained from direct military attacks on Iranian targets, and tensions between Washington and Jerusalem over the post-Gaza war strategy have grown, with the Biden administration pushing for a Palestinian state and Israel rejecting the idea.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden has been putting pressure on the Israeli government to delay and moderate its ground invasion of the Gaza Strip.

(US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger (L) meets with Egypt's President Anwar Sadat during his visit to Cairo on Nov 7, 1973. US President Joe Biden (left) in a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv on Oct 18.

site_title: AstraZeneca to buy China-based Gracell Biotechnologies in US$1.2 billion deal
summary: AstraZeneca will acquire China-based Gracell Biotechnologies for up to $1.2 billion, bolstering its cell therapy ambitions. The deal includes the acquisition of Gracell's cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investments of $234.1 million. Gracell's FasTCAR platform enhances T-cell fitness, potentially improving treatment effectiveness. The acquisition is expected to close in the first quarter of 2024 and will not impact AstraZeneca's financial guidance for 2023.

site_title: Port of Singapore hits three billion gross tonnage mark; Tuas Port development continuing: MOT
summary: The Port of Singapore has recorded 3 billion gross tonnage in annual vessel arrival tonnage, exceeding the 2022 mark of 2.83 billion. Challenges from geopolitical tensions and conflicts, including disruptions to the Red Sea and Suez Canal, are being monitored. Meanwhile, the development of Tuas Port continues, with three more berths opened and 70% of reclamation works completed. The port aims to be green and sustainable, with plans to reduce carbon emissions and energy consumption, and a just-in-time planning platform to be rolled out in 2024.

Carriers have been attacked by Yemeni rebels in the Red Sea, prompting major shipping liners to avoid the Suez Canal for now.

site_title: US retail sales grow 3.1% during holiday season, says Mastercard
summary: US retail sales rose 3.1% between Nov 1 and Dec 24, surpassing forecasted growth and meeting most of holiday sales for retailers. This growth was driven by the apparel and restaurant categories, which saw increases of 2.4% and 7.8%, respectively. However, electronics sales fell 0.4% due to higher interest rates and inflation. Ecommerce sales grew at a slower pace of 6.3% compared to last year's 10.6%. The increase marks a decline from last year's 7.6% growth.

images.alt_text: Retailers could potentially adjust their discounts in a bid to entice price-sensitive shoppers in the days before Christmas.

site_title: China criticises US sanctions on Russia’s Arctic LNG-2 project
summary: China has criticized US sanctions on Russia's Arctic LNG-2 project, stating that economic cooperation between the two countries should not be interfered with or restricted by any third party. Chinese state-owned oil majors CNOOC and China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) have also declared force majeure due to the US sanctions. The US imposed sanctions on the project in November as part of measures against Moscow over the war in Ukraine, causing foreign shareholders to suspend participation. China's foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said that China opposes unilateral sanctions and long-arm jurisdiction without international law basis.

images.alt_text: While it’s unclear what materials, if any, can be exploited, the claims come as Washington seeks to boost access to so-called critical minerals that are necessary for electric vehicle batteries and renewable energy projects.

site_title: Manchester United shares jump as Ratcliffe deal eases ownership uncertainty
summary: Manchester United's shares jumped 4% on Tuesday after billionaire Jim Ratcliffe's Ineos Group purchased a 25% stake in the club, valuing it at $6.3 billion including debt. The deal eases ownership uncertainty and could revitalize the struggling club, which has seen poor performance since Alex Ferguson's departure in 2013. Ineos will also manage Manchester United's football operations, replacing the Glazer family's involvement. This move comes after the Glazers explored strategic options, including a sale, in November last year.

images.alt_text: Manchester United have not been crowned Premier League champions since Alex Ferguson’s final season in charge, in 2013.
After clinching the treble of the club’s first ever Champions League, Premier League and FA Cup last season, City also lifted the UEFA Super Cup for the first time in August.

site_title: Explosions reported in Red Sea shipping lane off Yemen coast
summary: Explosions were reported in the Red Sea off Yemen's west coast, with two incidents involving unmanned aircraft and missiles, and a third explosion. Two vessels were reportedly safe, but details of the vessels or their cargo were not disclosed. The incidents occurred a week after the US announced a maritime security initiative in response to attacks by Yemen's Houthi militia, who have vowed to continue their attacks until Israel halts the conflict in Gaza. No immediate claim of responsibility was made.

images.alt_text: An Israeli navy missile boat patrols in the Red Sea off the coast of Israel's southern port city of Eliat on December 26, 2023. (Photo by Alberto PIZZOLI / AFP)
Maersk was preparing to allow for vessels both eastbound and westbound to resume transit through the Red Sea, under the protection from the multi-national security coalition.

site_title: Pharma giant Bristol Myers adds to buying spree with US$4.1 billion purchase
summary: Bristol Myers Squibb agreed to purchase radiological drug developer RayzeBio for approximately $4.1 billion, rounding out its portfolio with cancer-fighting radiation drugs. The deal includes a $500 million cash payment, making the company worth $3.6 billion net. This acquisition follows Bristol's $14 billion purchase of schizophrenia drug developer Karuna Therapeutics. The move aims to capitalize on pharmaceutical companies' interest in precise tumor delivery systems, which can lead to higher efficacy with fewer side effects.

site_title: Adani Green founders to invest US$1.12 billion via share warrants
summary: Adani Green Energy, a renewable energy unit of Indian billionaire Gautam Adani, has received board approval to raise up to $1.12 billion by issuing share warrants to its founders. The funds will be used for deleveraging and accelerated growth spends. The company plans to inject $1 billion into Adani Green via preferential shares, while raising at least $2 billion in new debt next year to support its growth plans. This move demonstrates the group's confidence in tapping funding sources locally and overseas.

site_title: Apple files appeal after Biden administration allows US trade tribunal’s ban on watch imports
summary: Apple has filed an appeal against a US trade tribunal's decision to ban imports of its Apple Watches that use patent-infringing technology for reading blood-oxygen levels. The ban, which takes effect on Tuesday, was made by the US International Trade Commission (ITC) after a complaint from medical monitoring technology company Masimo. Apple has asked the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit to halt the ban until redesigned versions of its watches are evaluated. The company has also paused sales of its Series 9 and Ultra 2 smartwatches in the US, while the less-expensive Apple Watch SE remains available.

images.alt_text: Sales will continue at Apple’s international online and in-person stores.
The Vision Pro marks Apple’s first new product category since it began selling smartwatches in 2015.

site_title: Deloitte proposes tax incentive changes in its Budget 2024 wish list
summary: Deloitte has proposed tax incentive changes in its Budget 2024 wish list to support economic resilience, social stability, and innovation in Singapore. The firm recommends reshaping the tax incentives and grants regime, including deferring taxes on foreign asset sales, allowing economic substance requirements to exempt foreign income, and expanding the scope of grant programs. Additionally, Deloitte suggests refining incentives in view of international developments, pushing sustainability, and allocating resources to address climate issues. The proposals aim to maintain a supportive, growth-oriented fiscal environment while upholding Singapore's fair minimum tax rate commitments.

images.alt_text: Tax credits, sustainability-related guidance and more social welfare schemes are among PwC's proposals for Budget 2024.

site_title: 3Cnergy shareholders approve RTO of DTP Infinities
summary: 3Cnergy shareholders approved a reverse takeover (RTO) of DTP Infinities, renaming the company Prosper Cap. Iqbal Jumabhoy will lead the new entity as CEO and executive director. The RTO includes a 100 to 1 share consolidation, reducing the share capital to 30.7 million shares, and the issuance of up to 211 million new shares to meet minimum public float requirements. The RTO aims to fortify Prosper Cap's portfolio through strategic investments in operational and revenue-generating properties.

site_title: Global 2024 staple food supplies to be strained by dry weather, export curbs
summary: Global staple food supplies are expected to be strained in 2024 due to dry weather, export curbs, and higher biofuel mandates. Asian rice production is forecast to drop, while global wheat, corn, and soybean prices are headed for losses in 2023. The El Nino weather phenomenon is expected to continue in the first half of 2024, threatening supplies of rice, wheat, and palm oil. This may lead to tighter supplies, higher prices, and increased volatility in the global food market.

images.alt_text: Palm oil is one of the only agri commodities that has booked a fall in price so far this year, which has pressured the margins of companies in the palm oil production sector.

site_title: WHO urges pandemic accord in 2024 after years of Covid pain
summary: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus urged the world to address gaps in emergency preparedness and response to prevent the next pandemic, citing a turning point in fighting major health challenges after three years of Covid-19. He hopes 2024 offers an opportunity to address these gaps, with countries negotiating the first-ever global agreement on pandemic threats. The WHO also lifted emergency declarations for Covid-19 and mpox, and approved new vaccines for malaria, dengue, and meningitis.

images.alt_text: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus addresses during a press conference at the World Health Organization's headquarters in Geneva, on December 14, 2022. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
Health Minister Ong Ye Kung said the current Covid-19 wave has possibly peaked.

site_title: Wall St opens higher as rate-cut bets strengthen
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Tuesday, December 26, as investors grew optimistic about early rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 19.93 points, or 0.05%, to 37,405.90, while the S&P 500 gained 4.23 points, or 0.09%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 35.72 points, or 0.24%. The gains were attributed to strengthening rate-cut bets, lifting investor sentiment after the Christmas holidays.

site_title: Intel to get US$3.2 billion government grant for new US$25 billion Israel chip plant
summary: Intel has secured a US$3.2 billion government grant from Israel to build a new US$25 billion chip plant in southern Israel, fostering a more resilient global supply chain. The expansion plan, set to open in 2027, will create several thousand jobs and commit to buying US$16.6 billion worth of goods and services from Israeli suppliers over the next decade. Intel employs nearly 12,000 people in Israel and operates four development and production sites in the country, including a manufacturing plant in Kiryat Gat.

images.alt_text: Intel’s pitch to consumers and businesses comes as it is fighting its way out of a post-pandemic PC slump where buyers who upgraded to work from home in 2020 have seen little reason to buy new equipment.

site_title: US dollar edges lower, index on track for worst year since 2020
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.04% to 101.59, on track for a 1.84% yearly loss, its worst performance since 2020. Investors await fresh clues on the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut timing as inflation falls closer to the 2% target. The euro rose 0.01% to $1.1024, while the yen gained 0.02% to 142.42, poised for an 8.63% gain this year. The US economy is expected to slow in 2024, but the Fed aims to avoid a hard landing by adjusting monetary conditions.

images.alt_text: US dollar-yen risk reversals also suggest that traders are hedging for the Japanese currency to strengthen.

site_title: Japan's Jan-March crude steel output forecast to rise 1.7%
summary: Japan's crude steel output is forecast to rise 1.7% year-on-year in the first three months of 2024 due to healthy demand from automakers. The country's annual output for the financial year to March 31 is expected to be 88.10 million metric tons, up 0.3% from a year earlier. Despite concerns over China's growing steel output and exports, exports are forecast to increase 1.4% in the first quarter, driven by a pick-up in speciality steel products.

images.alt_text: The acquisition will help the world’s fourth largest steel maker move towards 100 million tonnes of global crude steel capacity and make it a bigger supplier to the US auto industry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 26)
summary: Singapore's headline inflation fell to 3.6% in December, down from 4.7% in October, while core inflation, excluding accommodation and private transport, decreased to 3.2%, a 0.1% drop from the previous month. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to maintain interest rates in the January review, citing easing inflation. Meanwhile, factory output in Singapore grew 1% in November, underperforming expectations, and condo resale prices rose 0.4% in November, 7.4% higher year-over-year. Uncertainty remains over Red Sea diversions and surcharges for shipping.

site_title: China cracks down on 1.5 billion yuan of government investment scams
summary: Chinese authorities have cracked down on 260+ cases of online investment scams, involving 1.5 billion yuan (S$278.1 million) of funds from investors, with 180 criminal groups dismantled. The scams often use fabricated government documents and credentials to lure investors into fake national projects. The crackdown comes as China's slowing economy seeks to attract investment funds domestically and abroad. Global asset managers, including Temasek Holdings, have reported scams targeting their brands and logos. The move aims to combat rampant online fraud in China.

images.alt_text: The consensus expects the communication services sector to deliver 56 per cent earnings growth in 2023 vs. 16 per cent for the broader market.
The People’s Bank of China has cut its key policy rate twice this year but has stood pat since August, relying more on pump priming in money markets to spur economic growth.

site_title: MUFG brokerage JV sued again over Credit Suisse AT1 losses
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities, a joint brokerage venture between Japan's largest lender and US investment bank Morgan Stanley, has been sued by 26 Japanese investors over losses on Credit Suisse's Additional Tier 1 (AT1) notes. The investors claim the firm violated a suitability principle by selling the bonds to regular investors, despite being for professional institutions, and failed to adequately explain risks associated with the debt. The plaintiffs demand 1.7 billion yen (S$16 million) in compensation, following a separate 5.2 billion yen suit filed earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Japan’s largest lender has been building up its operations in India in recent years.
FILE PHOTO: Japan's national flag is seen behind the logo of  Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc (MUFG) at its bank branch in Tokyo, Japan September 5, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Closing date for Boustead Projects offer extended to Jan 10; valid acceptances at 98.76%
summary: Boustead Singapore's closing date for its cash exit offer for real estate unit Boustead Projects has been extended to Jan 10, 2024. As of Dec 26, valid acceptances amount to 309.385 million shares, or 98.76% of total shares. The offer price remains unchanged at S$1.18 per share. The extension comes after Boustead Projects' suspension from trading due to a lack of free float.

images.alt_text: KBIL, a joint venture company of Boustead Projects, intends to acquire Minh Quang to develop the land the latter has leased into industrial facilities.
The results translate to earnings per share at S$0.056, up 19 per cent from S$0.047 in the previous H1 period.
The entrance of Boustead Singapore’s office.

As part of the contract, wholly-owned subsidiary Boustead International Heaters will design, engineer and supply the generators for a floating production, storage and offloading vessel, to be deployed in Latin America.

site_title: Thailand plans new minimum wage hike in March, keeps inflation target next year
summary: Thailand plans to increase its minimum wage in January by 2.37%, with a further hike in March, despite concerns from companies about competitiveness. The government aims to raise the daily minimum wage to 400 baht, as part of its populist platform. The central bank has maintained its inflation target of 1-3% for 2024, and the cabinet has approved a draft budget bill and reduced property fees to boost growth. The government expects the wage hikes to boost growth by 0.5 percentage points.

images.alt_text: Businesses have expressed concern over rising costs and wages as a factor in holding back competitiveness amid sluggish economic growth.

site_title: Indonesia presidential candidate Prabowo cements lead in poll
summary: Indonesian presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto has cemented his lead in a poll, securing 46.7% of the vote ahead of the February 14 election. His running mate, President Joko Widodo's 36-year-old son Gibran Rakabuming Raka, will also be on the ballot. Prabowo's closest opponent, former Central Java governor Ganjar Pranowo, trails behind with 24.5% of the vote. The poll was conducted after televised debates between candidates, which also included a debate for vice presidential candidates on December 22.

images.alt_text: Indonesia officially starts the 75-day campaign period for next year’s presidential election.

site_title: Chinese gaming firms unveil share buybacks after regulatory move unnerves investors
summary: Chinese gaming firms have announced share buybacks worth up to $149 million in response to regulatory moves to clamp down on consumer spending on games. The plans aim to reassure investors after shares plummeted following the release of draft rules banning common incentive mechanisms in online games. The National Press and Publication Administration has since released a statement indicating a softer stance on the rules, approving new licenses for 105 domestic online games. The buyback announcements have stabilized share prices, with some companies seeing their shares rise, while others fell.

images.alt_text: The administration says on Saturday that it will listen to feedback from stakeholders including companies and players to improve the rules.
The administration is seeking public comment on the rules by Jan 22, 2024.

site_title: Former Sembcorp Marine Brazil unit president Martin Cheah acquitted
summary: Former Sembcorp Marine Brazil unit president Martin Cheah was acquitted on December 20 of charges stemming from Operation Car Wash, a Brazilian anti-corruption probe. Another individual, Guilherme Esteves de Jesus, was also acquitted on the same day. The charges were not against Sembcorp Marine's Brazilian subsidiary, Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz, and the outcome of the acquittal's impact on ongoing investigations remains unknown.

site_title: Adani secures power purchase pacts for 8 gigawatts of solar projects
summary: Adani Green has secured 25-year power purchase pacts for 8 gigawatts of solar projects, reaching a milestone in its plan to expand capacity to 45 gigawatts by 2030. The deals were secured with Solar Energy Corp of India and mark a shift towards long-term contracts among state power retailers. This comes as extreme weather conditions boost electricity demand in the country, following a post-pandemic economic recovery. With the latest deal, Adani Green has offtake agreements for 19.8 gigawatts of projects.

site_title: Weak yen fuels Japan’s 2023 equity rally during foreign demand
summary: Japan's equity market has reached 33-year highs, with the Topix index and Nikkei 225 Stock Average rising over 20% in 2023, beating most Asian benchmarks. The yen's depreciation against major currencies fueled the rally, with gauges tracking Japanese carmakers and electronics companies surging 33%. Foreign investors, including those in the US and Europe, are bullish on Japan's equities, driven by the country's push to increase shareholder value and corporate earnings less susceptible to foreign exchange fluctuations.

images.alt_text: A man looks at an electric monitor displaying the Japanese yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar and Nikkei share average outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan October 4, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Condo resale prices continue uptrend, volumes flat in November: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale prices in Singapore continued their uptrend for the fourth consecutive month in November, rising 0.4% from the previous month and 7.4% year-over-year. Resale volumes remained muted, with 848 units changing hands, compared to 847 units in October. The launch of new condos in November had a spillover effect on the resale market, with buyers pushing up prices. Prices increased across all regions, with the Outside Central Region leading gains at 10.7% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: Overall condo resale prices for October are up 0.4 per cent month on month, and 7.5 per cent year on year with all regions experiencing price increases
HDB resale prices continue to rise month-on-month in July 2023, though at a slower pace when compared to previous years.

site_title: Mongolians are circus stars all over the world, except at home
summary: Mongolia's circus industry, once a source of national pride, has declined due to lack of government support and inadequate training facilities. Despite producing talented performers, such as those working with Cirque du Soleil and Ringling Brothers, many Mongolians are forced to train abroad or work without pay. The country's former state circus, sold to a sumo wrestler, failed to revive the industry, and current efforts to establish a new circus have been met with limited success. Performers continue to face challenges in accessing training spaces and receiving fair compensation, highlighting the need for government intervention to support the country's rich cultural heritage.

images.alt_text: Cirque du Soleil
Cirque du Soleil looks to break into Hollywood with film deal

site_title: Moving on from a not-so-merry Christmas
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing a slowdown, with financial statements reflecting the impact. Sales volume in the prime landed sector fell for a second year, but transacted land rates remain 40% higher than 2019-2020 levels. Agents expect a pick-up in Good Class Bungalow sales in 2024 due to existing demand and realistic price expectations. Lower borrowing costs may also improve the buying mood, potentially lifting the market. However, the extent of the recovery is uncertain.

images.alt_text: BTO flat buyers can make hefty gains in the resale market, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Three land parcels in areas well known to developers and homebuyers alike - River Valley, Queenstown and Pasir Ris - should see strong interest, writes deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Homeowners living in private property and/or holding properties for investment will be hit hard next year, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

One largely unseen component of developers’ costs is the land betterment charge paid to the government in return for enhanced land use in building up a site, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
The residential rental market is cooling its heels after racing up in 2021 and 2022, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Singapore stocks end Tuesday flat as traders eye potential interest rate cuts
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index ended Tuesday flat, down 0.01% or 0.34 point to 3,139.98. Investors were cautious despite US inflation data easing, with hopes of interest rate cuts sparking optimism. The local market saw a slight decline, with advancers narrowly beating decliners 194 to 184, as 538.4 million securities worth S$355.9 million changed hands.

images.alt_text: An Apple store in New York, US, on Friday, June 30, 2023. The blowout rally in tech megacaps gained further traction on Friday, with the Nasdaq 100 poised to notch a record first-half of a year and Apple Inc. hitting the $3 trillion milestone. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg via Getty Images
The expectation was that a bounce in the world’s second-largest economy would be the wave that lifted all boats, helping emerging markets globally to a banner year.

site_title: India’s Infosys falls after US$1.5 billion AI deal termination
summary: India's Infosys shares fell 2.6% on Dec 26 after a US$1.5 billion AI deal with an unnamed global company was terminated. The 15-year deal, signed in September 2023, aimed to enhance digital experiences and provide business operation services. The deal's termination comes amid global uncertainties and challenges for IT and tech companies. This is the second major move by Infosys in two weeks, following the resignation of former CFO Nilanjan Roy.

site_title: Brace for supply chain risks from conflict and climate change in 2024
summary: Supply chain risks are expected to persist in 2024 due to ongoing conflicts, climate change, and severe weather events. Recent attacks in the Red Sea by Yemen's Houthi rebels have forced shipping companies to alter routes, disrupting global trade. The Russia-Ukraine war and escalating civil war in Sudan also pose threats to trade flows and commodity prices. Climate-related disruptions, such as a severe drought at the Panama Canal, may occur in 2024, highlighting the need for contingency plans and innovation efforts to mitigate supply chain shocks.

images.alt_text: epa11012863 The Galaxy Leader cargo ship, seized by the Houthis offshore of the Al-Salif port on the Red Sea in the province of Hodeidah, Yemen, 05 December 2023. The Galaxy Leader ship, reportedly linked to an Israeli businessman, was seized and re-routed to offshore of the Yemeni port of Al-Salif by the Houthis on 19 November 2023 in retaliation for Israel's airstrikes on the Gaza Strip, according to statements by the Houthis. The ship, carrying around 25 crew members belonging to various nations, was seized as it was on its way to India. The Houthis, who control most of Yemen 's Red Sea coast, have fired missiles and drones at Israel and attacked more vessels transiting the area. Thousands of Israelis and Palestinians have died since the militant group Hamas launched an unprecedented attack on Israel from the Gaza Strip on 07 October, and the Israeli strikes on the Palestinian enclave which followed it.  EPA-EFE/YAHYA ARHAB

site_title: Thai market sentiment to stay tepid despite encouraging export data: Maybank
summary: Maybank Securities remains defensive on Thai equities despite a positive goods exports performance in October, citing weak tourism data and twin deficits. The research house forecasts a 6% earnings revision, making market sentiment "tepid". Key sectors to watch include commerce, telcos, and energy, with top picks including Home Product Center and True Corporation. A "contrarian strategy" is seen as apt for this cycle, with a sustained soft-landing in the US and China's economy crucial for a thematic pivot for Thailand.

site_title: En blocked: Collective sales at standstill while commercial deals stir interest
summary: The Singapore collective sales market experienced a quiet year in 2023, with only eight successful deals out of 32 properties put on the market, due to high land acquisition costs and mismatched price expectations between buyers and sellers. Residential collective sales plummeted 69% to S$574.3 million, while commercial deals slipped 15% to S$1.53 billion. Despite this, pockets of activity are expected in 2024, particularly in the commercial sector, with developers focusing on small to medium-sized sites or those with redevelopment potential.

images.alt_text: Margins are at a point where one could question the rationale for continuing the Singapore private housing business.
Aerial view of Orchard Road. Orchard Bel Air, a coveted residential site located right at the doorstep of Orchard Boulevard MRT station is up for sale by tender.
Savills remains optimistic that the low base of 2023 and the  peaking of interest rates to give rise to more investment deals in 2024.

site_title: Philippines extends tariff cuts on imported rice, other food items to fight inflation
summary: Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr has approved the extension of reduced tariffs on rice and other food items until the end of 2024 to combat inflation. The tariff rate for rice remains at 35%, while import levies on corn will stay at 5-15% and pork products at 15-25%. The move aims to maintain affordable prices and ensure food security amid a threat of dry weather in the coming months.

site_title: Vietnam’s high-speed rail in the making; Asean, Japan mark 50 years of ties
summary: Vietnam announced progress in its high-speed railway project, while Japan is expected to provide loans for the project. Thailand plans a global tender for its 1 trillion baht Landbridge project, aiming to bypass Singapore and Malaysia. Indonesia's central bank kept interest rates flat at 6%, and Malaysia's exports declined for the ninth consecutive month. Laos prepares to assume Asean chairmanship despite economic challenges, including a devalued currency, high inflation, and mounting public debt. The 50-year Asean-Japan relations commemorative summit took place in Tokyo, with progress made on funding for Vietnam's high-speed railway project.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (left, with Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi) announces a new Cabinet line-up.
Singapore stands as Vietnam’s largest foreign investor for the third straight year, accounting for almost a quarter of total foreign capital investment in 2022, writes BT journalist Goh Ruoxue.
Malaysia’s industrial production fell for a second straight month in September, dipping by 0.5 per cent year-on-year.
Pedestrians stroll around the tourist hotspots in Kuala Lumpur. Malaysia is set to raise its sales and services tax at the start of 2024.

site_title: Uncertainty arises over Red Sea diversions, surcharges after Maersk’s U-turn
summary: Maersk has announced plans to resume transit through the Red Sea for eastbound and westbound vessels, citing protection from the multinational security initiative Operation Prosperity Guardian. However, the company notes that the overall risk in the area is not eliminated and may re-evaluate its situation if necessary. Other carriers, such as Hapag-Lloyd, are still weighing their options, with some opting to reroute around the Cape of Good Hope. Uncertainty remains over whether diversions will occur, and surcharges for rerouting may be dropped if carriers proceed with the original route.

images.alt_text: Carriers have been attacked by Yemeni rebels in the Red Sea, prompting major shipping liners to avoid the Suez Canal for now.
Trade is thin as some markets are still closed for the Boxing Day public holiday.
FILE PHOTO: Containers are seen on the Maersk's container ship Maersk Gibraltar at the APM Terminals in the port of Algeciras, Spain January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo
Geely says that most of the shipping firms it uses to export its electric vehicles to Europe have plans to go around the Cape of Good Hope to avoid the Suez Canal.
Greek Defense Minister Nikos Dendias says that his country, as a foremost shipping nation, has a “fundamental interest” in addressing a “massive threat” to global maritime transport.

Cargo ships wait at the entrance of the Panama Canal at Panama Bay off Panama City, on September 24, 2023. The Panama Canal Authority is continuing to restrict the number of vessels that pass through the Panama Canal locks as drought has caused water levels at Gatun Lake to drop. The locks depend on millions of gallons of fresh water from the manmade lake to fill locks in Panama City and Colon in order to transit shipping vessels from the Pacific Ocean to the Caribbean Sea. (Photo by Luis ACOSTA / AFP)

Generic photo of general scene at PSA (Singapore) at Pasir Panjang Terminal on Feb 9, 2023. Can use for stories on economy, shipping, ports, containers terminal, sailing, port hub, cranes, shipping vessels, harbour, transshipment, merchant, cargo ship.
The Houthis' attacks have disrupted a key trade route that links Europe and North America with Asia via the Suez Canal and caused container shipping costs to rise sharply.
According to logistics giant Kuehne+Nagel, 103 container vessels are rerouting from the Red Sea around Africa.

site_title: JTC to reclaim 172ha of land in Tuas for industrial use, improved connections to Tuas Port
summary: Singapore's JTC Corporation plans to reclaim 172ha of land in Tuas for industrial use and improved road connections to Tuas Port, set to begin in 2025 and end in 2029. The project aims to meet future industrial land demands and enhance infrastructure connections. The reclamation will use incineration bottom ash as a pilot, a first in Singapore, with environmental monitoring to ensure minimal environmental impact. The move aims to support the country's industrial activities and adapt to evolving trends in manufacturing and trade.

images.alt_text: People’s Park Complex was completed in 1973 and was once Singapore's largest shopping complex.

The cap relaxation will apply to four-room and larger HDB flats, living quarters of HDB commercial properties where the living space is at least equivalent to a four-room flat, as well as private residential properties of at least 90 square metres.
In terms of investment volumes, Singapore has recorded US$7.53 billion so far this year, while Hong Kong’s total is US$5.27 billion.
The Verge’s annex block and the basement wall structures of its main block were reused in the development of Tekka Place.

site_title: Barbra Streisand talks style
summary: Barbra Streisand, 81, has released a memoir that delves into her fashion sense, revealing her approach to projecting glamour and sex appeal without relying on physical features. Born a "skinny marink" from Brooklyn, she prioritized her wardrobe, documenting every detail, from childhood burgundy sweaters to high-end designer pieces. Streisand's unique style, inspired by period films and art, impressed Vogue editor Diana Vreeland and became a defining aspect of her image. She has continued to evolve her style, from Empire gowns to custom designs, and remains a fashion icon.

images.alt_text: Singer Barbra Streisand and actor James Brolin attend the "And So It Goes" premiere at Guild Hall in East Hampton, New York, on July 6, 2014. Streisand has been married to actor James Brolin for a quarter of a century.

site_title: Samsung delays production at new US factory to 2025: report
summary: Samsung has delayed the mass production of its new US chip plant in Taylor, Texas, to 2025, according to a report. The factory, valued at $17 billion, was initially expected to start production in the second half of 2024. The delay is attributed to a shortage of construction workers and machine installation technicians. This postponement may impact the Biden administration's plan to boost chip production in the US, which faces challenges such as environmental permit issues and limited financial support.

images.alt_text: A Samsung flag flutters outside the company's Seocho building in Seoul on April 27, 2023. - Samsung Electronics on April 27, reported its worst quarterly profits in 14 years, blaming slowing consumer spending on electronics and a global microchip glut that hit its core memory business. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)
The new real-time translation feature will be incorporated into Samsung’s new Galaxy flagship model, which will launch early next year, the representative said.
Earlier this month, Samsung SDI said it plans to invest 2.7 trillion won to build a second joint EV battery plant with Stellantis in the US.

site_title: Economists expect MAS to stand pat in January review amid easing headline, core inflation
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is expected to keep monetary policy settings unchanged in January, following the easing of headline and core inflation in November. Headline inflation fell to 3.6% and core inflation to 3.2%, both below expectations. Economists are divided on whether MAS will ease or tighten policy in 2024, with some expecting a slight easing by April and others anticipating further tightening. MAS maintains its inflation outlook for 2023 and 2024, with headline inflation expected to average 3-4% and core inflation 2.5-3.5% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Economists raise their inflation forecasts for 2024 to 3.4 per cent for headline inflation, up from their previous projection of 3.1 per cent, and 3 per cent for core inflation, up from 2.8 per cent.
Consumer spending may grow more slowly in 2024 as post-Covid exuberance dies out.
Food inflation XXX in October.

site_title: Oil little changed as investors eye Middle East tensions, US rate cut
summary: Oil prices remained little changed on Tuesday, influenced by Middle East tensions and expectations of a US interest rate cut. Brent crude futures fell 26 US cents to $79.13 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose three US cents to $73.59 a barrel. The US Federal Reserve's potential rate cut is seen as a boost to global economic growth and oil demand. Shipping firms have resumed operations in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden after a temporary suspension due to Houthi attacks and the Israel-Gaza conflict.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates cut consumer borrowing costs, which can boost economic growth and demand for oil.

site_title: UK economy forecast to narrow GDP gap with Germany by 2038
summary: The UK economy is forecast to narrow its GDP gap with Germany by 2038, becoming Europe's best-performing major economy in the next 15 years. The Centre for Economics and Business Research predicts the UK will maintain a GDP growth rate between 1.6-1.8% until 2038, retaining its position as the world's sixth-largest economy. Despite anaemic productivity growth and labour supply problems, the UK's strong services sector and London's financial hub are expected to drive growth.

images.alt_text: epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
The deficit between April and November climbs to £116.4 billion (S$195.7 billion), a rise of 27 per cent from a year earlier.
Official figures show Britain’s gross domestic product shrank 0.3 per cent in October.
The annual rate of consumer price increases falls to 3.9 per cent from 4.6 per cent in October, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS).

site_title: Japan penalises top property insurers for price fixing
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency has issued business improvement orders to the country's largest property and casualty insurers, Tokio Marine Holdings, MS&AD Insurance Group Holdings, and Sompo Holdings, for colluding to fix prices with corporate clients. The investigation found widespread, repeated, and continuous price-fixing, and the firms have been urged to take drastic measures to prevent a recurrence. The insurers, which control 90% of Japan's casualty-insurance market, have been ordered to submit plans to boost governance by the end of February.

images.alt_text: real estate, homeownership, homebuying

FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian holding her mobile phone walks past electronic boards showing the Japan's Nikkei average (top L) and the Japanese yen's exchange rate against the euro (top R) outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, February 9, 2016.  REUTERS/Yuya Shino/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: People make their way at  Ameyoko shopping district in Tokyo, Japan, May 20, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

Asset management has emerged as an area of focus for the banks this year as the financial regulator sought their help to shake up the industry in line with Japan’s policy pledge to turn dormant household savings into investments.

site_title: Maersk prepares to return to Red Sea under US-led protection
summary: AP MOLLER-MAERSK, the world's second-largest container line, is set to resume shipping through the Red Sea under US-led protection. The company's decision comes after Houthi attacks on merchant ships have caused widespread avoidance of the southern Red Sea. Maersk welcomed the creation of Operation Prosperity Guardian, a maritime task force established by the US and allies to protect vessels from Houthi attacks. The company prioritizes employee safety and will re-evaluate the safety situation if necessary, despite acknowledging that the overall risk is not eliminated in the area.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Containers are seen on the Maersk's container ship Maersk Gibraltar at the APM Terminals in the port of Algeciras, Spain January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: The world's first methanol-fueled container vessel Laura Maersk, owned by shipping company Maersk, is seen in Copenhagen, Denmark September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen/File Photo
Maersk says that its vessel Maersk Gibraltar is being targeted by a missile while traveling from Salalah, Oman, to Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and confirms that the crew and vessel are safe.

Maersk intends to scale up its warehousing and distribution in South-east Asia by up to 50 per cent, and expects to add nearly 480,000 square metres of capacity across Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines by 2026.

site_title: Asset managers turn bullish on yen as US Fed, BOJ path may reverse
