summary: Asset managers have turned bullish on the yen for the first time since May, citing expectations that the Bank of Japan will end its ultra-easy policy in 2024, while major peers cut interest rates. The yen reached its strongest level since July against the US dollar, and US dollar-yen risk reversals indicate traders are hedging for the Japanese currency to strengthen. This follows the Federal Reserve's signal of a potential rate cut next year and speculation about the BOJ ending its negative interest rate policy.

site_title: Singapore’s November factory output marks two straight months of growth, up lower-than-expected 1%
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 1% in November, extending October's surprise 7.6% growth, but underperforming economists' median expectations of a 2.2% increase. The electronics sector, however, posted a slower pace of growth, while other clusters recorded growth. The infocomm and consumer electronics segment marked the strongest growth, and semiconductor output and consumer electronics showed improvement from earlier contractions. Despite this, pockets of weakness in other key segments complicate the uptrend, and recovery will likely be driven by the electronics cycle upturn, with broader recovery expected towards the middle of 2024.

images.alt_text: Electronics was the best-performing cluster in October, with output expanding 14.8 per cent year on year, extending the previous month’s 12.7 per cent growth.
FILE PHOTO: A worker walks near a factory at the Keihin industrial zone in Kawasaki, Japan, March 8, 2017. REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: Singapore shares inch up on Tuesday amid thin trading; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3144.56. Thin trading and a slight rebound in banking stocks contributed to the gains. The market followed the US and European markets, which also saw gains. Major gainers included Seatrium, Biolidics, and mm2 Asia, while DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose. The gains came despite concerns over US interest rate cuts and global market volatility.

images.alt_text: CMG20231215-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Japan’s business service price growth holds at 30-year high
summary: Japan's business service price growth remains at a 30-year high, increasing 2.3% in November from the previous year, according to the Bank of Japan. This marks the second consecutive month of 2.3% gains, the fastest since April 1992. Hotels, internet advertising, and road transportation were major contributors to the yearly change. Despite a slowdown in consumer inflation, the BOJ governor expressed optimism that the economy will transition to a virtuous cycle between wages and prices, potentially leading to the end of negative interest rates by April.

site_title: Gold gains on prospects of US Fed rate cuts next year
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,056.80 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and lower bond yields amid rising expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut as early as March next year. The US dollar index fell 0.1% and 10-year bond yields edged lower to 3.9%, making gold more attractive for other currency holders. Traders now price in an 88% chance of a rate cut by the US central bank in March, boosting expectations for lower interest rates and a decrease in the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates decrease the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Japan’s labour demand holds steady in positive sign for wages
summary: Japan's labour market remained tight in November, with a job-to-applicants ratio of 1.28, indicating 128 jobs offered for every 100 applicants. The unemployment rate held steady at 2.5%, and the number of workers rose by 560,000 from the same month a year earlier. Economists believe this trend indicates workers are voluntarily quitting jobs to pursue better opportunities, leading to increased pressure on employers to boost wages ahead of annual wage negotiations. This could spur the virtuous wage-price cycle, supporting wage growth and workplace efficiency.

images.alt_text: Hotels in particular have rose 51.8 per cent compared with the previous year on the back of a post-pandemic surge in inbound tourism and domestic demand for travel.
Japan, like other economies around the world, has seen prices rise on the back of the Ukraine war, while a weaker yen has also made imports more expensive.
The fiscal 2024 economic growth projection is slightly higher than the previous estimate of 1.2 per cent.

site_title: BOJ’s Ueda signals chance of policy shift, progress on price goal
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda signaled a possible policy shift, stating that the likelihood of achieving the central bank's 2% inflation target is "gradually rising". He hinted that the BOJ will consider changing policy if the prospects of sustainably achieving the target increase sufficiently. Ueda emphasized that the BOJ will carefully examine economic developments and firms' wage- and price-setting behavior before making a decision. This comes as inflation has exceeded the target for over a year, leading many market players to expect a potential interest rate boost in 2024.

site_title: No one wants used EVs, making new ones a tougher sell too
summary: The global shift to electric vehicles (EVs) is facing a new hurdle as buyers shun used EVs due to a lack of subsidies, desire for better technology, and limited charging infrastructure. Prices for secondhand EVs are falling faster than those for combustion-engine cars, threatening earnings at rivals like Volkswagen and Stellantis. As new EVs come off leasing contracts and enter the market, companies must find ways to address the problem, as it could impact decarbonization efforts and consumer confidence. Manufacturers are exploring new battery technologies and mobility offerings to boost demand.

images.alt_text: Thailand is aiming to convert about a third of its annual production of 2.5 million vehicles into EVs by 2030.

site_title: Goldman’s painful 2023 lesson on China forces rethink of emerging markets
summary: Goldman Sachs' head of global currency, rates, and emerging-markets strategy has learned two main lessons from the 2023 market downturn, which was initially expected to be fueled by a post-pandemic China reopening boom. The bank had predicted a 15% rally in the Chinese stock market, but Chinese stocks instead fell over 15% and many emerging markets performed well. This experience forces Goldman to rethink its approach to emerging markets, highlighting the importance of caution and accurate predictions in the market.

images.alt_text: Life and health reinsurance is buoyed by robust fundamentals and bright spots in the Asia-Pacific region, where several emerging markets are experiencing rapid population growth, a rising middle class, and consistent economic growth, said market watchers.
The yuan, Indian rupee and Malaysian ringgit are among the least volatile exchange rates in the asset class over the last 30 days.

site_title: Blackstone allocates most real estate investment to Europe: report
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, allocated 55% of its 2023 real estate investments to European assets, exceeding its typical 20-30% allocation to the region. This shift was driven by rising interest rates, which led to bargain prices. Blackstone reduced its total spend on new properties from $47 billion in 2022 to $9 billion in the first three quarters of 2023. The firm is targeting high-growth areas such as logistics warehouses, data centers, and student accommodations with its remaining $40 billion of "dry powder".

site_title: Prada plots major New York City expansion with US$835 million building deal
summary: Prada is expanding its New York presence with the acquisition of two buildings on Fifth Avenue, valued at US$835 million. The Italian fashion brand purchased 720 Fifth Ave for approximately US$410 million and 724 Fifth Ave for US$425 million. This move is part of its major expansion plans in the US, amid strong retail sales in the country despite a global slowdown in luxury goods demand.

images.alt_text: Prada says the building housing its Fifth Avenue flagship offers high strategic value after an influx of residential, hospitality and retail investments in the neighbourhood.
Prada says the property’s location offers high strategic value after an influx of residential, hospitality and retail investments in the neighbourhood.
Prada will have bigger stores, more local products and more events in China, according to Gianfranco D’Attis, Prada CEO .

site_title: Toyota’s Daihatsu to compensate suppliers over output halt
summary: Daihatsu Motor, Toyota's small car unit, will compensate 423 domestic suppliers for halted production in Japan due to a safety scandal. The company halted production until the end of January and is assessing the impact on its supplier network. Daihatsu will consider compensation based on past business volumes and may also provide support to smaller subcontractors. The company has resumed production of Perodua brand cars in Malaysia and shipments from its Indonesian subsidiary have resumed. The halt affects 64 models, including some sold under Toyota's brand.

images.alt_text: The models include Veloz and Avanza; shipments in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam and Cambodia have been halted.
Daihatsu has resumed shipments from its subsidiary in Indonesia, Astra Daihatsu Motor, it is the only unit where the company has done so.

site_title: Japan automakers to invest 150 billion baht in Thailand over five years: Thai government
summary: Japan's major automakers, Toyota, Honda, Isuzu, and Mitsubishi, plan to invest 150 billion baht (S$5.75 billion) in Thailand over five years, supporting the country's transition to electric vehicles (EVs). Thailand aims to convert a third of its annual 2.5 million vehicle production into EVs by 2030. This investment will include the production of electric pickup trucks, and follows Chinese EV makers' recent investments in the country. The move is part of Thailand's policy to phase out combustion engine vehicles and is seen as a significant boost to its EV manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: January-to-November exports declined 1.5 per cent from the same period last year.
People take part in the annual LGBTQ Pride parade in Bangkok, Thailand, June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Thailand has one of the highest rates of gun ownership in the region with 10 million firearms in circulation – roughly one for every seven Thais.
A wage committee comprising government, employers and employee representatives has agreed to increase the pay threshold range to 330 to 370 baht.

site_title: Number of Londoners buying homes outside capital falls to 9-year low
summary: Londoners spent £29 billion on homes outside the capital in 2023, a 33% decrease from 2022, marking the lowest nine-year record. Affordability pressures, including 14-year high mortgage rates and high inflation, led to a decline in London outmigration. Downsizers and first-time buyers accounted for most of those leaving the capital, with 41% moving further out and 39% spending 39% less on their new property. Mortgage costs are expected to decline, potentially slowing outmigration, while slowing rental costs in London may also encourage some to stay.

images.alt_text: In real terms, house prices are no higher than in late 2015, and Bloomberg Economics says they have further to fall.
Lenders make commitments on £51.5 billion (S$86.7 billion) of mortgages in the third quarter, according to the BOE’s Mortgage Lenders and Administrators Statistics.
Prices of prime country properties–those in the top 5 per cent of the market–are forecast to end the year down 7 per cent, according to broker Knight Frank.

site_title: India’s Paytm confirms it will axe jobs to cut costs
summary: Paytm, the Indian fintech firm, confirmed plans to axe jobs as part of cost-cutting measures to achieve its first net profit since listing in 2021. The company will save 10-15% in employee costs with the help of artificial intelligence. Paytm had an average of 32,798 directly employed staff and 1,589 contracted employees worldwide during its fiscal year to March 2023. The exact number of jobs to be cut is not specified, contradicting recent media reports suggesting over 1,000 roles would be eliminated.

images.alt_text: File photo: Commuters move past a bus stop with Paytm advertisements in Mumbai, India, November 10, 2021. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni/File photo

site_title: China bond inflow surprise may be false dawn as PBOC hands tied
summary: China has seen a surge in foreign bond inflows, with investors boosting holdings by 251 billion yuan (S$47.8 billion) in November, the second-largest on record. However, experts warn that this may be a false dawn, as Beijing's constraints on monetary easing and concerns over China's long-term debt woes may limit the appeal of its bonds. The People's Bank of China has cut its key policy rate twice this year but has stood pat since August, and US monetary tightening has deterred the PBOC from adopting aggressive easing measures.

images.alt_text: For years, Chinese companies have been basing their foreign exchange accounting on the PBOC daily yuan fixing, rather than the prevailing market rate, as recommended by the country’s Ministry of Finance.
The central bank has already geared up support for the economy via massive liquidity infusions, offering lenders a net 800 billion yuan of one-year policy loans in an operation in mid-December.
Most new and outstanding loans in the world’s second-largest economy are based on the one-year LPR, which stands at 3.45 per cent.
China has space to step up support for the economy, given that its central government debt burden is relatively low and consumer prices are also low, according to the central bank adviser.

site_title: Yandex’s restructuring deal expected to be delayed to next year
summary: Yandex's restructuring deal is expected to be delayed until early 2024, three sources familiar with the negotiations said. The Russian tech company aims to recoup shareholder funds by selling its main revenue-generating Russian businesses, such as search and ride-hailing operations. The deal, initially expected in December, was supposed to involve spinning off Yandex's Russian businesses from its Dutch parent company, Yandex NV, to retain access to Western markets despite sanctions. The completion of the restructuring now depends on shareholder and government approvals.

images.alt_text: Yandex's revamp is expected to involve the sale of its main revenue-generating Russian businesses, such as search and ride-hailing, and developing four other business lines internationally.

site_title: Russia short of around 4.8 million workers in 2023, crunch to persist: report
summary: Russia faces a labor shortage of approximately 4.8 million workers in 2023 and 2024, according to a report by Izvestia. Hundreds of thousands of highly-qualified IT specialists left the country due to the special military operation in Ukraine. Labor shortages have increased sharply, with drivers and shop workers in high demand, and companies are raising wages to attract more employees. Experts attribute the shortages to poor demographics and migration, which are expected to persist in 2024.

images.alt_text: The move significantly expands the US financial battle against President Vladimir Putin, whose forces show little sign of relenting in Ukraine’s east.
FILE PHOTO: Sergei Petrov, founder of Russian car dealer Rolf, speaks as he attends the Reuters Russia Investment Summit in Moscow, September 24, 2014.  REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: In Hong Kong, Chinese tourists abandon luxury for thrift
summary: Mainland Chinese tourists returning to Hong Kong are adopting more frugal consumption habits, shifting away from luxury goods and seeking diverse experiences instead. The new wave of visitors, who made over 21.4 million arrivals in the first 10 months of 2023, are spending significantly less time and money compared to pre-pandemic times. This change poses challenges for Hong Kong retailers as they adjust to the new normal, with a focus on offering value and unique experiences to attract these cautious spenders.

site_title: The year’s top-performing S-Reit looks to repeat its act in 2024
summary: Digital Core Reit, Singapore's top-performing S-Reit, is poised for continued growth in 2024 after resolving customer bankruptcy issues. The Reit's units have rallied 15.5% this year, beating other S-Reits. The company plans to diversify and expand into Asia-Pacific markets, with a focus on Japan and Singapore. With a US$15 billion acquisition pipeline, Digital Core aims to scale and achieve diversification, potentially issuing equity to do so. Analysts have given the stock a "buy" call, with an average target price of US$0.70, representing a 10.6% upside.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit is among the top three performers in December for S-Reits with office properties in the US.

site_title: Thai November export growth misses forecast; rice shipments surge
summary: Thailand's November exports rose 4.9% from last year, but missed forecasts, with rice shipments surging 41.8% to 1 million tonnes. The country's full-year exports are expected to post a small drop before rising 2% in 2024. November's exports were helped by higher shipments of agricultural products and electronic goods. However, attacks by Yemen's Houthi militants on ships in the Red Sea could impact Thai exports in January.

images.alt_text: People take part in the annual LGBTQ Pride parade in Bangkok, Thailand, June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Thailand has one of the highest rates of gun ownership in the region with 10 million firearms in circulation – roughly one for every seven Thais.
A wage committee comprising government, employers and employee representatives has agreed to increase the pay threshold range to 330 to 370 baht.

site_title: Christmas in China brings glittering decor and foreign influence concerns
summary: China marks Christmas with glittering decorations, but with a focus on managing foreign influences. In some areas, shopping malls and schools have been told not to promote or celebrate foreign traditions, with schools urging students to be confident in their own culture. The Communist Party has expressed concern about "foreign influences" and has called for Christianity to be "sinicized" to align with Chinese values and traditions. The Vatican has also been involved in disputes with Beijing over the appointment of Catholic bishops.

images.alt_text: “Tonight, our hearts are in Bethlehem, where the Prince of Peace is once more rejected by the futile logic of war, by the clash of arms that even today prevents him from finding room in the world,” the pope Francis says.
Palestinian girls at the Church of the Nativity, built on the site where Jesus is believed to have been born, in the West Bank city of Bethlehem.

site_title: Disney, Reliance sign non-binding agreement for India media operations merger: ET
summary: Reliance Industries and Walt Disney Co. signed a non-binding agreement to merge their Indian media operations, with Reliance owning 51% and Disney holding 49%. The deal, expected to be completed by February, would create one of India's biggest entertainment empires. The merger is a response to Disney's struggling streaming app Hotstar, which has seen a user exodus. Reliance's Viacom18 will take control of Star India through a stock swap, with a planned investment of $1 billion to $1.5 billion in the business.

images.alt_text: Netflix’s ad revenue will likely jump 50.3 per cent to about US$1 billion next year.
Reliance was reported by Bloomberg in October to be valuing Disney’s India assets at between US$7 billion and US$8 billion.
In June, Pixar will release Inside Out 2 in cinemas, a sequel to a 2015 film that grossed US$858.8 million in worldwide ticket sales.
The Zootopia-themed land at Shanghai Disneyland..

site_title: 3 predictions to help leaders succeed in an AI-driven workforce in 2024
summary: Artificial intelligence is transforming the workforce, and leaders must adapt to succeed. Three key trends will shape the future of work: skills will take center stage, learning will become more flexible and accessible, and adaptive leadership is crucial for success. As AI automates tasks, soft skills will become increasingly valuable, and professionals will need to acquire new skills to stay relevant. Companies must empower employees to learn and upskill, and leaders must cultivate a resilient and adaptable culture to thrive in an AI-driven world.

site_title: PBOC’s yuan support through fixing causes headache for companies
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, has artificially strengthened the yuan by fixing it at a consistently higher rate than the prevailing market rate, causing financial headaches for companies. This has resulted in unrealized losses for companies like Whirlpool China, which would have incurred a smaller loss if based on the spot rate. The practice has prompted some local businesses to consider using the spot rate for accounting purposes, potentially prompting the PBOC to narrow the basis for macro-prudential reasons.

images.alt_text: The central bank has already geared up support for the economy via massive liquidity infusions, offering lenders a net 800 billion yuan of one-year policy loans in an operation in mid-December.
Most new and outstanding loans in the world’s second-largest economy are based on the one-year LPR, which stands at 3.45 per cent.
China has space to step up support for the economy, given that its central government debt burden is relatively low and consumer prices are also low, according to the central bank adviser.
China’s yuan has had a volatile year, having weakened 6.14 per cent against the US dollar at one point before recouping some of the losses on growing bets that US interest rates have peaked.

site_title: Bank of Russia governor says she is bracing for more sanctions
summary: Bank of Russia Governor Elvira Nabiullina stated that Russia's economy restructuring is proceeding quickly, as businesses adapt to sanctions. However, she warned that the country is bracing for a strengthening of penalties, citing the US Treasury's announcement of sanctions against banks facilitating deals for Russia's war machine. The European Union has also backed a 12th package of sanctions against Russia, putting pressure on the economy. Nabiullina emphasized the need for preparedness, despite the initial adaptation of businesses to the sanctions.

site_title: Unwrapping the power of giving
summary: A next-generation philanthropist shares five key lessons learned from her journey into philanthropy. Firstly, finding one's purpose takes patience and work, often requiring exploration and witnessing the impact of others. Secondly, good philanthropy goes beyond generosity, focusing on strategic, risk-taking, and systems thinking. Thirdly, valuing people and partnerships is crucial in building effective collaborations. Fourthly, philanthropy plays a significant role in discovery and experimentation, taking calculated risks to address complex issues. Lastly, finding like-minded communities to amplify impact is vital in accelerating a philanthropist's journey, highlighting the importance of collective action in creating meaningful change.

images.alt_text: Philanthropist Laurence Lien launches a new foundation to connect donors with non-profits in the region.

Temasek Trust's Desmond Kuek says PAA "will harness the strengths, ideas and best practices of members and partners to jointly pioneer philanthropic innovations, to realise our bold ambitions as an alliance to prime Asia as a force for good".
Venture philanthropy, like impact investing, uses investment capital to drive impact on multiple fronts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine Matheson, Mandarin Oriental, mm2 Asia, Abundance International
summary: Mandarin Oriental is selling its interests in its Paris hotel for 205 million euros. The sale proceeds will go towards the group's general development strategy. Jardine Matheson shares rose 0.1% after the news, while Mandarin Oriental shares remained flat. Meanwhile, mm2 Asia's chairman Melvin Ang invested S$6.1 million in the company's rights issue. These developments may impact the trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Philippine actions in South China Sea ‘extremely dangerous’: Chinese state media
summary: China's state media accused the Philippines of repeatedly infringing on China's territory in the South China Sea, spreading false information, and colluding with extraterritorial forces, causing harm to regional peace and stability. This comes amid heightened tensions between Beijing and Manila over a spate of run-ins in the sea, including a recent incident where China allegedly rammed a Philippine ship carrying the armed forces chief of staff. China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi warned of a resolute response if the dispute escalates, while the Philippines has bolstered military relations with Japan and the US, further straining ties.

images.alt_text: Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr announced the joint US-Philippine maritime and air patrols in a post on social media platform X. Above: A China Coast Guard ship near a Philippine Coast Guard vessel in the disputed Second Thomas Shoal in the South China Sea on Nov. 10.
A China Coast Guard ship moves past a Philippine Coast Guard vessel BRP Sindangan, in the disputed Second Thomas Shoal, in the South China Sea, on Nov 10, 2023.

site_title: China earthquake death toll rises to 149, two still missing after a week
summary: A magnitude 6.2 earthquake in China's remote northwestern region has killed at least 149 people, with two still missing after a week. The epicenter was in the provinces of Gansu and Qinghai, where over 200,000 homes were destroyed and 15,000 were on the brink of collapse. The quake displaced 145,000 people and injured 781, with 117 deaths reported in Gansu. Local authorities attribute the severity of the damage to the shallowness of the quake and poor construction of homes in the area.

images.alt_text: Epicentre is about 100 kilometres southwest of Gansu province’s capital, Lanzhou.

site_title: Debt capital market set to pick up in 2024, driven by strong Asian fundamentals
summary: The debt capital market is expected to pick up in 2024, driven by strong Asian fundamentals, particularly in Singapore and other regional countries. Demand for bonds remains strong due to higher-than-normal base interest rates set by the US Federal Reserve, and investors are seeking safe-haven assets amid market uncertainty. Market watchers expect more issuances from sovereigns, financial institutions, and corporates, with a focus on green, sustainable bonds, which are a "fast-growing segment" in the region.

images.alt_text: A growing part of what will keep firms here globally competitive is hinging on the companies’ readiness to adapt to new ESG regulations, even if they may not necessarily apply yet, observers said.
Advisory fees from completed mergers and acquisitions are down 41 per cent year on year to US$205.2 million.

site_title: South Korea fines global banks record 26.5 billion won for illegal naked short selling
summary: South Korea has fined two global investment banks, including BNP Paribas and HSBC Holdings, a record 26.5 billion won (S$27 million) for engaging in naked short selling, the nation's largest-ever penalty against the practice. The Securities and Futures Commission described the transactions as "intentional" and hurt market order and investor trust. The regulator will also investigate the banks and will release their names two months later. This decision follows a ban on short selling until June 2024 and previous fines on global hedge funds for similar violations.

images.alt_text: Korean banks slumped earlier this year after President Yoon Suk Yeol criticised them for engaging in a “money feast” at the expense of their customers.
Naked short selling is a practice that involves selling shares without borrowing them first.
Small business owners will get a cash refund to the tune of 90 per cent of the interest paid in excess of 4 per cent, up to a limit of 200 million won in loans for one year.

site_title: Bitcoin’s 160% rebound in 2023 is a gamble on ETF ‘demand shock’
summary: Bitcoin surged 160% in 2023, adding $530 billion to its market capitalization, as investors bet on the approval of a US Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) and the halving event in 2024, which is expected to curb supply growth. The approval of the ETF is considered a near-certain winner by crypto bulls, who see it as a catalyst for mainstream investment in the token. Despite the rally, the crypto market still faces challenges, including market depth issues and the ongoing recovery from the collapse of FTX.

images.alt_text: An unwelcome pest is how many financiers and regulators would describe the crypto industry. Criminals use cryptocurrencies to launder money. Terrorists use them to make payments. Hackers demand ransoms in bitcoin.
Unlike better-known NFT collections such as Bored Apes and CryptoPunks, inscriptions are minted directly on the blockchain through a protocol called Ordinals.

site_title: Morgan Stanley expects record Japan revenue as BOJ fuels trading
summary: Morgan Stanley expects to record its highest-ever income from Japan due to a trading boom fueled by the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) steps towards loosening its grip on bond yields. The firm's joint venture with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) is targeting to overtake Nomura Holdings as the top broker in the country. Morgan Stanley's CEO predicts a decade-long alliance with MUFG, with opportunities in Japan's asset management industry expected to be large. The trading boom sets the market apart from the rest of the world, with muted trader bonuses expected on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: The bank’s effort underscores the power shift underway in the lucrative business of providing debt financing to leveraged borrowers.
The Federal Reserve is looking into whether the bank has sufficient controls in place to prevent rich foreign customers from laundering money, the Wall Street Journal’s report added.
The bank had said earlier this year that it was cooperating with US regulators over investigations into its block-trading practices and providing authorities with information.

site_title: Ozempic maker set to build mega factory in Dublin
summary: Novo Nordisk, the maker of Ozempic and Wegovy, plans to build a 147,192 sqm mega factory in Dublin, creating up to 1,100 jobs. The €2 billion investment will be completed in 18-24 months and fully operational by 2026, addressing the company's manufacturing capacity issues due to soaring demand. The development will include filling and packaging facilities, warehouses, and laboratories, transforming Novo Nordisk into Europe's most valuable listed company.

site_title: Pope kicks off Christmas celebrations in shadow of wars
summary: Pope Francis kicked off Christmas celebrations on Sunday, Dec 24, amidst global conflicts, including Israel's war on Hamas and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. He called for peace, as children tracked Santa and revellers participated in various holiday activities worldwide. Meanwhile, global economic news included a slowdown in China's GDP growth and a decline in the UK economy.

images.alt_text: Palestinian girls at the Church of the Nativity, built on the site where Jesus is believed to have been born, in the West Bank city of Bethlehem.

site_title: Beijing records most hours of sub-zero temperatures in December since 1951
summary: Beijing has broken its record for most hours of sub-zero temperatures in December since 1951, with over 300 hours of below-freezing temperatures recorded since December 11. The city has suspended heat supply for most businesses except essential service providers, prioritizing residential heat usage. Several cities in Henan province, including Jiaozuo, Puyang, and Pingdingshan, have also suspended heat supply due to a heating supply crunch. Warm air is expected to flow from the north to south, lifting temperatures from the weekend.

images.alt_text: China's carbon emissions in the second quarter jumps 10 per cent on last year’s coronavirus-induced lull.
China has boosted its domestic soybean production significantly in the last two years by promoting more planting to reduce its reliance on overseas imports.

site_title: WealthBT: Positioning your portfolio for 2024 (Ep 33)
summary: WealthBT's podcast discusses positioning portfolios for 2024, as interest rates may reduce. Bond yields are attractive, offering returns above inflation, and value equities present opportunities. Geopolitical risk increases due to record elections in 2024. Balanced portfolios remain a viable option, and reinvesting cash is recommended. The podcast aims to protect and grow wealth for affluent individuals.

images.alt_text: Pre and post nuptials agreements are becoming more prevalent. Why and who really stands to gain?

Over the past five years, investors in energy transition have suffered a performance gap of 11.9 percentage points a year when cash inflows and outflows are taken into account, compared to a buy-and-hold strategy.
Mercer chief investment strategist Rich Nuzum says the window to invest profitably in a crisis has shortened from months during the 2008 global financial crisis to just days now.

site_title: Embarrassed by your cough? ‘Sick shaming’ leads to overuse of cold medicine
summary: The US sees a surge in cold and allergy medication sales, with upper-respiratory OTC medications rising 23% to $11.8 billion in the 52 weeks leading up to December. This trend is attributed to Americans feeling pressured to show up for work and social gatherings despite symptoms, leading to overuse of cold medicine. Experts warn that this can harm health, cause side effects, and prolong illnesses. The pandemic's normalization of working while sick has contributed to this phenomenon, with fewer people calling in sick and more employees feeling pressured to come to work despite symptoms.

images.alt_text: "Burnout" might feel like a dirty word, but like any afflication, we must name it in order to treat it.
There are several reasons we fear saying "I don't know" in the workplace setting, but they're worth examining to determine if we can find a safe context to do so.
The combination of greed and envy often leads to catastrophic consequences and severe negative psychological effects.
Almost half of Singaporeans openly admit that their mental health is negatively impacting their work productivity, according to research by Aon and TELUS Health.
From left: Nomura's Kelvin Ho, AIA Singapore's Wong Sze Keed and Dell's Ng Tian Beng.

site_title: Micron settles IP theft lawsuit amid push to repair Beijing ties
summary: Micron Technology has settled a global intellectual property (IP) theft lawsuit with Fujian Jinhua Integrated Circuit, a state-backed Chinese rival. The two companies will dismiss their complaints and end all lawsuits. This settlement comes amid efforts to mend ties with Beijing, following the Chinese government's May ban on Micron's chips from "critical infrastructure" due to cybersecurity concerns. The move may help Micron's business, which warned that about half of its sales tied to Chinese clients may be affected by the ban.

images.alt_text: Micron’s results reflect the beginning of a recovery in the memory market for memory and flash storage.
Micron makes DRAM chips and NAND flash memory chips, and competes with companies including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix.

site_title: Global air travel to surpass pre-Covid levels in 2024 as Asia-Pacific makes full recovery
summary: Global air travel is expected to surpass pre-Covid levels in 2024, driven by sustained demand and a full recovery in the Asia-Pacific region. Industry observers predict a banner year for airline profits, with SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong expecting capacity to reach 92% of pre-pandemic levels by December. However, persistent supply issues and thin profit margins may curb growth, posing obstacles to the industry's strong showing.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines originally flew non-stop between Singapore and New York (to be technically correct, the Manhattan-adjacent Newark) from 2004 to 2013, until rising oil costs grounded its gas-guzzling Airbus A340 jets.

site_title: 2024 likely to be a ‘tale of two halves’ for Brent
summary: The 2024 oil market is expected to be a "tale of two halves," with a cautious first half due to concerns over transit costs and halted supply in the Red Sea, and a stronger second half if demand growth and Opec+ supply cuts materialize. Despite low oil prices, investors should be cautious, as global demand is expected to remain flat and the strong US dollar could continue to weigh on oil prices. Brent oil prices are forecast to average around $90 a barrel in the second half, but this projection is vulnerable to downside risks, including Saudi Arabia's decision not to roll over its voluntary cuts or stricter US sanctions on Iran.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: ‘Beyond our borders’: Vietnam tech firm VNG takes on world’s best
summary: Vietnam's tech firm VNG, led by co-founder Le Hong Minh, is set to go public on the New York Stock Exchange with a listing expected to boost the company's global presence. As one of Vietnam's leading game publishers, VNG aims to expand its reach into Latin America and the Middle East. With a strong domestic market, the company's messaging platform Zalo has 75 million active users, surpassing Facebook. VNG has received funding from Chinese Internet giant Tencent and Singaporean state investor Temasek, and its revenue is dominated by gaming, with plans to build a large language model tailored to Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Singapore-South Korea joint fund invests US$2.3m in Vietnam proptech platform Rever

site_title: US dollar slips to 5-month low as US inflation cools
summary: The US dollar has hit a near five-month low due to data showing annual US inflation slowed further below 3% in November, cementing market expectations for a US interest rate cut next March. The dollar index edged down 0.08% to 101.7, after dipping to its lowest since late July. The Federal Reserve's dovish stance has boosted the case for the dollar to continue falling into 2024, despite strength in the US economy.

images.alt_text: The Swiss franc firms with the US dollar down as much as 0.3 per cent to 0.85355 francs, falling below the trough from July this year, and taking it to its weakest since January 2015.

site_title: China regulator to ‘earnestly study’ public concerns over draft video gaming rules
summary: China's National Press and Publication Administration has announced plans to "earnestly study" public concerns over draft video gaming rules, which aim to curb excessive spending and time spent on games. The draft rules, set to be released for public comment by January 22, 2024, would ban daily login rewards, first-time spending incentives, and consecutive spending limits. The move is part of efforts to promote the healthy development of the gaming industry, with the regulator seeking to improve the proposed rules after absorbing opinions from various stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Tencent (above) shares dropped more than 10 per cent and NetEase collapsed more than 20 per cent in reaction to proposals that would put limits on recharging in-game wallets and abolish features meant to increase gameplay.
Anime-style games from China such as miHoYo’s 'Genshin Impact' gained popularity and expanded revenue.

site_title: China’s Nio launches flagship EV to take on Maybach, Panamera
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, unveiled its flagship model, the ET9 executive sedan, featuring self-developed technologies such as semiconductors and large cylindrical battery cells. The car is positioned in the same class as Mercedes Benz's Maybach and Porsche's Panamera series, with an estimated price of 800,000 yuan (S$152,355) and expected to start delivery in the first quarter of 2025. Nio aims to increase appeal and improve profit margin in a consolidating market, amid a bruising price war and slowing car demand.

site_title: ClearMotion to supply smooth suspension tech for Nio’s ET9 EV
summary: US startup ClearMotion will supply its smooth suspension technology to Chinese EV maker Nio for its luxury sedan model, the ET9. The contract covers 750,000 cars over the lifetime of the model. ClearMotion's technology uses a combination of hardware and software to reduce motion inside the car by about 75% compared to existing technology. Nio plans to launch the ET9 in late 2024. ClearMotion aims to expand production to meet growing demand, with plans to raise more capital in the future.

images.alt_text: Upon completion of the deal, CYVN will own a 20.1 per cent stake in Nio, having subscribed for 294 million newly issued shares.

Nio, which currently competes with EVs offered by premium carmakers like BMW, and Mercedes-Benz at a price point above US$42,000 in China, is facing expanding losses as a price war started by Tesla weighed on its profitability.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of NIO seen on an EL6 car model is pictured at the NIO House, the showroom of the Chinese premium smart electric vehicle manufacture NIO Inc. in Berlin, Germany August 17, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse/File Photo

site_title: Singapore ESG indices slightly outpace STI in 2023, buoyed by renewables
summary: Singapore's ESG-focused stock indices outpaced the benchmark Straits Times Index in 2023, driven by the growth of renewable energy companies. The iEdge-OCBC Singapore Low Carbon Select 50 Capped Index and iEdge SG ESG Leaders Index returned 0.9% and 0.1% respectively, outperforming the STI's 0.6% drop. In 2024, renewable energy and sustainable aviation fuels are expected to remain key themes for ESG investors, with the Singapore government's carbon tax set to increase. Investors are also expected to monitor ESG-related regulations and the impact of climate transition plans on companies.

images.alt_text: A growing part of what will keep firms here globally competitive is hinging on the companies’ readiness to adapt to new ESG regulations, even if they may not necessarily apply yet, observers said.
Generic pictures of property landscape in Singapore.

site_title: 13 dead, 38 injured in explosion at Indonesia nickel plant
summary: At least 13 people, including eight Indonesians and five Chinese workers, were killed and 38 injured in an explosion at a nickel-processing plant in Indonesia's Central Sulawesi province. The blast occurred during repair work on a furnace, and an initial investigation found that a flammable liquid ignited, causing nearby oxygen tanks to explode. The incident is the latest in a series of safety concerns at the facility, which is owned by Indonesia Tsingshan Stainless Steel and operated by Tsingshan Holding Group.

images.alt_text: Billions of US dollars in investments have poured into the country to refine its nickel into batteries.

site_title: British billionaire Ratcliffe agrees deal to buy 25% of Manchester Utd
summary: British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe has agreed to buy a 25% stake in Manchester United for approximately $1.3 billion, aiming to return the club to the top of world football. Ratcliffe's INEOS company will take control of football operations, providing substantial funds for future investments in the outdated Old Trafford stadium. This deal marks Manchester United's first major ownership change since the Glazer family's takeover in 2005, with Ratcliffe vowing to restore the club's former glory.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: General view of the Manchester United logo ahead of the Europa League final Reuters / Phil Noble Livepic/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Google rejected Play Store fee changes due to impact on revenue, Epic lawsuit shows
summary: Google rejected proposed fee changes to its Play Store due to concerns about regulatory overreach, according to documents released as part of an Epic Games lawsuit. The company had considered charging a set fee per app, but estimated it could cost billions of dollars, and instead opted for a lower fee of 26% or 11% for developers who process payments themselves. This move mirrors a $700 million settlement announced last week with state attorneys general, and is seen as a step towards weakening app store rules amid growing pressure from regulators and lawmakers.

images.alt_text: Google faces other lawsuits challenging its search and digital advertising practices.

site_title: Challenges remain even as VCs ride out a tough year
summary: Venture capitalists in South-east Asia have faced a tough year, with exits falling to $1 billion across 44 transactions in 2023, down from $4.1 billion in 2022. Despite this, many VCs remain cautiously optimistic about 2024, with some expecting a recovery in the market. Key challenges include the lingering effect of the funding winter, lower valuations, and a lack of exits in local stock markets. However, some sectors, such as AI and healthcare, are expected to see increased investment opportunities. VCs are advising founders to focus on profitability and unit economics, and to be cautious about raising growth capital.

images.alt_text: In Indonesia, the number of Gen Z and millennial individuals now  stands at an astounding 145 million people, constituting 53.8 per cent of the  population. In the next decade, this demographic will enter their prime earning years.
Globally, PE and VC deal value and volumes are down year on year in both September and the entire third quarter.
Coins, stack, clock, money
Given valuation concerns and poor exit conditions, investors prefer early-stage over late-stage deals, according to Preqin.

China’s securities regulators publish draft rules that would require a qualified investor in PE and VC funds to put up at least three million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold in an effort to protect small investors.

site_title: Retailers dangle fewer discounts for inflation-weary shoppers
summary: US retailers are reducing discounts ahead of Christmas, with Macy's, Target, and Ulta Beauty cutting the number and size of price markdowns on key products from November 1 to December 1. Discounts fell from 49% to 46% at Macy's and from 10% to 5% at Ulta. Retailers aim to boost profits, as higher interest rates and financial pressures weigh on consumer spending, and shoppers are less likely to care about cost on Super Saturday, just two days before Christmas.

images.alt_text: Shoppers along the Magnificent Mile shopping district in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 15, 2023. US retail sales rose in July by more than forecast, suggesting consumers still have the wherewithal to sustain the economic expansion. Photographer: Jamie Kelter Davis/Bloomberg

site_title: S-Reits boost balance sheets ahead of financial year end
summary: Several Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have taken steps to boost their balance sheets ahead of the financial year end. Elite Commercial Reit raised £28 million through a preferential offering, Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust bought back €72.6 million in bonds, and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit and CapitaLand Ascott Trust divested properties to reduce debt and improve portfolio quality. These actions aim to keep gearing levels within the 40% psychological barrier, amid heightened investor attention on gearing levels and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit is among the top three performers in December for S-Reits with office properties in the US.

site_title: SocGen to sell stakes in Russian holdings to Potanin’s Rosbank
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) will sell stakes in Russian companies worth an estimated $75 million to Rosbank PJSC, a former local unit, allowing the French bank to complete its exit from Russia. The portfolio includes stakes in major companies such as Gazprom, Norilsk Nickel, Lukoil, and Rosneft. President Vladimir Putin approved an order allowing Rosbank to buy the stakes. The sale is a result of SocGen's previous sale of Rosbank to billionaire Vladimir Potanin last year.

images.alt_text: The potential sale of the German business comes as Barclays, the UK lender, is also seeking for a buyer for its German consumer-finance business

Societe Generale reported a 900 million-euro (S$1.32 billion) group net income for the three months-period ending in June, above the average analyst estimate compiled by the company of 670 million euros.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of Societe Generale is seen on the headquarters at the financial and business district of La Defense near Paris, France, February 4, 2020. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Flights delayed as Geneva airport workers go on strike
summary: Dozens of ground staff at Geneva airport went on strike on Dec 24 over a wage dispute with their employer, Dnata, causing delays to flights during the busy Christmas rush. The strike, which began at 4 am, affected around 80 strikers who handle about a fifth of the airport's traffic. Dnata has offered a 3% salary increase, but workers are demanding 5% and better working conditions. The strike is expected to continue until an agreement is reached, with flights delayed and some flights potentially landing at other airports.

images.alt_text: DHL Express expects the strike to garner “sympathy support” at various pickup and delivery locations across the US and that it is prepared to deploy replacement staff.

site_title: US wields risky bank sanctions in new bid to deny Putin cash
summary: The US has authorized secondary sanctions against Russian banks that facilitate deals with sanctioned entities, expanding its financial battle against President Vladimir Putin. The move aims to deny Russia the money it needs to wage war in Ukraine, despite concerns about unintended consequences and potential ripple effects. The decision comes as Republican lawmakers in Congress have refused to provide more military assistance for Ukraine, and Russia continues to press ahead with its war despite crippling sanctions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sergei Petrov, founder of Russian car dealer Rolf, speaks as he attends the Reuters Russia Investment Summit in Moscow, September 24, 2014.  REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: Warehouses shine on strong logistics demand; high rents to face resistance in 2024
summary: Singapore's industrial sector is expected to perform well in 2024, with warehouses shining as the bright spot due to strong demand from last-mile logistics and cold storage. Rents for warehouses are forecast to grow 6% year-over-year in 2023 and 5% in 2024. However, the business park segment is expected to underperform, with a flood of new supply and rising vacancy rates. Investment sales in industrial properties have been strong, with S$2.17 billion worth of transactions in 2023. The market may see some oversupply in 2024, but niche sectors such as self-storage and data centers are expected to remain attractive investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: JTC says overall prices of industrial space continue to rise in Q3.
Vibrant subsidiary disposing of warehouse for 29m yuan
The 8-storey development has been sold for S$81 million and will be use as a food factory, says Edmund Tie.

site_title: Actor Sean Penn’s charity lays off 28 in anticipation of US$20 million deficit
summary: Actor Sean Penn's charity, Core Response, is laying off 28 staff members, including 14 from its headquarters and 14 field employees, due to a US$20 million deficit for 2023. The layoffs come after a Businessweek investigation found concerns over the charity's financial management and lack of response to alleged sexual harassment. Core Response had grown rapidly during the pandemic, receiving US$30 million from billionaire Jack Dorsey, but has since restructured to address these issues and ensure its ongoing operations beyond 2024.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett, the world’s fifth-richest person is gradually giving away nearly all of the fortune he built at Omaha, Nebraska-based Berkshire, which he has run since 1965.

site_title: The Majurity Trust, URA shine a light on social issues for Marina Bay countdown
summary: The Majurity Trust and the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) partnered for the Marina Bay Singapore Countdown 2024, titled "Brightening Lives". Twenty-one students from five local educational institutions created artworks highlighting social issues such as elderly dementia, mental health, and employment, which will be projected onto iconic landmarks. The event aims to raise awareness and spark conversations on these topics, with the goal of improving lives in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Minister Desmond Lee (1st row, 4th from right), with representatives and volunteers from DBS and MSF, and ComLink+ families.

site_title: ‘God is under the rubble in Gaza’: Bethlehem’s subdued Christmas
summary: In Bethlehem, Christmas celebrations have been subdued due to Israel's war in Gaza. Typically, the city, seen as the birthplace of Jesus, is decorated with festive lights and music, but this year, churches have cancelled or toned down their festivities. A Lutheran church has created a creche with a baby Jesus wrapped in a keffiyeh, symbolizing the destruction in Gaza. The war has killed nearly 20,000 Palestinians, including children, and has paralysed the tourism sector, which normally brings in 1.5 million foreign tourists annually.

images.alt_text: Saudi king reaffirms support for Palestinian state
In Jerusalem's Old City, conflict means buyer and seller beware

site_title: Toyota halts some South-east Asia exports on Daihatsu safety scandal
summary: Toyota has halted shipments of six car models in South-east Asian countries due to a safety scandal involving its subsidiary Daihatsu Motor. The models, including Veloz and Avanza, were affected in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Cambodia, making up about 5% of Toyota's Asian production. Toyota is working with authorities to restart shipments and has suspended Daihatsu's Japan plants amid the fallout from an investigation that found Daihatsu did not properly test vehicles for collision safety.

site_title: US claims huge chunk of seabed amid strategic push for resources
summary: The US has extended its claims on the ocean floor by an area twice the size of California, securing rights to potentially resource-rich seabeds in the Arctic and Bering Sea. The claims, which cover about 1 million square km, are aimed at boosting access to critical minerals needed for electric vehicle batteries and renewable energy projects. The move has raised concerns about the potential impact on the fragile Arctic environment and may reduce the likelihood of the US joining the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines in South Sulawesi, Indonesia. Targets committed to at the COP28 climate summit include tripling global renewable-energy capacity by 2030.

site_title: Family split at LG, a South Korean giant, tests corporate succession
summary: A South Korean lawsuit challenges the patriarchal tradition at LG, a $10 billion conglomerate, by pitting the matriarch and her two daughters against the adopted male heir, Koo Kwang-mo. The women claim they were deceived into an agreement that left 75% of their late father's $1.5 billion fortune to Kwang-mo, while the widow and daughters were entitled to one-third and one-half, respectively. The lawsuit seeks to redistribute the estate according to the law, and the women are not seeking control of LG. The case raises questions about the company's succession and the treatment of female family members.

images.alt_text: LG Display warns of panel price weakness as wearables boost Q4 profit
LG Electronics Q4 profit plunges 80% as rivals crowd TV business

site_title: LA’s third-tallest tower sells for 45% below 2014 price
summary: The Aon Center, Los Angeles' third-tallest tower, sold for $147.8 million, 45% below its 2014 purchase price of $268.5 million. The sale reflects the city's struggling office market, with high vacancies and financing costs. Downtown LA's office space availability rate reached 30%, and rents were 40% lower than in more desirable areas. The sale is the largest office deal in downtown LA this year, with the new owners positioning the building to attract tenants despite the challenges.

images.alt_text: epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Rising Indonesia presidential candidate pledges change from Widodo era
summary: Indonesian presidential candidate Anies Baswedan, a former Jakarta governor, is promising change in his campaign slogan, vowing to deliver economic development felt by everyone, not just the elite. He's in a three-way battle ahead of February's vote, with polls suggesting a potential second-round runoff. Baswedan, 54, is one of the leading candidates in the world's third-largest democracy and fourth most populous nation.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has pledged to boost GDP growth to 5.2 per cent in 2024.

site_title: Artists use tech weapons against AI copycats
summary: Artists are fighting back against AI copycats by using software that makes their digital work appear dramatically different to AI models. Glaze, created by researchers at the University of Chicago, tweaks pixels to outsmart AI training, and has been downloaded over 1.6 million times. Other defenses, such as Kudurru and AntiFake, are being developed to block AI image and voice harvesting. These tools aim to protect human creators from invasive and abusive AI models, and researchers hope to push developers towards using consent and payment for data used in AI training.

images.alt_text: Lim Wenhui generates quirky images such as this using AI tools. She has parlayed her skills into a successful side hustle.

site_title: As office workers make their return, so does the lowly cubicle
summary: Cubicles, once considered a symbol of dehumanization, are experiencing a resurgence in popularity as office workers return to the office after the pandemic. High demand has made cubicles a $6.3 billion market, expected to grow to $8.3 billion by 2028. Design experts say modern cubicles prioritize comfort, relaxation, and privacy, with features like sound-masking panels and adjustable walls. Companies like Grassi are reconfiguring their offices to include hybrid spaces, combining cubicles with open collaborative areas. Employees are also taking ownership of their workspaces, decorating their cubicles with personal touches, reflecting a shift towards prioritizing comfort and well-being in the workplace.

images.alt_text: Many Americans are under pressure to show up for work and social gatherings; yet even the hint of a sniffle can be enough to brand someone an outcast.

site_title: More competition in the venture debt space as banks enter the arena
summary: Banks are entering the venture debt space in South-east Asia, with HSBC partnering with early-stage incubator Antler, and other banks such as OCBC and DBS launching their own venture debt offerings. This move aims to support startups and provide access to banking services, including venture debt, to help them grow. The banks' entry is seen as a boost to the venture debt market, which has gained popularity among startups in recent years. The partnerships also offer startups a more flexible financing option, with the potential to issue redeemable convertible preference shares as collateral.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro, Hong Kong dollar, U.S. dollar, Japanese yen, British pound and Chinese 100-yuan banknotes are seen in a picture illustration shot January 21, 2016. REUTERS/Jason Lee/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: ‘Revenge spending’ drives ballooning US credit card balances
summary: US credit card balances have surged, increasing by 4.7% to $48 billion in the third quarter of 2023, pushing the total to $1.08 trillion, the highest on record since 2003. Delinquency rates are slightly above pre-pandemic levels, and experts warn of a "silent recession" as Americans struggle to pay bills. The rise of buy now, pay later services and high interest rates are contributing to the issue, with an estimated 40% of Americans having drained their pandemic savings to cover expenses.

images.alt_text: American Express Co., Mastercard Inc. and Visa Inc. credit cards are displayed over bank notes for a photo illustration at the Fog Hill Market in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, July 20, 2011. Consumers may be relying more on their credit cards to pay for necessities like food and fuel, an indication that inflation is impacting spending habits. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Prada is expanding its NYC presence with pair of building purchases
summary: Prada has acquired two buildings on New York's Fifth Avenue, including its flagship store, for a combined US$835 million. The Italian fashion brand cited high strategic value for the properties amid a surge in residential, hospitality, and retail investments in the neighborhood. Despite a decline in property values and rising borrowing costs, Prada is expanding its NYC presence. The acquisitions are part of the brand's efforts to maintain its luxury market share, with retail sales in the US staying strong despite a global slowdown in demand for luxury goods.

images.alt_text: Prada will have bigger stores, more local products and more events in China, according to Gianfranco D’Attis, Prada CEO .
Prada says the property’s location offers high strategic value after an influx of residential, hospitality and retail investments in the neighbourhood.

site_title: Apple explores AI deals with news publishers
summary: Apple is exploring deals with major news publishers to license their archives for use in developing generative artificial intelligence (AI) systems. The negotiations, worth at least $50 million, involve publishers such as Vogue, NBC News, and People. Apple aims to catch up with rivals like Microsoft, OpenAI, and Google, but some publishers are concerned about the terms and potential legal liabilities. The deal could change the way people work and generate billions in sales, but Apple's intentions for applying generative AI to the news industry remain unclear.

images.alt_text: An Apple store in New York, US, on Friday, June 30, 2023. The blowout rally in tech megacaps gained further traction on Friday, with the Nasdaq 100 poised to notch a record first-half of a year and Apple Inc. hitting the $3 trillion milestone. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg via Getty Images
Sales will continue at Apple’s international online and in-person stores.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust director acquires more units
summary: NetLink NBN Trust director Tong Yew Heng acquired 100,000 units of the trust at S$0.835 per unit, increasing his direct interest to 750,000 units. Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with S$217 million of net institutional outflow. Leading net institutional outflows were Singtel, Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust. In contrast, Wilmar International, OCBC, DBS, and Keppel DC Reit led net institutional inflows. NetLink's revenue increased 2.9% in H1 FY24, driven by higher connections and installation-related revenue.

images.alt_text: epa10887181 A sales promotion woman holds a dress as she live-streams on an e-commerce platform at a shop in Depok, Indonesia, 28 September 2023. The Indonesian government announced a new regulation that officially bans social media sites such as TikTok and Instagram from selling goods and services directly, amid complaints from small and medium business traders, who lack buyers due to goods on social media being sold much cheaper. The Indonesian Trade Minister Zulkifli Hasan explained that social media such as TikTok and Instagram can only promote goods or services.  EPA-EFE/ADI WEDA

site_title: Supreme Court refuses to fast-track Trump immunity clash
summary: The US Supreme Court has refused to immediately decide whether former President Donald Trump is immune from prosecution for seeking to overturn his 2020 election loss. A federal appeals court will now review Trump's appeal of a ruling rejecting his claim of immunity, with a decision expected soon. The decision leaves key questions about Trump's legal fate open ahead of the 2024 primary election.

images.alt_text: The Colorado ruling is the first to say that Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election results render him ineligible to run for president again.

site_title: China identifies second set of projects in 1 trillion yuan spending plan
summary: China's top planning body has identified 9,600 public investment projects worth over 560 billion yuan as part of its one trillion yuan spending plan. The projects include flood control and disaster relief programs, which will improve the country's flood control system, emergency response mechanism, and disaster relief capabilities. The plan aims to boost the economy, which has been struggling with tepid consumer demand, weak exports, and a deepening real estate crisis. The additional bond issuance will widen China's 2023 budget deficit ratio to around 3.8%.

images.alt_text: China's carbon emissions in the second quarter jumps 10 per cent on last year’s coronavirus-induced lull.

site_title: mm2 Asia chairman subscribes for S$6.1 million worth of rights shares
summary: MM2 Asia chairman Melvin Ang has subscribed for S$6.1 million worth of rights shares at S$0.02 per share, following a renounceable rights issue approved by shareholders at an EGM on Dec 22. Ang intends to fully subscribe for over 307 million rights shares. The company plans to use the raised funds to position for future growth, including deleveraging its financial position and funding growth opportunities in media and entertainment in Asia. The issue was oversubscribed, with 99.77% of shareholders voting in favor.

images.alt_text: Broker's take: Maybank Kim Eng downgrades mm2 Asia to 'hold' with market optimism priced in
mm2 Asia posts 7.1% drop in Q4 earnings; DBS upgrades rating to 'buy' as value emerges

site_title: Paris Olympics river closure could sow harvest chaos, grain industry says
summary: The Paris region's planned river Seine closure for the 2024 Olympics could disrupt grain transport, affecting EU's top grain exporter. Intercereales, a grain industry group, warns of potential losses of 500 million euros due to the closure, which would impact barge traffic and grain shipments. The industry has requested special permission for grain barges to use the Seine during the closure, and the prefect's office has agreed to study solutions to minimize disruption.

images.alt_text: LVMH’s sponsorship includes its top fashion brands Louis Vuitton and Dior, as well as Moet Hennessy champagne and spirits labels and jeweller Chaumet, which will design medals for the event.

site_title: Shell, Trinidad’s NGC get 30-year licence to produce gas in Venezuela
summary: Shell and Trinidad's National Gas Company (NGC) have secured a 30-year licence to produce gas in Venezuela, following a US authorisation granted in January. The licence allows for an initial output of 185 million cubic feet per day of gas to be sent to Trinidad for producing liquefied natural gas (LNG) and petrochemicals. This deal could mark Venezuela's first exports of its vast offshore gas reserves, as the country seeks to monetize its gas reserves to complement its revenue from crude and fuel exports.

images.alt_text: Shell has employed about 93,000 globally on a full and part-time basis at the end of 2022.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James//File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James//File Photo
Shell will cut 200 jobs in 2024 and has placed another 130 positions under review as part of a drive to reduce the headcount in the unit.

site_title: Wall Street wins bid to keep non-compete clauses in New York
summary: New York Governor Kathy Hochul has vetoed a bill to ban employee non-compete clauses, following intense pressure from Wall Street, hospitals, and business groups. The legislation, which would have barred employers from restricting employees from obtaining new jobs, was passed by state lawmakers in June but was opposed by industry groups. Hochul's veto decision allows non-compete clauses to continue in contracts for employees earning over $250,000 per year. The move maintains New York as the second-most populous state to permit non-compete clauses, joining California.

images.alt_text: Though the claims data is volatile around this time of the year, it remains consistent with a fairly healthy labour market in the US, which is expected to keep the economy from recession next year.

site_title: 'Urban mining' offers green solution to old solar panels
summary: The world is facing a new pollution problem as the first wave of solar panels installed over the past few decades reaches the end of its expected lifespan of 30 years. To address this issue, companies like We Recycle Solar are adopting "urban mining" techniques to recover valuable materials such as silver, copper, aluminum, glass, and silicone from old solar panels. These recovered materials can be reused in new solar panels, reducing waste and the need for new raw materials. The process has shown a high recovery rate of up to 99% and has the potential to provide a sustainable solution to the growing problem of electronic waste.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bronze seal for the Department of the Treasury is shown at the U.S. Treasury building in Washington, U.S., Jan. 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo

site_title: Actor Charlie Sheen attacked in his Malibu home, suspect arrested
summary: Actor Charlie Sheen, 58, was attacked at his Malibu home on December 22, with suspect Electra Schrock, 47, arrested and charged with assault, burglary, and a deadly weapon. Schrock, a neighbor, allegedly forced her way into Sheen's home and attacked him when he opened the door. Sheen was seen by paramedics but not taken to a hospital. This incident is reportedly not the first confrontation between the neighbors, with previous incidents including a sticky liquid being squirted on Sheen's car.

images.alt_text: Matthew Perry (third from left), who played Chandler Bing on the hit TV sitcom Friends from 1994 to 2004, died at the age of 54, having been found unconscious in a swimming pool at his house in Los Angeles in October.

site_title: OpenAI in talks to raise new funding at US$100 billion valuation
summary: OpenAI is in talks to raise new funding at a valuation of $100 billion or more, cementing its position as one of the world's most valuable startups. The company, behind the popular chatbot ChatGPT, has been in discussions with investors for a fresh round of funding. This would make OpenAI the second-most valuable US startup, behind Elon Musk's Space Exploration Technologies. The company is also set to complete a separate tender offer in January, allowing employees to sell shares at a valuation of $86 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Microsoft-backed OpenAI will only deploy its latest technology if it is deemed safe in specific areas such as cybersecurity and nuclear threats.

site_title: US new home sales unexpectedly slump to a one-year low
summary: US new home sales unexpectedly fell to a one-year low in November, decreasing 12.2% to 590,000 annual pace. This decline, led by a sharp drop in the South, suggests a temporary setback for the housing market, which is otherwise on the mend despite recent reports of a six-month high in housing starts and a pickup in homebuilder sentiment.

images.alt_text: Existing home sales rise 0.8 per cent to an annual rate of 3.82 million, seasonally adjusted, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage falls 24 basis points in the week ended Dec 15.
As mortgage rates rise, builders have been forced to cut prices since the summer in an effort to boost affordability.
Many homeowners are unwilling to sell, in part because that means letting go of the cheap mortgages they locked in during the pandemic.
Investment in residential construction shot up 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Oil eases ahead of Christmas break on possible future Angola output increase
summary: Oil prices eased ahead of the Christmas break due to expectations of an increase in Angola's oil output after leaving Opec. Brent futures fell 0.4% to $79.07 a barrel, while US WTI crude fell 0.5% to $73.56 a barrel. The easing was partly due to lower interest rates cutting consumer borrowing costs and boosting economic growth and demand for oil. However, concerns over Houthi ship attacks in the Red Sea and their potential impact on supply costs kept prices up.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down 31 US cents at US$79.39 a barrel.

site_title: Record number of pro golfers earned US$1 million in 2023
summary: A record number of 188 male golfers earned at least US$1 million in the 2022-23 season, driven by the introduction of higher purses by the PGA Tour and LIV Golf. The PGA Tour's designated events, including a US$4.5 million payday for winning The Players Championship, helped Scottie Scheffler break his own single-season record. LIV Golf's second season concluded with Talor Gooch earning US$35.3 million, including an US$18 million bonus. The influx of cash has increased the number of golfers reaching the US$1 million mark, with all 49 LIV Golf members earning more than US$1 million.

site_title: Carnival’s credit rating boosted by S&P after quarterly results
summary: Carnival's credit rating was upgraded two notches to "BB-" by S&P Global Ratings, following the company's better-than-expected quarterly results, which included a 40% jump in revenue and operating income. The upgrade puts Carnival on par with competitor Royal Caribbean Cruises and is a step towards returning to investment-grade status. Carnival expects revenue growth to drive increases in adjusted free cash flow, which will help pay down debt and improve its leverage ratio.

images.alt_text: Travellers are looking to cruises in 2024 because they are still cheaper than land-based alternatives.

site_title: Rising consumer sentiment gives White House confidence ahead of 2024
summary: The US economy shows signs of improvement, with inflation slowing to a milestone level and consumer confidence rising. Gasoline costs have fallen, mortgage rates have receded, and supply-chain snarls have mostly abated. Despite this, voters give President Joe Biden little credit for his economic leadership, with a recent poll showing he trails Republican frontrunner Donald Trump in trust. The White House sees this as an opportunity to turn a liability into an asset, with aides arguing that conditions have improved for some Americans, despite feelings of uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Colorado ruling is the first to say that Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election results render him ineligible to run for president again.

site_title: Twitter violated contract by failing to pay millions in bonuses, US judge rules
summary: A US federal judge ruled that Twitter (now called X) violated a contract by failing to pay millions of dollars in bonuses to employees. Mark Schobinger, a former Twitter executive, sued the company after it promised 50% of his 2022 target bonuses but never made the payments. The judge ruled that the oral promise was a binding contract under California law and that Twitter's refusal to pay the bonuses constituted a breach of contract. This ruling comes as X faces numerous lawsuits from former employees and executives since Elon Musk's acquisition of the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The new logo of Twitter is seen in this illustration taken, July 24, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: BMW’s three best cars of 2023 are…
summary: BMW has released three of its best cars in Singapore for 2023: the 520i, i7 M70, and M2 Coupe. The 520i is a comfortable and modern sedan with a hybrid powertrain, while the i7 M70 is the most powerful BMW, boasting 660 horsepower. The M2 Coupe, a compact and playful car, offers a unique driving experience with its turbocharged engine and manual gearbox. The i7 M70 is the most luxurious and opulent, but its high price tag and size may be a drawback. The M2 Coupe, on the other hand, is a more affordable option that still packs a punch.

images.alt_text: The Model Y became the world’s best-selling car (of any kind) in the first quarter of this year.
2023 Tesla Model 3 review: Not half better

site_title: Man City cruise to first Club World Cup triumph
summary: Manchester City won the Club World Cup for the first time, defeating Fluminense 4-0 in the final. The victory marked City's fifth trophy of 2023, following their Champions League, Premier League, and FA Cup wins. City's coach Pep Guardiola made history as the first to win the Club World Cup four times with three different clubs. Julian Alvarez scored the fastest goal in a Club World Cup final, and Phil Foden and Alvarez added to the scoring in the final 20 minutes.

images.alt_text: Fifa and Uefa abuse their dominant position by forbidding clubs to compete in a European Super League (ESL), according to the EU’s top court ruling.

site_title: Canada's economy stalled again in October but likely up 0.1% in November
summary: Canada's economy stagnated in October, but is expected to grow 0.1% in November, according to Statistics Canada. The decline was offset by gains in retail trade and mining sectors, with retail trade experiencing its largest growth rate since January. The Bank of Canada's rate hikes have impacted the economy, but money markets still see a chance of a rate cut in January or March. The central bank expects growth to remain weak for a few quarters, and inflation is expected to cool to 2.5% by end-2024.

images.alt_text: Receipts for retailers are flat last month, according to an advance estimate from Statistics Canada.
Canada's economy avoids slipping into a technical recession – defined as two consecutive quarter-on-quarter contractions.
