site_title: Lionsgate to spin off studio business in US$4.6-billion Spac deal
summary: Lionsgate is spinning off its US$4.6 billion studio business in a deal with special purpose-acquisition company (Spac) Screaming Eagle Acquisition, valuing the business behind popular franchises like "Hunger Games" and "John Wick." The deal is expected to deliver US$350 million in gross proceeds to Lionsgate, with the new company expected to list in the spring of 2024. The studio unit has seen box-office success this year, with revenue rising 21% to US$790 million in the last reported quarter, despite concerns about the industry outlook following dual Hollywood strikes.

images.alt_text: Deadpool 3 release date moved from May 2024 to July 2024.
Pegasus Asia is reportedly expected to release its announcement by Dec 22, while Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition's will be released next week.
The film is a prequel, with Chalamet (left) as a younger version of Roald Dahl’s famous chocolatier Willy Wonka, a character first played by Gene Wilder and then Johnny Depp.

site_title: US annual inflation slows further below 3% in November
summary: US inflation slowed further below 3% in November, with the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index increasing 2.6% in the 12 months through November. This marks the first time the annual PCE price index was below 3% since March 2021. Consumer spending, accounting for over two-thirds of US economic activity, increased 0.2% last month. The slowing inflation rate may cement expectations for an interest rate cut next March.

images.alt_text: Fed chair Jerome Powell and his colleagues are now set to cut interest rates “earlier and faster,” beginning in March.

site_title: US: Wall Street turns negative ahead of long holiday weekend
summary: US stocks reversed gains on Friday ahead of the Christmas holiday weekend, turning negative after an initial rally on cooler-than-expected inflation data. The S&P 500 is on track for its eighth consecutive weekly gain, its longest streak since 2017. Small caps outperformed the broader market, with the Russell 2000 up 0.6%. Investors are taking a breather before the long weekend, digesting data that firmed bets for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in the new year.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 55.08 points, or 0.15 per cent, at the open to 37,349.27.

site_title: US unveils clean hydrogen plan, nuclear power role uncertain
summary: The US has proposed rules for low-carbon hydrogen production, offering tax credits to companies that produce hydrogen using clean energy sources like wind, solar, or nuclear power. The credit, ranging from 60 cents to $3 per kilogram, will be based on life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions from the power source. However, the administration is seeking feedback on how nuclear power can benefit, leaving the nuclear industry uncertain about its role in producing hydrogen. The proposal aims to reduce emissions and fight climate change by fueling heavy industry and transportation.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (left) and South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol will announce the Hydrogen Ammonia Global Value Chain on Nov 17.
Education and government policy are essential to increase adoption of sustainable technologies, Emerging Enterprise finalists say.
The Biden administration is throwing its weight behind hydrogen and the hubs – broad networks of hydrogen producers and consumers spanning multiple states – as part of its net-zero goal.

President Joe Biden during a tour of the Tioga Marine Terminal at the Port of Philadelphia on Oct 13. The Biden administration announced plans on Friday to award up to US$7 billion to create seven regional hubs around the country.

site_title: AnAn claims ‘balance’ despite chairman acting as half of key management team without CEO
summary: AnAn International claims to maintain a balance of power and accountability, despite its chairman, Zang Jian Jun, being the sole key management personnel alongside CFO Shu Kwan Fong. The company's former CEO, Zhao Guang Ming, resigned in 2018 to focus on personal career development. The board of directors, comprising three independent directors, actively participates in meetings and reviews major decisions made by Zang, ensuring independent decision-making. AnAn will consider appointing a lead independent director to align with corporate governance code standards.

images.alt_text: AnAn unit proposes acquisition of French petrol products distributor for 4m euros

site_title: Mandarin Oriental signs option to sell Paris hotel for 205 million euros
summary: Mandarin Oriental International has signed an option to sell its interests in Mandarin Oriental, Paris for 205 million euros, with the sale proceeds going towards the group's general development strategy. The luxury hotel, which opened in 2011, is one of the leading hotels in the French capital.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

site_title: Putin seizes control of Russia's biggest car dealership
summary: Vladimir Putin has placed Russia's largest car dealership, Rolf, under temporary state management. The move, driven by commercial logic, has been met with skepticism by its founder, Sergei Petrov, who questions the country's investment landscape. The seizure is the latest in a series of Western-owned assets taken control of by Moscow in response to sanctions. The decision raises concerns about Russia's attractiveness to foreign investors, particularly from Asia.

images.alt_text: “The General Court dismisses the action brought by Mr Abramovich, thereby upholding the restrictive measures taken against him,” The EU court says in its ruling.

site_title: ’Twas the Night Before Christmas turns 200 this year
summary: Clement Clarke Moore's poem "A Visit from St Nicholas," also known as "'Twas the Night Before Christmas," is celebrating its 200th anniversary. Published in 1823, the poem helped transform an unruly winter festival for adults into a peaceful domestic holiday focused on gift-giving and children. Moore's poem cemented the shift, popularizing the idea of Santa Claus coming on Christmas Eve and introducing eight reindeer with names like Dasher and Dancer. The poem has had a lasting impact on modern Christmas customs, making it the foundational writer of Christmas in the 19th century.

images.alt_text: The Christmas Tree Galaxy Cluster has stars that flicker over days or months, like the lights on a Christmas tree.
“I would’ve never thought in my wildest dreams that Rockin’ would be my signature song,” Brenda Lee says in a recent interview.

site_title: China’s Xiaohongshu on track for 2023 net profit
summary: China's Xiaohongshu, a social platform similar to Instagram, is on track to book a net profit of $500 million in 2023, according to people familiar with the matter. The e-commerce venture's strong performance could lead to a new funding round or initial public offering (IPO), backed by heavyweight investors including Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings. This success contrasts with Western peers, such as Meta's Instagram, which have struggled to convert traffic into online commerce revenue. Xiaohongshu's 200 million monthly users have been successfully converted into customers through its influencer marketing strategy and rich content.

images.alt_text: CHINESE social e-commerce app Xiaohongshu, known as China's answer to Instagram, has kicked off a round of layoffs, a source familiar with the matter said, as the company joined other Internet firms in retrenching.

site_title: Transport authorities investigating ERP overcharging incident at Grab
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Public Transport Council (PTC) are investigating an ERP overcharging incident on Grab's ride-hailing platform, affecting 60,787 trips from Nov 20 to Dec 4. Outdated ERP rates were applied, resulting in excess charges for 40,431 passengers, with charges ranging from S$1 to S$3. Grab has corrected the error, reimbursed affected passengers, and assured that action has been taken. LTA and PTC emphasized the importance of accurate fares and appreciate public assistance in reporting overcharging instances.

images.alt_text: A free market may be able to determine the most efficient ratio of ride-hailing and shared-car services in the market, but there are other considerations to the pricing of private transportation.
A tough ask to make richer errant motorists pay more for traffic offences
Singapore-based ride-hailing app Ryde is scrapping driver commission charges from Jan 2, 2024.

site_title: Saudi king’s widow wins UK suit for ‘Billionaire’s Row’ mansion
summary: A UK judge ruled in favor of King Fahd's widow, Al Jawharah Bint Ibrahim Abdulaziz Al Ibrahim, in a lawsuit over a London mansion on Billionaire's Row. The Liechtenstein-based Asturion Foundation, established by the late king, claimed to control assets including Kenstead Hall, but the judge rejected their claim, giving the widow control of the house worth "tens of millions" of pounds. The ruling provides a rare glimpse into the Saudi royal family's inheritance dispute, which includes other properties in France, Germany, and Spain.

images.alt_text: The US$63 billion project at Diriyah is set to feature dozens of hotels and thousands of homes.

site_title: Apac real estate outlook 2024: new cycle, sustained fundamentals
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate markets are expected to maintain resilience in 2024, driven by sustained fundamentals and long-term structural strengths. Despite global challenges, the region is poised to outperform, with growth in over two-thirds of major economies expected to remain stable or exceed 2023 levels. Key themes in 2024 include a focus on ESG and quality in the office market, synchronisation in prices and rental growth, opportunities in private credit, and a potential recovery in China's real estate market.

images.alt_text: In terms of investment volumes, Singapore has recorded US$7.53 billion so far this year, while Hong Kong’s total is US$5.27 billion.
Commercial real estate, which exhibits income growth potential, diversification benefits and relative stability, will see  strengthened interest.

site_title: German home prices tumble amid property rout
summary: Germany's residential property prices have dropped 10.2% in the third quarter from a year earlier, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of declines and the largest since 2000. The decline is attributed to a sharp rise in interest rates and costs, leading to insolvency among developers and a freeze in deals. The property sector's boom, fueled by low interest rates and strong demand, has burst, with single-family home prices falling 12.7% and apartment prices dropping 9.1%. This is the biggest property crisis in decades in Germany, Europe's largest economy.

images.alt_text: In November, 49.1 per cent of developers say they are suffering from a lack of new orders, up from 48.7 per cent in the previous month.

site_title: Toyota’s Daihatsu to halt domestic production until end-Jan: Nikkei
summary: Daihatsu Motor, a unit of Toyota, will halt domestic production until the end of January due to safety issues found in 64 models, including 24 sold under the Toyota brand. The company has resumed shipments from its Indonesian subsidiary, Astra Daihatsu Motor. Daihatsu is still discussing the matter internally and has not cited sources for the decision.

site_title: Chasen Holdings accepts offer to buy stake in its subsidiaries for S$67.4 million
summary: Chasen Holdings has accepted an offer to buy a 72% stake in its subsidiaries for S$67.4 million, with the sale price nearly four times its current market capitalization. The buyer is an international company, but details were not disclosed. The deal is subject to final agreements and necessary approvals, and Chasen expects to receive S$59.3 million on a cash-free, debt-free basis. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.047 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Asean growth story holds potential for some SGX stocks
New passenger drone's like a flight simulator that you can ride in

site_title: US durable goods orders surge in November on aircraft
summary: US durable goods orders surged 5.4% in November, driven by a 80.1% increase in civilian aircraft orders, with Boeing receiving 114 orders for civilian aircraft. Transportation equipment orders rebounded 15.3% and motor vehicle and parts orders rose 2.8%. However, business spending on equipment appeared lacklustre amid higher borrowing costs, and manufacturing activity remains tepid despite easing financial conditions.

images.alt_text: Shoppers along the Magnificent Mile shopping district in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 15, 2023. While prices remain higher overall, savings and higher wages have allowed consumers to maintain spending.

site_title: Lost goods at Abundance International unit could impact FY23 performance, company discloses
summary: Abundance International reported that one of its indirect wholly-owned subsidiaries lost goods valued at 3.3 million yuan (S$620,000) of acetic acid stored at a facility in Jiangsu province. If the unit cannot recover the full value, the company's FY23 performance may be impacted. The subsidiary is seeking legal advice and plans to recover the value and claim for damages, with updates to be provided to shareholders.

images.alt_text: A man walks in front of the Singapore Exchange building (SGX) on July 21, 2022.
Abundance International widens fiscal 2018 loss to US$743,000

site_title: From Taylor Swift concerts to Michelin meals, an expats’ guide to Asia-Pacific hubs
summary: Tokyo tops a Bloomberg analysis of 10 metrics, including potential salary increase, rent, and education costs, as the best expat destination in the Asia-Pacific region. Hong Kong comes in second, followed by Shanghai and Sydney. Singapore ranks fifth, despite being named the world's most expensive city due to an influx of foreign workers. The Japanese capital offers relatively low international school fees and steady rents, making it an attractive option for expats.

site_title: Europe: Shares end slightly higher ahead of Christmas holiday
summary: European stocks edged up 0.1% on Friday, marking their sixth consecutive week of gains, ahead of the Christmas holiday weekend. Softer-than-expected US inflation data boosted financial market expectations of an interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve next March, while traders are betting on rate cuts by the European Central Bank early next year despite attempts to manage those expectations. The Stoxx 600 index is set to end 2023 with a 12.4% jump.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany March 16, 2023. REUTERS/Heiko Becker//File Photo

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher after soft inflation data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, Dec 22, after a key inflation reading came in softer than expected, boosting investor optimism for a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut next year. The S&P 500 rose 7.17 points, or 0.15%, to 4,753.92, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 42.31 points, or 0.28%, to 15,006.18. In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 55.08 points, or 0.15%, to 37,349.27.

site_title: Surge in outbound travel, slowing wage growth hurting small retailers’ festive sales
summary: Singapore's small retailers are experiencing lower festive sales due to increased outbound travel and a strong Singapore dollar, which makes local consumers more likely to spend abroad. Typically, sales rise from October to December, but this year, EPOS clients' sales dropped 16.3% in October and 22.1% in November. A sentiment poll found 48 out of 58 retailers reported below pre-pandemic sales levels. Cooling wage growth and business expectations have also contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending may grow more slowly in 2024 as post-Covid exuberance dies out.
Though more Singapore residents have been heading abroad, restaurants and hotels foresee demand ramping up towards year-end.
The total retail sales value in October was S$4 billion, of which online sales accounted for 13.1 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation growth slows to 1.5% in November, beating economists’ forecast
summary: Malaysia's inflation growth slowed to 1.5% in November, beating economists' forecast of 1.7%. This is the third consecutive month of easing inflation, with food prices growing at 2.6% and housing, water, electricity, gas and other fuels rising 1.7%. Economists expect the government to implement targeted subsidies, particularly on fuel, which may influence inflation growth. Experts predict the inflation rate will remain below 2% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s inflation rate continued to moderate due to higher base last year and slower growth on food prices.

site_title: The wunderkind of watchmaking
summary: Kosovo-born watchmaker Rexhep Rexhepi, 36, has gained rock-star status in the watchmaking industry with his exquisite, hand-crafted timepieces. His brand, AKRIVIA, produces around 40 watches annually, with a waiting list that rivals high-end brands like FP Journe and Philippe Dufour. Rexhepi's watches have won prestigious awards, including the 2018 Grand Prix de Horlogerie de Geneve for the men's best watch. He aims to achieve 100% in-house movement production within a year and is driven by a desire to push the boundaries of classical watchmaking, inspired by 18th-century watchmakers like Abraham-Louis Breguet and George Daniel.

images.alt_text: George Kern, CEO Breitling

site_title: Covid-19 wave probably peaked, but slight surge possible: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung says the current Covid-19 wave may have peaked, with three consecutive days of falling infection numbers. While hospitalizations continue to rise, Ong notes that the healthcare system is not yet under strain. Experts warn that severe cases may peak after mild cases, and a "slight surge" is possible with the upcoming year-end festivities. Ong advises against reinstating mask mandates but encourages people to wear masks when sick, stay home, and get vaccinated, particularly for seniors and those with underlying conditions.

images.alt_text: The Health Ministry has reassured people that the numbers are not as high as during the pandemic. ST PHOTO: KELVIN CHNG

site_title: Maersk imposes container surcharge due to diversion from Red Sea
summary: Maersk, a major shipping company, has imposed extra charges on container transport due to the diversion of ships away from the Suez Canal and the Red Sea. The company cited "severe operational disruption" caused by multiple attacks in the area. Standard 20-foot containers traveling from China to Northern Europe will face a US$700 charge, consisting of a US$200 transit disruption surcharge and a US$500 peak season surcharge. Similar charges will apply to containers bound for the east coast of North America. The move affects routes across Maersk's network, triggering emergency contingency surcharges.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The world's first methanol-fueled container vessel Laura Maersk, owned by shipping company Maersk, is seen in Copenhagen, Denmark September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen/File Photo

site_title: Swiss franc at nine-year high as greenback weakens ahead of inflation data
summary: The Swiss franc reached a nearly nine-year high against the US dollar, reaching 0.85355 francs, as the greenback weakened ahead of the release of US inflation data. The euro also rose to a four-month high, while the Australian dollar reached its highest level since late July. The US dollar index has fallen 4.3% in the past three months, with traders betting on interest rate cuts in 2024. The US core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) print is expected to show a 3.3% annual increase, leading some to predict the Federal Reserve may ease policy sooner than expected.

images.alt_text: Sterling has fallen 0.7 per cent to US$1.2638 as traders priced in Bank of England rate cuts as soon as May.
The US dollar index has risen 0.3 per cent to 102.38.
The US dollar jumps 1.3 per cent on the yen.

site_title: Singapore investment banking fees down 24% to US$664.9 million in 2023: LSEG
summary: Singapore investment banking fees dropped 24% to US$664.9 million in 2023, with advisory fees from completed mergers and acquisitions falling 41% to US$205.2 million. DBS led the league with 14% of the total fee pool. M&A value hit US$50.7 billion, the lowest annual total since 2013, with Singapore-target deals declining 66% to US$14.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Total M&A deals fell 65 per cent in Q3 to US$35 billion, the lowest 9M total since 2013.
Fees generated from syndicate transactions account for US$125.9 million, a drop of 18 per cent from H1 2022.

site_title: Property group JBE said to buy Mercatus assets in HDB estates in low-S$80 million deal
summary: Singapore-based property group JBE has inked a deal to buy one of three bundles of commercial properties in HDB estates from NTUC Enterprise unit Mercatus for a low S$80 million price, reflecting a 4.5% net yield. JBE's purchase includes a FairPrice supermarket space and other commercial properties. Meanwhile, Evia Real Estate is in exclusive due diligence to acquire the other two bundles for over S$175 million, also reflecting a 4.5% net yield. The transactions are subject to HDB's approval.

site_title: Japan plans 10% reduction in debt sales next fiscal year
summary: Japan's finance ministry plans to issue 171 trillion yen of debt in the fiscal year starting April 1, a 10% reduction from the previous year, as it aims to lower its general government debt to 255% of its economy. The government plans to cut sales of 20-year securities to 12 trillion yen and 10-year notes to 31.2 trillion yen, marking a fourth straight year of decreases in sales. The move is seen as part of efforts to reduce the country's massive debt burden and comes amid expectations that the Bank of Japan will end its negative interest rate policy next year.

images.alt_text: Asset management has emerged as an area of focus for the banks this year as the financial regulator sought their help to shake up the industry in line with Japan’s policy pledge to turn dormant household savings into investments.
Benchmark 10-year JGBs and 20-year bonds would be cut, while liquidity enhancement bills would be increased.

site_title: Japan cuts spending for first time in 12 years in 2024/25 budget
summary: Japan's government announced a 2% reduction in its fiscal 2024/25 budget, marking the first cut in spending in 12 years. The budget is estimated at 112.07 trillion yen, down from 114.4 trillion yen, amid rising interest rates and a need to restore fiscal health. The country's public debt burden is over 31.2%, with borrowing costs expected to increase, and analysts predict the government may struggle to meet its aim of achieving a primary budget balance by the fiscal year-end in March 2026.

images.alt_text: The fiscal 2024 economic growth projection is slightly higher than the previous estimate of 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Taiwan signs landmark bilateral investment agreement with Canada
summary: Taiwan and Canada signed a landmark bilateral investment deal, boosting business ties between the two democracies. The agreement, completed in October, aims to strengthen supply chain links and resilience, and incorporates high standards on environmental protection and governance. Taiwan hopes the deal will support its bid to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, a free trade pact where Canada holds the rotating chair next year. The agreement reflects Taiwan's efforts to secure diplomatic and moral support from Western democracies amid growing pressure from China.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cargo trucks work inside a container yard in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang

site_title: India boosts AI in weather forecasts as floods, droughts increase
summary: India is testing artificial intelligence (AI) to improve weather forecasting, as the country experiences more intense clashes of weather systems due to global warming, resulting in extreme weather events that have killed nearly 3,000 people this year. The India Meteorological Department aims to generate higher-quality forecast data at lower cost using AI with an expanded observation network, potentially offering higher-resolution data for forecasts. The government plans to incorporate AI into traditional models, with a centre set up to test the idea through workshops and conferences.

site_title: China air pollution worsens in 2023, first time in decade
summary: China's air pollution worsened in 2023 for the first time in a decade, according to a study by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air. The national average PM2.5 level increased year-on-year, linked to human-caused emissions and unfavorable weather conditions. Chinese cities, including Beijing, recorded increased PM2.5 levels, with 80% of provincial capitals exceeding the standard. This comes as China is expected to see a 4% rise in fossil fuel CO2 emissions, with increases in coal, oil, and gas.

images.alt_text: After 13 days of talks and another sleepless night in a country built on oil wealth, the Emirati leadership of the COP28 summit announced that the world had reached a consensus.

site_title: Dutch housing crisis down to poor policy: UN official
summary: A UN official, Balakrishnan Rajagopal, attributes the Netherlands' housing crisis to poor government policy, not migration or refugees. The country faces a shortage of 390,000 homes, with the average house price at 430,000 euros. Rajagopal stated that the crisis is a result of decades of government policy favoring market-driven housing provision over protecting housing as a human right. He will present a full report to the UN Human Rights Council in March with recommendations.

images.alt_text: Netherlands house prices in 'crazy' boom

site_title: UK economy shrinks in Q3, raising risk of recession
summary: The UK economy shrank in Q3, with a 0.1% drop in GDP from Q2, downgrading the initial estimate of zero growth. Output fell 0.3% in October on a month-on-month basis, putting the economy at risk of a technical recession or a longer slump. Economists now expect GDP to be flat this quarter, raising pressure on the Bank of England to pivot to interest rate cuts sooner.

images.alt_text: The deficit between April and November climbs to £116.4 billion (S$195.7 billion), a rise of 27 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Indonesia economy to grow 5.2% in 2024 as investments pick up steam: Jokowi
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has expressed confidence that the country's economy will grow 5.2% in 2024, higher than IMF and World Bank forecasts. Despite global commodity boom losses and potential economic slowdowns, Widodo attributes the optimism to investments picking up steam, particularly in the new capital city of Nusantara. The government aims to attract 1,650 trillion rupiah in investments to achieve GDP growth of more than 5%. The country's presidential elections are set for February 2024, with Widodo's successor promising to continue his economic policies.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo greets a farmer at the paddy field area in Pekalongan, Central Java province, Indonesia, December 13, 2023. site_title: Canada to give Toronto more than C$471 million to help fight housing crisis
summary: Canada's federal government will provide over C$471 million to Toronto to build nearly 12,000 new housing units and alleviate the shelter crisis over the next three years. The funding comes from a C$4 billion special fund that encourages cities to loosen zoning rules to increase affordable housing. Toronto will streamline zoning approvals, expand affordable rental programs, and cut red tape to meet the federal government's requirements. The move aims to address the city's housing crisis, which is exacerbated by rising shelter costs due to higher interest rates and a growing population.

images.alt_text: The seasonally adjusted annualised rate of housing starts has fallen to 212,624 units from a downwardly revised 272,264 units in October.
The benchmark price of a home in Canada falls 1.1 per cent in November from a month earlier, the biggest decline since September 2022 and the third decrease in a row.

site_title: A breathtaking year for world sport
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

The year 2023 was marked by numerous memorable moments in sports. Shanti Pereira, a Singaporean sprinter, broke national records and won two medals at the Asian Games. Novak Djokovic secured his record-extending eighth year-end world No 1 ranking and is on track to break Margaret Court's record for most singles slams. Max Verstappen dominated Formula 1, winning 19 out of 22 races. Manchester City achieved a treble, while LeBron James broke Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's all-time leading scorer record. However, Luis Rubiales's shameful behavior overshadowed Spain's World Cup triumph, leading to his resignation and FIFA ban.

site_title: Japan’s inflation slows to 2.5% in November as energy bills drop
summary: Japan's inflation slowed to 2.5% in November, down from 2.9% in October, as electricity and gas bills declined. This is the lowest increase in prices since July 2022. Despite speculation that the Bank of Japan may shift away from negative interest rates, it maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy. The yen has strengthened against the US dollar, boosting stocks, and is expected to continue to appreciate in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The fiscal 2024 economic growth projection is slightly higher than the previous estimate of 1.2 per cent.
Decades of stop-start fiscal spending and reform have left Japan with the industrial world’s heaviest public debt burden – double the size of its economic output.
Benchmark 10-year JGBs and 20-year bonds would be cut, while liquidity enhancement bills would be increased.

site_title: Top-performing Korea hedge fund is bullish on banks for 2024
summary: A Korean hedge fund, Life Asset Management, is bullish on Korean bank stocks for 2024, citing a potential interest rate cut by the Bank of Korea. The fund's CEO, Darren Kang, expects a slower rate cut than market forecasts, allowing Korean banks to benefit from wider net interest margins. The move comes after President Yoon Suk Yeol criticized Korean banks for prioritizing profits over customers. Life Asset's 30% year-to-date return suggests a positive outlook for Korean financial stocks.

images.alt_text: Small business owners will get a cash refund to the tune of 90 per cent of the interest paid in excess of 4 per cent, up to a limit of 200 million won in loans for one year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 22)
summary: Advisory fees from completed mergers and acquisitions in the US fell 41% year-over-year to US$205.2 million. Investment banking fees in Singapore dropped 24% to US$664.9 million in 2023. Malaysia's inflation slowed to 1.5% in November, beating economists' forecasts. Indonesia's economy is expected to grow 5.2% in 2024, surpassing IMF and World Bank predictions. Sumitomo Life Insurance acquired Singlife, valuing the Singapore insurer at S$4.6 billion. Singapore stocks rose 0.9% at the end of the week, amid improved investor sentiment ahead of holidays.

site_title: Bristol Myers to buy schizophrenia drugmaker Karuna Therapeutics for US$14 billion
summary: Bristol Myers Squibb agreed to buy Karuna Therapeutics for $14 billion, gaining a promising schizophrenia drug. The deal comes after declining demand for two of Bristol's top drugs, Revlimid and Eliquis, which face generic competition. The acquisition is the second major deal for Bristol, following its $5.8 billion purchase of Mirati Therapeutics in May. The deal represents a 53.4% premium to Karuna's last closing price and is expected to power growth as patents on Bristol's older therapies expire.

images.alt_text: The purchase will give a boost to Bristol as patent expirations weigh on sales of its oncology medicines.
LOTTE Corp is buying one of Bristol Myers Squibb’s pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities for US$160 million, as the Korean chaebol seeks to diversify its operations.

site_title: Sumitomo Life nears deal for S$4 billion Singaporean insurer Singlife
summary: Sumitomo Life Insurance is nearing a deal to buy TPG's stake in Singapore Life Holdings, valued at S$4 billion to S$5 billion, to bolster its presence in South-east Asia. The Japanese insurer has increased its stake in Singlife to 27% and agreed to buy Aviva's 25.9% stake for S$900 million. Talks are at an advanced stage, and a deal could be announced as early as Friday. This acquisition would allow Sumitomo Life to wholly own Singlife, expanding its presence in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The issue comprises 23.7 million new shares, representing 4.92 per cent of the increased share capital of Singlife, which stood at S$2.26 billion post transaction.

site_title: Tesla launches Shanghai megapack battery project: Chinese state media
summary: Tesla has launched its Shanghai megapack battery project, a new manufacturing plant capable of producing 10,000 megapacks per year. The project, scheduled to begin construction in the first quarter of 2024, marks a slower-than-expected rollout compared to the previously stated third quarter start. The US electric vehicle manufacturer's Shanghai gigafactory is already producing 1.1 million units annually, but Tesla has yet to obtain approval to expand its EV capacity in Shanghai.

site_title: Blackstone to buy 80% of Sony payment unit for US$280 million
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, is set to acquire 80% of Sony Payment Services for approximately US$280 million. This deal marks Blackstone's first private equity investment in Japan in two years and its entry into the financial technology space. Sony Group will retain a 20% minority stake in the payment business, valued at 50 billion yen (S$466 million). The acquisition comes as Japanese corporations increasingly sell non-core assets to private equity investors, with Sony Payment offering payment processing services to business clients in Japan.

images.alt_text: The video is an annual tradition dating to 2018, giving executives the chance to have their “The Office” moment.
Private lenders are fighting back by pitching more flexible terms that banks cannot match.
Japanese hotels have been among the most popular real estate investments in the Asia-Pacific region this year.

site_title: Sweden's Electrolux Professional to buy Japan's Tosei
summary: Electrolux Professional has agreed to buy Japan's Tosei Corporation, a maker of professional laundry equipment and vacuum packing machines, for approximately 1.65 billion Swedish crowns (S$216.4 million). The deal is expected to strengthen Electrolux Professional's position in Japan's laundry market and expand its vacuum packing products in the fast-growing sous-vide cooking segment. Closing is anticipated in the first quarter of 2024.

site_title: Indonesia to fine palm oil companies 4.8 trillion rupiah for operating in forests
summary: Indonesia has fined palm oil companies operating within forest areas a total of 4.8 trillion rupiah (S$411.5 million) for violating rules. Over 475 billion rupiah in fines have been issued so far, targeting 200,000 hectares of oil palm plantations in forest areas. The measures aim to fix governance in the sector and return the land to forests. Companies must submit paperwork and pay fines to obtain cultivating rights by November 2, 2023.

images.alt_text: Palm oil is one of the only agri commodities that has booked a fall in price so far this year, which has pressured the margins of companies in the palm oil production sector.
Indonesia, the world’s biggest exporter of palm oil, uses proceeds from the levy to subsidise biodiesel and fund palm replanting programmes.
Malaysia expects higher demand particularly from China’s oleochemical and animal feed sectors.

site_title: Sumitomo Life moves to own all of Singlife, valuing Singapore insurer at S$4.6 billion
summary: Sumitomo Life Insurance has agreed to acquire all shares of Singlife, a Singaporean insurer, valuing it at S$4.6 billion. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to complete in Q1 2024. Sumitomo Life has been Singlife's strategic investor since 2019, citing a South-east Asia strategy and plans to strengthen earnings. Singlife will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Sumitomo Life, with access to capital and a nimble shareholding structure.

images.alt_text: Ferguson currently serves as the board chairman of Singlife Group, and as an independent non-executive director on the board of Paragon Reit.
The issue comprises 23.7 million new shares, representing 4.92 per cent of the increased share capital of Singlife, which stood at S$2.26 billion post transaction.
Aviva says it would buy the unit – known as AIG Life UK – from Corebridge Financial, a New York-listed company majority-owned by AIG.
The Singlife shareholders may or may not exercise their rights of first-offer and tag-along under the existing shareholders’ deed, which may also change the final consideration.
Two insurers now offer coverage for electric vehicle charging-related injuries and damage, though industry experts say complexities surrounding EV charging still exist.

site_title: Ryde to forgo driver commissions from Jan 2
summary: Ryde, a Singapore-based ride-hailing platform, will scrap its driver commission charges starting January 2, 2024. This move aims to increase driver take-home pay, motivate drivers, and improve the overall rider experience. The decision is seen as setting a new standard for the driver community and introducing the lowest-cost option for private-hire and taxi drivers.

images.alt_text: As until the IPO filing, a total of S$5.8 million funding was obtained by Ryde from venture capital companies.
Ride-hailing service Ryde expands crypto payment option to over 70, launches first NFT
Ride-hailing companies include temporary fee to help drivers defray costs

site_title: EU Commission examines Italy's tax case against Meta: sources
summary: The European Commission's VAT committee is evaluating Italy's tax claim against Meta, the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, over the tax treatment of online services provided in exchange for user data. Italy's tax agency claims Meta owes around 870 million euros in sales tax, but Meta strongly disagrees, citing the non-monetary exchange of a membership account for personal data. A non-binding assessment from the VAT committee could impact the case, with a "no" potentially leading to the drop of the criminal investigation and a wider tax implications for other EU member states.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Meta Platforms' business group is seen in Brussels, Belgium December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
Meta says that now EU users can create a Threads profile connected to their Instagram account.

site_title: China unveils new gaming curbs, sends tech stocks tumbling
summary: China has unveiled new gaming curbs, restricting in-game purchases and compulsive playing behavior. The draft regulations, published by the regulator, aim to limit recharging in-game wallets and abolish daily log-in rewards. Tencent shares dropped over 10% in Hong Kong, while rival Netease fell more than 20%. The move is seen as part of China's crackdown on big tech, with some independent game studios viewing the regulations as an opportunity to focus on innovation and high-quality user experience.

images.alt_text: At roughly 30 per cent, ByteDance would outpace the projected growth of far more established social media rivals Meta Platforms and Tencent, which is estimated to generate US$86 billion in revenue this year.

site_title: Zomato makes takeover offer for Indian e-commerce shipping startup Shiprocket: sources
summary: Zomato, an Indian food delivery company, has made an offer to acquire Shiprocket, an e-commerce shipping startup, valued at around US$2 billion. The move contradicts previous reports that Zomato had no plans for an acquisition. Shiprocket, led by co-founder Saahil Goel, has raised funds at a valuation of US$1.2 billion. A final decision has not been made, and Zomato could opt against proceeding with the deal. This acquisition would be Zomato's largest to date, following its initial public offering in 2021.

site_title: Alibaba names new commerce division heads in internal shuffle
summary: Alibaba appoints six new managers, including Taobao and Tmall heads, to report directly to CEO Eddie Wu as part of an internal shuffle. The move comes after the departure of longstanding e-commerce chief Trudy Dai and aims to reinvigorate growth in the face of fierce competition. The new appointees include Wu Jia, Chen Weiye, and Liu Bo, who will oversee user platform experience, operations, and Tmall, respectively. The appointments are part of Alibaba's efforts to reinvigorate its e-commerce unit.

images.alt_text: Once the most valuable company in China, Alibaba has fallen behind games and social media leader Tencent Holdings.
Alibaba slid as much as 1.4 per cent during intraday trading in Hong Kong, putting its market value at about US$187 billion at one point, below US-listed PDD Holdings’ US$188.3 billion.

Jack Ma, chairman of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., pauses during a fireside interview at the Viva Technology conference in Paris, France, on Thursday, May 16, 2019. Donald Trump’s latest offensive against China’s Huawei Technologies Co. puts Europe in an even bigger bind over which side to pick, but France's President Emmanuel Macron is holding the line. Photographer: Marlene Awaad/Bloomberg
The deal will improve Alibaba Health’s revenue growth and profitability outlook, while allowing it to provide better services to online stores, the company says.
The Alibaba Cloud logo is displayed near a screen showing the website of its Tongyi Qianwen AI chatbot, in this illustration picture taken June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
Alibaba shuts quantum computing lab in sign of broader cutback

Jack Ma’s whereabouts and activities have been the topic of intense discussion since 2020, when he stepped away from the limelight after Beijing clamped down on his twin companies — Alibaba and Ant Group.

site_title: Economists had a dreadful 2023
summary: Economists had a dismal 2023, with many predicting a recession that failed to materialize. Despite this, the US economy is expected to have grown by around 3% in 2023, similar to the 2005 growth rate. Research on inequality and social mobility has also yielded mixed results, with some studies challenging the notion of rising income disparities. Additionally, economists are re-examining their assumptions on the causes of mortality and labor market trends. The year's tumult has highlighted the importance of replicating studies, respecting economic theory, and maintaining optimism about the state of modern capitalism.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians on Wall Street in New York, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 8, 2023. Stocks fell around the world as traders rushed into bonds after a raft of news on China, Italy and the US fanned worries about the financial system and the global economy. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg
A woman takes pictures of the skyline of buildings from Mont Faber hill in Singapore on October 25, 2023. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: China’s Geely warns Red Sea attacks to delay Europe-bound EV shipments
summary: Chinese automaker Geely warns that delays in deliveries to Europe due to the Red Sea attacks may impact its electric vehicle sales. Most shipping firms are planning to take longer routes around the Cape of Good Hope to avoid the Suez Canal, resulting in higher freight costs. If the situation remains unresolved, shipping firms are expected to adjust freight rates, leading to rising transport costs. This may impact Geely's ability to meet its Europe-bound EV shipments, potentially affecting its sales.

images.alt_text: The car logo of Chinese automaker Geely is seen at a dealership in Artyom outside Vladivostok, Russia, March 22, 2023. REUTERS/Tatiana Meel/file photo

site_title: China’s BYD picks Hungary for its first European electric-car plant
summary: China's BYD plans to build its first European electric car factory in Szeged, Hungary, creating thousands of jobs and producing EVs and plug-in hybrids for the European market. The move aims to challenge Tesla as the dominant maker of battery-powered cars and may help BYD dodge potential import tariffs due to a Brussels probe into state subsidies to Chinese EV makers. This investment caps a year of courting from European countries and follows significant EV-related investments in Hungary, including a 7.3 billion euros battery plant by Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd.

images.alt_text: The EU’s probe kicked off in earnest in October with investigations of BYD, SAIC and Geely, bringing the bloc more in line with the US in looking to protect an industry that employs millions of workers.
BYD remains the dominant auto brand in China, having overtaken Volkswagen for the top sales spot this year.
Shenzhen-based BYD aims to sell 3 million hybrids and EVs this year, and November’s figure lifts it to 2.67 million so far in 2023.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to fully acquire taxi network operator A2B Australia for A$165.1 million
summary: ComfortDelGro has agreed to acquire Australian taxi network operator A2B Australia for A$165.1 million (S$145.7 million) through a scheme of arrangement. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the first half of 2024, subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals. ComfortDelGro aims to scale its point-to-point mobility business in Australia and diversify its offerings. The deal values A2B's issued equity at A$182 million on a fully diluted basis, with A2B's payment of a special dividend excluded.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro taxis seen travelling along Sims Avenue on Feb 20, 2023.
ComfortDelGro noted that demand remains high for taxi and private hire services, although competition is increasing.
ComfortDelGro will also be the startup’s preferred fleet partner, starting with a collaboration in the third quarter in Sydney and Melbourne.

site_title: TotalEnergies to sell stake in Scottish wind farm to Thailand’s PTTEP
summary: TotalEnergies is selling a 25.5% stake in the Seagreen wind farm in Scotland to Thailand's PTTEP for £522 million. The French oil company and Thai giant will each hold 25.5% of the 49% owned by SSE Renewables. The deal is part of TotalEnergies' transition strategy and aims to reach 12% profitability in its Integrated Power business. PTTEP and TotalEnergies have also signed a Memorandum of Understanding to explore joint opportunities in offshore wind and other renewable energy projects.

site_title: Five major Chinese banks cut interest rates on some deposits
summary: Five major Chinese banks, including the Agricultural Bank of China and China Construction Bank, cut interest rates on some deposits starting Friday, Dec 22. The cuts, ranging from 10-25 basis points, aim to offset pressure on banks' profitability and provide room to reduce lending costs. The moves follow the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China's decision to cut interest rates on some deposits. The cuts are expected to support the economy amid slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Royal Bank of Canada gets nod for C$13.5 billion purchase of HSBC unit
summary: The Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) has received approval from Canada's finance ministry to acquire HSBC's Canadian unit for C$13.5 billion. The deal, expected to close in the first quarter of 2024, requires RBC to establish a global banking hub in Vancouver, waive fees, and protect HSBC's Canadian workforce. RBC will also increase its workforce in Winnipeg and provide financing for affordable housing construction. The deal has been approved by the federal banking regulator and the Competition Bureau, despite concerns over competition and market concentration.

images.alt_text: Naked short selling is a practice that involves selling shares without borrowing them first.
HSBC and firms including Goldman Sachs Group and Citigroup have been cutting staff in the region as deals slow amid macro-economic concerns and tumultuous markets.
The problems are the result of an “internal system issue,” a HSBC spokesperson says.

site_title: Europe: Shares ease after two days of gains
summary: European stocks closed down 0.2% on Thursday, after two sessions of gains, as investors took stock of recent interest rate cut bets. The automobile and real estate sectors fell, while healthcare stocks rose 0.2%. Germany's DAX index declined 0.3% due to a survey showing retailers' sentiment sagged in December. The European Central Bank's vice-president stated it was too early to discuss interest rate cuts, amid concerns about inflation and global trade disruptions.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 edged up 0.3 per cent, with UK’s blue-chip FTSE 100 index jumping 1.0 per cent.

site_title: Hedge fund traders snap up some of London's priciest mansions
summary: Hedge fund traders and ultra-rich individuals have purchased luxury London homes in multimillion-dollar deals, despite the UK's broader housing woes. Transactions include £113 million mansion in Regent's Park and £138 million Mayfair mansion. The luxury market remains insulated from headwinds such as high borrowing costs, with wealthy buyers less dependent on debt. However, the market is showing signs of a two-tier structure, with homes above £10 million less vulnerable to interest rate concerns. Despite this, the biggest concerns for the rich include stamp duty, financial scrutiny, and potential election disruption.

images.alt_text: Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Former Swiss banker admits helping wealthy US taxpayers hide assets
summary: A former Swiss banker, Rolf Schnellmann, pleaded guilty to charges of helping wealthy US taxpayers hide millions of dollars in offshore bank accounts. Schnellmann, 61, was the head of Allied Finance Trust and participated in a tax fraud conspiracy from 2008 to 2014. He faces up to five years in prison for defrauding the Internal Revenue Service by hiding assets in undeclared bank accounts in Switzerland. The scheme, known as the "Singapore Solution," involved transferring funds through other jurisdictions to avoid detection.

images.alt_text: Fifa and Uefa abuse their dominant position by forbidding clubs to compete in a European Super League (ESL), according to the EU’s top court ruling.
Airbnb received more than 2,000 complaints from Australian customers over being charged in US dollars during this period.
Google faces other lawsuits challenging its search and digital advertising practices.

site_title: Shell extends job cuts as CEO seeks to trim costs
summary: Shell has begun cutting jobs beyond previously announced reductions in its low-carbon division as CEO Wael Sawan seeks to trim costs and improve competitiveness. The company aims to reduce "structural costs" by $3 billion by 2025, with roles being eliminated on a division-by-division basis. This move follows the company's previous announcement of 200 job cuts in its Low Carbon Solutions unit in 2024. Shell employed approximately 93,000 globally at the end of 2022, with Sawan pledging to be "ruthless" in improving the company's performance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James//File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James//File Photo
Shell will cut 200 jobs in 2024 and has placed another 130 positions under review as part of a drive to reduce the headcount in the unit.

site_title: China’s 30-year yield hits lowest since 2005 on deposit rate cuts
summary: China's 30-year sovereign bond yields dropped to 2.8% on Friday, the lowest since 2005, following a fresh round of large banks' deposit rate cuts. The central bank's liquidity support and deposit rate cuts are expected to steer investment towards the debt market, with analysts predicting a potential policy rate cut by the PBOC in 2024. The move is seen as a response to China's economic gloom and the US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate cut next year.

images.alt_text: The moves came after the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China’s largest lender by assets, on Thursday said it would cut interest rates on some deposits.
Most new and outstanding loans in the world’s second-largest economy are based on the one-year LPR, which stands at 3.45 per cent.
China has space to step up support for the economy, given that its central government debt burden is relatively low and consumer prices are also low, according to the central bank adviser.
China’s yuan has had a volatile year, having weakened 6.14 per cent against the US dollar at one point before recouping some of the losses on growing bets that US interest rates have peaked.
Over recent months, China has started to unleash fresh fiscal stimulus to shore up the economy.

site_title: Cybertruck designer says Tesla stainless steel pickup is no experiment
summary: Tesla's Cybertruck, a polarizing pickup with a stainless steel design, starts at $60,990, significantly higher than initially promised in 2019. Despite initial glitches and criticism, the vehicle is drawing interest from those new to trucks, with some owners already lining up at Tesla showrooms. Chief designer Franz von Holzhausen defends the design, stating it's a conversation starter and gets people talking about the brand, and believes it can be a high-volume vehicle, potentially appealing to those who've never owned a truck before.

images.alt_text: The EU’s probe kicked off in earnest in October with investigations of BYD, SAIC and Geely, bringing the bloc more in line with the US in looking to protect an industry that employs millions of workers.

The recall is the second this year involving Tesla’s automated-driving systems, which have come under escalating scrutiny after hundreds of crashes, some of which resulted in fatalities.
Tesla's new Cybertruck is the first car with a stainless-steel exterior since the launch of the DeLorean car which was featured in the 1985 movie "Back to the Future".

site_title: Nippon-US Steel deal deserves ‘serious scrutiny’, White House says
summary: The White House has expressed concern over Nippon Steel's proposed $14.9 billion acquisition of US Steel Corp, citing national security and supply chain reliability as key factors. The administration is urging careful review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US and possibly antitrust authorities. President Joe Biden supports domestic manufacturing and job creation, but views the deal as deserving "serious scrutiny" due to its foreign ownership and potential impact on the US steel industry.

images.alt_text: The acquisition will help the world’s fourth largest steel maker move towards 100 million tonnes of global crude steel capacity and make it a bigger supplier to the US auto industry.
Nippon Steel sees the US as a growth market that can help to offset declining demand in Japan

site_title: Asia: Markets bounce with Wall Street as US data fans rate-cut bets
summary: Asian markets surged on Friday, December 22, driven by US data that fueled expectations of a rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The US economy grew slightly less than expected in the third quarter, supporting the narrative of a cooling economy that will lead to rate cuts. Markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney, rose, while Shanghai dipped. Analysts say the advance may have gone too fast, but traders are betting on 150 basis points of rate cuts, more than policymakers have indicated, amid a "Santa Claus Rally" ahead of the PCE price index release next month.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Jakarta and Manila well in the red while Singapore and Wellington eked out small gains.

site_title: Gold hits near three-week high on US Fed rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices rose to a nearly three-week high, reaching $2,047.42 per ounce, due to rising bets of US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in early 2024. The US dollar and bond yields declined, making gold more attractive for investors. The market now expects an 83% chance of a Fed rate cut by March, up from 79% previously. The US GDP growth rate was revised to 4.9% annualized, while jobless claims increased slightly. The November core PCE index report is due later, providing further clarity on the US interest rate outlook.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was down 0.1 per cent against its rivals, making gold less expensive for other currency holders.

site_title: Biolidics’ private placement at S$0.0121 apiece to raise one-eighth of market cap
summary: Biolidics, a medtech company, entered a subscription agreement to issue 83 million new shares at S$0.0121 apiece, raising about one-eighth of its market capitalization. The new shares will represent 11.2% of the enlarged issued share capital. The funds will be used to improve cash flow and achieve trading status on Catalist. The company's net loss per share is expected to decrease by 61.5% upon completion of the subscription.

images.alt_text: Biolidics, who produces and distributes Covid-19 test kits, is seeking to extend its debt repayment deadline to Clearbridge Health.
The additional time will allow for a smooth handover of duties, said Biolidics, which previously developed Covid-19 PCR tests (pictured).
UOB shall remain as Biolidics' sponsor until Dec 31, or such other date that is mutually agreed with the company, the new sponsor, and/or SGX.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.4% to 3,125.35. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 85 to 30, with 69.3 million securities worth S$49.1 million changing hands. Banking stocks traded mixed, while US indices rebounded on Thursday driven by bullish investment sentiments amid moderating inflation.

images.alt_text: City Developments is expecting a substantial drop in its FY2023 net profit.

site_title: Sea to post first profitable year since IPO: CEO
summary: Sea, the parent of e-commerce platform Shopee, is on track to post its first profitable year since becoming a public company in 2023, according to CEO Forrest Li. The company booked a profitable Q1 and Q2 this year, but sank back into a loss in the third quarter. Li revealed this information in a memo to staff without providing details about Q4 financials, marking the group's first profitable year since its IPO.

images.alt_text: Forrest Li, chief executive of Sea, said in a letter to the company's employees on the anniversary of its IPO: "Let’s work on building up our company’s intrinsic value – and rest assured that the market, when it’s ready, will catch up with us.”

site_title: China import concerns spur US to launch semiconductor supply chain review
summary: The US Department of Commerce plans to launch a survey of the US semiconductor supply chain to address national security concerns related to Chinese-sourced chips. The survey aims to identify how US companies are sourcing legacy chips and will help promote a level playing field for legacy chip production. The department is also awarding nearly $40 billion in subsidies for semiconductor chips manufacturing to reduce risks posed by China. The move comes after China provided the Chinese semiconductor industry with an estimated $150 billion in subsidies in the last decade.

images.alt_text: Chinese EVs are already subject to a 25 per cent tariff, which has limited the number of cars Chinese automakers are sending to the US.
The meeting between Joe Biden and Xi Jinping was a timely reset at an incredibly tense moment in global geopolitics.
Over 50 per cent of drones sold in the United States are made by DJI.

site_title: Japan banks scramble to beef up asset management business amid government reform push
summary: Japan's top banks are scrambling to boost their asset management businesses amid a government push to turn dormant household savings into investments. The financial regulator aims to double the amount of assets under management to 200 trillion yen by March 2030. Banks such as Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group are hiring asset managers and diversifying products to capitalize on a potential shift in household investment habits. The move is seen as crucial to achieving Japan's policy pledge to combat deflation and inflation.

images.alt_text: Officers from Tokyo District Public Prosecutors Office on their way to search the office of Seiwa Policy Research Group, the largest faction of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), in Tokyo on Dec 19, 2023. The raid is linked to a funding scandal that forced Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to replace four ministers the previous week.

site_title: Book review: Poor Charlie’s Almanack
summary: Charlie Munger's book "Poor Charlie's Almanack" offers wisdom on investment success and life lessons through a collection of talks and anecdotes. The book, first published in 2005, features Munger's approach to life, learning, and decision-making, which emphasizes the importance of mental models, managing downside risks, and using all available information. Munger's style may seem outdated, but his wisdom remains valuable, and the book is a must-read for investors and non-investors alike, offering a philosophical companion to the Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting experience.

images.alt_text: Charlie Munger (right, with Warren Buffett at the left in this image) was more than a No. 2; he was the ultimate second banana. These are far from the same thing.
Berkshire Hathaway vice chair Charlie Munger, one of the world’s most revered investors, had many memorable rants over the years on the ills of the investing world.
Berkshire Hathaway said Charlie Munger died peacefully at a hospital in California, where he lived. No cause was given.

site_title: MUFG to build India operations amid economic slowdown in China
summary: Japan's largest lender, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG), plans to expand its operations in India amid the economic slowdown in China. The bank's CEO, Hironori Kamezawa, believes India's economic growth is "a sure thing," with the country forecast to grow 7% in the year ending March. Global lenders are pushing into India, driven by the soured mood on China and the nation's growing capital markets. MUFG's expansion in India aims to tap into the country's growth potential and capitalize on its economic growth prospects.

MUFG has been discussing with multiple parties about using its blockchain platform, Progmat, to mint stablecoins tied to foreign currencies.

site_title: Whampoa Group partners South Korean gaming company for US$100 million Web3 fund
summary: Whampoa Digital, the technology arm of Singapore family office Whampoa Group, has partnered with South Korean gaming company Wemade to establish a US$100 million Web3 fund. The fund will focus on investing in gaming studios and blockchain projects in the Middle East. Whampoa Digital will serve as an ecosystem partner, while Wemade will provide facilities and mentorship support. The collaboration aims to promote the seamless adoption of digital assets globally, with a focus on the gaming and Web3 industries.

site_title: Apple stops online sales of watches; older models can’t be fixed
summary: Apple has stopped selling the Apple Watch Series 9 and Ultra 2 in the US online due to a patent dispute with Masimo, which ruled that Apple violated two health-technology patents related to blood oxygen sensing. The company will no longer repair out-of-warranty models, and customers will not be able to get issues fixed by Apple. The ban remains in effect until Apple reaches a licensing agreement with Masimo or fixes the problem.

images.alt_text: An Apple store in New York, US, on Friday, June 30, 2023. The blowout rally in tech megacaps gained further traction on Friday, with the Nasdaq 100 poised to notch a record first-half of a year and Apple Inc. hitting the $3 trillion milestone. The Vision Pro marks Apple’s first new product category since it began selling smartwatches in 2015.

Apple has known for almost two months that a ban on its smartwatch sales imposed by ITC would take effect Dec 25 unless it persuades the Biden administration to intervene – or works out a settlement with Masimo.

site_title: Singapore IPO climate to look up in 2024, but observers mixed on return of Reits, Spacs
summary: Singapore's IPO market is expected to pick up in 2024, driven by falling interest rates and improving stock market valuations. However, market watchers are divided on whether local bourse will see new listings of real estate investment trusts (Reits) and special purpose acquisition companies (Spacs). Some experts, like PwC's Tham Tuck Seng, believe the lack of liquidity and research capabilities may deter companies from listing. Others, like JPMorgan's Vineet Mishra, see opportunities for stable, income-driven products like Reits and business trusts. UBS' David Cameron Smail expects interest in data centre and select industrial businesses to continue.
