Brent crude futures settled higher US$1.40, or 1.8 per cent, to US$77.95 a barrel.

site_title: ’Tis the season for sustainable gifts
summary: Sustainable gift ideas are available for last-minute shoppers this Christmas. Eco-friendly options include Moleskine's Precious and Ethical Collection featuring vegan covers, Simply R&J's upcycled vintage crockery, Another Sole's Anew Marshmallow sandals and tote bags, Our Barehands' handcrafted products from marginalised communities, Noble Panacea's green skincare products, Batti Candles' eco-friendly candles, and Triple Eyelid Studio's sustainable furniture made from upcycled wood. Wine enthusiasts can also consider Through The Grapevine's certified sustainable vineyards, offering a range of wines from Italy, South Africa, and New Zealand.

site_title: Indonesia central bank extends interest rate pause, sees possible easing in H2 2024
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, kept interest rates steady at 6% for the fourth consecutive month, as expected. The decision, made at the end of 2023, signals possible easing in the second half of 2024, with Governor Perry Warjiyo citing a focus on maintaining the rupiah's stability and controlling inflation. The central bank expects domestic inflation to be within its target of 1.5-3.5% in 2024, with the US Federal Reserve expected to cut interest rates by 50 basis points in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bank Indonesia's logo is seen at its headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, January 17, 2019. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: Sophia Road site sells for S$33.59 million, below guide price
summary: A residential redevelopment site at 132 Sophia Road in Singapore was sold for S$33.59 million, below the guide price of S$35 million. The 13,783 square feet site has a 103-year leasehold tenure and a land rate of S$1,172 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The sale was made to boutique property developer and investor Sin Thai Hin Development following a tender exercise that closed on November 29.

images.alt_text: One of the trio of bungalows in Nassim Road that changed hands for a total of S$206.7 million this year. The transaction is among at least S$700 million of deals in GCB Areas for which buyers did not lodge caveats.
Aerial view of Orchard Road. Orchard Bel Air, a coveted residential site located right at the doorstep of Orchard Boulevard MRT station is up for sale by tender.
The site, located at 1 Plymouth Avenue, is located near Stevens MRT interchange, Tanglin Community Club and schools such as Singapore Chinese Girls’ School and St Joseph’s Institution.
The upcoming redevelopments along Orchard Road must have a sense of distinctiveness to draw crowds back, said analysts.

site_title: UK budget deficit jumps 27% in first eight months of fiscal year
summary: The UK's budget deficit jumped 27% in the first eight months of the fiscal year, reaching £116.4 billion (S$195.7 billion) due to increased spending to help with the living standards crisis. Welfare costs rose 12% and public-sector staff costs also increased by 12% after benefits were raised by 10% in April. The government is under pressure to cut taxes, with tax revenue rising 4.5% and government debt reaching 97.5% of GDP, its highest level since the 1960s.

images.alt_text: Official figures show Britain’s gross domestic product shrank 0.3 per cent in October.
The annual rate of consumer price increases falls to 3.9 per cent from 4.6 per cent in October, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS).
Britain is keen to shake up listings and other financial rules to boost growth at a time when private money is needed to help the country invest to meet net-zero targets.
The improving mood in the services industry offset pessimism among manufacturers.
Britain’s economy has flat-lined till 2023 but earnings are now outpacing inflation again.

site_title: China's cold snap reaches Shanghai with chilliest year-end in 40 years
summary: China's financial hub Shanghai is experiencing its chilliest period in December in 40 years, with temperatures expected to remain below zero all day. The city's lowest temperatures on Thursday were forecast to be minus 4 to minus 6 deg C in suburbs, and minus 4 to minus 5 deg C in the city center. Authorities have issued warnings for low temperatures and wind, while northern cities continue to battle icy conditions. The cold snap is expected to ease only next week.

images.alt_text: The cold wave moving through the country from north to south is expected to drag temperatures lower into the weekend, even as Meteorological Centre says rain and snow will decrease.

site_title: Builder China Aoyuan seeks debt restructuring recognition in US
summary: China property developer Aoyuan Group has filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy in New York, seeking US court recognition for its offshore debt restructuring and warding off litigation. The move comes as the company undergoes restructuring in Hong Kong, Cayman Islands, and British Virgin Islands after deciding not to pay its debt. Aoyuan joins a growing list of Chinese developers, including China Evergrande Group, to tap the Chapter 15 system to handle cross-border assets. The company's dollar bonds, trading at below 2 US cents, are governed by New York law.

images.alt_text: Aoyuan cut to restricted default by Fitch

site_title: Three Arrows founders’ global assets worth US$1.1 billion frozen
summary: Three Arrows Capital's co-founders, Su Zhu and Kyle Davies, along with Davies' wife Kelly Chen, have had US$1.1 billion worth of assets frozen globally by court orders in the British Virgin Islands and Singapore. The freezing orders aim to prevent the trio from disposing of assets to "frustrate eventual enforcement" by liquidators seeking to maximize returns to creditors. The claims against the fund's liquidation exceed US$3 billion, and the founders and Chen can contest the orders in court.

images.alt_text: Zhu Su, co-founder of failed crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital
Like many crypto companies, Blockchain.com has faced challenges since the prices of most tokens tumbled in 2022.

Perhaps the most tangible indicator that crypto has moved on: Bitcoin has recovered all its losses since the May 2022 implosion of stablecoin TerraUSD, which set in motion the wave of failures that ultimately helped bring down FTX.
MAS still wants to foster a digital asset hub by encouraging projects aimed at institutional use of crypto’s underlying blockchain technology.
Zhu Su (above) and Davies are among the onetime darlings of crypto’s pandemic-era bull run whose reputations subsequently suffered as boom turned to bust, exposing risky practices.

site_title: Social media platform X back up after global outage
summary: Social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, experienced a global outage affecting over 77,000 US users and 7,000 in Canada and Britain. Users reported issues accessing posts, replies, and profiles. The cause of the outage is unknown, and emails to X's support teams bounced back. The outage comes after the platform faced upheaval following Elon Musk's US$44 billion acquisition, leading to layoffs of engineers responsible for fixing service outages. X was restored globally early on Thursday, December 21.

images.alt_text: The action against X platform is the first against a major online platform since EU implements the Digital Services Act (DSA).
X has historically relied on advertising for the bulk of its sales, but that business has been in decline since Musk’s takeover.

X, formerly known as Twitter, risks  losing as much US$75 million in advertising revenue by the end of the year as major brands pause their marketing campaigns on the platform, according to the New York Times.

site_title: South Korea, Japan resume high-level economic talks amid improved ties
summary: South Korea and Japan will hold high-level economic talks for the first time in eight years on December 21, amid improved ties. The talks, led by Deputy Foreign Minister Kang Jae-kwon and Senior Deputy Foreign Minister Keiichi Ono, aim to assess bilateral economic cooperation and discuss economic security policy. This follows recent steps to mend ties, including Japan's reinstatement of South Korea's "white list" for exports and South Korea's plan to compensate people forced to work under Japan's 1910-1945 occupation. The talks also come as the countries cooperate on a real-time missile data-sharing system.

images.alt_text: Global demand for chips at the heart of the economies for South Korean and some of its regional peers has held steady, supporting economic recoveries.
outh Korea’s year-on-year inflation eased to 3.3 per cent for the first time in four months in November.

site_title: Trans-cab, Prime Taxi to raise fares
summary: Two taxi operators, Trans-cab and Prime Taxi, are raising their flag-down fares by S$0.50, as well as distance and time-based charges by S$0.01, starting December 28. The fare hikes come a fortnight after ComfortDelGro, the largest taxi operator in Singapore, made similar adjustments. Trans-cab's fares will increase to S$4.60 for smaller taxis and S$5.50 for larger Toyota Alphard, while Prime Taxi's flag-down rate will remain unchanged for bigger cabs at S$5.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro noted that demand remains high for taxi and private hire services, although competition is increasing.
Recent developments may see the lines blur between taxis and private-hire cars – as well as offer a lifeline to the flagging taxi industry.

site_title: Samsung to set up chip packaging research facility in Japan
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest around $280 million over five years in a chip packaging research facility in Japan, with the Japanese government providing up to $185.9 million in subsidies. The facility will deepen ties with Japanese companies and support the revitalization of domestic chip manufacturing. The investment comes amid easing tensions between South Korea and Japan, and as the US encourages allies to counter China's growing technological prowess. The facility will allow Samsung to strengthen its leadership in chips and partner with packaging-related companies in Japan.

site_title: Quarz-led committee calls for another Sabana EGM with 12 resolutions on internalisation
summary: A Quarz-led committee is requisitioning another extraordinary general meeting (EGM) at Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) to address concerns over the internalisation of the Reit manager. The committee, which was formed to oversee the process, claims the trustee's lack of progress has left unitholders highly dissatisfied. The committee has tabled 12 resolutions to direct the trustee, disagreeing with their interpretation of the trust deed, which they believe jeopardises the internalisation process.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.

New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. Earlier this year, ESR Group and Quarz were embroiled in a public battle over the internalisation of the Reit management function of Sabana Reit,
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. On Aug 7, unitholders of Sabana Reit voted in favour of internalisation, with both resolutions carried.

site_title: US considering hiking tariffs on China EVs, solar products: WSJ
summary: The US is considering raising tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles (EVs), solar products, and EV battery packs. This move aims to limit reliance on China in the clean-energy supply chain and shield the US green industry against cheaper Chinese exports. Chinese EVs already face a 25% tariff, and raising it would likely have little immediate impact on US consumers. Other targets for potential tariff-rate increases include Chinese solar products and EV battery packs, which are crucial for the US market.

images.alt_text: The meeting between Joe Biden and Xi Jinping was a timely reset at an incredibly tense moment in global geopolitics.
Over 50 per cent of drones sold in the United States are made by DJI.

site_title: Philippines keeps inflation target at 2-4% to 2026
summary: The Philippines central bank has reaffirmed its inflation target range of 2-4% to 2026, citing a steady economy and a sustained return to the target. The current inflation rate of 4.1% in November is still above the target, but the central bank believes non-monetary measures and a "higher-for-longer" policy stance will keep inflation expectations anchored. The decision aims to maintain price stability and support economic growth.

site_title: Discount London office deals show more pain coming for lenders
summary: London's office market is experiencing significant pain for lenders as a series of sales reveal the extent of the correction. The sale of Canary Wharf's 5 Churchill Place, a 12-storey office block, shows lenders facing losses, with some bids being less than the amount of rent still owed by tenant JPMorgan. The post-pandemic surge in hybrid working and abrupt increase in finance costs have battered the market, with older buildings struggling to attract tenants. Lenders are facing credit losses and uncertainty about office occupational demand, with some buildings seeing values drop by 50% or more.

images.alt_text: The BOE says the buy-to-let market has been consolidating, pointing to evidence of a decline in the number of rental properties.

site_title: China to push for higher grain yields to ensure food security
summary: China aims to increase grain yields to ensure food security, following a record corn crop and bumper harvests of other grains. Policymakers plan to stabilize grain sowing areas and promote large-scale yield increases, with a focus on genetically modified corn. China's reliance on overseas imports, particularly from Brazil, is expected to continue, with Brazil surpassing the US as the country's largest corn supplier. To boost yields, Chinese corn breeders will plant more genetically modified corn next year.

images.alt_text: After retreating for most of September and October, rice price gains quickened again in November.
Farmer Tanyapong Jaikham and a team of workers plant the seedlings at various spots in the field in the northern province of Chiang Rai to depict cartoon cats, hoping to lure tourists and cat lovers.

site_title: South Korea banks pledge two trillion won amid profit-sharing pressure
summary: South Korea's commercial banks have pledged a combined 2 trillion won (S$2 billion) to support small business owners amid pressure from regulators and politicians to share profits from higher interest rates. The banks will provide a 90% cash refund to borrowers who paid interest above 4%, up to a limit of 200 million won in loans. The move aims to address criticism of banks' profits exceeding those of major companies, with the Financial Services Commission and Korea Federation of Banks leading the initiative.

site_title: Global IPO hopes rise for new year after Fed’s early holiday gift
summary: The global IPO market is expected to recover in 2024, with bankers hopeful that the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate reversal will prompt investors to shift assets to shares. Many stocks that listed in 2023 but fell in the after-market are now trading above their issue price, amid a global rally in equities. Several high-profile IPOs are planned, including a potential $90 billion valuation for Singapore-based fashion group Shein and a reported €1 billion listing for luxury distressed sneakers brand Golden Goose. However, dealmakers note that the market will need to see a few successful IPOs before it can open up to a wider group of companies.

images.alt_text: Interior and exterior of SGX
Britain is keen to shake up listings and other financial rules to boost growth at a time when private money is needed to help the country invest to meet net-zero targets.

site_title: US airlines ready for busier holiday travel after 2022 meltdown
summary: US airlines are better prepared for the holiday travel period this year after last year's congestion, which was exacerbated by storms and operational meltdowns. Airlines for America expects 39 million passengers, a 16% increase from 2022, with US passenger airlines having the largest workforce in two decades. Despite forecasts of record crowds, US airlines do not expect weather disruptions, while Canada's largest airport has increased staffing and expanded de-icing services. International destinations are expected to see a surge in demand, particularly to Caribbean resorts.

images.alt_text: SIA and its budget arm Scoot have carried 3.1 million passengers in November.

site_title: Shanghai, Beijing home sales surge after policy easing
summary: China's major cities, Shanghai and Beijing, saw a surge in home sales after policy easing efforts. Shanghai's new home sales increased by nearly 41% and Beijing's by 122%. The moves, which reduced downpayment ratios and eased mortgage thresholds, aim to boost demand for new and secondary homes. This follows a slump in existing home prices, which tumbled the most in over nine years. The success of these policies will be gauged by future sales figures, which may indicate if the measures can revive the property market.

site_title: GCB deals and prices expected to rise in 2024 on pent-up demand, motivated sellers
summary: The volume of Good Class Bungalow (GCB) transactions in Singapore is expected to pick up in 2024, driven by pent-up demand and realistic price expectations from motivated sellers. This is likely fueled by lower borrowing costs, which will improve the buying mood. The market saw a significant number of unregistered deals in 2023, totaling at least S$700 million, with several high-value transactions recorded this year.

images.alt_text: OK Lim's GCB in Third Avenue was sold for just below S$26.5 million to a Singapore family.
This bungalow in the Nassim Road GCB Area was completed about a decade ago. It changed hands earlier this year for S$88 million or S$3,917 psf on land area.
The Fed has changed the wording of its policy statement last week, to indicate that another rate hike is now unlikely.
This house on 17,905 sq ft of land in Tanglin Hill and completed in 1997 is currently on the market with an asking price of S$52 million or S$2,904 psf.
House along Nassim Road

site_title: South Korea is said to seek fines on HSBC, BNP for naked short selling
summary: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Service has recommended imposing fines of at least 10 billion won (S$7.7 million) each on HSBC Holdings and BNP Paribas for naked short selling, a practice considered illegal in the country. The recommendation was made after discovering "massive" illegal naked short-selling by global investment banks in local stocks. If finalized, the fines would be the country's first penalties on global investment banks for conducting naked short selling and a record for illegal short sellers, following a 3.87 billion won fine imposed earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Small business owners will get a cash refund to the tune of 90 per cent of the interest paid in excess of 4 per cent, up to a limit of 200 million won in loans for one year.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street losses as traders pause after rally
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, following Wall Street losses, as investors paused after a strong rally fueled by expectations of US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in 2024. Data showed inflation slowing and the jobs market softening, while the personal consumption expenditures price index, set for release Friday, could influence the Fed's decision-making. The rally's momentum may wane if the data doesn't surprise, with risk assets potentially rebounding and the year-end rally regaining momentum.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Tokyo and Seoul all rose more than one per cent, while there were also healthy gains in Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, Wellington and Jakarta, though Shanghai struggled.

site_title: SGX RegCo’s resolution with Stamford Land spotlights rules on allotment of rights shares
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) reached a resolution with Stamford Land, where the company's controlling shareholders will donate S$2 million to the SGX Investor Education Fund after violating a rule on allotting excess rights shares to directors and substantial shareholders without satisfying minority shareholder applications. This is the first time SGX RegCo has settled a rule violation in this manner. The regulator emphasized that companies should justify why strict compliance with the rule is not necessary, and minority shareholders should not be denied a "vastly disproportionate" allocation of excess rights shares if they have the money.

images.alt_text: 8 Finsbury Circus in London, which comprises 10 floors of Grade A commercial office units with ancillary retail units, contributed to the company's fair value loss on its investment property.
Stamford Land's Grace A commerical office on 8 Finsbury Circus in London.

site_title: Micron revenue forecast strong, shares jump after hours
summary: Micron Technology forecasted quarterly revenue above market estimates, with shares jumping 5% in extended trading. The company expects a recovery in the memory market, with demand for flash storage and dynamic random access memory improving next year. Supply levels of memory chips are expected to approach normal levels in the first half of 2024, leading to rising memory prices. Micron's adjusted earnings per share are forecasted to be 28 US cents, plus or minus 7 US cents, for the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Micron makes DRAM chips and NAND flash memory chips, and competes with companies including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix.
Micron has said the cyber probe has put half of its China sales at risk.
Micron expects the industry outlook to brighten considerably by 2025 – especially as artificial intelligence systems demand new types of more expensive memory chips.

site_title: Japan government lifts economic growth estimates
summary: Japan's government has raised its economic growth projections for fiscal 2023/24 to 1.6% from 1.3%, citing a recovery in inbound tourism and automobile output. External demand contributed 1.4 percentage points to overall growth. The forecast is slightly higher than the previous estimate of 1.2%. Domestic demand is expected to rebound in the next fiscal year with the help of planned income tax cuts and wage hikes. The government projects 1.3% growth for the next fiscal year and 3% inflation this fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Decades of stop-start fiscal spending and reform have left Japan with the industrial world’s heaviest public debt burden – double the size of its economic output.
Benchmark 10-year JGBs and 20-year bonds would be cut, while liquidity enhancement bills would be increased.
Japan’s economy experienced its sharpest contraction since the height of the pandemic in the three months to September.

site_title: Pioneer owner weighs sale of Japanese electronics maker
summary: BPEA EQT, the buyout firm that acquired Pioneer in 2019, is considering selling the Japanese electronics maker due to interest from potential buyers. A potential sale could value Pioneer at around US$1.5 billion. The firm has been discussing a sale with advisers and other industry players have shown preliminary interest in acquiring the asset. Pioneer, known for its audio and car navigation equipment, has shifted its focus to the autonomous car market. No final decisions have been made, and the buyout firm could still decide against a sale.

site_title: Gold prices gain on softer US dollar, Treasury yields
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,033.92 per ounce due to a softer US dollar and lower Treasury yields, as traders await November US inflation data for insights into the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook. Benchmark US 10-year bond yields fell to a five-month low, making gold less expensive for other currency holders. The US dollar was down 0.1% against its rivals, and Fed officials have signaled openness to lowering short-term borrowing costs, despite pushing back against rapid rate cuts in 2024.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates decrease the opportunity cost of holding nonyielding bullion and weigh on the US dollar, making gold cheaper for investors holding other currencies.

site_title: Boeing closer to resuming China 737 MAX deliveries after regulator nod: report
summary: Boeing has won clearance from China's aviation regulator, moving closer to resuming deliveries of 737 MAX aircraft to China after a four-year freeze. Individual deliveries still require approval from China's National Development and Reform Commission. The CAAC had previously welcomed Boeing's development in the Chinese market, and a test flight of a MAX aircraft for China Southern Airlines was observed. Restarting deliveries would symbolize the re-opening of doors to a key aerospace market, which Boeing projects will compose 20% of global aircraft demand by 2042.

images.alt_text: Boeing has been grappling with supply disruption at a time when it is saddled with almost US$40 billion of debt stemming from the Covid-19 travel slump and an earlier 737 MAX safety crisis.
Stephanie Pope, 51, will step into the newly-created post of Boeing executive vice-president and chief operating officer on Jan 1, reporting to CEO David Calhoun.
Boeing is willing to “actively deepen cooperation with China, work together to promote the development of the aviation industry, according to
Sources say Boeing now expects it will produce 42 of its 737s per month starting in February 2024.

site_title: Morgan Stanley mulls private credit fund bet with balance sheet
summary: Morgan Stanley is considering allocating a portion of its balance sheet into a new private credit fund, potentially raising $4 billion to $5 billion from external investors. The fund would focus on making large senior-secured loans to closely-held borrowers. This move underscores the shift in debt financing, as private lenders have gained competitiveness, allowing banks to miss out on fees. Other major banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and Barclays, are also exploring similar private credit strategies.

site_title: Property crisis lures global powerhouses to Australian rentals
summary: Global investors, including Blackstone and Brookfield, are pouring money into Australia's multifamily apartment market, where rental vacancies are around 1%. The sector is expected to grow to $10 billion by 2030, driven by favorable tax policies and a tight rental market. Heavyweight investors are investing in build-to-rent projects, with over $14 billion in institutional commitments. However, challenges remain, including underwriting risk in nascent markets and construction issues, which could impact the sector's growth and profitability.

images.alt_text: Airbnb received more than 2,000 complaints from Australian customers over being charged in US dollars during this period.

In his mid-year economic and fiscal outlook, Australia's Labor Treasurer Jim Chalmers projected a budget deficit of just A$1.1 billion (S$968 million) in the year to end June 2024, down from A$13.9 billion forecasted back in May.

site_title: Wells Fargo becomes first major US bank with a unionised branch
summary: Wells Fargo has become the first major US bank to unionise its workforce, with employees at a branch in Albuquerque, NM, voting 5-3 to join the Communications Workers of America's Wells Fargo Workers United. The unionisation effort aims to improve wages and working conditions, including pushing back against aggressive sales tactics. The union drive follows similar efforts at other Wells Fargo branches, with employees in Bethel, Alaska, set to vote on unionisation. Wells Fargo has vowed to fight the unionisation effort, citing its preference for direct relationships with workers over union negotiations.

images.alt_text: The proposed class action filed in San Francisco federal court claims Wells Fargo improperly classified “senior premier bankers” as management-level employees who are exempt from overtime pay under federal and state laws.
The move shows that even firms that are seeking to gain investment-banking market share are trimming their workforces in a slow dealmaking environment.
Wells Fargo beat analysts’ expectations for net interest income in the third quarter and raised its full-year guidance again as it continues to benefit from higher interest rates
FILE PHOTO: A customer enters the Wells Fargo bank branch in Golden, Colorado October 11, 2013.  REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: UK business confidence slips in December, economic concerns weigh: Lloyds
summary: UK business confidence fell to 35% in December, the largest monthly decline in over a year, according to a survey by Lloyds Bank. The decline follows official figures showing Britain's gross domestic product shrank 0.3% in October. Businesses are becoming more downbeat about the economic outlook, with hiring intentions cooling and pricing expectations falling for the first time since July. Economists attribute the decline to cost pressures and a challenging labour market, with minimum wage increases set to rise in April 2024.

images.alt_text: Britain is keen to shake up listings and other financial rules to boost growth at a time when private money is needed to help the country invest to meet net-zero targets.

The “step change” aims to bolster consumer protection against authorised push payment (APP) fraud, a common scam whereby people are tricked into sending money from their account to a fraudster posing as genuine payee.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, SIA Engineering
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit sold three logistics properties in Queensland, Australia for S$64.2 million, with net proceeds expected to be S$60.8 million. SIA Engineering Company signed a 15-year lease agreement for two hangars in Subang, Malaysia, establishing its third base-maintenance hub in the Asia-Pacific region. The deals may affect the trading of their securities.

site_title: Apple ramps up Vision Pro production, aiming for launch by February
summary: Apple is ramping up production of its Vision Pro mixed-reality headset, aiming for a launch by February. Production has been running at full speed in China, with customer-bound units expected to be ready by the end of January. The rollout will be complex, requiring new sales strategies and equipment, and will focus on making a good first impression. Apple is also training retail employees to market the product, which will be priced at $3,500 and has a two-hour battery life. The company hopes the Vision Pro will be successful in both consumer and corporate markets, with plans for a lower-cost model in the future.

images.alt_text: Apple has known for almost two months that a ban on its smartwatch sales imposed by ITC would take effect Dec 25 unless it persuades the Biden administration to intervene – or works out a settlement with Masimo.
Apple plans to stop selling the prohibited watches on its website on Thursday and then pull them from its roughly 270 brick-and-mortar outlets by Dec 24.
Apple has paused the sales of its Series 9 and Ultra 2 smartwatches after an order in October from the US International Trade Commission.

site_title: Citigroup is exiting distressed debt trading
summary: Citigroup is exiting its distressed debt trading business, a move aimed at reshaping the firm to achieve higher returns. The decision, part of CEO Jane Fraser's restructuring efforts, will impact around 20 positions and follows recent exits from municipal bond trading and underwriting. This move will remove a key player in distressed debt markets, joining other major banks such as Bank of America and Goldman Sachs in this field. The business had outperformed in 2021 but slowed significantly in the following years, in line with its volatile nature.

images.alt_text: Citigroup has retrenched in other areas in China, including shutting down its consumer banking business and selling its retail wealth management portfolio.
Citi’s municipal offering business has been under scrutiny from the Texas attorney general.
FILE PHOTO: The logo for Citibank is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Electric cars with recycled batteries are the next green holy grail
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) market is facing a growing need for efficient battery recycling due to the country's rapid EV adoption. Small-time traders, like 29-year-old Li, are collecting and selling used batteries to extract valuable metals like lithium, cobalt, and nickel. However, this unregulated market poses significant safety risks and undermines the credibility of China's recycled batteries. The government has introduced regulations, but enforcement power is lacking. Major players like GEM, which processes 10% of China's retired EV batteries, are calling for stricter rules to ensure a healthier market and lower costs for automakers. A well-regulated system could help China cement its position as a leader in the EV market, reduce carbon footprints, and better market its cars overseas.

images.alt_text: “After careful deliberations, we have made the decision not to move forward with developing the site,” Panasonic Energy says in a statement.
VinFast will supply the used batteries and Marubeni will repurpose into what it said would be affordable Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) that were easy to manufacture.
Zeekr says its upcoming 007 sedan would be the first model to be equipped with the fast-charging LFP batteries.
China starts to require export permits for additional graphite products from this month, raising fears of tighter global supplies of the material used in refractories and batteries.

site_title: Greenback edges up; sterling slides on inflation surprise
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.3% to 102.38, edging up against other major currencies, while sterling fell 0.6% after British inflation data showed a slowdown in the headline rate. Analysts expect no significant catalyst for US dollar moves until the US publishes its inflation data on Friday. The euro eased 0.4% and the yen fell 0.3% against the US dollar. European Central Bank policymaker Joachim Nagel warned traders to be cautious on upcoming rate cuts, citing the need for high interest rates in the eurozone.

site_title: BlackBerry posts surprise quarterly profit on resilient cybersecurity demand
summary: BlackBerry reported a surprise quarterly profit of 1 cent per share, driven by resilient demand for cybersecurity services amid rising online threats. Despite dwindling IT spending, cybersecurity-related expenditure remained stable. The company plans to simplify its corporate structure and split its IoT and cybersecurity businesses into standalone divisions. BlackBerry expects fourth-quarter revenue of $150-159 million and fourth-quarter operating cashflow usage to be further reduced. This marks a significant turnaround from a year-ago loss of five cents per share.

images.alt_text: BlackBerry will streamline its centralised corporate functions so that each business unit may operate independently and on a profitable and cashflow-positive basis.

site_title: How tech can help humans in HR
summary: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) can improve HR productivity by leveraging technology and job redesign. Digital applicant tracking systems and robotic process automation can help streamline tasks, freeing HR professionals to focus on strategic initiatives. Automation can also reduce manual errors and free up resources for employee concerns. Predictive analytics, data-driven insights, and e-learning platforms can facilitate data-driven decisions and targeted development plans. While technology will reshape HR roles, the human touch remains indispensable for a positive employee experience, and ethical and fair hiring practices remain crucial.

images.alt_text: The accounting industry in Singapore certainly holds a bright future with technology, innovative job redesign strategies and a diverse talent pool.
The Job Redesign Centre of Excellence was launched by Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng at the 2023 People Behind People Forum, IHRP’s annual signature event for the human resources industry.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open, tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% lower on Thursday, tracking a decline on Wall Street, where most indices ended sharply lower. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 5.41 points to 3,102.62, with losers outnumbering gainers 83 to 34. Key losers included Seatrium, Thai Beverage, and Rex International, while banking stocks were mixed. US stocks declined after a week-long rally, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 1.3% to 37,082.

images.alt_text: ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.

site_title: South Korea’s early exports show recovery momentum picks up
summary: South Korea's early trade data showed a 13% increase in exports from a year ago, driven by a 19.2% rise in chip exports and a 27.7% increase in automobile exports. Shipments to the US rose 30.2%, while those to Vietnam increased 13.8%. The recovery in South Korean trade supports the view of policymakers that exports will drive economic growth of over 2% in 2024. However, shipments to China remain slow, and the recovery could be patchy due to factors such as higher interest rates and China's real estate market situation.

images.alt_text: outh Korea’s year-on-year inflation eased to 3.3 per cent for the first time in four months in November.
South Korea this year enacted legislation on virtual assets to bring cryptocurrency markets under regulatory control for investor protection. It will come into effect from July 2024.
Low fertility threatens to undermine South Korea’s economic future by shrinking its workforce and slowing consumption.

site_title: Director of 980 companies jailed, fined over neglect of duty on money laundering discovery
summary: A 37-year-old Singaporean man, Xie Yong, was sentenced to four weeks' jail and fined S$57,000 for neglecting his duty in discovering money laundering in companies he directed, which totaled 980. Xie offered accounting and corporate services to foreign clients seeking to incorporate companies in Singapore. The case highlights the severity of corporate governance and the importance of detecting financial irregularities.

images.alt_text: pixgeneric
Wong Pei Ting

site_title: US: Dow falls 1.3% to break streak of records
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.3% to 37,082.00, snapping a five-day streak of record closes, amid disappointing FedEx results and a weakening demand forecast. In contrast, consumer confidence data showed an unexpected surge in December.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 37.79 points, or 0.10 per cent, at the open to 37,520.13.

site_title: Warner Bros is in talks to merge with Paramount Global
summary: Warner Bros Discovery is in talks with Paramount Global to merge, combining two of the world's largest media companies. The discussions, led by CEO David Zaslav and Paramount's Bob Bakish, come after a meeting on December 19. Paramount is controlled by the Redstone family through National Amusements, a family holding company. The talks are preliminary and may not result in an agreement, but the potential deal could create a media giant.

images.alt_text: The project is expected to create some 4,000 direct and indirect jobs in the UK, the company said in a statement.
FILE PHOTO: The exterior of the Warner Bros. Discovery Atlanta campus is pictured in Atlanta, Georgia, U.S. May 2, 2023. REUTERS/Alyssa Pointer/File Photo

site_title: US housing market shows signs of life after mortgage rates fall
summary: The US housing market is showing signs of life after mortgage rates fell by over one percentage point in eight weeks, the largest drop since 2009. Housing starts surged to a six-month high, sales of previously owned homes picked up, and builder optimism increased. Americans' home-buying plans rose, with consumers expecting lower interest rates and a improving economy. Although the pace of activity remains subdued, the decline in mortgage rates and lack of supply create an ideal setup for homebuilders, with sales up 20% this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Real estate signs advertise new homes for sale in multiple new developments in York County, South Carolina, U.S., February 29, 2020. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher on UK inflation cheer, Argenx sinks on failed drug study
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% as the UK's FTSE 100 index jumped 1.0% due to signs of fast-cooling inflation in Britain, boosting bets on interest rate cuts. However, shares of Belgian pharmaceutical company Argenx fell after a failed drug study. The pan-European Stoxx 600 closed higher, despite a pause in other main regional markets as investors weighed ECB policymakers' comments.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 has lagged its US peer S&P 500’s 24 per cent yearly advance, with the latter also benefiting from investors flocking to artificial intelligence stocks.

site_title: Trump barred from Colorado ballot in unprecedented ruling
summary: Colorado's Supreme Court has ruled that Donald Trump is ineligible to run for president due to his efforts to overturn the 2020 election results, citing a post-Civil War-era provision of the US Constitution. The 4-3 ruling bars Trump from the state's March 5 primary ballot, but he can appeal until January 4. The ruling comes as Trump leads in the Republican primary, setting the stage for a potential rematch against President Biden. The decision is expected to head to the US Supreme Court, where it could influence the outcome of the 2024 presidential election.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential candidate and former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at a rally in Durham, New Hampshire, U.S. December 16, 2023. REUTERS/Brian Snyder

site_title: US consumer confidence surges by most since early 2021
summary: US consumer confidence surged in December, the largest increase since early 2021, as Americans grew more optimistic about the labor market and inflation. The Conference Board's index rose to 110.7, exceeding the median forecast of 104.5. Consumers' expectations for business conditions and incomes improved, while expected inflation six months ahead fell to its lowest level since late 2020. Despite higher prices overall, savings and higher wages allowed consumers to maintain spending, a positive sign for the US economy.

images.alt_text: S&P Global flash US Composite PMI Output Index, which tracks the manufacturing and services sectors, increases to a five-month high of 51.0 this month from 50.7 in November.
Business inventories dip 0.1 per cent, the first decline since June, after increasing 0.2 per cent in September.

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - NOVEMBER 24: A Costumer visits the store on early morning Black Friday Sales at Macy's herald square on November 24, 2023 in New York City. The National Retail Federation projects that an estimated 182 million are planning to shop in-store and online through the five-day Thanksgiving weekend.   Kena Betancur/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by KENA BETANCUR / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

(FILES) In this file photo taken on September 24, 2022 Ford Motor Co. battery powered F-150 Lightning trucks under production at their Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan. - Ford will resume production on its F-150 Lightning electric truck on March 13, more than five weeks after a battery fire brought operations to a halt, the company said March 2, 2023. (Photo by JEFF KOWALSKY / AFP)
People shop in a supermarket as inflation affected consumer prices in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., June 10, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
The University of Michigan’s preliminary reading of its Consumer Sentiment Index shot up to 69.4, the highest since August, from November’s final reading of 61.3.
Employment gains are well above the 100,000 jobs per month needed to keep up with growth in the working age population.

site_title: US existing home sales edge up in November but still gloomy
summary: US existing home sales rose 0.8% to an annual rate of 3.82 million in November, according to the National Association of Realtors. Despite a slight increase, sales remain low due to high mortgage rates. The median home price rose 4% to $387,600, and analysts expect a durable recovery until mortgage rates fall further, likely in the second half of next year. NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun remains optimistic, citing a recent plunge in mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage falls 24 basis points in the week ended Dec 15.
A house under construction in New Jersey. Builders in the US are benefiting from a shortfall in listings of previously owned homes.
As mortgage rates rise, builders have been forced to cut prices since the summer in an effort to boost affordability.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage falls by 10 basis points to 7.07 per cent in the week ended Dec 8.

site_title: Panasonic says Oklahoma no longer candidate for new battery plant
summary: Panasonic Energy has decided not to move forward with developing a new electric vehicle battery plant in Oklahoma, citing careful deliberations. The company had previously considered building a plant in Oklahoma, its third in the US, but ultimately chose not to pursue the project. This decision comes after Panasonic chose Kansas for its second plant in the US last year, and will not impact operations in Nevada or Kansas. The company will continue to consider possibilities for expanding its North America business.

images.alt_text: Analysts say Panasonic could be following in the footsteps of Hitachi which in recent years sold off several businesses to transform into a digitally driven service firm.
Panasonic lowers its full-year operating profit forecast for the energy unit that makes batteries for Tesla and other automakers to 115 billion yen (S$215 million) from 135 billion yen.

site_title: Houthi leader threatens to attack US warships if Washington targets Yemen
summary: Houthi leader Abdel-Malek al-Houthi threatened to attack US warships if Washington targets Yemen, following the US-led security initiative to counter Houthi attacks on commercial vessels in the Red Sea. The Houthis have fired drones and missiles at international vessels, prompting major shipping lines to reroute around Africa. The US-led security initiative involves 11 countries patrolling the Red Sea to deter future Houthi attacks, which have disrupted a key trade route linking Europe and North America with Asia.

images.alt_text: According to logistics giant Kuehne+Nagel, 103 container vessels are rerouting from the Red Sea around Africa.

epa11014316 The Galaxy Leader cargo ship, seized by the Houthis offshore of the Al-Salif port on the Red Sea in the province of Hodeidah, Yemen, 05 December 2023 (issued 06 December 2023). Yemen's Houthis on 06 December 2023 claimed responsibility for the launch of the barrage of ballistic missiles toward Israel in support of the Palestinian people in the Gaza Strip, according to a statement by Houthis spokesman Yahya Saree. The Houthis vowed to continue their efforts to prevent Israeli ships from navigating in the Arabian and Red Seas, in retaliation for Israel's airstrikes on the Gaza Strip. Thousands of Israelis and Palestinians have died since the militant group Hamas launched an unprecedented attack on Israel from the Gaza Strip on 07 October, and the Israeli strikes on the Palestinian enclave which followed it.  EPA-EFE/YAHYA ARHAB
The Galaxy Leader, a car transportation vessel, has been seized by Houthi militants in the Red Sea. Incidents such as this have caused shipping carriers to detour via the Cape of Good Hope.

A Houthi fighter keeps watch on the deck of the Galaxy Leader cargo ship, seized by the Houthis on 5 Dec this year. Responding to attacks by the militants, the US is leading a multinational operation to safeguard commerce in the Red Sea.

site_title: Orchestrate a supply chain transformation in 2024
summary: A significant shift is expected in supply chain management in 2024, driven by the need to address environmental concerns and align with corporate financial goals. Supply chains will increasingly focus on driving efficiency, reducing waste, and incorporating digital assets and services. This requires a strategic approach known as supply chain orchestration, which brings together physical, digital, and financial assets to meet customer expectations and preserve the planet. The integration of technology, such as AI and machine learning, will play a crucial role in achieving these goals, enabling real-time transparency, hyper agility, and more resilient supply chains.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia has emerged as an attractive location in today's business landscape, as companies look to manage supply costs and mitigate risks.
Given the intersection of trade flows here, Singapore is in a strong position to help drive and promote leading practices in supply chains.

Unstable geopolitics and the possible re-emergence of pandemics have created new challenges beyond the usual price-value trade-offs in procurement from a simple focus on just cost, quality and delivery.

Singapore’s robust legal and regulatory framework can offer businesses much-needed stability, while other countries may contribute through strong manufacturing bases, abundant labour or advanced technologies.

site_title: Toyota recalling 1.1 million vehicles over potential airbag issue
summary: Toyota is recalling 1.1 million vehicles worldwide due to a potential airbag issue. The recall affects 2020-2022 model year vehicles, including various Toyota and Lexus models, due to a short circuit in a sensor that could cause airbags not to deploy as designed. The issue, which could result in the Occupant Classification System (OCS) sensors not working, affects one million vehicles in the US. Dealers will inspect and replace the sensors if necessary, and owners will be notified in February. This recall is related to a similar issue that occurred in 2022.

site_title: Oil settles up on Red Sea tensions; gains capped by US stock builds
summary: Oil prices rose slightly after a choppy trading session, with Brent crude futures up 47 US cents and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 28 US cents, settling at $79.70 and $74.22 barrels, respectively. The gains were limited by a surprise US crude inventory build and record domestic oil production. Tensions in the Middle East, following attacks on ships by Yemen's Houthi forces in the Red Sea, contributed to the price increase. A US-led task force to safeguard commerce in the region was also seen as a factor.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose US$1.28, or 1.6 per cent, to settle at US$79.23 a barrel, the highest since Dec 1.

site_title: Over 100 container ships reroute as US weighs Red Sea response
summary: Over 100 container ships are rerouting from the Red Sea due to attacks by Yemen-based Houthi militants, creating extra costs and delays for global trade. The US is weighing its response, considering strikes or diplomacy, amid concerns about provoking the Houthis. Companies are also exploring alternative routes, including rail and air, and insurance premiums are surging. The disruptions are expected to have a moderate economic impact, with higher prices for goods, but are seen as less severe than the 2021 Suez Canal shutdown.

images.alt_text: epa11014316 The Galaxy Leader cargo ship, seized by the Houthis offshore of the Al-Salif port on the Red Sea in the province of Hodeidah, Yemen, 05 December 2023 (issued 06 December 2023). The Houthis vowed to continue their efforts to prevent Israeli ships from navigating in the Arabian and Red Seas, in retaliation for Israel's airstrikes on the Gaza Strip. Thousands of Israelis and Palestinians have died since the militant group Hamas launched an unprecedented attack on Israel from the Gaza Strip on 07 October, and the Israeli strikes on the Palestinian enclave which followed it.
