summary: Hiap Hoe is purchasing Great Eastern Motor Lodge in Western Australia for A$40 million, with directors believing it offers high occupancy levels and potential for increased recurrent income streams. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust's tenant Kleio One-Solution has launched a counterclaim against the Reit's trustee over outstanding fees.

site_title: Spotify’s push into audiobooks sparks concern among authors
summary: Spotify has introduced complimentary audiobooks to its millions of subscribers as part of their monthly subscriptions, partnering with the Big Five publishers. However, US authors are concerned that the shift to streaming will reduce their earnings, with some arguing that they will only receive full royalties for complete listens, not partial ones. A new coalition, led by venture capitalist Bradley Tusk, is demanding more transparency from Spotify about its payment model, particularly how authors will be compensated.

images.alt_text: A tech platform should not be allowed to use its market power to steadily decrease payments to content creators, to sell user data and to price gouge advertisers.
Spotify CEO Daniel Ek says a reduction of this size will feel surprisingly large given the recent positive earnings report and its performance.
From early 2024, Spotify will require a minimum of 1,000 streams over 12 months before paying out royalties.

site_title: FedEx profit misses, cuts full-year revenue forecast, shares sink
summary: FedEx reported a quarterly profit that fell short of analysts' targets, with adjusted earnings increasing 23% to $1.01 billion, but shares sank 8.5% due to a cut in full-year revenue forecast. The company cited volatile macroeconomic conditions affecting customer demand, leading to a low single-digit percentage decline in revenue. FedEx expects to shelter profits by slashing costs and combining its Express and Ground delivery units, and plans to repurchase an additional $1 billion of common stock in 2024.

images.alt_text: “Given the softness in air cargo demand across the industry and current FedEx flight operations staffing levels, we shared information about this unique opportunity with our pilots,” says FedEx.

SingPost's Singapore CEO Neo Su Yin (left) and FedEx Express Singapore's managing director, Eric Tan (right). Both companies are conducting a trial for SingPost post offices to accept FedEx parcels at POPStop counters.
The global shipping downturn has hurt margins for the sector and FedEx’s challenge is matching costs and capacity to lower demand.

site_title: Britain proposes post-Brexit easing of company listings rules
summary: Britain's markets watchdog, the Financial Conduct Authority, proposes a single entry point for company listings to simplify and speed up the process, aiming to boost growth and compete with New York and EU centers. The move is part of a broader effort to attract private investment to meet the country's net-zero targets. The proposal merges the premium and standard listings into a single "commercial" listing, expected to ease rules and attract more companies to list in London. This is the largest shake-up of its kind in three decades, following Brexit.

images.alt_text: The improving mood in the services industry offset pessimism among manufacturers.
Britain’s economy has flat-lined till 2023 but earnings are now outpacing inflation again.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb on optimism over interest rate cuts
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Dec 19, driven by easing government bond yields and cooling inflation data in the eurozone. The Stoxx 600 lagged its US peer S&P 500's 24% yearly advance, but investors remain optimistic about interest rate cuts from major central banks in 2024. The travel and leisure index led sectoral gains, followed by miners and financial services.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 edged 0.3 per cent lower after the benchmark logged its first five-week winning streak since April on Friday.

site_title: Why is MAS suspending third-party channels for remittances to China?
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has suspended third-party channels for remitting money to China from January 1 to March 31, 2024, citing cases of remittances being frozen by Chinese law enforcement agencies. Licensed remittance companies in Singapore will need to use bank channels instead, with the aim of protecting consumers from potential losses. The suspension follows reports of over 670 cases of remittances being frozen, with a total affected amount of S$13 million.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

In line with the newly introduced Payment Services Act, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has initiated a payments regulatory evaluation programme to help payment services firms in their transition.

From left: Choo Wan Sim, head of UOB TMRW Digital (Singapore) and Jacquelyn Tan, head of group personal financial services showcasing the "scan to pay" feature on UOB TMRW App. UOB customers in Singapore can now use the function to make payments when they travel to Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia.  PHOTO: UOB

TEN FOREIGN NATIONALS TO BE CHARGED FOR OFFENCES INCLUDING FORGERY AND MONEY LAUNDERING WITH AN ESTIMATED VALUE OF ABOUT ONE BILLION IN CASH AND VARIOUS ASSETS SEIZED, FROZEN OR ISSUED WITH PROHIBITION OF DISPOSAL ORDERSThe total value of the properties and other goods seized in the recent raid amounts to over S$1 billion.

site_title: Volkswagen cost-cutting drive includes less staff, faster development
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to a cost-cutting drive with worker representatives, aiming to save 10 billion euros by 2026. The measures include reducing staff costs, speeding up development and production times, and implementing an efficient procurement strategy. The plan includes slashing administrative staff costs by a fifth, reducing product development cycles, and cutting production times. The company also plans to generate additional revenue through optimized after-sales business and reducing test vehicle usage by 50%.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen's November deliveries in China, dampened by lockdowns last year, grow 32.4 per cent, beating the average growth in the market of 26.6 per cent.
Volkswagen says the focus would be on “partial retirement and early retirement schemes to the maximum extent possible”.
Volkswagen wound down the site’s operations after the pandemic, reducing the number of staff from a peak of 650 to 197, of which just under a quarter are Uyghur.

site_title: TikTok deal gives Tokopedia a third chance at success
summary: Indonesia's largest tech company, GoTo, has agreed to cede operational control of its struggling e-commerce unit, Tokopedia, to social media giant TikTok. In the deal, TikTok will take a 75.01% stake in the merged entity, with GoTo owning the remaining 24.99%. Tokopedia will pay $340 million to acquire TikTok's business contracts and exclusive rights to operate TikTok Shop in Indonesia, while TikTok will invest an additional $1 billion in the new entity. The partnership aims to revive Tokopedia's fortunes and give TikTok a strong foothold in Indonesia's e-commerce market.

images.alt_text: Sea is likely to register lower earnings as Shopee is expected to suffer greater losses in the intensified e-commerce competition.
GoTo believes its profitability measures will pay off by the end of this year, but at the expense of GTV and transaction growth.

site_title: US launches Red Sea force as ships reroute to avoid attacks
summary: The US has launched a multinational operation, dubbed "Operation Prosperity Guardian," to safeguard commerce in the Red Sea amid increased attacks by Iran-backed Yemeni Houthi militants. The Houthis have stepped up missile and drone attacks on international vessels, forcing major shipping companies like BP and Maersk to reroute shipments, adding days to journey times and costs. The US, along with 9 other nations, will conduct joint patrols in the southern Red Sea and Gulf of Aden to deter the attacks. The operation aims to protect global trade and prevent a wider regional conflict.

images.alt_text: Cargo ship Galaxy Leader has been anchored off a Yemeni port controlled by Houthi rebels since it was seized by armed men in November.
The recent gains for shipping shares have provided some relief for investors after a year of underperformance for the sector.

site_title: Music royalty fund Hipgnosis delays HY results amid asset valuation doubts
summary: Hipgnosis Songs Fund, a music royalty fund, has delayed its half-year results due to concerns over the valuation of its assets. The company's investment adviser expressed doubts about the valuation, citing a higher figure than recent transactions in the sector. The board has also raised concerns about the value of assets in the results. Hipgnosis expects to publish the interim results by December 31. This delay casts doubt on the credibility of the independent valuer, Citrin Cooperman, and raises questions about the fund's ability to regain shareholder trust.

images.alt_text: Katy Perry has sold the rights to most of her music for a cool US$225 million to Litmus Music, in the latest in a series of high-profile payouts.
The estate of Michael Jackson is closing in on a deal to sell half its interests in the megastar's music catalogue, in a deal worth up to US$900 million, Variety reported on Feb 8, 2023.
Bloomberg reported in December that Bieber’s stake could fetch about US$200 million.

site_title: Iata calls Dutch Schiphol airport’s capacity proposal ‘a disgrace’
summary: International Air Transport Association (IATA) criticized Amsterdam Schiphol airport's proposed 460,000 flight limit in 2024 as "a disgrace," calling for an urgent action plan to restore confidence. The proposal is lower than industry demands but higher than environmentalist and residents' groups want. Schiphol's previous capacity was 483,000 flights, but the Dutch government scrapped plans for a cap in November. IATA claims the airport is making excuses for its operational issues and is causing damage to schedule planning worldwide, destroying confidence in the Netherlands' aviation position.

images.alt_text: “This decision is significantly more damaging than people have estimated,” says Iata head Willie Walsh.
“I truly believe SAF will always be priced at a premium to kerosene,” says Willie Walsh, director general of the International Air Transport Association (IATA).

site_title: ECB raises capital demands for 20 banks over bad loans
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has raised capital demands for 20 European banks due to inadequate provisions for bad loans. The move aims to ensure banks cover potential delinquencies amid a surge in interest rates and economic slowdown. The ECB will continue its focus on credit and liquidity risks in 2024, with a focus on climate-related requirements. The bank expects higher interest rates to increase funding costs and volatility, potentially boosting soured loans. The ECB aims to address these risks and maintain financial stability.

images.alt_text: Aside from price growth, Stournaras says “unit labour costs, unit profits and inflation expectations must all point to inflation going back to 2 per cent”.

site_title: Tenant of Sabana Reit launches counterclaim; allegations ‘misconceived’, Reit manager says
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust's (Reit) tenant Kleio One-Solution has launched a counterclaim against the Reit, despite admitting to being in arrears on rent payments. The Reit's manager considers the counterclaim "misconceived" and is seeking legal advice to challenge the allegations. The Reit's manager has not specified the allegations, but is exploring the possibility of applying for summary judgement against Kleio One-Solution. The Reit's units closed flat after the announcement.

images.alt_text: The trustee is seeking, among others, possession of the premises in Penjuru Lane as well as outstanding fixed rent, land rent, property tax and late payment interest of around S$2.1 million.
Sabana Reit gives more details of profit rate swaps, plans to pay out unused retained distributable income

site_title: Yen tumbles as BOJ sticks with ultra-loose policy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, as expected, and did not signal a change. This led to a 1.3% jump in the US dollar against the yen, with the euro also rising. The BOJ governor stated that the prospects for achieving the inflation target are "gradually heightening," but no specific timeline was provided. The BOJ's decision did not sway market expectations of rate cuts in 2024, with the US dollar still down over 4% since early October.

site_title: Independent financial adviser deems offer for Amara ‘fair and reasonable’
summary: Independent financial adviser Xandar Capital has deemed the S$0.60 per share offer from a consortium linked to Amara Holdings' CEO Albert Teo as "fair and reasonable" for the hotel group. The IFA estimates Amara's share value between S$0.53 and S$0.54, despite a 51.89% discount to its revalued net asset value (RNAV) per share. The offer, which has been accepted by 51.2% of shareholders, will be funded by interest-free loans and a bank loan.

images.alt_text: Amara Singapore Hotel

site_title: The 10 priciest NYC home sales show market doing ‘pretty darn well’
summary: New York City's ultra-luxury housing market is showing signs of stability, with 240 contracts signed for homes priced $10 million or more, compared to 235 last year. The top 10 most expensive sales this year include seven on billionaire's Row, with condos dominating the market. Despite slower sales and lower prices, the market is still holding up well, with aggregate sales totaling $650.9 million, a slight increase from last year's $640.7 million. The rich are still very rich, according to broker Donna Olshan, who attributes the market's resilience to its predictability.

images.alt_text: The report found that if about 220 office buildings were converted to housing, they could produce 54% less carbon emissions by 2050. That would be a decrease of up to 11 million tons of carbon dioxide.

site_title: Toshiba to be delisted after 74 years, faces future with new owners
summary: Toshiba, a Japanese conglomerate, will be delisted from the Tokyo exchange after 74 years following a US$14 billion takeover by a group of investors led by private equity firm Japan Industrial Partners. The new owners, including utility Chubu Electric Power and chipmaker Rohm, are expected to focus on high-margin digital services. Toshiba's CEO Taro Shimada will remain in his role, and the company's future is uncertain, with some industry insiders suggesting a potential split of its assets and operations.

images.alt_text: Toshiba has received a report from the buyer, a group led by Japan Industrial Partners (JIP), that the tender offer “is forecasted to be successful,” the company says

site_title: Ex-SGX global head of equity capital markets Nasser now in growth advisory consulting
summary: Former SGX global head of equity capital markets Mohamed Nasser Ismail has joined growth advisory firm JP Wilson, where he heads the newly established capital markets strategy arm. Nasser advises companies in South-east Asia on raising capital through private or public markets, including IPOs, which require meticulous planning and timely execution. He joined JP Wilson in November, after leaving SGX at the end of October.

images.alt_text: Mohamed Nasser Ismail, who has worked at the exchange for the past 18 years, will leave at the end of October for other opportunities, the exchange said.

site_title: US single-family housing starts surge in November
summary: US single-family housing starts surged 18% in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.143 million units, exceeding economists' forecasts. The jump was driven by declining mortgage rates, which averaged 6.95% last week, the lowest level since August. Single-family homebuilding could gain further momentum, with builders reducing prices to boost sales. Overall housing starts rose 14.8% to 1.560 million units, with activity moderating as builders work through a large stock of apartment buildings under construction.

images.alt_text: A living room inside 220 Central Park South.
As mortgage rates rise, builders have been forced to cut prices since the summer in an effort to boost affordability.

site_title: Bank of America will devote more capital to trading, says CEO Moynihan
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan announced the bank will devote more capital to trading as it seeks to increase market share. This move comes after the bank increased its trading division size three to four years ago, which has shown positive results. Moynihan stated that loan balance growth on the commercial side has been sluggish due to higher borrowing costs and economic concerns. Despite this, the bank expects a soft landing rather than a recession and sees consumers continuing to spend 4-5% more this year than last year.

images.alt_text: Brian Moynihan, chief executive officer of Bank of America Corp., departs after a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 6, 2023. The heads of the biggest US banks will use the hearing to make their case for watering down rule proposals they argue will harm the economy. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Accenture forecasts Q2 revenue below estimates on IT spending weakness
summary: Accenture forecasts Q2 revenue between $15.4 billion and $16 billion, below Wall Street estimates, due to cautious IT spending by clients amid macroeconomic uncertainty. The company expects IT services spending to remain muted in the near term, with slower budget-related decision-making, particularly in tech and media companies. This is in line with Accenture's previous warning of slower budget-related decision-making.

images.alt_text: Tham, Accenture's new country managing director for Singapore, will be in charge of leading the firm's business in Singapore.
Accenture, which consults and services various clients on generative AI projects, says it will have 80,000 people working on AI as it hires, buys other companies and trains more employees.

site_title: It’s Christmastime in the cosmos
summary: Astronomers have released Christmas-themed images of celestial phenomena, including the Christmas Tree Galaxy Cluster and the remnants of a 340-year-old star, Cassiopeia A. Using data from the James Webb Space Telescope, researchers detected 14 stars in the galaxy cluster that flicker like Christmas tree lights due to gravitational lensing. These observations provide insight into ancient galactic neighborhoods and the cosmic evolution of our solar system. The images are part of a tradition of connecting the season of light with cosmic events, with NASA releasing a White House advent calendar featuring images of celestial bodies.

images.alt_text: The launch comes on the heels of North Korea placing its first spy satellite into orbit last month, allowing Kim Jong Un’s regime to keep an eye on US troop movements in the region.
Psyche’s mission control team plans to spend the next three to four months conducting checks of the spacecraft’s systems before sending it on its journey into deep space.

site_title: BP short-lists three internal candidates for CEO: sources
summary: BP's board has shortlisted three internal candidates, including interim CEO Murray Auchincloss, for the CEO position. Auchincloss is seen as the most likely choice due to his experience leading the company and working with investors. The other two candidates are senior female executives, Carol Howle and Emma Delaney, who would become the first woman to lead a top Western oil and gas company if appointed. An internal appointment would signal support for BP's current strategy to slash carbon emissions and cut oil and gas output by 2030.

images.alt_text: BP says that the welfare of its crew is the company’s priority, underscoring that commercial pressures are taking a back seat in big firms’ decision-making.
BP’s board dismissed its former CEO Bernard Looney without notice effective on Dec 13 for serious misconduct.

Wind turbines stand behind trees at the Capital Wind Farm, operated by Infigen Energy, in Bungendore, New South Wales, Australia, on Thursday, July 24, 2014. The Australian government's A$10 billion ($9.4 billion) clean- energy bank, the Clean Energy Finance Corp., and Colonial First State Global Asset Management plan to create a fund allowing institutions to invest in the industry. Photographer: Mark Graham/Bloomberg
BP will maintain the pace of buybacks, pledging to repurchase US$1.5 billion of shares prior to reporting fourth-quarter results.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as investors pin hopes on Fed rate cuts
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, December 19, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 5.80 points, or 0.02%, to 37,311.82. Investors are betting on a potential policy pivot by the Federal Reserve next year, driving gains in recent weeks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the S&P 500 opening 3.16 points higher, or 0.07%, and the Nasdaq gaining 17.82 points, or 0.12%. The market optimism is driven by hopes of Fed rate cuts.

site_title: Thailand budgets US$970 million to renew electric vehicle hub push
summary: Thailand has allocated $970 million to 2027 to support its electric vehicle (EV) industry, with a new incentive package offering up to 40% cuts on import duties and a 2% excise tax rate for foreign EV makers. In return, foreign EV makers must manufacture EVs locally by 2027. The "EV 3.5 package" aims to attract new investments and facilitate traditional players' transition to EVs, bolstering Thailand's EV industry.

images.alt_text: Thailand is hoping to lure more investments now than the 981 billion baht commitments it received between 2019 and 2022 using less than half the target industries then.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 19)
summary: Shipping companies are rerouting from the Suez Canal due to attacks by Yemeni rebels in the Red Sea, causing delays and higher costs for Asia-Europe freight. Consumer goods will be impacted, with PwC calling for measures in Budget 2024 to support businesses and sustainability. Singapore's Ministry of Sustainability and Environment has published its eligibility list for carbon credits, and Singapore stocks rose amid rate cut expectations, with the STI up 0.1%.

site_title: MAS to tighten checks for single family offices’ tax incentives to deter abuse
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will broaden due diligence checks for single family offices applying for tax incentives, appointing specialized firms to screen for money laundering and terrorism financing risks. Applicants may be required to provide additional document validation if their screening results indicate potential risks. The measures follow the arrest of individuals believed to be involved in a S$2.8 billion money laundering ring, potentially connected to a single family office that received tax incentives. MAS aims to refine the tax incentive scheme to guard against illicit actors.

images.alt_text: The changes proposed include extending the scheme to cover mandatory third-party liability insurance that businesses purchase for specified mobility devices such as bicycle, personal mobility device, power-assisted bicycle, motorised wheelchair or mobility scooter.

In line with the newly introduced Payment Services Act, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has initiated a payments regulatory evaluation programme to help payment services firms in their transition.

site_title: Glove manufacturers, medical suppliers surf new Covid-19 wave
summary: Shares of Singapore-listed glove manufacturers Top Glove Corp, Riverstone Holdings, and personal protective equipment supplier Medtecs International Holdings have surged 20% year-to-date due to a Covid-19 wave. Top Glove rose 21.7%, Riverstone climbed 18.7%, and Medtecs jumped 48.1% in the past week. Analysts expect the price spike to be unsustainable in the long term.

site_title: Hong Kong's Sept-Nov unemployment holds steady at 2.9%
summary: Hong Kong's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained steady at 2.9% in September-November, unchanged from the previous three-month period. The government expects continued labour demand due to the recovery of tourism and private consumption, despite an unfavourable external environment. Secretary for Labour and Welfare Chris Sun stated that the labour market should remain tight in the near term, despite some negative effects.

site_title: India central bank tightens rules for lenders investing in alternative investment funds
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has tightened rules for lenders investing in alternative investment funds (AIFs) with existing borrowers. The new rules require lenders to liquidate their AIF investments within 30 days if the fund invests in an existing borrower. Lenders unable to liquidate their investments will need to make 100% provisions on these investments. The move aims to prevent AIFs from masking bad loans in the financial system, following investigations into misuse of AIFs worth $2.4 billion to $3.2 billion.

images.alt_text: The move to keep the benchmark repurchase rate at 6.5 per cent is in line with analyst expectations.

While credit growth is accelerating, banks and non bank finance companies (NBFCs) need to ensure lending to individual categories is “sustainable”, The Reserve Bank of India governor Shaktikanta Das says.
The RBI started a pilot programme for the e-rupee in December and is targeting a million transactions daily by year-end.
Monetary policy must remain actively focused on curbing prices “to ensure that the ongoing disinflation process progresses smoothly,” says Shaktikanta Das, governor of the Reserve Bank of India.

site_title: BlackRock updates spot bitcoin ETF proposal to allow cash redemptions
summary: BlackRock has updated its proposed spot bitcoin ETF to allow cash redemptions, a move that could help secure US Securities and Exchange Commission approval. The update allows for continuous basket issuances and redemptions in exchange for cash, with in-kind approval also possible. This change comes as a response to market participants' hopes for an early approval next year. The move is seen as a step towards securing approval for the ETF, which would track the market price of bitcoin and provide investors with exposure to the token without buying the currency.

site_title: Last orders? UK pubs hit by rising costs and changing tastes
summary: The UK pub industry is facing significant challenges, with rising costs and changing consumer habits contributing to a surge in closures. The number of pubs in England and Wales fell from 60,800 in 2000 to 45,800 in 2022, and an estimated 386 pubs closed in 2022 alone. Industry bodies, such as the British Beer and Pub Association, are calling for cuts in beer duties, business rates, and sales taxes to help the industry recover. Despite the closures, pubs remain an important part of British culture and heritage, and efforts are being made to preserve them.

images.alt_text: Wine losing favour among French younger generations who prefer beer and spirits over traditional wine culture.
At least 20 per cent of people employed in hospitality and food retail are paid at or near the national living wage, according to IGD, a trade group.

site_title: China can achieve 5% economic growth in 2024: central bank adviser
summary: China is expected to achieve 5% economic growth in 2024, according to policy adviser Wang Yiming, citing low central government debt and consumer prices. Investment and consumption growth are also forecast to rise, with exports returning to growth. The central bank may consider cutting interest rates if the Federal Reserve stops raising its rates. This prediction comes as Chinese leaders pledged to adjust policy to support an economic recovery in 2024.

images.alt_text: The effects of this year’s treasury bond issuance, cuts in interest rates, tax and fee cuts and other policies will continue into next year.

Pedestrians and shoppers on Nanjing Road shopping street in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. China’s Golden Week got off to a promising start as tourist trips and revenue jumped through the start of the holiday, suggesting some resilience in consumer appetites. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore to benefit from upturn in global semiconductor cycle
summary: Singapore is poised to benefit from a significant upturn in the global semiconductor cycle, with a projected 40% year-on-year growth in chip sales by 2025. The country's status as a tech hub is expected to be enhanced by AI developments and government incentives, leading to increased manufacturing output and electronics exports. Singapore's gross domestic product is forecast to soar by 4% in 2024, driven by its prime geographical location, bilingual population, and competitive advantages in semiconductor production and talent.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed NVIDIA logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Maersk reroutes vessels around Africa from Red Sea
summary: Maersk has rerouted around 20 of its vessels, around half of which were waiting in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, due to attacks on ships in the area. The company paused voyages and will now sail around Africa via the Cape of Good Hope. This decision aims to deliver faster and more predictable outcomes for customers and their supply chains. Maersk will assess future sailings on a case-by-case basis to determine if adjustments are necessary. The company expresses optimism about joint efforts to improve maritime security in the region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The world's first methanol-fueled container vessel Laura Maersk, owned by shipping company Maersk, is seen in Copenhagen, Denmark September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen/File Photo

site_title: Hyundai Motor to sell Russian plant, will take 287-billion won hit
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to sell its suspended Russian plant for a nominal 7,000 roubles (S$103.56) with operations halted since March 2022. The company will incur a 287 billion won (S$292.3 million) loss, but retains a buyback option. This sale follows other major automakers, such as Volkswagen, in pulling out of Russian assets. Hyundai and Kia were among the top selling brands in Russia before the war, and Chinese brands have since filled the gap. The deal is expected to be completed by December 28.

images.alt_text: Hyundai set up its first digital showroom on Amazon in 2018.
Hyundai expects the IONIQ 5 N to touch an electronically limited top speed of 260.7 km/h but did not reveal an estimate on the range offered.
Hyundai’s move comes as it pours billions into the US market to build electric vehicles and expand its market share.

site_title: Decathlon’s Singapore-based subsidiary secretly supplying Russia: report
summary: Decathlon's Singapore-based subsidiary has secretly continued selling clothes in Russia despite the company's official withdrawal from the market in protest of Russia's war in Ukraine. The French sports retailer sold its 60 local Russian outlets to Desport in October, but a report by investigative media site Disclose claims that the subsidiary is still supplying Russia. Decathlon denies the allegations, stating it operates no stores in Russia, employs no staff, and owns no stakes in active companies in the country.

images.alt_text: Decathlon’s plans for its China arm come as other foreign retail brands are reviewing their operations in the Asian country where economic growth has significantly slowed down in recent years.
Decathlon Lannion, which was acquired by IReit Global in 2021. The Reit's distributable income fell by 24.3 per cent year on year to 12.4 million euros, from 16.4 million euros.

site_title: Anwar’s trip spurs Japan’s RM6.6 billion investment in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim led a five-day trade mission to Japan, resulting in RM6.6 billion in potential investments and RM700 million in possible exports to the country. This brings the total potential investments from Japan to RM29.6 billion and anticipated exports to RM2.8 billion for the year. The new investments will focus on sectors including renewable energy, electronics, and digital economy.

site_title: Google to pay US$700 million to US consumers, states in Play store settlement
summary: Google has agreed to pay US$700 million to US consumers and states in an antitrust settlement over allegations of overcharging and restricting app distribution on Android devices. The company will pay US$630 million to consumers and US$70 million to states, without admitting wrongdoing. As part of the settlement, Google will simplify users' ability to download apps directly from developers and allow for greater competition in its Play app store. The settlement still requires a judge's final approval.

images.alt_text: For every 5 points that the Play Store fee rate decreases, Google loses about US$1.3 billion in operating income or 9 cents of earnings per share.

Jurors found for Epic on all counts, after more than a month of trial in Epic’s lawsuit, which accused Google of taking action to quash competitors and charge unduly high fees of up to 30 per cent to app developers.

site_title: Casino to sell stores to French rivals for 1.35 billion euros
summary: Casino, a French grocery store operator, is in exclusive talks to sell its hypermarkets and supermarkets to Groupement Les Mousquetaires (Intermarche) and Auchan Retail for 1.35 billion euros. The sale includes 313 stores with total sales of 3.6 billion euros in 2022. The deal is part of Casino's debt restructuring efforts, led by Czech billionaire Daniel Kretinsky, to avoid collapse and address operational issues. The sale will be completed by 2026, with all employees and certain real estate assets to be transferred to the new owners.

images.alt_text: Auchan's US$19b Carrefour talks said to stall over terms

site_title: Japan government bond yields fall after BOJ keeps policy unchanged
summary: Japan's government bond yields fell to 0.65% after the Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, reversing a rise prior to the announcement. The benchmark 10-year JGB yield was down a couple of points from Monday's close and off the day's high of 0.685%. The BOJ's move was expected, and analysts say yields may fall later in the day as investors buy back cash bonds, but volatility will persist due to liquidity concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese national flag is hoisted atop the headquarters of Bank of Japan in Tokyo, Japan September 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: India’s US$245 billion IT sector swallows tougher terms amid scramble for contracts
summary: India's $245 billion IT sector is accepting tougher contract terms to win large deals amid an uncertain global economy. Clients are cutting spending on non-essential projects, forcing companies to agree to contract terms such as guaranteed minimum cost savings, outcome-based billing, and reviewing cost overruns. Over 80% of IT deals tracked in 2023 had committed-savings clauses, up from 65% in 2019, according to Everest Group. This trend is expected to add pressure on the industry, with Infosys predicting its slowest annual sales expansion in at least a decade for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: All major IT firms, including Infosys, TCS, Wipro and HCLTech, have been lowering their IT spending, delaying and even cancelling contracts, as economic growth slows and on fears of higher-for-longer interest rates.
India’s Nifty IT index is up about 8 per cent this year, looking to recoup some of last year’s 26 per cent slump.

site_title: How to start growing wealth in 2024
summary: Investing in shares can provide higher returns than cash or bonds, but starting early and trading less are key to success. According to the article, becoming fabulously rich requires a combination of grit, determination, and a solid understanding of basic rules about money. The author emphasizes the importance of starting to invest early, as this allows individuals to fully exploit the returns from the stock market.

images.alt_text: Forced selling is bad news for investors in retirement who may rely on withdrawals from their principal, with interest and dividend income, to maintain their lifestyle.

site_title: Sino-Indian friendship can turbocharge Asian economies and investments
summary: China and India, two of the world's largest economies, could boost Asian economies and investments by improving their ties. Despite their vastly different political systems, the two countries share a large land border and have a history of rivalries. However, recent tensions have eased, and bilateral trade has recovered. China's ageing population and economic slowdown could make it more appealing to India, which is rapidly growing and seeking to upgrade its infrastructure. A harmonious relationship between the two countries could unleash a powerful economic driver for Asia, potentially rivaling the US's influence.

images.alt_text: Members of the US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) at the Apec Summit in San Francisco.

Picture taken on Wednesday, November 8, 2023
at The Clifford Pier at The Fullerton Bay Hotel
In Conversation with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Republic of Singapore ; Who is moderated by John Micklethwait, Editor-in-Chief, Bloomberg . 
during the sixth annual Bloomberg New Economy Forum.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on rate cut expectations; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,116.62, driven by expectations of looser financial conditions in 2024. Despite US Federal Reserve officials pushing back on interest rate cut expectations, 10-year and two-year Treasury yields remained below pre-December 13 levels. Mizuho Bank's Vishnu Varathan attributed this to market bets that the Fed is less concerned about sticky inflation dynamics. Gainers outpaced losers 275 to 251, with Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust being the top gainer, while City Developments Ltd was the biggest loser.

images.alt_text: Japan has seen inflation hold above 2 per cent for over a year and some firms have signalled their readiness to keep raising wages, increasing the chance of a near-term policy shift.
China’s yuan has had a volatile year, having weakened 6.14 per cent against the US dollar at one point before recouping some of the losses on growing bets that US interest rates have peaked.
Eyes are now on the Bank of Japan as it concludes a two-day meeting.

site_title: At Stockholm auction, vintage Ikea goes high-end
summary: A Stockholm auction house sold 122 vintage Ikea items for a total of $53,942, marking a shift towards high-end vintage market for the Swedish brand. The auction featured items from the 1950s to the 1990s, including a tubular sofa, lacquered chest of drawers, and "space age" lamps. The sale reflects Ikea's 80th anniversary and the growing interest in vintage design icons, with the company launching a new collection inspired by its iconic designs.

images.alt_text: Dresses that belonged to Princess Diana and a sketch study portrait are on display ahead of the auction Legends: Hollywood & Royalty at Julien's Auctions.
The collection included the shirt Messi wore during the first half of the final against France in Qatar.
Art and furniture pieces belonging to a late member of the Hermès family on display at auction.
This was the brown robe worn by Jeff Bridges' character, The Dude, in the 1998 film, The Big Lebowski.
A shirt worn by Prince during the 12th  American Music Awards was part of a collection of wardrobe items, jewellery and memorabilia auctioned by RR Auctions of Amherst, New Hampshire, USA.

If the set of six jerseys that Lionel Messi wore during Argentina’s victorious 2022 World Cup, indeed fetch above US$10 million, that could make the sale the most valuable collection of sports memorabilia ever auctioned off, Sotheby’s says.

site_title: TSMC chairman to retire next year, board recommends CEO as successor
summary: TSMC Chairman Mark Liu will retire in 2024, with the company's board recommending CEO CC Wei as his successor. Wei, a company veteran, has been on the board since 2017 and joined TSMC in 1998. The change in leadership is expected to have minimal impact on the company's operations or direction. TSMC is the world's largest contract chipmaker and a major supplier to companies like Apple and Nvidia, with a stock price soaring 30% this year.

images.alt_text: The artificial intelligence boom has spurred demand for chips that train large language models.
Chang says that cutting off China’s chip industry from the rest of the world would affect other players beyond China.
Japan is already shouldering roughly half of the cost of the first TSMC factory in Kumamoto, with up to 476 billion yen in subsidies.

site_title: Hiap Hoe unit buys Western Australian motel for A$40 million
summary: Real estate group Hiap Hoe announced the purchase of a 198-bedroom freehold motel property in Western Australia, Great Eastern Motor Lodge, for A$40 million. The property is situated along the Great Eastern Highway, connecting Perth Airport to the central business district. The lodge benefits from transport connections and serves as a focal point in the inner-city suburb of Rivervale, which is undergoing regeneration.

images.alt_text: Hiap Hoe returns to the black with net profit of S$16.2m in Q4

site_title: Singapore’s Atomionics taps gravity, AI in hunt for critical minerals
summary: Singapore-based start-up Atomionics has deployed its "virtual drill" technology, Gravio, using gravity and AI to define ore bodies in the mining industry, potentially cutting costs and speeding up projects. The technology, backed by Singapore government agencies and strategic investors, uses AI to process data in real-time, allowing for more precise ore body definition and reducing the need for costly drilling. The company has signed contracts with three major mining companies, expected to finish deployments early next year, and aims to cut "empty" samples by at least half.

images.alt_text: Microsoft-backed OpenAI will only deploy its latest technology if it is deemed safe in specific areas such as cybersecurity and nuclear threats.
AI is a leadership imperative with real impact, so generative AI must be managed across the board.
AI has the potential to contribute nearly S$1.36 trillion to the Asean economy by 2030.

site_title: Considering a Trump re-election in 2024 – fiscal and geopolitical challenges
summary: A potential second Trump presidency in 2025 poses significant uncertainty for the investment landscape, with the greatest impact expected to be in fiscal and geopolitical challenges. A new Trump administration is likely to deploy generous fiscal policy, potentially exacerbating US inflation and raising concerns about debt sustainability. Geopolitically, a second Trump presidency may slow down the multilateral approach of the Biden administration, leading to a realignment of the global order with emerging powers, particularly in Europe and Latin America. Investors may see an opportunity to diversify into dollar-denominated assets, but gold could also return as a long-term anchor of wealth preservation.

images.alt_text: America’s liberal political culture made a huge difference to the liberal international order that has existed since WWII.
Economists regard a soft landing as when policymakers succeed in slowing an economy enough to get inflation under control without causing a recession.

site_title: Japan ups assessment on business mood, thanks to upbeat profits
summary: Japan's Cabinet Office upgraded its view on business sentiment for the first time in two months, citing a broad recovery in corporate mood due to upbeat profits. The overall economic assessment remained unchanged, with the economy recovering "moderately" but with some areas stalled. Business confidence among big manufacturers reached a near two-year high, while non-manufacturers' sentiment improved to levels not seen since 1991. Despite this, domestic demand, wage growth, and capital investment appear to be stagnant, with consumer prices rising moderately. Global risks, including monetary tightening and the Chinese economy, are being closely monitored.

images.alt_text: Japan has seen inflation hold above 2 per cent for over a year and some firms have signalled their readiness to keep raising wages, increasing the chance of a near-term policy shift.

site_title: Thai lawmakers to debate same-sex marriage equality
summary: Thailand's cabinet has given the green light for parliament to debate legalizing same-sex unions, moving the country closer to equalizing marriage rights. The proposal, which has several hurdles to clear, aims to amend marriage law references to gender-neutral terms. If passed, Thailand would be the first South-east Asian country to recognize same-sex marriage, strengthening family structures and granting same rights and responsibilities as heterosexual couples.

images.alt_text: People take part in the annual LGBTQ Pride parade in Bangkok, Thailand, June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Marchers waved rainbow flags with one holding a placard that said “freedom to choose gender” and another that said “love is love”, in rainbow colours.

The Cabinet approved the draft legislation after receiving opinions from LGBTQ and religious groups, which don’t object to the proposal, Ratchada Thanadirek, a government spokesperson, said in a statement.

site_title: Sony wants to hear Zee’s plan to rescue merger ahead of deadline
summary: Sony has asked Zee Entertainment Enterprises to submit its proposals for rescuing the merger plan, which aims to create a $10 billion media behemoth. Zee had requested a deadline extension, citing that it won't meet the Dec 21 deadline. Sony stated it has not agreed to the extension, but is open to hearing Zee's proposals to complete the remaining closing conditions. The Tokyo-based company is seeking a plan to rescue the deal, which was agreed upon in a 2021 pact with Zee's CEO Punit Goenka.

site_title: Chocolate wars as Italian artisans battle Swiss giant
summary: Italian artisans are battling Swiss giant Lindt for European recognition of the gianduiotto, a small, creamy chocolate made with roasted hazelnuts and cocoa. The Italian Committee, comprising artisans and companies like Ferrero and Venchi, seeks a Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) to promote the traditional chocolate and increase sales. However, Lindt, owner of Italian producer Caffarel, claims to have invented the gianduiotto and wants to reduce hazelnut content and add powdered milk, sparking a dispute over the chocolate's authenticity and production methods.

images.alt_text: Guido Castagna is pictured in his laboratory where he is making the famous chocolate treat shaped like lingots, the 'Gianduiotto' with cacao, sugar and hazelnut, on December 12, 2023 in Giaveno near Turin, Northwestern Italy. In Turin, a committee was formed made up of large and small local chocolate producers in order to obtain PGI recognition (Protected Geographical Indication) for one of the most famous products in the area: the gianduiotto. But the Swiss Lindt group, owner of the Caffarel brand, opposes it. (Photo by MARCO BERTORELLO / AFP)

A picture shows chocolate treats 'Giuinott', the 'Gianduiotto' version made by Guido Castagna in his laboratory, on December 12, 2023 in Giaveno near Turin, Northwestern Italy. In Turin, a committee was formed made up of large and small local chocolate producers in order to obtain PGI recognition (Protected Geographical Indication) for one of the most famous products in the area: the gianduiotto. But the Swiss Lindt group, owner of the Caffarel brand, opposes it. (Photo by MARCO BERTORELLO / AFP)

site_title: Crisis in the Bab el-Mandeb threatens world trade
summary: A crisis has unfolded at the Bab el-Mandeb, a narrow entrance to the Red Sea, as Houthi rebels have been attacking and hijacking ships, abducting seafarers, and disrupting world trade. The Galaxy Leader, a British-owned vehicle carrier, was seized by armed men in November, and since then, no ships have been seized, but attacks on shipping have escalated. US warships and a British destroyer have intervened, and major shipping companies, including Maersk and BP, have stopped sailing into the Red Sea, re-routing around the Cape of Good Hope. The situation poses a significant threat to international trade and freedom of navigation.

images.alt_text: Carriers have been attacked by Yemeni rebels in the Red Sea, prompting major shipping liners to avoid the Suez Canal for now.

site_title: SpiceJet considers buying grounded Indian carrier Go Air
summary: SpiceJet is considering acquiring grounded Indian carrier Go Airlines, with the goal of creating a "strong and viable airline" through a possible combination. SpiceJet plans to submit an offer after conducting due diligence on Go, which has a fleet of 54 Airbus A320neos and has been grounded since May due to financial struggles. Go's CEO stepped down in November, citing staff unpaid wages for six months. SpiceJet aims to raise 22.5 billion rupees through preferential shares and warrants after reporting a quarterly loss.

images.alt_text: The additional pay, which the airline calls a retention allowance, will come into effect on Jun 1, according to an e-mail seen by Bloomberg News.
The airline, widely known as Go First, filed for bankruptcy protection last week, blaming “faulty” Pratt & Whitney engines for the grounding of about half its 54 Airbus A320neo.
Go Air is the third high-profile Indian airline forced to ground its entire fleet in the past decade or so in one of the toughest markets in the world.

site_title: TPG buys stake in Canadian warehouses from Oxford for US$750 million
summary: US private equity firm TPG has acquired a majority stake in a portfolio of warehouse properties in the Greater Toronto Area for $750 million. The deal gives TPG 75% ownership of two industrial parks in Brampton and Vaughan, while Oxford Properties Group retains 25% interest and will continue to manage the assets. The transaction values the 5.1 million-square-foot portfolio at C$1.3 billion, highlighting the attractiveness of Canada's industrial real estate market, despite interest rates remaining high.

images.alt_text: The company operates clinics and hospitals in locations including Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Indonesia.

site_title: Funding’s not-quite winter thaw
summary: Venture capital (VC) funding appears to be increasing, but with caution, as investors focus on securing returns in a challenging macroeconomic environment. VC funds are backing startups at earlier stages due to lower exit values, and down rounds have doubled to 16% in the second quarter of 2023. Meanwhile, private equity (PE) funds are also impacted by the "denominator effect," leading to capital allocations being influenced by market volatility.

images.alt_text: The AI race is also underway in the wider region of South-east Asia, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.
With many sharing the spotlight, startups building consumer brands have weakened in their attractiveness to investors, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Flash Coffee's Taiwan bankruptcy mirrors the Singapore one, with Flash Coffee’s holding company being the largest creditor, and staff salaries left unpaid, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
Some sectors and regions remain bright spots for investments, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.
The drop in private funding has had an unequal impact across countries, with Indonesia bearing the brunt of the fall, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.

site_title: Justin Quek to succeed Steven Tan as OrangeTee & Tie CEO
summary: OrangeTee & Tie has announced that Justin Quek will succeed Steven Tan as CEO effective January 1, 2024. Quek, who is currently deputy CEO, will lead the real estate agency in its efforts to reposition itself as a full-suite real estate service provider. Tan will remain as key executive officer and take on an active international role. This move marks a significant change in leadership for the company, which has been in Tan's hands for over 20 years.

images.alt_text: Faster price growth in city fringe was due to more condos obtaining their TOPs, says OrangeTee & Tie.

In August 2021, names, bank account numbers, NRIC and passport numbers, and property transaction and commission amounts were extracted from OrangeTee & Tie’s outdated database servers by hacking group Altdos.
Overall resale prices grow at a slower pace with ten HDB towns seeing a dip in average prices.

site_title: Australia central bank considered hiking again in December, paused for more data
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) considered hiking interest rates for a second consecutive month in December but paused, citing encouraging signs of inflation progress towards the bank's target range of 2-3%. The decision was made after data showed no radical change in the economic outlook and a risk of rising unemployment. The RBA now sees inflation running above target until late 2025, but expects it to slow to the top of the target range. Markets have priced out further rate hikes following a dovish turn from the US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: The Australian government is greatly expanding the RBA’s regulatory power over the payments system, particularly for mobile wallet services offered by the likes of Apple and Google.
Most economists reckon the RBA is done with tightening in this cycle, though a few see the risk of another hike early in 2024.

The interest rate poll, conducted from Nov 29 to Dec 1, showed 28 of 30 economists, including those at Australia’s big four banks, expect the central bank will keep its official cash rate on hold on Dec 5.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, CapitaLand India Trust, Elite Commercial Reit
summary: Nio's Singapore-listed shares rose 0.5% to US$7.92 after securing a US$2.2 billion investment from Abu Dhabi-backed fund CYVN Holdings. The investment will give CYVN a 20.1% stake in Nio. CapitaLand India Trust acquired two industrial facilities in Chennai for 1.8 billion rupees, while Elite Commercial Reit launched a non-renounceable preferential offering to raise about £28 million to repay debt and reduce gearing.

site_title: Malaysia’s exports fall for ninth consecutive month in November
summary: Malaysia's exports declined 5.9% year-over-year in November, marking the ninth consecutive month of decline, to RM122.1 billion. This was worse than the 4.5% contraction in October and the 5.2% decline predicted by economists. However, imports rose 1.7% year-over-year to RM109.7 billion, beating economists' projections. Economists expect Malaysia's exports to rebound in 2024 due to an improved Chinese economy and the bottoming out of the global tech sector.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara Malaysia governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour says that resilient domestic spending, underpinned by improved employment and rising tourism activities, bolstered Q3 growth.
Malaysia, a major hub in the semiconductor supply chain, is seen as well placed to grab further business as Chinese chip firms diversify outside of China for assembling needs.

site_title: Thai tycoons seen ramping up overseas investments again
summary: Thai tycoons are increasing their overseas investments as cash-rich large businesses look to fuel future growth beyond a sluggish local economy. Since 2012, Thai companies have announced deals worth around $107 billion, primarily in energy, financial services, and retail sectors. Despite a slow economic recovery and concerns over rising government debt, Thai conglomerates are expanding globally, with major deals recently completed in Brunei, Vietnam, Mexico, and Europe. The push for overseas expansion is driven by the need for growth and diversification, but a declining local stock market and lack of massive-value deals may raise concerns among investors.

images.alt_text: Workers unload sacks of rice imported from Thailand from a cargo ship at Malahayati Port in Krueng Raya, Indonesia's Aceh province, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)
Businesses have expressed concern over rising costs and wages as a factor in holding back competitiveness amid sluggish economic growth.

site_title: Dealmakers to miss US$3 trillion mark for first time in 10 years
summary: US dealmakers are poised to miss the $3 trillion mark for the first time in 10 years, with M&A and related transactions valued at $2.7 trillion going into the holiday period. This marks the lowest annual total since 2013, largely due to reluctant lenders and geopolitical tensions. Investment bankers face a bleak bonus season and potential job cuts if dealmaking doesn't improve in 2024. Private equity firms have spent 36% less on acquisitions this year, citing debt financing struggles and price disagreements with sellers. Geopolitical uncertainty, including the 2024 US presidential election, may hinder deal activity.

images.alt_text: US dealmakers advised on deals worth US$356.51 billion during the quarter – a 35 per cent jump from the same period last year. Deal volumes in Europe and Asia-Pacific fell 31 per cent and 9 per cent, respectively.

site_title: China expected to stand pat on lending benchmarks in December: survey
summary: China is expected to keep its lending benchmark rates unchanged in December, according to a Reuters survey of 28 market watchers. The People's Bank of China's one-year loan prime rate (LPR) and five-year rate are predicted to remain steady at 3.45% and 4.2% respectively, after the central bank kept its medium-term policy rate unchanged last week. This decision comes despite recent liquidity injections and fiscal support measures, with analysts forecasting potential rate cuts in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Over recent months, China has started to unleash fresh fiscal stimulus to shore up the economy.
Aggregate financing is 2.45 trillion yuan (S$461 billion), the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) says.
The PBOC set the daily reference rate at 7.1140 per US dollar, versus an average estimate at 7.1486 in a Bloomberg survey with analysts and traders.

site_title: How college football is clobbering housing markets across the country
summary: College football's popularity is fueling a surge in short-term rentals, destabilizing housing markets in cities reliant on the sport. Wealthy fans and investors are transforming single-family homes into de facto hotels, often leaving them empty the rest of the year. This has driven up rents and home prices, making it difficult for locals to afford housing. Experts say college athletics, particularly football, have become enormous in the US, causing this phenomenon. Local governments are struggling to regulate short-term rentals, with some cities imposing moratoriums, but advocates argue that more needs to be done to protect affordable housing.

images.alt_text: Properties near the coast at Glyfada suburb, near Athens, Greece, on March 27, 2023. Greece says it will double its investment threshold for its “golden visa” scheme to €500,000 in several key locations including Athens. Photographer: Nick Paleologos/Bloomberg

site_title: PwC hopes Budget 2024 will support businesses, sustainability and workers
summary: Professional services firm PwC has released its Budget 2024 wish list, proposing a refundable tax credit framework, a participation exemption for foreign asset disposal gains, and measures to uplift businesses, workers, and sustainability. The framework would support multinational enterprises, while also aligning with Singapore's economic policy. PwC also suggests measures to support workers, including social welfare schemes. The proposals aim to promote business growth and sustainability in the upcoming Budget 2024.

images.alt_text: A picture shows logos of the main communication brand also named GAFAM (for Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft)in Mulhouse, on June 2, 2023. (Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)
Some MPs wanted small- and medium-sized enterprises to get more help to offset high operating costs, and enhanced productivity and digitisation initiatives.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned of greater competition as advanced economies roll out subsidies for investment.
The plans announced in Budget 2023 will chart paths to create resilience for Singapore's continued prosperity in a changing world.

site_title: An anti-LGBTQ+ law in Uganda is hurting the economy
summary: Uganda's Anti-Homosexuality Act, a law that includes a death penalty provision for aggravated homosexuality, is negatively impacting the country's economy. The law has led to a decline in tourist bookings, with prospective customers hesitant to visit due to the country's harsh LGBTQ+ policies. According to Simon Azarwagye, owner of Azas Safaris, the travel company experienced a significant decrease in quote requests, from 89 to zero, after the law's introduction. This economic toll is a result of the law's deterrent effect on tourism, which is a significant contributor to Uganda's economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Participants pose for photos at a news conference ahead of the Gay Games in Hong Kong, China November 2, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
Transgender people in Japan can now change their legal gender without undergoing surgery.

site_title: Plum pickings in Punggol
summary: In Singapore, buying a subsidized Build-To-Order (BTO) flat can lead to significant gains in the resale market. A study by Mogul.sg found that median four-room flat resale prices in Punggol rose 42% between 2015 and 2023, outpacing the islandwide average. Meanwhile, interest rates are expected to peak in 2023, potentially leading to an inflection point for Singapore Reits in 2024.

images.alt_text: Three land parcels in areas well known to developers and homebuyers alike - River Valley, Queenstown and Pasir Ris - should see strong interest, writes deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Homeowners living in private property and/or holding properties for investment will be hit hard next year, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

One largely unseen component of developers’ costs is the land betterment charge paid to the government in return for enhanced land use in building up a site, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
The residential rental market is cooling its heels after racing up in 2021 and 2022, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Hyperlocal factors helped push sales of the 368-unit J’den project in Jurong, writes deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: EC World Reit secures renewal for one of two leases from China Tobacco
summary: EC World Reit secured renewal for one of two leases from China Tobacco for its Hengde Logistics property in Hangzhou, with a new lease period from January 1, 2024, to December 31, 2025. The 74,057 square meters of space will remain occupied by China Tobacco, with the same rental rate as before. This marks a positive development for the Reit, which recently lost a major lease contract for another space in the same property.

images.alt_text: Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio. The Reit's gross revenue was down 9.5 per cent to S$27 million in Q3 FY 2023, from S$29.8 million a year ago.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou owned by EC World REIT.
EC World Reit defers its H1 distribution due to insufficient funds.
Above: Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou, owned by EC World Reit. The China-focused Reit has fully repaid its onshore interest expenses due on Sep 20.

site_title: High chilli prices feed inflation in Indonesia ahead of central bank’s rate decision
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate is being driven by a surge in chili prices, reaching a record high of 100,000 rupiah (S$10) per kg in some regions. The prices are attributed to a drought-induced crop failure and underdeveloped supply-chain infrastructure. Despite this, economists expect inflation to remain within the central bank's 2-4% target range, with global disinflationary trends expected to counterbalance domestically driven inflation. The impact on the central bank's interest rate decision on Thursday is unlikely, but the high chili prices can still be felt across the economy.

images.alt_text: Street vendors sell their wears in front of an ATM in Vientiane, Laos. The IMF estimates the country's public debt to be 122 per cent of GDP in 2023.

site_title: Nippon Steel confident hefty premium for US Steel makes sense
summary: Nippon Steel has agreed to purchase US Steel for $14.9 billion, paying a 142% premium to US Steel's share price. The deal aims to increase Nippon Steel's global crude steel capacity to 100 million tonnes and make it a larger supplier to the US auto industry. The acquisition is seen as having "sufficient economic rationale" despite Nippon Steel's shares sinking 5.5% following the announcement. The deal is expected to propel Nippon Steel into the top 3 global steel makers and benefit from the US Inflation Reduction Act's incentives for renewable energy projects.

images.alt_text: Nippon Steel sees the US as a growth market that can help to offset declining demand in Japan

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as US Fed officials push back on rate cut bets
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday after US Federal Reserve officials dampened expectations for interest rate cuts next year. The yen edged up ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy decision, with officials including San Francisco Fed chief Mary Daly and Cleveland Fed chief Loretta Mester expressing skepticism about rapid rate cuts. The BOJ is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, with most observers predicting a slow course. Oil prices edged higher after attacks on cargo ships in the Red Sea led to a halt in shipping through the region.

images.alt_text: Asia struggled at the start of this week, with Tokyo down more than one per cent, and Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta also in the red.

site_title: The cockroach theory of crypto
summary: Bitcoin has surged to a two-year high, reaching almost $45,000, despite the crypto industry being plagued by issues such as money laundering, terrorism financing, and regulatory crackdowns. The industry's indestructibility, built into its technology, contributes to its resilience. As the first widespread use of bitcoin in despotic countries grows, and new applications like NFTs and social media platforms emerge, the value of crypto tokens continues to be justified. The recent court ruling in favor of Grayscale's bitcoin ETF application and the expected launch of ETFs by major fund managers could lead to a surge in cash into bitcoin, driven by its potential as a diversifier in portfolios.

images.alt_text: Cyborg cockroach. Singapore team studying use of cockroaches in rescue missions. Notoriously known to be a pest, the shiny, brown, oval-shaped madagascar hissing cockroach will soon have the capability to save lives. Fitted with a ‘backpack’ consisting of a chip, battery and camera, it can detect signs of life. This cyborg can be employed at disaster sites to search amid rubble and debris for survivors.
Representations of cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin, Dash, Ethereum, Ripple and Litecoin are seen in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
Cryptocurrencies stage a recovery this year after a torrid 2022 in which a market meltdown and a string of scandals.

site_title: Malaysia’s Cabinet shuffle; Xi-Vietnam diplomatic tango
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced a new Cabinet line-up, including political newcomer Amir Hamzah Azizan as second finance minister. The reshuffle, a year after Anwar took office, added four new ministries and saw five new ministers sworn in. Meanwhile, China's President Xi Jinping visited Vietnam for a two-day state visit, signing 37 cooperation deals. Indonesia is set to hold its general election in February, which could have a positive impact on the economy, according to a chief economist.

images.alt_text: Singapore stands as Vietnam’s largest foreign investor for the third straight year, accounting for almost a quarter of total foreign capital investment in 2022, writes BT journalist Goh Ruoxue.
Pedestrians stroll around the tourist hotspots in Kuala Lumpur. Malaysia is set to raise its sales and services tax at the start of 2024.

site_title: Papua New Guinea is sole host country on Singapore’s carbon credit eligibility list
summary: Singapore has confirmed its first carbon credit transfer agreement with Papua New Guinea, allowing the country to use up to 5% of its taxable emissions from 2024. This agreement makes Papua New Guinea the sole host country on Singapore's eligibility list under the International Carbon Credit Framework. The eligibility list, set to take effect on January 1, 2024, includes four carbon crediting programmes under Papua New Guinea, including the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) and American Carbon Registry. The Singapore government plans to review and update the list annually to maintain environmental integrity standards.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

Permanent Secretary of the Ministry for Sustainability and the Environment Stanley Loh and Vice Minister of Strategic Affairs of the Ministry of
Environment and Energy Carlos Isaac Pérez signed a Memorandum of
Understanding between Singapore and Costa Rica to collaborate on carbon credits under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement on the sidelines of COP28.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

Singapore's Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security Teo Chee Hean and Paraguay president Santiago Pena met on the sidelines of the 28th UN Climate Conference in Dubai on Dec 2, 2023.

GenZero, a Temasek subsidiary, signed a   memorandum of understanding in June 2023 to invest in a landscape restoration project in Ghana. The project builds on Singapore’s intergovernmental partnerships on Article 6 of the Paris Agreement.

site_title: Asean’s green future and debt trouble
summary: Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh unveiled a US$15.5 billion Resource Mobilisation Plan to support the country's energy transition, announced during the COP28 climate talks. Meanwhile, Malaysia is expected to see an increase in housing prices and rental rates, while Thailand's tourism target has rebounded following a surge in visitors from Malaysia. In Indonesia, presidential candidates are competing for the youth vote, and the central bank has ceased setting exchange rates for foreign currencies. These developments highlight the region's economic and environmental challenges, and the need for sustainable solutions.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s industrial production fell for a second straight month in September, dipping by 0.5 per cent year-on-year.
Pedestrians stroll around the tourist hotspots in Kuala Lumpur. Malaysia is set to raise its sales and services tax at the start of 2024.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves debt support for smaller firms, debtors
summary: Thailand's cabinet has approved a debt suspension program for smaller businesses and support for retail debtors, aiming to address the country's debt issues. The program aims to help 10.3 million people struggling to service debt. The government also plans to keep diesel prices at around 30 baht (S$1.14) per liter and electricity bills at up to 4.2 baht per unit to lower energy costs. This move is part of efforts to support the country's economy, where household debt is 90.7% of gross domestic product.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Srettha Thavisin, Prime Minister of Thailand, speaks at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) CEO Summit in San Francisco, California, U.S., November 15, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

site_title: At least 118 people dead in a magnitude 6.2 earthquake in northwest China
summary: A magnitude 6.2 earthquake struck northwest China, killing at least 118 people and injuring hundreds more in the deadliest quake in years. The epicenter was 100 km southwest of Gansu province's capital, Lanzhou. Thousands of homes were damaged, and power and water supplies were disrupted in some areas. Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for "all-out efforts" in search and rescue operations, with over 5,000 homes damaged and 1,400 firefighters and rescue personnel deployed.

images.alt_text: China has grappled with weather extremes this year, from ultra-low temperatures in January to record rainfall and a blistering hot summer, in wild swings that scientists attribute to climate change.

site_title: IMF sees India’s economy grow at 6.3% in current fiscal year
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has projected India's economy to grow at 6.3% in the current fiscal year and the next, driven by macroeconomic and financial stability. The growth is lower than the Reserve Bank of India's forecast of 7%. Retail inflation rose to 5.6% in November, driven by volatile food prices, but is expected to decline to the target of 4% as inflation remains volatile due to food price shocks. Comprehensive reforms are needed to unlock even higher growth from labor and human capital.

site_title: E-commerce firm Shopee buys credit arm from Brazil’s Warburg Pincus-backed Blu
summary: Shopee, a Singapore-based e-commerce firm, has acquired Brazil's local credit arm from Blu, a fintech backed by US private equity firm Warburg Pincus. The deal, which has received preliminary approval from Brazil's antitrust regulator Cade, aims to allow Shopee to offer credit directly to customers in Brazil's largest economy. Shopee has nine distribution centers in Brazil and plans to use the acquisition to grow its business and cut costs. The exact terms of the deal have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: Sea is likely to register lower earnings as Shopee is expected to suffer greater losses in the intensified e-commerce competition.
The growth of Sea's e-commerce arm, Shopee, will be key in achieving long-term profitability says Forrest Li, chairman and chief executive at Sea.

site_title: An unforgettable dining experience coming soon for BT readers
summary: The Business Times (BT) is hosting "A Night in Puglia: A Feast for the Senses" on Jan 22 at Fico, a casual beachside Italian restaurant in East Coast Park. The event features exclusive off-menu dishes created by chef-partner Mirko Febbrile, who was formerly the head chef of Michelin-starred Braci. Attendees will enjoy free-flow wine and can win prizes worth over S$1,500. The event is open to BT readers and can be registered for through bt.sg/btdine1.

images.alt_text: A very special group of subscribers got to meet key members of the BT team, including editor Chen Huifen, at our first ever Meet the BT Newsroom event in April.

site_title: Gold holds ground on softer dollar, focus on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices held steady at $2,027.15 per ounce, supported by a weaker US dollar. The US dollar dropped 0.1% against rivals, making gold less expensive for other currency holders. Investors await US economic data this week, including the November core personal consumption expenditure index report, which may influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook. Despite market expectations of interest rate cuts, the Fed is not committing to rate cuts soon, and gold prices remain stable.

images.alt_text: US gold futures edged 0.1 per cent lower to US$2,033.20.

site_title: US court approves order for Binance to pay US$2.7 billion to CFTC
summary: A US court approved a settlement between the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) and Binance, ordering the exchange and its former CEO, Changpeng Zhao, to pay US$2.7 billion and US$150 million, respectively, for violating US anti-money laundering laws. The settlement resolves a years-long probe into Binance's compliance issues, including failing to report suspicious transactions with terrorist groups and child sexual abuse material. Zhao pleaded guilty in November and will pay a US$150 million civil monetary penalty, while Binance will pay US$2.7 billion, including US$1.35 billion in ill-gotten transaction fees and US$1.35 billion in penalties.

images.alt_text: The District Court judge in Seattle agrees with the Justice Department that Zhao has not convinced the court he is unlikely to flee if allowed to return to the UAE.
Binance’s settlement with the CFTC and Treasury Department, negotiated by the Justice Department, was for breaking US anti-money laundering and sanctions laws.
Internal communications showed Zhao had direct knowledge Binance was violating US laws.

site_title: China flows into new stock funds plunge to lowest in decade
summary: China's retail investors are pulling out of mutual funds, with the amount of new portfolios raised this year plummeting to the lowest in a decade. Foreign funds have sold at unprecedented levels, and government policies are deemed insufficient. Households are prioritizing cash savings due to post-Covid uncertainties, and the benchmark CSI 300 Index is poised for an unprecedented third year of losses. Aggregate household savings have reached a record 134.6 trillion yuan, with retail investors disillusioned with professional fund managers, who have seen a 16% drop in stock-focused mutual funds this year.

images.alt_text: The IPO approval from the Shanghai Stock Exchange comes two months after it suspends the listing process in order to request Brite clarify its relationship with SMIC.
Morgan Stanley highlights clothing manufacturer Shenzhou International Group and toymaker Pop Mart International Group as stocks that should benefit from a global presence.
China has been experimenting with Reits to tap the world’s second-largest equity market to finance projects that would’ve otherwise been funded by local governments.

site_title: Bank Indonesia likely done with hikes, first cut in Q3 2024: poll
summary: Bank Indonesia is likely to maintain its key policy rate for a second month, with inflation staying within its 2-4% target range for the sixth consecutive month. The rupiah has stabilized, easing pressure on imported prices. Economists forecast the first rate cut in the third quarter of 2024, with a median forecast of a 50-basis-point cut to 5.5% by year-end. The central bank's governor, Perry Warjiyo, has said the policy rate will remain on hold into next year, citing manageable inflation and currency movement.
