images.alt_text: An unexpected Bank Indonesia hike in October, ahead of the Fed pause early last month, widened the interest rate gap with the US, and brought investors back.
BI governor Perry Warjiyo says the decision is consistent with maintaining the rupiah’s stability and mitigating against imported inflation.

site_title: Apple plans rescue for US$17 billion watch business in face of ban
summary: Apple plans to stop selling its prohibited smartwatches in the US on December 21 and remove them from its stores by December 24 due to a patent dispute with Masimo. The company is racing to make software changes to the blood-oxygen level feature, which Masimo claims infringes on its patents. Apple may settle with Masimo, but for now, it's focusing on modifying its technology and trying to win favor with regulators. If the ban holds, Apple will focus on its lower-end SE watch and prepare stores for the change, potentially removing hardware from devices and shipping new models after at least three months.

images.alt_text: Apple has paused the sales of its Series 9 and Ultra 2 smartwatches after an order in October from the US International Trade Commission.
Staff in at least three ministries and government bodies have been told not to use iPhones at work, according to a Reuters report.
Apple shares have soared by more than 50 per cent in 2023, adding about US$1 trillion in market value.

site_title: Amazon in talks with Diamond Sports for streaming deal, investment
summary: Amazon is in talks with Diamond Sports Group to invest in the bankrupt regional sports broadcaster and partner on streaming, potentially acquiring multiyear rights to MLB, NBA, and NHL games. Amazon would acquire an equity stake in Diamond and continue to operate the channels. The deal is subject to bankruptcy court approval and is part of Amazon's push to expand its advertising business through live sports.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s US expansion has already attracted the attention of politicians and regulators, who fret about the company’s growing influence over its audience.
Amazon dominates US e-commerce by capturing more than US$1 of every US$3 spent online.
Amazon alleges Microsoft's business practices limit cloud market choice.

site_title: South Korea’s Harim preferred buyer of shipper HMM for 6.4 trillion won: sources
summary: Harim Holdings has been chosen as the preferred buyer of South Korea's largest container shipper HMM, in a 6.4 trillion won (S$6.55 billion) deal. Harim's bulk shipping unit Pan Ocean led the consortium, and negotiations with HMM creditors will take place by mid-2024 for a 58% stake. The deal is expected to enable both companies to navigate market fluctuations better. Harim's shares jumped 6.1% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: hmm Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit launches fully underwritten preferential offering at £0.27 apiece
summary: Elite Commercial Reit launched a fully underwritten non-renounceable preferential offering at £0.27 apiece, raising about £28 million to repay debt and reduce gearing. The offering, which represents a 10% discount, is strongly supported by the Reit's sponsors and substantial unitholders. The funds will be used to reduce gearing to 43.5% and create debt headroom, enhancing the Reit's financial flexibility.

images.alt_text: Great Western House, Birkenhead, one of the properties in Elite Commercial Reit's portfolio. The overall portfolio's valuation as at Dec 1, 2023 stands at £412.5 million.
Newport Road, Cardiff, Wales is one of Elite Commercial Reit's properties.
Great Western House, Birkenhead. The 58 properties have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet, and include Great Western House in Birkenhead (pictured), and a building in Newport Road,

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust acquires pair of Chennai assets for 1.8 billion rupees
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has acquired two industrial facilities in Mahindra World City, Chennai, for 1.8 billion rupees, marking its second forward purchase transaction with the Casa Grande Group. The facilities, totaling 330,000 sq ft, are fully leased to international companies, and the acquisition is expected to be fully funded by debt and internal cash resources. The move expands Clint's portfolio in Chennai, now comprising two business parks, three industrial facilities, and a data centre under development.

images.alt_text: The data centre in Navi Mumbai is scheduled to be completed by mid-2025 with a power capacity of 108 megawatts.
Total property income for Q3 grew 23 per cent to 3.8 billion rupees, from 3 billion rupees previously.
Tincome from Block A in International Tech Park Hyderabad, which was completed in January
Pixgeneric / generic picture taken on 7 Feb 2023 of JCube mall, The 11 year old mall is  to close down on Aug 6, site to make way for 40-storey residential development.

site_title: 17Live’s precipitous share price fall may set back Singapore’s tech listing ambitions
summary: 17Live Group, a live-streaming platform operator, has seen its share price plummet to a third of its initial value following its business combination with Vertex Technology Acquisition Corp (VTAC) on December 8. The listing, which was touted as a "new economy" company, has been met with lukewarm investor reception, with the counter falling 19% in its mainboard debut. This disappointing performance may set back Singapore's tech listing ambitions, which were aimed at attracting tech growth stocks. The government, Singapore Exchange, and Temasek had launched initiatives in 2021 to achieve this goal, but the lackluster performance of 17Live's listing may have raised doubts about its ability to attract high-growth and high-tech companies.

images.alt_text: Left: Ng Jing Shen, chief technology officer of 17Live. The live-streaming platform listed on the Singapore Exchange after completing a business combination with Vertex Technology Acquisition Company.

epa10887181 A sales promotion woman holds a dress as she live-streams on an e-commerce platform at a shop in Depok, Indonesia, 28 September 2023. The Indonesian government announced a new regulation that officially bans social media sites such as TikTok and Instagram from selling goods and services directly, amid complaints from small and medium business traders, who lack buyers due to goods on social media being sold much cheaper. The Indonesian Trade Minister Zulkifli Hasan explained that social media such as TikTok and Instagram can only promote goods or services.  EPA-EFE/ADI WEDA

The acquisition of 17Live by VTAC could be one of the most important new listings to hit the Singapore market in a long while

site_title: Singapore shares retreat at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% to 3,104.77 on Tuesday, following a mixed performance in the US and Europe overnight. Across the broader market, losers outnumbered gainers 57 to 46. Key banking stocks showed mixed results, with DBS up 0.2% and UOB down 0.5%. The US markets closed mostly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 Index up 0.5% and 0.6% respectively. European stocks fell 0.3% due to auto shares and comments from central bank officials.

images.alt_text: Nio's Singapore-listed shares closed Monday up 0.5 per cent, or US$0.04, at US$7.92.

site_title: Lawmakers want Biden to reject export licenses for Chinese drone maker DJI
summary: US lawmakers, including 15 Republicans, have asked the Pentagon to block export licenses for US components to Chinese drone maker DJI due to national security concerns. The Commerce Department previously added DJI to the export control list in 2020, citing reports of human rights abuses and military ties. The lawmakers claim that US-made components in a recent DJI drone suggest government approval of export licenses, which they believe could harm US national security interests.

images.alt_text: The committee argued that China’s accession to the World Trade Organization in 2001 “undermined and impaired” benefits that the United States and other economies expected to get from expanded trade ties with the country.
BIS is under pressure from Republicans to be tougher on Huawei and SMIC.
Companies such as Intel, Micron, GlobalFoundries are among those seeking significant funding from the chip programme.

site_title: Fresh wave of hybrid NFTs are clogging blockchains in speculative frenzy
summary: A new wave of hybrid NFTs, called inscriptions, are flooding smaller blockchains, causing transaction fees to rise and networks to slow down. Unlike popular NFT collections like Bored Apes and CryptoPunks, inscriptions are minted directly on the blockchain through the Ordinals protocol. This trend is part of a speculative frenzy in the crypto market, similar to the recent popularity of dog-themed memecoins. Experts say it's comparable to the hype surrounding dog coins, with investors creating their own versions on various chains.

images.alt_text: An illustration picture taken in London on December 30, 2021, shows gold plated souvenir cryptocurrency coins arranged by a screen displaying a NFT (Non-Fungible Token) logo. - Non-fungible tokens or NFTs are cryptographic assets stored on a blockchain with unique identification metadata that distinguish them from each other. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Hired: Successful job redesign starts with purpose (Ep 4)
summary: Job redesign is not feared or resisted by employees, but rather can be a successful process. Peter Wu from South Beach Consortium, who led a job redesign, achieved awards for the company. Wu emphasizes the importance of purpose in guiding the redesign process. The company's general manager, Samantha Tan, also shares the benefits of job redesign, including improved job satisfaction and employee engagement. Wu's approach shows that job redesign can be a positive change for employers.

images.alt_text: CWT staff embrace job redesign and wish it could have happened 20 years ago, according to CEO Ricky Loo.

site_title: MAS to suspend non-bank and non-card channels for remittance to China from Jan 1, 2024
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has directed remittance companies to suspend non-bank and non-card channels for cross-border money transfers to China from January 1, 2024, to March 31, 2024. This move comes after reports of remittances being frozen in China due to non-compliance. Remittance companies have a 14-day period to adjust their practices and complete existing remittances. The suspension applies to services using non-bank and non-card channels, and only bank or card network-assisted services will be allowed.

images.alt_text: Money laundering illustration
The digital revolution against trade fraud

site_title: Navigating the post-COP28 landscape for global decarbonisation
summary: The 2023 UN Climate Change Conference (COP28) marked a significant moment in global climate action, with nearly 200 nations committing to tripling renewable-energy capacity and doubling energy efficiency by 2030. However, the declaration raises three critical areas that need sharper focus: realignment, retirement, and reinforcement. Key challenges include transitioning away from fossil fuels, balancing environmental imperatives with economic realities, and championing technological solutions and innovative financing. Countries like Singapore can lead the transition to a sustainable era by establishing credibility, providing financial incentives, and forming partnerships. Decarbonisation has the potential to become a significant economic pillar within the next few decades.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.
After 13 days of talks and another sleepless night in a country built on oil wealth, the Emirati leadership of the COP28 summit announced that the world had reached a consensus.

Climate activists protest after a draft of a negotiation deal was released, at the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, December 13, 2023. REUTERS/Rula Rouhana

site_title: Consumer goods will face ‘largest impact’ from delays, higher costs as vessels avoid Red Sea
summary: Shipping disruptions due to Yemeni rebel attacks in the Red Sea are expected to impact consumer goods with the largest impact, as major shipping lines reroute from the Suez Canal to avoid the area. Delays and higher costs are anticipated, with shipping costs potentially rising by at least 15% and rates increasing significantly. The rerouting of shipping traffic has implications, including higher bunker consumption and increased risk of incidents. At least 12% of global trade passes through the Suez Canal, and the automotive industry may be affected, with 41.3% of vehicles and 20.8% of parts shipped on the affected route.

images.alt_text: A powerful El Nino has reduced rainfall in the region, sapping the canal’s water levels.

“The rise in geopolitical risk premium, which has come in the form of regular hostilities towards commercial vessels in the Red Sea by Iran-backed Houthi rebels plays its indisputable part in oil’s resurrection,”says analyst.
The recent gains for shipping shares have provided some relief for investors after a year of underperformance for the sector.
The market lost ground this week across the whole VLCC sector.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly higher, boosted by merger activity
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly higher, boosted by merger activity, particularly a deal by Nippon Steel to buy US Steel for $14.1 billion. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat, while the S&P 500 rose 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 0.6%. Tech-focused stocks, including Meta Platforms and Alphabet, also gained ground. Despite a surge in oil prices due to geopolitical tensions, market sentiment remains positive, with analysts citing a "year-end rally" and "relative strength in mega cap stocks."

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 34.98 points, or 0.12 per cent, at the open to 37,352.14.

site_title: Washington-area office default risk surpasses that in San Francisco
summary: The Washington area has surpassed San Francisco as the region with the highest share of office buildings at risk of default, with 72% of loans in the US capital region considered "criticized" due to high vacancies and expiring leases. This is attributed to the federal government's slow response to changing work patterns and the potential for office demand to soften if government austerity measures kick in. The office vacancy rate in Washington is 21.1%, compared to 34% for San Francisco, and landlords, including Brookfield, have defaulted on office loans in the area.

images.alt_text: The report found that if about 220 office buildings were converted to housing, they could produce 54% less carbon emissions by 2050. That would be a decrease of up to 11 million tons of carbon dioxide.
Office buildings in Singapore's Central Business District remain relevant post-pandemic.

site_title: Oil jumps more than 3% on Red Sea tanker attack, reroutings
summary: Oil prices surged over 3% on Monday, driven by attacks on ships in the Red Sea by Iran-backed Houthi rebels, disrupting maritime trade and raising supply concerns. Brent crude futures rose $2.82 to $79.37 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained $2.44 to $73.87 a barrel. Analysts attribute the price increase to a rise in geopolitical risk premium, while Russia announced deeper oil export cuts in December to support global prices. However, some experts express skepticism about the extent of Russia's voluntary output cuts.

images.alt_text: The recent gains for shipping shares have provided some relief for investors after a year of underperformance for the sector.

site_title: Oil gains nearly 2% as tankers reroute after Red Sea attacks
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Monday as investors worried about disruptions to maritime trade and supply costs after the Iran-aligned Yemeni Houthi militant group attacked ships in the Red Sea. The Norwegian-owned vessel attacked on Monday prompted oil major BP to temporarily pause all transit through the water, while other shipping firms avoided the route. Brent crude futures rose $1.40 to $77.95 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $1.04 to $72.47 a barrel.

images.alt_text: “The rise in geopolitical risk premium, which has come in the form of regular hostilities towards commercial vessels in the Red Sea by Iran-backed Houthi rebels plays its indisputable part in oil’s resurrection,”says analyst.

site_title: Sanctioning China will work no better than sanctioning Russia
summary: Western sanctions on Russia have had limited effect, with the Russian economy continuing to grow despite strong international pressure. Demand for Russian exports, particularly oil and gas, remains high, and Russia can easily find alternative buyers. The limited success of sanctions can be attributed to Russia's diversified economy and strong energy exports. Policymakers should learn from this experience and focus on sound economic reasoning rather than speculation, as the benefits of maintaining trade relations with China far outweigh the theoretical advantages of increased geostrategic flexibility.

images.alt_text: The key to targetting Russia's oil resources is lower oil prices, not lower export volumes.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on July 15, 2022 pipes and pressure gauges for gas lines are pictured at Open Grid Europe (OGE), one of Europe's largest gas transmission system operators, in Werne, Germany. The European Commission on July 20, 2022 urged EU countries to reduce demand for natural gas by 15 per cent over the coming months to secure winter stocks and defeat Russian "blackmail".
The smartest EU sanction on Russia

(FILES) Pipes and pressure gauges for gas lines at Open Grid Europe (OGE), one of Europe's largest gas transmission system operators, in Werne, western Germany, July 2022.  Germany has an  energy intensity below the EU average.
Is Putin's war driving up commodity prices?

site_title: Building a better tomorrow for all, together
summary: Standard Chartered, a Singapore-based bank, has committed to leveraging its resources and employee volunteers to create positive community impact. Over 4,500 employees volunteered at least once in 2023, supporting causes such as women's empowerment, education, and environmental sustainability. The bank's community initiatives, including the Silver Lining program for seniors and the Futuremakers initiative to empower young women, aim to drive economic growth and create a more inclusive society. Standard Chartered has received numerous awards for its corporate giving and diversity and inclusion efforts, and plans to continue its community-focused approach in 2024.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon turns into a big run for charity
StanChart volunteers guiding seniors on smartphone queries at a digital clinic. The bank hopes to help the seniors embrace digital as a lifestyle.
Simon Cooper (centre) and StanChart volunteers collecting gifts for children under the Grant-A-Wish project.
StanChart employees volunteer to make a difference to the community

site_title: Livestreaming platform 17Live aims to convince investors of booming content creator industry
summary: 17Live, a Taiwanese livestreaming platform, has listed on the Singapore Exchange after completing a business combination with Vertex Technology Acquisition Company. Despite its optimistic outlook on the booming content creator industry, the company's share price tumbled 18.8% on its first day of trading. 17Live aims to educate investors about the industry through a rigorous investor relations program, focusing on its V-Livers, or virtual livestreamers, and plans to expand into new geographical locations, including South-east Asia. The company has generated operating profits and is Ebitda positive since FY2020, but recorded a loss of US$118.2 million for the first half of FY2023.

wcvtac - むらゆき🐈❄VLiver😈 (Murayuki) – VLiver performance

Credit VTAC

epa10887181 A sales promotion woman holds a dress as she live-streams on an e-commerce platform at a shop in Depok, Indonesia, 28 September 2023. The Indonesian government announced a new regulation that officially bans social media sites such as TikTok and Instagram from selling goods and services directly, amid complaints from small and medium business traders, who lack buyers due to goods on social media being sold much cheaper. The Indonesian Trade Minister Zulkifli Hasan explained that social media such as TikTok and Instagram can only promote goods or services.  EPA-EFE/ADI WEDA

site_title: Powell pivot splits views on Fed rate scenarios for 2024
summary: US Federal Reserve interest rate expectations for 2024 have shifted, with investors divided on whether rates will remain elevated or decrease. Despite recent dovish statements from Fed Chair Jerome Powell, BlackRock's Ben Powell and Janus Henderson's Sat Duhra expect interest rates to stay higher for longer due to inflation concerns. In contrast, some analysts, including ING and Fidelity's Christopher Wong, forecast rate cuts, citing potential economic slowdowns and recession risks. The CME FedWatch Tool now shows a 73.1% probability of a rate cut in March, but investors remain cautious amid the uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Fed has changed the wording of its policy statement last week, to indicate that another rate hike is now unlikely.
Manulife US Reit is among the top three performers in December for S-Reits with office properties in the US.
The dollar index remained on track for its worst weekly performance in a month.

site_title: BOJ keeps ultra-loose policy; focus shifts to exit timing
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, keeping short-term and 10-year interest rates at -0.1% and 0%, respectively. Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that conditions remain uncertain, and the central bank will scrutinize wage inflation before considering a policy shift. The BOJ repeated its commitment to take "additional easing steps" if necessary, citing high uncertainty in the economy. The yen fell broadly, while Japanese stock futures jumped following the decision, which was seen as a delay in phasing out stimulus.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan’s stimulus policy, including negative interest rates, should be ditched in the “not so distant future,” says Masakazu Tokura, chief of business lobby Keidanren.
The BOJ gets an update on national inflation trends on Friday, with the pace of gains for prices excluding fresh food seen moderating to 2.6 per cent in November.
A pedestrian walks past the Bank of Japan (BoJ) complex in central Tokyo on October 4, 2023. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

FILE PHOTO: Fumio Kishida, Japan's prime minister, speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo, Japan, November 2, 2023.  Kiyoshi Ota/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Your possessions do not define you
summary: A Singaporean businessman shares his personal experience of growing up feeling inferior due to lack of wealth, but finds transformation through his success in the military. He argues that people's perceptions of success are often based on wealth, education, and titles, rather than individual achievements. He advocates for not measuring others' success by what they have, and instead focusing on personal values and impact. The author believes that one's identity comes from loved ones, not possessions, and encourages readers to re-evaluate their own self-worth.

images.alt_text: Monitoring portfolio returns aganst planning assumptions enables advisers to gauge whether a portfolio's performance is sufficient for clients' long term needs.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher, all eyes on economic data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, December 18, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 34.98 points, or 0.12%, to 37,352.14. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 12.39 and 0.20 points, respectively. The market is watching economic data this week, which could provide insight into when the Federal Reserve may start cutting interest rates.

site_title: Chipmaker Qorvo to sell some China facilities to Luxshare Precision Industry
summary: Qorvo, a US-based chipmaker, has agreed to sell its assembly and test facilities in Beijing and Dezhou, China to Luxshare Precision Industry. The transaction is expected to close by mid-2024, with Luxshare acquiring the facilities and their operations and assets. Qorvo will maintain its sales, engineering, and customer support employees in China and establish a long-term supply agreement with Luxshare to assemble and test products. The deal aims to reduce capital intensity and support long-term gross margin objectives.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
The 7-nanometre processor was designed by Huawei and produced by Semiconductor Manufacturing International.
Apple’s sales in China have fallen in three of the four quarters in its 2023 fiscal year, which ended Sep 30.

site_title: Adobe and Figma terminate US$20 billion deal after regulator clash
summary: Adobe has terminated its planned $20 billion acquisition of Figma after regulators in Europe and the UK expressed concerns that the deal would harm the creative software sector. Adobe will pay Figma a $1 billion termination fee. The decision comes after the US Justice Department prepared a lawsuit to block the acquisition earlier this year. The companies cited "no clear path" to regulatory approvals, despite Figma's rapid growth in the web design market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Adobe logo is seen on smartphone in this illustration taken June 13, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
UK CMA says Adobe will not offer any proposals to address its concerns.

site_title: South Korea’s Coupang to acquire luxury e-commerce retailer Farfetch for US$500 million
summary: Coupang, South Korea's largest e-commerce retailer, will acquire luxury e-commerce platform Farfetch for $500 million, providing a lifeline to the struggling company. Farfetch, once valued at over $23 billion, has faced financial difficulties due to high costs and debt. The acquisition will allow Farfetch to continue operations and provide an elevated experience for exclusive brands, with its founder and CEO, Jose Neves, remaining in an unspecified role. The deal caps a challenging year for luxury e-commerce companies, with other prominent players facing financial struggles.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the luxury goods company Richemont is pictured at its headquarters in Bellevue near Geneva, Switzerland, June 2, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Sanctions fail to stifle Russian economy
summary: Russia's economy has defied sanctions, with the country experiencing a 5.5% GDP growth in the third quarter of 2023. Despite the war with Ukraine, most Russians have accepted the conflict and are supporting the Putin regime. A poll found that 72% of respondents supported an immediate ceasefire, but only 25% were willing to return the Russian-speaking eastern territory to Ukraine. The sanctions have led to a vacuum in the market, allowing Russian businessmen to acquire Western assets at discounted prices. The Russian rouble has devalued by 30% this year, contributing to 7.5% inflation, but interest rates are expected to remain high, dragging the economy down to 1.5-2.5% growth in the next two years.

images.alt_text: Contrary to analysts’ expectations, the Russian economy has not collapsed as a result of Western sanctions. One reason is that demand for Russian exports – particularly oil and gas – remains strong.

MCDONALD'S is selling its Russia business to its current licensee Alexander Govor and the restaurants would operate under a new brand, ending more than 3 decades of presence in the country following its invasion of Ukraine.
People gather for the launching of the new coffee shop "Stars Coffee", which opens following Starbucks' exit from the Russian market.
Beverages imported from Japan and China on sale in Vladivostok, Russia. Sellers have been advertising drinks such as Coca-Cola as imported, so buyers know it is the real thing.

site_title: US solar firm SunPower shares slide after raising going concern doubts
summary: US solar firm SunPower shares plummet 25% after the company reported substantial doubts about its ability to continue as a going concern. The delay in filing quarterly results led to a breach of a credit agreement, potentially resulting in the immediate payment of $65.3 million. SunPower cited issues with microinverter components at third-party locations as the cause of the financial concerns. The company's stock value may be significantly reduced if it fails to continue its business operations.

site_title: Hong Kong billionaire Cheng Family’s NWS reshuffles leaders amid succession saga
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Henry Cheng has reshuffled leaders at his US$26 billion business empire, NWS Holdings. Three of Cheng's children now lead major listed arms: Brian, 41, co-CEO, Adrian, 44, CEO of real estate developer New World Development, and Sonia, joint vice-chairman of Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group. CEO Eric Ma resigned, and Henry Cheng remains chairman of all three companies. The changes, effective January 1, come amid succession uncertainty and pressure from New World's high debt level and a real estate sector sell-off.

images.alt_text: New World, which has one of the highest debt ratios among its peers after a years-long expansion spree, had US$8.4 billion dollars worth of outstanding bonds before it launched the tender offer for seven of its bonds.

site_title: Europe: Shares ease as ECB officials temper rate cut optimism
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3% on Monday, marking its first five-week winning streak since April, as auto shares declined and ECB officials tempered expectations of early interest rate cuts. ECB policymakers pushed back against market expectations, with Slovak central bank chief Peter Kazimir stating that rate cuts are premature and ECB policymaker Bostjan Vasle suggesting a reassessment in spring. The decline was driven by a decline in German business morale and a drop in expectations, while energy stocks rose due to disruptions in maritime trade.

site_title: EU launches ‘illegal content’ probe into Elon Musk’s X
summary: The European Union has launched a formal probe into Elon Musk's X platform, the first major online platform to be targeted under the Digital Services Act, for allegedly spreading disinformation related to Hamas's October 7 attack in Israel. The probe will examine four areas, including the dissemination of illegal content and the effectiveness of X's efforts to combat disinformation. If proven infringements, the EU can impose fines up to 6% of X's global revenues or ban the platform operating in the EU.

images.alt_text: X has historically relied on advertising for the bulk of its sales, but that business has been in decline since Musk’s takeover.

X, formerly known as Twitter, risks  losing as much US$75 million in advertising revenue by the end of the year as major brands pause their marketing campaigns on the platform, according to the New York Times.

Elon Musk has faced a torrent of criticism since he on Nov 15 agreed with a user who falsely claimed Jewish people were stoking hatred against white people, saying the user who referenced the “Great Replacement” conspiracy theory was speaking “the actual truth.”

site_title: Apple to halt US sales of Series 9, Ultra 2 smartwatches on patent dispute
summary: Apple has paused sales of its Series 9 and Ultra 2 smartwatches in the US due to a patent dispute with medical technology company Masimo. The US International Trade Commission had ordered Apple to stop importing its Apple Watches in October, citing patent infringement. Apple will halt sales from its website starting December 21 and from retail locations after December 24, as a precautionary measure in case the ruling stands. A presidential review period is ongoing until December 25.

site_title: BP to pause all tanker transits through the Red Sea
summary: BP has paused all tanker transits through the Red Sea following an escalation in attacks on merchant vessels by Houthi militants, citing crew welfare as its priority. The decision applies to all BP-owned and chartered ships, and comes days after major shipping lines temporarily halted operations in the area. Avoiding the Red Sea means sailing around Africa, delaying cargo deliveries, and impacting global energy flows. The move is expected to put pressure on other firms to follow suit.

images.alt_text: The recent gains for shipping shares have provided some relief for investors after a year of underperformance for the sector.

site_title: Singapore’s green report card a reminder of broader issues for the Republic
summary: Singapore's green report card highlights the tension between economic growth and emissions. The government's public sector emissions, covering Scope 1 and 2 emissions, totaled 3.7 million tonnes in 2023, under 10% of the country's total emissions of 53.7 million tonnes. The report notes the growing impact of digitalization, which can both enable green efforts and exact an environmental toll through energy consumption. The government must balance green efforts with other priorities, such as economic growth, and consider the climate impact of digitalization to mitigate emissions.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

Government chief sustainability officer Lim Tuang Liang said the public sector believes that its transparency through reporting will spur agencies to continuously strive to minimise the environmental impact of their operations.

site_title: Diamond sales slowly restart after efforts to halt price Crash
summary: The diamond industry has slowly restarted sales after a price crash, with Russia's Alrosa and De Beers resuming rough diamond sales at the end of November and early December, respectively. The move aims to alleviate the industry's supply glut, which was exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, inflation, and the global property crisis in China. Although sales have been limited, the efforts appear to be working, with some price gains for rough diamonds. However, concerns remain about the impact of large stockpiles on the market recovery.

images.alt_text:
rmgem - India's diamond processing hub of Surat employs at least a million workers to cut, polish and set the gem. Around 90 per cent of the world's diamonds are polished in India. 

Photo credit: GJEPC

site_title: AI can create more jobs than it potentially eliminates: Tech Mahindra CEO
summary: Tech Mahindra's outgoing CEO CP Gurnani believes that generative AI technology will create more jobs than it eliminates, citing its potential to create new job opportunities and expand the market. Despite concerns about job losses, Gurnani emphasizes that skilled people will not be replaced, and young engineers should invest in learning new skills. This stance contrasts with some industry executives who have predicted significant job losses due to AI automation.

images.alt_text: SenseTime’s focus this year turned from its traditional strengths in facial recognition to generative AI.
AI is a leadership imperative with real impact, so generative AI must be managed across the board.

site_title: Explained: Why English football club finances are under scrutiny
summary: English Premier League football club Everton has been sanctioned for using accounting tricks to play down its financial losses, resulting in assessed losses of £287 million over three years. The club was docked 10 points and is at risk of relegation due to rules that cap losses at £105 million. Everton deducted interest payments on loans to build a new stadium, which the league deemed as a permitted infrastructure investment, but the club claimed it was for working capital. The club is appealing the decision, while other Premier League clubs, including Chelsea and Manchester City, face similar allegations of financial irregularities.

images.alt_text: The collection included the shirt Messi wore during the first half of the final against France in Qatar.

site_title: ECB must see inflation below 3% by mid-2024 before cutting rates: policymaker
summary: European Central Bank policymaker Yannis Stournaras stated that the ECB must see inflation below 3% by mid-2024 before cutting interest rates from record highs. Stournaras emphasized the need for sustained low inflation, alongside unit labor costs, unit profits, and inflation expectations, to justify rate cuts. This stance contrasts with market expectations, which anticipate rate cuts in April or March, and highlights the ECB's resolve to combat the worst bout of inflation in a generation.

images.alt_text: The Fed has changed the wording of its policy statement last week, to indicate that another rate hike is now unlikely.
The BOJ gets an update on national inflation trends on Friday, with the pace of gains for prices excluding fresh food seen moderating to 2.6 per cent in November.
The dollar index remained on track for its worst weekly performance in a month.

site_title: Japan’s Nippon Steel to buy US Steel in US$14.9 billion deal
summary: Japan's Nippon Steel agreed to buy US Steel for $14.9 billion in a cash deal, prevailing over rival bids from Cleveland-Cliffs and ArcelorMittal. The acquisition will help Nippon expand its US production, offsetting declining demand in Japan, and move towards 100 million tonnes of global crude steel capacity. US Steel's shares rose 28% following the deal, and the company will honour all employee commitments, including collective bargaining agreements. The transaction is expected to close in 2024, subject to US regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: As Nippon Steel expands in lower-emission business including carbon capture and storage, it plans to issue a green bond on the Japanese market to co-finance production of electrical steel sheets used in eco-friendly car motors, it said.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence brightens as interest rates ease
summary: US homebuilder confidence rose in December, increasing to 37 from 34 the month prior, according to the National Association of Homebuilders/Wells Fargo Index. This uptick is attributed to easing interest rates, with mortgage rates down roughly 50 basis points over the past month, causing some prospective buyers to re-evaluate the market. Builders report an increase in traffic, with NAHB chairman Alicia Huey stating that some buyers who previously felt priced out are taking a second look.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage falls by 10 basis points to 7.07 per cent in the week ended Dec 8.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage decreases 20 basis points to 7.17 per cent in the week ended Dec 1, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.
Many homeowners are unwilling to sell, in part because that means letting go of the cheap mortgages they locked in during the pandemic.
Investment in residential construction shot up 1.2 per cent.
Pending home sales are down 6.6 per cent from a year earlier on an unadjusted basis.
FILE PHOTO: A newly constructed home available for sale is pictured in a new housing development area in Vista, California March 20, 2012. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: UK recession risk returns with data signalling possible downgrade
summary: The UK's economy may be at risk of a technical recession, with the threat of a downgrade to GDP estimates due out this week. Weaker-than-expected retail sales have raised concerns, potentially shaving a couple of tenths of a percentage point off growth. A downgrade could revive talk of a technical recession, which would be a bleak backdrop for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's re-election bid. Despite mixed data, business and consumer surveys show optimism, while insolvencies and slowing demand from the Bank of England's agents paint a more dour picture.

images.alt_text: A handout photograph released by the UK Parliament shows Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaking during Prime Minister's Questions (PMQs), in the House of Commons, in London, on November 29, 2023. (Photo by Jessica TAYLOR / UK PARLIAMENT / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - NO USE FOR ENTERTAINMENT, SATIRICAL, ADVERTISING PURPOSES - MANDATORY CREDIT " AFP PHOTO / Jessica TAYLOR / UK Parliament"
UK economy begins tepid recovery in May after record slump

site_title: What climate negotiations changed
summary: The recent COP28 climate negotiations have sparked debate among businesses, with some viewing the agreements as a step forward and others as a hindrance to their year-end results and 2024 outlook. The conference agreed on a "transition away" from fossil fuels, but the shift to renewables and energy efficiency will be complex and slower in the region of Asean, where coal, oil, and gas dominate power generation. To accelerate the transition, funding, seamless border electricity transfers, and carbon markets are needed, with opportunities for businesses that can adapt to the changing landscape.

Workers installing solar panels on the rooftop of Block 850 Tampines Street 82 as part of HDB's SolarNova Programme on Nov 17, 2023.
