site_title: Yen clings on to gains ahead of key BOJ decision; US dollar slips
summary: The Japanese yen held near its recent highs ahead of the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) key decision, despite a 0.4% rise in the US dollar to 142.76. The yen has gained 6% in value since hitting a multi-decade low against the US dollar in November. Investors await Tuesday's BOJ decision for further clarity on the bank's rate outlook, with a policy shift unlikely to come as early as December. The Australian and New Zealand dollars also rose, while the euro edged down 0.5% to 155.74.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan’s stimulus policy, including negative interest rates, should be ditched in the “not so distant future,” says Masakazu Tokura, chief of business lobby Keidanren.

site_title: Luxury fashion company Golden Goose to raise 1 billion euros in IPO: sources
summary: Golden Goose, a luxury fashion company, plans to raise about 1 billion euros from an initial public offering (IPO) in Milan. The company's majority owner, Permira, has enlisted seven banks to underwrite the deal, which is set to be one of Europe's biggest IPOs next year. Golden Goose posted a 30% revenue jump to 501 million euros in 2022, following a trend of fashion companies raising funds through IPOs. The move is seen as a way to breathe new life into Europe's capital markets.

images.alt_text: Since the business combination was completed on Dec 8, 17Live has been in the red every day. The sell-off had already started earlier in December, when it was still trading as VTAC.
The IPO approval from the Shanghai Stock Exchange comes two months after it suspends the listing process in order to request Brite clarify its relationship with SMIC.
Hong Kong’s total retail sales are down about 20 per cent from 2018 levels and in an effort to reduce the reliance on luxury spending by Chinese shoppers.

FILE PHOTO: A banner to celebrate the IPO of online fashion house Farfetch is displayed on the facade of the of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., September 21, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Shipping stocks advance as Red Sea attacks seen squeezing supply
summary: Shipping stocks surged globally on Monday as militant attacks on the Red Sea were expected to disrupt routes, driving up prices for moving goods in ocean containers. AP Moller-Maersk, Hapag-Lloyd, and ZIM Integrated Shipping Services rose 4.7%, 5.5%, and 8% respectively, with some analysts predicting a 6% effective container supply reduction if all trades were re-routed through South Africa. The recent gains provide relief for investors after a year of underperformance for the sector.

images.alt_text: Maersk says that its vessel Maersk Gibraltar is being targeted by a missile while traveling from Salalah, Oman, to Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and confirms that the crew and vessel are safe.

site_title: India KFC operator Devyani International enters Thailand with US$129 million deal
summary: Devyani International, an India-based KFC operator, has entered Thailand with a $129 million deal. The acquisition will add 274 KFC outlets in Thailand, employing over 4,500 people. This deal complements Devyani's existing 500 KFC outlets in India, Nepal, and Nigeria. The acquisition is expected to be completed by March 2024, with Devyani citing Thailand's strong poultry market as a growth opportunity.

site_title: Singapore welcomes Japan’s leadership to help Asia become greener: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong welcomed Japan's leadership in its Asia Zero Emission Community (Azec) initiative, which aims to promote green and sustainable growth in the region. The initiative, led by Japan, includes 12 Asean countries and Australia, and focuses on customized pathways to reduce carbon emissions. Lee expressed support for Azec, noting that Singapore will need to adopt similar strategies to reach net zero by 2050. The two countries also agreed on a Green and Digital Shipping Corridor to decarbonize the maritime industry, and Japan will issue $15 billion in climate transition bonds to support the initiative.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (left) with   PM Lee at the  the opening session of the Asean-Japan Commemorative Summit Meeting at the Hotel Okura Tokyo on Dec 17.

site_title: Southwest Airlines agrees to US$140 million penalty over 2022 holiday meltdown
summary: Southwest Airlines agreed to a record-setting $140 million civil penalty over the December 2022 holiday meltdown that caused 16,900 flight cancellations and stranded 2 million passengers. The settlement includes a $35 million cash fine and a three-year mandate to provide $90 million in travel vouchers to passengers delayed at least three hours. The US Department of Transportation credits the settlement as a "strong deterrent" to airlines, following the Biden administration's efforts to require new passenger compensation.

images.alt_text: In the aftermath of a meltdown that led to 16,700 flight cancellations, blame has fallen on an outmoded crew scheduling system and an unusual point-to-point route network.

site_title: Software firm Alteryx to be taken private in US$4.4 billion deal
summary: Alteryx, a data analytics company, has agreed to be acquired by private-equity firms Clearlake Capital Group and Insight Partners in a deal valued at US$4.4 billion, including debt. Alteryx's stockholders will receive US$48.25 per share in cash, valuing its equity at US$3.46 billion. The deal comes after the company faced setbacks in winning new business and fierce competition from larger rivals, leading to a decline in its valuation and making it an acquisition target.

images.alt_text: Since the business combination was completed on Dec 8, 17Live has been in the red every day. The sell-off had already started earlier in December, when it was still trading as VTAC.
“It is clear that no realistic remedy would satisfy the concerns the CMA is maintaining,” says Adobe.

site_title: The economic year ahead will not be binary
summary: The global economy in 2024 is expected to be more nuanced and complex than predicted, with multiple factors influencing its trajectory. The pandemic's ongoing impact, decoupling, and industrial policy are introducing new dynamics in fiscal policy and trade relations. Trade tensions, particularly between the US, China, and Europe, are also likely to escalate, driven by competition for domestic manufacturing and energy security. Additionally, the shift in interest rates and its impact on consumers and companies will be felt over time, rather than all at once, leading to unpredictable disruptions.

images.alt_text: At the COP28 climate summit last week, around 110 countries pledged to treble renewable energy capacity by 2030.
Fed Chair Jerome Powell flagged the uncertainty of the US economic outlook and said he couldn’t definitively rule out higher rates at this point, even as officials looked toward a lower policy rate.

site_title: Princess Diana dress sells for record US$1.1 million at auction
summary: A black and blue ballerina-length evening dress worn by Princess Diana in 1985 has sold for a record-breaking US$1.1 million at an auction. The dress, designed by Jacques Azagury, was first worn by Diana in Florence and later photographed in Vancouver. The sale, part of the "Hollywood Legends" sale, more than doubled the estimated price of US$100,000 - US$200,000. The dress features a long black velvet bodice and a two-tier blue organza skirt. Julien's Auctions now holds the world record for the most expensive Princess Diana dress sold at auction.

images.alt_text: The "Black Sheep Jumper" designed by Sally Muir and Joanna Osborne and worn on several occasions by Britain's late Princess Diana, at Sotheby's auction house in London, Britain on July 17, 2023.

site_title: Metech notes ex-JV partner’s expertise after SGX queries about continued collaboration
summary: Metech International has partnered with former joint-venture (JV) partner Deng Yiming to expand its diamond business despite previous issues, including missing diamonds and inflated machine prices. Deng brings extensive experience in the semiconductor retail industry, and Metech has agreed to repay S$483,000 in damages. The company has also updated its internal policies and is seeking to implement safeguards to protect its interests. Metech's lab-grown diamond business generated only S$3,000 in revenue for the 12 months ended June 30, 2023, compared to S$2.78 million in the previous year.

images.alt_text: diamond, cubic zirconia, jewel

site_title: Shanghai Stock Exchange approves Brite Semiconductor for IPO
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange approved Brite Semiconductor's initial public offering (IPO) after the company clarified its relationship with SMIC, a Chinese chip foundry blacklisted by the Trump Administration. Brite, which buys wafers from SMIC, denied unreasonable purchase prices and maintained no direct or indirect controlling shareholder. The IPO will raise 600 million yuan (S$112 million) on Shanghai's STAR Market, with Beijing classifying Brite as a "little giant" with preferential access to government support.

site_title: Thai rice farmer makes art with plantings that depict cats
summary: Thai rice farmer Tanyapong Jaikham has created a unique art piece by planting cartoon cat seedlings in a rice field in Chiang Rai province. The artwork, based on a traditional Thai proverb, uses coordinates from the Global Positioning System to position the seedlings, which change tint as they grow. The final harvest stage will reveal a portrait of a cat, attracting tourists and cat lovers. The project aims to develop tourism and agriculture simultaneously, showcasing the interaction of art and technology.

images.alt_text: Former rescue dogs Alba and Rosie pose with a painting they helped to create at the Bristol Animal Rescue Centre.

site_title: Arm lays off over 70 engineers in China, relocating roles
summary: ARM Holdings has laid off over 70 software engineers in China, relocating some roles outside the Asian nation. The move follows a downturn in smartphone sales and a slump in the semiconductor industry. The company, which has been impacted by restrictions on technology exports to Chinese companies, is restructuring its China software engineering resources. About 15 staff will be offered different roles working on China-related projects, while the remaining jobs are currently filled by contract software engineers.

images.alt_text: Arm’s chip designs are widely used by smartphone makers, and the sluggish sales are a symptom of problems in that industry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 18)
summary: Singapore's GDP growth slowed to 0.3% in November, easing from October's 5.7% increase. Key exports rose 1% in November, driven by a surge in pharmaceutical products. Hoteliers are investing in new facilities to capitalize on shifts in travel behavior. Sembcorp partnered with Japanese companies to produce green ammonia in India for export to Japan. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks fell 0.1% amid uncertainty over Asian central bank rate decisions.

site_title: German business expectations fall, dampening hope of rebound
summary: Germany's business expectations have worsened, falling to 84.3 in December from 85.1 the previous month, as hesitant consumers, weak global demand, and geopolitical tensions continue to affect the economy. This marks the first decline since August and undermines hopes of a recovery early next year. The Ifo institute's expectations gauge and current conditions index also dropped, with companies expressing less satisfaction and greater skepticism about the first half of 2024. The Bundesbank still predicts growth will return next year, but now expects 0.4% expansion in 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers assemble campers at Knaus-Tabbert AG factory in Jandelsbrunn near Passau, Germany, March 16, 2021. REUTERS/Andreas Gebert/File Photo
Germany’s constitutional court ruling forced Chancellor Scholz’s government to suspend a constitutionally enshrined “debt brake” for the 2023 budget and to re-think its 2024 plans.
Production declines 0.4 per cent from September, led by the machinery and equipment sector,.

site_title: Delivery Hero to close tech hubs in Turkey and Taiwan, cut jobs
summary: Delivery Hero to close global tech hubs in Turkey and Taiwan, reducing workforce by around 13% at its Berlin headquarters. The company aims to reach profitability while maintaining growth amid investor concerns. This move follows a pandemic-driven boost in the company's fortunes.

site_title: Unilever to sell Q-Tips maker Elida Beauty to US firm
summary: Unilever will sell its non-core beauty and personal care division, Elida Beauty, to US private equity firm Yellow Wood Partners for an undisclosed amount, expected to be completed in mid-2024. Elida's portfolio includes brands such as Q-Tips, Brut, and Caress, generating £800 million in revenues in 2022. Unilever initially attempted to divest Elida in 2021 but revived the process in September 2023 after failing to meet valuation expectations. This sale marks the second time Yellow Wood has acquired a non-core brand from Unilever in a year, following the purchase of Suave in May.

images.alt_text: Surge in eating at home cushions virus hit for Unilever
Unilever's India unit beats estimates as consumers stockpile

site_title: Business-leisure travel, long-stay services next growth opportunity for hoteliers
summary: Hoteliers are shifting focus to lifestyle hotels, long-stay services, and niche markets as traditional hotel brands diversify their offerings. Despite a 39.8% decrease in hotel investment volume in the Asia-Pacific region from January to October 2023, the industry is expected to recover in 2024 due to improving airlift, rising room rates, and easing cost pressures. The region's luxury hotel segment is expected to see robust growth, while midscale and economy hotels may lag due to high travel costs and a slow return of Chinese tourists.

images.alt_text: The lobby of Pullman Bangkok King Power hosts a co-working space, where guests can relax, socialise, or hold small group meetings.
Market players from hospitality and tourism industries said the impact of higher hotel room rates in Malaysia will be offset by favourable exchange rates for international tourists.
Indonesia, China, India, Malaysia and Australia are the top five source countries for visitors to Singapore in October.
Investors have announced new hospitality funds in recent months

site_title: To trade the Fed’s pivot, Wall Street turns to short-dated debt
summary: The Federal Reserve's pivot towards monetary easing has led investors to flock to short-term debt, particularly two-year Treasury notes, which offer a 4.4% yield. The Fed's quarterly projections show 75 basis points in interest rate cuts next year, with the federal funds rate expected to drop to 3.6% by the end of 2025. Investors are positioning for a soft landing, with 68% of respondents predicting the yield curve will turn positive by the second half of 2024. Long-term debt is expected to underperform, with traders seeking compensation for added risk.

images.alt_text: The Fed has changed the wording of its policy statement last week, to indicate that another rate hike is now unlikely.
Interest rate expectations appear to have fallen since the dovish statements made by US Fed Chair Jerome Powell on Dec 13.

site_title: GSK’s cancer drug combination meets primary goal in late-stage trial
summary: GSK's cancer drug combination of Zejula and Jemperli met the primary goal in a late-stage trial for treating endometrial cancer. The trial showed that Jemperli plus chemotherapy followed by Jemperli and Zejula improved progression-free survival, a key metric, in both overall patient populations and those with specific tumor types. The analysis of full trial data, including overall survival, is ongoing. The results provide a boost to GSK's oncology business, which has sought to rebuild after Jemperli's approval in the US and UK.

images.alt_text: Britain secures 60m doses of Sanofi/GSK coronavirus vaccine
GSK profit misses target as vaccine sales disappoint, stockpiling eases

site_title: BOJ must normalise monetary policy as soon as possible: business lobby head
summary: Bank of Japan Chief Masakazu Tokura urges the central bank to normalize monetary policy as soon as possible, citing the need to adjust to changing real interest rates. The US has stabilized inflation and real interest rates, while Japan's real interest rates may have turned negative, sparking speculation about a shift away from stimulus policy. Tokura notes that business circles are pushing for sustainable wage hikes and a complete end to deflation, warning that an interest rate policy out of harmony with fundamentals could harm the economy.

images.alt_text: The BOJ gets an update on national inflation trends on Friday, with the pace of gains for prices excluding fresh food seen moderating to 2.6 per cent in November.
A pedestrian walks past the Bank of Japan (BoJ) complex in central Tokyo on October 4, 2023. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

FILE PHOTO: Fumio Kishida, Japan's prime minister, speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo, Japan, November 2, 2023.  Kiyoshi Ota/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: People walk at a crossing in Shibuya shopping area, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, in Tokyo, Japan August 7, 2021. REUTERS/Androniki Christodoulou/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam’s VinFast agrees deal with Marubeni to recycle used EV batteries
summary: Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast has signed a memorandum of understanding with Japan's Marubeni to recycle used EV batteries. VinFast will supply the used batteries, while Marubeni will repurpose them into affordable Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) that are easy to manufacture. The process does not require disassembly, processing, and repackaging of the batteries. The deal was signed during a regional leaders summit in Japan and aims to promote sustainable recycling of EV batteries.

site_title:
Vietnam property developer faces trial 
over 304 trillion dong bond fraud
summary: Vietnam's property developer Van Thinh Phat chairperson Truong My Lan will go on trial for allegedly embezzling 304 trillion dong (S$16.7 billion) from a bank, including setting up fake loan applications to withdraw money from Saigon Commercial Bank. Lan, who holds over 90% of the bank's shares, will face charges of embezzlement, bribery, and violating banking regulations. The trial is set to take place at the Ho Chi Minh City People's Court, with 85 others, including a former State Bank of Vietnam official, also facing trial.

images.alt_text: VinFast will supply the used batteries and Marubeni will repurpose into what it said would be affordable Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) that were easy to manufacture.

site_title: IBM to buy Software AG's enterprise tech business for 2.13 billion euros
summary: IBM will acquire Software AG's enterprise integration platforms, StreamSets and webMethods, for 2.13 billion euros, bolstering its AI and hybrid cloud offerings. The platforms provide application integration, API management, and data integration services. The acquisition is expected to enhance IBM's capabilities in these areas, supporting its hybrid cloud strategy.

images.alt_text: The report comes a day after Elon Musk endorsed an antisemitic post on X that falsely claimed members of the Jewish community were stoking hatred against white people.
As part of its transformation, IBM has divested its managed infrastructure, weather and health businesses in recent years.
Pedestrians walk past International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) offices in New York, U.S., on Monday, Nov. 14, 2011. Photographer: Scott Eells

site_title: China banks step up sales of bad loans as consumer defaults rise
summary: China's banks are accelerating the sale of bad loans to mitigate systemic financial risks amid rising consumer defaults. Issuance of securities backed by non-performing loans (NPLs) is expected to jump 40% this year to a record. Six banks, including China Everbright Bank, plan to issue 1.5 billion yuan worth of asset-backed securities (ABS) this week. The move aims to reduce NPLs on banks' books and revitalise dormant assets. Outstanding bad loans at Chinese banks have reached 3.2 trillion yuan, up one-third from 2019.

images.alt_text: Middle class households are being forced to rethink their money priorities, with some pulling away from investing, or selling assets to free up liquidity.

site_title: China’s IM Motors seeks approval on L3 highly autonomous vehicles
summary: IM Motors, backed by Alibaba Group investments, is applying to China's industry ministry for Level 3 autonomous driving cars. The company's electric vehicles could be among the first models approved as legitimate highly autonomous driving vehicles by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT). This move follows new policies by Chinese regulators to accelerate the adoption of autonomous driving technologies. IM Motors' approval could mark a significant step forward in the development of autonomous vehicles in China.

site_title: SIA to launch non-stop flights to London’s Gatwick Airport in June 2024
summary: Singapore Airlines will launch non-stop flights between Singapore and London's Gatwick Airport in June 2024, with the SQ310 service operating five times weekly on Mondays, Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays. The first flight is set to depart Singapore for Gatwick on June 21, 2024. The return leg, SQ309, will operate five times weekly, providing options for passengers to connect to SIA and Scoot flights to destinations in South-east Asia, Australia, and New Zealand.

images.alt_text: SIA and its budget arm Scoot have carried 3.1 million passengers in November.
Singapore Airlines said it is aware of the Facebook account  “Singapore Airlines Travel” impersonating it and publishing fake advertisements.
Singapore Airlines Group carried just under 3.1 million passengers this month, up 36.1 per cent from Oct 2022.
SIA will codeshare on PAL’s flights from Manila to 27 destinations within the Philippines.
SIA and Scoot say sustainable fuels are critical to the group’s goals of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: BlackRock to invest up to US$400 million in Dubai decarbonisation firm
summary: BlackRock has agreed to invest up to $400 million in Dubai-based decarbonisation company Positive Zero, a decentralized energy transition business, through a diversified infrastructure fund. The investment aims to support Positive Zero's goal of boosting energy transition projects in Gulf countries, aligning with the UAE's objective to triple renewable energy capacity by 2030. Positive Zero was founded by climate investment-focused Creek Capital, a company led by Mohammed Abdulghaffar Hussain and David Auriau. The investment is expected to help Positive Zero capitalize on the UAE's ambitious energy-transition objectives.

images.alt_text: “Coal-powered plants in Asia are much younger than those in the US and Europe, making it difficult to shut them down immediately,” says Dai-ichi Life Research Institute's Mei Makinouchi.
A growing part of what will keep firms here globally competitive is hinging on the companies’ readiness to adapt to new ESG regulations, even if they may not necessarily apply yet, observers said.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

site_title: Sembcorp inks pact to supply Japan with green ammonia produced in India
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a memorandum of understanding with Sojitz Corporation and Kyushu Electric Power to construct green ammonia facilities in India for export to Japan. The partnership aims to support Japan's goal of achieving net zero by 2050 and will be part of Sembcorp's strategic transformation to a "green" portfolio. Subject to final investment and supply arrangements, the facilities will produce green ammonia for transport to Japan, with Sojitz and Kyushu Electric overseeing the supply chain.

images.alt_text: The group’s wholly-owned renewables subsidiary Green Infra Wind Energy will undertake the build-own-operate project.
The SolarLand Phase 1 site on Jurong Island. The tender is the largest project by capacity awarded by a public sector agency in Singapore to date, said Sembcorp.
The assets collectively amount to 428 megawatts (MW), Sembcorp said in an announcement on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: YTL Power up 200%; analysts say Malaysia’s best stock still has legs
summary: YTL Power International has seen a 200% surge in its share price this year, making it the biggest gainer among local companies with a market capitalization of over RM1 billion. Analysts predict the stock could climb 60% next year, driven by strong earnings from its overseas assets, particularly in Singapore and the UK. The company's tie-up with Nvidia to build an AI data centre is also seen as a positive factor. Despite soaring 200% this year, valuations remain undemanding, with the stock trading at 7 times forward-earnings estimates.

images.alt_text: Nvidia, which dominates the market for AI chips, declined to comment.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid uncertainty over Asian central bank rate decisions; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Monday amid uncertainty over Asian central bank rate decisions. The Straits Times Index dropped 3.28 points to 3,113.23, with losers beating gainers 309 to 256. Regional indices were mixed, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 1% and Japan's Nikkei 225 dropping 0.6%. Asia's central banks are moving in different directions, contributing to market uncertainty, with the Bank of Japan considering rate hikes and the People's Bank of China easing policy to combat deflation.

images.alt_text: CMG20231031-HengYY01/  王彦燕 /  组屋 [Pasir Panjang Rd]
The Fed has changed the wording of its policy statement last week, to indicate that another rate hike is now unlikely.

site_title: Partnerships and focusing on SMEs key for Anext Bank
summary: Anext Bank, a digital bank backed by Ant International, is focusing on serving micro, small-and-medium enterprises (MSMEs) in the region. The bank has partnered with companies and startups to better understand the needs of its customers, including foreign business owners. With 68% of its customer base comprised of MSMEs, Anext aims to double down on its efforts to expand its product suite and network, leveraging technologies such as artificial intelligence and data analytics to provide financial services across the region. The bank's goal is to achieve financial inclusion and create a path to business and financial viability for organizations.

images.alt_text: ANEXT is the latest digital bank to be unveiled in Singapore.
On Jun 6, Ant added to its regional presence with the unveiling of its long-awaited Singapore digital wholesale bank: Anext Bank.
Ant is accelerating digital bank operations in South-east Asia, replicating strategies in China that catapulted its fintech operations to becoming the country’s biggest.

site_title: Japan promotes using co-firing technology in Asia
summary: Japan is promoting co-firing technology, using less-polluting ammonia or hydrogen, to reduce emissions at coal-fired power plants in Asia. The technique may extend the life of existing power plants, as they are younger than those in the US and Europe, making immediate shutdowns difficult. Japan's offer comes as part of the Asia Zero Emission Community, which includes Indonesia and Thailand, and aims to provide decarbonization solutions such as bendable solar panels and offshore wind. This move may be seen as a compromise on reducing emissions in Asia.

images.alt_text: A growing part of what will keep firms here globally competitive is hinging on the companies’ readiness to adapt to new ESG regulations, even if they may not necessarily apply yet, observers said.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

site_title: Asian fertiliser buyers turn away from key exporter China amid growing curbs
summary: Asian fertiliser buyers are shifting away from China, the world's top exporter, due to growing curbs on shipments to protect domestic prices. China's export quotas and lengthy inspection requirements have led to a decline in phosphate and urea exports, pushing up global prices. India, one of the world's top fertiliser buyers, has seen a 58% drop in Chinese urea exports, while Malaysia and South Korea are also diversifying their supplies. Analysts predict China's urea exports will remain tight into 2024, with expected incremental growth to around 4 million tonnes.

images.alt_text: epa10831138 A view of a lotus plantation situated within Dal Lake in Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian Kashmir, 31 August 2023. Lotus seeds are a popular ingredient in Kashmiri cuisine and large parts of Asia.  EPA-EFE/FAROOQ KHAN

site_title: Hong Kong’s tycoon-owned property giants could take a leaf from Singapore groups
summary: Hong Kong's property giants, such as Sun Hung Kai Properties and Swire Properties, have been slow to adopt Reits, missing out on selling stakes in properties to free up capital and build a fund management business. In contrast, Singapore has a thriving Reit market with four times as many listed Reits and property-related business trusts. With the upcoming change of CEO at Hongkong Land, a Singaporean executive from Mapletree may bring a fresh perspective, potentially leading to a major push into real estate fund management and a shift towards a more capital-efficient business model, potentially closing the gap with Singapore's Reit market.

images.alt_text: Michael Smith will take on the role of CEO with effect from Apr 1, 2024, and will be relocating to Hong Kong.
Hongkong Land said the weak economic outlook in China weighed on consumer sentiment.

site_title: Goldman ramps up credit business in India, targets rich diaspora
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to expand its credit business in India, targeting the country's wealthy diaspora, as investors shift focus from China to the nation's growing economy. The firm aims to broaden loan offerings through its shadow banking unit and secure a currency trading license. Goldman joins other Wall Street lenders and private equity giants in chasing opportunities in India, which is forecast to grow 7% in the year ending March. This expansion is expected to fuel dealmaking in the country, driven by private capital seeking to invest in India.

images.alt_text: The latest changes come as Goldman seeks to retain that advantage – and as its rivals scramble to respond to the rise of a new asset class that competes directly with their leveraged finance business.
Goldman is trying to bring compensation more in line with rival investment firms as it moves towards third-party capital to fund its investing activities instead of relying on its own balance sheet.

site_title: Zee asks Sony’s Indian arm for extension of merger deadline
summary: Zee Entertainment Enterprises has asked Sony's Indian arm for an extension of the merger deadline to make the scheme effective, citing a lack of votes needed to reappoint independent board directors. The deal, worth $10 billion, has been delayed due to regulatory uncertainties. Sony is pushing for its Indian operations managing director NP Singh to head the merged company, while Zee's candidate Punit Goenka is under investigation. The reappointment of independent directors was crucial as they could have influenced the selection of the merged entity's head. A new deadline has not been set.

images.alt_text: Zee and Sony offer concessions such as pricing discounts to help ease regulatory concerns and receive antitrust approval for the merger.

site_title: China allocates 237.9 billion yuan from sovereign bonds for disaster-hit infrastructure: state media
summary: China has allocated 237.9 billion yuan (S$45.16 billion) from sovereign bonds to support infrastructure renovation in areas hit by natural disasters. This move is part of a plan to issue 1 trillion yuan of sovereign bonds to enhance disaster-prevention infrastructure, widening China's 2023 fiscal deficit target to 3.8% of GDP. The plan aims to rebuild areas affected by floods and improve urban infrastructure to cope with future disasters.

images.alt_text: The cold wave moving through the country from north to south is expected to drag temperatures lower into the weekend, even as Meteorological Centre says rain and snow will decrease.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as US Fed rate-cut rally fades
summary: Asia markets fell on Monday, with Tokyo and other major cities experiencing declines of over one percent. Investors are cautious following last week's US Federal Reserve interest rate rally, with officials downplaying expectations of future rate cuts. The Bank of Japan's meeting this week is also being closely watched, although recent speculation of a policy shift has faded. Despite this, equities are expected to end the year on a high, with the Fed suggesting it will begin loosening monetary policy after inflation data showed a soft landing.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led the advances, surging more than three per cent, while Shanghai was also on the rise.

site_title: Joe Biden safe after car collides with his motorcade in Delaware
summary: President Joe Biden was unharmed after a car collided with a motorcade SUV in his security detail in Delaware on Sunday. The incident occurred while Biden was having lunch with his re-election team. The damaged car was quickly surrounded by police, and secret service agents escorted Biden to his vehicle. Television footage showed agents escorting Biden after the impact, which caused damage to the car's bumper. No injuries or fatalities were reported, and Biden's safety has been confirmed.

site_title: China wealth firm Hywin vows to fix defaults as shares tank 59%
summary: China wealth manager Hywin Holdings has formed a special task force to address delayed payments on investment offerings, following a 59% decline in its US-listed shares. The firm, which distributes real estate wealth management products, has acknowledged delayed payments on certain asset-backed products and is working with developers such as Evergrande Group. The move comes as China's property crisis continues to hurt middle-class families, with defaults by major developers contributing to the economic downturn. Hywin's shares have dropped 59% amid investor concerns over redemption issues.

images.alt_text: Hywin derives most of its revenues from distributing real estate products, including those investing in projects from troubled China Evergrande Group and Sunac China Holdings.

site_title: Editors Talk: Why we need visuals (Ep 9)
summary: SPH Media's editors discuss the importance of visuals in their podcast, "Editors Talk: Why we need visuals (Ep 9)". The conversation highlights the role of visuals in reaching a wider audience, increasing engagement, and enhancing the overall reading experience. The editors emphasize the need for a more visual-centric approach in media consumption, citing the success of digital platforms and social media in driving this trend. The discussion concludes that incorporating more visuals will be crucial for media outlets to stay relevant in the digital age.

site_title: Chinese battery maker REPT Battero Energy rises in HK debut
summary: Chinese battery maker REPT Battero Energy, a unit of Tsingshan Holding Group, rose in its Hong Kong IPO debut after pricing near the bottom of the marketed range. The IPO marked a positive start to the year for new share sales in Hong Kong, which had seen a tepid year for new listings. REPT Battero Energy's shares rose on their first day of trading, despite the IPO pricing being near the bottom of the marketed range.

site_title: Women health med-tech Biorithm bags US$3.5 million in Series A
summary: Biorithm, a Singapore-based women's health med-tech startup, secured US$3.5 million in Series A funding co-led by Adaptive Capital Partners and Seeds Capital. The funding will be used to expand across South-east Asia and the US, further research, and foster global partnerships to strengthen the women's health ecosystem. Biorithm aims to revolutionize the global maternal health market, with the goal of improving patient experience.

site_title: US, Britain call for release of pro-democracy tycoon Jimmy Lai as Hong Kong trial starts
summary: US and British governments have called for the release of pro-democracy tycoon Jimmy Lai, who is standing trial in Hong Kong on national security charges that could send him to jail for life. Lai, 76, is accused of "collusion" with foreign forces under a 2020 sweeping national security law imposed by Beijing. The trial, scheduled for 80 working days, will be closely watched as a barometer for Hong Kong's political freedoms and judicial independence. Critics have condemned the prosecution as politically motivated, with the US and Britain calling for Lai's release.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai (R) is escorted into a Correctional Services van outside the Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong on February 1, 2021, after being ordered to remain in jail while judges consider his fresh bail application, the first major legal challenge to a sweeping national security law Beijing imposed on the city last year. Pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai is set to stand trial on December 18, 2023, where he faces internationally condemned national security charges that could send him to jail for life. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: Thailand plans global tender for 1 trillion baht Landbridge project to help bypass Malacca Strait
summary: Thailand plans to hold an international bidding process for the 1 trillion baht (S$38 billion) Landbridge project, aiming to bypass the Malacca Strait and significantly reduce shipping times between the Indian and Pacific oceans. The 50-year concession will be granted to the winning consortium, which may comprise shippers, logistics operators, and investors. The project, divided into four phases between 2025 and 2040, is expected to break even in 24 years. Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has pitched the project to prospective investors from the US, China, and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin making a pitch  to potential investors about the land bridge project during his recent visit to the US.
Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin makes a pitch to potential investors about the Landbridge project during his recent visit to the US. PHOTO: X
Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin made a pitch to potential investors about the Landbridge project during his recent visit to the US.
Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin addresses the 78th United Nations General Assembly at UN headquarters in New York City on September 22, 2023. (Photo by Bryan R. Smith / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong comeback story turns into terrible year for investors
summary: Hong Kong's financial market experienced a disastrous year in 2023, with the Hang Seng Index falling 15% and initial public offerings raising the smallest amount since the dotcom bubble. Home sales are projected to be the lowest since records began in 2002, and office rents have dropped to levels last seen 13 years ago. Despite this, Hong Kong remains a leading financial hub, home to the regional headquarters of Wall Street banks and a majority of Asia's hedge fund managers. However, the city faces significant challenges, including a slowdown in China's economy and increased scrutiny from Beijing, which could impact investor confidence and Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of Two International Finance Centre (IFC), HSBC headquarters and Bank of China in Hong Kong, China, July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: FTX files plan to end bankruptcy, pay crypto creditors billions
summary: FTX has filed a plan to end its bankruptcy, proposing to distribute billions of US dollars to customers and creditors as cash after liquidating most of its cryptocurrencies. The plan, which will be voted on by creditors next year, leaves key questions unanswered, including the potential restart of the defunct crypto exchange. FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried was convicted of orchestrating a massive fraud that led to the exchange's collapse, and the company has been working to untangle a complex web of debt owed to various creditors since filing for bankruptcy last year.

site_title: Citigroup’s China investment bank plans delayed by data law
summary: Citigroup's plans to establish a wholly-owned securities business in China have been delayed due to the need to comply with the country's data laws. The bank now expects to start the business by the end of 2024, rather than mid-2023, as previously estimated. This delay comes amid a backdrop of property market turmoil and weak business confidence in China, as well as increased scrutiny of data movement across borders. Citigroup has already made some hires and invested in technology infrastructure, but the process is ongoing and uncertain.

images.alt_text: Citi’s municipal offering business has been under scrutiny from the Texas attorney general.
FILE PHOTO: The logo for Citibank is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Citi says it would strip out a layer of management and cut jobs in a sweeping reorganisation.
The debate at Citigroup is focused on how profits from the muni operation have been a laggard.

site_title: Gold listless as focus turns to US inflation report
summary: US gold futures fell 0.1% to US$2,033.20, while spot gold remained unchanged at US$2,019.49 per ounce, ahead of the US inflation report this week. The Fed's recent dovish pivot has sparked market expectations of rate cuts, but New York Fed president John Williams cautioned against premature speculation. Analysts forecast the November core PCE index to rise 0.2% last month, potentially supporting non-interest-bearing bullion.

images.alt_text: The fortunes of gold as a solid and respected basis for money has gone through a series of evolutions over the last 300 years.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: Will I lose my job to AI?  (Ep 5)
summary: A podcast series "Lens On Singapore" explores the concept of upskilling and reskilling in the era of digital disruption and AI. Claressa Monteiro discusses the reality of upskilling and reskilling, the importance of unlearning, and the challenges of adapting to AI-driven job displacement. The conversation also touches on the role of employers in upskilling and the uniqueness of job opportunities in Singapore.

images.alt_text: While there are numerous courses, the question is whether the time investment in  guarantees our continued employability.

site_title: SenseTime plunges after death of China AI firm’s co-founder
summary: SenseTime, a Chinese AI firm, plummeted 18% in Hong Kong after the death of co-founder and major shareholder Tang Xiao'ou, who died after an illness. The company's growth has slowed due to competition, US sanctions, and a US blacklist, resulting in a 21% stake loss and a $1.1 billion net worth. Tang's death also comes after short-seller accusations and a decline in the stock's price, which was less than a third of its listing price.

images.alt_text: SenseTime CEO Xu Li took to the stage on Monday (Apr 10) to show the capabilities of its large AI model SenseNova and a user-facing chatbot called SenseChat.

site_title: Hong Kong luxury retailers adjusting to drop in high-spending Chinese tourists
summary: Hong Kong's luxury retailers are adjusting to a decline in high-spending Chinese tourists, with total retail sales down about 20% from 2018 levels. The shift in consumer preferences is driving a focus on local culture and experience-based tourism, prompting retailers to prioritize food and beverage outlets. Luxury brands such as Harvey Nichols, Valentino, and Burberry are closing stores, while others like Louis Vuitton and Chanel are opening new locations. Despite this, the city is expected to recover to its pre-Covid personal luxury goods sales levels by mid-2024, with repositioning efforts and increased competition from Hainan island.

images.alt_text: It’s the first time Hong Kong dropped out of the top three spots in the rankings since they began in 2003.
Hong Kong’s borrowing costs have surged in the last two years as the Fed aggressively raised rates to fight inflation.
Sunday’s voting day stretched to midnight, after a rare 90-minute extension was granted following a failure in the digital system used to confirm voters’ eligibility.

site_title: Next-gen challenge for the wealthy: How to raise good stewards of wealth and values
summary: The ultra-wealthy are facing a significant challenge in raising responsible heirs to take over their families' wealth and values. A survey of Apac family offices found that 58% of respondents believed their next-generation members were "inadequately qualified" to take over. The lack of a succession plan and reluctance to relinquish control are also major concerns. Experts believe that imparting core family values, teaching hard and soft skills, and providing opportunities for young heirs to practice these skills are key to raising responsible leaders. Ultimately, the task of nurturing younger family leaders cannot be outsourced, and must start and be sustained within the family.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Over the next 20 to 30 years, more than 1,000 billionaires are expected to pass on an estimated US$5.2 trillion to the next generation.

site_title: Chinese firms look to Malaysia for assembly of high-end chips: sources
summary: Chinese semiconductor design companies are tapping Malaysian firms to assemble high-end chips, including graphics processing units (GPUs), to hedge against US sanctions on China's chip industry. The requests only include assembly and not fabrication, and some contracts have already been agreed upon. Malaysia, a major hub in the semiconductor supply chain, is seen as a good option due to its affordable costs, experienced workforce, and sophisticated equipment. The move aims to limit China's access to high-end GPUs that could fuel AI breakthroughs or power supercomputers and military applications.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production in October rose 2.7 per cent from a year earlier, faster than expected, government data showed on Monday.
The Tourism Authority of Thailand expects a further recovery to 35 million visitors next year, including 8.2 million from China.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Monday’s open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares began Monday in negative territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.7% to 3,094.69 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 86 to 59, with 85.7 million securities worth S$91.2 million changing hands. Local banks were mixed, with DBS being the sole gainer, while medical technology companies Biolidics and Medtecs International advanced. The decline follows a global rally on optimism over rate cuts, with US stocks finishing the week mostly higher.

images.alt_text: SIA group passenger traffic rises 17.6% year on year in November

site_title: China’s economic conditions to improve in 2024: officials
summary: China's economy is expected to see more favorable conditions and opportunities in 2024, with macroeconomic policies continuing to support economic recovery. Despite weak demand, consumption, and enterprise investment, officials plan to shift focus to sustained consumption growth. The government aims to cultivate new areas such as smart homes, recreation, and tourism, and will monitor the real estate market. China's growth forecast has been revised upward to 5.4% by the International Monetary Fund, and the government targets around 5% growth. Officials aim to achieve policy objectives of real estate risk prevention and market stabilization.

images.alt_text: Middle class households are being forced to rethink their money priorities, with some pulling away from investing, or selling assets to free up liquidity.
Revenue from land sales falls 1.5 per cent in November from a year earlier, compared with a 25.4 per cent slump the prior month.
In the first 11 months, China fiscal revenue logs a 7.9 per cent increase from a year earlier, compared with 8.1 per cent growth in the January-to-October period.

Pedestrians and shoppers on Nanjing Road shopping street in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. China’s Golden Week got off to a promising start as tourist trips and revenue jumped through the start of the holiday, suggesting some resilience in consumer appetites. Source: Bloomberg

site_title:
Business travel emissions drop 
as many firms fly less: survey
summary: Business travel emissions have dropped by at least 50% globally among 217 firms between 2019 and 2022, with many opting for video conferencing or rail trips instead of flying. Major companies such as SAP, PwC, and Lloyd's Banking Group reduced their corporate air travel emissions by over 75%. However, 21 companies, including L3Harris, Boston Scientific, and Marriott International, increased their emissions by more than 69%. Advocates see this trend as a step towards minimizing overall emissions, while airlines warn of potential economic harm.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is Singapore's top source of visitors in November, followed by China, Malaysia, India and Australia.
Analysts expect Singapore-listed stocks in the hospitality, transport and retail sectors to gain from relaxed visa regulations between China and Singapore next year.

site_title: Forging a more inclusive digital future with DBS Foundation
summary: DBS Foundation has developed community-centric digital literacy programmes to bridge the gap for non-digital natives in Singapore, as the city-state's digitalisation drive accelerates. With 99% of resident households connected to the internet and 97% owning smartphones, the foundation aims to ensure no one gets left behind. The programmes focus on digital literacy, providing a more inclusive digital future for all.

images.alt_text: Minister Desmond Lee (1st row, 4th from right), with representatives and volunteers from DBS and MSF, and ComLink+ families.
This year, DBS has set up pop-up markets in the community offering a wide range of food and household necessities, giving beneficiaries the freedom to choose what they want and need.
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (right) at Tuesday's pilot financial literacy workshop by DBS Foundation and SG Enable, where persons with disabilities received guidance from DBS volunteers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Clas, SIA, Manulife US Reit, Lendlease Global Reit, Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Singapore Airlines' passenger traffic rose 17.6% year-on-year in November, surpassing capacity growth. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Ascott Trust divested three hotels in Osaka, Japan, for $100.3 million. Manulife US Reit completed the divestment of Park Place in Arizona, and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit restructured a lease at its Milan portfolio property. Cromwell European Reit repurchased 10% of its bonds for $72.6 million.

images.alt_text: STI down 1.9% over the week on earnings declines and misses

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Gold - the ultimate safe haven investment (Ep 158)
summary: Gold is considered a safe haven investment due to its history and liquidity profile, comparable to major global currency and equity markets. In 2023, gold tested record highs, and its performance is expected to continue in 2024. High liquidity is not compromised, making it an attractive option for investors. Robin Tsui of State Street Global Advisors emphasizes gold's role as an ultimate diversifier, and gold ETFs or jewelry may be suitable investment choices for 2024.

images.alt_text: There are still wealth building opportunities within real estate in 2024.
Don’t let fears hold you back from achieving your financial goals.

site_title: Fed rate cuts could spur risk-taking in 2024
summary: The US Federal Reserve held its federal funds rate steady at 5.25-5.5% for the third consecutive meeting, signaling a slowdown in interest rate hikes. The Fed now expects three 25-basis-point rate cuts in 2024, leading to a federal funds rate of 4.5-4.75%. This dovish shift is expected to boost markets, but investors should focus on companies with strong balance sheets and reasonable market valuations due to slowing global economic growth. A weaker US dollar could also support Asian economies, allowing central banks to implement looser monetary policy.

site_title: Mitsubishi UFJ unit to buy Australia’s Link Administration for A$1.2 billion
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Finance Group's unit has agreed to buy Australia's Link Administration for A$1.2 billion, with Link shareholders set to receive A$2.26 per share. The deal is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, with the acquisition expected to take place from June 2024 onwards. The purchase will enable Mitsubishi UFJ to expand its global business, particularly in Australian funds and corporate clients.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit buys back 50 million euros in bonds due 2025
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) repurchased 50 million euros (S$72.6 million) of its 500 million euro 2.125% bonds due 2025, reducing the outstanding amount to 450 million euros. The move aims to reduce refinancing risk and protect unitholders' equity ahead of rising interest rates. The Reit's manager expects to book a profit of 3 million euros from the discounted purchase price and plans further asset sales in 2024 to manage liquidity.

images.alt_text: The results bring the Reit's year-to-date DPU to 11.795 euro cents.
Artist's impression of Via Nervesa 21 in Milan, Italy, after redevelopment.
Simon Garing, chief executive of the manager of Cromwell European Reit.
Viale Europa 95

site_title: BOJ isn’t ready for a requiem to the negative-rate era
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is unlikely to end its negative interest-rate era this week, as governor Kazuo Ueda is waiting for hard evidence of sustainable inflation. The BOJ's inflation rate, excluding fresh food, moderated to 2.6% in November, which may not be enough to justify a rate hike. Economists expect the BOJ to raise interest rates no later than April, with two-thirds predicting a rate hike in the coming months. Meanwhile, other central banks, such as the US Federal Reserve, are also considering rate cuts, and investors are monitoring economic data from around the world.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks past the Bank of Japan (BoJ) complex in central Tokyo on October 4, 2023. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

The 10-year JGB yield climbed as high as 5 basis points (bps) to 0.8 per cent earlier in the session, its highest since Nov 16.

site_title: Hot chocolate for the holidays: Wonka tops North America box office
summary: Wonka, a prequel to the classic film, topped North America's box office with an estimated $39 million in the US and Canada, and $112 million overseas. The fantasy musical, starring Timothee Chalamet as a younger Willy Wonka, showed strong momentum and is expected to build through the holiday season. Wonka took the top spot, followed by Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes and The Boy and the Heron.

The process of creating this world, though exhausting and very time consuming – and really the amount of detail is insane – has been incredibly rewarding,” says Rebel Moon's director Zack Snyder.

site_title: Singapore exports up 1% in November after 13 months of contractions
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 1% in November, ending 13 months of contractions, according to data from Enterprise Singapore. This growth was driven by a surge in pharmaceutical product shipments. The result fell short of private-sector economists' expectations of a 1.5% year-on-year growth, but still eased from October's 5.7% increase.

images.alt_text: EnterpriseSG expects trade performance to xxx in 2024.
Decline in Singapore key exports continues to ease in October, with narrowing 3.4% fall
Because the majority of goods produced in Singapore are not consumed or purchased locally, strong global demand for our goods is key to our economic growth.

site_title: Nissan to export China-developed EVs to global markets
summary: Nissan plans to export China-developed electric vehicles (EVs) to global markets, targeting the same markets as Chinese rivals such as BYD. The company has struck a deal with Tsinghua University to leverage local resources and accelerate research and development on electrification. Nissan aims to export existing internal combustion engine vehicles and upcoming pure electric and plug-in hybrid cars, with a focus on overseas markets. This move follows other foreign brands like Tesla, BMW, and Ford that are expanding their exports of China-made cars to take advantage of lower manufacturing costs.

images.alt_text: The sale will be implemented as part of a share buyback programme announced by Nissan, and is to be executed on Wednesday, Renault says.

Nissan and Mitsubishi confirms they would invest respectively up to 600 million euros and 200 million euros in Ampere, which has been carved out from the rest of Renault and is due to list on the market next year.

(Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Is luxury’s favourite e-tailer about to go bust?
summary: Luxury e-tailer Farfetch is facing a potential collapse after its share price plummeted to a record low of 60 US cents, wiping out nearly a third of its value. The company, valued at over $20 billion in 2021, is struggling to maintain profitability despite backing from major investors like Alibaba and Richemont. Founder Jose Neves is seeking a white knight investor to take the company private, but if problems are not solved, Farfetch may be forced to file for bankruptcy or be liquidated, potentially disrupting the luxury shopping experience for consumers.

images.alt_text: The Bloomberg Subdial Watch Index, which tracks prices for the 50 most traded watch models by transaction value, has dropped about 10 per cent in 2023.
Coming out of 2019's slowdown, companies here have been looking to the upcoming Budget for support - a hope that has intensified as the Covid-19 outbreak threatens to hammer the Singapore economy.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit’s Italy fund restructures lease for Sky Complex in Milan
summary: Lendlease Global Reit's commercial Italy fund has restructured a lease at Milan's Sky Complex, extending the initial term of nine years and one month to 2026 with an option for termination. This move reduces tenant concentration risk and increases rent for two buildings by 1.5%, with a new tenant incentive. The third building will be returned to the landlord in Q1 2024, which will redesign it for multi-tenancy use, broadening the Reit's tenancy base. The new lease is expected to have minimal impact on the Reit's distribution and net asset value.

images.alt_text: Lendlease Global Reit's retail portfolio in Singapore comprises Jem (above) and 313@somerset.
Australia's Lendlease Group scraps dividend as lockdown hits earnings

site_title: Laos battles mounting debt, inflation as it prepares for Asean chairmanship
summary: Laos, set to assume Asean chairmanship in January, is battling mounting debt and inflation, with the IMF estimating public debt at 122% of GDP in 2023. The country's sovereign rating was downgraded during the Covid-19 period, and its currency is the most devalued in the region. Laos has increased its debt through commercial-rate lending for capital-intensive projects, but faces challenges in repaying the loans. The government aims to reduce the annual budget deficit and increase revenue collection, but may need to rely on Chinese banks to defer payments on past loans to alleviate debt and inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: People are seen at a market after army seized power in a coup in Yangon, Myanmar February 2, 2021. REUTERS/Stringer

Laos Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Saleumxay Kommasith (left) shares about the country’s plans for its upcoming Asean chairmanship year, and participated in a question-and-answer segment moderated by Choi Shing Kwok, director and chief executive officer of Iseas-Yusof Ishak Institute.

site_title: Podcast: Extending our career shelf life
summary: Singaporean mid-career professionals are concerned about the impact of digital disruption and AI on their employability. Experts from Workforce Singapore, Singapore Human Resources Institute, and PSB Academy emphasize the importance of upskilling and reskilling. They stress that companies should collaborate with employees to stay relevant, and individuals should focus on deep learning and unlearning old ways of thinking. The experts also encourage graduates to stay calm, as early data shows better employment rates, and have the business and moral courage to look from afresh.

site_title: Private credit rebounds in the crypto sector with a 55% jump in 2023
summary: Private credit in the crypto sector has rebounded with a 55% jump in 2023, reaching US$408 million in active loans via digital ledgers. Blockchain-based private credit platforms, such as Centrifuge and Maple Finance, are offering lower borrowing rates, often under 10%, compared to traditional providers seeking double-digit rates. The sector's recovery is attributed to increased transparency and liquidation mechanisms on blockchains, which reduce lending risks. Despite this, the industry still faces challenges, including uneven access to banks and a lack of a credit rating system, complicating the shift between tokens and fiat currency.

images.alt_text: The Commission disagrees current securities regulations and laws are “unworkable” for the crypto sector, according to a letter from SEC to Coinbase.
Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) CEO Summit in San Francisco, California, U.S. November 16, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Barria
Stablecoins are a form of cryptocurrency backed by an asset or fiat currency.

site_title: From migrant workers to seniors: Dormitory operators eye diversification into eldercare
summary: Migrant worker dormitory operators are diversifying into eldercare services, capitalizing on their pandemic-era experiences. At least two operators, TS Group and Tee Up Capital, are exploring apartments for seniors and live-in foreign worker caregivers. The eldercare sector is expected to grow significantly as Singapore ages and government support boosts the industry's development. Market watchers anticipate higher yields for senior living assets, but the sector is still in its development stage. Experts warn that dorm operators will need to consider their responsibilities and focus on long-term returns, as they navigate the transition into eldercare.

images.alt_text: Public assisted-living housing, including Community Care Apartments, have been incorporated into new Build-To-Order projects, such as Harmony Village @ Bukit Batok that was launched in February 2021.
The development will comprise 200 units of assisted-living apartments, a nursing home with 100 beds, a wellness clubhouse and a geriatric care centre.
Centurion Corp's profits slip 10% in Q2 from costs to manage Covid-19 in workers' dorms

site_title: Global competitiveness of Asean firms increasingly rides on ESG readiness
summary: Asean firms' global competitiveness is increasingly tied to their ESG readiness, with new regulations and carbon pricing mechanisms set to emerge. The European Union's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) and potential tariffs on imported goods could prompt South-east Asian countries to develop separate pricing schemes. Companies must adapt to climate, human rights, biodiversity, and nature-resource management regulations, with Singapore's carbon tax and Indonesia's trial coal-sector carbon pricing being the only national initiatives. Asean countries are also expected to develop stricter environmental regulations, including biodiversity targets and disclosures.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu stands in front of the Singapore Pavilion at the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Dec 11, 2023.

The confusing and difficult issue of carbon pricing

The Asian Development Bank will “almost definitely” upgrade its 2023 growth forecast for developing Asia when it releases its outlook report in April, “if nothing crazy happens” between now and then, the lender's chief economist Albert Park said.
The Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) will put an emissions tariff on imports of carbon intensive goods entering the European Union (EU).
The Dalat Photovoltaic Base in Ordos city, China, April 2023.
Besides tried-and-tested renewable energy options such as solar and wind, the transition focus could lead to greater acceptability around liquefied natural gas as a transition fuel.

site_title: Singapore’s carbon ambitions intact despite COP28 disappointment
summary: Singapore has emerged from COP28 with its carbon ambitions intact, despite disappointment in the global collaboration to create a high-integrity and standardized global carbon market. The nation leveraged its strengths in professional services and trading to advance its goal of becoming a global carbon services and trading center. Singapore scored wins in regional partnerships and domestic climate action, but missed a breakthrough on implementing Article 6, a mechanism to standardize carbon credits. The country remains committed to its net-zero strategy and will continue to engage in international cooperation to achieve its climate ambitions.

images.alt_text: MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures

Permanent Secretary of the Ministry for Sustainability and the Environment Stanley Loh and Vice Minister of Strategic Affairs of the Ministry of
Environment and Energy Carlos Isaac Pérez signed a Memorandum of
Understanding between Singapore and Costa Rica to collaborate on carbon credits under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement on the sidelines of COP28.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

site_title: China’s real estate meltdown is battering middle-class wealth
summary: China's real estate market meltdown is significantly impacting middle-class households, with household wealth declining 30% in stocks, 30% in salary packages, and 20% in investment properties. The housing sector's value is expected to shrink to 16% of China's GDP by 2026, putting 5 million people at risk of unemployment or reduced incomes. Financial investments are also underperforming, with Chinese shares underperforming emerging-market peers and mutual funds in the red. As a result, many are rethinking their money priorities, selling assets, and opting for more conservative investment strategies to protect their wealth.

images.alt_text: Revenue from land sales falls 1.5 per cent in November from a year earlier, compared with a 25.4 per cent slump the prior month.
In the first 11 months, China fiscal revenue logs a 7.9 per cent increase from a year earlier, compared with 8.1 per cent growth in the January-to-October period.
China has been ramping up measures to cushion the impact of the property downturn on its economy, but the sector has failed to stage a robust rebound.

site_title: Canada to announce all new cars must be zero emissions by 2035
summary: Canada plans to announce new regulations requiring all new cars to be zero-emission vehicles by 2035, following the provinces of British Columbia and Quebec. The Electric Vehicle Availability Standard aims to ensure supply and reduce wait times for electric vehicles. The move is part of global efforts to push for electrification, with similar regulations already in place in other countries. The exact details of the new regulations are set to be unveiled this week, with the goal of making electric vehicles more accessible to the Canadian market.

site_title: Higher supply in softening market to keep private home prices in check in 2024
summary: Analysts predict Singapore's private home prices will moderate further in 2024 due to a higher supply of new launches, keeping prices in check. Developers are expected to turn conservative with pricing, and interest rate cuts may spark optimism in the second half of the year. Suburban Outside Central Region (OCR) locations, where prices have risen the fastest, may see eased prices, with affordability becoming a concern.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of National Development announced the ...
Many private residential property landlords can expect to see much higher property tax bills in 2024.

For homebuilding stocks, the bulk of the monthly advance was made during the first three sessions of November after the Federal Reserve announced it would hold its benchmark rate steady for a second meeting.

site_title: CDLHT shifts Singapore hotel focus to occupancy as room-rate rally runs its course
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts, a Singapore hotel operator, is shifting focus from room rates to occupancy as the room-rate rally runs its course. Despite challenges during the pandemic, the hospitality sector has shown operational and financial resilience. The group's CEO, Vincent Yeo, attributes the rise in room rates to the "evolution of hotel room rates" in Singapore, driven by a labour shortage and strong demand. Room rates reached a 16-year high in September, but slipped in October due to seasonal factors and competition from other destinations. CDLHT aims to boost occupancy, which has yet to catch up with pre-Covid levels, and is diversifying into other segments, such as rental housing and build-to-rent residential.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, China, India, Malaysia and Australia are the top five source countries for visitors to Singapore in October.
Average room rates decrease across all four hotel categories in October.
Overall, hotel room revenues surge to S$390.8 million for the month, surpassing August 2019’s S$383.4 million to mark a new high.
The lobby of Pullman Bangkok King Power hosts a co-working space, where guests can relax, socialise, or hold small group meetings.
W Singapore at Sentosa Cove is one of the properties under CDL Hospitality Trusts.  W Hotel has achived its highest Q3 RevPAR as at the end of September.

site_title: Canadian housing starts dive as higher rates bite
summary: Canada's housing starts plummeted 22% in November to 212,624 units, missing estimates by a wide margin. Higher borrowing costs and labour shortages have impacted construction timelines, with the seasonally adjusted annualised rate falling from 272,264 units in October. Economists expect continued slower starts rates in the coming months, exacerbating a housing crisis in Canada and potentially hurting the popularity of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's Liberal government.

images.alt_text: The benchmark price of a home in Canada falls 1.1 per cent in November from a month earlier, the biggest decline since September 2022 and the third decrease in a row.
October 2, 2017 - Toronto, Canada - An aerial view of suburban homes in the GTA. (Credit Image: James MacDonald)

site_title: 2 men bilked wine investors out of nearly US$100 million in Ponzi scheme, US says
summary: Two British men, Stephen Burton and James Wellesley, have been accused of running a nearly two-year Ponzi scheme that bilked investors out of nearly $100 million. The men promised loans to wealthy wine collectors, but the collectors never existed, and the wine reserves were fabricated. Burton, 58, pleaded not guilty to charges of wire fraud, wire fraud conspiracy, and money laundering conspiracy, while Wellesley, 56, remains in extradition proceedings in Britain. If convicted, each faces up to 20 years in prison.

images.alt_text: How to read a wine label

site_title: Manulife US Reit enters master restructuring agreement, divests Arizona property Park Place
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (MUST) has completed a master restructuring plan to remedy its financial woes. The plan involves divesting the Park Place property in Arizona for approximately US$98.7 million and raising funds through asset dispositions and a sponsor-lender loan. MUST's lenders have obtained necessary approvals, and unitholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of the plan. The divestment brings MUST's portfolio to 10 office properties in Arizona, California, Georgia, New Jersey, Virginia, and Washington DC, with US$1,180 million of facilities potentially affected by a breach of default event condition.

images.alt_text: The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.
Manulife US Reit is among the top three performers in December for S-Reits with office properties in the US.
The first resolution, which was to approve the divestment of the Reit’s Park Place property to the sponsor for US$98.7 million, saw 97.7 per cent or 545.6 million votes in favour.
The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.
Park Place was only purchased recently at the end of 2021 for US$106 million.

site_title: Wall Street’s China stock bulls seek redemption after a humbling year
summary: Wall Street's optimism about China's stock market has taken a hit after a 14% drop in the MSCI China Index in 2023. Despite policymakers' efforts to address a housing slump and extend funding support, expectations for 2024 are modest, with many analysts predicting single-digit gains. The market's dismal performance is attributed to underappreciation of headwinds, including weak consumption and prolonged housing woes, as well as opaque and unpredictable policymaking. Despite this, some analysts remain bullish, citing a potential "relief rally" driven by easing Sino-US tensions and improving revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Hywin derives most of its revenues from distributing real estate products, including those investing in projects from troubled China Evergrande Group and Sunac China Holdings.

site_title: Wall Street says Basel 3 ‘endgame’ will upend climate finance
summary: Wall Street's major banks warn that stricter capital requirements under Basel 3 will significantly impact green finance, making it more costly to provide finance. The rules, set to be implemented in the US, will require banks to set aside more capital, potentially leading to a shift away from green projects and into shadow banking markets. This could hinder investment in climate and development finance, as seen in a recent decline in the S&P Global Clean Energy Index. Regulators are urged to reconsider the impact of Basel 3 on green finance models.

images.alt_text: Deserted villas in a suburb of Shenyang, China. .Wall Street’s misplaced optimism likely resulted from an under-appreciation of the magnitude of headwinds in the country including prolonged housing woes.

site_title: What is the US Federal Reserve’s dot plot and why does it matter?
summary: The US Federal Reserve's dot plot is a chart showing estimates of the federal funds rate, controlled by the Fed, and its significance lies in its ability to provide a glimpse into the Fed's monetary policy intentions. The plot is updated every three months and features estimates from the Fed's rate-setting committee, with the median dot serving as a key indicator. The dot plot's shifting projections can signal changes in the Fed's plans for monetary policy tightening or loosening, and its anonymous nature has led to both praise and criticism, with some arguing it lacks consistency and transparency.

images.alt_text: Economists regard a soft landing as when policymakers succeed in slowing an economy enough to get inflation under control without causing a recession.

site_title: 2023 Tesla Model Y review: Spring cleaning
summary: The 2023 Tesla Model Y has undergone a significant transformation with a revised suspension, featuring softer coil springs and less rigid top mounts, resulting in a smoother ride. This update has greatly improved the car's comfort and practicality, making it a more appealing option for families. The Model Y's performance remains strong, with a 295 horsepower motor and impressive acceleration. Despite external competition from combustion engines, the Model Y's updated suspension and overall design make it a worthwhile investment, especially at its competitive price point.

site_title:
The era of GenAI in financial services needs 
a special kind of leader
summary: Financial services leaders must adapt to the era of generative AI, which requires a new kind of leader. Only 37% of leaders are confident in their ability to implement AI, highlighting the need for effective management. Key factors to consider when choosing the right leader include their ability to drive the AI agenda, structure the organisation for data sharing, and change mindsets and communicate compellingly. The best leaders will possess a human-centred approach, emotional intelligence, and strong social skills to manage and motivate employees during the AI-driven transformation.

images.alt_text: AI raises mainy questions in a world of increasing economic complexity.
