site_title: Singapore expresses grave concern on worsening Gaza crisis at UN meet
summary: Singapore has expressed grave concern over the worsening humanitarian situation in Gaza, calling for an immediate ceasefire. Following a UN General Assembly meeting, 153 countries voted in favor of a resolution demanding a humanitarian ceasefire and the release of hostages, while 10, including Israel and the US, voted against it. The crisis has resulted in over 18,700 Palestinian deaths and 116 Israeli soldier fatalities. Singapore supports a two-state solution and urges leaders to show restraint, exercise leadership, and take steps towards a durable, just, and comprehensive solution.

images.alt_text: In his most blunt remarks since the Oct 7 attack on Israel by Hamas which provoked the current conflict, US President Joe Biden told donors that Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu needed to “change” his stance on a two-state solution for the Palestinians.

site_title: The countdown for a Bitcoin ETF decision is approaching a critical deadline
summary: US regulators are set to decide on a Bitcoin ETF by January 10, with fewer than 30 days left. The decision could mark a significant shift into traditional finance for the crypto world. The Securities and Exchange Commission will review an application from Cathie Wood's ARK Investment and 21Shares, the first to file this year, to approve or deny a physically-backed Bitcoin ETF. A greenlight could offer digital-money proponents a path to redemption post-FTX and potentially boost Bitcoin's price.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin logos on a screen in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023. Bitcoin shrugged off a dip in global stock markets to set another more than 19-month high, a sign of its decoupling from other assets. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Navigating the AI revolution: what’s next for Asean businesses in 2024
summary: Asean businesses can expect significant opportunities and challenges in 2024 as AI transforms the enterprise. AI is poised to contribute nearly S$1.36 trillion to the Asean economy by 2030, but businesses must develop a robust data foundation, prioritize data harmonisation, and balance data privacy with AI adoption. Trusted data sharing will also be essential for seamless and secure data flows across Asean member states. Furthermore, customer expectations will grow, and competition will intensify, requiring businesses to connect with customers through new channels and provide personalized experiences. Companies that can adapt quickly and pivot to placing AI, data, CRM, and trust at the core of their business strategy will succeed in the AI revolution.

site_title: USDJPY eyes further downside with structural breakdown
summary: The USDJPY currency pair experienced a significant 19.4% appreciation from its January low to a 13-month peak in November, but has since retraced sharply to 141.6 on Dec 7 before rebounding to 142. Analysts predict further downside due to a structural breakdown from a large rising channel and a bearish trend reversal signaled by the bearish crossover of the 20-day EMA below the 50-day EMA. The Relative Strength Index (RSI) also validates the bearish momentum, with a reading below 30, indicating an oversold condition.

images.alt_text: Despite the strong upward move to hit a 12-month high, technical indicators on the USDJPY suggest that a correction to the downside is highly probable.

site_title: Can the Oompa-Loompas be saved?
summary: The film "Wonka" addresses the colonialist aspects of Roald Dahl's original book "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" by depicting the Oompa-Loompas as a single, judgmental figure who serves as a mentor to the main character, Wonka. The film's director, Paul King, drew inspiration from the 1971 version of the story, where the Oompa-Loompas were played by actors with dwarfism. Hugh Grant, who plays the Oompa-Loompa, brings a new level of agency to the character, making him a more complex and nuanced figure. The film aims to redeem the Oompa-Loompas by telling their story from their perspective, providing a fresh take on the classic characters.

images.alt_text: Barbie has claimed nine nods, including best drama as well as acting nominations for stars Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling.

site_title: BOE warns of more pain for renters as landlords exit
summary: The Bank of England warned UK renters of further increases in rental prices due to the exit of buy-to-let landlords, who are responding to higher mortgage costs. The buy-to-let sector, worth £300 billion, is consolidating and evidence suggests a decline in rental properties. Renters have limited capacity to absorb further increases in costs, and rental arrears have risen in recent years. While the pace of rental cost increases is predicted to slow in 2024, renters can expect higher rents in the short term.

images.alt_text: UK hospitality industry sales slump 87% as coronavirus lockdown bites

site_title: Public urged to mask up in crowded places as Covid cases top 56,000 in first week of December
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 cases surged to 56,043 in the first week of December, a 75% increase over the previous week. The health ministry urges the public to wear masks in crowded places, especially indoors or around vulnerable individuals. To address the surge, the government will open a second Covid-19 treatment facility and increase hospital beds, with an average hospitalization rate of 350 daily admissions. The public is also advised to get vaccinated and take precautions to avoid crowded areas.

images.alt_text: DPM Lawrence Wong also said that posts and messages showing him endorsing commercial products were deepfakes.
The Health Ministry has reassured people that the numbers are not as high as during the pandemic. ST PHOTO: KELVIN CHNG
The Ministry of Health says that the estimated number of local Covid-19 infections in the week of Nov 19 to Nov 25 had doubled to 22,094 from 10,726 in the previous week.

site_title: Japan, Malaysia sign 400 million yen maritime security assistance deal
summary: Japan and Malaysia signed a 400 million yen (S$3.8 million) maritime security assistance deal to boost Malaysia's security, amid growing tensions with China in the South China Sea. The deal includes equipment such as rescue boats and supplies, and follows similar aid packages to the Philippines and Bangladesh. Japan aims to strengthen its ties with ASEAN countries and provide support to boost their international standing, particularly in countering China's assertiveness.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s growth forecast for 2023 has been cut considerably to 5.2 per cent from 5.8 per cent earlier.

site_title: Native oysters return to Belfast after a century's absence
summary: Native oysters have returned to Belfast's harbour after a century's absence due to a nursery installation project. The narrow Belfast Lough channel was once home to large oyster reefs, but overfishing, disease, and pollution decimated the population in the early 1900s. The Ulster Wildlife group has initiated a project to boost marine life and water quality by installing oyster nurseries. This effort aims to restore the natural balance and promote biodiversity in the harbour.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s roughly 5 million hectares of coral reefs account for a fifth of the world’s total, according to Greenpeace.

site_title: Yes, cybercriminals are exploiting AI too. Here’s how to stay one step ahead of them
summary: Cybercriminals are exploiting artificial intelligence (AI) tools, increasing the volume of attacks due to their scalability. AI has been in use for years, but recent Generative AI (GenAI) tools like ChatGPT have generated public interest. Businesses using AI tools should consider managing complexity and potential risks to stay ahead of cyber threats. Scaling AI tools makes them more difficult to combat, and companies must adapt to these challenges to protect themselves. Effective leadership and strategy will be crucial in mitigating the risks associated with AI.

site_title: Harvard College early applications drop 17% from last year
summary: Harvard University reported a 17% decline in early college applications, with 7,921 submissions this year compared to 9,553 last year. The drop is attributed to incidents of antisemitism on campus following an attack by Hamas and a widely criticized testimony by university president Claudine Gay at a congressional hearing. Meanwhile, rival Yale University saw a 1.4% increase in early applications, and the University of Pennsylvania's applications rose to over 8,500.

images.alt_text: Israel’s air and ground assault over the past 10 weeks has killed more than 18,700 Palestinians, while thousands more are missing and feared dead.

site_title: China’s ban on Apple’s iPhone accelerates
summary: China's ban on Apple's iPhone accelerates, with state agencies and companies in at least eight provinces instructing employees to use local brands instead of foreign devices. Staff in at least three ministries and government bodies have been told not to use iPhones at work, a Reuters report said. The move is part of China's efforts to reduce reliance on foreign technologies and promote domestic semiconductor chip manufacturing. The ban comes as Apple's shares were marginally down in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Apple shares have soared by more than 50 per cent in 2023, adding about US$1 trillion in market value.

site_title: Homelessness in the US rises to a record high in 2023
summary: The US homeless population has reached a record high, with 653,104 people counted in January, a 12% increase from the previous year, the largest one-year jump since 2007. The surge is attributed to a sharp rise in rents and the end of pandemic-era measures, including financial aid and eviction bans. The growth affects all demographics, including veterans, who saw a significant expansion of federal aid. Experts point to the shortage of affordable homes and high housing costs as major causes, while some researchers attribute the rise to the influx of migrants entering the homeless services system.

images.alt_text: FILE -- An encampment along a street in Phoenix, Feb. 10, 2023. A report found that the national homeless population has increased by more than 70,000 people, a rise of 12 percent. By the government’s count, 653,104 people in the U.S. were homeless in January. (Todd Heisler/The New York Times)

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust to sell three Japanese hotels for 10.7 billion yen
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust is selling three Japanese hotels in Osaka for 10.7 billion yen (S$100.2 million), 15% above book value. The sale is part of its portfolio reconstitution strategy, with expected net proceeds of 3.9 billion yen and a net gain of 1.1 billion yen. The divestments will enable the trust to redeploy capital to stronger-yielding assets, with 30 properties remaining in Japan, including serviced residences and hotels in gateway cities like Tokyo and Fukuoka.

images.alt_text: Novotel Sydney Paramatta is one of the two assets located outside Sydney's city centre that CapitaLand Ascott Trust is divesting.
CapitaLand Q4 profit almost doubles to S$926.6m

site_title: White House sees greater chances for economic ‘soft landing’
summary: US President Joe Biden's top economic adviser, Lael Brainard, says recent data indicates a "greater chance" of an economic 'soft landing', where inflation is controlled without causing a recession. Brainard credits Biden's focus on supply-chain issues and immigration, which has helped the labour force rebound, for the positive indicators. Economists regard a soft landing as slowing the economy enough to control inflation. The Federal Reserve's historic monetary policy tightening may be over as inflation falls faster than expected, and stocks have rallied, with the S&P 500 index up 23% for the year.

images.alt_text: FILE — Produce at a Wegmans supermarket in Brooklyn, Oct. 19, 2023. As inflation slows, prices for some physical goods are falling outright, which could lift consumers’ holiday spirits. (Maansi Srivastava/The New York Times)

site_title: 17Live share price falls as VTAC Spac investors exit; StarHub continues share buyback
summary: 17Live's share price fell as investors exited the company, following its business combination with VTAC Spac on Dec 8. The Straits Times Index gained 0.6% over the period, with 87 filings for changes in director interests and 56 filings for share buybacks by 25 companies. This marks the first trading session for 17Live after the acquisition.

images.alt_text: Chin Yau Seng took the helm of the Singapore Airlines’ (SIA) listed aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) subsidiary in October, crossing over from the airline’s cargo division.
VTAC, led by non-executive chairman Chua Kee Lock,  has endorsed the merger, citing 17Live’s strong management, the potential for scale, and its alignment with Vertex Holdings’ areas of expertise.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for December 15, 2023, reveals that the tanker and dry bulk market lost ground across the whole VLCC sector. In contrast, the capesize market experienced a dynamic week, with the Pacific market rising by $1,155 on the BCI 5TC to $36,475. The Atlantic market faced challenges, with sluggish activity, widening bid/offer gaps, and weaker fixtures. Overall, the BCI 5TC closed the week at $34,107, reflecting regional fluctuations and ongoing uncertainties.

images.alt_text: A Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) tanker on August 23, 2021.

site_title: Dollar rebounds as Fed’s Williams talks down rate cuts
summary: The dollar index rebounded on Friday after Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams pushed back against market expectations of 75 basis point rate cuts in 2024, saying "we aren't really talking about rate cuts right now". Despite this, the dollar index remains on track for its worst weekly performance in a month. The market's rate cut expectations were fueled by Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's dovish tone at the previous meeting, but Williams' comments tempered the market's reaction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Four thousand U.S. dollars are counted out by a banker counting currency at a bank in Westminster, Colorado November 3, 2009.  REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: Panama Canal to allow more ship traffic in January as rains ease drought
summary: The Panama Canal will increase ship traffic in January due to improved rainfall in the region, easing drought conditions. The canal authority will allow up to 24 vessels to pass through daily, up from 22 currently, following record-low rainfall in October. The increase is attributed to better-than-expected November rains, which have replenished water levels in Lake Gatun. The move aims to reduce congestion and alleviate financial burdens on shippers who have been waiting in line for days or weeks.

site_title: China shows off its C919 passenger jet with flyby of Hong Kong’s Victoria Harbour
summary: China showcased its domestically made C919 passenger jet with a flyby of Hong Kong's Victoria Harbour, performing two loops at low altitudes. The aircraft, designed to compete with Airbus and Boeing, has received 1,061 orders but only three are operating commercially. This marks the first major new aircraft to do a low-altitude Victoria Harbour flyby since an Airbus A380 in 2007. The move highlights China's growing aircraft-manufacturing capabilities.

site_title: Singapore keen on deeper defence ties with Japan to promote regional peace and stability: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed his country's commitment to deeper defense ties with Japan, aiming to promote regional peace and stability. Lee welcomed Japan's Self-Defence Forces aircraft and vessels to stop over in Singapore and supported Japan's efforts to resolve the abduction issue. He also highlighted the importance of cooperation on maritime security, cyber security, and nuclear non-proliferation. The two leaders discussed deeper defense cooperation and exchanges during a bilateral meeting on Dec 16, with Singapore set to take over as Asean-Japan dialogue relations coordinator in July 2024.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida greets Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong upon arrival for the opening session of the ASEAN-Japan Commemorative Summit Meeting at the Hotel Okura Tokyo in Tokyo, Japan, December 17, 2023. KAZUHIRO NOGI/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Europe must rearm as new threats loom, German minister says
summary: German Defence Minister Boris Pistorius warns that Europe must increase its own military capabilities to ensure security as new threats emerge by the end of the decade. With Russia ramping up its military production in Ukraine and threatening neighboring countries, Pistorius emphasizes the need for Europeans to engage more in their own defense. However, he notes that this will take time, as the region works to increase its own weapons production. The US shift in focus towards the Indo-Pacific may also reduce its military engagement in Europe.

images.alt_text: A man shelters from the rain under an umbrella as he walks past the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on July 27, 2023 ahead of thr ECB's monthly announcement on eurozone monetary policy. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Success abroad drives rare winners in dismal China stock market
summary: Chinese stocks are among the worst-performing globally this year, but rare winners have emerged, including PDD and Miniso Group, which have surged 80% and 70% respectively due to their global success. Morgan Stanley highlights Shenzhou International Group and Pop Mart International Group as stocks that could benefit from their international presence. These successes are a contrast to the benchmark stock gauge, which is on track for an unprecedented third straight year of losses, amid uncertainty over the domestic economy heading into 2024.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led the advances, surging more than three per cent, while Shanghai was also on the rise.

site_title: ‘Born rebel’: Hong Kong pro-democracy media mogul Jimmy Lai
summary: Jimmy Lai, a 76-year-old Hong Kong media mogul, will stand trial on Monday on internationally condemned national security charges. Lai, a jailed critic of the Chinese Communist Party, is the first person to contest a "foreign collusion" charge under Hong Kong's national security law, imposed in 2020. He faces the possibility of spending the rest of his life in prison, after being denied bail and having his choice of representation. Lai has already been found guilty in five separate cases and has been in prison for over three years, calling the national security law a "death knell" for Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Singapore and Hong Kong have much to learn from each other - Hong Kong's family-owned property giants could emulate Singapore groups in going capital light.

site_title: How to tackle corruption in Singapore before it festers
summary: Singapore's zero-tolerance approach to corruption has been shaken by the July arrest of Transport Minister S Iswaran in a graft-related probe. The arrest highlights the need for a more nuanced approach to combating corruption, focusing on ethical issues rather than just financial aspects. Implementing a code of ethics and conduct, and a broader compliance program with features like whistleblowing channels and disciplinary processes, can help organisations guard against corruption. With Singapore's Corruption Perceptions Index score dropping to 5th place globally, the authorities must take firm action to restore investor confidence and maintain the country's incorruptibility.

site_title: Singapore F&B scene remains festive despite surge in outbound travel
summary: Singapore's food and beverage scene remains festive despite a surge in outbound travel, with hotels and restaurants anticipating a further increase in demand near Christmas. Locals make up 50-75% of reservations for Christmas and New Year's Eve, with demand driven mostly by locals. Despite overall spending not matching last year's levels, some F&B players expect a strong year-end, with Saint Pierre and the Orchard Hotel Singapore reporting increased bookings and orders. However, some operators note a 10-15% drop in spending across Unlisted Collection's restaurants due to inflationary pressures and cautious consumers.

images.alt_text: This year’s Christmas On A Great Street light-up, organised by the Orchard Road Business Association, will be incorporating more sustainability features.
Pan Pacific Orchard festive takeaway.

site_title: Europe: Shares end fifth week higher on rate-cut optimism
summary: European shares ended the week with a fifth consecutive gain, driven by optimism over potential interest rate cuts from the US Federal Reserve. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% on Friday, while the German DAX remained flat and France's CAC-40 climbed 0.3%. Despite economic concerns, including Germany's worsening recession and French business slowdown, rate-sensitive real estate stocks were top gainers, while the telecommunications sector took the biggest hit. The European Central Bank held rates steady, but some analysts expect rate cuts starting in April.

images.alt_text: The pan-European index closed 0.9 per cent higher to an over 22-month high.

site_title: Dow at another record as Wall Street cheers more weekly gains
summary: US stocks reached record highs, with the Dow finishing at 37,305.16 for a third straight day, and the S&P 500 essentially flat. The rally extends since late October, driven by the Federal Reserve's signal to cut interest rates next year. However, New York Federal Reserve president John Williams dampened expectations for an imminent rate cut. Individual stocks like Costco jumped 4.5% after announcing a special cash dividend. Despite the sideways move in the S&P 500, all three indices scored weekly gains for the seventh straight time.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 53.85 points, or 0.14 per cent, at the open to 37,194.50.

site_title: 2024: Inflection point for S-Reits?
summary: The article discusses the performance of Singapore Reits (S-Reits) in 2023, which was a challenging year due to elevated interest rates. Despite this, some S-Reits, such as Manulife US Reit, performed well in December. Higher interest rates are expected to continue affecting the sector, making Reits less attractive compared to other assets with higher yields. The article suggests that 2024 may be an inflection point for S-Reits, with potential changes in interest rates and regulatory environment that could impact their performance.

images.alt_text: Reit ETFs provide investors with instant diversification and access to Singapore and regional Reit markets, as it tracks the performance of an underlying index.

site_title: US manufacturing output rises, outlook for factories weak
summary: US manufacturing output rose 0.3% in November, driven by a rebound in motor vehicle production after the end of strikes. However, overall manufacturing activity remains weak, with economists predicting a lackluster outlook for factories due to higher borrowing costs and softening demand for goods. The Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and new economic projections suggest a possible end to monetary policy tightening in 2024, but manufacturing is unlikely to provide significant economic growth in the near term.

images.alt_text: Business inventories dip 0.1 per cent, the first decline since June, after increasing 0.2 per cent in September.

site_title: Matthew Perry died of accidental ketamine overdose, examiner finds
summary: Matthew Perry, the 54-year-old actor best known for his role as Chandler Bing on the hit TV sitcom Friends, died from an accidental ketamine overdose, according to a Los Angeles County Medical Examiner's office report. Perry had struggled with addiction to drugs, including ketamine, and related health issues, but had reportedly been clean for 19 months prior to his death. The manner of death is classified as an accident, with contributing factors including drowning, coronary artery disease, and buprenorphine effects.

images.alt_text: Matthew Perry (third from left), who played Chandler Bing on the hit TV sitcom from 1994-2004, died at the age of 54, having struggled for decades with addiction and related serious health issues.

The Matthew Perry Foundation “will honor his legacy and be guided by his own words and experiences and driven by his passion for making a difference in as many lives as possible,” according its website.

site_title: Cordlife’s six-month suspension to take effect from Dec 15
summary: Cordlife, a Singaporean cord blood banking company, has been suspended by the Ministry of Health for six months, starting December 15. The suspension is due to seven storage tanks found to have been kept at temperatures above acceptable limits, affecting 19,500 cord-blood units. During the suspension, Cordlife must cease collecting, testing, and storing new cord blood and human tissues, and cannot provide new tests to patients. The company will also work to regain public trust in its protocols and standards.

site_title: India built the world’s biggest office in hopes of dominating diamond trade
summary: India has officially opened the world's largest office complex, the Surat Diamond Bourse, in Gujarat state, surpassing the Pentagon's size. The 6.7 million sq ft complex aims to centralize the diamond industry, with 90% of the world's rough diamonds cut and polished in Surat before being sold to buyers like the US and China. The inauguration by PM Narendra Modi marks a significant economic boost for Gujarat and solidifies Surat's position as the world's diamond capital, despite challenges from geopolitics and competition from established diamond exchanges.

images.alt_text: As part of the settlement, Deng Yiming will still have to pay S$483,000 in damages to Metech, as ordered by the High Court in October.

site_title: Shipping giants pause Red Sea route as Houthi attacks intensify
summary: Shipping giants AP Moller-Maersk and Hapag-Lloyd have paused their transits through the Red Sea due to Houthi militant attacks on merchant ships, sparking trade disruption and economic risks. The attacks, which have escalated in recent days, have targeted ships connected to Israel, and insurance costs are climbing. The US is considering forming a maritime task force to protect ships and has called for more military support to end the attacks, which pose a significant international problem. The pause will add thousands of miles to trade routes, boost fuel bills, and delay cargo deliveries.

images.alt_text: George Recine, a Boston advertising executive, outside Goldie, a falafel restaurant in Philadelphia that was the target of a recent pro-Palestinian protest, on Dec. 6, 2023. Recine knew was that the owners had donated restaurant proceeds to an Israeli medical nonprofit organization that has supplied that nation’s troops with toiletries and gear in the Israel-Hamas war, but didn’t think an American restaurant serving Israeli food should be a target. (Kriston Jae Bethel/The New York Times)

In his most blunt remarks since the Oct 7 attack on Israel by Hamas which provoked the current conflict, US President Joe Biden told donors that Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu needed to “change” his stance on a two-state solution for the Palestinians.
The UN General Assembly, which includes all 193 member nations, voted 153 in favour of the resolution.

Maersk intends to scale up its warehousing and distribution in South-east Asia by up to 50 per cent, and expects to add nearly 480,000 square metres of capacity across Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines by 2026.
Shipping industry leader Maersk is investing in green fuels to power its fleet as it strives to reach net-zero emissions by 2040.
Maersk expects to save US$600 million through the job cost measures.

site_title: US SEC denies Coinbase petition for crypto rulemaking
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) denied a petition by Coinbase, the country's largest crypto exchange, to create new rules for the digital asset industry. The SEC stated that existing laws and regulations are "unworkable" for the crypto sector, disagreeing with Coinbase's claim that current securities regulations are inadequate. Coinbase had sued the SEC in April 2023, seeking a response to its petition. The decision was made by SEC Chair Gary Gensler, who has previously rejected similar claims.

site_title: Oil: Prices take a small loss in seesaw session
summary: Oil prices declined slightly on Friday, closing down 0.08% at $76.55 a barrel for Brent futures and 0.21% at $71.43 for US West Texas Intermediate crude. The drop was attributed to mixed signals on oil demand and interest rate expectations. Despite a weaker US dollar, which makes dollar-denominated oil cheaper for foreign buyers, the market remains sensitive to new headlines. The International Energy Agency predicted a 1.1 million barrel per day increase in world oil consumption in 2024, less than half of OPEC's forecast.

images.alt_text: The market has turned around after dropping to a hit its lowest in nearly six months during Wednesday’s session.

site_title: Disgraced ex-IMF chief Rato begins trial for tax evasion
summary: Former IMF chief Rodrigo Rato, 74, begins a trial in Madrid on charges of corruption, money laundering, and tax evasion, facing a potential sentence of over 60 years in prison. Rato, who was found guilty of embezzlement in 2018, denies wrongdoing and will not testify until April. The trial, which started on December 15, follows an investigation into his personal wealth and a kickback scheme during his time at Bankia, where he allegedly benefited from advertising campaigns.

images.alt_text: European Union governments hoping to receive a slice of the hundreds of billions of euros in jointly raised recovery funds will need to put forward plans of specific reforms and commit to spend the cash on digital infrastructure projects and the transition to a low-carbon economy.
The District Court judge in Seattle agrees with the Justice Department that Zhao has not convinced the court he is unlikely to flee if allowed to return to the UAE.
“The Bitcoin Group expressly points out that there are currently no indications of violations of money laundering and terrorist financing laws within the Group,” the company says.

site_title: Nio to launch cheaper Firefly brand in Europe in 2024
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, plans to launch its cheaper Firefly brand in Europe in 2024, a year ahead of schedule, with a second brand, Alps, potentially launching after 2025. The Firefly brand will offer smaller models for families, while Nio faces expanding losses due to a price war started by Tesla. The company has taken cost-cutting measures, including layoffs and partnerships to develop battery swapping technology and lower-cost battery packs. This move aims to capitalize on a cost advantage in Europe, where demand for EVs has slowed at home.

images.alt_text: Zeekr says its upcoming 007 sedan would be the first model to be equipped with the fast-charging LFP batteries.

site_title: Making innovation purpose-fit for an inclusive and accessible world
summary: The Singapore government emphasizes the need for mutual support and assurance in its recent Forward Singapore 2023 report, shifting from "social assistance" to "social empowerment" for a more inclusive society. The report highlights the importance of addressing the needs of persons with intellectual disabilities (PWIDs), who face challenges in education, employment, healthcare, and social inclusion. To support PWIDs, libraries and public spaces, such as NLB's Punggol library, have incorporated accessible facilities, including calm pods and assistive technologies, while the Woodlands Integrated Transport Hub provides seamless access and navigation.

images.alt_text: SG Enable chairman Moses Lee says the agency will continue pushing for inclusive employment.
Making disability inclusion part of every firm's DNA

site_title: German parliament’s lower house approves 2023 budget
summary: Germany's lower house parliament approved the 2023 budget with 392 votes in favour and 274 against, exceeding the borrowing permitted under the debt brake by 44.8 billion euros. The decision was made due to a constitutional court ruling that blocked the transfer of unused pandemic funds to green investment. The budget includes 43.2 billion euros for energy price subsidies and 1.6 billion euros for a flood relief fund, and will be voted on in the upper house in the afternoon.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view during a plenum session of the lower house of parliament Bundestag, as German Chancellor Olaf Scholz gives a government statement about the upcoming European Council meeting, in Berlin, Germany, October 19, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse/File photo

site_title: Volkswagen year-to-date sales hit 8.3 million cars
summary: Volkswagen's year-to-date car sales reached 8.3 million, exceeding the lower end of its annual forecast of 9 million. In November, deliveries in China grew 32.4% due to increased demand, beating the market average of 26.6%. Electric vehicle sales in China also surged 80%. Globally, the biggest sales increase was in the Middle East and Africa at 28.2%, followed by Europe at 22.5%. The company's group sales revenue is expected to be 10-15% higher than in 2022.

site_title: China issues third batch of rare earth quotas for 2023
summary: China has set its third batch of quotas for rare earth mining output at 15,000 metric tonnes and smelting and separation at 13,850 tonnes for 2023. The quotas, issued by the Industry and Information Technology Ministry, are closely monitored by market participants as an indicator of supply. The total 2023 rare earth mining quota stands at 255,000 tonnes and the total smelting and separation quota at 243,850 tonnes, up 21.4% and 20.7% respectively from the previous year.

images.alt_text: China exports 648 kilogrammes of wrought and unwrought germanium products last month, versus 1 kilogramme in September, and 2.41 tons in October 2022.
China accounts for 70 per cent of global mine production of rare earths in 2022, followed by the US, Australia, Myanmar and Thailand.

site_title: Chinese EV-maker XPeng plunges after Alibaba plans stake sale
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker XPeng's shares plummeted 8.6% after Alibaba Group announced plans to sell 25 million of XPeng's American depositary receipts, reducing its stake from 10.2% to 7.5%. The sale, worth around $391 million, is part of Alibaba's strategy to monetize its investment and does not reflect a change in its view on XPeng. Despite the stake reduction, Alibaba remains XPeng's second-largest shareholder. XPeng reported a wider-than-expected third-quarter loss and is expected to ship fewer than 150,000 vehicles for the year.

images.alt_text: A sign of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker XPeng Motors is pictured at its booth in a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: US business activity picks up in December
summary: US business activity increased in December, with the S&P Global flash US Composite PMI Output Index reaching a five-month high of 51.0, up from 50.7 in November. The improvement was driven by the services sector, while manufacturing activity declined further. A reading above 50 indicates expansion in the private sector, suggesting that economic growth may be more resilient than feared, particularly in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing output rises 0.3 per cent last month, according to the Federal Reserve.
Business inventories dip 0.1 per cent, the first decline since June, after increasing 0.2 per cent in September.

(FILES) Cranes wait to unload cargo shipping containers from ships at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California on June 7, 2023. An increase in exports helped to reduce the overall US trade deficit in August to the smallest since late 2020, according to government data released on October 5, 2023. The trade gap shrank to $58.3 billion, down nearly 10 percent from July's revised figure of $64.7 billion, said the Commerce Department. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - NOVEMBER 24: A Costumer visits the store on early morning Black Friday Sales at Macy's herald square on November 24, 2023 in New York City. The National Retail Federation projects that an estimated 182 million are planning to shop in-store and online through the five-day Thanksgiving weekend.   Kena Betancur/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by KENA BETANCUR / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

(FILES) In this file photo taken on September 24, 2022 Ford Motor Co. battery powered F-150 Lightning trucks under production at their Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan. - Ford will resume production on its F-150 Lightning electric truck on March 13, more than five weeks after a battery fire brought operations to a halt, the company said March 2, 2023. (Photo by JEFF KOWALSKY / AFP)
People shop in a supermarket as inflation affected consumer prices in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., June 10, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
The University of Michigan’s preliminary reading of its Consumer Sentiment Index shot up to 69.4, the highest since August, from November’s final reading of 61.3.

site_title: New York’s Met Museum to return looted antiquities to Cambodia
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has agreed to return over a dozen antiquities to Cambodia, resolving a decade-long investigation into the theft and trafficking of artefacts. The pieces, tied to illicit trafficking, were sold by deceased art dealer Douglas Latchford, who was indicted in 2019 on fraud and conspiracy charges. The repatriation marks a major step in recovering thousands of stolen stone and bronze sculptures from the ancient Khmer Empire, which were looted during Cambodia's 30-year civil war.

images.alt_text: This image released by the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York on December 15, 2023, shows a 7th century Head of Buddha. The attorney's office announced on December 15, the return to Cambodia of 13 Khmer works of art looted near the famous Angkor temples and trafficked internationally until they were held by New York's prestigious Metropolitan Museum of Art, which "voluntarily" returned them. US Attorney Damian Williams issued a press release announcing the return of statues and sculptures from the site of the ancient Khmer capital Kok Ker,  including the 10th-century representation of a goddess and the 7th-century Buddha head. (Photo by Handout / US Attorney's Office Southern District of New York / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO / US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York" - NO MARKETING NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS

site_title: Centurion to acquire remaining 51% stake in Malaysian property investment company
summary: Centurion Corp plans to acquire the remaining 51% stake in Malaysian property investment company Oriental Amber for RM2.6 million, completing the acquisition on Dec 21. Oriental Amber owns 3.07 hectares of freehold land in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, which will be developed into a 7,000-bed workers' accommodation. The acquisition is expected to have minimal impact on Centurion's financials and is part of the company's plan to expand its dormitory business.

site_title: OpenAI CEO promotes crypto project Worldcoin after fundraising report
summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has reaffirmed his support for cryptocurrency project Worldcoin, following reports of a $50 million fundraising effort. The company aims to create a global identity and financial network, with over 2.6 million people signing up for iris scanning in exchange for a digital ID and cryptocurrency. Altman believes that as AI becomes more prevalent, identifying unique humans will become increasingly important, and Worldcoin's technology will play a key role in this process.

images.alt_text: Worldcoin’s white paper on its website says that, over the next 15 years, a total of 10 billion of the tokens will be released into the market.
Worldcoin’s website says the project is “completely private” and that the biometric data is either deleted or users can opt to have it stored in encrypted form.

site_title: Sri Lanka’s economy returns to growth, led by agriculture
summary: Sri Lanka's economy grew 1.6% in the quarter from July to September, marking the first expansion since 2021, driven by a lower base, moderating inflation, and a strengthening currency. The agriculture sector grew 3% and industrial output increased by 0.3%, while services grew by 1.3%. The growth is attributed to a US$2.9 billion IMF bailout and lower interest rates. However, the economy is expected to contract by 3.6% this year, and challenges lie ahead, including higher taxes and foreign debt restructuring.

images.alt_text: A container ships is seen docked at the Colombo International Container Terminal (CICT) port in Colombo on December 9, 2022. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow muted at open as rate-cut cheer ebbs
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 53.85 points, or 0.14%, to 37,194.50. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 35.90 points, or 0.24%, to 14,797.46. Recent upbeat sentiment was dampened by comments from a US Federal Reserve official, which may have contributed to the market's decline.

site_title: Exploring different shades of the drinking experience
summary: White Shades, a multi-storey shophouse space, is revamping its concept and menus, including a new colour-themed menu. The space, which opened in July, will now feature different concepts on each of its four floors, catering to various moods and preferences. Founder Bai Jiawei emphasizes the need to have fun and be spontaneous, treating White Shades as a "no-brainer" place to be. The changes come about six months after the space's opening, aiming to keep the experience fresh and exciting for customers.

images.alt_text: The Blond-ie, which uses LeVeL33's Blond Lager, is a favourite at the microbrewery.
The Yamaoroshi cocktail at Bar Kakure uses freshly grated wasabi.

site_title: Vivendi starts legal action against Telecom Italia network sale
summary: Vivendi, Telecom Italia's largest investor, has launched a lawsuit in a Milan court to block the 22 billion euro sale of Telecom Italia's landline network to US-based KKR. The sale was approved by Telecom Italia's board without a full shareholder meeting, prompting Vivendi to seek a court injunction. Vivendi had previously stated it opposed any network sale below 30 billion euros, and is also considering selling its 1.3 billion euro stake in the former phone monopoly.

images.alt_text: Telecom Italia has for months sought to sell the grid.

site_title: Prince Harry was hacked by UK tabloid newspapers, judge says
summary: Prince Harry was awarded $179,720 in a phone hacking lawsuit against UK newspaper group MGN, which includes the Daily Mirror and The Sunday People. Judge Timothy Fancourt found that phone hacking was "widespread and habitual" between 2006 and 2011, and that private investigators were used to collect information unlawfully. The royal claimed that the hacking had a disruptive role in his life and that senior management at the newspapers turned a blind eye to the behavior. This is Prince Harry's first appearance in a London court since Queen Victoria's son in the 1890s.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex steps out of a car, outside the Rolls Building of the High Court in London, Britain June 7, 2023. REUTERS/Hannah McKay     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange CEO Aguzin to leave firm; Chan to succeed
summary: Hong Kong Exchange CEO Nicolas Aguzin will leave the company in May after a three-year contract, and will be succeeded by co-CEO Bonnie Chan. Chan, 54, is the first woman to take the top job at the exchange. Aguzin, who led the bourse during a tumultuous period, informed the board he would not seek reappointment. Chan's appointment marks a significant shift in the exchange's leadership, following a period of decline in trading and IPOs under Aguzin's leadership.

images.alt_text: It was a “good half year for HKEX, despite continued global macro uncertainty”, bourse chief executive Nicolas Aguzin said in the earnings report.

site_title: China’s Hywin hits record low over missed payments amid property woes
summary: China's wealth manager Hywin Holdings hit a record low of nearly 18% on Dec 15 after missing client redemption requests, citing troubles in the country's faltering property sector. The company's shares plummeted by over 50% in two trading sessions, with its stock now down nearly 60% year-to-date. Analysts warn that Hywin could be a "falling domino" in the Chinese property chain, highlighting the fragile health of the market despite government efforts to slow down the crisis.

images.alt_text: Revenue from land sales falls 1.5 per cent in November from a year earlier, compared with a 25.4 per cent slump the prior month.
China has been ramping up measures to cushion the impact of the property downturn on its economy, but the sector has failed to stage a robust rebound.
China has been experimenting with Reits to tap the world’s second-largest equity market to finance projects that would’ve otherwise been funded by local governments.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo is seen on the headquarters of China Evergrande Group in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China September 26, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Beijing cuts the down-payment ratio for second homes to 40 per cent or 50 per cent, depending on the locations of the properties, according to city's housing authorities.

site_title: Gear up for the new section 10L of the Singapore Income Tax Act 1947
summary: Singapore has enacted section 10L in the Singapore Income Tax Act 1947, treating gains from foreign asset sales as income chargeable to tax if entities don't have economic substance in Singapore. This applies to gains on or after Jan 1, 2024. If foreign taxes are paid, a foreign tax credit claim will be granted. Foreign entities not operating in Singapore are exempt, and gains derived by individuals from foreign assets under certain circumstances are also exempt.

images.alt_text: Skyline of Singapore's Business District taken from Marina Bay Sands on Oct 17, 2023. For stories on sustainability, garden city, air quality and more.

site_title: China issues draft contingency plan for data security incidents
summary: China has proposed a draft contingency plan to respond to data security incidents, featuring a four-tier, color-coded system based on severity. The plan aims to mitigate large-scale data leaks and hacking within its borders. Key incidents include losses exceeding 1 billion yuan and affecting over 100 million people or sensitive information of over 10 million people. The plan requires immediate reporting of "grave" incidents to the local industry regulatory department, with a 24-hour work rota and notification to the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology within 10 minutes of the incident.

site_title: Foreign investors increase China’s onshore bond holdings in November
summary: Foreign investors increased China's onshore yuan bond holdings for the third consecutive month in November, reaching 3.49 trillion yuan. The increase came as the interest rate gap between China and the US narrowed to its lowest in over four months, easing downside pressure on the yuan. This move is attributed to a softening US dollar.

site_title: India’s Nov merchandise trade deficit narrows sharply on subdued imports
summary: India's merchandise trade deficit narrowed to $20.58 billion in November, from a record $23.60 billion in the previous month, due to moderation in imports of gold, petroleum, and electronic goods. Merchandise exports stood at $33.9 billion, while imports were $54.48 billion. Gold imports nearly halved to $3.45 billion, and electronic goods imports declined by 17% to $6.49 billion. The November trade deficit was lower than expected, with services exports at $28.68 billion and imports at $13.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Food inflation, which makes up about half of the consumer price basket, accelerated to 8.7 per cent from 6.61 per cent in October.
The move to keep the benchmark repurchase rate at 6.5 per cent is in line with analyst expectations.

site_title: Stamford Land shareholders donate S$2 million to SGX education fund in resolution over allocation of rights
summary: Stamford Land's controlling shareholders have agreed to donate S$2 million to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Investor Education Fund as part of a resolution over the allocation of rights. The donation comes after the company's lead manager UOB advised that minority shareholders should have priority over directors and controlling shareholders in allocating excess rights shares. The SGX reiterated its rules, which prioritize minority shareholders, and put out a regulatory column emphasizing the importance of this principle.

images.alt_text: 8 Finsbury Circus in London, which comprises 10 floors of Grade A commercial office units with ancillary retail units, contributed to the company's fair value loss on its investment property.

site_title: Mike Johnson may be the next House Speaker to lose his job
summary: US House Speaker Mike Johnson faces potential job loss after a contentious vote on a bipartisan defense policy bill. The bill passed with more Democratic than Republican support, despite strong objections from ultra-conservatives in the Freedom Caucus. Johnson's decision to send the bill to the Senate despite opposition from hardliners has angered lawmakers on the right, who may stall action on government funding, Ukraine aid, and border policy. Johnson's second chance at government funding in January may be threatened if he fails to strike a deal with Senate Democrats and the White House.

images.alt_text: FILE — House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) takes questions during a news conference at the Capitol in Washington, Nov. 2, 2023. Johnson on Saturday, Nov. 11, pitched House Republicans on a convoluted plan to avert a government shutdown at the end of next week, proposing a bill that would temporarily extend funding for some federal agencies until late January and for others through early February. (Kenny Holston/The New York Times)

site_title: Greenback heads for worst week in five months on Fed rate outlook
summary: The US dollar is poised for its largest weekly drop in five months due to diverging interest rate expectations between the Federal Reserve and other central banks. The Fed's possible rate cuts contrast with a tough stance from European central banks, leading to gains in the euro and pound. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled the end of monetary policy tightening, with discussions of rate cuts on the horizon, further fueling the dollar's decline.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of currencies, slips as far as 102.27, its lowest since Aug 10.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. one dollar banknotes are seen in front of displayed stock graph in this illustration taken, February 8, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Northstar Group bags US$140 million in capital commitments at fund’s final close
summary: Northstar Group's early-stage investment fund, Northstar Ventures I, has reached its final close with US$140 million in capital commitments, exceeding its initial US$90 million target. The fund now manages over US$2.6 billion in committed capital, with a focus on consumer Internet, financial technology, and enterprise software sectors. It has investments in over 10 early-stage companies in South-east Asia, including Indonesian electric vehicle maker Maka Motors and Gently, a direct-to-consumer personal care brand. The fund aims to support entrepreneurial founders and accelerate growth with its broad network and multi-stage investments.

images.alt_text: Innovalues manufactures precision machine parts including automotive components, printer rollers and mechanical devices, according to its website.
Northstar Ventures I has a core focus on the consumer internet, financial technology and enterprise software sectors.

site_title: Competition watchdog consults on ANA’s proposed Nippon Cargo Airlines acquisition
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) is seeking public feedback on ANA Holdings' proposed acquisition of Nippon Cargo Airlines (NCA). The acquisition, which would see ANA acquire a 100% stake in NCA, is being reviewed under the Competition Act 2004 to ensure it does not substantially lessen competition in the international air cargo transport market. The public consultation will close on January 2, 2024, and ANA and NCA argue that the acquisition will not infringe on the competition law, citing available substitutes, strong competition, and limited vertical integration.

images.alt_text: Japan’s largest airline plans to cut about 30 domestic and international flights a day between Jan 10 and Mar 30 as it conducts inspections of P&W’s engines installed on its 33 Airbus fleet.
SATS shares have fallen more than 30 per cent from the closing price of S$3.87 on Sept 27, before the proposed acqusition was announced.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 15)
summary: Singapore's government reported a 3.5% reduction in total emissions to 3.7 million tonnes in FY22, despite increased electricity usage, due to the closure of the Tuas incineration plant. The country's tourist arrivals fell to 1.1 million in November, marking the fourth straight month of declines. The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) is seeking public feedback on proposed amendments to the Cybersecurity Bill. Meanwhile, shares in Singapore fell 0.2% in contrast to regional markets, which ended positively after the US Federal Reserve hinted at an end to rate hikes.

site_title: JPMorgan AM appoints Ayaz Ebrahim CEO of Singapore, South-east Asia
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management (JPMAM) has appointed Ayaz Ebrahim as the new CEO of Singapore and South-east Asia, subject to regulatory approval. Ebrahim, with over three decades of experience in investments, succeeds Sherene Ban and will focus on deepening client relationships and driving growth in the region. He will retain his investment responsibilities within the emerging markets and Asia-Pacific team and report to Dan Watkins and Anuj Arora. The appointment aims to strengthen JPMAM's presence in a strategically important market.

site_title: Yellen urges China to shift from 'unfair' state-driven economic policy
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged China to shift from a state-driven economic policy, citing "unfair" practices that discourage investors. Yellen highlighted concerns over limited protection for intellectual property, preferential treatment for domestic competitors, and coercive actions against American companies. In response, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said Beijing hopes the US will be consistent with its words and actions, warning against sanctions. Yellen plans to discuss "difficult areas of concern" on her next trip to China, including outbound investment restrictions and national security issues.

images.alt_text: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has emerged as something of a “good cop” in the Biden administration’s handling of China relations, gradually building ties with the country’s economic leadership.

SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - NOVEMBER 10: U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference following a bilateral meeting with People’s Republic of China (PRC) Vice Premier He Lifeng at the Ritz Carlton Hotel on November 10, 2023 in San Francisco, California. Secretary Yellen and Vice Premier Lifeng will hold meetings ahead of the APEC summit being held in San Francisco.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Shell agrees to sell stake in Germany's Schwedt refinery to Prax Group
summary: Shell has agreed to sell its 37.5% stake in Germany's PCK Schwedt oil refinery to Prax Group, as part of efforts to reduce its global network of refineries. The deal, expected to close in the first half of 2024, is part of Shell's strategy to focus on core sites integrated with trading hubs and chemicals activities. The refinery supplies most of Berlin's fuel, and the sale is subject to regulatory clearance and pre-emption rights by Rosneft and Eni, which own majority and minority stakes in the refinery, respectively.

site_title: China’s gloomy economic data paints ‘dire’ growth picture
summary: China's economic recovery remains weak, hampered by a lingering real estate crisis and stubbornly low consumer confidence. Industrial output and retail sales expanded in November, but distorted by favorable comparisons to pre-pandemic periods. Analysts say the numbers indicate a further slowdown, with property investment plummeting 9.4% this year and home prices falling at a nine-year high. The government is under pressure to implement supportive measures to boost growth, with expectations of an ambitious 5% growth target in 2024.

images.alt_text: Retail sales rose 10.1 per cent in November.

site_title: SIA group passenger traffic rises 17.6% year on year in November
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted a 17.6% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in November, with 3.1 million passengers carried. Revenue passenger kilometres rose 15.4% to 9.2 billion. The group's passenger load factor increased to 89.8%, outpacing capacity growth. Cargo operations also saw a 5.8% increase in load factor, driven by major retail events. SIA's passenger network now covers 119 destinations in 35 countries, while its cargo network covers 124 destinations in 37 countries.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines Group carried just under 3.1 million passengers this month, up 36.1 per cent from Oct 2022.
SIA's September cargo load factor improves on reduced capacity
SIA posts record H1 loss of S$3.47b on impairments for older aircraft, ineffective fuel hedges

site_title: Eurozone’s rising recession chances fail to shift ECB on cuts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) rejected talk of imminent interest-rate cuts despite rising eurozone recession chances due to private-sector weakness. The S&P Global purchasing managers' index contracted for a seventh month, defying expectations, while ECB policymakers, including President Christine Lagarde, urged "confidence and patience" and said rate cuts weren't discussed at the latest policy meeting. Economists predict a potential eurozone recession in the second half of the year, with forecasts suggesting Germany and France will expand just 0.4% and 0.2% next year, respectively.

images.alt_text: The BOE, in particular, showed an appetite to stick with tight monetary policy, as three of nine rate-setters even voted for another hike.

site_title: UK companies report strongest growth in six months: S&P
summary: UK companies reported the strongest growth in output in six months, with S&P Global's composite Purchasing Manager Index rising to 51.7 in December, above the 50 threshold indicating expansion. The improvement in services offset pessimism among manufacturers, where output fell at a sharper pace. The Bank of England rebuffed speculation about lower interest rates, citing a resilient economy that may contribute to inflation. The UK's economic resilience contrasts with the eurozone, where PMIs worsened, raising recession concerns.

images.alt_text: Britain’s economy has flat-lined till 2023 but earnings are now outpacing inflation again.
FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England in the City of London, Britain, September 25, 2023. REUTERS/Hollie Adams/File Photo
While UK inflation is down from the 41-year high of 11.1 per cent which it hit in October 2022, at 4.6 per cent it is still more than double the Bank of England’s target.
Gross domestic product (GDP) falls by 0.3 per cent from September, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) says.
Including bonuses, which are typically volatile, pay growth slows to 7.2 per cent from 8.0 per cent in the three months to September.

site_title:
Eurozone business woes deepen 
in December: PMI
summary: The eurozone economy has deepened its downturn, with business activity declining in every month of the quarter, according to a closely watched survey. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 47.0 in December, indicating a contraction, and is now below the 50 level separating growth from contraction for the seventh month. The likelihood of the eurozone being in a recession since the third quarter remains high, according to chief economist Cyrus de la Rubia, with firms reducing headcount for a second month and demand for services falling.

images.alt_text: Recent surveys signal the downturn in the eurozone has continued in services and manufacturing.

site_title: Assisted-living flats in Bukit Batok delayed after HDB axes contractor over poor progress
summary: The completion date of Harmony Village @ Bukit Batok, Singapore's first assisted living public housing flats, has been delayed by 3-4 months due to the termination of the main contractor, JSM Construction Group. The new completion date is between September and October 2024, following the appointment of Qingjian International (South Pacific) Group Development Co. to take over the project on February 14. The delay is attributed to poor progress by the original contractor, prompting the Housing Board to intervene.

site_title: China’s fiscal revenue growth gathers pace in November
summary: China's fiscal revenue grew 7.9% in the first 11 months, a slight decrease from the 8.1% growth in the January-to-October period. November's fiscal revenue increased by 4.3% year-on-year, quickening from a 2.6% gain in October. Fiscal expenditures grew 4.9% in the first 11 months, also slowing from the 4.6% gain in the first 10 months. This data suggests China's fiscal growth is still steady despite a slight slowdown.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians and shoppers on Nanjing Road shopping street in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. China’s Golden Week got off to a promising start as tourist trips and revenue jumped through the start of the holiday, suggesting some resilience in consumer appetites. Source: Bloomberg
Retail sales rose 10.1 per cent in November.
The central bank cut policy rates twice this year to support the economy.
Aggregate financing is 2.45 trillion yuan (S$461 billion), the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) says.

Fitch forecast mainland China’s gross domestic product (GDP) growth would moderate to 4.6 per cent from just over 5 per cent in 2023, adding it “forecast growth to be broadly stable and generally at levels above those of rating peers.”

site_title: CSA consults public on proposed amendments to Cybersecurity Bill
summary: The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) has launched a public consultation on proposed amendments to the Cybersecurity Bill, aiming to ensure the country's cybersecurity laws remain fit for purpose. The amendments will address emerging challenges in cyberspace, updating laws to protect critical information infrastructure and entities of special cybersecurity interest. The proposed changes include extending regulatory oversight, providing greater situational awareness, and requiring entities to adhere to cybersecurity standards and report incidents. The consultation will run until January 15, 2024, with the goal of ensuring Singapore's digital infrastructure and services remain safe and secure.

The law enforcement from more than 20 countries in October, which led to hundreds of arrests, demonstrated the “expanding geographical footprint” of the crime, the Interpol says.
The Australian government’s announcement comes after several damaging cyberattacks on major Australian businesses and infrastructure in the past year.
Okta’s shares slumped in October after the company said that the breach allowed some hackers to view files uploaded by certain clients.

site_title: Singapore consumer spending to slow next year: Mastercard
summary: Singapore's real consumer spending is expected to grow at a slower pace of 2.8% in 2024, driven by a stablisation in external trade, amid inflationary pressures. Despite slower consumer spending, the economy is forecast to grow faster in real terms by 2.7% in 2024, driven by a stablisation in external trade. Consumers have become more prudent in purchases to manage living costs and debt servicing, allocating a smaller share to discretionary spending.

Singapore's wired people+tech leadership = edge in recovery

site_title: German economic activity deteriorates in Dec: PMI
summary: Germany's economic activity deteriorated in December, with both manufacturing and services sectors contracting. The manufacturing PMI rose to 43.1, below expectations, while the services sector PMI fell to 48.4, below forecasts. The composite PMI index declined to 46.7, indicating a recession in the country's largest economy at the end of the year. This marks the sixth consecutive month of contraction, pointing to a technical recession.

images.alt_text: Germany’s constitutional court ruling forced Chancellor Scholz’s government to suspend a constitutionally enshrined “debt brake” for the 2023 budget and to re-think its 2024 plans.

site_title: China govt land sales revenue falls at slower pace in November
summary: China's government land sales revenue fell 1.5% in November from a year earlier, a slower decline than the 25.4% drop in the previous month. Revenue for the year-to-date fell 17.9% to 4.2 trillion yuan (S$785.7 billion). The property downturn remains a challenge for China's economy, with new home prices falling for the fifth straight month and property investment dropping 9.4% year on year. Authorities have rolled out measures to support the property market and mitigate financial risks from local government debt.

images.alt_text: In the first 11 months, China fiscal revenue logs a 7.9 per cent increase from a year earlier, compared with 8.1 per cent growth in the January-to-October period.
China has been ramping up measures to cushion the impact of the property downturn on its economy, but the sector has failed to stage a robust rebound.
China has been experimenting with Reits to tap the world’s second-largest equity market to finance projects that would’ve otherwise been funded by local governments.
Beijing cuts the down-payment ratio for second homes to 40 per cent or 50 per cent, depending on the locations of the properties, according to city's housing authorities.

site_title: Issue 79: Implementing Article 6 carbon credit trading; COP28 finds a path forward
summary: Singapore has signed implementation agreements with several countries, including Papua New Guinea, Bhutan, Ghana, Vietnam, and Paraguay, to use carbon credits generated in these countries to meet its emissions reduction targets. The agreements include an "Overall Mitigation in Global Emissions" feature, which aims to ensure that the carbon credit trading leads to actual emissions reductions. The feature involves canceling at least 2% of participating credits at first issuance, representing actual emissions reductions. The mechanism is expected to raise prices for carbon credits and lower the number of credits traded, but may increase the amount of emissions reduced.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines in South Sulawesi. The interest to invest in technologies that address carbon emissions and the impacts of climate change has been growing over the past five years.

From left: Janice Bong, managing director for power & renewables, Keppel’s infrastructure division; Cindy Lim, chief executive of Keppel’s infrastructure division; Mahesh Kolli, president of AM Green; and Prasad Joshi, head of business development at AM Green.

site_title: Philippines to study constitution change for investment push: Marcos
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos has ordered a study on revising the country's constitution to make it more investment-friendly, citing laws that discourage foreign investors. The study comes as Marcos aims to boost foreign investment and economic growth. The 1987 constitution limits the presidency to a single six-year term, a provision put in place after Marcos' father was ousted 20 years ago. The move is seen as a key part of Marcos' economic agenda, with the Philippines seeking to attract more foreign investment and become a more attractive destination for businesses.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank has said that monetary policy will remain tighter for longer until inflationary expectations are back on target.

site_title: Singapore shares fall in contrast to regional markets; STI dips 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Friday, despite a positive trend in regional markets, as investors took profits following the US Federal Reserve's hint at an end to rate hikes. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,116.51. Blue-chip companies like City Developments and Great Eastern rose, while local banks DBS and OCBC ended mixed. Regional markets, however, ended higher, with the Hang Seng Index up 2.4% and the Nikkei 225 up 0.9%.

images.alt_text: The placement of shares - subject to the approval of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) - to two individuals and a company at S$0.35 per share would raise about S$6.55 million.

site_title: Singapore shares nearly flat at Friday’s open; STI down 0.04%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened nearly flat at 3,121.85, down 0.04% or 1.1 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 38, driven by Seatrium's steady performance, while banking stocks were mixed. This contrasts with global markets, which finished higher overnight due to solid US retail sales data and steady interest rates.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering's marine unit is upgrading the Singapore navy's formidable-class frigates.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon Tanoto offers to buy tissue maker Vinda
summary: Indonesian tycoon Sukanto Tanoto's family, through RGE, has offered to buy Vinda International Holdings shares for HK$23.50 each, representing a 13.5% premium to the last closing price. The offer is worth a maximum of HK$26 billion and is expected to be completed in mid-2024. The deal includes the sale of shares by Essity and Vinda founder Li Chaowang, who together own a 72.62% stake in the Hong Kong-listed tissue maker.

images.alt_text: From left: Benny Lee, executive vice-president (external affairs) at RGE, Anderson Tanoto, managing director at RGE, Heng Swee Keat, Deputy Prime Minister and Coordinating Minister for Economic Policies, Anthony Lin, vice-chairman of HWN, Tan See Leng, executive director at HWN.

site_title: China’s video games market recovers in 2023, domestic sales surpass 303 billion yuan
summary: China's video game market experienced a significant recovery in 2023, with domestic sales reaching 303 billion yuan (S$57.1 billion), a 13% increase from the previous year. The growth marks a turnaround after the market contracted for the first time in 2022 due to Beijing's crackdown on gaming addiction concerns. Domestic revenue from homegrown games grew 15% to 256 billion yuan, while foreign market revenue declined 5.65% to US$16.3 billion. Anime-style games, such as miHoYo's "Genshin Impact," gained popularity and expanded revenue.

images.alt_text: Tencent remains China’s biggest Internet company.

site_title: Central banks shouldn’t rush to join Fed policy pivot, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) advises central banks not to rush to join the Federal Reserve's policy pivot against inflation. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warns that countries may prematurely declare victory, leading to entrenched inflation and a harder fight. She cautions that central banks should consider their own domestic conditions, rather than simply following the Fed's lead. The IMF advises the Bank of Korea to calibrate its actions according to data, and the fight against inflation is still in its "very last mile."

images.alt_text: IMF chief warns global economic crisis 'far from over'
IMF says coronavirus may shrink global imbalances further in 2020

site_title: Beauty startup Rose All Day Cosmetics raises US$5.41 million Series A round
summary: Rose All Day Cosmetics, an Indonesian beauty brand, has secured US$5.41 million in Series A funding led by SWC Global. The funds will be used to expand distribution in Indonesia, enter other Asean countries, and improve product offerings. The company, co-founded by Cindy Nyoto Gunawan and Tiffany Danielle, aims to grow its team and increase market reach. This investment marks the latest in a series of funding for the startup, which turned profitable within 1.5 years of its launch.

images.alt_text: Both VC funds and investors have been cautious with their capital as valuations have fallen from the boom of 2021 and 2022.

Vegrow marks GIC’s first agri-tech and B2B investment in India.
Headquartered in Singapore, SME financing platform Validus intends to use its fresh US$20 million investment from 01Fintech to expand in fast-growing markets such as Indonesia.

site_title: Quantitative easing revives gold’s reserve asset status
summary: Central banks' use of quantitative easing (QE) has led to a resurgence in gold's status as a reserve asset. As inflation rises and government bond values fall, central banks face balance sheet losses, potentially causing political headaches. Gold's value has historically been "indexed" to inflation, maintaining its real value, but it does not yield a nominal return, unlike government bonds. The recent QE and budgetary challenges in countries like the US, UK, and Germany have led to a revision in central bank behavior, potentially paving the way for gold to regain its former role as a monetary circuit basis.

images.alt_text: Lower US interest rates put pressure on the US dollar and bond yields, and increase the appeal of non-yielding bullion.
