site_title: Tencent launches party game ‘DreamStar’, analysts say poses a threat to NetEase
summary: Tencent Holdings launched its new party game 'DreamStar', a move seen as a threat to NetEase's popular game 'Egg Party'. Analysts predict 'DreamStar' could impact NetEase revenue by 2-3% and earn between $5-6 billion in its first year. The launch comes as NetEase's market capitalization reached $67 billion, surpassing Meituan to become China's fourth-largest internet company.

images.alt_text: NetEase is still up 43 per cent this year, far outpacing Tencent as well as Chinese technology and global game peers.
Tencent has been pushing services that use the AI inference chip Zixiao it developed with deep learning startup Enflame, touting performance comparable to some Nvidia chips.
Tencent still relies heavily on domestic game sales in China, but in recent years it has amped up efforts to acquire slices of up-and-coming studios from Europe to Japan.

site_title: Gold prices set for weekly gain on US Fed rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices are set for a weekly gain as the US Federal Reserve's decision to leave interest rates unchanged and discuss potential rate cuts boosts demand for the safe-haven asset. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $2,033.29 per ounce, but rose 1.5% for the week. The US dollar hit a four-month low, making gold less expensive for other currency holders, while benchmark US 10-year bond yields hovered near their lowest level since July.

images.alt_text: Robin Tsui, gold strategist for Asia-Pacific at State Street Global Advisors, said central banks net purchases of gold is 14 per cent ahead of 2022. This sector has bought a net 800 tonnes of gold for the first nine months of 2023, the highest on record, he said.

site_title: November visitor arrivals slip again to 1.1 million as slow China recovery continues
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals declined for the fourth consecutive month to 1.1 million in November, 2.3% lower than October, and 34.8% higher than November 2022. Indonesia was the top source of visitors, followed by China, Malaysia, India, and Australia. The decline is attributed to seasonal trends, high airfares, and accommodation costs, as well as a slower-than-expected recovery in China's outbound travel. Business travel has not fully recovered amid economic uncertainty, with arrivals expected to increase in December.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, China, India, Malaysia and Australia are the top five source countries for visitors to Singapore in October.
Average room rates decrease across all four hotel categories in October.

site_title: Meta, TikTok report jump in Malaysia government requests to remove content in 2023
summary: Malaysia made a record number of requests to restrict content on social media platforms Meta and TikTok in 2023, with Meta restricting 3,100 pages and posts and TikTok receiving 340 requests to remove or restrict content. The Malaysian government claims the efforts aim to protect users from online harms, but critics say it may stifle free speech and expression. The government has denied allegations of stifling dissent, citing laws on illegal gambling, hate speech, and racially or religiously divisive content.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: TikTok app logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
GoTo becomes a passive backer of the joint venture, relinquishing control of its Tokopedia e-commerce arm.
TikTok’s US expansion has already attracted the attention of politicians and regulators, who fret about the company’s growing influence over its audience.
Sea is likely to register lower earnings as Shopee is expected to suffer greater losses in the intensified e-commerce competition.
Shopping features within the TikTok app in Indonesia will be operated and maintained by the enlarged Tokopedia entity.

site_title: Used Rolex prices seen benefiting from rate cuts: Subdial Index
summary: The Bloomberg Subdial Watch Index, tracking luxury watch prices, dropped about 10% in 2023 due to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. However, with the Fed signaling an end to its rate hikes, lending costs may decline next year, sparking optimism for a turnaround in the watch market. Christy Davis, co-founder of Subdial, believes a "soft landing" of stable rates could lead to increased valuations for used luxury watches, particularly those from top brands like Rolex, Patek Philippe, and Audemars Piguet.

images.alt_text: Chrono24 has experienced slowing sales growth, amid prices pullback for luxury watches from top brands including Rolex, Patek Philippe and Audemars Piguet.
The acquisition of Universal Geneve will give Breitling its second major brand.

site_title: Lisbon’s hot housing market defies push to deter foreign buyers
summary: Portugal's capital, Lisbon, is experiencing a hot housing market, with residential property prices rising 5.8% in November to a record 5,426 euros per square meter. The city's housing prices have surpassed those of Milan, Madrid, and Berlin, making it difficult for locals to afford homes. Despite the government's efforts to curb demand by ending the golden visa program and cutting tax incentives, foreign buyers continue to drive the market, with long waits for construction licenses and a severe shortage of homes available. The situation highlights the challenges of managing housing prices and the need to balance supply and demand.

images.alt_text: Thousands of Portuguese on Saturday (Sep 30) protest against soaring rents and house prices stoked by growing gentrification and record tourism.

Residential housing and other buildings stand on the bank of the Douro river in Oporto, Portugal, on Tuesday, May 8, 2012. Portuguese Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho said 2012 is the "most challenging" year for his country. Photographer: Mario Proenca/Bloomberg

site_title: Sun Life Singapore names new chief executive
summary: Sun Life Singapore appoints Christopher Albrecht as its new chief executive, effective January 1, 2024. Albrecht, with over 25 years of experience in insurance and HNW banking, will lead the strategic and operational aspects of the business. He reports to Karim Gilani, president of Greater China, Singapore and international HNW.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Prosecution considering more charges against money laundering accused Su Baolin; defence restates cancer risk
summary: Prosecutors in Singapore are considering additional charges against money laundering accused Su Baolin, including forgery and fraud, following the discovery of potentially forged documents related to his company Xinbao Investment Holdings. Su, who faces two existing forgery charges, allegedly artificially inflated the company's revenue and trade receivables to give the impression of profitability. His assets overseas, including significant holdings in Myanmar's cryptocurrency Tether, may also be a factor in his "likely prospect of increased jail time" if found guilty. Su's bail was denied for the second time, with the judge citing his flight risk and inadequate medical care.

images.alt_text: The Business Times previously reported that Su purchased a Sentosa Cove villa in March 2021 for slightly over S$39.33 million..
Su Baolin, one of the 10 foreigners arrested and charged for their alleged involvement in a S$2.8 billion money-laundering case, will return to court on Dec 15 for his bail review.

site_title: Freezing temperatures, snow, ice blanket China, shutting highways
summary: China is experiencing a severe cold wave, with temperatures plummeting to below freezing across most of the country. Authorities have limited traffic flows on highways in several provinces due to icy patches and vehicle collisions. Temperatures are expected to drop as low as minus 40 degrees Celsius in parts of Heilongjiang and Xinjiang provinces. The cold wave is expected to drag temperatures lower into the weekend, although Meteorological Centre forecasts a decrease in rain and snow.

images.alt_text: Independent refiners sometimes substitute crude for fuel oil to produce diesel and petrol when quotas are tight.
The trade has proved so attractive that foreign investor NCD holdings grew 80 per cent in the first 10 months of 2023 to a record high at 290 billion yuan.

site_title: New private home sales more than treble in November to highest in four months
summary: Singapore's new private home sales surged in November with 784 units sold, a 286.2% increase from October and 201.5% year-over-year. The strong sales were driven by three launches – J'Den, Hillock Green, and Watten House – which sold 570 units. The median transacted unit price in the suburban outside central region (OCR) rose 12.7% to S$2,340 psf, while the median price in the rest of central region (RCR) rose 5.4% to S$2,551 psf. Despite a decline in foreign buying, the market is expected to rebound in 2024 with 7,000 to 8,000 new homes sold, according to CBRE.

images.alt_text: Property analysts are expecting upcoming November launches to drive developer sales volumes up from October's low.
Overall condo resale prices for October are up 0.4 per cent month on month, and 7.5 per cent year on year with all regions experiencing price increases
For the first time since October 2021, HDB rental prices for October are down from a month prior.

site_title: Singapore government cuts FY22 emissions by 3.5% on incineration plant closure
summary: The Singapore government has achieved a 3.5% reduction in total emissions to 3.7 million tonnes in FY22, primarily due to the decommissioning of the Tuas incineration plant. Despite increased electricity consumption, the public sector's transparency through reporting is believed to have spurred agencies to minimize their environmental impact. However, direct and power consumption-based emissions are expected to increase in the current fiscal year. The government aims to continue reducing emissions and has set a goal to ink a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first Asean country by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: Lim Tuang Liang, Government Chief Sustainability Officer, Ministry of Sustainability and the Environment, Singapore
The first low-carbon electricity import projects that recently received conditional approval from Singapore’s Energy Market Authority may only come only after 2027.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu stands in front of the Singapore Pavilion at the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Dec 11, 2023.

site_title: Messi’s shirts from Argentina’s World Cup triumph fetch US$7.8 million
summary: Lionel Messi's collection of six World Cup shirts sold at an auction in New York for US$7.8 million, shattering the previous record for a player's memorabilia. The collection includes the shirt worn during the final against France in Qatar. Sotheby's described the shirts as "tangible reminders of the pinnacle moment in the career of the most decorated football player in history." This sale surpasses Michael Jordan's game-worn jersey record, fetching US$10.1 million last year.

site_title: Fitch places LMIRT on ‘rating watch negative’, cautions of another likely downgrade
summary: Fitch Ratings has placed Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) on its "rating watch negative" list, citing the proposed tender offer and consent solicitation exercise as a distressed debt exchange. This move reflects Fitch's expectation that LMIRT's rating will likely be downgraded to "C" if the consent solicitation exercises are successful and the tender offer is accepted by investors. The downgrade follows a previous downgrade to "CCC-" in April.

images.alt_text: The trust's gross revenue for its third quarter slipped 3.8 per cent to S$49.8 million for the quarter, from S$51.7million a year ago.
Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust will not be paying its distribution to holders of its S$140 million and S$120 million perpetual securities.
LMIRT's reported a decline Q1 2023 results on a depreciating Rupiah despite improved operating perfomance.
Fitch says its latest rating action reflects the increased likelihood that LMIRT would be unable to refinance its S$547 million debt maturing over the next 18 months.
LMIRT continues to explore options and measures to maintain a sustainable capital structure and reduce the aggregate leverage of the trust, says its manager.

site_title: China’s November oil refinery runs fall on prior month
summary: China's oil refinery throughput in November fell to 59.53 million metric tonnes, a 14.48 million barrels per day, the lowest level since January-February, due to weak margins and reduced crude oil imports. Independent refiners cut run rates amid tight quotas, substituting crude for fuel oil to produce diesel and petrol. Despite lower crude prices, refiners faced margin pressure due to competition from Russia and Venezuela suppliers. Domestic crude oil production increased to 17.20 million metric tonnes, while natural gas production rose 5.3% from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: Prices for other crude oil at similar quality to Saudi grades are assessed at much lower prices.

site_title: US regulators add artificial intelligence to potential financial system risks
summary: US regulators have warned that the rapid adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) in the financial system could create new risks if not properly supervised. The Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) flagged AI as a potential risk, citing concerns over opacity, bias, and cybersecurity threats. The panel recommended that firms and regulators deepen expertise and capacity to monitor AI innovation and usage, and to identify emerging risks. The FSOC also emphasized the need to better gauge risks stemming from climate change and non-bank entities.

images.alt_text: Intel’s pitch to consumers and businesses comes as it is fighting its way out of a post-pandemic PC slump where buyers who upgraded to work from home in 2020 have seen little reason to buy new equipment.
The proposed measures are based on a survey conducted by SNEF in October on employers’ current and future challenges.
Gemini is capable of more sophisticated reasoning and understanding information with a greater degree of nuance than Google’s prior technology.

site_title: Indonesia trade surplus narrows to US$2.4 billion in November, misses expectation
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus narrowed to $2.41 billion in November, missing expectations, as imports increased more than anticipated and exports declined 8.6% year-over-year. Shipments of coal and palm oil, the country's top commodities, fell 34.3% and 12.6% respectively. Imports rose 3.3% due to higher purchases of consumer and capital goods. The trade balance is expected to narrow further, with some economists forecasting a current account deficit of 0.4% of GDP this year.

images.alt_text: Drought has delayed Indonesia’s planting for the 2024 harvest, after the country’s output this year dropped to 30.9 million metric tons from 31.53 million tons a year ago.
The World Bank projects Indonesia’s economy to grow by 4.9 per cent next year, a decrease from this year’s 5 per cent, due to a slowdown in trade and lower commodity prices.
The last IPO to raise more than US$500 million in Jakarta was Amman Mineral Internasional in July.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street to extend US Fed-fuelled rally
summary: Asian markets continued their rally on Friday, driven by the US Federal Reserve's indication of interest rate cuts in 2024. Hong Kong led the gains, surging over 3% as Shanghai also rose. Tokyo rebounded from a previous day's loss, while Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila also saw gains. The rally is seen as a "Santa rally" amid declining inflation and recession concerns, with some experts predicting more than three interest rate cuts. However, some experts warn that the rally may see a slight pullback, with a "temperature check" expected.

images.alt_text: When markets in Asia opened on Thursday (Dec 14), most key indices in the region joined a global rally in stocks.

site_title: China’s November new home prices fall for fifth straight month
summary: China's new home prices fell 0.3% month-on-month in November, marking the fifth consecutive decline, according to official data. The sector remains weak due to dampened demand and investment confidence. Despite measures to cushion the impact, prices fell at the fastest pace in seven months year-on-year, down 0.2%. Authorities have relaxed home purchase restrictions in Beijing and Shanghai to revive the market. Fitch Ratings projects a 5-7% decline in home prices next year, with the decline extending into 2025.

images.alt_text: China has been experimenting with Reits to tap the world’s second-largest equity market to finance projects that would’ve otherwise been funded by local governments.
Beijing cuts the down-payment ratio for second homes to 40 per cent or 50 per cent, depending on the locations of the properties, according to city's housing authorities.

site_title: A feast for all the senses
summary: The annual ChildAid charity fundraiser, organised by BT and ST, took place on Dec 4, featuring a musical dinner theatre with 48 child talents performing on multiple stages with 360-degree surround sound. The event raised over S$2 million for two charities, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and his wife attending and participating in a whodunit mystery. The evening included a Peranakan fusion dinner and audience interaction, with top donors including UOB, Mohamed Abdul Jaleel, and Citi Singapore.

site_title: Bank of Korea governor says urgent to introduce central bank digital currency
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong emphasized the need for introducing a central bank digital currency (CBDC) due to the growing popularity of stablecoins, which pose challenges to monetary policy and financial stability. Stablecoins, backed by assets or fiat currencies, have been linked to the collapse of TerraUSD and Luna last year. The Bank of Korea is already developing a wholesale CBDC in cooperation with the Bank for International Settlements, highlighting the urgency of introducing a CBDC to address these challenges.

site_title: Oil rises 4% on weaker US dollar, IEA demand upgrade
summary: Oil prices rose 4% on Thursday, driven by a weaker US dollar and an upgrade to the International Energy Agency's oil demand forecast for 2024. Brent futures increased to $77.26 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $72.36. The IEA lifted its forecast, citing improved US economic outlook and lower oil prices. The US dollar fell to a four-month low after the US Federal Reserve signaled lower borrowing costs for 2024.

images.alt_text: Oil steady as Covid-19 cases, lockdowns dampen vaccination news

site_title: Citigroup closes municipal underwriting and market-making unit: memo
summary: Citigroup has decided to close its municipal underwriting and market-making unit due to unviable economics, according to a memo. The unit will be unwound in the first quarter, resulting in most employees leaving. This move comes after discussions with Jefferies, where a team of bankers departed last month. The decision also follows scrutiny from the Texas attorney general over Citigroup's municipal bond offerings.

site_title: Philippine central bank says it’s not yet convinced about downward inflation trend
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Philippine central bank) maintained its benchmark interest rate at 6.5% for a second consecutive meeting, citing insufficient data to confirm a downward trend in inflation. Governor Eli Remolona stated that the policy needs to remain "sufficiently tight" to bring inflation back to target, indicating that the bank is not yet convinced of a policy easing. The decision reflects the central bank's cautious approach to monetary policy amid ongoing inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: The central bank will not lower banks’ reserve requirement ratio while it is still hawkish, governor Eli Remolona says.
“Keeping policy rates steady will allow previous rate adjustments to continue to work their way through the economy,” says Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

site_title: Once-hot China Reits get slammed as property slump dents demand
summary: China's real estate investment trusts (Reits) have suffered a significant downturn, with 28 trusts losing 31% this year and all but three trading below their debut prices. The Reits, which were initially hailed as a way to tap the world's second-largest equity market, are now underperforming the benchmark CSI 300 Index by 18 percentage points. The decline is attributed to China's deepening property crisis, weak rental demand, and a stock market slump, with some Reits losing up to 50% of their value.

images.alt_text: The trade has proved so attractive that foreign investor NCD holdings grew 80 per cent in the first 10 months of 2023 to a record high at 290 billion yuan.
China stocks face US$722b overhang as share lock-ups end

site_title: China cash crunch a boon for foreigners snapping up bank bonds
summary: Foreign investors are snapping up Chinese bank bonds, particularly negotiable certificates of deposit (NCDs), due to attractive interest rates and a premium for swapping US dollars into yuan. NCD holdings grew 80% in the first 10 months of 2023 to a record high of 290 billion yuan. This trend contrasts with a 9% drop in sovereign bond holdings, as investors seek higher yields amid a shortage of yuan in the financial system and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Singapore, China lay groundwork towards post-Covid world with new agreements
Singapore and China lay groundwork towards post Covid-19 world with new agreements
China to keep economic operations in reasonable range, says Premier Li

site_title: Boustead Singapore shareholders approve acquisition of Boustead Projects shares from chairman Wong Fong Fui and children
summary: Boustead Singapore shareholders have approved the acquisition of Boustead Projects shares from chairman Wong Fong Fui and his children, with all three resolutions garnering over 90% support. Wong, who is also chairman and group CEO of Boustead Singapore, will retain his position. The approval is seen as a strategic move to strengthen the company's financial position.

images.alt_text: With depressed share prices, major shareholders will be tempted to take listed groups private.
Boustead Singapore's S$1.18 exit offer price represents a 24.2 per cent increase from its previous voluntary unconditional general offer of S$0.95 per share.
Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore.

site_title: How digital payments could revolutionise liquidity itself
summary: Digital payments are revolutionizing liquidity, enabling real-time transactions and bridging the gap between illiquid and liquid assets. Asia, particularly South-East Asia, is leading the charge, with digital payments set to grow nearly sevenfold by 2027. This shift is driven by the increasing adoption of digital wallets, real-time settlement, and tokenisation, which enables the conversion of previously illiquid assets into cash equivalents. As technology advances, barriers between assets will fall, and consumers will be able to access a wider range of value storage options, fundamentally changing the concept of liquidity.

images.alt_text: The payments industry must now keep up with the multitude of payment options and fast-changing customer preferences.
MAS on Thursday (Nov 16) published a blueprint outlining the infrastructure required for a digital Singapore dollar, and announced that it will be expanding trials on digital money.

site_title: Making lemonade out of macro lemons
summary: Investors must adapt to a new regime of higher interest rates, increased volatility, and greater dispersion of returns. The macroeconomic outlook is uncertain, with the US economy growing slowly and no clear landing in sight. Central banks will maintain higher rates to align with production constraints, making it essential to outperform cash yields around 5%. To navigate this shift, investors should adopt a more dynamic portfolio approach, changing asset allocations frequently to capitalize on opportunities.

images.alt_text: At the COP28 climate summit last week, around 110 countries pledged to treble renewable energy capacity by 2030.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity extends declines as pressures persist: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank for a seventh consecutive month in December, with the manufacturing PMI dropping to 47.7 from 48.3 in November. The service sector showed modest gains, but overall sector performance remained subdued. Input costs rose due to a weaker yen and higher labor costs, while output charges eased. Business confidence weakened, with expectations for business activity at its lowest since March 2022.

images.alt_text: Core orders, a highly volatile data series regarded as a leading indicator of capital spending in the coming six to nine months, were up 0.7 per cent in October from the previous month.
Producer price growth stayed below the most recent consumer inflation reading for a third month.

site_title: Apple is so big, it’s almost eclipsing France’s stock market
summary: Apple's market value has surpassed that of France's, approaching $3.1 trillion, after soaring by over 50% in 2023, adding $1 trillion in value. The company's market value is now comparable to Europe's largest stock market. Analysts attribute the surge to Apple's premium positioning, services sales growth, and commodity price benefits, with some projecting share gains to $230 in 2024. The company's revenue is expected to re-accelerate in 2024, driven by demand for smartphones, laptops, and computers.

images.alt_text: Apple could block apps that don't comply with new privacy feature
Apple launches US$550 over-ear headphones into crowded market

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Keppel DC Reit, Manulife US Reit, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: ST Engineering upgraded Singapore's navy frigates, with the first upgrade expected by 2028. Keppel DC Reit's Chinese subsidiary issued a letter demanding late rentals from a tenant, and the Reit's units rose 16.4% after unitholders voted in favor of a recapitalization plan. Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager will hold an EGM to consider replacing the current trustee-manager. Boustead Singapore shareholders voted to acquire Boustead Projects shares from its chairman and his children.

site_title: Asian IPO market seen brighter in 2024 but elections cast shadows
summary: The Asian IPO market is expected to improve in 2024, with interest rates stabilizing globally, but elections in the region and US could impact demand. This year saw a 20% decline in Asia-Pacific share sales to $229 billion, the weakest since 2012. Despite this, bankers are optimistic about the market, citing a strong pipeline of deals and improved sentiment. Elections in Taiwan, Indonesia, South Korea, and India, as well as the US, may affect business decisions and slow down major deals, including Alibaba's planned Hong Kong IPO.

images.alt_text: Chinese companies raised a record amount through IPOs last year, defying a global slump and bringing hopes to bankers in Asia that the end of Covid Zero policy would boost activity even further.

site_title: Shohei the time value of money
summary: Shohei Ohtani, the Japanese baseball star, signed a 10-year, $700 million contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers, with an initial annual payment of $2 million. However, the majority of the contract is back-loaded, with annual payments of $68 million starting in 2034 and continuing until he's 50. This structure is similar to that of former Mets player Bobby Bonilla, whose contract is still being paid out 22 years after his retirement.

images.alt_text: Japan has, to date, managed a transition away from explosive growth with little social upheaval. Unemployment never rose above 6 per cent, and homelessness has been cut by 80 per cent.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit demands 48.3 million yuan late payment from China data centre tenant
summary: KEPPEL DC Reit's China unit, KDCR Guangdong, has issued a letter of demand to tenant Guangdong Bluesea Data Development, demanding 48.3 million yuan (S$9.1 million) in owed rentals and related expenses, plus 32.2 million yuan in security deposits. The demand comes after Bluesea paid instalments up to October but missed the November payment. The Reit has been in "close discussion" with Bluesea, but the payment failure has led to the demand.

images.alt_text: The net proceeds from the floating rate notes will be used for purposes including financing or refinancing acquisitions and/or investments of the Reit, development or enhancement works initiated by the trustee, general working capital and capital expenditure.

site_title: China central bank boosts liquidity offering via policy loans, rate unchanged
summary: China's central bank boosted liquidity by injecting 800 billion yuan into the banking system through medium-term policy loans, while keeping interest rates unchanged at 2.5%. The move aims to counteract short-term factors and increase mid to long-term base money supply. Despite steady policy rates, market participants expect China to maintain an accommodative monetary stance and possibly unleash further stimulus, including interest rate cuts and reserve requirement ratio reductions, to boost the economy in the new year.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Yellen to visit China again in 2024, focusing on ‘difficult’ topics
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen plans to visit China again in 2024, focusing on deepening economic cooperation while addressing national security concerns and human rights. Yellen aims to engage with China on difficult topics, such as export controls and investment restrictions, while preventing crises through resilient communication. Her strategy involves compartmentalization, balancing confrontation with collaboration. Yellen emphasizes the importance of gathering information about China's economy and plans to increase exchanges between financial regulators in the US and China.

images.alt_text: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - NOVEMBER 10: U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference following a bilateral meeting with People’s Republic of China (PRC) Vice Premier He Lifeng at the Ritz Carlton Hotel on November 10, 2023 in San Francisco, California. site_title: UK consumers turn a little more optimistic in December: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence rose to -22 in December, up from -24 in November, according to a GfK survey. The index, which measures household optimism, has shown a tendency to rise in December in recent years. The outlook for personal finances improved, with earnings now outpacing inflation. This is an encouraging sign for the year to come, despite the ongoing cost-of-living crisis. The Bank of England left interest rates on hold, citing a slightly shallower inflation path than predicted.

site_title: ECB and BOE are reluctant to join US Fed in pivoting towards rate cuts
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) president Christine Lagarde and Bank of England (BOE) chief Andrew Bailey expressed reluctance to join the US Federal Reserve in pivoting towards interest-rate cuts, citing ongoing inflation concerns. The BOE showed an appetite to stick with tight monetary policy, with three rate-setters voting for another hike. The ECB and BOE are expected to begin easing monetary policy later than investors anticipate, with the Fed likely to cut rates first in March.

images.alt_text: The ECB is likely to discuss whether to stop replacing bonds that mature although it could defer a decision until early next year.

site_title: Elegance in every tick
summary: High-end watch brands Patek Philippe, Jaeger-LeCoultre, Omega, Blancpain, and Bulgari unveil elegant timepieces for women. The Patek Philippe Calatrava Reference 4997/200R-001 features a domed dial with 76 round diamonds, while the Jaeger-LeCoultre Rendez-Vous Dazzling Night & Day boasts a full diamond-set dial. Omega's Planet Ocean 600M is a serious dive watch option, and Blancpain's Ladybird Colours Moon Phases features a textured mother-of-pearl dial with oversized Roman numerals. Meanwhile, Bulgari's Octo Roma Precious Tourbillon Lumière showcases mastery of jewellers with 5.05 carats of diamonds.

site_title: Blackstone goes all-in on Taylor Swift fandom with holiday video
summary: Blackstone, a private equity firm, has released an annual holiday video showcasing its "corporate Swiftie" fandom. The video, which dates back to 2018, features executives lip-syncing to Taylor Swift songs and referencing the firm's investments. The video aims to poke fun at the firm's corporate culture and is not meant to be taken seriously. CEO Steve Schwarzman dons a rainbow jacket inspired by Swift's tour attire to clarify that Blackstone is not to be confused with BlackRock. The video was sent to employees, investors, and portfolio company leaders.

site_title: US Congress passes huge US$886 billion defence budget for 2024
summary: The US Congress has approved a $886 billion defense budget for 2024, providing a 5% pay hike to military personnel. The budget extends a controversial overseas electronic surveillance system and provides billions to enhance deterrence in the Indo-Pacific region, targeting China's rising influence. The bill also extends military aid to Ukraine, releasing $300 million, despite a requested $61 billion package still being debated. The document now awaits President Joe Biden's final approval.

site_title: Hermes heir art auction raises at least 23 million euros in Paris
summary: An auction of art and furniture pieces from the late Hubert Guerrand-Hermes, a member of the Hermès family, raised at least 23 million euros in Paris. The collection, featuring pieces by Pierre Soulages, Francois-Xavier Lalanne, and Lucio Fontana, exceeded preliminary estimates by almost triple. A royal chair previously owned by Queen Marie-Antoinette sold for 2.6 million euros, a record price for an 18th-century chair. The auction continues until December 19 with online sessions also available.

images.alt_text: If the set of six jerseys that Lionel Messi wore during Argentina’s victorious 2022 World Cup, indeed fetch above US$10 million, that could make the sale the most valuable collection of sports memorabilia ever auctioned off, Sotheby’s says.

site_title: US business inventories unexpectedly fall in October
summary: US business inventories unexpectedly fell 0.1% in October, marking the first decline since June. This decline is expected to subtract from gross domestic product in the fourth quarter, potentially weighing on economic growth. Inventories had increased 0.6% on a year-on-year basis in October, contradicting economists' expectations of no change. Higher interest rates and limited scope for businesses to restock may be contributing factors.

site_title: US: Stocks rise again, lifting Dow to fresh record
summary: US stocks rose, lifting the Dow to a fresh record, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at 37,248.35, up 0.4%. Retail sales in the US rose unexpectedly in November, and the Federal Reserve's policy decision included a forecast for interest rate cuts in 2024. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, with the 10-year US Treasury yield falling below 4% for the first time since August. The market cheered the Fed's pivot, with some analysts optimistic about the victory in fighting inflation.

site_title: GM’s Cruise to slash 24% of its workforce
summary: General Motors' self-driving business Cruise will slash 24% of its full-time workforce, impacting about 900 employees, primarily in commercial operations and corporate functions. This move comes after Cruise fired nine executives, including its chief operating officer, on Wednesday.

site_title: Market uncertainty, recession risks could pave way for record gold prices in 2024
summary: Gold prices are expected to rise in 2024, driven by market uncertainty, recession risks, and central bank demand. Spot gold prices have risen 10.6% this year, and central banks have bought a net 800 tonnes of gold, the highest on record. Market watchers predict gold could surpass previous records, with State Street Global Advisors expecting a price range of US$1,900 to US$2,350 per ounce. Analysts also note that geopolitical tensions and interest rate changes will impact gold prices, but a potential recession could boost demand for the metal.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates tend to support non-interest-bearing bullion.

Taiwan remains a critical player in advanced semiconductor manufacturing. But the US is also trying to diversify semiconductor production out of Taiwan into the US and other close allies.

site_title: Sheffield Green swings back to black with US$3.5 million net profit in FY2023
summary: Sheffield Green, a human resources provider, posted a net profit of US$3.5 million for FY2023, reversing a net loss of US$0.2 million in the previous period. Revenue more than tripled to US$27.6 million, driven by increased contracts and personnel in the offshore wind industry. The company's human resource services business segment also saw significant growth. Sheffield Green's net operating cash flows turned positive, with US$2.1 million, and plans to expand into other international markets, including the US and Japan, to capitalize on rising demand for renewable energy personnel.

site_title: Canadian home prices fall most in 14 months amid rate squeeze
summary: Canadian home prices dropped 1.1% in November, the largest decline in 14 months, amid persistently high borrowing costs. The benchmark price now sits at C$735,500, down from May levels. Mortgage rates remain high, with home sales and new listings also decreasing. Economists expect the Bank of Canada to lower interest rates in the second quarter of next year, potentially alleviating pressure on buyers and sellers.

site_title: US$47 billion Gulf wealth fund eyes IPO spree after record listing
summary: Oman's US$47 billion Gulf wealth fund is planning to list around 30 assets, including landmark deals in energy and logistics, over the next five years to upgrade its emerging-market status. The fund, which oversees around US$47 billion in assets, aims to enhance private-sector participation and deepen the capital market. This includes listing as many as five large firms by 2026, following the success of the October listing of OQ Gas Networks, which raised US$749 million. The move is part of Oman's efforts to draw more listings and improve its credit rating, recently upgraded to Ba1 by Moody's.

images.alt_text: Israel described it as a “historic decision that will shorten the route to Asia, lower costs for Israelis and help Israeli airlines be more competitive”.

site_title: Europe: Shares at 22-month high as dovish US Fed overshadows ECB rate cut snub
summary: European shares reached a 22-month high, closing 0.9% higher, as investors reacted to the US Federal Reserve's dovish shift and shrugged off the European Central Bank's decision not to cut interest rates. The ECB reaffirmed borrowing costs at record highs despite lower inflation expectations. Despite this, the Fed's dovish shift is seen as a factor in the market's optimism, with the Stoxx 600 gaining 12.3% year-to-date. Rate-sensitive stocks rose, while the eurozone's equity volatility index reached its lowest level since 2020.

site_title: ST Engineering unit wins contract to upgrade Singapore navy frigates
summary: ST Engineering has won a contract to upgrade Singapore's navy frigates through its subsidiary ST Engineering Marine. The contract involves upgrading the marine and electrical systems, ship management system, and power generation system. The work will be done progressively, with the first frigate expected to complete its upgrades by 2028. The contract value was not disclosed, but shares of ST Engineering rose 1.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Eurozone yields fall sharply after Fed and ECB, spreads tighten
summary: Eurozone sovereign bond yields plummeted to multi-month lows after the European Central Bank (ECB) left interest rates unchanged and cut inflation forecasts, signaling an early end to its bond purchase scheme. Germany's 10-year bond yield fell to 2.029%, its lowest since March, while Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese yields also dropped. Analysts attribute the decline to the ECB's decision, which supported peripheral sovereign bonds and priced in 153 bps of rate cuts in 2024. The spread between Italian and German yields tightened to 165 bps, indicating a narrowing premium for highly indebted countries.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, November 17, 2023.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Europe rocked by migration crises
summary: Europe is facing a severe migration crisis, with many countries struggling to balance the need for workers with concerns over immigration. The UK's plans to send asylum seekers to Rwanda were met with significant opposition in the House of Commons, with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak ultimately winning the vote despite significant reservations from Conservative MPs. The bill's cost and potential impact on asylum seekers and human rights remain concerns, with critics arguing it sets a precedent and does not address the root causes of migration. The crisis highlights the complexity of tackling migration in Europe and the need for effective, just policies.

images.alt_text: (FILES) An aerial view shows rolled-up inflatable dinghies and outboard engines, stored in a Port Authority yard in Dover, southeast England on March 6, 2023, that are believed to have been used by migrants and asylum seekers who were picked up at sea whilst crossing the English Channel from France to England. UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak on December 12, 2023 sought to avoid a humiliating defeat for his latest plans to send migrants to Rwanda that have split his ruling Conservative party. The Safety of Rwanda (Asylum and Immigration) Bill is Sunak's answer to a unanimous Supreme Court ruling last month that deporting asylum seekers to Rwanda was illegal in international law. Interior minister James Cleverly admitted the plans were "novel" and "pushing at the edge of the envelope" but addressed the court's concerns. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust to hold EGM by Jan 22 on requisition to internalise trustee-manager
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) by January 22, 2024, in response to a requisition notice from a group of 15 investors. The investors aim to replace the current trustee-manager with an internally owned entity, which will be wholly owned by Dasin Retail Trust's unitholders. This move is seen as a plan to internalize the trustee-manager, following a creditors' winding-up petition against the major shareholder, Sino-Ocean Capital, set to be heard on March 27, 2024.

site_title: Investors remain cautious even as tap for startup funding flows again
summary: Investors in the South-east Asia startup ecosystem are cautiously pouring funds into startups, despite a slight easing of the funding dry spell. Late-stage venture capital investors are still cautious, with nine out of 10 series B and C investors expressing extreme caution compared to last year. Funding activity has picked up, but the quantum of cheques being written remains low, with some investors attributing this to founders being more aware of dilution and VCs having less fear of missing out. The ecosystem is expected to endure pain for the next six months, with some companies facing reduced valuations and investors facing tougher fundraising conditions.

images.alt_text: Coins, stack, clock, money
Given valuation concerns and poor exit conditions, investors prefer early-stage over late-stage deals, according to Preqin.

site_title: Clubs spent record US$888 million in agent service fees in 2023: Fifa
summary: Soccer clubs spent a record US$888.1 million in agent service fees in 2023, a 42.5% increase from the previous year. English clubs led the way, spending over US$280 million, while 86.6% of the global expenditure came from European clubs, according to FIFA. This surpasses the previous record of US$654.7 million set in 2019.

images.alt_text: “Premier League shareholders today agreed to amend the rule on amortisation of player registration costs to bring it in line with Uefa’s regulations,” the league says.
24 of the 36 clubs in the top two divisions of German football vote in favour of the plan to secure private equity investment, enough to give the proposal the necessary two-thirds majority.
Last weekend’s match between Chelsea FC and Liverpool Football Club was watched by a record-breaking 1 million-plus audience on the free-to-air BBC.

site_title: Testing the Balmuda toaster
summary: The Balmuda toaster, priced at S$539, is a high-end appliance that offers a premium toasting experience. It features a unique steam-heating system, which softens and plumps up bread to perfection. The toaster excels in toasting bread and croissants, but may not perform well with pastries filled with fillings. It also lacks a built-in tray, requiring users to take extra precautions to avoid spills. While it may not be practical for everyone, the Balmuda toaster offers exceptional results for those willing to invest in its unique features and sleek design.

images.alt_text: Gen Terao, founder and CEO of Balmuda Design.

site_title: Taiwan central bank cuts GDP outlook, stands pat on rates
summary: Taiwan's central bank cut its 2023 economic growth forecast due to sluggish global demand, but kept interest rates at 1.875% in a unanimous decision, extending a pause in its tightening efforts. The bank had raised rates five times by a total of 75 basis points to combat inflationary pressures, which have eased. This decision aligns with expectations from a Reuters poll, where 28 out of 29 economists predicted the bank would maintain rates on hold.

site_title: Intel says dozens of PC makers are using its new AI-enabled chip
summary: Intel announced that dozens of PC makers, including Dell Technologies, Microsoft, and Lenovo, are using its new AI-enabled "Meteor Lake" chip. The chip, featuring a neural processing unit (NPU), will be available in laptops starting Thursday at Best Buy and other global retailers. Intel aims to entice consumers to upgrade their machines for a new era of AI applications, expecting the "AI PC" to comprise 80% of PCs sold within the next four years. This move comes as Intel fights a post-pandemic PC slump.

images.alt_text: The US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit reverses the jury’s 2021 verdict that Intel infringed one VLSI patent, and sent the case back to Texas for a new trial.
Vietnam is keen to position itself as an alternative to China and Taiwan, amid political risks and trade tensions with the United States.
AI-enabled PCs refer to machines that come with advanced chips capable of running large-language models and apps powered by the technology directly on the device, instead of the cloud.
PC sales and manufacturing contracts are increasing after a post-pandemic slump that pushed Intel’s margins to their lowest in a decade.

site_title: China Evergrande to exit Shanghai Henggen Real Estate amid liquidity crunch
summary: China Evergrande announced it will sell its 30% stake in Shanghai Henggen Real Estate for 663.2 million yuan, amid a liquidity crunch. The sale is expected to result in a 55 million yuan loss for Evergrande. This move comes as the company seeks to restructure its debt and has been granted an adjournment on a liquidation petition until January 29. The sale is related to the Shanghai North Bund Project, which has generated no rental income since 2021 and 2022.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after Fed hints at rate cuts
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, Dec 14, after the Federal Reserve hinted at an end to aggressive rate hikes and lower borrowing costs next year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 25.39 points, or 0.07%, to 37,115.63, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher. The positive start follows a day after the Fed's comments, which may alleviate concerns about the impact of interest rate hikes on the economy.

site_title: Tee International to acquire signage manufacturer for S$14 million
summary: Tee International is proposing to acquire Carats&Co Pte Ltd, a sign and advertising display manufacturer, for S$14 million. The acquisition is considered a strategic investment, as the manufacturer's business is complementary to Tee International's core engineering and construction business segment. The proposed deal aims to leverage Carats&Co's market access and technical knowledge, allowing Tee International to expand its business and achieve consistent financial growth. The acquisition comes after Tee International applied for a further extension of time to submit its revised trading resumption proposal.

images.alt_text: Tee International on Friday extended the longstop date of its subscription agreement with an entity known as Meta5.

site_title: US import prices post second straight monthly decline in November
summary: US import prices fell for a second straight month in November, declining 0.4% after a 0.6% drop in October. This marks the 10th consecutive month of annual import price decreases, suggesting import deflation could help lower domestic inflation. Energy products and motor vehicles led the decline, with imported fuel prices decreasing 5.6% and the cost of imported motor vehicles, parts, and engines falling 0.1%. The move is seen as a positive sign for the US economy, with the Federal Reserve signaling an end to historic monetary policy tightening and potential rate cuts in 2024.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - NOVEMBER 24: A Costumer visits the store on early morning Black Friday Sales at Macy's herald square on November 24, 2023 in New York City. The National Retail Federation projects that an estimated 182 million are planning to shop in-store and online through the five-day Thanksgiving weekend.   Kena Betancur/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by KENA BETANCUR / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: ECB pushes back against rate cut bets with pledge to stay tight
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reaffirmed its decision to keep interest rates at record highs, contradicting investor bets on imminent rate cuts. Despite easing inflation expectations, the ECB cited "domestic price pressures" and strong growth in unit labor costs, indicating that rates will remain restrictive for as long as necessary. The ECB's deposit rate remains at 4%, unchanged since July 2022, and the bank also brought forward the end of its bond-buying scheme. The decision is a sharp reversal from the sequence of 10 consecutive interest rate hikes that ended in September.

images.alt_text: The ECB is likely to discuss whether to stop replacing bonds that mature although it could defer a decision until early next year.
The European Central Bank is expected to leave interest rates unchanged on Thursday for its second meeting in a row.

site_title: Air France-KLM lifts profitability goal as rebound continues
summary: Air France-KLM has raised its profitability goal, aiming for an operating margin of 8% between 2026 and 2028. The airline group's shares jumped 7.9% in Paris trading, driven by the promise of sustained and more profitable growth. This surpasses the company's previous medium-term prediction of a 7% to 8% margin. Air France-KLM also announced estimated net capital expenditures of up to $5.07 billion annually from 2024 to 2026 to invest in fleet upgrades and aircraft maintenance.

images.alt_text: Operating income advanced 31 per cent from a year earlier to a record 1.34 billion euros (S$1.93 billion), slightly below analysts’ estimates.

site_title: Greenback hits four-month low after Fed pivots, ECB leaves rates unchanged
summary: The US dollar index fell to a four-month low of 102.27, its lowest since August 10, after the Federal Reserve indicated its interest-rate hiking cycle has ended and lower borrowing costs are coming in 2024. The Fed's projections implied 75 basis points of cuts next year, contradicting market expectations of a dovish tone. The ECB left interest rates unchanged, while the Bank of England held rates steady, and the Norwegian krone strengthened after a surprise rate hike. The yen also rose against the greenback, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars reached four-month highs.

site_title: Meta rolls out Twitter rival Threads in the EU
summary: Meta's text-based app Threads has launched in the European Union, months after its global launch in July. The app, which is a rival to X (formerly Twitter), allows EU users to create a profile connected to their Instagram account and has added features such as a "Following Feed" and the ability to edit posts. Meta aims to comply with EU regulations, including the Digital Markets Act, which designates the company as a "gatekeeper" and imposes stricter rules on online companies. The app's launch follows Meta's efforts to address concerns over data usage and misinformation.

images.alt_text: The Threads application on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Tuesday, July 11, 2023. Meta Platforms Inc.'s answer to Twitter Inc. has rocketed to 100 million users in less than a week, Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg announced on Monday. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: A Singapore designer’s technicolour home
summary: Singapore designer Lim Wenhui's 132-square-meter apartment is a technicolour home that showcases her unique style and love for vibrant colours. The apartment's open-plan design enhances its spaciousness and free-flowing sensibility. Lim, a partner in Spark Architects, drew inspiration from various sources, including surrealist directors and designers, to create a kaleidoscopic backdrop. The apartment features a mix of round shapes and contrasting colours, with a focus on creating a calming and uplifting atmosphere. Lim's design approach prioritizes self-expression and happiness, making her home a true reflection of her personality.

site_title: China EV maker Zeekr unveils fast-charging LFP battery
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Zeekr unveiled a fast-charging lithium iron phosphate (LFP) battery, set to power its upcoming 007 sedan. The battery charges in 15 minutes to reach a 500 km driving range. Zeekr aims to reduce dependence on external suppliers, following rival Nio's plan to spin off its battery unit. This move is part of the company's effort to cut costs and improve efficiency in the competitive EV market.

site_title: Bank of England says rates to stay high for ‘extended period’
summary: The Bank of England maintained interest rates at a 15-year high of 5.25% as it voted 6-3 to keep rates high for an "extended period". The decision contrasts with the US Federal Reserve's signal to cut US interest rates next year, and the BOE remains concerned about inflation in Britain. Governor Andrew Bailey stated that while rates have helped bring inflation down, there is still work to be done to return it to target. The decision is at odds with market expectations, which see rates dropping to 4.25% by the end of next year.

images.alt_text: Fed Chair Jerome Powell flagged the uncertainty of the US economic outlook and said he couldn’t definitively rule out higher rates at this point, even as officials looked toward a lower policy rate.

site_title: Malaysia’s Tenaga Nasional appoints new CEO
summary: Malaysia's Tenaga Nasional has appointed Megat Jalaluddin Bin Megat Hassan as its new CEO for a two-year term starting March 1. Hassan, who has been with the company since 2009 and is currently chief operating officer, will succeed Baharin bin Din. This change comes as Baharin leaves the company upon completion of his tenure.

site_title: US retail sales unexpectedly rebound in November; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly rose 0.3% in November, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 0.1% decline. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles, petrol, and food services, increased 0.4% for the month. The Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and new economic projections suggest the economy may continue to grow at a moderate pace in the fourth quarter, with GDP forecasts at 1.2% and inflation-adjusted consumer spending expected to grow at 2% annually. Initial jobless claims also fell to 202,000 for the week ended December 9, down 19,000 from the previous week.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 24, 2022 Ford Motor Co. battery powered F-150 Lightning trucks under production at their Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan. - Ford will resume production on its F-150 Lightning electric truck on March 13, more than five weeks after a battery fire brought operations to a halt, the company said March 2, 2023. (Photo by JEFF KOWALSKY / AFP)

site_title: Foreign philanthropists lend buzz to Singapore’s art scene
summary: Foreign philanthropists are lending their support to Singapore's art scene, contributing to its cultural life through high-calibre shows featuring world-class artists. Notable contributors include Pierre Lorinet from France, Vir and Simran Kotak from India, and the M Art Foundation from China. Their efforts aim to communicate complex messages and challenge perceptions through art, with recent exhibitions including Yinka Shonibare's batik installation, Danh Vo's sculptures, and minimalist masterworks at Gillman Barracks. Their philanthropic efforts are helping shape Singapore's cultural landscape.

images.alt_text: A view of the William Lim-designed house at C-1 Holland Park, with its iconic V-shaped butterfly roof.
Hilmi Johandi’s history-based paintings at Ota Fine Arts, one of the 116 galleries participating in Art SG.

site_title: ABN Amro to buy mobile bokerage BUX to boost digital presence
summary: ABN Amro Bank has agreed to acquire online brokerage firm BUX BV, aiming to boost its retail investment and digital presence. BUX, a leading mobile brokerage firm with 500,000 clients across eight countries, will be acquired without disclosing terms. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to tap into BUX's younger, starter investor base, with ABN Amro's chief commercial officer citing this as an attractive aspect of the deal.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 14)
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, driven by the US Federal Reserve's pause on interest rate hikes and signals of future rate cuts in 2024. Singapore's job vacancies fell in September, while retrenchments rose, prompting close monitoring. The Singapore National Employers Federation proposed Budget 2024 with AI adoption grants, while the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore sought proposals for methanol bunkering solutions. Resale prices in new HDB estates, such as Punggol, rose at a higher-than-average pace, and Singapore shares finished 0.6% higher, led by real estate investment trusts.

site_title: Yellen says 'shock' management key to US-China stability
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says managing "shocks" in the US-China relationship is crucial to preventing escalation. She aims to "make our communication resilient" to prevent misunderstandings from causing harm. Yellen's priorities include discussing "difficult areas of concern," promoting clarity on China's economic policies, and seeking more transparency on non-market practices. Her next trip to China will focus on these issues, including outbound investment restrictions and national security concerns. The goal is to maintain stability in the relationship despite ongoing challenges.

images.alt_text: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - NOVEMBER 10: U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference following a bilateral meeting with People’s Republic of China (PRC) Vice Premier He Lifeng at the Ritz Carlton Hotel on November 10, 2023 in San Francisco, California. Secretary Yellen and Vice Premier Lifeng will hold meetings ahead of the APEC summit being held in San Francisco.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Apple is so big that it’s almost eclipsing France’s stock market
summary: Apple's market value has surpassed that of France's stock market, with a combined value of $3.2 trillion and $3.1 trillion, respectively. The technology giant's market value has surged over 50% in 2023, adding $1 trillion in value, driven by a rebound in demand for smartphones, laptops, and computers. Analysts project Apple's revenue will re-accelerate in 2024, with Wall Street expecting a strong year for the company.

images.alt_text: Apple has seen revenue fall every quarter in fiscal 2023 relative to the same period the year before.
The enhancement will require Face ID or Touch ID when accessing stored passwords, changing Apple ID settings, looking at payment information and disabling Find My iPhone.
Starting next year, Apple plans to give added weighting to streams of songs that are mixed in Dolby Atmos technology.

site_title: Stamford Tyres H1 profit falls 24.5% to S$1.6 million on lower sales
summary: Stamford Tyres' first-half profit plummeted 24.5% to S$1.6 million due to lower sales in South-east Asia and export markets, resulting in a 1.4% decline in revenue to S$95.6 million. The company attributed the decline to higher production costs and lower gross profit margins. Despite the poor performance, Stamford Tyres plans to diversify its product offerings and improve sales productivity to adapt to the challenging global economic outlook. No dividend was declared for the half year, and shares closed 1.1% higher at S$0.191.

images.alt_text: The tyre and wheel distributor’s H1 revenue was 10.2 per cent higher at S$97 million.

site_title: GoTo struck Tiktok deal to halt market share slide: CEO
summary: GoTo Group, a leading e-commerce platform in Indonesia, has struck a deal with TikTok to halt its market share slide. The joint venture will see TikTok invest $1.5 billion in a venture it will control, with GoTo relinquishing control of its Tokopedia arm. The partnership aims to address regulatory obstacles and increase market share, with TikTok's share now at 11% and GoTo's at 23%. GoTo shares rose 9% following the announcement, and the company is expected to achieve positive adjusted earnings this quarter.

site_title: China approves first graphite export permits after rule change
summary: China has approved export permits for graphite, its first since a rule change aimed at protecting national security. The move, effective this month, requires permits for additional graphite products, raising concerns about tighter global supplies. The world's top graphite producer and exporter will now need licenses for shipments to the US, Japan, and South Korea, where graphite is used in refractories and batteries. This change follows earlier export controls on graphite and chip-making metals, causing shipments to plummet in August and September.

site_title: Indonesia calls in army to help farmers plant rice as drought curbs output
summary: Indonesia has deployed the military to assist farmers in planting rice due to severe drought affecting the 2024 harvest. The drought, fueled by El Nino weather, has led to a 1.64% drop in the country's rice output to 30.9 million tonnes from last year. The government aims to encourage farmers to plant rice despite planting being behind schedule. President Joko Widodo has instructed military supervisory officers to help farmers take advantage of recent rainfall. This move aims to alleviate food security concerns and stabilize rice prices.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s biggest shipments of rice come from Thailand, followed by Vietnam, India, Pakistan and Myanmar.
This aerial photo taken on June 27, 2023 shows farmers working at a rice field in Haian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Rolex reseller Chrono24 taps Zalando executive as CEO
summary: Chrono24, the largest online luxury watch reseller, has appointed Carsten Keller, a Zalando executive, as its new CEO. Keller will replace co-CEOs Tim Stracke and Holger Felgner, who will remain shareholders and board members. Chrono24 has experienced slowing sales growth amid falling luxury watch prices, with year-over-year sales volume expected to rise 3% in 2023. Keller's appointment marks a significant change of guard at the company, valued at over $1 billion, and comes as the company considers a public share listing.

site_title: Swiss central bank signals end of hikes, economists eye cuts in 2024
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) kept interest rates unchanged at 1.75% and lowered its inflation forecasts, signaling the end of recent rate hikes and potentially lower borrowing costs in 2024. The bank dropped references to future rate hikes and no longer focuses on selling foreign currency, a tactic that helped dampen imported inflation. Analysts see the move as a dovish shift, with some predicting rate cuts as early as March or June 2024.

Swiss consumer price growth remains lower than many advanced economies, showcasing how the country’s strong currency has sheltered it from the ravages of inflation elsewhere.

site_title: Do new HDB estates outperform on resale? Punggol data suggests so
summary: Punggol's new HDB estates have seen higher-than-average resale price growth, with four-room flats rising 42% and five-room flats 50% in value between 2015 and 2023. This "first-mover" advantage is attributed to factors such as lower launch prices, more flats reaching the minimum occupation period, and improved amenities. Experts suggest that Punggol's relatively new age and connectivity improvements will continue to drive price growth, with potential similar gains in upcoming new towns like Tengah.

images.alt_text: The projects in the December 2023 BTO exercise are in Bedok, Bishan, Bukit Merah, Bukit Panjang, Jurong West, Queenstown and Woodlands.
Industry watchers largely expect demand in the HDB resale market to remain muted for December 2023 due to the holiday season.
As at 5pm on Dec 11, about four first-time applicants were vying for each of the 260 five-room flats at Urban Rise @ Woodlands.

site_title: Manulife US Reit unitholders vote overwhelmingly in favour of recapitalisation plan
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (MUST) unitholders voted overwhelmingly in favour of its recapitalisation plan, with over 97% of votes supporting each of the three inter-conditional resolutions. The plan involves divestment of Park Place property for US$98.7 million, a six-year loan of US$137 million, and adopting a disposition mandate to dispose of properties. The move aims to remedy financial covenant breaches and provide time to sell assets, with distributions to continue halted until December 2025.

images.alt_text: The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.

Park Place was only purchased recently at the end of 2021 for US$106 million.
The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.

site_title: Japan’s Kishida removes ministers in bid to stay in power
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida reshuffled his cabinet in an attempt to contain a funding scandal, replacing four ministers accused of concealing income from fundraising events. Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno and trade minister Yasutoshi Nishimura were among those removed. The reshuffle aims to shore up support for Kishida's government, which is the most unpopular in over a decade. The move's effectiveness remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: (Clockwise from top left) Japan's Economy and Industry Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura, Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno, Internal Affairs Minister Junji Suzuki and , Agriculture Minister Ichiro Miyashita have tendered their resignations.

site_title: US House launches Republican impeachment inquiry against Biden
summary: The US House of Representatives voted 221-212 along party lines to formalize an impeachment inquiry into President Joe Biden, escalating Republicans' battle with Democrats ahead of the 2024 election. Republicans have seized on Biden's son Hunter's international dealings, but no evidence of corruption by the president has been provided. Biden slammed the move as "baseless" and accused Republicans of stalling on key issues while obsessing over scoring political points. The inquiry's outcome is unlikely to lead to an actual impeachment trial, given the Democratic-controlled Senate.

site_title: Temu files new lawsuit against Shein after ‘intensified’ clash
summary: Temu, a Chinese-owned online marketplace, has filed a new lawsuit against Shein, accusing the fast-fashion rival of intensifying anticompetitive practices. The lawsuit claims Shein filed tens of thousands of copyright takedown notices, forced suppliers into exclusive agreements, and threatened merchants. Temu alleges that Shein's actions are a "desperate plan" to eliminate the competitive threat posed by Temu, which has widened its gap in US transactions since surpassing Shein in May.

images.alt_text: Shein has a huge valuation and is primed for an IPO.
Shein has held talks with the London Stock Exchange about the possibility of a public listing in the United Kingdom.
Amazon dominates US e-commerce by capturing more than US$1 of every US$3 spent online.

site_title: World Bank cuts Thai growth outlook to 2.5% this year, 3.2% next year
summary: The World Bank has revised Thailand's economic growth outlook, cutting it to 2.5% for 2023 and 3.2% for 2024. The downgrade was attributed to a contraction in exports and ongoing fiscal consolidation. However, the bank expects tourism, private consumption, and a rebound in exports due to favorable global trade to support growth. The planned digital wallet program could further boost growth, but poses risks to the fiscal deficit and public debt. Downside risks include heightened geopolitical conflict and high oil prices, which could lead to inflationary pressures.

site_title: Reits lead Singapore stocks higher after Fed holds rates steady; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% on Thursday, driven by gains in real estate investment trusts (Reits), led by CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, which increased 5.3%. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 3,122.95. The Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates steady in 2024 was seen as a positive signal for borrowing costs. A total of 1.6 billion securities worth S$1.5 billion changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 385 to 211.

site_title: Singapore to see commercial operation of battery-swapping electric motorcycles in 2024
summary: Singapore will see commercial operations of battery-swapping electric motorcycles by Gogoro and Mo Batteries in 2024, following the commencement of the Electric Vehicles Charging Act in December 2023. The companies, which have been testing the concept since early 2023, plan to expand their operations after obtaining regulatory approval. The charge-and-swap system, which allows riders to quickly swap out batteries, is being touted as a faster alternative to traditional charging methods.

Under the new collaboration, C&C would lease Gogoro 2 Series Smartscooters to foodpanda riders, who can swap out depleted batteries for new ones in seconds at battery swapping stations.

Known for its green-hued battery swap distribution network for riders, Gogoro has ambitious plans, seeing potential to replace vast fleets of heavily-polluting, gasoline-powered scooters with electric two-wheelers, as Asia’s metropolises bid to improve air quality.
Singaporean electric motorcycle and mobility startup Charged has three models (left to right): the Anoa cargo bike, Rimau urban commuter, and Maleo ride-hailing model.

site_title: China extends homebuying easing to Beijing and Shanghai
summary: China has relaxed homebuying curbs in Beijing and Shanghai, extending efforts to stem an unprecedented housing downturn. Beijing lowered the down-payment ratio for first homes to 30% and for second homes to 40% or 50%, while Shanghai cut the ratio to 30% for first homes and 50% for second homes. The measures aim to stabilize the real estate market, which accounts for 20% of China's economy, amid a 22-month decline in home sales. The move is part of a broader effort to prevent a downward spiral in the property sector.

(Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Japan’s central bank to sit tight on policy, may drop hints on pivot
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its ultra-loose policy settings next week, with no major changes to its policy guiding short-term interest rates and the 10-year bond yield. The BOJ may drop hints on when it will exit negative interest rates, with April being the most likely timing. Despite the BOJ's quarterly "tankan" survey showing strength in Japan's corporate sector, weak signs in consumption and global economic uncertainties may warrant maintaining the status quo. The BOJ's decision may be influenced by the changing global monetary policy environment, particularly the Federal Reserve's signal of potential rate cuts.

site_title: Philippine central bank keeps interest rate steady as expected
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) maintained its benchmark interest rate at 6.50% for a second consecutive meeting, as inflation slowed to 4.1% in November, just below the central bank's target of 2-4%. The decision follows the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates steady, and BSP Governor Eli Remolona expressed concerns about price risks, including from El Nino and oil price surges. The move is seen as a sign that the BSP may not need to ease rates in the near future.

images.alt_text: The central bank will not lower banks’ reserve requirement ratio while it is still hawkish, governor Eli Remolona says.

site_title: Vietnam tech group FPT makes play for US car industry with US$100 million investment pledge
summary: Vietnam-based tech company FPT has established an automotive subsidiary in the US, FPT Automotive, with a pledge to invest up to $100 million over the next five years. The move aims to capitalize on the growing role of software in vehicles, providing solutions to tier-1 suppliers, OEMs, and chipmakers for "future-ready" and "software-defined" vehicles. FPT's automotive business is part of a broader expansion into North America, following acquisitions and investments made in the past year.

images.alt_text: FPT Software gained 300 additional employees through its acquisition of Phoenix-based Intertec International's IT services division.
Vietnam's FPT has been collaborating with US software firm Landing AI since 2022 to leverage what they call “large vision models” to implement computer vision solutions for industries.

site_title: Zack Snyder creates his own ‘Star Wars’ with ‘Rebel Moon’
summary: Director Zack Snyder has created his own 'Star Wars' universe with his Netflix sci-fi movie epic 'Rebel Moon', after his initial pitch to Lucasfilm was rejected. The film, released on Dec 22, follows Kora, a mysterious stranger, as she defends a peaceful village from the tyrannical Imperium. Snyder has stated that he finds the process of creating his own world to be "incredibly rewarding" and allows him to deconstruct sci-fi icons and tropes. A "director's cut" with a more adult tone is planned for release next summer, with a companion video game, graphic novel, and animated film also in the works.

images.alt_text: The streaming giant has begun disclosing more data.
Netflix’s ad revenue will likely jump 50.3 per cent to about US$1 billion next year.
'Leave the World Behind' has also drawn the attention of Elon Musk for a scene featuring self-driving Teslas in a multicar pileup.
The tennis face-off between Nadal (pictured) and Alcaraz will stream as a dual broadcast in English and Spanish. Tickets for the event start at US$88 and will go on sale on Friday.
The two-part sixth, and final, season of The Crown that premieres on Netflix on Nov 16, explores Princess Diana’s final days before she perishes in a car accident.

site_title: SNEF proposes Budget 2024 to boost current support schemes, introduce corporate grants for AI adoption
summary: The Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) has proposed Budget 2024 measures to boost current support schemes and introduce corporate grants for artificial intelligence (AI) adoption, aiming to boost productivity and competitiveness. The proposal, based on a survey of 237 employers, includes subsidised training for AI-related courses and specific grants to encourage AI adoption. SNEF also called for higher absentee payroll funding and course-fee funding to upskill and reskill the workforce, amid concerns about wage costs and capability transfer.

site_title: Not enough affordable housing around the world
summary: The world is facing a severe shortage of affordable housing, with cities worldwide struggling to provide decent homes for the average worker. Housing costs have increased significantly, with median-priced homes costing over 4.1 times median annual income. Many cities, including Hong Kong, London, and Beijing, have seen housing become unaffordable, leading to growing inequality and displacement of essential workers. Governments and private developers are exploring solutions, including rent control, tax incentives, and higher density development, but a global shortage of affordable housing remains a pressing concern, with the world's population projected to reach 68% urban by 2050.

images.alt_text: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - SEPTEMBER 08: An aerial view of homes in a housing development in the Chatsworth neighborhood on September 08, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. site_title: Will books survive Spotify?
summary: Spotify's new audiobook offering may harm the future of publishing, as the company extracts money from content creators, selling user data and price-gouging advertisers. In 2020, 90% of Spotify's royalties went to the top 0.8% of artists, leaving the majority struggling to earn a living. This business strategy, popularized by "The Long Tail," has proven to be a winner-takes-all game, resulting in a gradual deterioration of culture and collective memories.

images.alt_text: Spotify is now aiming to use LLMs to replicate that across its non-music content such as podcasts and audiobooks.
