The number of exits valued at US$162.2 billion in Q3 is down from 2022, and the average timeline from investment to exit has increased to six years. Despite this, lower VC valuations could benefit 2023-vintage funds, with Preqin predicting a positive tailwind for future fundraising.

images.alt_text: Coins, stack, clock, money

site_title: Foreign investors boost Asian bond buys in November amid US rate cut signals
summary: Foreign investors significantly boosted Asian bond purchases in November, driven by a sharp fall in US Treasury yields and expectations of potential Federal Reserve rate cuts. The largest monthly net purchase since May totaled US$6.36 billion in South Korean, Indian, Malaysian, Indonesian, and Thai bonds. Indian bonds saw the highest inflow since August 2017, while South Korea's exports exceeded expectations, signaling economic resilience. Portfolio flows into emerging Asia are expected to recover due to improving fundamentals and the end of the US rate hike cycle.

images.alt_text: Since August 2022, BI has raised interest rates by a total of 250 basis points.
The Chinese government has embarked on a big push in recent months to lure foreign investment back to the country.
China’s direct investment liabilities in its balance of payments declined by US$11.8 billion in the third quarter.
If passed into law, the new requirements will apply to specified entities, with only "a handful" expected to be designated under the law, said Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong.
Thailand is hoping to lure more investments now than the 981 billion baht commitments it received between 2019 and 2022 using less than half the target industries then.

site_title: Fitch says China 2024 outlook neutral, but debt challenges mount
summary: Fitch Ratings has forecast mainland China's 2024 GDP growth to moderate to 4.6% from 5% in 2023, citing subdued external demand, property sector challenges, and local government debt as headwinds. The neutral outlook contrasts with government advisers' recommended 2024 growth targets of 4.5-5.5%. The moderate growth forecast is seen as stable, but below rating peers.

images.alt_text: Beijing is on target to meet its conservative annual growth target of about 5 per cent this year.
China will implement a proactive fiscal policy and a prudent monetary policy in 2024.

China’s securities regulators publish draft rules that would require a qualified investor in PE and VC funds to put up at least three million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold in an effort to protect small investors.
China's consumer price index, the main gauge of inflation, fell 0.5 per cent year-on-year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

The rating action for financial institutions including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is primarily driven by the change in outlook to negative from stable on the government’s credit ratings, according to Moody’s.
Moody’s says the “principal driver” of Hong Kong’s negative rating outlook is the “tight linkage between the credit profiles” of the finance hub and China.

While the economy is seen on track to hit the government’s annual growth target of around 5 per cent this year, Moody’s expects China’s annual economic growth to slow to an average 3.8 per cent from 2026 to 2030.

site_title: iPhone supplier Murata targets China budget smartphone makers
summary: Japanese smartphone component supplier Murata Manufacturing aims to increase sales to Chinese makers of lower-end handsets for emerging markets. The company expects the smartphone market to grow 5% in 2025, driven by demand for mid- and low-end handsets in India, Africa, and South-east Asia. Murata President Norio Nakajima stated that exports to areas with growing populations are increasing, despite saturated strongholds. This move comes as the industry grapples with depressed smartphone demand as consumers hold on to handsets for longer.

images.alt_text: The enhancement will require Face ID or Touch ID when accessing stored passwords, changing Apple ID settings, looking at payment information and disabling Find My iPhone.
Foxconn has rapidly expanded its presence in India over the past year by investing heavily in manufacturing facilities in the south of the country.
Starting next year, Apple plans to give added weighting to streams of songs that are mixed in Dolby Atmos technology.
The iPhone maker says it “took steps to protect our users by blocking techniques that exploit fake credentials in order to gain access to iMessage”.
Steve Hotelling’s work included some of Apple’s most complex and critical technologies for the iPhone, iPad and Apple Watch, as well as the upcoming Vision Pro headset.
Apple has been touting India as its next big growth driver as it looks to move some production away from China.

site_title: Technical issue disrupts clearing of Singdollar cheques deposited on Dec 12
summary: A technical issue has disrupted the clearing process for Singapore-dollar cheques deposited on December 12, causing delays in crediting and receiving funds on December 13. The Association of Banks in Singapore expects a delay, with funds credited from 5pm on Wednesday. The issue may also affect US dollar-denominated cheques. The Monetary Authority of Singapore had previously announced plans to eliminate corporate cheques by 2025, with banks set to charge for their use starting November 1.

images.alt_text: Local consumers largely rely on credit and debit cards, which make up around 57 per cent of electronic payments.

As cloud computing, open APIs and embedded finance reach an inflection point, their intersection with emerging technologies such as blockchain, AI and quantum computing will create a digital Big Bang, which will change financial services beyond recognition
The new rules were introduced by the Monetary Authority of Singapore on Friday, after it concluded a public consultation on the proposal to eliminate all corporate cheques by 2025.
MAS will be consulting on ending corporate cheques by 2025, DPM Wong said in a speech on Wednesday (Nov 2)

site_title: Dubai summit adopts world-first ‘transition’ from fossil fuels
summary: The COP28 summit in Dubai has reached a historic consensus, calling for the world to transition away from fossil fuels and achieve net zero emissions by 2050. Nearly 200 nations approved the agreement, which marks the first time fossil fuels have been mentioned in a climate summit in 28 years. The deal requires countries to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 43% by 2030 and calls for a just, orderly, and equitable transition to clean energy systems. While environmentalists welcome the progress, they note that the agreement stops short of calls for a "phase-out" of fossil fuels and contains loopholes for continued use of transitional fuels.

images.alt_text: Climate activists at a protest against fossil fuels at Dubai's Expo City during the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Dec 12, 2023.

site_title: How Shein outgrew Zara and H&M and pioneered fast-fashion 2.0
summary: Shein has surpassed Zara and H&M as the leading fast-fashion retailer, with $23 billion in global revenue in 2022 and a valuation poised for an IPO. The China-founded e-tailer's low prices and ultra-flexible supply chain have drawn shoppers away from traditional brick-and-mortar retailers. Shein's ability to rapidly ramp up production and send products directly to consumers via air freight has given it a significant advantage over its competitors. As investors await the release of sales results from Zara and H&M, analysts warn that the two retailers face challenges from Shein's fast-growing market share and its reputation for copying designs.

images.alt_text: Shein has held talks with the London Stock Exchange about the possibility of a public listing in the United Kingdom.
Amazon dominates US e-commerce by capturing more than US$1 of every US$3 spent online.

Convincing regulators that its supply chain is clean will likely be a major regulatory hurdle as Shein works to convince the US Securities and Exchange Commission that its shares should be traded publicly.
Shein has become popular thanks to its trendy clothing at ultra-low prices.

site_title: China’s credit growth disappoints in November as bond sales slow
summary: China's credit growth slowed in November, with aggregate financing reaching 2.45 trillion yuan ($461 billion), lower than forecast. This marks a decrease from October's 1.85 trillion yuan and last year's 2 trillion yuan. Financial institutions offered 1.09 trillion yuan of new loans, below projections. The People's Bank of China has shifted towards fiscal stimulus, selling more debt to fund infrastructure and disaster relief, rather than cutting interest rates to boost credit demand. The central bank aims to control the money supply and smooth out the credit cycle.

images.alt_text: The surge in Asian bond purchases in November coincided with a sharp fall in US Treasury yields.
The PBOC set the daily reference rate at 7.1140 per US dollar, versus an average estimate at 7.1486 in a Bloomberg survey with analysts and traders.
The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: The neglected issue that will define Europe’s future
summary: The European Union is at a critical juncture, with failure to agree on new fiscal rules potentially jeopardizing the sustainability of its monetary union. The current fiscal rules, introduced in 2020, are set to expire, and a new agreement is needed to compensate for the lack of a fully federal fiscal union. The EU faces significant challenges, including the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, and the failure to address the EU's populist problem and the eurozone's fundamental flaw of the absence of a fiscal union.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags fly outside the European Commission in Brussels, Belgium November 8, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Apac private equity to face challenges in fundraising, returns
summary: Asia-Pacific private equity faces challenges in fundraising due to uncertainty around China, with no substitute for the region. A report by Preqin found Apac private equity raised US$26.7 billion, a 5.3% share of global fundraising, down from 20.8% in 2021. North America dominated fundraising, accounting for 67% of the global total. The decline in Apac's share of capital raised is attributed to waning investor appetite amidst China's economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Some 58 per cent of Asia-Pacific family offices saw an increase in AUM, with 32 per cent reporting an increase of more than 10 per cent.

China’s securities regulators publish draft rules that would require a qualified investor in PE and VC funds to put up at least three million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold in an effort to protect small investors.

site_title: Three Arrows’ Zhu Su probed in Singapore court as liquidators step up hunt for assets
summary: Zhu Su, co-founder of collapsed crypto fund Three Arrows Capital, faced a two-day court hearing in Singapore, responding to lawyers for liquidator Teneo, who seek to recoup billions of dollars for creditors. Zhu is seeking to recover $1.3 billion from him and fellow founder Kyle Davies, who are accused of failing to cooperate with the probe. The questioning is a civil matter, and details will be shared with creditors to maximize recoveries. Zhu has previously denied cooperating with liquidators, claiming they have obtained "baseless" court orders.

images.alt_text: Zhu Su (above) and Davies are among the onetime darlings of crypto’s pandemic-era bull run whose reputations subsequently suffered as boom turned to bust, exposing risky practices.

site_title: SGX appoints CFO Ng Yao Loong as co-head of equities
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) appoints CFO Ng Yao Loong as co-head of equities, effective mid-2024. He will work alongside Janice Kan, with Ng continuing as CFO until the transition. The appointment aims to provide dedicated leadership in developing the securities market. SGX revamped its management structure in September, with Michael Syn becoming president and head of global markets. A search for a new CFO is underway.

site_title: The magical solutions floating out of Dubai won’t fix the climate crisis
summary: Dubai's COP28 climate conference failed to deliver significant action on climate change, with voluntary commitments from fossil fuel companies and nations falling short of needed emissions reductions. The US proposal to build on existing voluntary carbon market standards was seen as undermining the UN's efforts to solidify an internationally regulated carbon market. Despite some hopeful announcements, including new US regulations on methane and plans to create a fund for vulnerable nations, the conference's proposals were deemed too little, too late. Experts warn that the climate crisis is already being felt, with Earth's average temperature rising to 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

images.alt_text: The proposed deal would specifically call for “transitioning away from fossil fuels in energy systems, in a just, orderly and equitable manner ... so as to achieve net zero by 2050 in keeping with the science.”

“While the pledges are positive steps forward in tackling the energy sector’s greenhouse gas emissions, they would not be nearly enough to move the world onto a path to reaching international climate targets, in particular the goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 deg C,” says the International Energy Agency.

site_title: Putting on a good show, from concerts to conventions
summary: The Ebenex Group, a Singapore-based events solutions company, aims to list on the Singapore Exchange by 2028. Founded by David Ebenezer Toh in 2003 as a second-hand musical instrument shop, the group has diversified into various businesses, including concert amplifiers, audio-visual production, venue management, and content creation. Following the COVID-19 pandemic, Toh pivoted the company into virtual events, which became a lucrative segment. The group has made several acquisitions and investments to expand its offerings, including a majority stake in DJ equipment rental business Dangerfreq and a strategic investment in Indonesian LED lighting display supplier Caiyida. Toh plans to expand the company's reach in Malaysia and Southeast Asia, with a goal of listing on the Singapore Exchange by 2028 and reaching $150 million in overall revenue.

images.alt_text: Music has been part of the group’s DNA since it was founded in 2005 at The Substation Garden, said Timbre Group founder and chief executive officer Danny Loong.

David Ebenezer Toh after a sharing session on his company’s Roxy Rockstars programme at Fairfield Methodist School's Education and Career Guidance talk. Some Secondary 3 and 4 students expressed interesting in joining Roxy Rockstars after their O-levels, as the programme is open to 17- to 35-year-olds.

site_title: Google, Meta, Qualcomm team up to push for open digital ecosystems
summary: Google, Meta, Qualcomm, and seven other tech companies formed the Coalition for Open Digital Ecosystems (CODE) to promote open platforms and systems in Europe. The group aims to boost growth and innovation by implementing the Digital Markets Act (DMA) and future EU regulatory framework developments. CODE will work with academics, policymakers, and companies to achieve digital openness, with a focus on cross-industry collaboration and interoperable systems. The move may counter possible future legislation and address EU tech rules.

images.alt_text: EU countries and lawmakers are close to clinching a provisional deal on rules governing the use of artificial intelligence, people with direct knowledge of the discussions said on Friday.
The AI Act would not apply to free and open-source licences unless, for example, they were deemed high-risk or being used for already banned purposes.
BEUC says it is likely that Meta users’ data would continue to be collected and used for other purposes even if they select the new service.

site_title: German government to keep debt brake in 2024 budget
summary: Germany's government has agreed to keep the "debt brake" in its 2024 budget, a constitutional court ruling that forced Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government to suspend it for the 2023 budget. The decision comes after a month of negotiations between coalition parties, which had been at odds over the budget plan. The government will not declare an emergency situation to suspend rules on net new borrowing, and the budget deal is expected to ease tensions within the alliance.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz speaks, as he receives relatives of members of the German Armed Forces and police officers on foreign missions, in Berlin, Germany December 11, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse
A rise in ZEW economic sentiment index to 12.8 points in December from 9.8 points in November.
In November, 49.1 per cent of developers say they are suffering from a lack of new orders, up from 48.7 per cent in the previous month.
Production declines 0.4 per cent from September, led by the machinery and equipment sector,.
The failure of talks between coalition leaders before Wednesday means it is unlikely parliament will approve a 2024 budget by the end of the year.
Exports to EU countries shrink by 2.7 per cent in October, according to federal statistics office.

site_title: Indonesian presidential hopeful Ganjar projects grassroots appeal as popularity slips
summary: Indonesian presidential hopeful Ganjar Pranowo faces an uphill battle ahead of February's election, slipping in popularity as defense minister and former general Prabowo Subianto commands a 20-point lead. Ganjar is focusing on a grassroots campaign to boost his prospects, using social media to emphasize his common man appeal. He has pledged to create 17 million new jobs, expand social welfare, and strengthen anti-corruption efforts if elected. Despite being a long-time member of the ruling Democratic Party of Struggle, Ganjar's popularity has been hurt by President Jokowi's perceived switch to Prabowo as his running mate.

images.alt_text: Indonesia officially starts the 75-day campaign period for next year’s presidential election.

Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto and former provincial governor Ganjar Pranowo, will consider ending state-run Perusahaan Listrik Negara’s (top) monopoly in order to allow renewable power producers to sell directly to customers.

site_title: Crypto and ketamine: the murder that shocked South Korea
summary: A South Korean man, Lee Kyung Woo, was sentenced to life in prison for kidnapping and murdering a woman over a cryptocurrency dispute. The victim, a 48-year-old woman, was abducted, drugged, and killed with ketamine from her wife's plastic surgery clinic. Lee claimed to be a former undercover agent for missions in North Korea and was paid 70 million won to carry out the crime. The victim's son, who believed his mother died from COVID-19, will likely experience lifelong loneliness and loss.

images.alt_text: Both Seoul and Washington are seeking the cryptocurrency entrepreneur's extradition.
(From left) Changpeng ‘CZ’ Zhao; Sam Bankman-Fried; Do Kwon.
South Korea has long been known for its strong blockchain and crypto community.
Daniel Shin was charged by South Korean prosecutors in April.
Retail investors are restricted to larger coins like Bitcoin and Ether that feature in at least two acceptable, investible indexes.
Gemini on Monday said Singapore will be its hub for the Asia-Pacific region and announced plans to boost headcount in the city-state to more than 100 in the next 12 months.
The sentence follows a court hearing last week at which Do Kwon drops his request for checking authenticity of the Costa Rican passports after Interpol’s confirmation they are fake.

site_title: ADB cuts Asean growth forecasts for 2023, 2024 on lacklustre manufacturing
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has cut its growth forecasts for South-east Asia and developing Asia, citing a lacklustre manufacturing sector and weaker external demand. For 2023, the ADB now expects a 4.3% GDP growth in South-east Asia, down from its September forecast of 4.6%. In 2024, growth is anticipated to pick up to 4.7%, but remains a downward revision from previous forecasts. Thailand's growth forecast was cut to 2.5% due to weaker merchandise exports, while Vietnam's forecast remained unchanged at 6% despite a slower-than-expected economy.

images.alt_text: Contractions of manufactured export growth hurt major exporting economies in South-east Asia.
Inflation in developing Asia was forecast to ease to 3.5 per cent this year.

site_title: Agritech startup Vegrow raises US$46 million in Series C round led by GIC
summary: Vegrow, an India-based agritech startup, has secured US$46 million in a Series C funding round led by GIC, marking the sovereign wealth fund's first investment in the Indian agritech and B2B space. Existing investors also participated in the round. The funds will be used to expand Vegrow's reach in India and strengthen its global network. The company has achieved operational profitability with a fivefold increase in revenue in the past year, leveraging technology to match demand and supply in India's fruits segment.

site_title: Big bet on a return to the office in central London
summary: The City of London Corp has approved 10 new office towers, including one exceeding the height of all others in the area, with over 10 million sq ft of office space under construction and another 5 million sq ft in the pipeline. Despite a 9.5% office vacancy rate, developers face a "favourable environment" due to economic challenges and demand for "best in class" offices. The district aims to entice workers and visitors back with art galleries, historical sites, and leisure activities, and officials are loosening rules to convert older buildings into venues for culture and hospitality.

images.alt_text: It could be argued that the future skyline is at least a step towards order, moving on from the visual anarchy of recent years when towers cropped up along the Thames without any apparent visual coherence or care.

site_title: Bank watchdog keeps rule that’s slowing Canada’s mortgage market
summary: Canada's banking regulator has maintained the qualifying stress test for mortgage borrowers, keeping pressure on the nation's prospective home buyers. The test, which requires borrowers to prove they can handle payments on loans with rates of 8% or more, will remain in place. Despite rising mortgage rates, Canada's housing market has seen relatively little financial distress among borrowers. The stress test has been credited by regulators as a key factor in maintaining the resilience of Canada's financial system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A for sale sign is displayed outside a home in Toronto, Ontario in Toronto, Ontario, Canada December 13, 2021. REUTERS/Carlos Osorio/File Photo

site_title: When political protesters target the falafel
summary: Pro-Palestinian protesters targeted a Philadelphia falafel restaurant, Goldie, for its owners' donations to an Israeli medical non-profit organization. The incident drew condemnation from Pennsylvania's governor and the White House. The restaurant serves as a de facto town square, allowing patrons to express their opinions and ignite social change through food. This practice, seen in various protests and boycotts throughout US history, highlights the role of restaurants as cultural barometers for social change and cultural understanding. The incident is part of a broader trend of chefs and restaurants using their platforms to bring politics into their businesses.

images.alt_text: The Egyptian McDonald's October and November sales fell by at least 70 per cent compared to the same months last year.

site_title: Weak economy casts shadow over Indonesia’s election season: World Bank
summary: The World Bank warns that Indonesia's economy is expected to grow 4.9% in 2024, down from 5% this year, due to a slowdown in trade and lower commodity prices. The economy faces downside risks, mainly due to global factors, including high US interest rates and the Middle East geopolitical crisis. Indonesia's current account deficit has increased to $900 million, mainly due to declining commodity prices. Inflation is expected to decrease, while foreign direct investment remains a steady source of external financing.

images.alt_text: Sea is likely to register lower earnings as Shopee is expected to suffer greater losses in the intensified e-commerce competition.

site_title: China official vows to prevent collective defaults of developers
summary: China's Vice Minister of Housing and Urban-Rural Development, Dong Jianguo, pledged to prevent a collective default of property developers by "forcefully preventing them from defaulting on their debts all at once." Regulators will support financially sound builders and help them solve short-term cash problems. Dong differentiated between insolvent and sound developers, stating that those violating regulations should be liquidated. This comes as China faces a severe housing slowdown and a liquidity crisis, with dozens of developers missing debt payments since a crackdown on excess leverage.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This aerial photo taken on October 10, 2023 shows buildings of China's developer Country Garden Holdings in Zhenjiang, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. Shares in heavily indebted Chinese developer Country Garden soared more than 17 percent on November 23, 2023, as signs emerge that Chinese officials are planning more concrete support for the troubled sector. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Thai minimum wage hike will ‘not be a disaster’ for businesses: PM
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin defended a minimum wage hike, stating it won't be a disaster for businesses. A 2.37% increase to 330-370 baht per day was agreed upon by a wage committee, but the PM deemed it too low. The government has already reduced electricity and energy prices to support businesses. A larger hike is proposed this month, and the PM believes the wage increase will have a positive effect if done properly, allowing Thais to have work with dignity.

images.alt_text: The central bank will next review policy rates on Feb 7, when most economists expect no policy change.

site_title: Thailand inflation to gradually speed up to within targeted range: central bank
summary: Thailand's inflation is forecast to gradually speed up to within its targeted range of 1-3% by the end of 2024, according to the Bank of Thailand. The central bank expects inflation to be 1.3% this year, with 2024 inflation projected at 2.0%, despite government subsidies. The bank targets a low inflation rate, citing structural impediments to the country's economic recovery. The central bank will review policy rates on February 7, with most economists expecting no change.

images.alt_text: The measures will be aimed at helping about 10.3 million people struggling to service debt, says Thailand Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin.
The value of Thai investments in foreign capital markets reached US$106 billion in 2022, according to Bank of Thailand statistics.

site_title: 🐶 How much it costs to be a pawrent
summary: In Singapore, the number of dogs licensed by the Animal and Veterinary Service grew by 25% from 2019 to 2022, with owners willing to splurge on their pets. The cost of owning a pet can range from buying a small dog (S$4,500) to adopting a pet (S$250 for a kitten), with medical costs including sterilization (S$170-S$450 for cats, S$400-S$900 for dogs). Recurring costs include food (S$80-S$250 per month), grooming (S$40-S$170), and training (S$450-S$1,000). The biggest commitment, however, is time, with pet owners dedicating hours to care for their pets.

site_title: UK builders going rogue but fewer offenders caught
summary: The UK's planning system is under scrutiny as rogue builders continue to evade regulations, with fewer cases being brought to justice. Despite a 50% drop in average new cases since 2010, local authorities have struggled to enforce planning conditions due to underfunding and staff shortages. The number of people killed in construction-related incidents rose to 45 in 2022-23, highlighting the risks of lack of enforcement. The government's plans to introduce a new permitted development right have raised concerns that enforcement is becoming less of a priority, with critics arguing that this approach prioritizes delivery over integrity.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

Scaffolders work on a building site in The City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. Average earnings excluding bonuses rose 7.3% in the year through June, only slightly less than the 7.9% rate of consumer-price inflation, Bloomberg Economics predicts ahead of official labor market data due to be published on Aug. 15. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
Persimmon, along with several British homebuilders, are dishing out incentives in a desperate attempt to jumpstart demand as high interest rates bump up home loan costs and dent sales.

site_title: ASML, Samsung to invest one trillion won on research plant in South Korea
summary: ASML and Samsung Electronics will invest one trillion won (S$1 billion) in a South Korean plant to develop cutting-edge semiconductor processing technology using next-generation extreme ultraviolet equipment. The plant, expected to expand ASML's presence in Korea, follows a diplomatic exchange between Korea and the Netherlands. The deal aims to enhance geographic diversity and counter a trade war between the US and China. Additionally, the countries announced plans to establish the "Korea-Netherlands Advanced Semiconductor Academy" to provide education opportunities for Korean semiconductor-related students and workers.

site_title: London hedge fund Aspect Capital explores fund business in China: sources
summary: London-based hedge fund Aspect Capital is set to apply to establish a Shanghai office and offer its products in mainland China, a move amid efforts by China to lure foreign investment. The fund, overseeing over $8 billion in assets, aims to tap into China's increasing demand for alternative assets. Aspect Capital's move comes as some global investors still see potential in China's market, despite economic and geopolitical challenges. The fund plans to register as a wholly foreign-owned enterprise (WFOE), joining other foreign institutions like Blackrock and Blackstone.

images.alt_text: Beijing is on target to meet its conservative annual growth target of about 5 per cent this year.
China will implement a proactive fiscal policy and a prudent monetary policy in 2024.

China’s securities regulators publish draft rules that would require a qualified investor in PE and VC funds to put up at least three million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold in an effort to protect small investors.
China's consumer price index, the main gauge of inflation, fell 0.5 per cent year-on-year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: The world’s copper supply is suddenly looking scarce
summary: A forecast surplus of copper in 2024 has suddenly disappeared due to operational setbacks and supply disruptions. One of the world's biggest copper mines, Cobre Panama, was ordered to close in Panama amid protests, while Anglo American reduced its copper production target by 200,000 tonnes. This sudden removal of 600,000 tonnes of expected supply is expected to move the market from a surplus to balance or even a deficit, with analysts warning of a tight market and potential price increases.

images.alt_text: Metals demand in the biggest commodities consumer has been helped by booming consumption in new-energy sectors from electric vehicles to solar power.

site_title: UK economy shrinks, testing BOE’s resolve on rates
summary: The UK economy shrank by 0.3% in October, its first decline since July, raising concerns of a recession and testing the Bank of England's resolve to keep interest rates high. The decline was led by the services sector, while manufacturing and construction also contracted. The move has sparked bets on the Bank of England cutting interest rates in June 2024, but the central bank is expected to keep rates at 5.25% and signal no near-term rate cuts. The economic contraction has raised concerns about Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's target to boost economic growth before a national election in 2025.

images.alt_text: A handout photograph released by the UK Parliament shows Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaking during Prime Minister's Questions (PMQs), in the House of Commons, in London, on November 29, 2023. (Photo by Jessica TAYLOR / UK PARLIAMENT / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - NO USE FOR ENTERTAINMENT, SATIRICAL, ADVERTISING PURPOSES - MANDATORY CREDIT " AFP PHOTO / Jessica TAYLOR / UK Parliament"
Including bonuses, which are typically volatile, pay growth slows to 7.2 per cent from 8.0 per cent in the three months to September.
British factories raised output at three times the pace of growth in orders in the final three months of 2023, Make UK said.
FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England (BoE) building, the BoE confirmed to raise interest rates to 1.75%, in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska//File Photo
Inflation expectations in five to 10 years’ time pick up to 3.5 per cent in October from 3.3 per cent in September.

site_title: Maybank turns positive on Malaysian glove stocks
summary: Maybank Securities has upgraded its glove sector rating to "positive" from "negative" due to improving sales volumes and stabilizing raw material prices. Analyst Wong Wei Sum expects plant utilization rates to increase, leading to lower production costs. The research house has raised its ratings for Hartalega and Kossan Rubber Industries to "buy" calls, while maintaining a "hold" rating on Top Glove. Maybank has also raised its price targets for Hartalega and Kossan Rubber. The upgrade is considered a "contrarian rating" due to the competitive landscape.

images.alt_text: Apart from Supermax, a number of other Malaysian glove makers like Smart Glove, Brightway Group and YTY Group have also had run-ins with the US CBP.
UOB Kay Hian says sector valuations are currently trading close to one standard deviation above the mean to “merely recovering” 2024 earnings estimates.

Malaysian companies, including some of the world’s major suppliers of palm oil and medical gloves, have come under increased scrutiny over suspected abuse of foreign workers, a significant part of the country’s manufacturing workforce.

site_title: China policymakers visit Hong Kong to boost finance hub
summary: China's financial policymakers visited Hong Kong to boost its status as a hub for investments, deals, and talent. The meeting with bankers aims to enhance Hong Kong's position as an international finance center, address risks and challenges, and strengthen ties with mainland China. Hong Kong faces challenges, including a brain drain, dwindling dealmaking, and a struggling economy, with major banks cutting staffing and smaller brokers shutting down. China's top leaders have pledged to support Hong Kong's unique status and strengths, and the city's leader has defended his focus on national security amid the challenges.

images.alt_text: Sunday’s voting day stretched to midnight, after a rare 90-minute extension was granted following a failure in the digital system used to confirm voters’ eligibility.
In terms of investment volumes, Singapore has recorded US$7.53 billion so far this year, while Hong Kong’s total is US$5.27 billion.
Hong Kong’s property market continues to slump as rates rise and capital flees in search of safer investments like fixed deposits.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after US inflation data as Fed decision looms
summary: Asia's stock markets were mixed on Wednesday, with Tokyo, Sydney, Wellington, and Taipei rising, but Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Manila, and Jakarta falling. The US inflation report showed consumer prices slowed marginally, tempering expectations for an interest rate cut early next year. However, core prices remained resilient, and traders now expect the Federal Reserve to cut rates by less than previously thought, with the first cut potentially coming later in 2024. The Fed's decision is expected to be announced later in the day, with its statement and comments from Jerome Powell to be closely watched.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares are largely flat on Wednesday morning.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday; STI dips 0.02%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.02% down at 3,101.8, following a mixed global market. Losers slightly outnumbered gainers 48 to 47, with 54.9 million securities changing hands. Quantum Healthcare and ESR-Logos Real Estate Investment Trust were the most actively traded counters, while Thai Beverage shed 1% in early trade. The local banks were trading mixed, with DBS rising 0.4% and OCBC slipping 0.1%.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering expects the proposed acquisition to be cash flow positive from the first year post completion.

site_title: IMF board clears first review of Bangladesh’s US$4.7 billion bailout
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) cleared Bangladesh's first review of its $4.7 billion bailout, providing $689.8 million in funding to address high inflation and economic challenges. The IMF recommended tightening monetary policy, supporting neutral fiscal policy, and increasing exchange rate flexibility to restore near-term macroeconomic stability. The country is battling rising living costs and violent protests ahead of national elections in January. The IMF projects 6% real GDP growth in 2024 and expects inflation to moderate to 7.25% by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: The Stockholm-based company tells its garment providers in Bangladesh that it will absorb the increase of wages in its product prices.

Garment workers and activists take part in a protest in Dhaka on November 7, 2023. Police fired tear gas at thousands of workers who set a bus on fire outside Bangladesh's capital on November 7, with tensions are rising ahead of a new minimum wage announcement for millions of garment labourers. (Photo by Munir uz ZAMAN / AFP)

Bangladesh’s US$416-billion economy has recently struggled to pay for imported fuel as its US dollar reserves have shrunk by more than a third due to costly imports following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: UN General Assembly overwhelmingly demands Gaza ceasefire
summary: The UN General Assembly overwhelmingly passed a non-binding resolution demanding a ceasefire in Gaza, with 153 countries voting in favour and 10, including the US and Israel, voting against. The resolution, which was passed after the Security Council failed to make a similar call, demands an immediate humanitarian ceasefire and the protection of civilians. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned of a looming "complete breakdown of public order" in the besieged Gaza Strip, while the US ambassador to the UN said the resolution was a "despicable sign of double standards."

images.alt_text: Both sides blame each other for breaking the truce.
Israel believes Hamas’ top leadership is hiding in southern Gaza.

Never before in the period after World War II has the world seen so many conflicts, with 55 now active, including a war between rival military factions in Sudan and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the United Nations notes.

United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says: "The situation is fast deteriorating into a catastrophe with potentially irreversible implications for Palestinians as a whole and for peace and security in the region."

Research by law professors Robert Jackson Jr from New York University and Joshua Mitts of Columbia University found significant short-selling of shares leading up to the attacks, which triggered a war nearly two months old.

site_title: China shows off homegrown C919 jet in Hong Kong
summary: China's domestically produced C919 passenger jet made its overseas debut at Hong Kong International Airport on December 13, 2023. The aircraft, developed by the state-owned Commercial Aircraft Corp of China (COMAC), is designed to compete with Western rivals like the Boeing 737 MAX and Airbus A320. The C919 has received official certification to fly but has yet to secure international buyers, despite China's investment in the project. The jet will make a flyover over Hong Kong's Victoria Harbour on Saturday, showcasing its capabilities to international media and guests.

images.alt_text: Boeing is willing to “actively deepen cooperation with China, work together to promote the development of the aviation industry, according to
Thai Airways is boosting its requirements to as many as 80 Boeing wide-body 787 Dreamliner jets.
Global airlines are forecast to reach  a record revenue of almost US$1 trillion in 2024.
Tourists check in at the new Siem Reap-Angkor International Airport in Siem Reap, Cambodia, Nov 15, 2023.
If their merger goes through, JetBlue would become the fifth-largest airline in the country and further reduce competition in the industry.

site_title: Business confidence up among Japan’s big manufacturers: BOJ tankan
summary: Business confidence among Japan's largest manufacturers rose to a reading of plus 12, up from plus 9 three months earlier, according to the Bank of Japan's Tankan survey. This marks the third straight quarter of improvement, with optimism also growing among non-manufacturers. The increase is attributed to the materials sector benefiting from price revisions and lower crude oil futures, as well as the ongoing weakness of the yen benefiting exporters. The survey's results beat market expectations and are seen as key data affecting the central bank's policy decisions.

images.alt_text: Corporate restructuring is gathering pace in Japan, with large companies spinning off non-essential operations while small-to-mid sized business owners confront succession planning.
The Japanese government plans to offer tax incentives for a decade to boost mass production in five areas including  semiconductor devices manufacturing.
Producer price growth stayed below the most recent consumer inflation reading for a third month.
The US dollar’s rise against the yen has helped push the USdollar US index, which tracks the currency against six peers, up 0.16 per cent to 104.13.
FILE PHOTO: People walk at a crossing in Shibuya shopping area, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, in Tokyo, Japan August 7, 2021. REUTERS/Androniki Christodoulou/File Photo

site_title: Gold flat as investors gear up for US Fed verdict
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,980.58 per ounce as investors await the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and policy outlook on Wednesday. The Fed is expected to leave interest rates unchanged, with a 75% chance of a rate cut in May. Gold tends to benefit when interest rates fall, reducing the opportunity cost of holding bullion. The Fed's decision will be released later in the day, followed by a press conference by Chair Jerome Powell.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates tend to support non-interest-bearing bullion.

site_title: Economists cut Singapore’s 2024 growth forecast to 2.3%, maintain 2023 projection at 1%: survey
summary: Economists have lowered their forecast for Singapore's 2024 growth to 2.3%, down from 2.5% in the previous quarter's survey. Inflation is expected to rise to 3.4% for headline inflation and 3% for core inflation in 2024. The growth outlook remains cautious due to a still uncertain global economic environment. Despite this, some economists believe that manufacturing and non-oil domestic exports (NODX) readings may improve, leading to a gradual and fragile upturn. Monetary policy is expected to remain unchanged in January's policy meeting, but some respondents anticipate potential policy tweaks later in the year.

images.alt_text: For the full year, the most likely outcome is for the economy to grow between 0 per cent and 0.9 per cent.
EnterpriseSG expects trade performance to xxx in 2024.
MTI narrowed its full-year outlook to “around 1 per cent”, the midpoint of its earlier forecast range, due to “subdued external demand”.
The economy has expanded by 1.1 per cent year on year in the third quarter of this year, faster than the 0.5 per cent clocked in Q2.
Decline in Singapore key exports continues to ease in October, with narrowing 3.4% fall

site_title: SpaceX value jumps closer to US$180 billion in tender offer
summary: SpaceX's value is estimated to jump closer to $180 billion with a tender offer to sell insider shares at $97 apiece. The company, led by Elon Musk, has seen strong investor demand for a stake in its dominant space transportation company and fast-growing Starlink internet service. SpaceX has notched a record 90 successful rocket launches this year and has become a valuable launch provider for the US government and NASA. The tender offer could range from $500 million to $750 million, and terms and size may change.

images.alt_text: The launch comes on the heels of North Korea placing its first spy satellite into orbit last month, allowing Kim Jong Un’s regime to keep an eye on US troop movements in the region.

Starship is key to Musk’s ambitions of carrying payloads and people to distant destinations such as the moon and Mars.
SpaceX’s current valuation of about US$150 billion makes it one of the most valuable private companies in the world.

site_title: Developing Asia to end 2023 on brighter note as China’s economy recovers: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has raised its 2023 growth forecast for developing Asia to 4.9% due to a recovery in China's economy, which is expected to grow 5.2% this year. This marks a brighter note for the region, with inflation forecast to ease to 3.5% in 2023. The ADB maintains its growth forecast for developing Asia at 4.8% for next year, despite ongoing economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Amro expects Asean+3 to grow by 4.3 per cent this year and at 4.5 per cent in 2024.
Morgan Stanley is optimistic about India's growth and project a medium-term growth rate of 6.5 per cent.
Asia has struggled to ramp up production this year amid patchy demand from economies including the US, Europe and China.

site_title: China puts focus on industrial policy, skips big demand stimulus
summary: China's top leaders, including President Xi Jinping, have pledged to prioritize industrial policy and technological innovation in 2024, aiming to boost economic growth. Despite a sluggish domestic demand, the country is on track to meet its conservative annual growth target of 5% this year. The meeting emphasized the need for structural reforms over cyclical measures to revive the economy, and officials vowed to support companies in producing higher-value products. However, economists warn that this approach may not be enough to stimulate growth, and some see a need for more aggressive policies, including monetary easing, to offset deflation.

images.alt_text: China will implement a proactive fiscal policy and a prudent monetary policy in 2024.

China’s securities regulators publish draft rules that would require a qualified investor in PE and VC funds to put up at least three million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold in an effort to protect small investors.
China's consumer price index, the main gauge of inflation, fell 0.5 per cent year-on-year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: TikTok shop wants to beat Amazon at its own game
summary: TikTok has launched its US e-commerce platform, TikTok Shop, aiming to compete with Amazon by offering a unique shopping experience. The platform has attracted 150 million US users, with the average user spending 33 hours a month on the site. TikTok has subsidized discounts and shipping for merchants, generating significant sales, including a record $10,000 in sales on Cyber Monday. However, Amazon remains dominant, with 173 million US Prime subscribers and a loyal customer base. To compete, TikTok must persuade more merchants to sign up and keep them engaged, while avoiding alienating users who primarily use the platform for entertainment.

images.alt_text: Sea is likely to register lower earnings as Shopee is expected to suffer greater losses in the intensified e-commerce competition.
Shopping features within the TikTok app in Indonesia will be operated and maintained by the enlarged Tokopedia entity.
Indonesia in October banned online shopping on social media platforms to protect smaller merchants and users’ data, after which TikTok had to close its e-commerce service TikTok Shop.

site_title: Proposed COP28 climate deal calls for ‘transitioning away from fossil fuels’
summary: A proposed COP28 climate deal calls for transitioning away from fossil fuels in energy systems to achieve net zero by 2050, a first in three decades of climate summits. The draft, reflecting the consensus view of nearly 200 countries, aims to transition away from fossil fuels in a just, orderly, and equitable manner. It also calls for tripling renewable energy capacity globally by 2030 and accelerating technologies to reduce coal. However, the deal does not commit rich countries to offer more financing to help developing countries transition away from fossil fuels, and faces opposition from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec).

images.alt_text: Delegates meet on the day of COP28 draft deal negotiations, during the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP28) in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, December 12, 2023.REUTERS/Thaier Al-Sudani

site_title: Australia government sees budget almost in balance for 2023/24
summary: Australia's Labor government projects a budget deficit of A$1.1 billion for the 2023/24 fiscal year, down from A$13.9 billion forecasted in May. This improvement is attributed to higher revenues, particularly from the mining sector, and lower-than-expected prices for iron ore. The government aims to control inflation, which currently stands at 5.4%, and has resisted calls for more cost-of-living handouts. Economic growth is expected to slow to 1.75% this year, before picking up to 2.25% in the following year.

images.alt_text: The Australian government is greatly expanding the RBA’s regulatory power over the payments system, particularly for mobile wallet services offered by the likes of Apple and Google.
Australian consumers have been much more downbeat than business this year, as high inflation and rising borrowing costs ate into spending power.

The surge in migration has helped fuel Australia’s growing housing crisis, which has seen rents grow at their fastest rates in decades and worsened the cost-of-living crunch for a nation already struggling with stubbornly high inflation.

Foreign investment charges for the purchase of established homes will triple, Treasurer Jim Chalmers says. Penalties for buyers from overseas who leave their properties vacant will double while application fees for investment in build-to-rent projects will be reduced.

site_title: Snapchat+ users rise to seven million in sign of demand for its new AI features
summary: Snapchat has reached 7 million subscribers for its premium service, Snapchat+, which offers early or exclusive access to features, including AI tools. The service, launched in July 2022, has seen a significant increase in users, with a 40% rise from 5 million in September. The company aims for 10 million users in the medium term and expects revenue from subscribers to help offset development costs. With a monthly fee of $3.99, Snapchat+ generates over $330 million annually, according to Bloomberg estimates.

images.alt_text: People will be able to link their Snapchat and Amazon accounts to take advantage of the in-app shopping feature, according to Amazon.

The court decision covers hundreds of lawsuits filed on behalf of individual children who allegedly suffered negative physical, mental and emotional health effects from social media use including anxiety, depression, and occasionally suicide.

site_title: Banks raise credit card rates, fees to keep up with higher-rate environment
summary: Major banks in Singapore have raised credit card interest rates and fees in response to the higher interest rate environment. HSBC, DBS, OCBC, UOB, Citibank, Maybank, and StanChart have all increased their rates, with HSBC raising interest rates to 27.8% and cash advance fees to 8% or S$15, whichever is higher. The moves come as the US Federal Reserve hikes interest rates to combat inflation, with the Fed expected to hold rates steady at its next meeting.

images.alt_text: Local consumers largely rely on credit and debit cards, which make up around 57 per cent of electronic payments.
2023’s Financial Wellness Index score fell to 60 points – the lowest since the inception of the index in 2019, OCBC said.
