The banking disruptions have so far been restricted to traditional banks. And experts believe digital banks should be more resilient to outages due to fundamental differences in the way their systems are set up.

site_title: Sweden posts sharp home-price plunge as borrowing costs soar
summary: Sweden's real estate market has experienced a sharp 11% drop in home prices year-over-year in the 12 months leading up to September, the largest decline globally among 56 markets tracked by Knight Frank. This decline is attributed to higher interest rates and a recession affecting households with floating mortgage rates. In contrast, global home prices rose 3.5% on average, with some countries experiencing higher price increases due to housing shortages. Experts expect lower interest rates to lift sales activity, but global sales volume remains low due to postponed purchases and cancellations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past apartment blocks in Stockholm April 8, 2014.  Picture taken April 8, 2014. REUTERS/Ints Kalnins/File Photo
Sweden's GDP shrinks 0.3 per cent in third quarter after 0.8 per cent drop in second.

site_title: Japan plans tax breaks for 10 years to boost EV, chip production: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government plans to offer 10-year tax incentives for mass production in five areas, including electric vehicle and semiconductor devices manufacturing. The tax breaks will include 400,000 yen for each EV, 30 yen per liter of sustainable aviation fuel, and 20,000 yen for each tonne of green steel. Businesses in semiconductor production will receive up to a 20% corporate income tax break, while others will receive a 40% cap. The move aims to boost domestic production and reduce reliance on imports.

site_title: Myanmar overtakes Afghanistan as world’s top opium producer
summary: Myanmar has surpassed Afghanistan as the world's top opium producer, according to a United Nations report. Opium production increased by 36% to 1,080 metric tonnes, with 47,000 hectares of land under poppy cultivation, a 18% rise from last year. This surge in production is attributed to worsening stability and security in the country since the military takeover in 2021. Afghanistan saw a 95% drop in opium production due to the Taliban's ban, potentially boosting the regime's efforts to gain international recognition. The opium economy is estimated to be worth $1 billion to $2.5 billion annually.

images.alt_text: People are seen at a market after army seized power in a coup in Yangon, Myanmar February 2, 2021. REUTERS/Stringer

Laos Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Saleumxay Kommasith (left) shares about the country’s plans for its upcoming Asean chairmanship year, and participated in a question-and-answer segment moderated by Choi Shing Kwok, director and chief executive officer of Iseas-Yusof Ishak Institute.
Myanmar central bank will allow banks and dealers to decide exchange rates themselves.

site_title: US FTC finalises car-buying rules to rein in junk fees, bait-and-switch
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has finalized rules to rein in "junk fees" and bait-and-switch tactics in car buying, requiring upfront pricing and banning misrepresentations about prices and costs. The new rule aims to protect consumers from deceptive practices that cost them $3.4 billion annually. Dealers will no longer be allowed to charge for useless add-ons or lie to consumers about financing information. The rule is expected to fundamentally change the car-buying process, with some industry groups criticizing it as "heavy-handed bureaucratic overreach."

images.alt_text: Passenger vehicle sales in China are projected to rise by 3.1 per cent to 26.8 million units next year, slowing from a 10.3 per cent increase this year, according to CAAM estimates.
Employees at SK On EV battery factory in Seosan, South Korea, Oct 19, 2023. South Korean battery makers say that global automakers are now pressuring them to develop LFP batteries.
Huawei, the target of US sanctions since 2019, hopes the presence of foreign investors would help defend the business from potential further geopolitical tensions
Singapore stands as Vietnam’s largest foreign investor for the third straight year, accounting for almost a quarter of total foreign capital investment in 2022, writes BT journalist Goh Ruoxue.
Five out of six panellists felt the time was ripe to review and change the system, given that the technology to control usage has matured.

An electric rickshaw driver charges up at a Mahindra showroom in Darbhanga, India. Of all the changes the world is making to slow global warming, electric vehicle sales are the only category on track to meet climate goals.
Are AI-powered drive-thrus the labour-saving solution for the F&B industry?

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, StarHub, Sembcorp, Mapletree Logistics Trust
summary: ST Engineering is acquiring cryptographic technology company D'Crypt from StarHub's indirect subsidiary for S$67.5 million, plus a S$5 million earn-out consideration. Sembcorp Industries has won a 117 megawatt-peak project to "solarise" vacant land and rooftops on Jurong Island, while Mapletree Logistics Trust is acquiring a Grade A warehouse in India for S$14.5 million. These developments may impact trading of ST Engineering, StarHub, Sembcorp, and Mapletree Logistics Trust.

site_title: Let locals ride on Changi Airport’s success with a Changi Airport retail Reit
summary: A potential retail Reit by Changi Airport Group could be well-received by investors, leveraging the airport's strong retail offering and growing passenger traffic. The Reit would benefit from increasing demand for air travel, with Changi Airport handling 15.3 million passengers in the third quarter of 2023, up 52% from the same period in 2022. The trust could also capitalize on the airport's expansion plans, including the upcoming Terminal 5, and its unique retail and F&B offerings, such as Jewel Changi Airport.

images.alt_text: The departure hall at Changi Airport Terminal 2 northern wing.

site_title: Biden warns Netanyahu risks losing support for Hamas war
summary: US President Joe Biden warned Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that his "indiscriminate" bombing of Gaza risks losing global support, as over 18,400 people, mostly women and children, have been killed in the conflict since October 7. Biden urged Netanyahu to change his stance on a two-state solution for Palestinians, which he said the current government is making difficult for him to move. Netanyahu responded with a "disagreement" over post-conflict governance, reflecting a rare rift between the allies.

images.alt_text: Never before in the period after World War II has the world seen so many conflicts, with 55 now active, including a war between rival military factions in Sudan and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the United Nations notes.

United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says: "The situation is fast deteriorating into a catastrophe with potentially irreversible implications for Palestinians as a whole and for peace and security in the region."

The remains of houses destroyed during fighting with Hamas militants in Kibbutz Be'eri, Israel, on Sunday, Oct. 22, 2023. Be’eri is one of a dozen communities around the Gaza Strip, along with several military bases, that fell prey to the shock invasion by Hamas — which is designated a terrorist organization by the US and European Union - on Oct. 7. Photographer: Kobi Wolf/Bloomberg
The UN General Assembly, which includes all 193 member nations, voted 153 in favour of the resolution.

site_title: ST Engineering to acquire D’Crypt from StarHub unit for at least S$67.5 million
summary: ST Engineering agreed to acquire D'Crypt from an indirect subsidiary of StarHub for at least S$67.5 million, aligning with its cyber business growth strategy. The deal, expected to be cash flow positive from the first year, will allow StarHub to optimize its resources and execute its 3C strategy. D'Crypt specializes in cryptographic technology design and offers solutions in encrypted communications, secure computing, and high-performance computing. The acquisition is expected to be earnings accretive by the second year post-completion.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering's order book as at end-September stands at S$27.5 billion.
Excluding Dare+ provisions, non-operating items and its corresponding tax effects, StarHub's net profit after tax would have fallen by 34.6 per cent to S$53.2 million in the second half of the year.
Can telcos do more than sit on their assets?

site_title: S&P gives Tether poor marks in new stablecoin scale
summary: S&P Global has given Tether and Dai, two of the world's top stablecoins, near-bottom marks of 4 in its new risk assessment scale. Tether's low score reflects a lack of information about its reserve assets and significant exposure to riskier assets. TrueUSD was graded a "weak" 5 due to a lack of information on its reserve assets. The ratings highlight weaknesses in areas such as regulation, governance, and transparency, underscoring the need for greater oversight in the stablecoin market.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins are seen as a bridge between highly volatile cryptocurrencies and fiat currency, which is the government-issued money that we use in everyday transactions.
Paxos is also looking to partner with enterprise clients to issue the USD-backed stablecoin in Singapore once it receives full approval from the regulator.
Circle has raised money from investors including Goldman Sachs Group, General Catalyst Partners, BlackRock, Fidelity Management and Research and Marshall Wace.

site_title: US seizes crypto linked to South-east Asian investment scam
summary: US authorities have seized approximately $500,000 in cryptocurrency linked to a South-east Asian investment scam known as "pig butchering," according to a recent court filing. The scam, which involved manipulating unsuspecting people into investing in bogus crypto schemes, was allegedly orchestrated by Chinese businessman Wang Yicheng. The seized funds were traced to Wang's account, which received over $90 million since its opening in 2020. The US Secret Service said the account was used for laundering stolen funds.

images.alt_text: The top 10 hacks have netted criminals almost 70 per cent of all stolen funds this year.
Justin Sun is also linked to the Poloniex exchange and the HECO Bridge, a network set up by HTX to enable transfers between blockchains.

site_title: US House committee urges ‘reset’ on China economic ties
summary: A bipartisan US House committee has called for a "reset" of Washington's economic ties with China, citing concerns over Beijing's trade practices and human rights abuses. The 53-page report recommends moving China to a new tariff classification, renewing the "China Safeguard mechanism" to impose tariffs without proof, and conducting a stress test of US banks in case of a potential conflict. The proposals aim to boost economic resilience and ensure "American leadership for decades to come."

images.alt_text: Beijing is on target to meet its conservative annual growth target of about 5 per cent this year.

(FILES) This aerial photo taken on October 10, 2023 shows buildings of China's developer Country Garden Holdings in Zhenjiang, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. Shares in heavily indebted Chinese developer Country Garden soared more than 17 percent on November 23, 2023, as signs emerge that Chinese officials are planning more concrete support for the troubled sector. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
The measures come as China’s top leaders last week pledged to stimulate domestic demand and stabilise foreign trade and capital.
Companies such as Intel, Micron, GlobalFoundries are among those seeking significant funding from the chip programme.
Huawei has outlined plans for the factory with an initial investment of 200 million euros (S$289 million) in 2020, but the roll-out was delayed by the Covid-19 pandemic.
Vietnam is estimated to hold the world’s second-largest deposits of strategic minerals which are at the moment crucial for electric vehicles and wind turbines.

site_title: Climate negotiators eye fossil fuel compromise in marathon talks
summary: Climate negotiators at the COP28 conference in Dubai are nearing a deal after marathon talks, with nearly 200 countries debating a historic phase-out of fossil fuels. A draft deal, which was initially rejected, has been revised to include a "should" instead of "could" for reducing fossil fuel consumption and production, with a goal of transitioning away from fossil fuels in the next decade to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Western negotiators are open to compromise language, but Saudi-led oil producers remain opposed to the idea of a phase-out.

images.alt_text: Climate activists pushing for an end to fossil fuels at the COP 28 climate summit. Negotiators from nearly 200 countries at the summit are attempting to agree on a deal to limit climate change.
Climate activists at a protest against fossil fuels at Dubai's Expo City during the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Dec 12, 2023.

With hours to go until the Dubai summit officially ends, US climate envoy John Kerry told ministers that this was “the last COP that we’ll have a chance to be able to keep 1.5 deg C alive. This is it.”
Activists protesting against fossil fuel at COP28 on Dec 4; a coalition of more than 100 countries want an agreement that includes language to phase out fossil fuels.
Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said Singapore will not claim from the fund despite investing heavily in coastal protection measures.

Permanent Secretary of the Ministry for Sustainability and the Environment Stanley Loh and Vice Minister of Strategic Affairs of the Ministry of
Environment and Energy Carlos Isaac Pérez signed a Memorandum of
Understanding between Singapore and Costa Rica to collaborate on carbon credits under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement on the sidelines of COP28.

The conference has yielded a slew of commitments from countries to hit targets like tripling renewable energy and nuclear power deployments, slash coal use, and curb emissions of the powerful greenhouse gas methane.

“While the pledges are positive steps forward in tackling the energy sector’s greenhouse gas emissions, they would not be nearly enough to move the world onto a path to reaching international climate targets, in particular the goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 deg C,” says the International Energy Agency.

site_title: WeWork strikes new agreement at New York City office tower in quest for viability
summary: WeWork has reached a new agreement with its landlord at 1440 Broadway in New York City, maintaining a 300,000-square-foot space spanning 10 floors. The deal includes reduced rent and a shortened lease term, as the company navigates bankruptcy. WeWork has cancelled around 70 leases and expects to request more, but the agreement allows the company to maintain a foothold in the heart of Times Square. The court will still need to approve the agreement.

images.alt_text: A WeWork co-working office space in New York, US, on Tuesday, Nov. 7, 2023. WeWork Inc. filed for bankruptcy, capping a tumultuous period that saw the once high-flying startup navigate a failed initial public offering, Covid-19 lockdowns, a blank-check merger and slow return-to-office trends. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

site_title: Elon Musk’s X 2023 ad sales projected to slump to about US$2.5 billion
summary: Elon Musk's X, formerly Twitter, is expected to generate around $2.5 billion in ad revenue in 2023, a significant decline from previous years. This represents a 70-75% reliance on advertising, down from over $1 billion per quarter in 2022. The company's ad sales have been impacted by Musk's handling of content moderation, with some advertisers pulling out due to concerns over antisemitic and extremist content. Musk had originally targeted $3 billion in revenue but will fall short, citing incomplete information from sources.

images.alt_text: X, formerly known as Twitter, risks  losing as much US$75 million in advertising revenue by the end of the year as major brands pause their marketing campaigns on the platform, according to the New York Times.

Elon Musk has faced a torrent of criticism since he on Nov 15 agreed with a user who falsely claimed Jewish people were stoking hatred against white people, saying the user who referenced the “Great Replacement” conspiracy theory was speaking “the actual truth.”
Internal documents show that the company is in a more difficult position than previously known and that concerns about Musk and the platform have spread far beyond companies.

site_title: US doubts performance, yield of Huawei’s advanced chip
summary: The US Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) expresses doubts about Huawei's ability to produce a 7-nanometre chip at the required performance threshold, citing concerns about the chip's performance and yield. This comes as the Biden administration tightens export controls on advanced semiconductor chips and equipment to China. BIS Assistant Secretary Thea Kendler stated that the chip's performance is "poorer" than what Huawei had in the past, and export controls are meant to slow China's acquisition of advanced technology.

images.alt_text: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo is under increasing pressure to act from Republicans who say that the SMIC chip demonstrates a clear violation of US sanctions against Huawei.
Huawei has outlined plans for the factory with an initial investment of 200 million euros (S$289 million) in 2020, but the roll-out was delayed by the Covid-19 pandemic.
Huawei, the target of US sanctions since 2019, hopes the presence of foreign investors would help defend the business from potential further geopolitical tensions
The 7-nanometre processor was designed by Huawei and produced by Semiconductor Manufacturing International.

site_title: Apple tightens passcode security on iPhones to thwart thieves
summary: Apple has released iOS 17.3 with a new Stolen Device Protection feature, requiring Face ID or Touch ID for accessing stored passwords, changing Apple ID settings, and disabling Find My iPhone. This enhancement aims to prevent thieves from gaining access to critical device data by knowing a user's passcode. The feature will add a one-hour delay and require a second scan for sensitive tasks, and will be available publicly early next year. This move is intended to thwart thieves who can steal devices by observing users inputting their passcodes in public.

site_title: Oil falls more than 3% on softening demand, oversupply concerns
summary: Oil prices fell over 3% on Tuesday, reaching their lowest level in six months, due to concerns about oversupply and softening demand. The US consumer price index unexpectedly rose in November, bolstering the view that the Federal Reserve may not cut interest rates early next year, which could slow economic growth and impact oil demand. Global oil demand growth is expected to slow in 2024, with Opec and the International Energy Agency split on the extent.

images.alt_text: Climate activists pushing for an end to fossil fuels at the COP 28 climate summit. Negotiators from nearly 200 countries at the summit are attempting to agree on a deal to limit climate change.
Brent crude futures settled up 19 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to US$76.03 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled up 9 cents, or 0.1 per cent, at US$71.32 on Monday.

site_title: Pfizer gets OK for US$43 billion Seagen deal after donating cancer drug rights
summary: Pfizer has received regulatory approvals to close its $43 billion deal to buy Seagen, a US-based cancer therapy company. To address US antitrust concerns, Pfizer will donate the royalty rights from sales of its cancer drug Bavencio, which generated $271 million in 2022. The deal includes Pfizer creating a separate cancer drugs operation and splitting its commercial business into two divisions. Key executives, including Angela Hwang and Aamir Malik, will step down, and Alexandre de Germay will become commercial chief for the international unit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Test tubes are seen in front of a displayed AstraZeneca logo in this illustration taken, May 21, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: China says it will step up policy adjustments to spur recovery in 2024
summary: China's top leaders have agreed to step up policy adjustments in 2024 to spur economic recovery, with a focus on boosting effective demand and expanding domestic demand. The country will implement a proactive fiscal policy and a prudent monetary policy, with the aim of achieving reasonable economic growth of around 5% next year. Authorities will also strengthen counter-cyclical and cross-cyclical macro policy adjustments to overcome challenges such as insufficient demand, overcapacity, and weak public expectations.

images.alt_text: China’s securities regulators publish draft rules that would require a qualified investor in PE and VC funds to put up at least three million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold in an effort to protect small investors.
China's consumer price index, the main gauge of inflation, fell 0.5 per cent year-on-year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.
Bai Yunxi, 33, a full-time astrologer, laughs during an interview with Reuters in Dali, Yunnan province, China, Nov 10, 2023.
China will continue to implement a prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy in 2024, state media reported the Politburo as saying.

site_title: Google’s Epic legal defeat threatens US$200 billion app store industry
summary: Google's loss in a US$200 billion app store industry case against Epic Games may accelerate the weakening of app store rules. A San Francisco jury found Google had acted unfairly as a monopoly, forcing developers to use its billing system and offering custom agreements. The verdict could lead to changes in the marketplace, with big tech companies making accommodations for developers to avoid legal exposure. The case may also influence Apple, which has already made adjustments to its policies. The ruling has the potential to shift the industry towards a more open environment, rather than closed app store ecosystems.

images.alt_text: Jurors found for Epic on all counts, after more than a month of trial in Epic’s lawsuit, which accused Google of taking action to quash competitors and charge unduly high fees of up to 30 per cent to app developers.

(FILES) This illustration photograph taken on October 30, 2023 in Mulhouse, eastern France, shows figurines next to a screen displaying a logo of Google, a US multinational technology company. The Canadian government and Google announced on November 29, 2023 a "historic" deal to support the country's media, heading off an imminent threat by the digital giant to block news on its platform. (Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)

According to the deal, Canadian news will continue to be shared on Google’s platforms in return for the company making annual payments to Canadian news companies in the range of C$100 million (S$98 million).

site_title: Sembcorp unit bags 117 MWp solar project by JTC
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit has won a 117 MWp solar project on Jurong Island, the largest public sector project by capacity in Singapore. The project will increase the island's solar generation capacity to 142.2 MWp, reducing 63,220 tonnes of carbon emissions annually. The project also involves a virtual power plant and will support solar deployment demand from 12 Jurong Island companies, expanding solar adoption on the island.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries, IHI Corporation and GE Vernova’s gas power business are exploring the potential retrofitting of Sembcorp’s Sakra power plant in Singapore with ammonia-firing capabilities.
Sembcorp may find it tough to stop buying renewable capacity
Maybank estimates Sembcorp's new contract in the Middle East to be S$400 million.

site_title: Europe: France, Germany shares hit record highs, but give up gains after US CPI data
summary: Europe's stock markets saw record highs for France and Germany, but ultimately ended the day flat as traders reassessed interest rate expectations following the US consumer prices report. France's CAC-40 index hit a record high, while Germany's DAX touched a record high before closing. Despite some gains, the pan-European Stoxx 600 slipped 0.2% as traders pulled back bets on interest rate cuts. Central banks are expected to remind markets they could still hike rates if needed, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.5 per cent higher at 36,577.94 on Tuesday.

site_title: Global shipping industry braces for lower consumer spending, higher carbon taxes
summary: The global shipping industry is bracing for lower consumer spending and higher carbon taxes in 2024, which could cut into profits. Continued slow demand and excess supply are expected to be major challenges. Industry observers say adverse macroeconomic conditions, including reduced consumer spending and high interest rates, will keep demand low. The Baltic and International Maritime Council (Bimco) predicts a weakening trend in the industry, which began in 2022, to continue in 2024 and 2025.

images.alt_text: Maersk expects to save US$600 million through the job cost measures.
Five to 10 per cent of the fuel demand for shipping in 2030 would amount to about 5.3 million metric tons of hydrogen, 29.8 million metric tons of ammonia, or 28.1 million metric tons of methanol.
Ships passing through the drought-stricken Panama Canal are facing long waits, surcharges, and time and fuel-consuming detours around South America to avoid the delays.

Rodolphe Saade, chief executive officer of CMA CGM , says: "The difficulty in our sector is that we have a number of container ships that will come into the market starting next year and that runs the risk of creating an imbalance between supply and demand."

site_title: Yellen sees inflation gradually heading back to Fed’s 2% target
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that inflation is "certainly meaningfully coming down" and sees no reason why it shouldn't gradually decline to the Federal Reserve's 2% goal. Despite recent data showing slight increases in US consumer prices, Yellen believes the "last mile" to achieving the target won't be difficult. The Fed is expected to hold interest rates steady in its upcoming meeting, with Chair Jerome Powell pushing back against rate cut predictions.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks during a press conference in Mexico City, Mexico, Nov 6, 2023.

Many economists believe that the US non-inflationary growth rate is about 1.8 per cent annually, but Janet Yellen has argued that federal investments in infrastructure, semiconductors and clean energy technology are raising its productive capacity.

site_title: Netflix posts viewer data on every show, film for first time
summary: Netflix has released global mid-year viewer data for every title on its service, the first of regular reports, following a months-long fight with Hollywood labour unions. The most-watched title globally was "The Night Agent," with 812.1 million hours of viewing, followed by "Ginny & Georgia" and "The Glory." This disclosure aims to address "mistrust over time" with creatives and follows increased transparency demands after two strikes. The data covers over 18,000 titles, including popular shows and films, and will be published semiannually.

images.alt_text: Netflix’s ad revenue will likely jump 50.3 per cent to about US$1 billion next year.
'Leave the World Behind' has also drawn the attention of Elon Musk for a scene featuring self-driving Teslas in a multicar pileup.
The tennis face-off between Nadal (pictured) and Alcaraz will stream as a dual broadcast in English and Spanish. Tickets for the event start at US$88 and will go on sale on Friday.

site_title: English Premier League clubs agree five-year limit on transfer fee amortisation
summary: Premier League clubs have agreed to limit the amortisation period of player transfer fees to five years, aligning with UEFA regulations. This change, effective for new or extended contracts, aims to bring the Premier League in line with UEFA's rules. The decision follows concerns over clubs exploiting amortisation to circumvent Financial Fair Play regulations, with Chelsea previously signing players on long-term contracts to spread transfer fees. The rule change will not apply to existing contracts, and the Premier League Board will have the authority to stop a club from registering new players if they owe a transfer debt.

images.alt_text: 24 of the 36 clubs in the top two divisions of German football vote in favour of the plan to secure private equity investment, enough to give the proposal the necessary two-thirds majority.
Everton's Abdoulaye Doucoure (left) celebrates after scoring against Newcastle in a 3-0 win on Dec 7, 2023.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq subdued at open after inflation data
summary: US stocks opened subdued on Tuesday, December 12, amid cautious investor sentiment ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 37.17 points, or 0.10%, to 36,442.10. The latest inflation reading cemented expectations that interest rates have peaked, leading investors to remain cautious.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to acquire India warehouse for 900 million rupees
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is set to acquire a Grade A warehouse in Farukhnagar, Delhi, India, for 900 million rupees (S$14.5 million). The acquisition, expected to be completed in Q4 FY2024, will be 100% funded by debt and is projected to be distribution-per-unit accretive on a historical pro-forma basis. The warehouse features a 12-meter floor-to-ceiling height and is fully leased to one of India's largest third-party logistics players with an eight-year remaining lease. The deal is expected to expand MLT's India assets under management and increase gross revenue from the country.

images.alt_text: After the divestments, MLT’s portfolio will consist of 185 properties.
Generic scenes as seen from level 17 of the Mapletree Business City located on Pasir Panjang Road.
Mapletree Logistics Trust expects expects to divest S$500 million in assets in the coming years.
Gross revenue for the quarter rose 1.5 per cent to S$186.7 million, while net property income gained 1.2 per cent to S$162 million.

site_title: Foxconn to invest additional 139.11 billion rupees in India's Karnataka state
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract manufacturer, plans to invest an additional 139.11 billion rupees (S$2.2 billion) in India's Karnataka state. The Taiwan-based company is diversifying production away from China due to Covid-19 disruptions and geopolitical tensions. The investment will support the production of casing components for iPhones and chip-making equipment, with the goal of creating around 50,000 jobs by April 2024. This marks the company's continued expansion in India, following an initial investment of US$600 million in August.

site_title: Crypto ‘comeback’? This time it’s not different
summary: The crypto industry is experiencing a resurgence, with Bitcoin reaching a 20-month high of over $44,000 in December and Ethereum rising to above $2,200. The Federal Reserve's end to interest rate hikes and possible spot Bitcoin ETF approval are contributing to the market's recovery. Investors, who have been holding on since the last bubble, are optimistic that prices will continue to rise, despite past crashes. However, the industry's maturity is still questionable, with concerns about volatility and the potential for another bubble.

images.alt_text: The District Court judge in Seattle agrees with the Justice Department that Zhao has not convinced the court he is unlikely to flee if allowed to return to the UAE.
Bitcoin has been on a tear this year on expectations that regulators will allow the first US spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds, widening the potential base of crypto investors.
Cryptocurrencies stage a recovery this year after a torrid 2022 in which a market meltdown and a string of scandals.

site_title: UK PM Rishi Sunak faces tough economy going into election year
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faces a tough economy heading into the election year, with his party trailing behind Labour in polls. Despite tax giveaways, Sunak's Conservative government is 19 points behind Labour, with the negative poll gap fluctuating around 20% for over a year. The UK is expected to narrowly avoid a recession next year, with inflation expected to decline to around 4% by mid-year, but the pound sterling could still plunge 10% or more if a recession occurs, according to ING's base case scenario.

images.alt_text: Consumers expect prices to rise by 3.3 per cent over the next 12 months, according BOE survey.

Just over a year since he became UK prime minister, Rishi Sunak is struggling to maintain his authority, as politicians on both the left and the right of his Conservative Party are threatening to vote against his flagship asylum policy.

site_title: Boustead Projects venture inks deal for Vietnam industrial property company
summary: KBIL, a joint-venture company of Boustead Projects, has entered a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire Minh Quang Industrial Development Joint Stock Company for US$10.7 million. The acquisition aims to develop the leased land into industrial facilities for lease, adding to KBIL's portfolio. The deal is funded by KBIL issuing equity to Boustead Projects and Khai Toan Joint Stock Company. The proposed acquisition is not expected to impact Boustead Projects' earnings per share or net tangible assets for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: The results translate to earnings per share at S$0.056, up 19 per cent from S$0.047 in the previous H1 period.
Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore.

site_title: Breitling buys watchmaker Universal Geneve in first major deal
summary: Breitling has acquired Swiss luxury watchmaker Universal Geneve in its first major deal, marking a turning point for the company. The acquisition, valued at approximately 60 million Swiss francs, will give Breitling its second major brand. Universal Geneve, founded in 1894, will be revived under Breitling's CEO Georges Kern, with plans to bring back classic models and hire a team of designers and executives to run the brand as a separate entity. The first watches could come to market by 2026, priced above Breitling's average price of 6,700 Swiss francs.

images.alt_text: George Kern, CEO Breitling

site_title: Hackers stole about US$1.7 billion this year from crypto projects
summary: Hackers have stolen approximately US$1.7 billion from crypto projects this year, a decline of about half from 2022's US$4 billion. Infrastructure attacks, such as private-key theft, accounted for nearly 60% of the total stolen funds. Despite potential additional hacks in December, this year is likely to finish with significantly lower totals. Experts attribute the decline to improved security measures and increased law enforcement actions, which are critical for the growth of the crypto ecosystem.

site_title: JPMorgan client’s US$50 million battle is instructive for the legions of ageing baby boomers
summary: JPMorgan has filed a counterclaim in a lawsuit against the Doelgers, accusing them of having no merit and seeking unspecified damages. The couple, who had entrusted JPMorgan with managing their $50 million portfolio, claim the bank failed to detect Peter's cognitive decline, leading to a significant wealth wipeout. The Doelgers' case highlights the issue of detecting cognitive decline in elderly investors, with a study suggesting that households of accredited investors over 80 years old typically score worse than unaccredited investors. JPMorgan maintains it has policies and procedures for protecting vulnerable clients and disputes the allegations, with a court-ordered exam declaring Peter unable to testify in the litigation.

images.alt_text: The US Virgin Islands says the enormous sum that propped up Epstein’s sex trafficking bolsters key allegations in its suit that JPMorgan knowingly benefited from the financier’s wrongdoing and ignored red flags.

site_title: US consumer prices rise in November
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in November, exceeding expectations, as underlying inflation increased. The 12-month increase in the consumer price index (CPI) rose to 3.1%, with core CPI increasing 4.0% on a year-over-year basis. The strong employment report last week, which showed job gains accelerated and the unemployment rate fell, led financial markets to push back expectations of an interest rate cut. The Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged, with officials guiding that rate cuts are not yet being considered.

images.alt_text: Employment gains are well above the 100,000 jobs per month needed to keep up with growth in the working age population.

site_title: AstraZeneca buys respiratory vaccine developer Icosavax in US$1.1 billion deal
summary: AstraZeneca agreed to buy US-based respiratory vaccine developer Icosavax in a deal valued at up to $1.1 billion, bolstering its pipeline with a combination vaccine targeting RSV and human metapneumovirus. The upfront payment represents a 43% premium to Icosavax's last close, and the deal aims to target the multi-billion RSV market. The acquisition will add to AstraZeneca's existing RSV portfolio and compete with existing vaccines from GSK and Pfizer.

images.alt_text: Astra is testing a separate experimental compound that’s a long-acting analogue to a hormone called amylin.

site_title: US: Stocks extend rally, reach highest level since early 2022
summary: US stocks extended their rally, reaching their highest level since early 2022, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.5% higher at 36,577.94. The S&P 500 advanced 0.5% to 4,643.70, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 0.7% to 14,533.40. The rally came despite mixed inflation data, with core inflation holding steady and analysts hoping for a more decisive report. Individual companies such as Ford and Boeing also saw gains, while Hasbro and Oracle fell after announcing job cuts and revenue misses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A street sign for Wall Street is seen in the financial district in New York, U.S., November 8, 2021.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: US dollar pares losses as consumer prices rise in November
summary: The US dollar partially recovered from losses after data showed US consumer prices rose 0.1% in November, beating expectations. This rise in inflation, at an annual pace of 3.1%, was in line with forecasts. The dollar initially fell 0.14% before bouncing back. Meanwhile, the euro rose 0.18% and the Japanese yen dipped 0.4% due to volatility in the yen market. Markets expect substantial rate cuts from central banks next year, with a 50% chance of the first Federal Reserve rate cut in March.

site_title: India’s inflation accelerates, fuelled by rising food prices
summary: India's inflation accelerated to 8.7% in November, driven by rising food prices, surpassing the central bank's 4% target. Food inflation rose to 8.7% from 6.61% in October, with prices of vegetables such as onions and tomatoes surging due to monsoon-related shortages. The Reserve Bank of India is likely to keep interest rates higher for longer to curb inflation. Industrial production data showed growth accelerated to 11.7% in October, while the government restricts food exports to rein in price pressures ahead of the 2024 election.

site_title: Zara regrets campaign ‘misunderstanding’ after Gaza boycott calls
summary: Zara withdrew its ad campaign featuring statues wrapped in white, sparking calls for a boycott after some pro-Palestinian activists claimed the images resembled photos of corpses in Gaza. The campaign, meant to showcase unfinished sculptures, was removed after tens of thousands of complaints on Instagram. Zara apologized for the "misunderstanding" and stated it had no intention to offend. The incident highlights the challenges global brands face in navigating sensitivities around the Gaza war.

images.alt_text: The White House will be open to heightening the standard for initial asylum screenings, according to a Reuters source.

Research by law professors Robert Jackson Jr from New York University and Joshua Mitts of Columbia University found significant short-selling of shares leading up to the attacks, which triggered a war nearly two months old.
Both sides blame each other for breaking the truce.
Israel believes Hamas’ top leadership is hiding in southern Gaza.
The Egyptian McDonald's October and November sales fell by at least 70 per cent compared to the same months last year.

site_title: China pledges fresh support for property market
summary: China's top decision-makers pledged to support the country's struggling real estate market, aiming to "actively yet safely defuse risks" and meet the financing needs of real estate enterprises. The move comes as the sector faces a deep debt crisis, with some developers owing hundreds of billions of dollars and facing potential liquidation. China's economy is battling headwinds, but officials acknowledged that "favourable conditions outweigh unfavourable factors" in the development, with a target growth rate of around 5% this year.

images.alt_text: China will implement a proactive fiscal policy and a prudent monetary policy in 2024.

site_title: The board’s key priorities for sustainability
summary: Boards of directors play a crucial role in guiding companies towards sustainability, with key priorities including ensuring competencies for the board and senior management, appointing a chief sustainability officer (CSO), and putting in place an appropriate sustainability governance structure. Boards must review their corporate governance structure to address sustainability in an integrated manner and assess material sustainability-related factors, including climate change, labor practices, and environmental issues. Effective integration of ESG into the business requires consideration of material ESG factors in business plans, risk management, and policies. Investors must scrutinize the true sustainability credentials of boards and senior management.

site_title: South-east Asia and Singapore score wins despite fresh tussle in UN climate talks
summary: Singapore and South-east Asia scored wins at COP28, with Singapore leading the way for early phase-out of coal plants in the region. The 28th UN climate change conference concluded with the go-ahead for a loss-and-damage fund, a long-fought finance facility for developing countries. However, the event was marred by criticism over the draft of the Global Stocktake report, which some deemed inadequate. Despite this, COP28 president Sultan Al Jaber expressed confidence in the progress made, calling it "unprecedented."

images.alt_text: MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 12)
summary: Singapore's National Climate Change Secretariat aims to complete a playbook for countries to increase their use of existing carbon-crediting programmes by mid-2024. The playbook is being developed in collaboration with Gold Standard and Verra's Verified Carbon Standard Program, a global verification programme. This move is part of efforts to develop best practices for carbon-crediting, which can help countries meet their climate change goals.

site_title: JIC-led group is frontrunner for Shinko Electric stake: sources
summary: A consortium led by Japan Investment Corp (JIC) is in advanced discussions to acquire Fujitsu's 50% stake in Shinko Electric Industries, a chip packaging unit. The JIC-led group plans to make an offer for the remaining shares and delist the company. Shinko Electric could be valued at over 800 billion yen (S$7.4 billion), representing a 12% premium based on the stock price.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi has set up a team to explore the possibility of entering the so-called back-end manufacturing process, which involves mounting chips on frames, connecting wires and packaging.

site_title: Bill Gates’ Breakthrough Energy backs startup that uses liquid tin to store energy
summary: Bill Gates' Breakthrough Energy Ventures backs startup Fourth Power, which uses liquid tin to store energy generated by renewables as heat for hours to days. This technology could help solve intermittency issues with renewables and is up to 10 times cheaper than other approaches. Fourth Power plans to build a prototype facility that can store 1 megawatt-hour of energy, enough to power 1,000 homes, with possible completion in 2026. Breakthrough Energy has also backed other startups in the thermal energy storage industry to help emerging firms scale and advance low-cost utility-scale renewable grid.

site_title: A small but welcome step in prying Open AI’s black box
summary: The European Union has agreed on a comprehensive AI legislation, the AI Act, which will require companies to share details about their training data, including "general purpose" AI systems like ChatGPT. The law, set to come into force in 2025, will also force companies to report on security risks, energy demands, and audit themselves. However, critics argue the draft legislation is too vague, leaving room for companies to hide key data points. The move aims to address biased data and improve transparency in AI development, but experts call for more specifics to effectively regulate the industry.

images.alt_text: The AI Act would not apply to free and open-source licences unless, for example, they were deemed high-risk or being used for already banned purposes.
AIs are manipulating humanity. And they’re about to wield even more unimaginably vast power to manipulate our unconscious.

site_title: UK lenders face smaller impact from Basel rules than rivals, says BOE
summary: The Bank of England published its first "near final" policy statement on implementing the Basel rules, stating that UK lenders will face a 3% increase in capital requirements, significantly less than their European Union and US peers. The rules, introduced after the 2007-09 financial crisis, aim to strengthen banks' capital buffers to mitigate future crises. The UK's tweaks to the original proposals followed a public consultation, and the final policy statement will be published in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England (BoE) building, the BoE confirmed to raise interest rates to 1.75%, in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska//File Photo

site_title: UK pay growth slows but BOE seen sticking to line on rates
summary: The UK's wage growth slowed to 7.2% in the three months to October, down from 7.8% in the previous period, but remains high, fueling concerns the Bank of England will stick to its tight stance on interest rates. Economists see this as a sign of easing wage pressure, but annual growth remains above the 2% inflation target, leading the BOE to maintain its "high-for-longer" message. Sterling weakened, and British government bond yields fell sharply after the data.

images.alt_text: A handout photograph released by the UK Parliament shows Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaking during Prime Minister's Questions (PMQs), in the House of Commons, in London, on November 29, 2023. site_title: UK mortgage lending falls sharply as arrears increase: BOE
summary: UK mortgage lending fell sharply in the third quarter, with lenders making commitments on £51.5 billion (S$86.7 billion) of mortgages, a 16.5% decrease from the previous quarter and 41.4% from a year ago. Arrears increased 11.4% on the previous quarter to £18.8 billion, the highest level since 2015. The Bank of England's interest rate hikes appear to be slowing the housing market, but house prices remain resilient, with lending to first-time buyers increasing to 25.8% of gross advances.

images.alt_text: UK households are facing pressures on multiple fronts, triggered by pricey mortgage rates and the worst cost-of-living crisis in a generation.
Prices of prime country properties–those in the top 5 per cent of the market–are forecast to end the year down 7 per cent, according to broker Knight Frank.
UK households have been under pressure this year from mortgage rates that reached 14-year highs and stubbornly high inflation.

Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
The S&P Global/CIPS UK construction Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) edges down to 45.5 from October’s reading of 45.6, well below the 50.0 growth threshold.
The ONS household cost index shows the average mortgage borrower having a 9.3 per cent personal rate of inflation, far above the headline 6.7 per cent consumer prices index for September.

site_title: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire almost halves stake in PC maker HP
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, has cut its stake in PC maker HP by half, from 97.85 million shares to 51.5 million shares, or 5.2% of the company, as of November 30. This marks the second consecutive quarter Berkshire is expected to be a seller in HP.

site_title: As market cycles shorten, scenario modelling is key to action and profits: Mercer chief strategist
summary: Mercer's chief investment strategist Rich Nuzum warns that the window to invest profitably in a crisis has shortened to just days, citing examples of the Covid-19 drawdown and the US gilts crisis. Clients are preparing for five potential "shock" scenarios, including a Magnificent 7 stock crash, a Middle East conflict, and a cyberattack. Meanwhile, a weaker Chinese economy presents opportunities for investors, particularly non-American investors in China. Nuzum advises retail investors to diversify into alternative investments, such as private debt, and to consider hedging via stakes in innovative private companies.

images.alt_text: China’s securities regulators publish draft rules that would require a qualified investor in PE and VC funds to put up at least three million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold in an effort to protect small investors.
Corporate restructuring is gathering pace in Japan, with large companies spinning off non-essential operations while small-to-mid sized business owners confront succession planning.

Over the past five years, investors in energy transition have suffered a performance gap of 11.9 percentage points a year when cash inflows and outflows are taken into account, compared to a buy-and-hold strategy.

site_title: COP28 heads for overtime as countries wrangle over fossil fuels
summary: COP28 climate summit negotiations are nearing overtime as countries struggle to agree on a deal to limit climate change. A draft proposal was criticized for omitting a "phase-out" of fossil fuels, with many countries demanding a stronger commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The UAE's COP28 presidency aims for a "historic" result, but negotiators from nearly 200 countries are still far from reaching a consensus, with some countries opposing the mention of fossil fuels altogether. The summit's end deadline looms, and tensions remain high as countries try to agree on a plan of action to avert disastrous climate change consequences.

images.alt_text: Climate activists at a protest against fossil fuels at Dubai's Expo City during the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Dec 12, 2023.

site_title: Large IPOs seen to make comeback in Jakarta after February polls
summary: Indonesia is poised to resume large IPOs in 2024 after the February presidential election, with mid-to-large sized deals expected to raise funds for companies in the retail and consumer sectors. The country's Financial Services Authority has set a conservative fundraising goal of $15 billion to $20 billion. Outgoing President Joko Widodo's policies have also encouraged renewable energy and electric vehicle companies to raise funds domestically. Several companies, including state-backed palm oil firm PalmCo and Pertamina Hulu Energi, are expected to list in Jakarta in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing is a key driver of the Indonesian economy and its growth is supported by strong domestic demand, said Amalia Adininggar Widyasanti, the acting head of Statistics Indonesia.
From January to October this year, Indonesia receives 9.49 million foreign visitors, an increase of 124.3 per cent from the same period in 2022.
“AI-based programming activities need to be predicated on the ethics governing its use and development,” according to the draft produced by Indonesia’s communications ministry.

site_title: German investor morale up in December on ECB expectations: ZEW
summary: German investor morale improved in December, with the ZEW economic sentiment index rising to 12.8 points, beating expectations. This marks the fifth consecutive month of increases, indicating respondents expect the economic situation in Germany to improve over the next six months. The assessment of the current situation also rose slightly, despite a budget crisis. The construction industry was particularly optimistic, with expectations of interest rate cuts by the ECB doubling. Analysts see the results as signs of a slightly improving German economy, but note that emerging forces remain weak and fragile.

images.alt_text: In November, 49.1 per cent of developers say they are suffering from a lack of new orders, up from 48.7 per cent in the previous month.
Production declines 0.4 per cent from September, led by the machinery and equipment sector,.
German firms are building supply chains that are independent of China, shifting some operations away from the country and growing markets elsewhere in Asia.
Exports to EU countries shrink by 2.7 per cent in October, according to federal statistics office.
“Employment is now only growing marginally and demand for workers continues to weaken,” says head of Germany’s Federal Labor Agency.

site_title: Myanmar to see growth of just 1% in year to March 2024, says World Bank
summary: Myanmar's economy is expected to grow just 1% in the year to March 2024, according to a World Bank report, due to rising conflict, trade disruptions, and high inflation. The country has seen a "broad-based slowdown" across key sectors since a 2021 military coup, which has led to major upheaval and the displacement of over 2 million people. The economy is 10% smaller than in 2019, and consumer prices have surged by nearly 29% in the past year, particularly affecting the poor.

images.alt_text: A missile fired from a Myanmar military base on Oct 28, 2023. Myanmar has been in crisis since the military launched a coup in 2021 and embarked on a deadly crackdown.

site_title: For investors in 2024: Elections, focus on real returns, tech disruption and sustainability
summary: Key economic indicators for 2024 include a mild US recession, core inflation below 3%, and interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. This is expected to benefit risk assets. Investors should focus on real returns, quality companies, and resilient business models. Technological disruption, including generative AI, is creating opportunities for growth. Sustainability is also a key theme, with 110 countries pledging to treble renewable energy capacity by 2030. Investors should build diversified portfolios with wider sources of income and growth, favoring safe-haven assets, alternatives, and quality growth sectors.

images.alt_text: Attendees inside pollution pods, geodesic domes simulating air pollution levels from Beijing, London and New Delhi, at the Blue Zone on day three of the COP28 climate conference at Expo City in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Saturday, Dec. 2, 2023. More than 70,000 politicians, diplomats, campaigners, financiers and business leaders will fly to Dubai to talk about arresting the world's slide toward environmental catastrophe. Taiwan remains a critical player in advanced semiconductor manufacturing. But the US is also trying to diversify semiconductor production out of Taiwan into the US and other close allies.
Delegates at a panel discussion on the topic of "BRICS Rising Influence in the Multipolar International Order" at the Doha Forum in the Qatari capital on Dec 10, 2023.

site_title: American exceptionalism in 2024
summary: The US presidential election in 2024 will significantly impact the country's approach to the world, with three main camps vying for dominance: liberal internationalists, retrenchers, and America Firsters. American exceptionalism, rooted in the Enlightenment, Puritan roots, and geopolitical advantages, has shaped the country's foreign policy since WWII. The liberal order, created by the US, would look vastly different if Hitler or Stalin had prevailed. The 2024 election will influence ongoing conflicts in Europe, Asia, and the Middle East, with the outcome having far-reaching implications for global power dynamics.

images.alt_text: Republican US presidential candidates such as Vivek Ramaswamy and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis have expressed scepticism and reservations about America's support for Ukraine in Russia's war of aggression.
History shows that globalisation is largely driven by technological changes that reduce the importance of distance, and that will not change.

site_title: Xi vows greater focus on Vietnam as China aims to check US
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has strengthened ties with Vietnam during a two-day visit, signing 37 cooperation deals and pledging to deepen their partnership. The agreements include a memorandum of understanding on cross-border rail development, aimed at boosting trade between the two countries. Xi also emphasized the importance of security, connectivity, and green energy cooperation. The visit comes as China and the US vie for influence in the region, with Vietnam navigating a delicate balancing act between its two major trading partners. The partnership is seen as a triumph of Vietnam's "bamboo diplomacy."

site_title: Tomorrow’s thematic winners
summary: The article discusses the five key themes that are expected to drive secular growth: rising Asia, digital disruption, energy transition, feeding the world, and shifting lifestyles. These themes have sub-themes such as cloud computing, artificial intelligence, clean energy, food tech, and digital health, which are expected to have a significant impact on various industries. Generative AI is expected to be a major driver of change, with the global cloud computing market projected to reach $2.3 trillion by 2032 and the global AI market expected to reach $2.6 trillion by 2032. Thematic investments offer a forward-looking perspective and can provide higher long-term growth opportunities, making them a good satellite to a core portfolio.

site_title: Netflix to squeak past Disney+ in US advertising revenue in 2024: report
summary: Netflix is expected to surpass Disney+ in US advertising revenue in 2024, with ad revenue projected to jump 50.3% to around $1 billion, according to a report. This growth is attributed to Netflix's password-sharing crackdown and price hikes, which have added nearly nine million subscribers in the September quarter. In contrast, Disney+ is expected to post a 16.1% rise in revenue from commercials to around $912 million. The report suggests that Disney may narrow the gap in the future due to the adoption of its ad tier and the combining of Disney+ and Hulu into one app.

images.alt_text: 'Leave the World Behind' has also drawn the attention of Elon Musk for a scene featuring self-driving Teslas in a multicar pileup.
The tennis face-off between Nadal (pictured) and Alcaraz will stream as a dual broadcast in English and Spanish. Tickets for the event start at US$88 and will go on sale on Friday.
After resisting commercials for years, Netflix had a change of heart in April 2022 after it lost subscribers in the first quarter of the year.
Reliance was reported by Bloomberg in October to be valuing Disney’s India assets at between US$7 billion and US$8 billion.
In June, Pixar will release Inside Out 2 in cinemas, a sequel to a 2015 film that grossed US$858.8 million in worldwide ticket sales.
The two-part sixth, and final, season of The Crown that premieres on Netflix on Nov 16, explores Princess Diana’s final days before she perishes in a car accident.
Top Bollywood stars feature in online shows, some of which have faced criticism from lawmakers and the public for scenes deemed vulgar or offensive to religious sentiments.

site_title: Swiss National Bank confronts franc strength for first time since hiking began
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is expected to signal a potential end to its interest rate hikes, which may include toning down its statement on buying the franc, after the currency reached its highest level against the euro since 2015. The SNB's actions could temper the franc's gains, despite borrowing costs remaining unchanged at the central bank's meeting on Thursday. Strategists predict the SNB will take steps to curb the franc's strength, marking the first time since rate hikes began 18 months ago.

images.alt_text: Swiss consumer price growth remains lower than many advanced economies, showcasing how the country’s strong currency has sheltered it from the ravages of inflation elsewhere.

site_title: Barbie pips Oppenheimer to lead in Golden Globe nominations
summary: Barbie, starring Margot Robbie, has topped the list of nominees for the Golden Globe awards with nine nods, surpassing Oppenheimer, which received eight nominations. Barbie will compete for best comedy or musical film alongside American Fiction and The Holdovers, while Oppenheimer is in the running for best movie drama. The nominations reflect increased diversity and inclusion, with two female directors and 60% racial and ethnic diversity among the 300 voting journalist members.

images.alt_text: Barbie has claimed nine nods, including best drama as well as acting nominations for stars Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling.
'Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour' has generated nearly US$250 million.

Katie Boehly, US businessman Todd Boehly, Helen Hoehne, and a guest arrive for the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on Jan 10, 2023. The scandal-hit association of foreign journalists that created the Golden Globes will be wound down as the Hollywood award show is formally purchased by private investors including US billionaire Todd Boehly.

site_title: Love, mystery and danger on the night train, from Tolstoy to Bond
summary: The Berlin-Paris night train, a romance of railways, has returned to Europe after falling out of favor in the early 21st century. The service, which runs three days a week initially, aims to reduce carbon emissions and revive the trend of night trains that inspired writers and filmmakers like Agatha Christie, David Lean, and Alfred Hitchcock. Night trains have long been associated with love, mystery, and danger, offering a unique setting for crime, romance, and intrigue, as noted by author Andrew Martin.

images.alt_text: Amtrak locomotives at Union Station in Washington, DC, Nov 28, 2023. President Joe Biden’s administration unveiled major rail investments on Friday including the United States’ first high-speed train - between Los Angeles and Las Vegas - which it aims to complete by 2028.

site_title: Dubai unveils new investment fund with billions in assets
summary: Dubai has unveiled a new investment fund with billions of dollars in assets, set to invest government money locally and internationally. The Dubai Investment Fund will house assets worth billions of dollars, including stakes in state-owned companies such as Dewa and Dubai Taxi. The fund will focus on sustainable returns and explore prospects in local and international financial markets, with Dubai Deputy Ruler Sheikh Maktoum Mohammed as chairman. This move is part of the government's plan to offer stakes in 10 state-owned companies, and is seen as a way to manage assets responsibly and increase transparency.

images.alt_text: The unrelenting appetite for Middle East listings comes even as regional geopolitical tensions are high and as investors fret about high interest rates, volatility and economic growth.
The IPOs are part of a plan unveiled about two years ago to list 10 state-owned companies in a bid to boost flagging trading volumes and catch up with IPO drives in Abu Dhabi and Riyadh.
