site_title: China venture capital, private equity funds rattled by proposed changes
summary: China's securities regulators have published draft rules requiring a qualified investor in private equity (PE) and venture capital (VC) funds to put up at least 3 million yuan (S$560,989), tripling the current threshold, to protect small investors. Industry players fear the changes could wipe out small funds and choke financing to struggling startups, with some estimating up to 1,000 private fund management firms could be eliminated. The rules aim to protect small investors but venture capitalists warn it could backfire in a tough fundraising environment.

images.alt_text: The CSRC (top) is seeking opinion on the proposal to “reasonably” reduce transaction fees, and plans to strengthen supervision of the distribution of commissions for securities trading of public funds.
China's consumer price index, the main gauge of inflation, fell 0.5 per cent year-on-year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.
Bai Yunxi, 33, a full-time astrologer, laughs during an interview with Reuters in Dali, Yunnan province, China, Nov 10, 2023.
China will continue to implement a prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy in 2024, state media reported the Politburo as saying.

site_title: UK’s once-hot country home market faces a rough post-Covid reality
summary: The UK's high-end country home market, which experienced a pandemic boom, is now facing a slump. Prices of prime country properties are forecast to end the year down 7% according to Knight Frank. Homes are taking longer to sell, with an average of 79 days to sell in the year through November, compared to 55 days across Great Britain. Sellers are struggling to find buyers willing to pay above asking prices, with some clients negotiating discounts of up to 12% off the original price. The slowdown is attributed to rising borrowing costs, economic uncertainty, and negative sentiment ahead of a general election.

images.alt_text: Rightmove said the number of sales agreed so far this year was 13 per cent lower than over the same period last year, adding that this was less of a drop than it had expected, given the very high number of house purchases in early 2022.
A one-hour walk from Rutland Gate, through Hyde Park and the affluent Marylebone district, leads to The Holme, a 40-room mansion in Regent’s Park.

site_title: US expects to make multi-billion chips awards within the next year
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo expects to make around a dozen semiconductor chip funding awards within the next year, including multi-billion dollar announcements that could reshape US chip production. The first award, $35 million to a BAE Systems facility, was announced on Monday. Raimondo anticipates larger, multi-billion dollar awards in the future, with 10-12 total announcements expected.

images.alt_text: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo is under increasing pressure to act from Republicans who say that the SMIC chip demonstrates a clear violation of US sanctions against Huawei.
The 7-nanometre processor was designed by Huawei and produced by Semiconductor Manufacturing International.

site_title: Boeing deepens strategy cuts as operations take center-stage: sources
summary: Boeing is deepening its strategy cuts, halving the number of planners working in key divisions, as it refocuses on tackling industrial pressures. The move comes as the company grapples with supply disruptions and $40 billion in debt from the Covid-19 travel slump and 737 MAX safety crisis. The cuts are expected to impact 200 strategists across the company, with some being told not to return to work. The shift in focus is seen as a response to the changing industry landscape, with Boeing's new CEO, Stephanie Pope, aiming to simplify corporate structure and prioritize operational priorities.

images.alt_text: Stephanie Pope, 51, will step into the newly-created post of Boeing executive vice-president and chief operating officer on Jan 1, reporting to CEO David Calhoun.
Boeing is willing to “actively deepen cooperation with China, work together to promote the development of the aviation industry, according to
Sources say Boeing now expects it will produce 42 of its 737s per month starting in February 2024.
Thai Airways is boosting its requirements to as many as 80 Boeing wide-body 787 Dreamliner jets.

site_title: Former AGV executive director charged with 13 price-rigging offences
summary: Former AGV Group executive director Albert Ang Nam Wah has been charged with 13 price-rigging offences for allegedly conspiring with two others to artificially inflate the company's share prices between November 2017 and February 2018. Ang faces a maximum punishment of a fine of S$250,000 and seven years' imprisonment. He was also the CEO of AGV Group from 2015 to 2020. The case will be heard on January 10, with Ang currently out on S$150,000 bail.

images.alt_text: AGV Group, a provider of hot dip galvanising services, was asked by the bourse operator to disclose the details of alleged mismanagement and wrongdoing.
SGX has reprimanded Albert Ang, former executive director of AGV Group, for a breach of Catalist rules.
Police reports have been filed against individuals from AGV's subsidiaries.
AGV Group independent directors urge company to 'consider facts holistically' after EGM requisitioned to remove them
AGV Group unit receives RM1.6m letter of demand from RHB Bank
AGV flags going concern uncertainty amid Covid impact

site_title: Not all growth is created equal
summary: A company's growth can be detrimental to shareholder value if not managed prudently. Starbucks' aggressive expansion in the 2000s led to internal competition, diminishing returns, and a decline in its unique experience, ultimately resulting in a 54% drop in its stock price in 2008. This serves as a cautionary tale, emphasizing the importance of making smart capital allocation decisions to achieve optimal returns. Warren Buffett's one-dollar test, which evaluates whether retained earnings improve shareholder value, can guide companies in making informed decisions about capital investment.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong has more than doubled its sales and tripled its profits over 10 years. Its stock price has also appreciated by more than three times over the period.

site_title: DPM Wong says rumours of circuit breaker measures and posts of him endorsing products are fake
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has denied circulating online rumors about a potential circuit breaker measure and his endorsement of commercial products. He stated that these claims are "falsehoods" and urged the public to remain vigilant online. This comes as Singapore experiences an increase in Covid-19 cases, with the highest number of infections recorded in 2023.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Health says that the estimated number of local Covid-19 infections in the week of Nov 19 to Nov 25 had doubled to 22,094 from 10,726 in the previous week.
The Health Ministry has reassured people that the numbers are not as high as during the pandemic. ST PHOTO: KELVIN CHNG

site_title: Private credit is attracting record number of Japanese investors
summary: A record 236 Japanese investors have poured money into domestic private credit deals, seeking higher returns of around 10% compared to benchmark Japanese debt yields less than 1%. The surge is driven by potential returns and currency hedging costs that can wipe out income on overseas debt. Private credit in Japan is being used in situations addressing fundamental economic problems, such as corporate restructuring and succession planning, but concerns arise as interest rates are expected to rise next year, making debt repayment harder.

images.alt_text: The latest changes come as Goldman seeks to retain that advantage – and as its rivals scramble to respond to the rise of a new asset class that competes directly with their leveraged finance business.
Higher interest rates bring higher investment yields but place pressure on borrowers. In such circumstances, senior lenders are in a safer position.
The Bank of England's warning comes a week after two senior Democratic senators asked US regulators to deepen their assessment of the risks private credit may pose to the financial system.
Investors need to be sharp-eyed about what private credit managers are doing with their money.

site_title: Climate talks always fail, but they are failing better
summary: The COP28 summit in Dubai failed to achieve significant progress in reducing fossil fuel usage and meeting the goal of net-zero emissions by 2050. Despite a draft text calling for a rapid decline in coal usage and a reduction in all fossil fuels, many countries, including oil exporters, are unlikely to agree to the agreement. The European Union's climate commissioner described the text as "clearly insufficient," and the Marshall Islands called it a "death warrant." However, the draft's modest goals, such as tripling renewable capacity globally and doubling energy efficiency improvements, may still contribute to a slow decline in emissions, with the five-year growth rate of emissions running at its slowest pace since World War II.

images.alt_text: Activists protesting against fossil fuel at COP28 on Dec 4; a coalition of more than 100 countries want an agreement that includes language to phase out fossil fuels.

With hours to go until the Dubai summit officially ends, US climate envoy John Kerry told ministers that this was “the last COP that we’ll have a chance to be able to keep 1.5 deg C alive. This is it.”

“While the pledges are positive steps forward in tackling the energy sector’s greenhouse gas emissions, they would not be nearly enough to move the world onto a path to reaching international climate targets, in particular the goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 deg C,” says the International Energy Agency.

site_title: The apple of my AI
summary: Singapore has announced its National AI Strategy 2.0 (Nais 2.0), a nationwide plan to position the country as a world leader in AI. The plan includes AI-specific training programs, a carbon budget for data centers, and a dedicated physical space for AI collaboration. This is part of a broader AI race in South-east Asia, with companies like Nvidia investing in the region. Meanwhile, Bytedance's TikTok and tech giant GoTo have announced a merger of their Indonesian e-commerce businesses, and climate tech venture builder Wavemaker Impact has secured $60 million for its first fund.

images.alt_text: With many sharing the spotlight, startups building consumer brands have weakened in their attractiveness to investors, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Flash Coffee's Taiwan bankruptcy mirrors the Singapore one, with Flash Coffee’s holding company being the largest creditor, and staff salaries left unpaid, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
Some sectors and regions remain bright spots for investments, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.
The drop in private funding has had an unequal impact across countries, with Indonesia bearing the brunt of the fall, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.

It will be interesting to watch how Kopi Kenangan balances rapid global expansion via a franchise model with maintaining standards and customer stickiness, writes Garage correspondent Sharanya Pillai.

site_title: Disney, Reliance working on terms of India media operations merger: report
summary: Reliance Industries and Walt Disney are finalizing a non-binding term sheet to merge their Indian media operations. The deal, expected to be announced in January, involves a share swap between Reliance's Viacom18 and Disney's Star India. Reliance is likely to pay cash for a 51% stake in the proposed Viacom18 unit, with Disney retaining 49%. The unit's board will have equal representation from both parties, and the deal is valued at between $7 billion and $8 billion, according to Bloomberg.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a Reliance Industries Limited sign board installed on a road divider in the western Indian city of Gandhinagar, January 17, 2014. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares rise ahead of Federal Reserve meeting; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,102.31, driven by gains in Sembcorp Industries and local banking stocks. The benchmark index was influenced by a global Wall Street rally ahead of the US Federal Reserve's final meeting of the year. Regional markets also rose, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and South Korea's Kospi Composite Index gaining 1.1% and 0.4%, respectively. The US consumer price index data release later on Tuesday is expected to set the tone for US policymakers.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 54 to 36.
US billionaire investor Howard Marks views emerging economies as "teenagers" - full of potential yet also "volatile and tempestuous".

site_title: You’ll pay more to see the Mona Lisa: The Louvre is raising its admission price
summary: The Louvre Museum in Paris will raise its basic ticket price to 22 euros (S$31.80) from 17 euros, starting January 15, as part of a broader effort to offset rising energy costs and support free admission programs for local residents. The price hike, approximately 30% increase, comes ahead of the Summer Olympics in Paris, which is expected to attract nearly 10 million visitors. The move is part of the museum's larger revamp, led by President and Director Laurence des Cars, aimed at rebalancing the Louvre and reducing congestion.

images.alt_text: The Louvre exhibition, titled “The Origins of the Sacred Image: Icons from the Bohdan and Varvara Khanenko National Museum of Arts in Kyiv”, will continue until Nov 6.

site_title: Renault to sell first tranche of Nissan stake, booking 1.5 billion euros loss
summary: Renault is selling a 5% stake in Nissan as part of a share buyback program, marking the first tranche of a planned disposal of its holding. The sale, valued at 765 million euros, will result in a 1.5 billion euro loss for Renault. The move is part of a restructuring of the Renault-Nissan alliance, aiming for a downsized partnership. Renault's stake in Nissan will be reduced to 15% from around 43%. The sale will be executed on Wednesday and is expected to be funded by Nissan.

images.alt_text: Nissan and Mitsubishi confirms they would invest respectively up to 600 million euros and 200 million euros in Ampere, which has been carved out from the rest of Renault and is due to list on the market next year.
Renault plans to use proceeds from Nissan stake sales to continue investing in its electric vehicle and software business Ampere, its sports-car division Alpine and its recycling unit.
Renault and Nissan finalised at the end of July the terms of a restructured alliance after months of negotiations.
Both Renault and Nissan are under pressure as competition from Tesla and Chinese EV makers intensifies.

site_title: Court rules Asti’s EGM invalid; requisitioners fail to unseat board
summary: The Singapore High Court has ruled that Asti Holdings' August 22 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) is invalid due to improper conduct. The meeting was called by four shareholders seeking to replace the company's entire board, but the court dismissed their application to enforce resolutions from the meeting. This decision comes amid Asti's share suspension and delisting from the Singapore Exchange due to failing to meet watch list requirements.

images.alt_text: Asti says it was unable to produce its audited financial statement for FY2022 by the deadline of Sep 30, 2023, because it does not have an appointed auditor.
Shareholders only voted on two resolutions at the AGM, is in view of ongoing legal applications by dissenting shareholders.
opinion poll, opinion polling, survey
Asti's shareholders seek to restrain its five directors from convening or holding its FY2021 annual general meeting.
The FY2021 annual general meeting is legally sanctioned and must proceed on Aug 31, said Asti Holdings in a bourse filing on Sunday.
The new development comes one day after Asti’s supposedly-ousted board said it would take the requisitioning shareholders and other individuals to court.

site_title: Nokia lowers 2026 profit margin target, wins Deutsche Telekom contract
summary: Nokia revised its 2026 profit margin target to at least 13% due to a loss in a US telecom contract with AT&T. The company still believes it can achieve its previous target, but considers the current market conditions in its mobile networks business as a factor. Nokia announced a deal with Deutsche Telekom to use open radio access network (Oran) technology in Germany, marking a return to the commercial networks. The company plans to revamp its mobile networks business by lowering its cost base to achieve a double-digit operating margin.

images.alt_text: AT&T has been analysing Open RAN for six months with a team of hundreds, an executive said and has looked at multiple vendors and sought proposals.
Nokia said on Tuesday it is suing Amazon and HP over patent infringements on video-related technologies.
Comparable net sales fell to 4.98 billion euros from 6.24 billion euros last year, missing the estimated 5.67 billion euros.
The Nokia XR21 European edition is priced from 649 euros, or £549, HMD says.
Nokia says it now expects second-half net sales broadly similar to the first half with some sequential improvement in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Australia‘s central bank flags broad payments system reforms
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is considering broad reforms to the payments system, including regulations on mobile wallet services, surcharges on buy-now-pay-later services, and improved transparency on costs. Governor Michele Bullock aims to expand the RBA's regulatory power by next year, allowing for a review of the retail payments system. The RBA also plans to modernize the direct entry system for salaries and welfare payments, and will continue working on a central bank digital currency and a project to develop tokenized asset markets.

images.alt_text: The surge in migration has helped fuel Australia’s growing housing crisis, which has seen rents grow at their fastest rates in decades and worsened the cost-of-living crunch for a nation already struggling with stubbornly high inflation.

Foreign investment charges for the purchase of established homes will triple, Treasurer Jim Chalmers says. Penalties for buyers from overseas who leave their properties vacant will double while application fees for investment in build-to-rent projects will be reduced.

Australia’s Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (right) reacts as he speaks during a press conference with Papua New Guinea’s Prime Minister James Marape at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia. Dec 7, 2023.
Australian consumers have been much more downbeat than business this year, as high inflation and rising borrowing costs ate into spending power.

site_title: TikTok-GoTo partnership takes away Indonesian group’s burden, pressures Sea: analysts
summary: A partnership between TikTok and GoTo is expected to hurt Sea's margin but relieve the Indonesian tech giant's cash-burning burden. Analysts downgraded Sea's target price to $42 from $62, citing greater losses for Shopee amid intensified e-commerce competition. The deal is expected to pressure Sea's profitability, with losses for FY2024 widening by 25.1% and e-commerce adjusted Ebitda forecast revised into the red.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
JD.com is adopting discounts and lower prices to try and turn the tide at a time consumers are cutting back on big-ticket spending.
Shopping features within the TikTok app in Indonesia will be operated and maintained by the enlarged Tokopedia entity.
Sea’s valuation is undemanding, with current share price implying a 0.5 multiple to the forecasted FY2024 sales of Shopee, says the analysts.
Indonesia in October banned online shopping on social media platforms to protect smaller merchants and users’ data, after which TikTok had to close its e-commerce service TikTok Shop.
ByteDance’s ultimate goal is to revive its online shopping service in South-east Asia’s largest retail arena.

site_title: Bain to sell Japan Wind Development to Infroneer for US$1.5 billion: sources
summary: US private equity firm Bain Capital is selling Japan Wind Development to Infroneer Holdings for approximately US$1.5 billion. The sale, through a competitive bidding process, marks a significant step for Infroneer in developing wind power projects. This deal follows a surge in renewable energy investments in Japan, as the country transitions to a zero-emission economy. The sale comes amid a record high number of M&A deals in the Japanese renewable energy sector, with over US$1.8 billion in deals for the year to date.

Brands should base their top priorities in the region on future-facing opportunities there – and seek funding accordingly.

site_title: Swiss banking secrecy? Gone. Reformers are now targeting legal secrecy
summary: Switzerland is poised to introduce a law requiring lawyers to report suspicious financial transactions, aiming to combat money laundering. The draft law, targeting lawyers who help set up shell companies and purchase real estate for clients, could lead to fines of up to $570,730. However, lawyers and the Swiss bar association have expressed concerns over the law's vagueness and potential impact on their businesses, with some arguing it could lead to an unbearable amount of compliance work. The law's passage is uncertain, with the Swiss parliament's oversight committee questioning the law's clarity.

images.alt_text: Forget Londongrad: Switzerland in focus as sanctions target rich

site_title: Singapore, global verification programmes to develop carbon-crediting best practices
summary: Singapore's National Climate Change Secretariat is collaborating with Gold Standard and Verra's Verified Carbon Standard to develop a playbook for countries to increase their use of existing carbon-crediting programs by mid-2024. The playbook aims to define roles, exchange information, and implement harmonized approaches to achieve Paris Agreement targets. The collaboration seeks to support national registries in integrating with existing market structures, benefiting countries, corporates, and investors. This will help money reach projects that achieve real impact, and mitigate the risk of divergent approaches hindering Article 6 implementation.

images.alt_text:
Permanent Secretary of the Ministry for Sustainability and the Environment Stanley Loh and Vice Minister of Strategic Affairs of the Ministry of
Environment and Energy Carlos Isaac Pérez signed a Memorandum of
Understanding between Singapore and Costa Rica to collaborate on carbon credits under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement on the sidelines of COP28.
Another trend Sustainable Fitch expects in 2024 is localisation, whereby sustainable finance is being increasingly tailored for each region’s needs.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.
East Kalimantan to protect forests and wildlife such as the orangutan.

site_title: China lifts ban on Australian red meat exporters
summary: China has lifted suspensions targeting three major Australian red meat exporters, winning praise from Canberra as the trading partners mend their strained relationship. The suspensions were a result of a diplomatic dispute between 2020 and 2022, resulting in lost trade worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The move comes as China has normalized trade with Australia, including lifting tariffs on barley, halting an import ban on timber, and resuming coal shipments. Australian officials welcome the decision, calling it a "win for our agricultural sector" and a positive step towards stabilizing relations with China.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Chinese vice-premier Ding Xuexiang meet in Tianjin, China to co-chair the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.

Crews flying Pacific missions on the US Navy’s top maritime surveillance and attack aircraft will be using AI algorithms to rapidly process sonar data gathered by underwater devices of the US, UK and Australia.
China has unleashed a flurry of market access concessions in the wake of last month’s leaders’ summit.

site_title: Wanda reaches agreement with pre-IPO investors to stay put
summary: Dalian Wanda Group, a Chinese property giant, has reached an agreement with pre-IPO investors to avoid immediate repayment of over $4 billion. The investors, including PAG, will re-invest their money at the year-end deadline after Wanda pays back their original stakes. This deal prevents Wanda from repaying the investors before its mall operating unit's shares are listed. The agreement is seen as a temporary reprieve for Wanda, which had faced a looming repayment deadline.

images.alt_text: Wanda Properties International wants to push back the maturity on the 7.25 per cent note by almost a year to Dec 29, 2024, according to a statement to the Hong Kong stock exchange.

site_title: KKR nears deal for Cotiviti valuing firm at US$11 billion
summary: KKR is nearing a deal to buy a 50% stake in healthcare technology company Cotiviti, valuing the firm at between $10 billion and $11 billion. Veritas Capital is in talks with KKR and other lenders, including Wall Street banks and private credit funds, to provide financing for the deal, with a potential $5 billion to $6 billion debt package. The deal could be the largest direct loan on record, and conditions in the market have improved, making a debt package from banks more attractive.

images.alt_text: The transaction is expected to be completed in the first half of next year, subject to regulatory approval.
KKR’s global impact team so far has made 18 investments.
Telecom Italia has for months sought to sell the grid.
KKR’s move comes at a difficult time for fundraising globally, as higher borrowing costs and economic uncertainty leave investors wary.

site_title: Watching the lay of the land
summary: The Singapore government plans to roll out 5,450 residential units through land sales in the first half of 2024, a 5.6% increase from the current half-year. The increase will be the highest since 2013. Three land parcels in River Valley, Queenstown, and Pasir Ris are expected to see strong interest, while two sites in Tengah and Bayshore estates are also anticipated to attract attention. The government aims to meet demand and keep the market stable, with the land sales program also introducing a new category of long-stay serviced apartments.

images.alt_text: Homeowners living in private property and/or holding properties for investment will be hit hard next year, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

One largely unseen component of developers’ costs is the land betterment charge paid to the government in return for enhanced land use in building up a site, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
The residential rental market is cooling its heels after racing up in 2021 and 2022, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Hyperlocal factors helped push sales of the 368-unit J’den project in Jurong, writes deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Lee Yeow Seng, group chief executive of  IOI Properties, has extensive interest in downtown Singapore, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: Tencent game threat seen overdone in NetEase’s US$8 billion sell-off
summary: NetEase, a Chinese gaming company, saw its US$8 billion market value drop by 43% over three weeks due to concerns about competition from Tencent's upcoming game "Dream Star". Despite this, NetEase's shares are still up 43% this year, outpacing its peers. Analysts believe NetEase's strong market position, popular game "Eggy Party", and upcoming releases will help the company rebound, with many giving it a "buy" rating and predicting a 30% gain in the next year.

images.alt_text: Tencent has been pushing services that use the AI inference chip Zixiao it developed with deep learning startup Enflame, touting performance comparable to some Nvidia chips.
Tencent still relies heavily on domestic game sales in China, but in recent years it has amped up efforts to acquire slices of up-and-coming studios from Europe to Japan.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar seeks to solidify power with return of influential leaders in Cabinet reshuffle
summary: Malaysia Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has announced a new Cabinet line-up of 60 people, up from 55 previously, in a move to solidify his power. The new Cabinet includes 31 ministers and 29 deputy ministers, with 31 familiar faces from the previous government returning. Notable changes include portfolio swaps and the dropping of human resource minister V Sivakumar, who will be replaced by former deputy finance minister Steven Sim. The new lineup aims to strengthen Anwar's government ahead of the 2028 general election.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production in October rose 2.7 per cent from a year earlier, faster than expected, government data showed on Monday.
The investments are set to create nearly 90,000 new job opportunities, and is Malaysia’s best achievement for the corresponding period over the past decade.
Bank Negara Malaysia governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour says that resilient domestic spending, underpinned by improved employment and rising tourism activities, bolstered Q3 growth.
Malaysian trade is heavily dependent on China and remained sluggish last quarter but signs of a Chinese economic recovery hint at a potential upturn.

site_title: Asia tracks Wall Street rally ahead of run of data, Fed decision
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday, following Wall Street's lead, as traders await data and the US Federal Reserve's final policy meeting of the year. A string of data indicating a slowdown in inflation and labor market suggests bets on the central bank cutting borrowing costs. Investors expect a benign inflation print or one that won't upset the market's bullish dynamics ahead of the Fed meeting. The yen edged back against the dollar after tumbling on Monday, while Europe's stocks rose, with Frankfurt hitting a record high and Paris near its peak.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4 per cent to 36,404.93 on Monday, its highest close since January 2022.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 54 to 36.

site_title: Occupants of seven-storey Bronx apartment escape death after building collapses
summary: A seven-storey building in the Bronx partially collapsed on Monday, prompting a massive rescue effort. Miraculously, no one was killed, but two people sustained minor injuries while evacuating the building. Firefighters searched the 12-foot-tall pile of debris and confirmed no one was trapped or injured. The cause of the collapse is still unknown, but city building records have raised questions about the building's safety for years. The building's owner was issued a $2,400 fine last month for deteriorated and broken mudsills, and the building's brick facade was deemed "unsafe" in 2020 due to significant masonry damage.

site_title: BlackRock, Aimco back US$800 million Asia infrastructure fund
summary: BlackRock and Aimco have backed a US$800 million Asia-focused infrastructure fund, Seraya Partners Fund I, which has exceeded its target of US$750 million. The fund, set up by a Singapore-based private equity firm in 2021, has attracted investors from BlackRock, Alberta Investment Management, and other insurers and sovereign wealth funds. Despite geopolitical risks, investors are drawn to the region due to infrastructure deals trading at half the value of US and European valuations, earning a gross percentage return in the low 20s. The fund's managing partner sees a "golden period" for infrastructure investments in Asia.

site_title: More than half of Apac family offices report asset growth despite challenges: study
summary: Asia-Pacific family offices have reported asset growth despite challenging market conditions, with 58% of 76 family offices in the region increasing their assets under management. The total wealth of these families stood at US$68 billion, and their aggregate AUM stood at US$41 billion. They adopted innovative asset-allocation strategies, including increasing exposure to equities and reducing borrowings, to counter inflation and rising interest rates. The region is expected to see a significant generational shift, with 47% of family offices under the control of their next generation within five years.

images.alt_text: Edwin Conway of BlackRock says:  “We think of decarbonisation as one of the best investment opportunity sets across private markets, because the world is in transition.”

Ongoing investigations and supervisory engagements suggest that one or more of the accused persons in the S$2.8 billion money laundering probe may have been linked to SFOs that were awarded tax incentives.
Inflation and the high cost of debt has led family offices to move down the risk curve to pursue value-add and opportunistic strategies.
Industry players and observers that spoke to BT said the police bust – the largest AML operation in Singapore’s history – should be viewed in a positive light.

site_title: China car sales expected to rise 3% in 2024: industry association
summary: China's car sales are projected to rise 3% in 2024, reaching 26.8 million units, slowing from a 10.3% increase this year, according to the China Association of Auto Manufacturers (CAAM). New energy vehicle sales are expected to grow 20% in 2024, while car exports are forecast to rise to 5.5 million units. The auto market faces challenges from shrinking demand, supply shocks, and weakening expectations.

site_title: Singapore shares open Tuesday slightly higher; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1% to 3,092.40. Gainers outnumbered losers 54 to 36, with 33.8 million securities worth S$40.7 million traded. The market follows overnight gains in US and European stock markets, as investors await central bank interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange's total securities market turnover in November is up 1 per cent from the prior month.

site_title: Japan’s input inflation eases further to slowest pace since 2021
summary: Japan's producer price growth eased to 0.3% in November, the slowest pace since February 2021, supporting the Bank of Japan's view that inflation is moderating. This marks the 11th straight month of slowing growth, with lumber and utilities costs continuing to decline. The news suggests that inflationary pressure is easing, aligning with the Bank of Japan's expectations.

images.alt_text: Household spending in Q3 is down with income stagnant, based on internal affairs ministry data.
The BOJ remains a dovish outlier among global peers, having maintained ultra-loose policy even as major central banks elsewhere raised interest rates aggressively to fight rampant inflation.
The service sector has been a bright spot for the world’s third-largest economy, helping offset the drag to growth from struggling manufacturing.

site_title: Investors in China’s lagging markets to play defence in 2024
summary: Investors in China's lagging markets are expected to focus on defensive sectors and companies with global reach in 2024, seeking insulation from an economic downturn. Despite sell-side analysts forecasting Chinese equities to outperform the S&P 500, investors are cautious due to China's underperformance in the past three years. Defensive sectors like health, medical innovation, and exporters in the electric vehicles supply chain are expected to top the list, with multinationals such as PDD Holdings also attracting attention. Goldman Sachs forecasts the CSI300 index to rise 23% by the end of 2024, while Morgan Stanley expects a 14% gain.

images.alt_text: The market declines come on the heels of the Politburo meeting, where policymakers pledged to strengthen fiscal support but dropped the wording “forceful” when mentioning monetary policy.
The weak earnings momentum may give investors more reasons to sell Chinese equities after the CSI 300 benchmark for mainland shares tumbled to its lowest since 2019 this week.
The Beijing Stock Exchange has vowed to tighten supervision and issued warnings against abnormal trading.  The Beijing Stock Exchange 50 Index has gained nearly 50 per cent since its October low.

site_title: Epic Games wins antitrust case against Google over Play app store
summary: Epic Games has won a high-profile antitrust case against Google, with jurors finding for Epic on all counts after a month-long trial. The lawsuit accused Google of taking action to quash competitors and charging unduly high fees of up to 30% to app developers. The verdict could upend the app store economy, giving developers more sway over their app distribution and profit. Google has vowed to appeal, but the ruling marks a significant defeat for the tech giant.

images.alt_text: Tencent still relies heavily on domestic game sales in China, but in recent years it has amped up efforts to acquire slices of up-and-coming studios from Europe to Japan.
Lego Fortnite is part of a larger strategy by Epic to create more virtual worlds where gamers can socialise and play.
Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai is set to be called by Epic Games to testify in an antitrust trial over Google Play policies.
The Epic Games job cuts are announced in a memo to staff.
“I will leave having been privileged to work on products that have touched millions of lives across the world,” says Jim Ryan, president and CEO of Sony Interactive Entertainment.

site_title: Bank of America banker warns China property slump to last years, hit deals
summary: A Bank of America banker, Martin Siah, predicts China's property downturn will last years due to a lack of investor confidence in the world's second-largest economy. The sector has seen a drought of deals, with M&A transactions falling 39% to $102.3 billion this year. Siah expects a multi-year recovery timeframe for China's real estate sector, contrasting with his positive outlook for Japan's real estate market, which is attracting investors due to healthy inflation and corporate reforms.

The value of new home sales among the 100 biggest real estate companies falls 29.6 per cent from a year earlier to 390.19 billion yuan (S$73.3 billion).

site_title: Australia business mood darkens as activity slows: survey
summary: Australia's business confidence has fallen to its lowest since the pandemic, according to a survey by National Australia Bank. The index of business conditions dropped 4 points to +9 in November, while the confidence index slid 6 points to -9, the worst reading since 2012. High inflation and rising borrowing costs have weighed on consumer spending power, but strong population growth and government spending on infrastructure have helped insulate some firms. The Reserve Bank of Australia has maintained interest rates at a 12-year high of 4.35%.

images.alt_text: The surge in migration has helped fuel Australia’s growing housing crisis, which has seen rents grow at their fastest rates in decades and worsened the cost-of-living crunch for a nation already struggling with stubbornly high inflation.

Foreign investment charges for the purchase of established homes will triple, Treasurer Jim Chalmers says. Penalties for buyers from overseas who leave their properties vacant will double while application fees for investment in build-to-rent projects will be reduced.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the balance on goods rose to A$7.1 billion (S$6.24 billion), from A$6.2 billion in September.
Australia's GDP advanced 0.2 per cent from the prior quarter, slower than economists’ estimate of a 0.5 per cent gain, Australian Bureau of Statistics data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Important to build agility as AI disrupts roles in banking: OCBC’s Lee Hwee Boon
summary: OCBC's head of group human resources, Lee Hwee Boon, emphasizes the need for bankers to build agility, resilience, and critical thinking skills as AI disrupts roles in the industry. With 28 years of experience in various roles, Lee believes that each experience has allowed her to build key skills to help her succeed in the next role. As AI transforms the future of work, Lee expects the next challenge to be preparing the company and workforce for change, requiring a focus on mobility, speed to market, and resource planning.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An OCBC Bank signage is pictured at their office in Singapore July 11, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
Like most banks, OCBC’s net interest margin (NIM) also benefitted from rising interest rates, rising 21 basis points from a year ago to 2.27 per cent in the third quarter ended September.

site_title: Oil settles slightly higher, investors still wary
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Monday, with Brent crude futures increasing 19 cents to $76.03 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 9 cents to $71.32 a barrel. Despite a 0.3% gain, investors remain wary due to lingering concerns over crude oversupply and softer fuel demand growth next year, resulting in a seventh consecutive weekly decline.

images.alt_text: Prices for other crude oil at similar quality to Saudi grades are assessed at much lower prices.
Malaysia's industrial production in October rose 2.7 per cent from a year earlier, faster than expected, government data showed on Monday.

site_title: JD.com founder channels Jack Ma in urging staff to fix problems
summary: JD.com founder Richard Liu urged staff to address deep-seated issues, echoing Alibaba founder Jack Ma's call to action last month. Liu acknowledged problems such as poor merchant support and high-priced items, calling for change to prevent the company's demise. JD.com is adopting discounts and lower prices in response to declining consumer spending, while Alibaba shares have declined 19% this year. The company's shares have fallen 50% this year, surpassing Alibaba's decline, as up-and-comers like PDD Holdings and ByteDance's Douyin gain ground in China's e-commerce market.

images.alt_text: JD.com reports net revenue of 247.7 billion yuan (S$46.1 billion) for the third quarter, missing analysts’ average estimate of 249.26 billion yuan.
JD.com’s share price has halved this year and the stock is trailing most of its peers on the Hang Seng Tech Index and Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index.

site_title: British firms in China wary to invest over slowdown: survey
summary: British firms in China are delaying investment decisions due to a gloomy economic outlook and geopolitical uncertainty, according to a survey by the British Chamber of Commerce in China. 55% of surveyed companies plan to cut or maintain investment levels, with domestic economic uncertainty and geopolitical tensions cited as major concerns. China has taken steps to improve its business environment, including visa-free access for six countries, in an effort to attract foreign capital.

images.alt_text: People walk on the Bund promenade along the Huangpu River in the Huangpu district in Shanghai on December 6, 2023. (Photo by Hector RETAMAL / AFP)
Passenger vehicle sales in China are projected to rise by 3.1 per cent to 26.8 million units next year, slowing from a 10.3 per cent increase this year, according to CAAM estimates.
The property slump was among the factors that prompted a recent downgrade of the nation’s credit outlook by Moody’s Investors Service.
Employees at SK On EV battery factory in Seosan, South Korea, Oct 19, 2023. South Korean battery makers say that global automakers are now pressuring them to develop LFP batteries.
The measures come as China’s top leaders last week pledged to stimulate domestic demand and stabilise foreign trade and capital.
Tencent has been pushing services that use the AI inference chip Zixiao it developed with deep learning startup Enflame, touting performance comparable to some Nvidia chips.
Huawei, the target of US sanctions since 2019, hopes the presence of foreign investors would help defend the business from potential further geopolitical tensions

site_title: Gold edges higher as dollar slips, US inflation data in focus
summary: Gold prices edged higher on Tuesday after hitting a three-week low, as the US dollar eased and investors awaited US inflation data and central bank policy meetings. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,985.49 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.4% to $2,000.60. Economists expect US inflation to be flat for November, and traders expect the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates unchanged this week, with a 77% chance of a rate cut in May.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates tend to support non-interest-bearing bullion.

site_title: Raimondo vows ‘strongest possible’ action on Huawei’s chip breakthrough
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo vowed to take the "strongest possible" action against Huawei following the company's development of a 7-nanometre chip, which powers a recently released smartphone. The chip, manufactured by China's SMIC, has raised concerns about a potential violation of US sanctions against Huawei. Raimondo's department is probing the situation, and she has requested more resources to enforce controls. The move comes amid pressure from Republicans who argue that the chip demonstrates a clear violation of US sanctions.

images.alt_text: Gina Raimondo Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg
Huawei has outlined plans for the factory with an initial investment of 200 million euros (S$289 million) in 2020, but the roll-out was delayed by the Covid-19 pandemic.
Huawei, the target of US sanctions since 2019, hopes the presence of foreign investors would help defend the business from potential further geopolitical tensions
The 7-nanometre processor was designed by Huawei and produced by Semiconductor Manufacturing International.

site_title:
AI is eating the Internet. Will it 
eat itself too?
summary: Artificial Intelligence is increasingly producing unwanted content, such as fake reviews, images, and videos, flooding the internet. This has raised concerns that AI-generated content could lead to a breakdown in trust and potentially destabilize society. In response, tech firms are developing more advanced AI detection algorithms, including Google's generative AI search feature, which aims to provide coherent answers while culling out low-quality content. However, this solution may ultimately rely on more AI, potentially exacerbating the problem and leading to a "model collapse" where AI output becomes meaningless.

images.alt_text: In its publicity material, Eleven Labs produced a video of actor Leonardo DiCaprio being voiced by several other celebrities.
A AFP journalist watches a video manipulated with artificial intelligence to potentially deceive viewers, or "deepfake" at his desk in Washington, DC, Jan 25, 2019.

Alphabet unit Google, Facebook, Twitter and other tech companies will have to take measures to counter deepfakes and fake accounts on their platforms or risk hefty fines under an updated European Union (EU) code of practice, according to an EU document seen by Reuters.
Facebook AI software able to dig up origins of deepfake images
The online retailer is developing a system to let Alexa mimic any voice after hearing less than a minute of audio.

site_title: Citi explores new deal structures in battered CO2 offsets market
summary: Citi is exploring new deal structures to entice risk-averse investors into the carbon offset market, which has faced integrity issues and governance challenges. The market has the potential to reach $1 trillion, and Citi sees carbon credits as a tool to mobilize more climate funding for emerging markets. The bank is working with other global banks to construct deals that use carbon credits as loss-absorbing capital, and is optimistic about the market's long-term prospects.

Citigroup’s aim is to be able to offer a potential borrower a high-yield bond, leveraged loan, or private credit option, which the company, or their private equity owner, could then choose depending on their needs.
A Citigroup index shows downgrades to US earnings estimates have outnumbered upgrades for nine weeks in a row – the longest streak since February.

site_title: Obamas score a hit with Netflix film ‘Leave the World Behind’
summary: The Obamas' film 'Leave the World Behind' has become a massive hit on Netflix, becoming the No 1 picture globally and in 85 countries. The two-hour-plus apocalyptic thriller, released on December 8, drew 2.6 million US households in its first two days, 73% more than another recent Netflix release. The film stars Julia Roberts, Mahershala Ali, and Ethan Hawke and was co-produced by Higher Ground Productions, the Obamas' production company, which has also produced award-winning documentaries like 'American Factory' and podcasts like 'Renegades: Born in the USA'.

images.alt_text: The tennis face-off between Nadal (pictured) and Alcaraz will stream as a dual broadcast in English and Spanish. Tickets for the event start at US$88 and will go on sale on Friday.
The two-part sixth, and final, season of The Crown that premieres on Netflix on Nov 16, explores Princess Diana’s final days before she perishes in a car accident.
After resisting commercials for years, Netflix had a change of heart in April 2022 after it lost subscribers in the first quarter of the year.

site_title: London to lead long-awaited slowdown in UK rent growth next year
summary: The UK's rental market is expected to slow down in 2024, with average annual rent increases projected to fall to 5% by December, down from 10% in October. In London, rental growth is set to rise just 2% by the end of next year, the lowest annual increase since 2021. The slowdown is attributed to a weaker labor market, slower earnings growth, and growing affordability pressures. This may lead to landlords adjusting prices more realistically, with some offering rent reductions of over 5%.

images.alt_text: UK households have been under pressure this year from mortgage rates that reached 14-year highs and stubbornly high inflation.

Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
The S&P Global/CIPS UK construction Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) edges down to 45.5 from October’s reading of 45.6, well below the 50.0 growth threshold.
The ONS household cost index shows the average mortgage borrower having a 9.3 per cent personal rate of inflation, far above the headline 6.7 per cent consumer prices index for September.

site_title: Rising egg prices show cracks in sanctions-hit Russian economy
summary: Russia's sanctions-hit economy is showing cracks as egg prices surge 40% in November, with inflation accelerating to 7.5% year-on-year. The price jump is attributed to rising poultry feed and veterinary products, indirectly caused by Western sanctions. Concerns are mounting as eggs are a key ingredient in traditional Russian holiday dishes. Authorities have launched checks on potentially unjustified price increases and considered importing eggs from Turkey, while experts warn that the situation could worsen if the sanctions remain in place.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky (pictured) “will discuss Ukraine’s urgent needs” as it fights off a Russian invasion, and “the vital importance of the United States’ continued support at this critical moment,” the White House said in a statement.

Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a meeting with Omsk Region Acting Governor Vitaly Khotsenko at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia August 28, 2023. Sputnik/Mikhail Klimentyev/Kremlin via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY.
The White House will be open to heightening the standard for initial asylum screenings, according to a Reuters source.
The G-7 said on Wednesday that it will ban all imports of rough diamonds directly from Russia from Jan 1, 2024.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Wing Tai, CSE Global
summary: The Singapore Exchange's total securities market turnover in November rose 1% from the prior month, while securities daily average value climbed 6%. Reits reported the most active daily turnover since March 2023, with all Singapore Reits ending the month in positive territory. Wing Tai acquired a Melbourne property for AS$28 million, while CSE Global secured two major US contracts worth US$20.8 million. Shares of these companies saw varying movements before the announcements, with SGX closing 0.7% lower, Wing Tai closing 0.8% higher, and CSE Global closing 1.2% lower.

site_title: Manulife to reinsure C$13 billion with KKR’s Global Atlantic
summary: Manulife Financial has agreed to reinsure C$13 billion of long-term care reserves with KKR's Global Atlantic Financial Group, the largest long-term care reinsurance transaction in industry history. The deal, expected to be completed in the first half of next year, will release C$1.2 billion of capital and add to core earnings per share. Manulife's shares rose 2.7% following the announcement, while Global Atlantic will retain underlying spread-based risks of the reinsured portion.

images.alt_text: Manulife is going ahead with job cuts after reporting a boost in third-quarter earnings from its business in Asia.
Asia is an important area for global and regional insurers as the region’s rapidly growing middle-class seeks life and healthcare insurance as well as investment options.

site_title: Goldman reshuffles private credit in bid to double assets
summary: Goldman Sachs is reshuffling senior executives in its $110 billion private credit unit, aiming to double the business in the medium term. Marc Nachmann, global head of asset and wealth management, sees private credit as a "big opportunity set" across the alternative space. Greg Olafson will become global head of private credit, while James Reynolds and Kevin Sterling will lead direct lending and investment-grade private credit, respectively. The moves come as Goldman seeks to retain its lead in the $1.6 trillion private credit market, which competes with its leveraged finance business.

images.alt_text: Inflation data last month show that US consumer prices were unchanged in October, and the annual rise in underlying inflation was the smallest in two years.

Japanese hotels have been among the most popular real estate investments in the Asia-Pacific region this year.
The ECB raised its deposit rate to a record high 4 per cent via ten straight moves ending in September.

site_title: Oracle reports disappointing sales on slowing cloud momentum
summary: Oracle's cloud computing business reported slowing quarterly sales growth, with revenue increasing 25% to $4.8 billion in the period ended Nov 30. This marks the second consecutive quarter of slowing growth for the business, fuelling investor fears about the company's expansion efforts. The shares dropped 8% in extended trading after closing at $115.13 in New York. Oracle's focus on competing with Amazon, Microsoft, and Google's cloud infrastructure business is still in progress, with analysts citing the availability of graphics processors as a key factor for future growth.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise ahead of central bank rate decisions
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% on Monday, reaching its highest level in 22 months, driven by bets of interest rate cuts amid slowing inflation and a likely shallow recession. The index has advanced 11.6% so far this year, mainly boosted by expectations of lower interest rates. Goldman Sachs raised its 12-month forecast for the Stoxx 600 to 500, implying a nearly 6% gain through 2024-end. Investors await key US inflation reports and interest rate decisions from major central banks this week, which may impact global monetary policy easing expectations.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4 per cent to 36,404.93 on Monday, its highest close since January 2022.

site_title: South Korean auto battery firms take on Chinese rivals but with trepidation
summary: South Korean auto battery firms, LG Energy Solution, SK On, and Samsung SDI, are under pressure from global automakers to develop more affordable lithium iron phosphate (LFP) batteries, favored by Chinese rivals. However, they are hesitant due to concerns about price competitiveness, citing slower electric vehicle sales and potential changes in US subsidies. The firms plan to build LFP batteries, but it will be a challenging task, with estimates suggesting Korean-made LFP batteries could be 17-40% more expensive than Chinese products.

site_title: First-timers’ median application rate below one in December BTO exercise
summary: In Singapore's latest Build-To-Order (BTO) sales exercise in December, first-time applicants faced a low median application rate of below one for three-room and larger flats. Only four first-time applicants were competing for each of the 260 five-room flats at Urban Rise @ Woodlands, with a median rate of two applicants for the 614 four-room flats. The higher rates were attributed to the projects' proximity to MRT stations and amenities, while demand was muted for flats in mature estates under the prime location public housing model, with most first-time applicants assured of booking a flat.

site_title: Boeing promotion of Pope could be stepping stone to CEO
summary: Boeing named 51-year-old Stephanie Pope as its new chief operating officer, elevating her as a potential successor to CEO David Calhoun. Pope, current head of Boeing Global Services, will report to Calhoun and oversee key business units. The appointment comes as Boeing aims to restore operational and financial strength, with a focus on improving performance and profitability by 2025-26. Pope's background in strategy and finance makes her a strong contender to succeed Calhoun as CEO, with some analysts predicting she could be the next CEO.

Rolls-Royce, a maker of airplane engines, will be opening a factory in Singapore to produce wide chord fan blade (WCFB).

site_title: Hasbro is cutting about 1,100 jobs, citing weak holiday sales
summary: Hasbro is cutting approximately 1,100 jobs, about 20% of its staff, due to weak holiday sales of toys and games. The company cited "market headwinds" and expects a 19% decline in sales this quarter. The job cuts are expected to result in annual savings of $100 million, with related costs of $134 million. Hasbro will also relocate employees from a Rhode Island office to its nearby headquarters in Pawtucket. The company's shares fell 8.7% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Hasbro now expects fiscal 2023 revenue to fall 13 per cent to 15 per cent.

site_title: GIC to buy out partner to become majority shareholder of reinsurance broker Miller
summary: GIC has agreed to buy out its partner's stake in UK specialist insurance and reinsurance broker Miller, becoming the majority shareholder. The transaction was first announced in 2021, with financial details not disclosed. GIC's CEO Choo Yong Cheen stated that the further investment is consistent with GIC's strategy of developing long-term relationships with its portfolio companies. Miller has reported significant sustained growth, with annualized revenues exceeding £200 million and a headcount of over 900 employees. The acquisition is expected to enable Miller to maintain its "exciting trajectory".

site_title: Taylor Swift gets Golden Globe nomination in new film category
summary: Taylor Swift's concert film "Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour" has been nominated for a Golden Globe in the new "Cinematic and Box Office Achievement" category, which recognizes films that both fans and critics love. The category aims to shift focus from artier films to more commercially successful ones. Swift's film is among eight nominees, including "Barbie" and "Oppenheimer", which have generated over $1.4 billion and $951 million in ticket sales, respectively. The ceremony will take place on January 7 and is under new management after a scandal led to a boycott by Hollywood stars.

site_title: Renault to pick partner for new Twingo EV by early 2024
summary: Renault is set to pick a partner for its new Twingo electric vehicle (EV) by early 2024, with Volkswagen reportedly in talks with the French carmaker. Renault aims to democratize the EV market with its Legend model, priced under 20,000 euros. Volkswagen is also developing an all-EV under 25,000 euros, with plans to launch by 2025. The partnership decision could help reduce EV prices in Europe, which averaged over 65,000 euros in the first half of 2023.

images.alt_text: The new Renault Twingo eletric car is presented on November 15, 2023 in Boulogne-Billancourt. (Photo by Miguel MEDINA / AFP)

Nissan and Mitsubishi confirms they would invest respectively up to 600 million euros and 200 million euros in Ampere, which has been carved out from the rest of Renault and is due to list on the market next year.

site_title: JPMorgan begins First Republic makeover as it opens more branches
summary: JPMorgan Chase is expanding its national footprint by opening 167 new branches, exceeding its earlier projection of 150, as part of its acquisition of failed First Republic Bank. Despite some departures, a majority of First Republic employees who moved to JPMorgan in July have stayed put. The bank aims to retain First Republic's affluent client base and revamp its branches with a different design and signature perks. JPMorgan's CEO, Jennifer Roberts, stated that branches are a winning strategy for the bank, capturing more market share, with 75% of customers visiting a branch annually.

site_title: Eight in 10 employers plan to give bonuses averaging one month or more: survey
summary: Most employers in Singapore plan to give bonuses averaging one month or more, with 84% of employers expected to award bonuses in the 2023-2024 period. Half of employers intend to award bonuses averaging one month's salary, while 27% plan to give bonuses exceeding one month and up to 1.5 months. Meanwhile, most workers can expect salary raises of 3-5% due to the expected bonuses. Despite a weakening employment outlook, 44% of employers expect headcount to grow in the next quarter, with skills in environmental, social, and corporate governance in high demand.

site_title: Tides turning for reinsurance on higher interest rates, lower Covid-related claims
summary: Reinsurance industry outlook for 2024 is positive, driven by higher interest rates and lower Covid-related claims. Emerging Asia's growing wealthy population is increasing demand for life and health insurance, benefiting reinsurance companies. Key highlights include Swiss Re's L&H segment reporting a 35% profit margin and expecting $900 million in profit this year. Reinsurance capital is expected to increase, and underwriting profits are expected to be forthcoming due to rising rates. The industry is adapting to a new way of helping clients stay resilient in a changing world, with a longer reinsurance capital cycle anticipated.

site_title: Fury as climate draft deal falls short of fossil fuel phase-out
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry expressed urgency as the Dubai COP28 summit nears its end, stating it's "the last COP we'll have a chance to keep 1.5 deg C alive." The draft deal fell short of calling for a phase-out of fossil fuels, disappointing Western powers and environmentalists. The landmark 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit warming to 1.5 deg C to avoid climate change's worst effects, but the deal's failure may limit progress in achieving this goal.

EPA-EFE/ALI HAIDER

site_title: US Supreme Court asked to decide if Trump has immunity from prosecution
summary: The US Supreme Court has been asked to rule on whether former President Donald Trump has immunity from prosecution for charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election. Federal prosecutors, led by Special Counsel Jack Smith, are seeking a quick decision to allow Trump's trial to proceed as scheduled on March 4, 2024. Trump's lawyers claim absolute immunity, but a lower court has rejected this claim. The Supreme Court, with a 6-3 conservative majority, is being asked to expedite its ruling to ensure Trump receives a fair trial.

site_title: What a T+1 settlement cycle in US means for financial institutions, investors
summary: The US will transition to a T+1 settlement cycle in 2024, halving the time it takes to settle securities transactions from two business days to one. This move, set to begin on May 28, 2024, will have a significant impact on financial institutions and investors, particularly those in Asia, due to the larger time zone difference. While the US is not the first to implement a T+1 cycle, other countries such as Canada and Mexico plan to follow suit. The change is expected to reduce market risk for investors and improve market liquidity, but may also increase pressure on back offices in Asia to process trades faster.

images.alt_text: For market participants in Asia Pacific, T+1 settlement in America would mean, in effect, only a few hours for operations teams to process trades, given the time zone differences.
