site_title: Australia to raise fees for foreigners buying existing houses
summary: Australia will triple foreign investment charges for buying existing houses and double penalties for vacant properties. The government aims to boost housing supply by making it more expensive for foreign owners to keep properties vacant. Incentives will also be provided for foreign investors to buy into new housing developments, with reduced application fees for build-to-rent projects. The changes are expected to raise revenue for the government while encouraging foreign investment in affordable housing. The adjustments will take effect from December 14.

images.alt_text: Many people crowded Sydney’s beaches or sought relief in the shade as authorities warned the most vulnerable - including the elderly and very young - to shelter in cool buildings.

site_title: Hermes creates Europe’s biggest family fortune after spurning LVMH
summary: Hermes has created Europe's largest family fortune after rejecting a takeover bid from LVMH. In 2010, LVMH's Bernard Arnault offered strategic and operational help to Hermes, but the family saw it as a takeover attempt. Hermes' fifth- and sixth-generation owners, led by Axel Dumas, decided to maintain their independence. The family's fortune has grown significantly, with Dumas becoming the executive chairman. The decision to spurn LVMH has allowed Hermes to maintain its heritage and reputation, cementing its position as a luxury brand.

images.alt_text: The fashion and leather goods division, home to Louis Vuitton and Dior, records sales growth of 9 per cent.
Exclusivity the name of the game as luxury firms target China’s wealthiest for growth
Sales in the Americas rise 20 per cent, despite smaller price hikes than in other parts of the world, with even growth rates on both US coasts, Hermes says.

site_title: WTI expected to retest year’s lows
summary: US crude oil production reached a record high for the second consecutive month, driven by increased industry efficiency, weighing on oil prices. Despite the Opec+ meeting's announcement to cut oil output by 2.2 million barrels per day, oil prices failed to recover. The US factory orders data showed a 3.6% decline, the largest drop in over three years, further dampening oil market sentiment. Multiple bearish signals remain for WTI crude oil, suggesting a potential retest of the year's lows at around $67 per barrel.

site_title: Cordlife did not disclose irregular temperatures earlier as board assessed ‘no material impact’ on financials
summary: Cordlife, a Singapore-based cord blood banking company, has revealed that its board was informed of irregular temperatures in one of its tanks in February 2023, but did not make an announcement, deeming it to have "no material impact" on its financial performance. An unannounced audit by the Ministry of Health (MOH) found seven cord blood units exposed to temperatures above acceptable limits. The incident was reported to the board, but it was not disclosed to the public until November 30, 2023.

images.alt_text: 康盛人生将脐带血干细胞低温保存，有助长期保存干细胞的活力与功能。
Cordlife says its storage operations ‘not’ impacted by accredited bodies’ suspension, probe

site_title: South-east Asian investors bullish on electric bikes, clean energy in 2024
summary: South-east Asian investors remain bullish on electric bikes, clean energy, and climate tech in 2024, driven by growing interest in technologies addressing carbon emissions and climate change. In 2023, 15 climate tech deals worth US$156.6 million were recorded, with electric two-wheelers, sustainable agriculture, and renewable energy being prominent themes. Notable investments include Indonesia's Alva, Maka Motors, and Singapore's Ion Mobility, which raised US$50 million, US$37.6 million, and US$18.7 million, respectively. The sector is expected to stay resilient despite a funding winter affecting other startups.

images.alt_text: The US-based Tesla unveiled the first experience centre in Kuala Lumpur on Oct 19, many were attracted to the centre to have a sneak peek of the refreshed Model 3.
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 16, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: More US commercial property owners to tap securities market in 2024: Moody's
summary: US commercial property owners are expected to shift to commercial mortgage-backed security (CMBS) lenders in 2024 due to tightened lending standards by banks. Elevated interest rates, volatility in property values, and weakened cash flows have led to this shift, with CMBS investors attracted to higher yields. About 19% of performing CMBS conduit loans carry high default risk, but investors will help them refinance through 10% or greater yields. This trend is expected to continue, with transaction levels remaining low and interest-only loans on the rise.

images.alt_text: Foreign investment charges for the purchase of established homes will triple, Treasurer Jim Chalmers says. Penalties for buyers from overseas who leave their properties vacant will double while application fees for investment in build-to-rent projects will be reduced.

site_title: COP28 considers end to fossil fuels in move opposed by Opec
summary: COP28 climate summit in Dubai is considering a deal to phase out fossil fuels, but Opec is opposing the move, citing concerns over the impact on oil and gas production. At least 80 countries are demanding a deal that calls for an eventual end to fossil fuel use, with scientists urging ambitious action to avert the worst impacts of climate change. A final draft of the agreement includes options to phase out fossil fuels, but divisions remain, with some countries pushing for a more gradual transition and others calling for greater support for developing nations to shift to clean energy.

images.alt_text: A man stands near a COP28 sign in a metro station in Dubai on November 28, 2023, ahead of the United Nations climate summit. The UN chief urged world leaders to take decisive action to tackle ever-worsening climate change when they gather at the COP28 summit in Dubai starting this week. (Photo by Jewel SAMAD / AFP)

COP28 president Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber speaks during a press conference at the United Nations climate summit in Dubai on December 4, 2023. The Emirati president of the UN's COP28 talks said on December 4 he respects climate science, after a leaked video showed him declaring that no science says a fossil fuel phaseout will help achieve climate goals. (Photo by KARIM SAHIB / AFP)
Coal is transported on barges in Samarinda, East Kalimantan in January 11, 2022.
Putin’s meeting with the Saudi crown prince came after oil prices fell despite a pledge by Opec+  to further cut output.

site_title: Indonesia’s Mitratel takes bold approach in acquiring towers divested by telcos
summary: Indonesia's largest telecom tower operator, Mitratel, has acquired 803 towers worth 1.75 trillion rupiah (S$151 million) from Gametraco Tunggal, expanding its network outside Java island. This deal, along with previous acquisitions, solidifies Mitratel's position as the largest tower company in South-east Asia, owning approximately 38,000 towers. The company expects the towers to contribute up to 190 billion rupiah annually to its revenue, with revenue growth predicted to increase by 11% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: CK Hutchison Holdings and Qatar’s Ooredoo QPSC combined their Indonesian telecom businesses in a US$6 billion transaction last year.
Singtel's first green loan requires that its two data centres, DC West and DC Kim Chuan, must obtain at least a Green Mark GoldPlus certification from Singapore’s Building and Construction Authority.

site_title: SGX listcos’ Q3 profits fall 6.8%; tech, Reits expected to lead recovery in 2024
summary: SGX-listed companies' Q3 profits fell 6.8% to S$8.7 billion, amid high interest rates, inflation, and an economic slowdown in China. Banking sector earnings remained resilient, while tech and Reits are expected to see recovery in 2024. Companies with exposure to China, such as Wilmar International, reported significant year-on-year declines in profits. Analysts predict a rebound in the Reit sector, driven by developments like the US Federal Reserve's rate pause and the return of international travellers. The tech sector is also expected to recover, with inventory restocking potentially benefiting local companies in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines has posted S$1.4 billion in earnings for the first half of FY2024 ended September.
IHH said it saw more patients, and benefited from higher revenue intensity across all its markets. There was also an improved case mix, the group said.

site_title: COP28 pledges meet only 30% of needed energy emission cuts: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency reported that pledges made at the COP28 climate summit would only reduce energy-related greenhouse gas emissions by 30% of the needed cuts by 2030, falling short of international climate targets. The 130 countries that signed the pledge on renewables and energy efficiency include the US, but exclude China, India, Saudi Arabia, and Russia. The agency emphasized that the pledges are a "positive step forward" but would not be enough to limit global warming to 1.5°C.

images.alt_text: Climate activists protest against fossil fuels at Dubai's Expo City during the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

site_title: Hong Kong holds first 'patriots only' local elections
summary: Hong Kong held its first "patriots only" local elections on December 10, with officials dismissing concerns of low turnout. The election, which replaced the previous democratic system, saw 88 directly elected seats and 382 seats controlled by government loyalists and rural landlords. Authorities attempted to drum up enthusiasm, but polling booths appeared to have few voters. The city leader, John Lee, said the election was the "last piece of the puzzle" to implement the principle of patriots ruling Hong Kong, and the councillors will "behave as local consultative bodies in name, and as the government's echo chamber in practice."

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s property market continues to slump as rates rise and capital flees in search of safer investments like fixed deposits.

site_title: Japan industry minister says reviewing finances amid funds scandal: media
summary: Japanese industry minister Yasutoshi Nishimura is reviewing his finances amid allegations of undeclared funding. He claims to be examining his report and will provide a thorough explanation at an appropriate time. The allegations have led to speculation that several top lawmakers, including Nishimura and other Cabinet members, may be replaced by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida. Tokyo prosecutors are investigating lawmakers after the parliament session ends on Wednesday, further straining the government's already low public support.

site_title: Reenova Investment not in financial position to make exit offer: liquidator
summary: Reenova Investment Holding, a Singapore-listed company, is unable to make an exit offer due to insufficient funds to settle creditors' claims. Its liquidator, Luke Furler, has written to the largest shareholder to explore options. Reenova has been on the financial watch list since 2019 and was placed under judicial management in 2022. The company's judicial managers have applied for winding up, which was approved by the court in August. The company's delisting from SGX was announced in November.

site_title: New trains, new tracks: US rail to get much-needed facelift
summary: The US rail network is set for a major facelift, with President Joe Biden's administration unveiling $66 billion in funding for passenger trains, aiming to double numbers by 2040. The investment includes the country's first high-speed train between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, expected to be completed by 2028. New trains, tracks, and stations will be built, with the goal of making rail travel faster, more frequent, and comfortable. The move is part of a broader effort to reduce the country's reliance on cars and planes, with the aim of reducing carbon emissions and improving the travel experience.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (left) has proposed to his Japanese counterpart Fumio Kishida that Japan provide ODA loans for the North-South railway project.
Deeper trade ties and railways connections are expected to be discussed on Friday as China’s top diplomat Wang Yi meets Vietnam’s Deputy Prime Minister Tran Luu Quang in Hanoi, diplomats said.

site_title:
Dollar up after strong US jobs data,
takes back some losses from yen
summary: The US dollar rose 0.3% against the yen and is on track for a modest weekly gain after new job data showed the US economy's labor market remains strong, with 199,000 jobs added in November and an unemployment rate of 3.7%. The data suggests the Federal Reserve is unlikely to cut interest rates soon, contradicting market expectations. The yen surged 1.2% earlier in the week after the Bank of Japan hinted at policy changes, but its gains dissipated on Friday.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda says the central bank has several options on which interest rates to target once it pulls short-term borrowing costs out of negative territory.

site_title: China, Philippines vessels face off in second day of clashes
summary: Philippine and Chinese vessels clashed in the South China Sea on Sunday, with the Philippines' sea task force reporting its vessels were damaged after being "directly targeted" by a Chinese coast guard ship with a water cannon during a supply mission. A Philippine boat was also rammed by a Chinese vessel, with China's Coast Guard blaming the Philippine boat for "deliberately colliding" with its vessel. The incidents marked the second day of clashes between the two countries over maritime territory, escalating tensions in the dispute.

images.alt_text: China's consumer price index, the main gauge of inflation, fell 0.5 per cent year-on-year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of December 8, 2023, reveals a mixed market for various commodity shipping segments. The LNG period assessment fell to $85,000 for six months, $96,900 for one year, and $104,200 for three-year-term deals. The Capesize market experienced significant fluctuations, with rates declining due to profit-taking and a lack of major players in the Pacific market. In contrast, the Panamax market saw a rise in rates, particularly in the Atlantic basin, as demand and supply were balanced. The Ultramax/Supramax market also saw a patchy week, with rates remaining healthy in the Atlantic but easing in Asia.

site_title: Guterres says UN Security Council ‘paralysed’ over Gaza
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres described the UN Security Council as "paralysed" due to geostrategic divisions, hindering its ability to demand a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip. The council's delayed response to the Israel-Hamas war, which began on October 7, has severely undermined its authority and credibility. Guterres expressed concern that the situation is deteriorating into a catastrophe with irreversible implications for Palestinians and regional peace and security.

images.alt_text: Research by law professors Robert Jackson Jr from New York University and Joshua Mitts of Columbia University found significant short-selling of shares leading up to the attacks, which triggered a war nearly two months old.

site_title: Australia to cut record high migration as housing crisis bites
summary: Australia plans to cut record-high migration levels to address the growing housing crisis, which has seen rents rise at their fastest rates in decades. The country welcomed over 500,000 new arrivals in the financial year ended June 30, the highest annual arrivals in history. To control migration, the government will release a Migration Strategy on Monday, aiming to return migrant intake to near pre-pandemic levels by June 2025. The strategy includes measures to ease workforce shortages, such as introducing a new Skills in Demand visa and cracking down on international student visas.

images.alt_text: Foreign investment charges for the purchase of established homes will triple, Treasurer Jim Chalmers says. Penalties for buyers from overseas who leave their properties vacant will double while application fees for investment in build-to-rent projects will be reduced.

site_title: Rich nations need to ditch fossil fuels by 2040: scientists
summary: Rich nations must stop using oil and gas by 2040 to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, according to climate scientists. This would give poorer nations until 2050. The recommendation, made to the UN, comes as climate negotiators at COP28 talks debate the future of fossil fuels. The Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research and Exeter University emphasize that a total phase-out of fossil fuels is necessary, with a stop to coal by 2030.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

site_title:
Five Reit ETFs in Singapore average 7.2 per cent total returns, ride on
rate cut expectations
summary: Five Singapore Reit exchange-traded funds (ETFs) averaged 7.2% total returns in November, driven by expectations that the rate hike cycle may end. This performance was the second-best among Singapore-listed ETFs, following those with Vietnam Equities underlying. S-Reits rebounded 7% in November, their best month in three years, and the iEdge S-Reit Index gained 1.5% in the first week of December. The Reit ETFs' performance was largely attributed to their exposure to the Singapore Reit market and the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit’s data centre in Northern Virginia. The Reit is one of four truststhat maintained double digit total return gains in the year to date till end November

site_title: AI-powered drive-thru is actually run almost entirely by humans
summary: A US-based provider of AI-powered drive-thrus, Presto Automation, has revealed that its systems rely heavily on human intervention, contrary to initial claims. The company, which partnered with OpenAI, states that "off-site agents" in locations like the Philippines assist with over 70% of customer interactions to ensure accuracy. This contradicts the firms' marketing claims that AI systems can take orders with minimal human intervention. The company's filings with the US Securities and Exchange Commission also disclose this information.

site_title: Sydney swelters in hottest day in three years
summary: Australia's eastern coast is experiencing a heatwave, with Sydney reaching its highest temperature in three years, 38.9°C (38.2°F). The heatwave has also led to dozens of bush and grass fires burning out of control across New South Wales, prompting authorities to warn the most vulnerable to shelter in cool buildings. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese warned of the dangers of climate change, stating it's a threat to people's health and environment. Temperatures are expected to remain high, with some areas reaching up to 10°C above average.

Global temperatures were around 1.4 deg Celsius above the pre-industrial average for the first 10 months of the year, prompting the WMO to declared it the warmest ever recorded.

site_title: China deflation accelerated in November: official data
summary: China's consumer price index fell 0.5% year-on-year in November, accelerating deflation, according to official data. The decline, linked to energy and food price drops, poses a threat to the broader economy as consumers delay purchases, forcing companies to cut production and potentially lay off workers. China's economy grew 4.9% in the third quarter, below the annual target of 5%. President Xi Jinping urged measures to boost the economy, including expanding domestic demand and preventing risks.

images.alt_text: The CSRC (top) is seeking opinion on the proposal to “reasonably” reduce transaction fees, and plans to strengthen supervision of the distribution of commissions for securities trading of public funds.
Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong met with Chinese Finance Minister Lan Fo'an at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing, China, where they discussed areas for further cooperation.
China will continue to implement a prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy in 2024, state media reported the Politburo as saying.
China's overseas shipments edged up 0.5 per cent on-year to US$291 billion, the General Administration of Customs said, marking their first increase since April.

The rating action for financial institutions including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is primarily driven by the change in outlook to negative from stable on the government’s credit ratings, according to Moody’s.

site_title: DBS Foundation partners MSF to give boost to lower-income families
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) to launch the DBS Foundation X MSF partnership, donating S$30 million over three years to support lower-income families with children living in rental flats. The initiative includes two packages: Preschool Education and Saving for Home Ownership, aiming to provide targeted support and financial knowledge to families. The partnership is part of DBS' S$1 billion pledge to uplift vulnerable segments of society over the next decade, with the goal of improving the livelihoods of 8,500 children and 1,400 families yearly.

images.alt_text: This year, for the first time, Certis will engage beneficiaries from The Business Times Budding Artists Fund through activities outside the centre.

site_title: The Hour Glass continues buyback, Wilmar chair Kuok raises stake
summary: Luxury watch retailer The Hour Glass acquired over 1 million shares through share buybacks from Dec 1 to Dec 7, with an average share price of S$1.58. The company's shares have declined 8% over the past month, and its net profit for the first half of FY2024 fell 9% to S$77 million. Meanwhile, Wilmar International chairman Kuok Khoon Hong raised his stake in the agribusiness to 13.56% after acquiring over 4 million shares over three days, coinciding with a steady drop in the company's share price.

images.alt_text: DBS says recovering sales volumes for consumer products will also propel higher profitability for Wilmar.
The company expects to remain profitable for the full financial year, but is cautious.
Fitch Solutions unit BMI notes that the year-to-date average for crude palm oil prices stands at RM3,805.20 per tonne, versus last year’s average of RM4,910.
There were 53 filings on the Singapore Exchange for changes in director interests and substantial shareholdings from Nov 24 through Nov 30, from 33 primary-listed stocks.

site_title: Europe agrees to landmark AI rules in bid to lead global race
summary: The European Union has reached a provisional agreement on landmark AI rules, becoming the first major world power to govern AI use. The EU aims to regulate AI systems like ChatGPT, limit law enforcement's use of biometric surveillance, and ban social scoring and AI manipulation. Safeguards include consumer complaints, fines ranging from 7.5 million euros to 35 million euros, and a unique legal framework for trustworthy technology. The agreement targets large powerful AI models to prevent systemic risks to the EU, with negotiations to finalize details in the coming days.

images.alt_text: EU countries and lawmakers are close to clinching a provisional deal on rules governing the use of artificial intelligence, people with direct knowledge of the discussions said on Friday.
Nvidia, which dominates the market for AI chips, declined to comment.
Traders are almost fully pricing in the likelihood of the Fed keeping rates unchanged at its meeting next week.

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman joined a fireside chat at AI Day 2023, which gathered thousands of AI fanatics in Vietnam on Dec 5 and 6.
The Singapore Conference on AI (SCAI) brought together 42 delegates from around the world to discuss "critical questions of AI".

site_title: China proposes cut to transaction fees on funds to boost market
summary: China's financial regulator, the CSRC, proposes cutting commission rates for public funds to boost market activity amid a downturn in the economy. The regulator plans to strengthen supervision of commission distribution and set caps on fees allocated to individual brokerages. The proposals aim to stimulate trading and support state-owned entities' green bond issuance. The CSRC seeks public opinion on the proposals, which are part of a broader effort to address the country's economic challenges.

site_title: Oil gains over 2% but records seventh weekly decline
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Friday, with Brent crude futures settling at $75.84 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures at $71.23 a barrel, after US data showed stronger-than-expected job growth. Despite this, both benchmarks fell for a seventh straight week, their longest streak of weekly declines in half a decade, due to lingering oversupply concerns. Chinese customs data also showed a 9% decline in crude oil imports in November, fueling the market's downturn.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows emissions from the chimneys of Yara France plant in Montoir-de-Bretagne near Saint-Nazaire, France, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
Front-month prices for Brent signal that traders believe the market may have become oversupplied.

site_title: Jousting makes comeback in England as competitive sport
summary: Jousting has made a comeback in England as a competitive sport, with modern-day tournaments held at historic castles and stately homes. Knights on horseback charge at each other with wooden lances, aiming for each other's heads, and competing for points rather than trying to unseat their opponents. The sport, which dates back to the 10th century, requires finely honed skill and horsemanship, and has even seen calls for it to be made an Olympic sport. Despite its elitist roots, the sport has become more inclusive, with women participating and the cost of equipment exceeding $21,000.

images.alt_text: Everton's Abdoulaye Doucoure (left) celebrates after scoring against Newcastle in a 3-0 win on Dec 7, 2023.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida plans to replace chief cabinet secretary Matsuno: report
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to replace Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno amid allegations that Matsuno failed to report receiving over 10 million yen in unreported political funds from the ruling party's biggest faction. This move comes as the ruling Liberal Democratic Party faces mounting scrutiny over allegations lawmakers, including Matsuno and other high-profile members, may have pocketed over 100 million yen in unreported fundraising proceeds. Tokyo prosecutors are set to investigate lawmakers after the current parliament session ends on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: The fundraising scandal within the Liberal Democratic Party is another blow for Prime Minister Fumio Kishida’s unpopular administration which has seen its ratings sink below 30 per cent in recent polls.
The yen has fallen to close to a level of 152 against the US dollar in November, just short of its historic low reached last year.

With inflation having held above the Bank of Japan’s 2 per cent target for more than a year, companies have faced unprecedented pressure to compensate employees with pay hikes to retain and lure talent.

site_title: Wall Street gets ready to cash in on US$1t climate market
summary: Banks from Wall Street and the City of London are positioning themselves to capitalize on the growing carbon offset market. Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, and Barclays are building up carbon trading and finance desks to finance carbon sequestration projects, trade credits, and advise corporate clients buying offsets. The move aims to bridge the financing gap for local projects in emerging markets. According to Sonia Battikh, Citi's global head of carbon offsets trading, banks can play a crucial role in channeling money to projects that lack financial clout.

images.alt_text: epa11018996 A man inspects the Sustainability Pavilion at the Green Zone as part of the venue of the 2023 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP28) in Dubai, UAE, 09 December 2023. COP28 runs from 30 November to 12 December, and is expected to host one of the largest number of participants in the annual global climate conference as over 70,000 estimated attendees, including the member states of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), business leaders, young people, climate scientists, Indigenous Peoples and other relevant stakeholders will attend. site_title: How unhealthy are ultra-processed foods?
summary: Researchers have long warned that ultra-processed foods are linked to various health issues, but some experts argue the definition can be vague. The NOVA classification system, introduced in 2009, groups foods by processing level, with the fourth group considered ultra-processed. However, critics claim the scale can be misleading, and some ultra-processed foods, like non-dairy milks, may be healthy. A recent study showed that a diet consisting of 91% ultra-processed foods could be healthy, but experts caution that taxation or banning these foods could be regressive and affect vulnerable groups.

images.alt_text: The global food industry and agricultural markets have come under increasing scrutiny after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine pushed up prices, adding to a cost-of-living crisis.

(FILES) A woman shops for groceries at a supermarket in Monterey Park, California on October 19, 2022. The US inflation measure most closely watched by the Federal Reserve declined sharply in May, official figures showed June 30, 2029, returning to a downward trend after a jump a month earlier. Much of the slowdown was due to a sharp drop in energy prices, and food prices to a lesser extent. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)
Sustainable food is not just about where it’s grown and who grows it, but also what the final product does to the consumer.
Firms are experimenting with ever more novel ingredients in search of meat- and dairy-like properties that will attract ever more shoppers.
French blue cheese makers see red over nutrition labelling

site_title: Europe: Shares hit near 22-month highs on luxury boost
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.7% higher for the day and 1.3% up for the week, hitting its highest level since February 2022. Traders expect central banks to switch to interest rate cuts early next year, driving gains in travel and leisure stocks. Energy and miners were the worst hit, with a 2.6% drop. The rally marks the fourth consecutive week of gains, as investors anticipate a shift in monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 36,247.87, up 0.4 per cent for Friday and eking out a weekly gain.

site_title: Banyan Tree to go separate ways with China Vanke in JVs
summary: Banyan Tree, a hotel management company, will go separate ways with China Vanke's subsidiaries in joint ventures (JVs) after buying out each other's stakes. Banyan Tree will acquire stakes in two JVs for 480 million yuan (S$90.2 million) from China Vanke units, while selling its shares in another JV for 30 million yuan. The move aims to streamline strategic decision-making and enhance operational efficiency.

images.alt_text: Banyan Tree Group's net profit nearly doubles to S$981,000 for the first half of its 2023 financial year, on the back of a tourism recovery post-pandemic.

site_title: Tesla Cybertruck‘s stiff structure, sharp design raise safety concerns: experts
summary: Tesla's new Cybertruck has raised safety concerns among experts due to its stiff stainless-steel exterior and sharp design. Crash test videos of the vehicle, which Tesla live-streamed, have sparked worries that the material could cause more damage to pedestrians and cyclists in the event of a collision. Experts point to the potential for "red flags" in the crash test data, citing the heavy weight and high acceleration of the truck, which could lead to lethal outcomes for non-occupants.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, who is the richest person on the planet with a fortune of US$209 billion, owns 13 per cent of Tesla and derives the majority of his wealth from the auto company.
Shenzhen-based BYD aims to sell 3 million hybrids and EVs this year, and November’s figure lifts it to 2.67 million so far in 2023.
Tesla’s new Cybertruck on display at a Tesla store in San Diego, California, US, Nov 20, 2023.
The deliveries of the much-awaited pickup truck will begin on Nov 30.
The automaker is expected to start shipments of its revamped Model 3 compact sedan and the Blade Runner-inspired Cybertruck in the last three months of the year.
Volkswagen has pinned some of its slide in China on losing sight of the aesthetics and in-car features that were luring Chinese customers.
Tesla said sales in the July to September period reached US$23.35 billion, lower than the US$24.19 billion forecasted by analysts polled by Factset.
The new Model 3 promises a longer driving range for China.

site_title: Led by Taylor Swift’s US$1 billion tour, 2023 concerts set new record
summary: Taylor Swift's "Eras Tour" broke the US$1 billion mark in ticket sales, becoming the first to surpass this threshold in 60 dates from March to November 2023. The top 100 concert tours of 2023 generated a record US$9.17 billion in ticket sales, with total sales rising 46% from the previous year. The average revenue per concert increased by 53% to US$2.37 million, and average ticket prices rose 23% to US$130.81. Beyonce's "Renaissance Tour" came in second, with Elton John's "Farewell Yellow Brick Road Tour" at US$939 million.

images.alt_text: Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong (second from left) with KASM chairman Keith Magnus (second from right) at the Singapore Sports Hub on Dec 6, 2023.
Taylor Swift attends a premiere for Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour in Los Angeles, California, U.S., October 11, 2023. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni
“I would’ve never thought in my wildest dreams that Rockin’ would be my signature song,” Brenda Lee says in a recent interview.
Beyonce’s global run earns US$579 million.

Organisers have faced criticism after fans said they were forbidden to enter the stadium with water bottles at the concert last Friday, despite a heat index that hit 59 deg C in the Brazilian beach city that day.
Fans wait in line outside Nilton Santos stadium for the Taylor Swift concert, following the death of a fan due to the heat during the first day concert.

site_title: US job growth accelerates in November; unemployment rate drops to 3.7%
summary: US job growth accelerated in November with 199,000 jobs added, exceeding economists' forecasts. The unemployment rate dropped to 3.7%, driven by a rise in labor supply rather than layoffs. Average hourly earnings increased 0.4%, keeping the annual wage growth at 4%. The strong labor market suggests the Federal Reserve may not cut interest rates as soon as expected, with the central bank expected to keep rates unchanged next week.

images.alt_text: Nonfarm productivity, which measures hourly output per worker, increases at a 5.2 per cent annualised rate last quarter.

Representative Sara McKethan, left, hands a list of employment descriptions to a job seeker during the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Sara McKethan
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, fall 617,000 to 8.733 million on the last day of October, according to Jolts report.
Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, increases 0.2 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.7 per cent gain in September.
US GDP rises at an upwardly revised 5.2 per cent annualised pace in the third quarter, the fastest in nearly two years.

site_title: US: Stocks finish higher after strong jobs report
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 36,247.87, up 0.4% on Friday, securing a weekly gain. The US economy added 199,000 jobs in November, with the jobless rate falling to 3.7% from 3.9%. This stronger-than-expected jobs report lifted the market, with investors seeing it as a reassuring sign of a "soft-landing" for the economy. The labor market remains strong but is slightly easing, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 32.56 points, or 0.09 per cent, at the open to 36,084.82.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as upbeat jobs report dampens rate-cut hopes
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, December 8, as a strong jobs report and declining unemployment rate reduced expectations for an early interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 32.56 points, or 0.09%, to 36,084.82, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The stronger-than-expected jobs report signalled resilience in the labor market, dampening hopes for a rate cut in early 2024.

site_title: EU countries, lawmakers close to deal on AI rules, sources say
summary: EU countries and lawmakers are close to a provisional deal on rules governing artificial intelligence, according to sources. The deal comes after nearly 24-hour negotiations, with the European Commission proposing the rules two years ago. A formal announcement is expected soon, marking a significant step towards regulating AI use across the EU.

site_title: Creepy crawlies or culinary delights: The buzz around South-east Asia’s booming bug business
summary: South-east Asia's edible insects market is booming, with Thailand dominating the industry. The region's market is expected to reach US$1.58 billion by 2030, with a compound annual growth rate of 24.1%. Insects are seen as a sustainable alternative to traditional livestock, requiring less water, land, and greenhouse gas emissions. They are also highly nutritious, containing all nine essential amino acids and rich in micronutrients. Countries such as Cambodia, Laos, and Singapore are promoting insect consumption, with Singapore poised to be a leader in the region due to its technological advancements and food regulations.

images.alt_text: Kamala Shrestha along with Mana Maya Shrestha, Sita Tamang, Samjhana Shrestha and Bina Kumari Shrestha work as they feed and collect Black Soldier Fly larvae at a farm in Bhardev village on the outskirts of Lalitpur, Nepal.
While some consumers think eating insects is just gross, Japan has a rich culinary history of insects as food.

site_title: World food prices hold steady in November: FAO
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) world food price index held steady in November at 120.4 points, around October's levels. This marked a 10.7% decline from last November. Lower international cereal prices offset higher vegetable oil prices, with palm oil prices rebounding 6% and sugar prices rising 1.4%. The FAO raised its forecast for world cereal production to a record 2.823 billion metric tons.

images.alt_text: Infant milk on sale in a supermarket on 11 December 2014. Milk powder companies Abbott, Nestle, Wyeth Nutrition, FrieslandCampina and Mead Johnson attributed high prices to factors such as product innovation, nutrition research – which makers of simpler dairy products might not do as much – and rising business costs.
Food inflation XXX in October.
FILE PHOTO: A customer shops at a Carrefour supermarket in Montesson near Paris, France, September 13, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo
Workers unload sacks of onions from a truck at a wholesale market in Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, India, in April. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg
Rice, which rocketed almost 10 per cent in August, dipped 0.5 per cent last month amid low import demand, FAO said.
The agricultural and food security ministry has been instructed to step up enforcement and monitoring to curb hoarding, Anwar Ibrahim says.

site_title: Italy's Mario Draghi not interested in role of EU Commission chief
summary: Former European Central Bank president Mario Draghi is not interested in becoming the next head of the European Commission, according to a source close to him. This comes after French President Emmanuel Macron reportedly lobbied other European leaders to support Draghi for the role. The current Commission President, Ursula von der Leyen, may become the new Nato secretary general if she is not reappointed. Draghi had previously been asked by von der Leyen to develop a plan to boost the EU's economic competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Even if Macron (left) and Scholz don’t patch up their relationship, it is possible that future incumbents will see a compelling need to do so.

site_title: Climate change is costly – but so is climate policy
summary: Climate change is a costly issue, but so is climate policy. Despite 27 climate conferences, global emissions have increased, with the Covid-19 economic shutdown being the only exception. The claim that green energy is on the verge of replacing fossil fuels is exaggerated, with taxpayer-funded subsidies supporting the transition. A new study shows that pursuing net-zero emissions by 2050 would cost between $10 trillion and $43 trillion annually, equivalent to 4-18% of global GDP. Economists argue that highly ambitious climate policies are a bad deal, with phenomenally high costs and low additional benefits.

images.alt_text: A man stands near a COP28 sign in a metro station in Dubai on November 28, 2023, ahead of the United Nations climate summit. The UN chief urged world leaders to take decisive action to tackle ever-worsening climate change when they gather at the COP28 summit in Dubai starting this week. (Photo by Jewel SAMAD / AFP)
Calls to overhaul the way the banks are run in response to the climate crisis have picked up amid record extreme weather events.

A fallen saguaro cactus decays in the Sonoran Desert near Arizona, US, Aug 2. The cacti are under stress from extreme heat during Arizona’s brutal summer. Heatwaves capture the headlines but globally, cold causes far more deaths.
The second Sustainable Development Goals summit in New York. Progress on the goals is happening at less than a quarter of the pledged speed.

site_title: US consumers see brighter days ahead as inflation fears tumble
summary: US consumer sentiment surged in December, jumping 13% to 69.4, the highest since August, due to easing inflation fears. The median expectation among economists was 62.0. Inflation expectations plummeted to 3.1% from 4.5% in November, the lowest since March 2021. The Consumer Sentiment Index's current conditions gauge rose to 74.0, while the expectations index climbed to 66.4, the highest since July. This upward trend is likely to be welcomed by Federal Reserve officials, who are expected to leave interest rates unchanged at 5.25% to 5.50% amid subsiding inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: Employment gains are well above the 100,000 jobs per month needed to keep up with growth in the working age population.
The Institute for Supply Management says that its non-manufacturing PMI rises to 52.7 in November from 51.8, which was a 5-month low.
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, fall 617,000 to 8.733 million on the last day of October, according to Jolts report.
Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, increases 0.2 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.7 per cent gain in September.
US GDP rises at an upwardly revised 5.2 per cent annualised pace in the third quarter, the fastest in nearly two years.

site_title: Breitling heading in the direction of cool
summary: Breitling CEO Georges Kern has signed a five-year contract, with his own capital invested in the brand, to continue the company's revitalization efforts. Kern, who took over the brand in 2017, has transformed Breitling into a more "cool" and relaxed luxury watch brand, reflecting post-Covid societal trends. The brand's extensive collections have been given a "refresh" with brighter colors, sleeker designs, and in-house movements. Breitling's sales have jumped 25% to $1.3 billion in 2023, making it one of the world's top 10 watchmakers. Kern plans to focus on excellence and expand the brand's "upscale" offerings.

images.alt_text: The bar counter in Panerai's boutiques is the watch brand's "bestselling spot", says CEO Jean Marc Pontroué.

site_title: China says Boeing welcome to deepen development in its market
summary: China's aviation regulator has welcomed Boeing to deepen its development in the Chinese market, citing 50 years of "friendly exchanges and cooperation" between the two. Boeing's senior vice-president, Mike Fleming, expressed optimism about the company's future development in China, where the country is reportedly considering resuming purchases of its 737 Max aircraft. The move comes as China and the US are pushing for increased flights between them, with relations showing signs of thawing after months of tensions. Boeing is committed to "actively deepening cooperation" with China and providing better products for the benefit of the people of China, the US, and the world.

images.alt_text: The Boeing logo is seen on the side of a Boeing 737 MAX at the Farnborough International Airshow, in Farnborough, Britain, July 20, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Cziborra
Sources say Boeing now expects it will produce 42 of its 737s per month starting in February 2024.
Thai Airways is boosting its requirements to as many as 80 Boeing wide-body 787 Dreamliner jets.
One of the largest US exporters, Boeing has seen sales to China dry up as trade hostilities simmered.

site_title: Indonesia inflation to continue to ease in 2024 as food, energy prices decline: Bank Mandiri chief economist
summary: Indonesia's inflation is expected to continue easing in 2024 as food and energy prices decline, according to Bank Mandiri chief economist Andry Asmoro. The country's economic growth is estimated at 5.05% this year and 5.3-5.7% in 2024. The upcoming presidential and legislative elections are forecast to have a positive impact on the economy with stable consumption, lower interest rates, and higher capital expenditure. Indonesia's fiscal deficit is expected to be maintained at 2.3% of GDP in 2023, with annual GDP growth of more than 5% anticipated.

images.alt_text: Unless another candidate emerges in the coming weeks, Ganjar is widely seen as the leader of the three frontrunners.
“Hopefully, this decade can be seen as an acceleration toward Golden Indonesia 2045,” says Indonesian President Joko Widodo.

site_title: Condo maintenance fees on the rise, set to go higher as costs climb
summary: Maintenance fees at private condominiums in Singapore have increased by up to 30% over the past decade, with some owners paying up to S$2,000 a month. The rise in fees is attributed to higher labor, material, and utility costs, as well as increased wages for lower-wage sectors. The progressive wage model and higher electricity and water tariffs also contribute to the rising costs. Developers estimate monthly maintenance fees for new projects, but actual fees may be higher due to unexpected costs and delays.

images.alt_text: Margins are at a point where one could question the rationale for continuing the Singapore private housing business.
Construction cost for residential apartments is up 26% between 2021 to 2023, says Turner & Townsend.
Facade of Raffles Town Club, whose lease at Plymouth Avenue will not be renewed, with the site being slated for future housing development.

site_title: Perennial Holdings launches its brands in its S$1 billion Tianjin development
summary: Perennial Holdings has launched its S$1 billion development in Tianjin, China, featuring eldercare, medical, and hotel facilities. The 3.5 million square-foot Perennial International Healthcare and Business City Tianjin includes an eldercare home, assisted living apartments, a nursing hospital, three branded hospitals, and four hotels with 960 rooms. This integrated healthcare-centric development is one of the first large-scale projects in China, offering a range of services and facilities under one roof.

images.alt_text: The development will comprise 200 units of assisted-living apartments, a nursing home with 100 beds, a wellness clubhouse and a geriatric care centre.

site_title: Eurozone yields rise as US jobs growth accelerates
summary: Eurozone bond yields rose on Friday after the US economy added more jobs than expected in November, dampening expectations for the Federal Reserve's rate cuts in 2024. Germany's 10-year yield rose 7.5 basis points to 2.272%, its highest level since April, while Italy's 10-year sovereign bond yield increased 12 basis points to 4.07%. Markets expect a 70% chance of the European Central Bank loosening policy in March 2024, with some analysts skeptical about the policy path, citing concerns about inflation and debt sustainability.

images.alt_text: Following ECB official Isabel Schnabel’s comments, Germany’s 10-year bond yield has fallen to its lowest level since June, to 2.279 per cent.

site_title: Thailand to raise minimum wage by 2.37% from Jan 1
summary: Thailand's minimum wage will increase by 2.37% starting January 1, to between 330-370 baht (S$12.51-S$14.03) per day, short of the 400 baht promised by the ruling party. The decision was made by a committee of government representatives, private companies, and labor groups. Permanent Secretary of Labour Pairoj Chotikasathien stated that the adjustment aims to allow workers to achieve a standard of living based on economic conditions and suitable for businesses. Another wage increase is planned for 2024 to reach 400 baht.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 2.8 per cent this year, but PM Srettha Thavisin has a target of 5 per cent annual growth.

site_title: Ossia International to leave SGX watch list on Dec 11
summary: Ossia International, a luxury-goods retailer and distributor, has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to exit the watch list, effective December 11, 2023. The company was placed on the list in 2017 due to consecutive pre-tax losses and low market capitalization. After multiple extensions, Ossia International reported a profit and earnings for the six months to September, meeting the criteria for removal. The exit is seen as a positive step to improve the quality of listed companies in Singapore and promote investor confidence.

site_title: Honeywell boosts building safety ops with US$4.95 billion deal for Carrier unit
summary: Honeywell has agreed to buy Carrier's security unit for $4.95 billion in cash, bolstering its building safety business. The deal, Honeywell's largest under new CEO Vimal Kapur, will provide access to Carrier's brands, including electronic locks and cloud-based lock makers. The acquisition is expected to close before the end of 2024 and be cash-earnings per share accretive to Honeywell. The move aims to counter weak demand for Honeywell's building technologies business, which has been struggling with low revenue growth.

images.alt_text: The workplace is a new battlefront against domestic violence, argues SCWO CEO Koh Yan Ping.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment expects ‘significant’ fall in net profit for FY2023
summary: CapitaLand Investment expects a "significant" decrease in net profit for FY2023 due to dampening macro-economic sentiment, higher interest rates, and geopolitical tensions. The company anticipates fair value losses on its portfolio of investment properties, primarily in China, Australia, and Europe, but notes that core operating earnings and operating cash flow remain stable. CapitaLand Investment will release its financial results for FY2023 in February 2024, after which the company's shares closed unchanged at S$3.10.

images.alt_text: Loh has lowered CLI's earnings estimates for FY2023 to FY2025 by 7 to 14 per cent to factor in higher interest costs in 2023 and 2024, lower Ebitda margins and revenue growth for the fund management business, as well as a slower recovery of its China properties.
CapitaLand will introduce its shopping rewards programmes CapitaStar and eCapitaVoucher at Kallang Wave Mall.
CapitaLand Investment registers a dip in 9M revenue.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 8)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong of Singapore met Chinese Finance Minister Lan Fo'an in Beijing, discussing collaboration areas. Despite China's slowing growth, Singapore remains open to collaboration, with opportunities for mutual work. Singapore secured its first carbon credit transfer deal at COP28, and its cashless economy continues to progress despite recent bank outages. The Straits Times Index rose 1.2% on Friday, driven by the carbon credit deal and a strong performance in the US market.

site_title: Key UK mortgage rate drops below 6% for first time since June
summary: The average two-year UK fixed-rate mortgage dropped below 6% for the first time since June, standing at 5.99%, according to Moneyfacts Group. The Bank of England's double pause in interest rates has contributed to the decline. This development has provided a glimmer of hope that the worst of Britain's home loans crunch may be over, with households facing declining borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
The S&P Global/CIPS UK construction Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) edges down to 45.5 from October’s reading of 45.6, well below the 50.0 growth threshold.
The ONS household cost index shows the average mortgage borrower having a 9.3 per cent personal rate of inflation, far above the headline 6.7 per cent consumer prices index for September.

epa10695346 A picture taken with a drone shows houses in east London, Britain, 16 June 2023. House prices across the UK fell by 1 percent on average, first annual decline since December 2012, according to Halifax Mortgages. UK mortgage rates are heading up towards 6 percent interest rates and higher borrowing costs are adding to the burden on homeowners with the biggest mortgage squeeze since 1991.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN

site_title: Cordlife probe could take 6 more weeks: Health Minister Ong Ye Kung
summary: Health Minister Ong Ye Kung says investigations into the Cordlife cord blood banking company's shortcomings should take another 6 weeks. The Ministry of Health is supervising Cordlife's activities and inventory management, and ensuring the company implements processes in line with regulations. Parents who requested a transfer of their cord-blood units to another bank are advised to wait until the full impact of the breaches is known. The ministry will also take necessary regulatory and enforcement actions against Cordlife, depending on the probe's findings.

images.alt_text: Cordlife says its storage operations ‘not’ impacted by accredited bodies’ suspension, probe
康盛人生将脐带血干细胞低温保存，有助长期保存干细胞的活力与功能。
Cordlife has been barred for six months from collecting, testing, processing and storing new cord-blood or tissue samples, as well as from running new test types for patients.
The group, as one of the five private cord blood banks in Asia, has been barred from collecting, testing, processing and storing new cord-blood or tissue samples.
Cordlife Group said that it will continue to store affected cord blood units for clients, as they “may still be valuable in light of developments in the field of cell and gene therapy.”

site_title: Forecasts of China’s slowing growth have no impact on collaboration with Singapore: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said forecasts of China's slowing growth have no impact on the country's collaboration with Singapore, citing opportunities in areas like manufacturing, logistics, and renewable energy. The two countries are set to implement a 30-day visa-free travel arrangement, which will facilitate greater travel and benefit businesses, academics, students, and tourists. Wong also highlighted the potential for Singapore to learn from China's advancements in green technologies, with a new collaboration framework announced for Tianjin Eco-City.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong meets with his Chinese counterpart, Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang, in Tianjin, China on Dec 7.
Singapore and China signed more than 20 Memoranda of Understanding and agreements at the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Chinese vice-premier Ding Xuexiang meet in Tianjin, China to co-chair the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.

site_title: Tesla’s Nordic fallout deepens with court loss, widening embargo
summary: Tesla faces a deepening crisis in the Nordic region after a Swedish court ruled against the company's labour dispute, blocking the delivery of cars to customers in the country's fifth-largest market. The court found Tesla did not provide sufficient arguments on why the company would suffer harm from parcels not being handed out. This ruling comes as a union in Finland announced sympathy action against Tesla. CEO Elon Musk has called the Swedish labour action "insane," further exacerbating investor concern.

images.alt_text: A banner reading "We demand a collective agreement" outside the Tesla service centre in Segeltorp, Sweden, on Dec 5. The labour dispute has spread to Denmark and Norway, where unions have warned they will block shipments of Tesla cars.

site_title: UK households more upbeat on inflation and rates peaking
summary: British households are becoming more optimistic about inflation and interest rates, according to a Bank of England survey. Consumers expect prices to rise by 3.3% over the next 12 months, the lowest rate in two years. This suggests that the central bank's "higher-for-longer" messaging is taking effect, with fewer people expecting rate hikes. The survey's findings indicate a shift in public perception, with households becoming more upbeat about the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England (BoE) building, the BoE confirmed to raise interest rates to 1.75%, in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska//File Photo
Inflation expectations in five to 10 years’ time pick up to 3.5 per cent in October from 3.3 per cent in September.
Britain’s economy is still suffering from weak growth.

Dave Ramsden, deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The Bank of England hiked interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis and warned the economy is on course to shrink under pressure from double-digit inflation. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
Despite lingering cost-of-living pressures, GfK’s headline consumer confidence index was stronger than anticipated in November, increasing to -24 from October’s three-month low of -30.

site_title: Softening consumption may delay BOJ's exit from easy policy
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers are concerned about recent signs of flagging consumption, which may delay their exit from easy monetary policy. Despite Governor Kazuo Ueda's comments suggesting an "even more challenging" situation in the year-end and next year, the BOJ has not signaled an imminent policy shift. The central bank is instead focusing on pulling short-term interest rates out of negative territory and meeting its inflation target, which is running above 2%. The timing of a potential rate hike remains uncertain, with some analysts predicting a rate hike in June next year.

images.alt_text: Household spending in Q3 is down with income stagnant, based on internal affairs ministry data.

site_title: Putin to run again for president in March 2024
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024, allowing him to potentially extend his rule until at least 2036. Putin, 71, has led Russia since the turn of the century and has won four presidential ballots. The upcoming election is expected to be heavily influenced by the ongoing Ukraine conflict, with analysts noting that Putin will likely seek a large mandate to conceal domestic discord. Despite opposition and human rights concerns, Putin's popularity remains high, and he faces little major competition in the election.

images.alt_text: epa10717510 Russian President Vladimir Putin tours an exhibition of perspective Russian brands before the plenary session of the Strong Ideas for a New Time forum, in Moscow, Russia, 29 June 2023.  EPA-EFE/GAVRIIL GRIGOROV/SPUTNIK/KREMLIN POOL MANDATORY CREDIT

site_title: Genting Singapore’s Resorts World casino fined S$2.25 million for due diligence lapses
summary: Genting Singapore's Resorts World Sentosa has been fined S$2.25 million by the Gambling Regulatory Authority for failing to conduct proper customer due diligence checks from 2016 to 2019. The lapses occurred when employees collected cash deposits of S$5,000 or more and failed to establish the identities of third-party depositors. The operator has taken corrective actions, including revoking an employee's license and conducting a review of its corporate culture. The fine is expected to have a minimal impact on Genting Singapore's financials for the year ending December 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: Few shoppers were seen at The Forum at Resorts World Sentosa on 12 February 2020.
Genting Singapore said that Resorts World Sentosa, which is wholly owned by the group, has “continued to benefit from the sustained recovery of travel and tourism.”

site_title: Indonesia’s GoTo in talks with TikTok over potential e-commerce partnership
summary: Indonesia's tech giant GoTo is in talks with TikTok for a potential e-commerce partnership. The talks follow Indonesia's October ban on online shopping on social media platforms, which led to TikTok closing its e-commerce service TikTok Shop. GoTo has refuted reports of TikTok's parent company ByteDance acquiring a 50% stake in the company, stating that discussions are "still continuing" and do not include a takeover plan. No final decision has been reached yet.

images.alt_text: ByteDance’s ultimate goal is to revive its online shopping service in South-east Asia’s largest retail arena.
TikTok is in the process of obtaining an e-commerce permit from Indonesia’s government, state news agency Antara reported, citing the deputy trade minister.
FILE PHOTO: TikTok app logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The funds will support e-commerce, education and community initiatives over the next three years, Chew says.

site_title: STI rises 1.2% despite mixed regional showing
summary: Singapore shares ended Friday in the black, with the Straits Times Index gaining 1.2% to 3,110.73. Advancers led decliners 357 to 215, with offshore and marine company Seatrium jumping 7.9% and three local banks ending higher. However, property developer UOL retreated 0.3%. Regional markets showed mixed performances, with South Korea's Kospi Composite Index rising 1%, while Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 1.7%.

images.alt_text:
wcvtac - むらゆき🐈❄VLiver😈 (Murayuki) – VLiver performance

Credit VTAC

site_title: Microsoft’s partnership with OpenAI facing UK scrutiny
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is seeking views on whether Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI, the tech giant's largest backer, could result in UK competition issues. The CMA will examine if the balance of power between the two firms has shifted, potentially giving one side more control. The move comes after a governance meltdown and a non-voting observer role for Microsoft on OpenAI's board. The CMA's investigation follows a recent approval of Microsoft's acquisition of Activision Blizzard, marking a shift in scrutiny for the tech giant.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit issues S$90 million floating rate notes
summary: Keppel DC Reit issued S$90 million floating rate notes with a maturity date of Dec 3, 2026, as part of its S$2 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. The notes have an interest rate based on the compounded daily Singapore Overnight Rate Average plus an agreed spread, and will be unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by the trustee. The net proceeds will be used for financing or refinancing acquisitions, development works, and general working capital. The issuance is subject to conditions, including the appointment of the Reit manager and replacement or substitute manager.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit’s data centre in Northern Virginia. The Reit is one of four truststhat maintained double digit total return gains in the year to date till end November

site_title: Bank of England to hold its line against rate cut talk
summary: The Bank of England is expected to hold interest rates at a 15-year high on December 14, according to economists in a Reuters poll. The BOE will likely maintain its "hawkish" stance against rate cuts, despite other central banks signaling a possible shift. The European Central Bank and US Federal Reserve are also expected to keep rates on hold. Analysts attribute the BOE's decision to the persistence of high inflation in the UK, which remains above the 2% target.

images.alt_text: epa10783058 Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey gestures while speaking during a press conference at the Bank of England in London, Britain, 03 August 2023. UK mortgage owners are bracing for a further increase in interests rates 03 August. The Bank of England is set to raise interests rates by a quarter percent in a bid to being down inflation.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Japan's 10-year JGB yield jumps on speculation of imminent BOJ policy shift
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield jumped to 0.8% earlier in the session, its highest since November 16, amid speculation that the Bank of Japan may end its negative interest rate policy soon. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda stated the central bank anticipates a challenging year-end and next year, fueling expectations of a policy shift. The yen surged to a multi-month high against the dollar, and yields on other maturities fell, with the 20-year JGB yield at 1.54%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

The results come in a week where financial markets were jolted by the prospect of an even earlier end to sub-zero borrowing costs as traders reacted to comments from BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda and one of his deputies.

site_title: Sabana Reit partners Keppel unit to install rooftop solar panels at five more properties
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has partnered with Keppel unit to install rooftop solar panels at five properties in Singapore, with an estimated solar generation capacity of 2.4 megawatt-peak. The installations are expected to reduce over 27,000 tonnes of carbon emissions and power over 800 three-room HDB flats annually. The project is the second phase of Sabana's sustainability partnership, with the Reit aiming to have majority of its multi-tenanted properties covered by renewable energy by Q4 2024.

images.alt_text: Mercantile Pacific Asia's warehouse in Singapore. With around 200 employees, the Singapore facility has the capacity to handle 200,000 units of used devices a year. PHOTO: MERCANTILE PACIFIC ASIA

The trustee is seeking, among others, possession of the premises in Penjuru Lane as well as outstanding fixed rent, land rent, property tax and late payment interest of around S$2.1 million.

site_title: Country Garden bondholders meet Shenzhen Exchange over payment
summary: Country Garden Holdings' bondholders met with the Shenzhen Stock Exchange to discuss repayment options amid the company's struggles to meet debt obligations due to cratering property prices. Some bondholders have registered their put option to seek early repayment, but may choose not to exercise it, extending the bond's CDS expiration until December 2024. The meeting highlights Country Garden's debt woes, which have epitomized China's property crisis, and raises questions about the value of Chinese developers' CDS products.

images.alt_text: An Oct 18, 2023 photo of a Country Garden project in Suqian, Jiangsu province.
The inclusion of distressed builders such as Country Garden,  underscores regulators’ shifting stance towards some of the nation’s biggest private developers as the property crisis deepens.

site_title: Issue 78: Science, policy and fossil fuels; S-E Asia goes big on transition finance
summary: COP28 negotiations have failed to reach an agreement on a "phase out" or "phase down" of fossil fuels, with COP28 president Sultan Al Jaber stating there is no scientific basis for a phase out. However, a report by the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) found that the median share of primary energy supply from fossil fuels in 1.5-degree pathways is about 33%, down from 83% in 2020. The report highlights the importance of transitioning to renewable energy sources and notes that fossil fuel carbon capture and storage costs the most and reduces the least emissions.

images.alt_text: COP28 president Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber speaks during a press conference at the United Nations climate summit in Dubai on December 4, 2023. The Emirati president of the UN's COP28 talks said on December 4 he respects climate science, after a leaked video showed him declaring that no science says a fossil fuel phaseout will help achieve climate goals. site_title: Trafficking for cyber fraud an increasingly globalised crime: Interpol
summary: Interpol reported that human trafficking for cyber fraud is becoming a globalized crime, with scam centers emerging in Latin America and victims sourced from other continents. The coordinated operation in October led to hundreds of arrests, demonstrating the "expanding geographical footprint" of the crime. Most cases originate in South-east Asia, where hundreds of thousands of people are trafficked to work in scam centers, generating billions of US dollars in revenue annually. The phenomenon is spreading, with new scam centers appearing in Latin America, and victims are being confined under armed guard and taught to defraud banks.

images.alt_text: Okta’s shares slumped in October after the company said that the breach allowed some hackers to view files uploaded by certain clients.
Earlier this month, leading AI developers agreed to work with governments to test new frontier models before they are released to help manage the risks of the rapidly developing technology.
The Australian government’s announcement comes after several damaging cyberattacks on major Australian businesses and infrastructure in the past year.

site_title: Converting NYC office buildings to homes can help the environment
summary: A new report by Arup found that converting 220 NYC office buildings to housing could reduce carbon emissions by 54% by 2050, saving up to 11 million tons of CO2. The report suggests that this could be achieved by reusing existing buildings, installing energy-efficient facades, and upgrading to electric heating and cooling systems. The proposal aligns with Mayor Eric Adams' plan to change the city's zoning code and Local Law 97, which aims for zero emissions by 2050. However, property owners are hesitant due to high conversion costs and lack of tax incentives.

images.alt_text: Many agents across the country are facing a slower year as mortgage rates hovering above 7 per cent push some would-be buyers to the sidelines.

site_title: Everton’s US buyer leaves trail of questions over its finances
summary: Everton's US buyer, 777 Partners, is facing scrutiny over its finances as the Premier League considers approving the $700 million takeover. The firm has been accused of financial mismanagement, including delayed paychecks and unpaid bonuses, and has been probed by the US Attorney's Office over money laundering allegations. Despite assurances from the firm's founder, Josh Wander, that it has a strong underlying business performance, concerns over 777 Partners' ability to manage Everton's finances have raised questions about the future of the English Premier League club.

images.alt_text: Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong (second from left) with KASM chairman Keith Magnus (second from right) at the Singapore Sports Hub on Dec 6, 2023.

Lionel Messi made an instant impact on Inter Miami’s fortunes, playing a pivotal role in helping the team win the expanded Leagues Cup, a cross-border competition for teams from MLS and Mexico’s top flight.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei suffers worst week since September on hawkish BOJ bets
summary: Japan's Nikkei index suffered its worst week since September, falling 3.36% for the week, due to speculation about an imminent end to the Bank of Japan's decade-old stimulus measures. The yen surged 2% overnight, hitting a four-month high, eroding the value of overseas revenue for automakers and exporters. Toyota Group companies were among the biggest laggards, with losses ranging from 3.69% to 4.51%. Despite the decline, the Nikkei remains up nearly 24% this year.

site_title: Two-thirds of BOJ watchers expect end of negative rate regime by April
summary: BOJ watchers anticipate the end of Japan's negative interest rate regime by April, with over two-thirds of economists expecting the move. A survey found half of respondents predict the rate cut in April, up from 29% in October. The BOJ is expected to retain its current policies, with the focus on whether Governor Kazuo Ueda will signal a policy shift. Economists also expect a short-term rate hike as the next policy step, with 78% predicting this move.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda says the central bank has several options on which interest rates to target once it pulls short-term borrowing costs out of negative territory.

Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, Oct. 31, 2023. The Bank of Japan further loosened its grip on government bond yields while continuing to stick with its negative interest rate in a decision that prompted a retreat in the yen. site_title: Lotus Eletre S review: When ACBC does AC/DC
summary: The Lotus Eletre S, a large electric SUV, has been reviewed for its impressive performance, refinement, and grandiosity. With 603 horsepower, it boasts a gentle yet powerful acceleration, precise steering, and a comfortable ride. The interior features a lavish cockpit area, plenty of screens, and a plush, recycled-fibre trim. Although its size can be overwhelming, the Eletre's handling and centre of gravity provide a unique driving experience. With a range of up to 600 km and fast charging capabilities, the Eletre is a compelling option for those considering an electric vehicle, potentially rivaling luxury SUVs like the Bentley Bentayga.

images.alt_text: 2023 Tesla Model 3 review: Not half better

site_title: Nikki Haley’s rise in the primaries
summary: Nikki Haley, a former South Carolina governor and US ambassador, is gaining momentum in the Republican presidential primaries, running neck-and-neck with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis in Iowa and ahead of DeSantis in New Hampshire and South Carolina. Despite her centrist views and support from the Republican establishment, Haley faces challenges in winning over Trump's base of blue-collar workers. She may still be a long shot to beat Democratic President Joe Biden in the general election, but her emergence as a viable candidate could force Trump out of the race, allowing her to accumulate convention delegates and potentially challenge him in key states.

images.alt_text: Former South Carolina governor and former US ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley announces her run for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination at a campaign event in Charleston, South Carolina, Feb 15, 2023.
Nikki Haley, former Republican Governor of South Carolina and US Ambassador to the United Nations, announces her bid for the Republican presidential nomination, in Charleston, S.C. on Feb 15, 2023.

site_title: Singapore scores first carbon credit transfer deal at COP28
summary: Singapore has signed its first carbon credit transfer agreement with Papua New Guinea, allowing Singapore to offset up to 5% of its taxable emissions from 2024. The agreement is aligned with Article 6 of the Paris Agreement and will enable Singapore to purchase carbon credits from Papua New Guinea to reduce its emissions. The deal also includes a clause requiring project developers to cancel 2% of the carbon credits and contribute to climate adaptation in Papua New Guinea.

images.alt_text: GenZero, a Temasek-owned investment platform company, announced on Jun 8, 2023 that it would invest in a restoration project in Ghana aiming to generate carbon credits with corresponding adjustments.
