site_title: Swedish housing-price decline confirmed by broker data
summary: Sweden's housing prices have resumed a decline, falling 1% from the prior month in November, according to data from Svensk Maklarstatistik. This marks the second weakening of the market this year, following a period of stabilization. The market's decline is attributed to rising borrowing costs and inflation above target, which has reduced households' spending power. Economists expect prices to continue declining, with a total drop of 15% from peak to trough, and a sharp slowdown in housing construction, weighing heavily on the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Sweden’s construction market has been severely hit by rising rates and higher input costs, which in turn is weighing down the country’s economic growth.

Residential apartment blocks in Stockholm, Sweden, on Tuesday, June 13, 2023. Swedish households are becoming more optimistic about the development in the housing market, according to a survey from the country’s largest bank. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: 17Live tumbles 19% in mainboard debut after VTAC de-Spac
summary: 17Live Group, a live-streaming platform, listed on the Singapore Exchange with its shares tumbling 18.8% to S$3.15 on its first trading day following a business combination with Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation (VTAC). The company's losses widened to US$118.2 million in the first half of 2023, driven by a 24.7% drop in revenue. VTAC's cornerstone investor, Fullerton Fund Management, redeemed its 2.6 million shares, grossing about S$13 million. The listing marks Singapore's first completed de-Spac transaction and 17Live's first listing on the SGX.

images.alt_text: The number of outstanding shares to calculate redepmtion price includes the shares held by Venezio and the sponsor Vertex Venture Holdings, but excludes the promote shares, says VTAC.

The Spac’s shareholders are due to meet at 2 pm on Friday to vote on the business combination with e-commerce streaming company 17Live.  If the proposed combination does not pass, the redemption requests will be cancelled.
The acquisition of 17Live by VTAC could be one of the most important new listings to hit the Singapore market in a long while

site_title: Fed up with poor pay, Vietnam workers turn to TikTok
summary: Vietnam's young workers are turning to TikTok to escape low-paying jobs, with many finding success as social commerce influencers. The country's growing cadre of TikTok livestreamers, including 23-year-old Vi Thi Anh, earn significantly more hawking food products to thousands of followers. Between June and September, over 118,000 people lost their jobs in the garment and footwear sector. Experts say online selling offers a way to ease the worry of being laid off, with nearly 80% of Vietnam's 100 million people having internet access and a high percentage of Gen Z using TikTok.

images.alt_text: While TikTok Shop is fast emerging as a serious contender against incumbent e-commerce majors such as Shopee and Lazada in South-east Asia, Momentum Works also sees TikTok competing with Amazon in the US and Middle East.

site_title: More people in hospital with Covid-19 as infections climb to highest number in Singapore in 2023
summary: Covid-19 infections in Singapore have reached the highest number this year, with 32,035 cases diagnosed in the week ending Dec 2. Hospitalizations and intensive care cases have also increased, with 225 daily hospitalizations and four ICU cases. The Health Ministry reassures that the numbers are not as high as during the pandemic and urges people to stay home if unwell, keep up-to-date vaccinations, and exercise social responsibility. The ministry expects the numbers to rise further, but hospital capacity will be preserved for those who truly need acute care.

site_title: White House open to new asylum limits for Ukraine aid: source
summary: The White House is open to heightening initial asylum screenings and expanding a "safe third country" provision to deny asylum to migrants who pass through another country en route to the US. The Biden administration is considering new restrictions to secure $20 billion in military aid for Ukraine and Israel in a supplemental funding bill. The White House and Congress are racing to strike a deal that would pair border security measures with military aid, with a bipartisan group of senators discussing a numerical limitation on asylum claims and a fast-track deportation process.

images.alt_text: “There is no magical pot of funding available to meet this moment, we are out of money – and nearly out of time,” says Shalanda Young, director of Office of Management and Budget.
US Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer holds a press conference after the Senate passed a continuing resolution to avoid a shutdown of the federal government, in Washington, US, Nov 15, 2023.

House Speaker Mike Johnson walks to his office after a vote on legislation to keep federal funding flowing into early 2024 on Capitol Hill. With many Republicans refusing to back more government spending, Democrats supplied the bulk of the votes.

site_title: Hong Kong's property downturn may yet save century-old townhouse
summary: A century-old Hong Kong townhouse is up for sale at US$18 million, potentially saving it from demolition due to the city's property downturn. The four-story, neo-classical building survived Allied bombing runs and the demolition wave of the 1970s and '80s, but demand for redevelopment has collapsed. The property, which includes a basement and lower floors, is being marketed as a boutique hotel or converted into apartments, with discussions ongoing. The townhouse's history dates back to the 1920s and has been home to Lee Yuet, a retired government architect, who fled Japan's invasion during WWII.

images.alt_text: Unauthorised construction has long been an issue in Hong Kong, but successive administrations have done little to tackle the problem.

New World, which has one of the highest debt ratios among its peers after a years-long expansion spree, had US$8.4 billion dollars worth of outstanding bonds before it launched the tender offer for seven of its bonds.

site_title: India central bank holds rate as focus stays on inflation
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) left its benchmark repurchase rate unchanged at 6.5% for the fifth consecutive time, aligning with analyst expectations. The decision aims to manage inflation risks, particularly from food prices, and is based on the prediction of faster economic growth in the third-largest economy. The RBI also maintained its policy stance of "withdrawal of accommodation," indicating that interest rates may remain higher for longer. The decision was seen as a stable move, with stocks advancing 0.4% and the rupee and government bonds trading flat.

images.alt_text: India’s economy expands 7.6 per cent in the September quarter.

While credit growth is accelerating, banks and non bank finance companies (NBFCs) need to ensure lending to individual categories is “sustainable”, The Reserve Bank of India governor Shaktikanta Das says.
With its large and relatively youthful population, India could benefit from a powerful “demographic dividend” in the coming years.
India’s retail inflation eased in October to a four-month low of 4.87 per cent, edging closer to the central bank’s target of 4 per cent.

site_title: Singapore’s cashless march continues despite bank outages
summary: Singapore's push towards a cashless society has been accelerated by recent banking outages, but the momentum remains intact. Despite disruptions, consumers have been advised to carry some cash as a backup, and experts believe the growth and resiliency of cashless payments are key factors in the country's progress. Local consumers rely heavily on credit and debit cards, making up 57% of electronic payments, and the proportion of cash at point-of-sale transactions is expected to fall further to 13% by 2026. However, smaller merchants and experts emphasize the need for greater inclusion and alternative channels to ensure the success of digital payments.

images.alt_text: DBS will also be allowed to acquire new business ventures during this period, or reduce the size of its branch and ATM networks in Singapore.

site_title: ChatGPT needs more time to localise for different countries and cultures: OpenAI CEO
summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman stated that ChatGPT needs more time to adapt to diverse country and cultural needs, acknowledging the company's "unnaturally fast growth." Altman emphasized the need for patience as OpenAI navigates compliance with local laws in various countries. He also highlighted the challenges of making ChatGPT work effectively in non-English languages, particularly in Vietnam, where OpenAI has recently opened-sourced its PhoGPT model.

images.alt_text: The large language model could eventually be used as the basis of various text-to-speech or text-to-image generative programmes.

site_title: Nvidia strikes deal with Malaysia’s YTL Power to develop AI infrastructure
summary: Nvidia has partnered with YTL Power International to develop AI infrastructure in Malaysia, strengthening the country's fast-growing AI ecosystem and semiconductor manufacturing power. The first phase of the project is expected to be operational by mid-2024, with the companies collaborating on building Malaysia's fastest supercomputers using Nvidia AI chips. YTL Power will also utilize Nvidia's AI cloud computing platform to build a large language model in Malay. The partnership aims to establish Malaysia as a significant hub for computing infrastructure in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Nvidia will deliver a new set of products for the Chinese market that’s in line with the latest rules coming from Washington, Jensen Huang says.
Nvidia is looking to potentially make "large investments" in artificial intelligence in Singapore, said CEO Jensen Huang.

site_title: China to spur domestic demand, economic recovery in 2024
summary: China plans to spur domestic demand and consolidate economic recovery in 2024 by implementing a prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy. The Politburo, chaired by President Xi Jinping, aims to enhance economic vitality, prevent risks, and improve social expectations. The country will also promote effective economic growth and quality improvement.

images.alt_text: A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: DHL Express US air hub workers strike during holiday rush
summary: Over 1,100 DHL Express workers at the US air hub in Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport went on strike on November 7 to protest unfair labor practices and stalled contract talks. The strike threatens to delay packages during the peak holiday shipping season. DHL Express has deployed replacement staff and plans to move flights to other locations to minimize disruption. The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has filed unfair labor practices with the National Labor Relations Board and is prosecuting the company civilly.

images.alt_text: The Teamsters union representing US workers at United Parcel Service says UPS laid off roughly three dozen specialist and administrative workers at its Centennial hub in Louisville, Kentucky.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades Japan Foods to ‘neutral’ as operational costs stay elevated
summary: RHB downgraded Japan Foods to "neutral" from "buy" due to the company's H1 2024 core earnings falling below estimates amid elevated operating costs. The research team attributed the higher costs to delayed inflation and rapid expansion in store count. RHB also cut its target price by a third to S$0.30, citing the stock is trading at 13 times its ex-cash earnings.

images.alt_text: Japan Foods chairman and CEO Takahashi Kenichi says the higher capital expenditure and operating expenses are in line with the group's expanded business activities.
RHB Research lowers its price target for Japan Foods' but expects the company's sales outlook to be positive.

site_title: Attractive income opportunities for uncertain markets
summary: US fixed income yields have risen, making them attractive despite restrictive monetary policy. The Federal Reserve's rate hikes, although significant, may have been behind the curve in tackling inflation. The pause in hikes may be due to the lack of banking stress and the Fed's understanding of regional banks' collapse. Bond yields remain high, potentially doing the work of the Fed, and may remain so through year-end. This could lead to a continued focus on fixed income versus equities, with high-quality fixed income and high-quality dividend stocks preferred.

images.alt_text: Berkshire Hathaway vice chair Charlie Munger, one of the world’s most revered investors, had many memorable rants over the years on the ills of the investing world.

While parts of the stock market have fared well during the first quarter of 2023, the writer believes there are more existing headwinds than tailwinds for equities, and the economic background remains uncertain.

site_title: Maybank appoints wealth management head Alvin Lee as Singapore CEO
summary: Maybank appoints Alvin Lee as its new Singapore CEO, effective January 1, 2024. Lee, who has led the bank's community financial services and wealth management, will oversee the bank's entire operations in Singapore. He succeeds Dr. John Lee Hin Hock, who retires at the end of the year. Lee's appointment is expected to steer Maybank Singapore towards impactful results locally and regionally, according to the bank's president and group CEO Khairussaleh Ramli.

images.alt_text: UOB Kay Hian expects Maybank to report RM2.7 billion in fourth-quarter net profit.
Maybank targets to achieve a return on equity of between 10.5 per cent and 11 per cent for FY2023.

“We have chosen Singapore as our offshore hub for our Islamic wealth management given the position of Singapore as a wealth management player not just in the region but also globally,” says John Chong, Maybank’s Group CEO of Community Financial Services.

site_title: Sugar isn’t a harmless pleasure. It’s time to acknowledge this
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) call for countries to increase taxes on sugary drinks has sparked debate in Singapore, where lower-sugar drinks are already being marketed as a healthier choice. Singapore's Health Promotion Board (HPB) has given a milk drink with no added sugar a "D" grade, while its chocolate-flavored counterpart received a "B" grade, despite both having only milk as an ingredient. Experts argue that taxes must be accompanied by education campaigns and that Singapore should reconsider its stance on sugary drinks, as excessive sugar consumption is linked to various health issues.

images.alt_text: Sustainable food is not just about where it’s grown and who grows it, but also what the final product does to the consumer.
Throughout the carbonated-beverage business, from Diet Coke and Coke Zero Sugar, to Diet Pepsi and Diet Dr Pepper, aspartame is used to provide calorie-free sweetness.

“Coca-Cola has one of the best production and distribution systems globally... who have successfully navigated plenty of hurdles in the past, like sugar taxes and reformulations associated with that,” says Charlie Higgs, an associate partner at Redburn.
The taxes on junk food and sweetened beverages are forecast to generate 76 billion pesos in additional revenue during the first year, says Philippines’ Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno.

site_title: Japan’s Q3 GDP falls faster than first estimates as consumption sags
summary: Japan's Q3 GDP fell faster than initially estimated, driven by a decline in household spending and stagnant income. Consumer and business spending both shrank, leading to a decrease in GDP. Real wages and household spending continued to fall in October, with prolonged inflation discouraging shoppers. Economists expect weakness in personal consumption to persist due to declining real disposable income.

images.alt_text: The lacklustre economy may give the Bank of Japan a reason to delay any policy shift away from its massive monetary easing stance.
Fumio Kishida has already opted for more spending to try and support consumers and firms amid a continuing drop in his approval ratings.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Friday, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending at 3,090.02. The US Nasdaq Composite finished 1.4% higher, supported by tech stocks. Local banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also rose. In contrast, European shares slipped due to data showing Germany's industrial sector may continue to drag on the economy.

images.alt_text: Thomson Medical shares closed flat at S$0.056 on Thursday, before the news.

site_title: Some shops run out of ART kits as Covid-19 cases rise in Singapore
summary: Singapore is experiencing a surge in Covid-19 cases, with the estimated number of local infections doubling to 22,094 in the week of Nov 19 to Nov 25. As a result, some pharmacies and stores, including FairPrice, Guardian, and 7-Eleven, have run out of antigen rapid test (ART) kits, with restocking schedules being met with uncertainty. The Ministry of Health attributed the surge to the year-end travelling season and waning population immunity. Retailers are working to ensure sufficient ART kits are available, but stock levels remain a concern.

images.alt_text: Life and health reinsurance is buoyed by robust fundamentals and bright spots in the Asia-Pacific region, where several emerging markets are experiencing rapid population growth, a rising middle class, and consistent economic growth, said market watchers.

site_title: More than 10 million people have signed up for X in December, CEO says
summary: X, formerly Twitter, has seen over 10 million new sign-ups in December, according to CEO Linda Yaccarino. This comes as major brands, including Apple and Disney, pause their marketing campaigns due to concerns over the platform's content. X risks losing $75 million in advertising revenue by the end of the year. Billionaire owner Elon Musk has faced criticism for his handling of antisemitism and hate speech on the platform. The company has filed a lawsuit against watchdog group Media Matters for defamation.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, 52, oversees six companies: Tesla, SpaceX, X, Neuralink, Boring and xAI.
Musk has made a number of previous posts that promoted or amplified antisemitic content.

Elon Musk has faced a torrent of criticism since he on Nov 15 agreed with a user who falsely claimed Jewish people were stoking hatred against white people, saying the user who referenced the “Great Replacement” conspiracy theory was speaking “the actual truth.”

site_title: Corporate governance challenges of group companies
summary: In group structures, corporate governance challenges arise from conflicts of interests between parent and subsidiary companies, as well as differing perceptions amongst boards. Certain jurisdictions allow directors to act in the interests of the group, while others require boards to prioritize the group company's interests. Conflicts of interest can occur when parent companies nominate directors to group companies, who may owe obligations to both the parent and group companies. Adopting a group governance framework and engaging in ongoing communications between parent and group companies can help balance control and flexibility. Effective governance is crucial for maximizing the benefits of group structures while minimizing associated risks.

images.alt_text: Group structures can offer advantages, including efficient decision-making and pooling of resources.
As artificial intelligence (AI) continues to revolutionise industries, ChatGPT stands out as a pivotal innovation.
In retrospect, the extremely high leverage to buy and sell cryptocurrencies at FTX should have set alarm bells ringing.
Businesses need to move past digitisation and instead digitalise their entire operations to capture new digital business opportunities.
Corporate culture is broadly the shared set of values, beliefs and practices associated with an organisation about who to hire, how to behave and lead, and what to reward and punish.

site_title: A senior lawyer’s interaction with AI: Learning to ask good questions
summary: A senior lawyer reflects on the increasing importance of embracing artificial intelligence (AI) in the legal profession, citing its potential to streamline work, reduce costs, and enhance efficiency. Goldman Sachs estimates 44% of current legal work tasks can be automated by AI, displacing those who do not adopt the technology. Lawyers can harness AI by asking clear, specific questions and using platforms like Harvey, which offers a range of tools for research, contract review, and document drafting. While AI is intelligent but not infallible, human lawyers possess unique advantages in contextualizing information and emotional intelligence, making them valuable assets in the evolving legal landscape.

images.alt_text: The free basic version of ChatGPT can be used to draft legal documents at no cost, though lawyers warn that the risks in doing so could outweigh any benefits.

CMG20220719-HoKJ01 LTPI comprises the Legal Technology Platform (LTP) and initiatives surrounding the continuous development of the LTP. The LTP is a secure, cloud-based legal matters management and collaboration tool, which helps law firms and lawyers streamline their daily tasks and workflows to improve processes and increase productivity.
Lawyers are to provide clients with effective legal representation, which often means they have to grapple with novel issues by coming up with arguments previously not advanced.
ChatGPT: Has artificial intelligence come for our jobs?

A logo sits illuminated on the offices of Pricewaterhouse Coopers International Ltd. (PwC) in Stuttgart, Germany, on Thursday, Jan. 25, 2018. Germany’s Federal Administrative Court in February will rule on a potential diesel ban in Stuttgart, with consequences likely for other polluted cities. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
Lawyers play a vital role in preventing legal problems by providing sound advice and guidance to clients.

site_title: OpenAI’s crisis is yet another wake-up call
summary: A recent crisis at OpenAI highlights the importance of effective governance in high-speed tech organizations. The company's founders, Sam Altman, Ilya Sutskever, and Greg Brockman, failed to establish a strong board structure, leading to a lack of diversity, limited experience, and poor decision-making. This resulted in the removal of the founders from the interim board, with Altman returning as CEO without formal decision power. The crisis underscores the need for good governance, which can harness the potential of individuals and organizations. Effective governance can prevent surprises and effectively overcome them, and it is crucial for startups to establish a robust board structure to ensure their success.

images.alt_text: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, who had recruited Altman to Microsoft after his ouster from OpenAI, had said earlier that governance at the ChatGPT maker needs to change.

Sam Altman, left, one of the founders of OpenAI, and Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive; July 15, 2019. Nadella moved fast to hire Sam Altman, who was pushed out of OpenAI on Nov 17, 2023, and asserted his company’s role in its partnership with the AI startup.
FILE PHOTO: Sam Altman, CEO of Microsoft-backed OpenAI and ChatGPT creator speaks during a talk at Tel Aviv University in Tel Aviv, Israel June 5, 2023. REUTERS/Amir Cohen/File Photo

Former Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes was convicted in November 2022 on four counts of defrauding investors and sentenced to more than 11 years in prison. Theranos is just one example, and not an exception, of how poor governance can lead to disaster.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Thomson Medical, Sasseur Reit, ValueMax, 17Live, Cordlife, 3Cnergy
summary: Thomson Medical Group has secured a one-month extension from the Singapore Exchange to restore its public float without a trading suspension, with the new deadline set for January 10, 2024. Sasseur Reit's subsidiary has extended an unsecured loan by a year, with the new repayment date set for March 2025.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.4 per cent or 12.98 points to end at 3,074.26.

site_title: Private capital: Lessons from the conglomerate era
summary: Global private capital firms are emulating the corporate conglomerate business model by aggregating multiple, loosely related businesses under a common umbrella, capital solutions. This approach aims to consolidate market power and diversify away economic risks. However, conglomerates have historically failed to maximize long-term shareholder value due to increased complexity and costs. Modern-day private capital firms now hold onto portfolio assets for longer periods and play a more active role in portfolio management. Despite the challenges, financial conglomerates can enrich senior management and provide significant levers for generating supernormal profits, but they can also lead to performance dilution and value erosion.

images.alt_text: The Newtonian revolution claimed that "all clouds are clocks -- even the most cloudy of clouds", as Karl Popper put it.
When retail investors ride into the private equity universe

site_title: Yen extends rally to second day as traders bet on early BOJ hike
summary: The yen surged 1.1% against the dollar on Friday, extending its rally to a second day, as traders bet on an early Bank of Japan (BOJ) hike to scrap its negative interest-rate regime. The currency has fallen about 9% against the greenback this year, the second-worst performance among G-10 peers. Economists expect the BOJ to end its negative rate regime by April, with some forecasting a policy shift before the end of the year. The BOJ's cautious approach has contrasted with the Federal Reserve's tightening cycle, shifting the risk-reward for USD/JPY longs.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda says the central bank has several options on which interest rates to target once it pulls short-term borrowing costs out of negative territory.

The results come in a week where financial markets were jolted by the prospect of an even earlier end to sub-zero borrowing costs as traders reacted to comments from BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda and one of his deputies.

site_title: Iron ore futures rise on strong Chinese export data, sustained demand
summary: Iron ore futures rose 2.6% to 965.5 yuan (S$181.22) per metric tonne on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange, on track to record its best week in five, driven by strong Chinese export data, sustained demand, and positive updates from major producers. China's iron ore imports climbed 3.4% in November, while Brazilian miner Vale maintained its production target for the second straight year. The upward rally is expected to continue due to recovering downstream demand and stable output guidance from major producers.

images.alt_text: The November imports stayed at an elevated level for the fourth consecutive month, above 100 million tonnes for the fifth time so far this year.

site_title: Japan sets aside 129.4 billion yen for chipmakers Toshiba and Rohm
summary: Japan is investing 129.4 billion yen (S$1.2 billion) to support Toshiba and Rohm's joint production of power semiconductors, essential for electric vehicles and factories. The investment will help boost production capacity at two plants in Ishikawa and Miyazaki prefectures. Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry will subsidize about a third of the cost, aiming to improve domestic power semiconductor manufacturers' competitiveness. This move is part of Japan's efforts to foster its chip sector and keep up with global demand.

images.alt_text: Semiconductors are the building blocks of technology. The current downturn is a temporary setback for chipmakers.
Japan, a leading provider of chipmaking tools and materials that lost its edge in manufacturing in recent decades, is providing large subsidies to domestic and foreign chipmakers to build capacity.

site_title: 3Cnergy shareholders to vote on S$443.8 million reverse takeover deal with DTP Infinities on Dec 26
summary: 3Cnergy, a CATALIST-listed company, will hold an extraordinary general meeting on December 26 to vote on a S$443.8 million reverse takeover deal with DTP Infinities. The enlarged group, to be renamed Prosper Cap Corporation, will be led by Iqbal Jumabhoy. As part of the deal, 3Cnergy will issue up to 1.3 billion new shares and consolidate existing shares, with net proceeds used to repay loans, fund asset enhancements, and for working capital.

images.alt_text: 3Cnergy believes the proposed acquisition would be good for the company, having considered the quality of assets DTP owns, existing shareholder loans capitalisation, the prospects of the hospitality industry and DTP’s business.
Auditors for 3Cnergy flag material uncertainty as liabilities exceed assets by S$18.9m

site_title: Binance's former chief has to stay in US until February sentencing: filing
summary: US District Judge Richard Jones has ruled that former Binance CEO Zhao Changpeng must remain in the continental United States until his February sentencing for violating US anti-money laundering laws. The judge agreed with the Justice Department that Zhao has not convinced the court he would not flee if allowed to return to the UAE, where he has been living. Zhao faces a maximum prison sentence of 18 months and has agreed not to appeal any sentence up to that length.

images.alt_text: Internal communications showed Zhao had direct knowledge Binance was violating US laws.
Changpeng Zhao (CZ) acquires a majority stake in the company that operates Trust Wallet in 2018.

Changpeng Zhao, the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, pleaded guilty to failing to implement anti-money laundering policies and US sanctions violations as part of a broad agreement with the US government.

FILE PHOTO: Zhao Changpeng, founder and chief executive officer of Binance, attends the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo
Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao leaves the US District Court on November 21, 2023 in Seattle, Washington. Zhao pleaded guilty to a money-laundering charge.

site_title: UPS fires about 35 newly-organised US workers: Teamsters union
summary: UPS fired about 35 newly-organised US workers at its Centennial hub in Louisville, Kentucky, despite an independent arbitrator's ruling that their work should not be performed by management. The Teamsters union plans to file unfair labour practice charges and potentially strike. The union represents 340,000 UPS workers, with general president Sean O'Brien vowing to act if UPS doesn't resolve the issue. UPS claims its ratified contract remains intact, and it does not expect disruptions to its operations.

site_title: Oil drops to 6-month low on weak economic outlook, high US supply
summary: Oil prices fell to a six-month low on Thursday, with Brent crude futures dropping 25 cents to $74.05 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 4 cents to $69.34. The decline is attributed to weak economic outlook, particularly in the US and China, as well as high US supply. China's crude oil imports fell 9% in November, while US gasoline stocks rose 5.4 million barrels last week. Analysts suggest the market may have become oversupplied, with some calling for Opec+ members to deepen oil supply cuts.

images.alt_text: Putin’s meeting with the Saudi crown prince came after oil prices fell despite a pledge by Opec+  to further cut output.
Russia is the world’s second-largest oil and fuel exporter after Saudi Arabia with overall volumes of around 6-7 million barrels per day.

site_title: Lego Fortnite debuts as part of Epic Games’ expansion plans
summary: Epic Games has released Lego Fortnite, a new survival-crafting game, as part of its expansion plans to create more virtual worlds for socializing and playing. The game allows players to craft tools, weapons, and shelters while incorporating outfits and elements from the original Fortnite game. This move is part of Epic's larger strategy to create interoperable virtual worlds, aligning with CEO Tim Sweeney's vision for the metaverse. The release follows Epic's investment of $1 billion in the Lego Group and its efforts to increase revenue through in-game purchases.

images.alt_text: This handout courtesy of Rockstar Games taken on December 4, 2023 shows a video grab of the trailer of "Grand Theft Auto 6" video game. The first trailer for "Grand Theft Auto VI" was officially released ahead of schedule December 4, 2023 due to a leak, touting a 2025 release for the next chapter of the massively successful video game franchise. ByteDance will tell employees to stop working on unreleased games by December, and that it will look for ways to divest from titles already launched, sources said.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip after recent rally, economic worries weigh
summary: European shares slipped, pausing at a four-month high, amid economic worries. The Stoxx 600 fell 0.3% and Germany's DAX dipped 0.2%. Data showed Germany's industrial sector struggling, with industrial production unexpectedly falling in October. The European Central Bank is expected to start cutting rates by the second quarter of next year, earlier than previously thought. Shares of banks and some companies fell, while others, such as BASF, rose on positive news.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6 per cent, while Germany’s DAX closed 0.8 per cent higher on Wednesday.

site_title: Tencent unveils big-budget open-world game led by ‘GTA’ veteran
summary: Tencent unveiled its big-budget open-world game, Last Sentinel, led by 'Grand Theft Auto' veteran Steve Martin. The game, set in a dystopian future Tokyo, is four years in development and part of Tencent's push to create new intellectual property. The 200-member creative team is based in California, and Martin expressed his desire to provide a new gaming experience with new IPs and characters. The game's launch date has not been announced, but a debut trailer has hinted at gameplay and introduced a female protagonist, Hiromi Shoda.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Tencent sign is seen at the World Internet Conference (WIC) in Wuzhen, Zhejiang province, China, October 20, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Hunter Biden hit with federal charges for tax evasion scheme
summary: The US Department of Justice has filed federal charges against Hunter Biden, accusing him of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes while spending millions on a lavish lifestyle. The charges, filed in Central California, include three felony and six misdemeanor tax offenses, with Hunter Biden facing up to 17 years in prison if convicted. The indictment alleges Hunter Biden earned handsomely while serving on corporate boards but failed to pay his tax bills, instead spending on an extravagant lifestyle. An investigation into Hunter Biden's business dealings is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Hunter Biden, son of US President Joe Biden, is offering to testify publicly rather than appear under subpoena for a private Dec 13 deposition, as he has been subpoenaed to do.

site_title: Close to two-thirds of home owners with Sibor mortgages yet to switch as deadline looms
summary: Around 57,000 Singapore home owners with mortgages pegged to the Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (Sibor) have yet to switch to alternative loan packages, despite the Sibor's discontinuation by the end of 2024. The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has urged homeowners to switch before the end of April 2024 to avoid automatic conversion to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) package. Those who switch can choose between the Sora conversion package or other fixed, floating, or hybrid loan packages offered by their banks.

images.alt_text: Industry watchers largely expect demand in the HDB resale market to remain muted for December 2023 due to the holiday season.
The Ordinary Account interest rate will remain unchanged at 2.5 per cent.

site_title: US won’t rule out military action against Houthis, official says
summary: The US won't rule out military action against Houthi rebels in Yemen, according to Deputy National Security Adviser Jon Finer. The Houthis have been blamed for targeting commercial ships, prompting a US warship to respond to distress calls. Finer stated that the US will focus on maritime security and sanctions, but reserves the right to take action if necessary. The Houthis are enabled by Iran, which poses a threat to international commerce and security at sea.

images.alt_text: Kamelia Hoter Ishay, 73, grandmother of Gali Tarshansky, 13, who was taken hostage on Oct 7 during the deadly attack by Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, holds up a poster with a picture of Gali.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong stressed that Singapore should not import foreign quarrels and politics, even as it buidls ties internationally.
The US has powerful means of controlling the conflict if it is willing to use them, says Bloomberg Opinion columnist Hal Brands.

site_title: Phishing scams on Facebook using SIA logo to sell cheap suitcases, police warn
summary: A phishing scam targeting Facebook users in Singapore has been reported, with fake advertisements using the Singapore Airlines (SIA) logo to sell cheap suitcases. The scam, impersonating "Singapore Airlines Travel", resulted in 14 victims losing a total of S$799. The fake Facebook page has been removed, and SIA has posted an advisory to inform the public. The airline is aware of the scam and has taken steps to prevent further incidents.

images.alt_text: The 11 tech giants have promised to take tougher action within six months to block and remove scams, such as fake adverts and romance fraud, from their platforms.
OCBC and UOB customers can lock their savings from Thursday; DBS is rolling out a locked account by Dec 7.

site_title: Biden impeachment inquiry set for House vote next week
summary: US House Republicans are set to vote next week on a resolution authorizing an impeachment inquiry into President Joe Biden, tied to his family's business dealings. The vote, which requires all lawmakers to support or oppose the inquiry, comes after conservative Republicans have been pursuing the investigation for months. The inquiry, led by the Judiciary Committee, probes whether Biden benefited from his son's foreign business dealings or abused his office. Despite opposition from Democrats, the resolution is expected to pass, with Speaker Mike Johnson believing it's necessary to counter arguments that the investigation is not legally legitimate.

images.alt_text: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy delivers a statement on allegations surrounding US President Joe Biden and his son Hunter Biden on Capitol Hill in Washington, US, Sept 12, 2023.
US President Joe Biden’s age is a particular concern with voters and there have been calls from some Democrats for him to step aside for a new candidate.

Former US President Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka Trump leaves after attending the Trump Organization civil fraud trial, in the New York State Supreme Court in the Manhattan borough of New York City, US., Nov 8, 2023.

FILE PHOTO: Hunter Biden, son of U.S. President Joe Biden, departs federal court after a  plea hearing on two misdemeanor charges of willfully failing to pay income taxes in Wilmington, Delaware, U.S. July 26, 2023. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Alphabet boost, payrolls data eyed
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by gains in Alphabet shares, and rose 0.19% at the open. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 69.74 points to 36,124.17, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, up 0.43% and 0.59%, respectively. Investors are awaiting monthly payrolls data to gauge the Federal Reserve's policy actions, which could impact market sentiment.

site_title: Cordlife says its storage operations ‘not’ impacted by accredited bodies’ suspension, probe
summary: Cordlife Group stated its cord-blood storage operations will not be impacted by the indefinite suspension of accreditation by the Foundation for the Accreditation of Cellular Therapy. The suspension followed the discovery of seven storage tanks kept at temperatures above acceptable limits at Cordlife's Singapore facility. The Association for the Advancement of Blood & Biotherapies is also investigating, but Cordlife's storage operations remain unaffected, according to the company's filing to the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends sharply higher as Alphabet and AMD fuel AI surge
summary: The Nasdaq ended sharply higher on Dec 7, driven by Alphabet's new AI model and AMD's estimate of a $45 billion data centre AI chip market this year. Other tech stocks like Nvidia, Amazon, and Apple also gained. The Philadelphia semiconductor index jumped, and the S&P 500 climbed 0.8% to 4,585.60 points, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2% to 36,117.13. Traders have largely priced in the likelihood of the Fed keeping interest rates unchanged at its meeting next week, with a nearly 64% chance of a rate cut in March.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2 per cent to 36,054.43 on Wednesday.

site_title: EU’s AI Act could exclude open-source models from regulation
summary: The European Union's AI Act may exempt open-source models from strict regulation unless deemed high-risk or used for banned purposes. A leaked compromise proposal suggests that free and open-source licenses would not be subject to regulation, potentially benefiting notable European companies operating in the open-source space, including Mistral and Aleph Alpha. The proposal halted negotiations after lawmakers failed to reach a consensus on regulating the rapidly-developing technology.

images.alt_text: According to a survey by financial services firm Six, integrating AI will be the primary focus for financial market institutions in the near future.
Embracing AI is becoming increasingly vital for lawyers as it continues to revolutionise the legal field.
“AI-based programming activities need to be predicated on the ethics governing its use and development,” according to the draft produced by Indonesia’s communications ministry.
The Singapore Conference on AI (SCAI) brought together 42 delegates from around the world to discuss "critical questions of AI".
Nvidia is looking to potentially make "large investments" in artificial intelligence in Singapore, said CEO Jensen Huang.
Dell’s shares soar nearly 90 per cent to a record through the end of November, amid expectations of a boost from artificial intelligence demand.

site_title: Two Teochew associations settle dispute over redevelopment of Teochew Building
summary: Singapore's two oldest Teochew associations, Ngee Ann Kongsi and Teochew Poit Ip Huay Kuan, have reached an amicable settlement agreement over the redevelopment of the historic Teochew Building, ending a 6-year feud. The agreement, signed on Dec 7, involves the demolition of the rear of the existing building and the construction of a new building with over 80% of the space dedicated to community use. The iconic Chinese-style roof will be conserved, and the terms of the agreement remain confidential. The settlement was facilitated by Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong.

images.alt_text: House of Tan Yeok Nee sold to entity linked to Bachtiar Karim's family

site_title: Boeing signals two-month delay to 737 production ramp-up: sources
summary: Boeing has signaled a two-month delay in its 737 production ramp-up, now expecting 42 jets per month starting in February 2024, down from the initial target of 42 jets per month by the end of 2023. The company had previously expected to reach this production level in December 2023, but the delay pushes subsequent rate increases to August 2024 and February 2025. Boeing still aims to hit its pre-pandemic goal of 57.7 aircraft per month in October 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Employees walk by the end of a 737 Max aircraft at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, U.S., March 27, 2019.  REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson/File Photo
Expanding its fleet with wide-body aircraft such as the 787 would mark a strategic shift for FlyDubai.
FILE PHOTO: A Boeing logo is seen at the 54th International Paris Airshow at Le Bourget Airport near Paris, France, June 18, 2023. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: UBS moves to merge parent banks
summary: UBS has begun the integration of Credit Suisse's parent bank, marking the first merger of two global systemically important banks. The Swiss bank's board of directors has given the green light for the respective parent banks, UBS AG and Credit Suisse AG, to fuse. The merger is expected to be completed in 2024, pending regulatory approvals. The integration will result in Credit Suisse no longer functioning as an independent bank, allowing for the migration of clients and the realization of synergies, with operational improvements expected in 2025 and 2026.

images.alt_text: The legal saga in France has rumbled on for more than a decade with UBS fighting on to cut the 4.5 billion euros penalty it initially got in 2019.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at the bank's branch in Shanghai, China, March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at the bank's branch in Shanghai, China, March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
A logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen next to a Swiss flag in Zurich, Switzerland March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Boeing closing in on Thai deal for 80 Dreamliners:  sources
summary: Boeing is in advanced talks to sell 80 wide-body 787 Dreamliner jets to Thai Airways, surpassing Airbus in the airline's fleet renewal talks. Thai Airways is boosting its requirements to bolster regional routes amid a post-pandemic travel boom. The deal could help Boeing recover from production issues and meet surging demand. The airline began restructuring debt worth 400 billion baht (S$15.2 billion) in 2021 and is looking to make the most of the travel boom. Boeing declined to comment, while Thai Airways did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: Brazil's priciest power transmission auction expects few bidders
summary: Brazil's largest-ever power transmission auction, scheduled for Dec 15, is expected to see little competition as potential bidders are deterred by the need for billions of dollars in investments and tech expertise. Three projects totaling 4,470 kilometers across five states are up for sale, with 21.7 billion reais (S$5.9 billion) in planned investments. Chinese company State Grid and Brazil's Eletrobras are considered top candidates, with Eletrobras already publicly stating its intention to bid.

images.alt_text: electricity, power pole, sky
Geely previously announced a hybrid gasoline engine development deal with Mercedes-Benz and holds a stake in the German automaker.
How Singapore and Asia's tech sector can lead in renewable energy adoption

site_title: Britain sets out safeguards for accessing cash in digital age
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has proposed rules requiring banks and building societies to assess cash access before closing a branch, addressing concerns over vulnerable consumers and small businesses relying on cash. The FCA aims to ensure people can access cash in the digital age, despite over 3 million consumers still using cash. Existing law allows retailers to decide whether to accept cash, but the FCA will finalize new rules by the third quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: The FCA proposals follow a recommendation from the BOE in October that the £250 billion-(S$422 billion) sterling money market funds sector, widely used by companies for day-to-day funding and parking cash overnight, needed to be more resilient.

site_title: Thomson Medical gets further grace period of 1 month to restore public float
summary: Thomson Medical Group has secured a one-month extension to restore its public float by January 10, 2024, without suspending trading in its shares. The company, which had a public float of 9.98% in September, received the extension from the Singapore Exchange after initially being granted three months to December 10, 2023. The grace period allows Thomson Medical to explore options to restore the public float while continuing to monitor trading activity and requesting a trading halt if necessary.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase moderately
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 1,000 to a seasonally adjusted 220,000 for the week ended Dec 2, indicating a moderate increase in the labor market. Despite this, economists believe the Federal Reserve is likely done raising interest rates, citing a mixed report that showed declining unemployment rolls in late November. Financial markets expect a rate cut as early as the first quarter, but data suggests the labor market is gradually losing momentum due to higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Representative Sara McKethan, left, hands a list of employment descriptions to a job seeker during the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Sara McKethan

site_title: Asean+3 agree on new financing facility to boost resilience
summary: The Asean+3 group of nations, comprising Japan, China, and South Korea, agreed on a new regional lending facility to boost resilience amid rising global economic uncertainty. The Rapid Financing Facility (RFF) will complement the existing Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralisation (CMIM) and be placed under its umbrella. The new facility aims to enhance the use of existing currency swap lines and provide a more accessible source of funds during emergencies. Deputies agreed on the facility's establishment and modalities, with a plan to endorse it by ministers and governors in May 2024.

images.alt_text: Amro expects Asean+3 to grow by 4.3 per cent this year and at 4.5 per cent in 2024.

site_title: Tata Motors lobbies India not to lower EV import taxes as Tesla looms
summary: Tata Motors is lobbying India to maintain its 100% import tax on electric vehicles, citing concerns that lower taxes would harm domestic industry and investors. The move comes as Tesla plans to set up an Indian factory, proposing lower import taxes for electric cars. India is reviewing a policy to cut import taxes on EVs to 15% for companies committing to local manufacturing, which could benefit Tesla. Tata argues that India's EV players need more government support, and lower duties could risk future fundraising.

images.alt_text: The lower import taxes could help Tesla sell its full range of models in India, and not just the new car it wants to make locally.

site_title: Singapore-listed semiconductor players could ride on industry recovery
summary: Singapore-listed semiconductor companies may benefit from the industry's nascent recovery, driven by improving demand and inventory normalization. IDC has upgraded the sector's market outlook to "growth" from "trough", with estimated revenue growth of 21.8% in 2024 to US$632.8 billion. However, experts warn that the recovery will be gradual, taking 12-18 months, and that companies further down the value chain may not perform as well. Analysts recommend Frencken Group as a top pick, citing its diversified business and high beta.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductors are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Russia, Saudi Arabia urge all Opec+ powers to join oil cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia, the world's two largest oil exporters, have called on all Opec+ members to join a voluntary agreement on output cuts to stabilize global oil markets and support the global economy. The call comes after a meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Salman, who stressed the need for Opec+ members to commit to the agreement. The move aims to address the recent decline in oil prices following a decision by Opec+ producers to cut output by 2.2 million barrels per day.

images.alt_text: This pool photograph distributed by Russian state agency Sputnik shows Russia's President Vladimir Putin shaking hands with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ahead of their talks in Riyadh on December 6, 2023. (Photo by Alexey NIKOLSKY / POOL / AFP)

site_title: K-pop company behind BTS wants to make its superfan app global
summary: Hybe, the management company behind K-pop group BTS, is doubling efforts to sign new artists to its Weverse app, aiming to draw fans globally and pursue profitability. The app has 69 million subscribers and 10.5 million monthly active users, and has added artists from Japan and the US, including AKB48 and Prettymuch. Hybe plans to integrate fan-related services, add in-app ads, and paid membership programs, with CEO Joon Choi stating that reaching 30-50 million monthly active users will enable more profit-making models.

images.alt_text: YG Entertainment announced on Wednesday that all members of Blackpink had renewed their contracts with the company for “group activities”.

The South Korean sensations Blackpink receive honorary MBEs (Members of the Order of the British Empire) from Britain's King Charles III, for its members’ work as advocates for the COP26 climate summit in 2021.
Each year, some 100 participants join The Academy Australia’s boot camp – spanning eight to 10 days – and receive training in singing, dancing and entertaining.
Photocards are the cornerstone of Kpop merchandise, as collectors' items packaged with other items to increase their sales.
Hybe, the company behind BTS, is expanding outside South Korea to diversify beyond K-pop.

site_title: US Democratic lawmakers ask payment firms to renew work on gun code
summary: US Democratic lawmakers, led by Senator Elizabeth Warren, have urged top payments companies to resume work on implementing a sales code for gun merchants, citing the need to combat gun violence amid mass shootings. The code, which helps detect suspicious firearms and ammunition sales, was delayed due to conflicting state laws. Seven states have passed laws prohibiting its use, while California requires its use. The lawmakers argue that there is no legal or technical rationale to avoid implementing the code in states where it remains legal.

images.alt_text: On the Nike site, the original Ja 1 link goes to a page that reads “THE PRODUCT YOU ARE LOOKING FOR IS NO LONGER AVAILABLE.”
A police officer near the Old National Bank building in downtown Louisville, Kentucky, on Monday (Apr 10). Early reports said there were multiple casualties.

Flowers are placed on a makeshift memorial in front of Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, on May 25, 2022. - The tight-knit Latino community of Uvalde was wracked with grief Wednesday after a teen in body armor marched into the school and killed 19 children and two teachers, in the latest spasm of deadly gun violence in the US. (Photo by CHANDAN KHANNA / AFP)

site_title: UK PM insists Rwanda migrants plan 'will work'
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak insists his immigration plan to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda will work, despite criticism from his ex-interior minister Suella Braverman and others. The plan aims to deter illegal migrants and stop boat crossings. Sunak's premiership is under threat due to the divisive issue, which is a major battleground in next year's general election.

images.alt_text: Britain's Home Secretary James Cleverly (R) and Rwanda's Foreign Minister Vincent Biruta shake hands after signing a new treaty to revive a controversial proposal by London to transfer migrants to the east African country.

site_title: EU watchdog orders top credit raters to tighten internal controls
summary: The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has ordered top credit rating agencies Fitch Ratings, Moody's, and S&P to tighten internal controls to ensure accurate and independent ratings of collateralized loan obligations (CLOs). The investigation, focusing on the "Big Three" rating agencies, raised concerns about the accuracy of their ratings. ESMA's action aims to maintain market integrity and protect investors.

images.alt_text: While the economy is seen on track to hit the government’s annual growth target of around 5 per cent this year, Moody’s expects China’s annual economic growth to slow to an average 3.8 per cent from 2026 to 2030.
The change in Moody's assessment removes a sword of Damocles that has constantly overshadowed Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni and her one-year-old coalition.
Moody’s is the last of the three major rating agencies to maintain a top rating for the US government.
WeWork had warned in August that “substantial doubt exists about the company’s ability to continue as a going concern.”
Fitch downgraded the US’s credit rating to AA+ from AAA in August.

site_title: We’ve got a new look - Pulse on the region
summary: Indonesia reported lower-than-expected GDP growth of 1.6% in the July-September period, while Malaysia's industrial production fell for a second consecutive month, dipping 0.5% year-on-year. Thailand's inflation rate dipped for the first time in 25 months, and the country's prime minister is focusing on turning around the economy. Economists expect modest growth in Malaysia's GDP in the third quarter. Meanwhile, Indonesia's finance minister lowered the government's growth forecast for 2023 to 5.04%, and Malaysia is studying the possibility of regulating TikTok and its e-commerce features.

images.alt_text: Planning for new urban areas at the Binh Duong - Vietnam's locality with the largest total industrial park area
Indonesia had 18.8 gigawatts (GW) of coal power considered under construction by the end of 2022. Most of these new coal plants, 13 GW or 69 per cent, are captive plants.

site_title: Electric Vehicles Charging Act to kick in on Friday
summary: Singapore's Electric Vehicles Charging Act takes effect on Friday, regulating the supply, installation, and use of EV chargers. The law aims to support the growing adoption of electric vehicles, with new EV registrations reaching 22% of total car registrations in November. The Act requires charger models to be type-approved by the Land Transport Authority and registers all chargers before use. Existing chargers can be registered for free if applications are submitted by June 8, 2024, and non-compliant chargers may face fines of up to $40,000 and imprisonment for up to two years.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister of State Dr Amy Khor trying out the EV charging app at the launch of the largest e-roaming service across both sides of the Causeway.

site_title: AI gaining acceptance in asset management, wealth advisory
summary: Financial institutions are increasingly integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into their operations to reduce costs. A survey by Six Group found that nearly half of 343 international financial institutions plan to focus on AI integration in the next three years. Generative AI technology has shifted the priority, enabling AI to "short-cut" data analysis and improve customer understanding. However, challenges remain, including the need for skilled talent to implement and manage AI systems, and the risk of suboptimal decisions. Financial institutions aim to leverage AI for investment decisions, internal processes, and customer management.

images.alt_text: The framework aims to enable financial institutions to use generative AI in a responsible manner, to solve common industry-wide challenges and enhance risk management.
The free basic version of ChatGPT can be used to draft legal documents at no cost, though lawyers warn that the risks in doing so could outweigh any benefits.
As attempted coups go, what happened at OpenAI was a colossal failure.

site_title: Hong Kong, Saudi Arabia formalise economic and financial relations
summary: Hong Kong and Saudi Arabia have formalized their economic and financial ties following high-level exchanges since Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Riyadh last year. Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee hailed the development, citing the city's achievements in finance, innovation, and sustainability. The two countries have signed agreements on investment promotion, green finance, and cross-border payments. Hong Kong's green bond issuances account for about one-third of Asia's total, and the city is planning to establish an AI and supercomputing center. The move is seen as a significant step forward in deepening ties between Hong Kong and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Economists slashed their expectations for Hong Kong's GDP growth in 2023 to 3.3 per cent from an earlier forecast of 4 per cent.
The centre will develop patents to be used around the world – licenced to companies such as current CATL partner Ford Motor.
Unauthorised construction has long been an issue in Hong Kong, but successive administrations have done little to tackle the problem.

site_title: Sasseur Reit extends 308 million yuan sponsor loan maturity by a year
summary: Sasseur Reit's wholly-owned subsidiary has extended a 308 million yuan (S$58.1 million) loan from its sponsor by a year, from March 2024 to March 2025. The terms and conditions of the loan agreement remain unchanged. The extension was made under a one-year loan agreement with an initial extension option. The Reit's units closed flat at S$0.695 following the announcement.

site_title: Yen surges after BOJ hints at policy shift
summary: The yen surged 2% to its strongest in three months after Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda hinted at a potential policy shift, sparking market optimism and a decline in the US dollar index. The euro fell to a three-week low, while the eurozone's European Central Bank may consider a rate cut in 2024. The BOJ's decision to pull short-term borrowing costs out of negative territory has raised hopes for a change in policy, with traders expecting the central bank to signal an end to negative rates.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, Oct. 31, 2023. The Bank of Japan further loosened its grip on government bond yields while continuing to stick with its negative interest rate in a decision that prompted a retreat in the yen. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia palm oil fund agency sees 2024 export levy collections at 29 trillion rupiah
summary: Indonesia's palm oil fund agency predicts 2024 export levy collections of 29 trillion rupiah ($2.5 billion), slightly below this year's estimate. The levy funds biodiesel subsidies and palm replanting programs. Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil exporter, has set a 35% palm oil blend in biodiesel, the highest in the world. The agency's estimate is based on a lower palm oil price in 2024.

site_title: Singapore, China launch new sustainability initiatives under Tianjin Eco-City bilateral project
summary: Singapore and China have launched 15 new sustainability initiatives under the Tianjin Eco-City bilateral project, aiming to deepen ties across the public sector, businesses, and academia in areas such as green shipping, low-carbon living, and innovation. The initiatives include the establishment of a green and digital shipping corridor and the development of a national green development demonstration zone. The projects are expected to promote high-quality green growth and serve as a model for other cities in China and beyond.

images.alt_text: Singapore and China signed more than 20 Memoranda of Understanding and agreements at the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Chinese vice-premier Ding Xuexiang meet in Tianjin, China to co-chair the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.

Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong having bilateral meeting with Chinese Premier Li Qiang at Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China on Dec 6, 2023. It is the second meeting this year between both leaders after Mr Wong met with Mr Li during his visit in May.
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong visiting China (Beijing and Tianjin) from 5 to 8 December 2023 for the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation (JCBC) and bilateral meetings.

Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong addressed a group of 300 overseas Singaporeans at a reception in Beijing.

site_title: Eurozone risks recession as German economy falters
summary: The Eurozone risks recession due to a slowdown in Germany's economy, with industrial production declining 0.4% in October, its lowest level since August 2020. The Eurozone's GDP also shrank 0.1% in the third quarter, attributed to changes in inventories. Household consumption remained strong, but a second quarter of contraction would indicate a recession. Weak global demand, expensive energy, and higher interest rates are affecting manufacturers, with several big firms cutting costs. Recent surveys suggest stabilisation in Germany, but the outlook remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Production declines 0.4 per cent from September, led by the machinery and equipment sector,.

A man shelters from the rain under an umbrella as he walks past the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on July 27, 2023 ahead of thr ECB's monthly announcement on eurozone monetary policy. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)
HCOB’s composite PMI rises to 47.6 from October’s near three-year low of 46.5 and coming in above a 47.1 preliminary estimate.
HCOB’s final eurozone manufacturing PMI, compiled by S&P Global, rises to 44.2 in November from October’s 43.1, above a preliminary estimate of 43.8.

site_title: Indonesia eyes visa waivers for 20 countries, including US, China, India
summary: Indonesia is considering granting visa-free entry to nationals of 20 countries, including the US, China, and India, to boost its tourism and economy. The move aims to attract more foreign visitors, following Singapore's recent introduction of a 30-day mutual visa exemption with China. This is part of a broader effort to increase tourism and investment, with the government aiming to reach pre-pandemic visitor numbers of over 16 million. The list of countries will be finalized within a month.

images.alt_text: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is the first recipient of Indonesia's golden visa, which has numerous perks such as priority security screening at airports and longer stay periods.
Sam Altman is granted a 10-year visa for his potential contributions to the development of artificial intelligence in Indonesia.

An individual who invests funds worth US$350,000 into shares of public companies, savings or deposit accounts or government bonds is eligible for a five-year stay, or US$700,000 for 10 years, according to a press release Saturday (Sep 2) citing Indonesia Director General of Immigration Silmy Karim.

site_title: People flows remain key to Singapore-China bilateral cooperation: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore and China are strengthening bilateral cooperation, with a focus on people-to-people links, trade, and emerging areas like digital and green economies. The two countries aim to establish a 30-day visa-free travel arrangement, starting in early 2024, to facilitate travel and financial relationships. This move follows the resumption of China's 15-day visa-free facility for Singaporean travelers and comes as both countries seek to deepen their economic and trade cooperation.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the city centre of Tianjin Eco-City.
Singapore and China signed more than 20 Memoranda of Understanding and agreements at the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Chinese vice-premier Ding Xuexiang meet in Tianjin, China to co-chair the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.

site_title: Thailand to tighten rules for foreign firms selling baht bonds
summary: Thailand plans to tighten rules for foreign firms selling baht-denominated bonds, requiring international credit rating for both private and public offerings starting January 1. This move aims to shield local investors from risky overseas issuers, but may drive away borrowers from neighboring countries, such as Laos and Myanmar. The new rules could lessen Thailand's appeal as a fund-raising source for these countries, particularly Laos, which has a low credit rating.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia’s second-largest economy grew 1.8 per cent in the April-to-June period year on year.

site_title: ValueMax to raise up to S$120 million through digital commercial papers
summary: ValueMax Group, a pawnbroker, has launched three digital commercial papers on two exchanges, aiming to raise between S$35 million and S$120 million. The papers, priced at 5% per annum, will be determined by the board after considering investor demand. The company expects to raise between S$20 million and S$50 million from accredited investors on one exchange and between S$10 million and S$50 million on another. The move is part of ValueMax's efforts to raise funds and diversify its financing options.

site_title: Saying goodbye to an architectural masterwork
summary: The William Lim-designed house at C-1 Holland Park, built in 1963, is set to be sold after a farewell gesture by its current owner, artist-photographer Tan Ngiap Heng. A group of artists, including Tan, have created artworks to capture the essence of the house, which will be unveiled during Singapore Art Week in January 2024. The house, an "unsung masterwork of Malayan modernism," is being sold due to its size being too big for the family and the siblings being too far away to look after it. The sale is a rare opportunity to own a piece of Singapore's architectural history.

images.alt_text: The winner of the World Building of the Year award is a bold exploration of campus design.

site_title: Tesla’s Nordic labour dispute spreads as pension fund sells stock
summary: A pension fund in Denmark, PensionDanmark, has sold its Tesla shares worth approximately $77.5 million after the company refused to sign a collective labour agreement with its workers. The dispute, which started in Sweden, has spread to Denmark and Norway, where unions have threatened to block shipments of Tesla cars. The move comes as Tesla CEO Elon Musk described the Swedish labour action as "insane".

images.alt_text: In Sweden, Tesla has for more than a month been locked in a dispute with labour unions after the carmaker refused to sign a collective bargaining agreement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of strengthening Singapore-China bilateral cooperation amid global economic uncertainty. The two countries signed 24 deals, including enhancements to the China-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, to deepen trade and investment links. HDB resale prices rose 0.4% in November, while Singapore shares fell 0.4% on the same day, wiping out gains from the previous day. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is seeking feedback on changes to the policy owners' protection scheme to enhance coverage and improve efficiency.

site_title: Nathania Ong: A sonic homecoming
summary: Singaporean actress Nathania Ong, who was the first to play Eponine in London's West End's Les Miserables, returns home to stage a charity concert, "Spirit of Giving: Nathania Ong – A Musical Homecoming," on December 20. The concert benefits underprivileged kids through The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. Ong, 25, will perform her favorite musical numbers, including "Don't Rain On My Parade" and "On My Own." The event aims to support artistically-gifted children from low-income homes in pursuing their passions.

site_title: Natural disasters caused US$100 billion in insured losses in 2023: Swiss Re
summary: Insured losses from natural disasters reached US$100 billion in 2023, according to Swiss Re. This is down from US$133 billion in 2022 but still above the 10-year average of US$89 billion. Severe thunderstorms caused a record US$60 billion in losses, with significant damage in the US and Europe. Total economic losses from natural catastrophes, including uninsured losses, are estimated at US$260 billion in 2023.

site_title: Myanmar crisis, Timor-Leste accession high on agenda as Laos gears up for Asean chair
summary: Laos Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Saleumxay Kommasith outlined his country's priorities as it prepares to chair the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) in January. Key challenges include the Myanmar crisis and Timor-Leste's accession, as well as disputes in the South China Sea. Laos has chaired Asean twice before, in 2004 and 2016, and aims to address major issues such as power rivalry, climate change, and economic disruptions during its upcoming chairmanship.

images.alt_text: A chair for a Myanmar representative is left unoccupied during a retreat session of the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, East Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia, May 11, 2023. Asean has barred Myanmar junta leaders from attending its high-level meetings over its failure to implement the plan, which its top general agreed to in April 2021 in a meeting in Jakarta.

site_title: Japan to legalise cannabis-based medicines
summary: Japan has passed a bill to legalize cannabis-based medicines, paving the way for the lifting of a ban on medical products derived from cannabis. The changes, which also toughen penalties for recreational use, come after a recent rise in cannabis-related arrests, particularly among young people. Under the revised laws, those caught using or possessing marijuana can face a prison sentence of up to seven years. The move is seen as a win for patient groups, but also tightens Japan's already strict cannabis policy.

images.alt_text: A cannabis dispensary along Khao San Road in Bangkok, Thailand, on Sunday, Sept. 10, 2023. An ongoing regulatory vacuum, which emerged a year ago after Thailand decriminalized cannabis before passing the bill to regulate wider uses of the plant, has led to a mushrooming of over 4,500 dispensaries all over the country. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: German industry unexpectedly shrinks amid recession threat
summary: Germany's industrial output declined 0.4% in October, marking a fifth consecutive monthly drop, amid recession fears. The machinery and equipment sector led the decline, following an energy-induced crisis and higher interest rates. Analysts predict another GDP contraction, increasing the likelihood of a recession. The downturn affects manufacturers, with several big firms cutting costs, and is also influenced by budget turmoil in Berlin. However, recent surveys suggest some stabilization, with the Ifo institute's business outlook reaching a six-month high.

images.alt_text: The failure of talks between coalition leaders before Wednesday means it is unlikely parliament will approve a 2024 budget by the end of the year.
German firms are building supply chains that are independent of China, shifting some operations away from the country and growing markets elsewhere in Asia.
Exports to EU countries shrink by 2.7 per cent in October, according to federal statistics office.
“Employment is now only growing marginally and demand for workers continues to weaken,” says head of Germany’s Federal Labor Agency.
According to the latest estimate, 1.8 million jobs remain unfilled in the German economy as a whole.
The HCOB German Flash Composite Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI), rose to a four-month high of 47.1 in November from October’s 45.9, above the 46.5 forecast by economists.

site_title: China says exports rise for first time in seven months
summary: China's overseas shipments rose 0.5% in November to $291 billion, marking their first increase since April, according to the General Administration of Customs. This is a departure from the 0.3% contraction forecast by analysts. However, imports slipped 0.6% to $224 billion, indicating a mixed economic performance. China's economy has been struggling to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, with exports declining since October and imports contracting for the first time in over a year.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Chinese vice-premier Ding Xuexiang meet in Tianjin, China to co-chair the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.

The rating action for financial institutions including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is primarily driven by the change in outlook to negative from stable on the government’s credit ratings, according to Moody’s.

Investors watch the stock trading board at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China, on Monday, Jan. 11, 2010. China stocks are entering a "new era" with the government's approval of short sales, stock index futures and margin trading set to boost trading, Morgan Stanley said.

site_title: Singapore, China to start 30-day visa-free travel in early 2024
summary: Singapore and China plan to establish a 30-day visa-free travel arrangement starting in early 2024, aiming to boost travel and economic ties between the two countries. This follows the recent resumption of China's 15-day visa-free facility for Singaporean travelers in July. The move is seen as a step to support the goal of reaching pre-Covid levels of direct flight connectivity and strengthening financial relationships between the two nations.
