site_title: 💳 Pay up, Gen Zs
summary: Gen Z is facing financial literacy challenges, with many having limited knowledge about managing their finances. The article emphasizes the importance of financial education for this generation, particularly in regards to investing and managing bills. It suggests that Gen Z should be aware of their financial obligations, such as paying bills on time, and consider seeking professional advice, like CPF investments, to make informed financial decisions.

site_title: CATL to spend over HK$1 billion on HK headquarters, R&D center
summary: CATL, the world's largest electric vehicle battery producer, is investing over HK$1 billion in a new Hong Kong headquarters and research and development center. The center will develop patents for global use, licensed to companies such as Ford Motor, and will employ over 500 people. The move comes as CATL faces US efforts to limit China's role in EV supply chains, with the company already having partnerships with major brands including Tesla and Volkswagen. The investment is part of CATL's expansion plans, with the company having a 37% global market share in electric vehicle batteries.

images.alt_text: As part of the partnership, Stellantis and CATL plan to build an LFP battery factory in Europe.
CATL sees its China market share tumble in September to the lowest in more than a year.
Shenzhen-based Londian has benefited from a surge in demand for EV batteries, which its copper wire forms part of.
Mass production of the superfast-charge battery will start by year-end, and it will be commercially available from the first quarter of 2024., CATL says.
Net profit for the three months ended June comes in at 10.895 billion yuan, up 63.22 per cent from a year earlier, according to a Reuters calculation based on CATL’s company filing.

site_title: Certis’ Community Give-Back 5 programme takes beneficiaries out of the classroom
summary: Certis has launched its Community Give-Back 5 programme, a five-year initiative to empower underserved children and youth through arts and technology. The programme kicked off on Dec 6 with a Disney Immersive Experience at the Sands Theatre, marking the first time beneficiaries will leave their classrooms. The initiative, in partnership with TRCL, aims to broaden horizons and deepen understanding of the arts, with three themes: convey, create and capture. The programme has benefited over 400 children and youth since its inception in 2019, with a donation of S$20,000 to BT BAF.

images.alt_text: The third initiative to mark the anniversary is the presentation of a cheque for S$6.2 million to the Lee Kuan Yew Centennial Fund, a ground-up initiative by business leaders to invest in and support the development of Singapore youth into visionary leaders.

site_title: BOJ chief meets PM Kishida, explains focus on wages, demand
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda met with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, discussing the central bank's focus on wages, demand, and the potential exit from decades of ultra-low interest rates. Ueda stated the BOJ aims to assess sustainable wage growth, service price inflation, and domestic demand strength to guide monetary policy. The meeting comes as market expectations rise for the BOJ to begin exiting its low-interest rate policy, with the central bank set to review its growth and inflation forecasts in December and January.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Ryozo Himino speaks during an interview with Reuters in Tokyo, Japan, June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo/File Photo
The BOJ remains a dovish outlier among global peers, having maintained ultra-loose policy even as major central banks elsewhere raised interest rates aggressively to fight rampant inflation.

site_title: Bitsmedia raises US$20 million in Series A funding for religious app Muslim Pro
summary: Singapore-based Bitsmedia has secured US$20 million in Series A funding for its religious app Muslim Pro, led by Gobi Partners and CMIA Capital Partners, with Bintang Capital Partners also participating. The funding comes after the company reported a S$8.1 million loss in 2022, down from a profit of S$1.2 million the previous year. Bitsmedia's revenue fell to S$12.1 million in 2022 from S$14 million the year before.

site_title: Economists see Hong Kong’s growth outlook worsening through 2024
summary: Hong Kong's GDP growth outlook has worsened, with economists slashing expectations for 2023 to 3.3% from 4%, and 2024 to 2.7% from 3%. The slowdown is attributed to challenges from China's economic slowdown and elevated interest rates, which weigh on the financial hub. Despite a tourism revival, the economy is expected to grow at a slower pace than previously forecast, with the fourth quarter expected to reach 4.8% year-over-year. The downgrades reflect a muted post-pandemic recovery and suggest tougher times ahead for the Asian financial center.

images.alt_text: The rating action for financial institutions including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is primarily driven by the change in outlook to negative from stable on the government’s credit ratings, according to Moody’s.
Moody’s says the “principal driver” of Hong Kong’s negative rating outlook is the “tight linkage between the credit profiles” of the finance hub and China.
The PBOC set the daily reference rate at 7.1140 per US dollar, versus an average estimate at 7.1486 in a Bloomberg survey with analysts and traders.
HSBC and firms including Goldman Sachs Group and Citigroup have been cutting staff in the region as deals slow amid macro-economic concerns and tumultuous markets.
Unauthorised construction has long been an issue in Hong Kong, but successive administrations have done little to tackle the problem.

site_title: Cut-off yield on latest 6-month T-bill slips to 3.74% as demand rises
summary: Singapore's latest 6-month Treasury bill (T-bill) auction received S$13.3 billion in applications, exceeding the S$5.9 billion on offer, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.25. The cut-off yield of 3.74% is down from 3.8% in the previous tranche, reflecting strong demand and expectations of a potential US interest rate cut in March 2024. This maintains demand for Singapore T-bills, which follow US yields closely and have attracted investors seeking attractive yields amid a possible US recession.

The December issuance received a total of S$1.9 billion in applications, exceeding the S$1 billion on offer.
Demand for the T-bills slid slightly, with applications totalling S$13 billion for the $6 billion on offer.
As we live longer and inflation stays high, one may need to work one's CPF savings harder.

site_title: Singapore shares slip; STI down 0.4%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.4% to 3,074.26 on Thursday, wiping out gains from the previous day. The broader market saw decliners outnumbering advancers 308 to 277, with 888 million securities changing hands. Jardine Matheson stocks declined heavily, falling 1.2% to close at US$40.20. The decline was attributed to a weaker market.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Chinese vice-premier Ding Xuexiang meet in Tianjin, China to co-chair the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.
The latest tranche of six-month T-bills received a total of S$13.3 billion in applications for the S$5.9 billion on offer, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.25.

site_title: BOJ rate-hike bets ramp up as Ueda and Himino spook traders
summary: The Bank of Japan's benchmark 10-year government bond yield jumped 8.5 basis points to 0.73% on Thursday, snapping a three-day decline, after weak demand from a 30-year government debt auction and comments from Governor Kazuo Ueda and Deputy Governor Ryozo Himino. The yen strengthened 0.4% against the dollar, with traders now expecting the BOJ to end its negative interest rate policy in December, citing a 45% chance of such an action. The BOJ's December policy meeting is seen as a "live" event, with market participants pricing in the central bank's exit from ultra-loose monetary policy in January.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Australia’s goods trade surplus widens to A$7.1 billion in October
summary: Australia's goods trade surplus widened to A$7.1 billion in October, surpassing market forecasts of A$7.5 billion. Exports rose 0.4% driven by increased iron ore and metal exports, while imports fell 1.9% due to a drop in industrial equipment and a stable car market. This marks a reversal of the sharp jump in imports the previous month. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has ceased reporting monthly data for service exports and imports, which will now be issued quarterly.

site_title: Rising war risks prompt property insurers to rethink cover
summary: International property insurers are reevaluating coverage for conflict zones due to rising war risks. Many have scaled back or stopped offering policies in Ukraine and Israel following recent conflicts, with insurers in the US, Bermuda, and Lloyd's of London reducing coverage for Taiwan due to concerns of a potential attack by China. Insurers are now considering reduced coverage for other vulnerable regions, with some clients struggling to secure coverage for areas like Israel, where rates have increased by 10 times or more.

images.alt_text: An oil processing facility at the Shaybah oil field in the Rub' Al-Khali desert, also known as the 'Empty Quarter,' in Shaybah, Saudi Arabia. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s Xi warns top EU officials not to engage in ‘confrontation’
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned top EU officials not to view each other as rivals and to avoid "confrontation" due to differing political systems. During the first in-person China-EU summit in four years, Xi offered to make the EU a key economic and trade partner and cooperate on science and technology. However, EU officials expressed concerns over China's influence on Russia, trade imbalances, and restrictions on EU businesses operating in China. The EU also urged China to eliminate "interference" in the bilateral relationship and to develop a "right perception" of each other.

images.alt_text: Trade will top the agenda when European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen (above) and European Council President Charles Michel meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Qiang on Thursday.

site_title: Signa insolvency is credit negative for some banks, says Moody's
summary: Moody's has downgraded the credit rating of some Austrian, German, and Swiss banks due to the insolvency of European property and retail giant Signa. The agency cites the "opaque and complicated" structure of Signa's loans and declining valuations of pledged assets as factors contributing to increased potential losses. This move adds to concerns about the eurozone's commercial property sector, which the European Central Bank has warned could struggle for years, posing a threat to banks and investors.

site_title: Russia pledges more oil data to ship trackers to soothe Opec+: sources
summary: Russia has pledged to provide more data on its fuel refining and exports to Opec+, aiming to soothe concerns about transparency. The country, the world's second-largest oil and fuel exporter, will share data on crude production, inventories, and refinery fuel output to give a more comprehensive picture of its compliance with production cuts. This comes after Opec+ asked Russia for more transparency on classified fuel shipments. The move is seen as a response to Saudi Arabia's concerns about Russia's production levels.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$2.90, or 3.8 per cent, at US$74.30 a barrel on Wednesday.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) sits outside its headquarters ahead of the OPEC and NON-OPEC meeting, Austria December 6, 2019. REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger
Brent crude oil futures fell 83 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$77.20 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) ended 72 cents, or 1.0 per cent, lower at US$72.32 on Tuesday.

site_title: Robinhood launches commission-free crypto trading in EU
summary: Robinhood has launched commission-free crypto trading in the European Union, allowing European investors to buy and sell over 25 cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ethereum. The app will also provide a monthly percentage of trading volume in Bitcoin to customers. This launch follows Robinhood's announcement to roll out brokerage services in the UK as part of its international expansion plan to "democratise finance".

site_title: We are all Argentines
summary: Argentina's presidential election saw Javier Milei win with 44.3% of the vote, but Sergio Massa, the sitting economy minister, garnered 11.5 million votes. Despite running a massive fiscal deficit financed by printing money, resulting in 135% inflation and 95% public debt, Massa won the first round. This election highlights how voters in Argentina continue to support misguided economic policies, despite their repeated failures. Massa's concession defeat may have been due to the unpopularity of his economic policies, which have led to Argentina's economic struggles.

images.alt_text: Argentine president-elect Javier Milei faces major hurdles to implement his more radical reform plans, which include US dollarizing the economy, shutting the central bank and privatising state entities.

Attention will now turn to how Javier Milei implements his most contested measures with only a handful of representatives in a fragmented congress and an impatient electorate, with more than 40 per cent of Argentines below the poverty line.

The Bemol Solar plant outside Manaus in Brazil. Latin America could be a clean energy powerhouse as it  is sunny, windy, and (in parts) endowed with abundant water, and therefore very competitive in solar, wind, and hydro power.
Chilean president Gabriel Boric arriving at the South American Presidents' Summit at the Itamaraty Palace in Brasilia, Brazil, May 30, 2023.

site_title: China's November iron ore imports stay at elevated level on improving margins
summary: China's iron ore imports in November rose 3.4% to 102.7 million metric tonnes, staying at an elevated level for the fourth consecutive month. Improved steel mill margins and a rebounding yuan fueled the increase. This brings the first 11 months of 2023 imports to a record high of 1.08 billion tonnes. Analysts expect the annual total to hit an all-time high, with December imports likely to remain near the same level as November due to winter restocking needs.

images.alt_text: The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) says it had recently held a meeting with major ports, to understand portside iron ore inventory and storage fees at yards.
Renewables account for 57% of overseas development projects that are currently planned or in construction, compared to 37% of the capacity built over the last decade
The most-traded January iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange (DCE) ended daytime trading 1.03 per cent higher at 935 yuan (S$174.47) a metric ton.

site_title: UK wage hike to hit shoppers’ pockets, warn pub and retail chiefs
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's move to increase the national living wage by almost 10% to £11.44 an hour could lead to higher prices and costs for retailers and hospitality businesses. The increase, set to take effect in April, affects around 3 million workers, with many in the retail and food sectors already struggling with labor costs and the cost-of-living crisis. Retailers warn of potential job cuts and price hikes, while some bosses, such as SSP Group's CEO, see the rise in wages as a positive step for society, with higher entry-level wages potentially filtering up through the workforce.

images.alt_text: Dave Ramsden, deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The Bank of England hiked interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis and warned the economy is on course to shrink under pressure from double-digit inflation. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
The Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, attends a press conference in London, Britain, May 11, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/Pool

Glass repairer Jamie Seale works to remove any imperfections in the lead crystal glassware produced in Cumbria Crystal's factory in Ulverston near Barrow-in-Furness, northern England, on March 16, 2023. - Cumbria Crystal are the only remaining factory in the UK that still has the knowledge and capacity to produce luxury, hand-blown, cut and finished stem and barware. The company specialises in the use traditional methods; shunning automated blowing and cutting used by many manufacturers. A typical glass will take 10-14 days to produce from start to finish and pass through at least 9 pairs or artisans' hands. The company produces crystal for all the British Embassies and Residencies across the world to grace formal dinners and state occasions as well as featuring in the TV drama Downton Abbey and James Bond films. (Photo by OLI SCARFF / AFP)

site_title: Woman who bought S$18.68m GCB loses lawsuit against property agency over seller’s brochure
summary: A Singapore woman, Jane Lam, sued her real estate agency, Realstar Premier Group, alleging false representations about the redevelopment potential of a S$18.68 million Good Class Bungalow (GCB). The agency's agent, Darren Teo, claimed to have shown her a marketing brochure that implied the entire land area could be redeveloped, but the High Court dismissed her negligent misrepresentation suit, stating that any false impression was a "misimpression on her part." The court ruled that Teo's role was limited to passing the brochure, and he did not have to verify its contents.

images.alt_text: The purchasers had taken the property developer to court in a bid to get a full refund of the money they paid in two aborted attempts to buy a unit at The Crest.

site_title: EV maker Nio considers more job cuts after shedding 10 per cent of staff
summary: Chinese electric carmaker Nio is considering further job cuts to reduce costs and improve efficiency, just weeks after eliminating 10% of its workforce. The company may cut 20-30% of its workforce in non-core businesses, with sales and central parts of the business still hiring. Nio has been struggling to meet sales targets and post losses, and has delayed or suspended international expansion plans, including entering the US market. The company's revenue forecast for the fourth quarter fell short of analyst estimates, and it has received a US$738.5 million investment from an Abu Dhabi government-backed fund.

images.alt_text: The logo of NIO seen on an EL6 car model is pictured at the NIO House, the showroom of the Chinese premium smart electric vehicle manufacture NIO Inc. in Berlin, Germany August 17, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse

site_title: China slams ‘smearing’ of Belt and Road project after Italy withdraws
summary: China has strongly reacted to Italy's decision to withdraw from the Belt and Road Initiative, calling it a "smearing" of the project. This move comes four years after Italy became the only G7 nation to sign up for the infrastructure project. Foreign ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin stated that China opposes smearing and undermining cooperation on the project, and also condemned "confrontation and division among camps that causes separation". China's President Xi Jinping's Belt and Road Initiative is a key component of his foreign policy strategy to expand China's influence overseas.

images.alt_text: Singapore and China signed more than 20 Memoranda of Understanding and agreements at the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.
An artist's impression of the city centre of Tianjin Eco-City.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Chinese vice-premier Ding Xuexiang meet in Tianjin, China to co-chair the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation.

site_title: Indonesia prepares ethics guidance for AI developers: draft
summary: Indonesia's communications ministry has drafted ethics guidance for AI developers to prevent potential misuse of the technology. The draft emphasizes the need for developers to establish ethics governing AI use and development, including risk management strategies and reporting mechanisms for incidents. The guidance aims to mitigate impacts and losses from AI use, ensuring the responsible development and deployment of AI in the country.

images.alt_text: Sam Altman is granted a 10-year visa for his potential contributions to the development of artificial intelligence in Indonesia.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence up slightly in November on government measures
summary: Thai consumer confidence increased to 60.9 in November, up from 60.2 in the previous month, according to the University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce. The rise is attributed to government measures reducing energy prices and relaxing visa rules for tourists. The slight increase suggests an improvement in consumer sentiment, which may support economic growth.

site_title: MAS seeks feedback on moves to beef up protection scheme when an insurer fails
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is seeking feedback on proposed changes to the Policy Owners' Protection (PPF) scheme, which protects policyholders when an insurer fails. The changes aim to enhance coverage, improve efficiency, and provide more prompt compensation to covered parties. Proposed expansions include coverage of mandatory third-party liability insurance for mobility devices and personal travel insurance policies. MAS also proposes simplifying calculations for refunds of unused premiums and introducing a seven-year time limit for reporting claim events. The public can submit comments on the proposals by February 16, 2024.

images.alt_text: A food delivery rider from Grab at Jurong East, 2 Dec 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong billionaire Cheng family boosts New World stake
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Henry Cheng's family increased its stake in New World Development by purchasing shares through Chow Tai Fook Capital, boosting the company's stake to 45.24% as of June 30. The move comes as New World's shares have dropped 50% this year, citing high debt levels and rising borrowing costs. Analysts say the family's support is likely to boost the stock, but the company's high debt-to-equity ratio and lower earnings will weigh on its share price.

images.alt_text: New World, which has one of the highest debt ratios among its peers after a years-long expansion spree, had US$8.4 billion dollars worth of outstanding bonds before it launched the tender offer for seven of its bonds.

site_title: Fintech startup Pontera raises US$60 million, plans more hiring in Israel
summary: Fintech startup Pontera has raised US$60 million in funding led by Iconiq Growth, valuing the company at over US$550 million. The company plans to use the funds to invest in product and engineering, including hiring 50 more employees in Israel. Pontera's annual revenue has quadrupled since 2021 and makes money by charging a percentage fee to financial advisors using its platform. The company counts Blumberg Capital and Lightspeed Venture Partners as backers, and has 220 employees, 65% of whom are based in Israel.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered group chief executive Bill Winters also sees plenty of potential in the tokenisation of assets, calling this field “extremely exciting”, albeit immature.

MADCash is founded by managing director Nuraizah Shamsul Baharin (left) and has brought on board Musyrifah Malek as a co-founder, in charge of improving the startup’s corporate governance policy and practices with her legal background.

site_title: Enhancements to FTA among 24 deals signed to deepen Singapore, China cooperation
summary: Singapore and China have signed over 20 memoranda of understanding and agreements at the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation, aiming to deepen trade and investment links between the two countries. The China-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (CSFTA) will be enhanced with more business-friendly and transparent rules, including greater market access for Singapore businesses and simplified customs procedures. The upgraded agreement also includes new initiatives on digital policy dialogue, financial cooperation, and tourism. The moves are expected to strengthen economic ties between Singapore and China, with the aim of fostering an "all-round, high-quality, future-oriented partnership".

site_title: Meta to start fully encrypting messages on Facebook and Messenger
summary: Meta has started rolling out end-to-end encryption for all personal chats and calls on Messenger and Facebook, making messages encrypted by default. The feature is available immediately, but it may take time for all accounts to be updated. This move aims to keep users safe from hackers, fraudsters, and criminals. Meta's decision comes after the British government urged the company to implement safety measures to protect children from sexual abuse.

site_title: KPMG plans merger of UK and Swiss businesses: FT
summary: KPMG is planning a merger of its UK and Swiss businesses, with partners told of the talks last Friday. The goal is to boost growth and profit by bringing together the two firms' collective power to invest and build new services for clients. KPMG UK has around 17,000 employees, while KPMG Switzerland has 2,600 employees. The move aims to give the company more collective power to invest and build new services, but a comment from KPMG was not immediately available.

images.alt_text: PricewaterhouseCoopers firms in Hong Kong and China have agreed to pay US$7 million for violating quality control standards after they failed to detect or prevent extensive answer-sharing on mandatory training courses.
John McCalla-Leacy,
The Singapore office of KPMG is training staff and building its own ESG capabilities accordingly, said managing partner Lee Sze Yeng.
The job cuts, affecting up to 2.4 per cent of the 25,000 workforce, will be directed mainly at PwC’s advisory business with a small number in the tax department also set to be affected.

site_title: Australia, Papua New Guinea announce security deal
summary: Australia and Papua New Guinea have reached a security deal, bolstering ties with a key Pacific neighbor amid China's growing influence. The agreement focuses on domestic security, addressing issues like arms trafficking, drug smuggling, and tribal violence. The deal includes more resources for Papua New Guinea's police and measures to tackle gender-based violence, as well as climate change, cyber security, and disaster relief. The agreement comes after Papua New Guinea granted the US "unimpeded" access to naval bases and ports, sparking concerns about sovereignty.

images.alt_text: China's ambassador to Solomon Islands Li Ming (left) sits with officials aboard a Chinese naval hospital ship after it arrived into Honiara, Solomon Islands on Aug 19, 2023. Solomon Islands and Kiribati both severed diplomatic links with Taiwan in September 2019, switching to Beijing in the wake of a sustained charm offensive.

“The United States is committed to ensuring an Indo-Pacific region that is free, open, prosperous, and secure. We’re committed to working with all the nations around this table to achieve that goal,” Joe Biden says.
US President Joe Biden  will host a second summit with Pacific island leaders this week.

Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister James Marape (fourth from right), India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi (fourth from left) and leaders posing for a group photo during the Forum for India-Pacific Islands Cooperation in Port Moresby. Papua New Guinea, May 22, 2023.
Under Philippines president Ferdinand Marcos Jr, the US is getting several new footholds in the country – a crucial link in the Pentagon’s “island chain” strategy for defensive lines in the Pacific.
Re-establishing an embassy is a renewal “of our commitment to the people of Solomon Islands and our partnerships in the Indo-Pacific region,” US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said in a statement.
Australia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the agreement is proof that the country remains the “security partner of choice” for Vanuatu.

site_title: Japan prosecutors to investigate ruling party heavyweights over fundraising: Yomiuri
summary: Japanese prosecutors will investigate dozens of ruling party lawmakers, including current ministers, over unreported fundraising of over 100 million yen. This scandal further weakens Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's administration, whose ratings have sunk below 30% in recent polls. Trade Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura and Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno, who previously oversaw the faction's bookkeeping, have declined to comment on allegations of improper fundraising. The investigation will begin after the current parliament session ends on Dec 13.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Ryozo Himino speaks during an interview with Reuters in Tokyo, Japan, June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: SingPost to raise international postage rates by S$0.05 in 2024
summary: SingPost will introduce a S$0.05 rate hike for most international airmail letters, printed papers, aerogrammes, and postcards from January 1, 2024. Exceptions include rates for aerogrammes to Malaysia and Brunei, which will remain at S$0.80 per piece, and mail charges for additional weightage. The rate hike is due to annual fee revisions made by the Universal Postal Union, which led to a progressive increase in international postal settlement rates.

images.alt_text: SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.
SingPost says its proposed acquisition of Border Express aligns with the group's strategic ambition to expand its logistics network and foster synergy within its Australian operations.

SingPost's Singapore CEO Neo Su Yin (left) and FedEx Express Singapore's managing director, Eric Tan (right). Both companies are conducting a trial for SingPost post offices to accept FedEx parcels at POPStop counters.
About 86 per cent of SingPost’s revenue is now generated internationally.

site_title: Singapore stocks open on Thursday tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks opened on Thursday with a 0.6% decline, mirroring overnight losses on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index fell 16.93 points to 3,070.31. Losers outnumbered gainers 66 to 37, with banking stocks leading the decline. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.6% on Wednesday.

site_title: Bank of England joins warnings on red-hot private credit market
summary: The Bank of England has joined warnings about the booming US$1.6-trillion private credit market, citing riskier types of corporate borrowing as vulnerable to "sharp revaluations" in credit markets. The central bank's Financial Policy Committee highlighted the interconnectedness of private credit with the leveraged world and private equity, and warned of potential disruptions to markets and the real economy if significant losses occur. This comes after two senior Democratic senators asked US regulators to assess the risks private credit may pose, and follows concerns from UBS Group AG Chairman Colm Kelleher about an asset bubble forming in private debt.

images.alt_text: The US dollar and euro currency.

The FCA proposals follow a recommendation from the BOE in October that the £250 billion-(S$422 billion) sterling money market funds sector, widely used by companies for day-to-day funding and parking cash overnight, needed to be more resilient.

Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
If traders are right, the ECB will be the first among major central banks to cut rates next year, and will deliver the most aggressive easing cycle.

site_title: Doctor Anywhere raises US$40.8 million in Series C1 extension round
summary: Healthcare startup Doctor Anywhere has raised US$40.8 million in a Series C1 extension all-equity funding round, with existing shareholders Square Peg and Novo Holdings participating. The funds will be used to scale up healthcare solutions, improve accessibility and efficiency, and expand specialist care. Doctor Anywhere aims to aid customers with early detection and preventive measures against chronic illnesses, following its acquisition of Asian Healthcare Specialists. The startup's 2022 revenue grew 61.8% to S$51.6 million, with losses widening to S$44.6 million.

images.alt_text: Lim Wai Mun, founder and chief executive officer of Doctor Anywhere said the acquisition would strengthen the group’s capabilities and enable the group deliver “more integrated, holistic care and greater value” for its users.
The deal values Asian Healthcare Specialists at S$109 million.
Doctor Anywhere bags US$65.7 million in Series C round led by Asia Partners

The lifting of Covid-19 restrictions was expected to lead to a decline in the popularity of telehealth services such as Doctor Anywhere's remote Covid testing offering (pictured). This has not turned out to be the case.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Klook snags US$210 million funding in travel bounceback
summary: Klook, a SoftBank-backed booking service, raised US$210 million in funding led by Bessemer Venture Partners to expand its travel booking platform as travel recovers post-pandemic. The startup, which turned cash-flow positive in mid-2023, plans to go public in the US or Hong Kong. Klook's revenue has increased with the lifting of Covid restrictions, and the company expects an outsized boost for travel demand in Asia, predicting double the growth of the West. This funding brings the startup's total raised to over US$900 million.

images.alt_text: The Expedia website on a laptop arranged in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, US, on Monday, July 31, 2023. Expedia Group Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on August 3. Photographer: Tiffany Hagler-Geard/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Petroleum-linked shares tumble as stocks retreat
summary: US stocks retreated, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.2% to 36,054.43 on Wednesday. The private sector added 103,000 jobs in November, below analyst estimates, and oil prices tumbled. This follows a gloomy week, as the job market cooled further.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 59.17 points, or 0.16 per cent at the open, to 36,183.73.

site_title: Asia tracks Wall Street sell-off as US labour market softens
summary: Asian stocks sank on Thursday, extending a global sell-off, as investors awaited key US jobs data and concerns over the labour market and economy. The US labour market showed signs of contracting faster than expected, fueling bets on the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates as early as the first quarter. Oil prices edged up but struggled to recover from a five-month low. The slowdown in jobs creation has caused concern, with analysts warning of a potential heavy sell-off in markets if the Fed or data shock sparks a hawkish turn.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2 per cent to 36,054.43 on Wednesday.
Singapore stocks open on Thursday tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.6%

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.4% in November, but volumes decline: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.4% in November, with a 5.4% year-on-year increase, but transaction volumes declined 2.8% from October and 0.1% from last year, according to SRX and 99.co. Industry watchers expect muted demand in December due to the holiday season, with Christine Sun citing increased housing options as a possible reason for the slowdown.

images.alt_text: The projects in the December 2023 BTO exercise are in Bedok, Bishan, Bukit Merah, Bukit Panjang, Jurong West, Queenstown and Woodlands.
To cushion the impact of property tax increases, amid concerns about the cost of living, the government will provide a one-off property tax rebate for all owner-occupied residential properties.
The community care apartments in Bedok is part of the Chai Chee Green BTO development which will comprise a total of 1,234 units.
Stricter rules for the non-selection of a BTO flat has led buyers to look towards the resale market instead, property analysts observe.
Arguably, HDB BTO 5-room flats should be bought mainly by larger households and not two-person households.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, ComfortDelGro, SingPost, Manulife US Reit
summary: Keppel's infrastructure division partnered with the Abu Dhabi Future Energy Company to develop decarbonization and sustainability solutions in Asean and the Middle East. ComfortDelGro will increase flag-down fares by S$0.50 for taxis starting Dec 13. Singapore Post will raise international airmail rates by S$0.05 from Jan 1, 2024. Manulife US Reit faced questions from Securities Investors Association (Singapore) regarding its fundraising proposal.

site_title: Singapore to take AI questions to UN body in hopes of shaping agenda
summary: Singapore has compiled a list of 12 questions on artificial intelligence to submit to the UN High-Level Advisory Body on AI, aiming to shape the global AI agenda. The questions, discussed at the Singapore Conference on AI, cover critical aspects such as AI development, use, evaluation, and governance. Experts believe collaboration between academia, industry, and government is key to harnessing AI for the public good. The UN advisory body, which runs until September 2024, will consider recommendations for international AI governance, and any developments will be shared in due course.

images.alt_text: Recent breakthroughs in generative AI have sparked renewed interest about the potential of AI, its risks and its implications for humanity, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the Singapore Conference on AI, which runs from Dec 4 to 6.

Artist impression of DC Tuas, which Singtel says will be one of the most efficient DC in the industry.

Developed market companies like Nvidia may have dominated the headlines as the first wave of investment opportunity centres around computing power, but there are secondary role opportunities in the wider tech supply chain for EM businesses.
Nvidia is looking to potentially make "large investments" in artificial intelligence in Singapore, said CEO Jensen Huang.

site_title: Regulators should clear path for unitholders of trusts to push for manager-internalisation
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trust (Reit) and business trust sector may see a boost if trusts are internally managed rather than externally managed. A group of investors, claiming to own over 10% of Dasin Retail Trust (DRT), recently requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove its existing trustee-manager. This comes after unitholders of Sabana Industrial Trust (Sabana Reit) voted to remove its manager and direct its trustee to set up an internal manager. Regulators, including MAS and SGX RegCo, should weigh in on whether ESR Group should be barred from voting on an extraordinary resolution to amend Sabana Reit's trust deed.

images.alt_text: Why has Quarz decided to push Sabana Reit down this path despite all the risks?
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's unitholders voted to remove its manager at its Aug 7 EGM.
The Reit’s trustee is in the process of searching and appointing an executive search firm to help staff the new internal manager.

New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. Earlier this year, ESR Group and Quarz were embroiled in a public battle over the internalisation of the Reit management function of Sabana Reit,
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. On Aug 7, unitholders of Sabana Reit voted in favour of internalisation, with both resolutions carried.

The offshore facility in default is used to finance the acquisitions of the trust’s initial portfolio comprising Xiaolan Metro Mall, Ocean Metro Mall, Dasin E-Colour and Shiqi Metro Mall.
The 400-million-yuan onshore facility is for Dasin Retail Trust's acquisitions of its initial portfolio including Ocean Metro Mall.
Ocean Metro Mall, one of Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio assets. Its unitholders are seeking to hold an extraordinary general meeting to internalise its trustee-manager.
Dasin Retail Trust is potentially divesting one or two of its malls as it looks to restructure its loan maturities.

site_title: G7 to ban Russian diamonds starting next year
summary: The G7 has agreed to ban imports of rough diamonds directly from Russia starting January 1, 2024, and processed diamonds from March 1, 2024, as part of efforts to curb Russia's war funding in Ukraine. The ban aims to reduce the flow of money from the diamond trade to Russia, with a full traceability system to be implemented by September. The move follows lobbying from the diamond industry, with Belgium proposing a digital ledger system for tracing diamonds. The G7 will continue to consult with diamond-producing countries on the tracing system.

images.alt_text: The EU proposal says the ban applied to Russia's non-industrial natural and synthetic diamonds and diamond jewellery from January 2024.
Taiwan remains a critical player in advanced semiconductor manufacturing. But the US is also trying to diversify semiconductor production out of Taiwan into the US and other close allies.
“There is no magical pot of funding available to meet this moment, we are out of money – and nearly out of time,” says Shalanda Young, director of Office of Management and Budget.

site_title: Britain names Samir Shah as new BBC chairman
summary: Britain's government named veteran TV executive Samir Shah as the new BBC chairman, replacing Richard Sharp who quit in April due to a loan to former Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Shah, 71, will negotiate with the government for an increase in the licence fee, which is facing a potential block by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak. The BBC is under increased funding pressures, aiming to cut £500 million in savings, including cuts to the flagship Newsnight programme. Shah's appointment comes at a crucial time for the BBC.

images.alt_text: BBC chairman Richard Sharp said he had agreed to a request to stay on until the end of June to give the government time to find his successor.

site_title: A year after government takeover, Sports Hub saw 30% increase in event days in 2023
summary: The Singapore Sports Hub marked its first full year after government takeover with a 30% increase in event days in 2023, exceeding pre-Covid levels in 2019. This growth is attributed to sold-out concerts, major sports events, and school sports events. The hub expects to draw close to a million visitors in 2024, with a stellar lineup of artistes and sports events. Minister Edwin Tong hailed the "progressive transformation" of the Sports Hub, while KASM chairman Keith Magnus attributed the success to Singapore's position as a leading destination for live sports and entertainment in Asia.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand will introduce its shopping rewards programmes CapitaStar and eCapitaVoucher at Kallang Wave Mall.
Thousands will travel there in early 2024 as British rock band Coldplay and American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift are scheduled to perform, each in a series of six dates at the National Stadium.
The Professional Triathletes Organisation's first Asian Open was held in August 2023, one of many international sporting events held in Singapore this year.

site_title: Apple executive who invented iPhone screen and Touch ID is leaving
summary: Apple senior executive Steve Hotelling, responsible for touch-screen technology, health sensors, and Face ID, is retiring from the company. Hotelling, who held hundreds of patents, including those related to the iPhone's multitouch screen and Touch ID, is leaving at a pivotal time for Apple's hardware technologies group, which is working to develop in-house technologies. His responsibilities are being divided among multiple executives, including Alan Gilchrist and Wei Chen. The departure marks a significant loss for Apple, with a longtime peer calling Hotelling "one of the most brilliant people I've ever met."

images.alt_text: “If the regulation is implemented on earlier models of mobile phones, they (Apple) will not be able to meet the PLI targets,” says Apple.

Foxconn says that with the second half of the year being the traditional peak season for the tech industry, revenue performance in the first two months of the fourth quarter had been slightly higher than expected.
Foxconn, which employs about 35,000 people at its Tamil Nadu iPhone factory, has yet to decide whether to resume production on Tuesday,
The companies have talked about offering a combined Paramount+ and Apple TV+ offering that would cost less than subscribing to both services separately.

site_title: Yellen says markets anticipating Fed moves can be ‘helpful complement’ to monetary policy
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that bond markets anticipating Federal Reserve rate moves can be a "helpful complement" to monetary policy if participants are thoughtful in interpreting data. Yellen declined to comment on whether markets are premature in anticipating rate cuts, but said the Fed wants to create financial conditions for inflation reduction. She reiterated her view that a "soft landing" scenario for the US economy is on track, but acknowledged risks and the possibility of slower growth than desirable.

images.alt_text: US trade deficit increases 5.1 per cent to US$64.3 billion.
Nonfarm productivity, which measures hourly output per worker, increases at a 5.2 per cent annualised rate last quarter.

Representative Sara McKethan, left, hands a list of employment descriptions to a job seeker during the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Sara McKethan

Many economists believe that the US non-inflationary growth rate is about 1.8 per cent annually, but Janet Yellen has argued that federal investments in infrastructure, semiconductors and clean energy technology are raising its productive capacity.

site_title: Europe: Germany’s DAX touches fresh record high on ECB rate cut hopes
summary: Germany's DAX index reached a fresh record high on Wednesday, rising 0.8% as investors bet on a swift European Central Bank rate cut in 2024 following disappointing industrial orders data. The Stoxx 600 index also rose 0.6%, with mining and healthcare stocks supporting gains. Eurozone government bond yields fell to multi-month lows, while US job openings data led investors to price in a potential Federal Reserve rate cut in March.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2 per cent to 36,054.43 on Wednesday.

site_title: Gold prices firm as US jobs data fuels rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices remained firm on Thursday, with spot gold up 0.1% at $2,027.12 per ounce, despite US gold futures falling 0.2% to $2,044.10. The news is attributed to cooling 10-year Treasury notes near a three-month low and robust worker productivity in the third quarter. Investors await US non-farm payrolls data on Friday, which may influence the Fed's interest rate projections at their upcoming meeting. A 60% chance of a rate cut by March next year has been priced in, according to the CME's FedWatch Tool.

images.alt_text: A stronger US dollar makes greenback-priced gold more expensive for other currency holders.

site_title: Chevron increases project spending budget for 2024
summary: Chevron has increased its 2024 capital expenditure budget to between US$18.5 billion and US$19.5 billion, a 11% rise from this year. The proposed acquisition of US rival Hess Corp is expected to close next year, with Chevron allocating US$5 billion to its Permian shale production operation and US$1.5 billion to other shale and tight oil businesses. This increase reflects the company's acquisition of PDC Energy earlier this year.

site_title: Keppel, Masdar tie up for decarbonisation, sustainability projects in Asean, Middle East
summary: Keppel and Masdar have partnered to develop decarbonisation and sustainability projects in ASEAN and the Middle East. The companies signed a memorandum of understanding at COP28, exploring solutions for utility-scale renewable projects, energy storage, and grid transmission systems. They will also co-develop large-scale floating solar photovoltaics systems in Singapore and the region, and identify opportunities in energy-as-a-service, waste-to-energy, and desalination treatment in the Middle East. The partnership aims to leverage Keppel's expertise in cross-border electricity trade and Masdar's plans to implement renewable projects in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: From right: Cindy Lim, CEO, Keppel’s Infrastructure Division and Mr Mohamed Jameel Al Ramahi, CEO, Masdar.

site_title: EU scientists say 2023 will be the warmest year on record globally
summary: EU scientists announced that 2023 will be the warmest year on record globally, with global mean temperatures 1.46 degrees Celsius above the 1850-1900 average. This surpasses the current record holder, 2016. The record-breaking temperatures, including two days warmer than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, were attributed to extraordinary global November temperatures. The announcement comes as governments negotiate the phase-out of CO2-emitting coal, oil, and gas at the COP28 summit in Dubai.

images.alt_text: Malaria remains a top killer of children.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on rate cut optimism
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by optimism about potential rate cuts from the Federal Reserve in early 2024, following data showing a cooling labor market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 59.17 points, or 0.16%, to 36,183.73, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained.

site_title: Volkswagen to reduce workforce as it chases profits
summary: Volkswagen plans to reduce its workforce globally, focusing on partial and early retirement schemes, to boost profitability and reboot its electric car shift. The company aims to reduce staff costs in non-production areas by 20% without significantly reducing the workforce. With 675,800 employees worldwide, the move is part of a $10.8 billion savings program to achieve its long-term profit margins goal of 9-11%. The measures also include process improvements and structural adjustments to address the weak global economy and rising costs.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen is in the middle of negotiations with its works council over a cost-cutting scheme at its VW brand, the first step in a group-wide drive to boost efficiency in the transition to electric cars.

site_title: Dell’s 90% rally hits wall as AI optimism met with reality check
summary: Dell's stock, which surged nearly 90% to a record in November, has faltered since its third-quarter report showed AI demand was not meeting expectations. Analysts, including Gabelli Funds and Morningstar, are questioning the stock's price tag, citing a lack of materialized growth. Despite this, Wall Street remains bullish, with over 70% of analysts having a buy-equivalent rating, and the average price target implying 13% upside. Dell's solid financial position and potential for future AI demand growth have left some investors optimistic about the company's long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: Dell is supplying Imbue with servers to enable the startup to process the vast amount of data needed to develop its AI systems and build models with advanced reasoning capabilities.
AI demand has recently emerged as a bright spot for Dell after several quarters of sales declines due to lower digital spending.
Dell is expected to see a demand boost for its PowerEdge servers and generative AI designs with Nvidia from rising investments in artificial intelligence by Big Tech companies.

site_title: Big US banks balk at new capital rules in Senate hearing
summary: Largest US banks, including JPMorgan Chase, expressed opposition to new proposed capital requirements, citing potential impact on loans to everyday Americans. The Basel III Endgame rule, aimed at strengthening the banking system post-2007-2009 financial crisis, would increase capital requirements by 20-25% on the largest banks. Banking executives, including JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, argued that the rule would lead to reduced lending and higher fees. Senate Republicans echoed these concerns, while Senator Sherrod Brown defended the rule, stating it would protect the bank system from another catastrophic meltdown.

images.alt_text: Flags are pictured during the first working session of G-7 foreign ministers in Muenster, Germany, November 3, 2022.  REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/Pool

Borrowers can get better conditions at new types of investment firms that are willing to take the risk that banks are no longer interested in bearing. But these investors require a certain level of control over their creditors.
Prior rate hikes by central banks and rising unemployment in advanced economies will weaken asset quality, Moody’s Investors Services says in an outlook report.
The US dollar and euro currency.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage decreases 20 basis points to 7.17 per cent in the week ended Dec 1, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

site_title: Fossil fuels are still needed, but they must be drastically reduced
summary: COP28 president Sultan Al Jaber stated that fossil fuels remain necessary in many net-zero pathways, but these projections come with caveats. Fossil fuels are expected to remain a significant energy source, around 30% of primary energy supply, in most scenarios aiming to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius by mid-century, according to the IPCC. This stance is nuanced, as it acknowledges the need to sharply reduce fossil fuel use, despite their expected role in the energy mix.

images.alt_text: Activists participate in a demonstration against fossil fuels, during the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Dec 5, 2023.
The allegations against Sultan Al Jaber, who is also CEO of UAE’s oil giant Adnoc, have fanned long-running suspicions over the wisdom of a petrostate hosting the COP28 talks.
Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean speaking to media at the sidelines of COP28
People protest against fossil fuels in Brussels, Belgium, Dec 3, 2023. The protest, coinciding with the COP28 in Dubai, is calling for urgent measures to combat climate change.
Calls to overhaul the way the banks are run in response to the climate crisis have picked up amid record extreme weather events.

site_title: Singapore food manufacturers in spotlight as Asean consumption recovers
summary: Singapore-listed food and beverage manufacturers are expected to benefit from a post-Covid consumption recovery in South-east Asia in 2024, with companies like Delfi and Food Empire showing resilience despite higher interest rates and inflationary pressures. Analysts favor Delfi due to its strong presence in Indonesia, while Food Empire's core market in Vietnam is also performing well. However, companies selling consumer goods with higher brand equity are faring better, and some products, such as instant coffee, are more resilient due to limited consumer alternatives. A gradual recovery is expected, with upside for investors in the year ahead.

images.alt_text: Consumers are spending more on travel, dining, and entertainment, says the bank, and this is testament to their preference for seeking out experiences over material possessions.

Food Empire’s potential dual primary listing on the Hong Kong exchange could be interesting to watch. But without significant operations in East Asia, it might be difficult for Food Empire to stir up interest in the Hong Kong market.
ThaiBev's Chang Beer. Both DBS and RHB maintain “buy” on the counter and perceived ThaiBev’s valuations to be attractive.
Delfi products
Local prices are up more than 40 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Oil falls 4% as build in petrol stocks fuel demand concerns
summary: Oil prices fell 3.8% to their lowest settlements since June, settling at $74.30 a barrel, amid concerns over global fuel demand and a larger-than-expected rise in US petrol inventories. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 5.4 million-barrel increase in petrol stocks last week, more than quintuple analysts' expectations. Concerns over China's economic health and the US dollar's two-week high also weighed on prices, with petrol demand lagging the 10-year seasonal average by 2.5%.

A man stands near a COP28 sign in a metro station in Dubai on November 28, 2023, ahead of the United Nations climate summit. Brent crude oil futures fell 83 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$77.20 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) ended 72 cents, or 1.0 per cent, lower at US$72.32 on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia still probing lawyers on Goldman-1MDB settlement
summary: Malaysia is still investigating lawyers involved in a 2020 settlement with Goldman Sachs over the 1MDB scandal, despite halting a court bid to obtain documents. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission withdrew the application amid disagreements over the settlement, which included a $2.5 billion payment and the return of $1.4 billion in seized assets. The investigation continues, focusing on corruption and money laundering, and lawyers have accused the commission of attempting to smear their reputations.

images.alt_text: Executives at Goldman Sachs had grown increasingly frustrated with Malaysia's demands to redo its existing 2020 pact in favour of more onerous penalties, and the lack of information tied to the looted assets the nation has been recovering.
As part of the 2020 settlement with Malaysia, Goldman made an initial US$2.5 billion payment in September of that year.

site_title: Why the world is watching the EU-Latin American deal’s fate
summary: The European Union's trade negotiations with Mercosur (Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, and Uruguay) are on the brink of collapse, with French President Emmanuel Macron's comments criticizing the deal and Argentina's new president, Javier Milei, expressing reservations. The collapse would be a significant setback for the EU, as it would delay trade liberalization and potentially slow Europe's "de-risking" process with China. The deal, which would create an integrated market of 780 million consumers and remove estimated 4 billion euros of import tariffs, is also seen as a key opportunity for the EU to deepen ties with Latin America and counterbalance the influence of Beijing and Moscow.

images.alt_text: European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen (L), with Brazilian president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, during her trip to Latin America, including Brazil, in June 2023.

site_title: World divided at COP28 over whether to end fossil fuel era
summary: COP28 climate talks in the UAE have seen opposition to a global agreement to phase out fossil fuels, with key countries like Russia, Saudi Arabia, and China opposing the move. Despite progress made at COP26, the talks have yet to address the issue directly. Over 80 countries are pushing for a broader pact to eliminate CO2-emitting fossil fuels, with Norway's Foreign Minister calling it a necessary tool to reach the goal of an emission-free energy system. The outcome of COP28 remains uncertain, with the world divided on the issue.

images.alt_text: A man stands near a COP28 sign in a metro station in Dubai on November 28, 2023, ahead of the United Nations climate summit. The UN chief urged world leaders to take decisive action to tackle ever-worsening climate change when they gather at the COP28 summit in Dubai starting this week. (Photo by Jewel SAMAD / AFP)

site_title: Standing strong in an overcrowded fitness industry
summary: Yoga Movement, a home-grown fitness boutique chain in Singapore, has opened its 10th studio and is gearing up for its first overseas expansion under new parent company Move Repeat. Founders Peter Thew and Alicia Pan had previously rejected investment offers to retain ownership, but are now working with Hong Kong-born businessman Allen Law. The brand has remained profitable despite the pandemic, attributing its success to a sound pricing strategy and managing rent costs. Yoga Movement plans to open its first overseas outlet in Hong Kong by 2024, with potential targets in Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: On Sep 27, Pure Group announced that it would be closing its two Suntec City branches. It is the latest body blow to Singapore’s gym industry, which could see more closures in central areas, said observers.

Pure Fitness'  branch at Suntec City.  Pure Group said membership acquisitions at Suntec City “proved challenging” in spite of "multiple efforts and campaigns to drive awareness and customer engagement”.
Fenix Fitness' sole outlet at Raffles Place.

site_title: Emmy-winning TV producer-writer Norman Lear dead at age 101
summary: Norman Lear, a renowned TV producer-writer and Emmy winner, has passed away at 101. Known for his groundbreaking comedy shows addressing social issues such as racism and abortion, Lear created iconic characters like Archie Bunker from "All in the Family" and Maude. He won six Emmy awards and was a prominent advocate for liberal causes, including voting rights. Lear dominated American TV screens in the 1970s and '80s with shows like "The Jeffersons" and "Sanford and Son." His legacy continues through his work and the Norman Lear Center at the University of Southern California.

images.alt_text: The Matthew Perry Foundation “will honor his legacy and be guided by his own words and experiences and driven by his passion for making a difference in as many lives as possible,” according its website.

site_title: Opec oil output drops in November, first fall since July
summary: OPEC oil output dropped to 27.81 million barrels per day in November, the first monthly decline since July, due to lower shipments by Nigeria and Iraq, as well as ongoing supply cuts by Saudi Arabia. The decline is expected to continue in 2024, with OPEC+ agreeing to further output cuts of 2.2 million barrels per day. Iran's output hit a five-year high in November, offsetting some of the cutbacks elsewhere, but OPEC's output still undershoots the target by almost 700,000 barrels per day.

images.alt_text: Brent crude oil futures fell 83 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$77.20 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) ended 72 cents, or 1.0 per cent, lower at US$72.32 on Tuesday.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to raise cab fares, extend surcharge hours
summary: ComfortDelGro, a transport company, will raise taxi fares by 0.50 Singapore dollars (S$) for regular taxis and 0.01 S$ for distance and waiting time fares, effective Dec 13. Flag-down fares will range from S$4.40 to S$4.80, while evening peak-hour surcharge hours will be extended to 11:59 pm. A new peak-hour surcharge will also be introduced on weekends and public holidays from 10 am to 1:59 pm. The adjustments aim to help taxi drivers cover higher operating costs due to rising fuel prices and inflation.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro noted that demand remains high for taxi and private hire services, although competition is increasing.

site_title: Primed for growth: Bold strategies for S-E Asian businesses
summary: Bain & Company's report, "Sync South-east Asia," reveals consumer behaviors in the region, highlighting value-conscious spending habits and a shift towards luxury goods. The report emphasizes the importance of personalized marketing, AI, and adapting to emerging demographics such as the solo economy and Gen Z. To succeed, companies should prioritize, sequence, and fund their ambitions, focusing on future-facing opportunities, and adopting a "shapeshifter" approach that delivers new solutions for unmet needs. The region's expected GDP growth and high- and upper-middle-class populations are expected to drive consumer spending, particularly in luxury goods, with AI-powered data analytics playing a key role in meeting consumer expectations.

images.alt_text: Increasingly, younger consumers are voting with their wallet for brands that align with their value system.
A pair of Louis Vuitton brand sneakers at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris. Bain estimates that global sales of personal luxury goods will reach at least 305 billion euros this year.
Fashion retailers in Shanghai are stuck with piles of unsold stock as cautious consumers stay away from the commercial hub’s glitzy shopping districts.

site_title: US third-quarter productivity revised higher; labour costs much weaker
summary: US nonfarm productivity increased at a 5.2% annualized rate in the third quarter, revised from 4.7%, the fastest pace since 2020. This growth puts downward pressure on labor costs, potentially contributing to lower inflation. Economists had forecast a 4.9% rate.

images.alt_text: Representative Sara McKethan, left, hands a list of employment descriptions to a job seeker during the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Sara McKethan
The Institute for Supply Management says that its non-manufacturing PMI rises to 52.7 in November from 51.8, which was a 5-month low.
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, fall 617,000 to 8.733 million on the last day of October, according to Jolts report.
Factory orders fall 3.6 per cent after a downwardly revised 2.3 per cent in September.
It is the 13th consecutive month that the ISM's PMI stayed below 50, which indicates contraction in manufacturing.

site_title: ExxonMobil forecasts increases in project spending, output
summary: ExxonMobil forecasts increased project spending and output through 2027, with annual spending to range between $22 billion and $27 billion. The company expects to raise its Low Carbon Solutions unit's budget to $20 billion, requiring government support. Exxon projects annual earnings and cash flow to rise by $14 billion through 2027, driven by cost cuts, higher oil output, and gains in refining and chemicals. The company also plans to increase its share buybacks to $20 billion annually and continue its divestment plan for refining operations.

images.alt_text: To access funding from the programme, companies will need to commit to cutting methane intensity by below 0.2 per cent, halting routine flaring of natural gas by 2030 and measuring and reporting emissions.

site_title: German coalition parties at loggerheads as budget crisis grows
summary: Germany's coalition parties are at an impasse over a 17-billion-euro budget hole in 2024, increasing uncertainty about financial plans in Europe's largest economy. Talks between coalition leaders failed to reach an agreement, making it unlikely that parliament will approve a 2024 budget by the end of the year. The budget crisis centers on lifting Germany's debt brake, a self-imposed limit on net new borrowing, and funding for local authorities, businesses, and federal states.

images.alt_text: Exports to EU countries shrink by 2.7 per cent in October, according to federal statistics office.
“Employment is now only growing marginally and demand for workers continues to weaken,” says head of Germany’s Federal Labor Agency.
According to the latest estimate, 1.8 million jobs remain unfilled in the German economy as a whole.
The revised 2023 budget will now be sent to parliament for approval, with an initial debate scheduled for Friday morning.
Finance Minister Christian Lindner's budget for next year squeezes spending across all government departments except for defence and cuts net new debt from around 45 billion euros this year.

site_title: US mortgage rate drops to four-month low, boosting refinancing
summary: US mortgage rates dropped to a four-month low of 7.17% in the week ended Dec 1, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This marks the largest drop in five weeks, with a 20 basis point decrease. The rate has fallen 69 basis points since October, sparking a surge in refinancing activity, which jumped nearly 14% in the week. Economists predict this drop will lead to increased housing inventory and sales as owners refinance to lower rates.

site_title: US private payrolls miss expectations in November
summary: US private payrolls rose 103,000 jobs in November, missing expectations of 130,000. This follows 525 basis points of interest rate hikes since March 2022, causing the labour market to slow. Economists predict the Labor Department's report will show 153,000 jobs added, with total nonfarm payrolls estimated to have increased 180,000. The labour market is cooling, with job openings falling to a 2½-year low, leading to speculation that the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates as soon as next March.

images.alt_text: Many economists believe that the US non-inflationary growth rate is about 1.8 per cent annually, but Janet Yellen has argued that federal investments in infrastructure, semiconductors and clean energy technology are raising its productive capacity.
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, fall 617,000 to 8.733 million on the last day of October, according to Jolts report.

site_title: MAS publishes code of conduct for ESG rating and data providers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has published a code of conduct for environmental, social and governance (ESG) rating and data providers, setting baseline industry standards for transparency and reliability. The code, which is voluntary, aims to establish standards for methodologies, data sources, and governance. The MAS will regulate ESG rating providers as capital markets services licensees under the Securities and Futures Act, with second-party opinion providers able to opt-in. Providers are required to disclose their adoption of the code and publish a checklist of their compliance within 12 months.

images.alt_text: The survey of Iosco members to coincide with the COP28 UN climate summit in Dubai shows most jurisdictions do not specifically define greenwashing in legally binding provisions.

site_title: US trade deficit widens in October on weak exports
summary: The US trade deficit widened 5.1% in October to $64.3 billion, exceeding expectations. Exports declined, likely impacting economic growth in the fourth quarter. The October increase reversed September's decline, which was revised to $61.2 billion. Economists had forecast a $64.2 billion deficit. The widening trade gap may pose a challenge to the US economy, particularly in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Nonfarm productivity, which measures hourly output per worker, increases at a 5.2 per cent annualised rate last quarter.

Representative Sara McKethan, left, hands a list of employment descriptions to a job seeker during the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015.
