Job openings, a measure of labour demand, fall 617,000 to 8.733 million on the last day of October, according to Jolts report.
Factory orders fall 3.6 per cent after a downwardly revised 2.3 per cent in September.
It is the 13th consecutive month that the ISM's PMI stayed below 50, which indicates contraction in manufacturing.

site_title: Asean gathers pace to grow a regional carbon market even as UN talks run into speed bumps
summary: Asean nations are moving forward with establishing a regional carbon market, despite stalled international talks at COP28. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is developing a common framework and standards for carbon trading, with Singapore as a key buyer. Efforts are underway to scale up the voluntary carbon market, with Bursa Malaysia and Climate Impact X working to standardize high-integrity carbon credits and connect market exchanges. The aim is to eventually set up a compliance market in the region, with Asean countries aiming to leapfrog past past mistakes in carbon project development.

images.alt_text: VCMs cover pollution-reducing projects, such as reforestation, renewable energy, biogas and solar power, that generate carbon credits companies buy to offset their emissions and meet net-zero targets.
CIX’s new set of standardised contracts will field the Core Carbon Principles credits, which are expected to come on stream next year.

A female polar bear on the Hudson Bay shoreline, near Churchill, Manitoba, Canada, August 2022. Rising temperatures melt away the Arctic sea ice upon which the bears depend for survival.  Scientists can calculate how much new greenhouse gas emissions will increase the number of ice-free days in the bears' habitats, and how that in turn will affect the percentage of cubs that reach adulthood.
Terrace homes at Frasers Property Australia's Minnippi Quarter development.

Fire fighting at a peatland in Pekanbaru, Indonesia's Riau province. Southeast Asia has one of the world's most valuable investable carbon stocks, driven by increasing financing opportunities for nature-based transactions in the region that are committed to reducing deforestation.
Container ships are docked at PSA's Tanjong Pagar terminal in Singapore.

site_title: Bitcoin hype will clash with the Rolex recession
summary: Bitcoin's price surged to a 19-month high, reaching around $42,000, despite a global economic slowdown and possible recession. The increase is attributed to speculation and sentiment, rather than a clear use case for the cryptocurrency. Analysts point to the correlation between money supply growth and crypto assets, but note that this may not be sustainable. The "Rolex recession" concept, where the value of second-hand luxury watches also decreased, suggests a shift towards more tangible assets. Some experts recommend allocating a small portion of a portfolio to crypto, but warn of opportunity costs and the environmental impact of investing in a carbon-intensive asset.

images.alt_text: Smaller virtual currencies such as Ether, Avalanche and meme-crowd favourite Dogecoin have also been advancing.

site_title: Myanmar central bank to stop setting forex rates
summary: Myanmar's central bank will stop setting exchange rates for foreign currencies, allowing banks and dealers to decide rates themselves. This move comes as the country's economy struggles under military rule, with foreign reserves under pressure and sanctions on military-owned energy firms expected to further squeeze income. The decision is seen as a sign the junta is in trouble, with some analysts predicting a further decline in the kyat. The central bank's move is part of a series of measures to ease forex controls, which have been tightened since the 2021 coup.

images.alt_text: A man counts 1,000 kyat notes at a black market petrol stall in Yangon, Myanmar, on Tuesday, Oct. 7, 2008. Myanmar, already one of the world's poorest nations, suffered a loss of about one-third of its normal food production this year because of a cyclone that devastated the country's Irrawaddy delta region in May. Photographer: Will Baxter/Bloomberg News

site_title: US dollar touches 2-week high, euro soft as traders bet on Q1 rate cuts
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week high against the euro, with the euro down 0.2% at a three-week low of US$1.0773, as traders expect the European Central Bank to cut interest rates as early as March. The euro touched a three-month low against the pound, a five-week low versus the yen, and a six-and-a-half week low against the Swiss franc. The Federal Reserve is also expected to cut rates, with a 60% chance of a March cut, according to the CME's FedWatch tool.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index is up 0.15 per cent, around one-week highs.

site_title: UK plans higher liquidity requirements for money market funds
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) proposed new regulations for money market funds, increasing minimum liquidity requirements to 15% daily and 50% weekly, to ensure funds can withstand large withdrawals during market stresses. The measures follow a Bank of England recommendation to increase the £250 billion sterling money market funds sector's resilience. The proposals will be open for consultation until March 8, 2024, aiming to prevent fire sales of assets during investor withdrawals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England (BoE) building, the BoE confirmed to raise interest rates to 1.75%, in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska//File Photo
The arbitrage has been created by a liquidity facility set up by the Bank of England last year to alleviate cash shortages as it winds down its bond-buying programme.

site_title: Toyota to sell entire stake in Japan's Harmonic Drive Systems
summary: Toyota plans to sell its entire stake in Harmonic Drive Systems, a Japanese precision control equipment maker, through an open market overseas sale. The 4,379,400 shares will be sold at an undecided price, valued at $123 million. This move follows Toyota's recent divestment of stakes in suppliers Denso and KDDI, as it invests in electrification. Harmonic Drive Systems will also buy back up to 700,000 shares to mitigate the impact on its shareholders.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Toyota logo is seen during the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 5, 2023. REUTERS/David 'Dee' Delgado/File Photo

site_title: EU proposes three-year delay before tariffs hit EV trade with UK
summary: The European Union proposed a three-year delay to tariffs on electric vehicles traded with the UK, set to take effect on January 1, 2024. The delay, until 2027, aims to alleviate concerns from carmakers and EU member states that local battery supply chains aren't ready. The EU's trade chief, Valdis Dombrovskis, said the proposal provides predictability and stability for the industry amid global competitive pressure. The recommendation must be approved by EU capitals and the British government before implementation.

site_title: Taylor Swift is Time’s person of the year
summary: Taylor Swift has been named Time's person of the year, representing joy and positivity to the world. The decision, made by Time magazine's editor-in-chief Sam Jacobs, was not easy but aimed to highlight someone bringing light to the world. Swift beat out finalists including King Charles III and Barbie, and her accomplishments as an artist are deemed so significant that recounting them is almost beside the point.

images.alt_text: The comic book will be released on Dec 13 and will be available in digital, paperback and hardcover with two covers.

site_title: McDonald’s plans to add about 10,000 new stores by 2027, double loyalty programme sales
summary: McDonald's plans to expand its restaurant count to approximately 50,000 in over 100 countries by 2027, a 10,000 new store increase, and double its loyalty programme sales to $45 billion annually by 2027. The company also aims to increase its loyalty programme user base to 250 million customers. To achieve this, McDonald's will invest in automating processes and speeding up service at its stores, including deploying artificial intelligence solutions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 6)
summary: The government has increased its land supply for private homes under the confirmed list of the half-yearly Government Land Sales (GLS) programme for the seventh consecutive time, to 5,450 units in H1 2024. Singapore and China reaffirmed their close ties, discussing cooperation in emerging areas such as the digital economy and renewable energy. COE premiums dipped across the board, except for small cars, while CPF interest rates for Special, MediSave, and Retirement accounts were raised to 4.08%. NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang hinted at a new supercomputer to be built in Singapore, and will meet with PM Lee to discuss AI plans.

site_title: Putin in the UAE to start Gulf visit with oil in focus
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin arrived in the UAE on December 6 to start a rare foreign trip focusing on bolstering cooperation among strategic oil producers. He will meet with UAE Foreign Minister Sheikh Abdullah Zayed and Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed Salman to discuss OPEC+ production cuts and reduce fossil fuel use at the COP28 summit. The visit coincides with a shift in Putin's confidence on the global stage, as he seeks to demonstrate international cooperation and counter Western fatigue and sanctions.

images.alt_text: Brent crude oil futures fell 83 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$77.20 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) ended 72 cents, or 1.0 per cent, lower at US$72.32 on Tuesday.
FILE PHOTO: A well head and drilling rig in the Yarakta oilfield, owned by Irkutsk Oil Company (INK), in the Irkutsk region, Russia, March 11, 2019. REUTERS/Vasily Fedosenko/File Photo

site_title: China EV maker Nio to spin off its battery production unit, say sources
summary: China's electric vehicle maker Nio plans to spin off its battery manufacturing unit, led by senior engineers from Apple and Panasonic, as part of efforts to turn profitable and reduce costs. The spin-off could happen as early as the end of this year, with the new firm seeking external investors. Nio will outsource all battery manufacturing, previously planning to develop and manufacture some batteries in-house. The move aims to improve efficiency and reduce costs, with the company already trimming its workforce and deferring long-term investments.

images.alt_text: Nio expects to sell as many as 49,000 vehicles in the quarter – well below analysts’ average forecast of 59,426.

Chinese electric vehicle companies like NIO are pulling ever further ahead, partly through government support but also rapid technological advances. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)

site_title: Philippines inflation to return to target by December, barring shocks: central bank
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) governor, Eli Remolona, stated that inflation in the Philippines could return to the central bank's 2-4% target range by December, barring supply shocks. November's inflation rate was 4.1%, the slowest in 20 months, with the year-to-date average inflation rate at 6.2%. The central bank will maintain a hawkish stance, not lowering banks' reserve requirement ratio, and will keep interest rates steady at 6.5%. The BSP aims to keep monetary policy "sufficiently tight" until a sustained downtrend in inflation is evident.

site_title: UK coping with higher rates for now but risks lie ahead: BOE
summary: The Bank of England's half-yearly Financial Stability Report reveals that UK businesses and households are coping with higher interest rates, but the financial sector faces risks and banks must adapt to changes in funding. Despite wage and income growth reducing household strain, interest rates are likely to remain high to control inflation, and the UK banking system is considered well-capitalized. Risks include a slowdown in the economy, upheaval in China's real estate market, and tensions in the Middle East, which could impact oil prices and economic growth.
