site_title: Setting directions for the design scene
summary: The World Architecture Festival (WAF) took place in Singapore, featuring a series of talks, exhibitions, and a live-judged architectural competition. The event, now 16 years old, focused on 'Catalyst', driving positive change through design. Nearly 500 entries were shortlisted, with winners representing trends and ideas of the design world. Meanwhile, a historic home built by William Lim in 1963 was recently renovated and will feature public artworks inspired by the house, which is set to be sold.

site_title: Former PM Boris Johnson apologises to families at UK Covid inquiry
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson apologized to families of those who lost loved ones during the Covid-19 pandemic as he testified at the official inquiry into Britain's handling of the pandemic. Johnson expressed deep regret for the suffering and loss caused by the pandemic, saying he was "deeply sorry" for the pain and loss of victims and their families. The inquiry has already heard damaging testimony about Johnson's handling of the crisis, including claims of government incompetence and backstabbing, and he faces two days of questioning in what are likely to be the most emotionally charged sessions so far.

images.alt_text: Former special advisor at 10 Downing Street, Dominic Cummings, giving evidence to the UK Covid-19 inquiry, in west London, Oct 31, 2023.

site_title: Moody’s cuts outlook on Chinese banks after sovereign downgrade
summary: Moody's cut its outlook on eight Chinese banks to negative from stable, citing concerns over the nation's sovereign debt. The rating agency's change in outlook was driven by a downgrade to negative from stable on China's government credit ratings. Moody's expects support for financially-stressed entities to be more selective, posing protracted risks to state-owned enterprises and local governments. The affected banks include Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China Development Bank, and others, with some seeing Chinese markets find support following the announcement.

site_title: River Valley, Queenstown, Pasir Ris housing sites expected to be top draws in H1 2024 land sales
summary: Singapore's GLS programme for the first half of 2024 is expected to boost private home supply by 5.6% to 5,450 units, including executive condos, with 10 new sites to be sold. The confirmed list features sites in River Valley, Queenstown, and Pasir Ris, with the River Valley Green plot expected to launch in March and the Margaret Drive plot in May. The Jalan Loyang Besar EC site is also highly anticipated, with analysts predicting strong interest. The programme aims to regulate bids and land prices, ensuring sufficient supply to keep prices in check.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Orchard Road. Orchard Bel Air, a coveted residential site located right at the doorstep of Orchard Boulevard MRT station is up for sale by tender.

site_title: Shenzhen developer’s bond saga shows limit of state support
summary: A Shenzhen-based developer, China South City, is seeking to extend the maturity and lower the interest rates of five dollar notes due in 2024, despite having received state backing. The move comes as authorities try to support the struggling Chinese property sector, but the developer's low willingness to service its offshore dollar bonds has raised concerns about the effectiveness of government help. The company's actions have disappointed, and some bondholders are planning to reject the proposal, highlighting the limitations of state support in addressing the sector's slump.

images.alt_text: The value of new home sales among the 100 biggest real estate companies falls 29.6 per cent from a year earlier to 390.19 billion yuan (S$73.3 billion).

site_title: Unprecedented US exports are weighing on global crude market
summary: US crude exports are nearing a record of 6 million barrels a day, flooding the global market and weighing on prices. Domestic production has surged to a record above 13 million barrels a day, catching some market participants by surprise. The glut has weakened US crude timespreads, depressing physical crude prices in Europe and triggering worries about oversupply. International benchmark Brent has softened, while US oil exports compete with regional supplies, particularly in Asia.

images.alt_text: Brent crude oil futures fell 83 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$77.20 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) ended 72 cents, or 1.0 per cent, lower at US$72.32 on Tuesday.
The cuts in Saudi oil prices highlight the heated competition to win Asian customers in an oversupplied market.
Opec+ announced production cuts that are voluntary in nature, raising doubts about whether or not producers would fully implement them.

Brent crude futures were down 0.6 per cent, or 49 cents, to US$78.39 a barrel by 0406 GMT on Monday, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were at US$73.65 a barrel, down 0.6 per cent, or 42 cents.

site_title: HappyIce ready to take its frozen vending machines to rest of S-E Asia
summary: HappyIce, a Singapore-based ice cream vending machine manufacturer, plans to expand into South-east Asia, targeting Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines. The company aims to place 1,000 vending machines in each market over time, capitalizing on the region's growing ice cream market, which is expected to reach $9.5 billion by 2028. HappyIce is concluding its latest round of Series A funding to support regional expansion, with plans to provide its vending machine solution to 50 more countries within five years.

images.alt_text: Chinese ice cream and bubble tea chain Mixue opened its 1,000th store in Vietnam this June via its fast-growing franchise model

SBF country head for Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines Tan Teck Lee (right) and Malaysian Investment Development Authority (Mida) executive director of investment promotion Najihah Abas at the briefing during SBF’s visit to Malaysia.

site_title: Sias quizzes Manulife US Reit manager, sponsor over recapitalisation plan
summary: The Securities and Investments Association (Sias) has questioned the manager of Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (MUST) and its sponsor over a proposed recapitalisation plan that includes a sponsor-lender loan and asset dispositions. Sias expressed concerns over the alignment of interests between the sponsor, manager, and unitholders, as well as the potential risks and conflicts of interest. The plan aims to raise funds to address MUST's financial issues, including a breach of financial covenants, and will be voted on by unitholders in an upcoming extraordinary general meeting.

images.alt_text: The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.
Part of the deal unveiled last week involves MUST's sponsor taking Park Place off its books for US$98.7 million

site_title: Private pension crackdown could ease UK worker shortage crisis
summary: The UK government is considering a crackdown on private pension pots to address the worker shortage crisis, which is driving up inflation. Easy access to generous private retirement savings is contributing to the inactivity crisis, allowing people as young as 55 to leave the labour force. Labour force participation remains below pre-Covid levels, and inactivity is 450,000 higher than before the pandemic. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is exploring measures to incentivize older workers to stay in the labour force, including raising the age for private pension draws and limiting withdrawals.

images.alt_text: Dave Ramsden, deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The Bank of England hiked interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis and warned the economy is on course to shrink under pressure from double-digit inflation. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: There is a better way to pick a presidential nominee
summary: The Democratic Party's decision to re-nominate President Joe Biden for 2024 may be a strategic mistake, with many voices questioning the long primary process. The current system, which involves state-level primaries and caucuses, is convoluted and outdated, allowing politicians to position themselves a year in advance. This process doesn't allow for swift adjustments, making it difficult to adapt to changing circumstances. Alternative methods, like direct party leadership selection, exist in most democracies, but are not currently used in the US.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden’s age is a particular concern with voters and there have been calls from some Democrats for him to step aside for a new candidate.

Former president Donald Trump speaks during a rally at Stevens High School in Claremont, N.H., Nov. 11, 2023. Truth Social, the online platform at the core of Trump Media, has had challenges attracting advertising revenue. (Sophie Park/The New York Times)
According to most opinion polls, the American people don’t want to see either Biden or Trump occupying the White House after 2024.

Former US President Donald Trump speaks to members of media at New York State Supreme Court in New York, US, on Monday, Nov 6, 2023. Trump is facing off against New York attorney general Letitia James in a contentious civil trial that threatens his control over his real estate empire in the state.

Joe Biden’s victory in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary in South Carolina helped revive his flagging candidacy and propelled the former vice-president to the nomination and eventually the White House.
The appeal of ‘Trumpism’ remains strong with key US groups, evidenced by polls of Republican party identifiers in 2023.

site_title: Airlines’ expected US$25.7 billion profit for 2024 is ‘tribute to aviation’s resilience’: Iata
summary: Global airlines are forecast to achieve record revenue of almost US$1 trillion in 2024, with a net profit of US$25.7 billion, according to the International Air Travel Association (Iata). The projected total revenue is a 7.6% increase from 2023, driven by strong demand for air travel, with 4.7 billion people expected to travel via air next year. Despite the improvement, the net profit margin of 2.7% is considered "far below" what investors in other industries would accept, and the industry's profitability remains fragile due to various factors, including high interest rates, inflation, and supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: (Left to right) Vincent Hwa, director (Air Traffic Services) Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS); Padhraic Kelleher president, International Civic Aviation Ogranisation Air Navigation Commisison, Han Kok Juan director-general CAAS, Ng Tee Chiou, deputy director-general CAAS, at the Singapore Air Traffic Control Centre.

FILE PHOTO: An IndiGo Airlines aircraft arrives at a gate of the domestic airport in Mumbai February 22, 2012.  Picture taken on February 22, 2012. REUTERS/Vivek Prakash (INDIA - Tags: TRANSPORT BUSINESS)/File Photo
Tourists check in at the new Siem Reap-Angkor International Airport in Siem Reap, Cambodia, Nov 15, 2023.
Global flight capacity is projected to grow 3.6 per cent annually between 2019 and 2041, while CO2 emissions will rise – not fall – at a rate of 2.7 per cent, according to Cirium.

site_title: China starts up world’s first fourth-generation nuclear reactor
summary: China has started commercial operations at the world's first fourth-generation nuclear reactor, the Shidaowan plant in China's northern Shandong province. The 200 megawatt high-temperature, gas-cooled reactor is designed to use fuel more efficiently and improve safety and environmental performance. China aims to produce 10% of its electricity from nuclear by 2035 and 18% by 2060, as it seeks to meet its carbon emissions goals. The plant was developed jointly by state-run utility Huaneng, Tsinghua University, and China National Nuclear Corporation.

images.alt_text: “Investment from China in this project to the tune of US$4.8 billion sends a message loud and clear that Pakistan is a place where Chinese companies and investors continue to show their trust and faith,” Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif Sharif says.

site_title: Moody’s downgrades Hong Kong rating outlook to negative
summary: Moody's downgraded Hong Kong's credit rating outlook to negative, citing a "tight linkage" between the finance hub and China as the principal driver. The downgrade follows a similar change for China, which Moody's also downgraded to negative. Hong Kong's economy has slowed in the second half of the year, with growth estimates revised down to 3.2%, and Moody's expects further erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy due to China's increasing influence. This erosion is expected to impact Hong Kong's creditworthiness and fiscal buffers.

images.alt_text: While the economy is seen on track to hit the government’s annual growth target of around 5 per cent this year, Moody’s expects China’s annual economic growth to slow to an average 3.8 per cent from 2026 to 2030.
Prior rate hikes by central banks and rising unemployment in advanced economies will weaken asset quality, Moody’s Investors Services says in an outlook report.
Moody’s statement comes after Fitch Ratings announced on Tuesday that it was placing Israel’s A+ foreign- and local-currency issuer default ratings on “Ratings Watch Negative.”

site_title: UK construction sector contracts sharply in November: PMI
summary: The UK construction sector experienced its third consecutive month of decline in November, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK construction PMI falling to 45.5, below the 50.0 growth threshold. The sector's slump is attributed to higher Bank of England interest rates, leading to lower house-building activity. Raw material costs decreased at the fastest rate since 2009, while the overall economy showed a more positive picture with a 50.2 all-sector PMI.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
The ONS household cost index shows the average mortgage borrower having a 9.3 per cent personal rate of inflation, far above the headline 6.7 per cent consumer prices index for September.

epa10695346 A picture taken with a drone shows houses in east London, Britain, 16 June 2023. House prices across the UK fell by 1 percent on average, first annual decline since December 2012, according to Halifax Mortgages. UK mortgage rates are heading up towards 6 percent interest rates and higher borrowing costs are adding to the burden on homeowners with the biggest mortgage squeeze since 1991.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN

A pedestrian passes a row of terraced houses in southeast London, U.K., on Thursday, July 21, 2016. London's seven-year housing boom may be about to end after the U.K. voted to leave the European Union. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
UK house average prices slip 0.1 per cent year on year to £291,000 (S$489,046), with Wales bearing the brunt of the declines.

A boat on the River Thames passes residential apartments in the Millwall district of London, U.K., on Tuesday, May 12, 2020. The pandemic has crushed hopes of a recovery in Londons housing market after years of sustained declines. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
The remarkable resilience of property prices is likely to be a double-edged sword for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
Property prices rise 1.1 per cent in October to £281,974 (S$470,700), which was also the biggest increase since February 2023.
S&P Global’s construction purchasing managers index edges up to 45.6 in October from 45 the previous month, remaining well below the threshold of 50 indicating a contraction.

site_title: Singapore stocks rebound after two sessions of losses; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rebounded after two sessions of losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.3% to close at 3,087.24. The biggest winner was Jardine Matheson, with its shares rising 2.2%. Other heavily traded counters, such as Seatrium and Manulife US Reit, also closed higher. The banking sector was also up, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC gaining 0.1-0.2% each. The rebound was attributed to mixed market conditions, with bonds rising after US job data missed expectations.

images.alt_text: Gainers are on par with losers in early trade at 47 each.

ST20231206-202350050488-Lim Yaohui-Elizabeth Law-elbilat/
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong having bilateral meeting with Chinese Premier Li Qiang at Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China on Dec 6, 2023. It is the second meeting this year between both leaders after Mr Wong met with Mr Li during his visit in May.
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong visiting China (Beijing and Tianjin) from 5 to 8 December 2023 for the 19th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation (JCBC) and bilateral meetings.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: Singapore premium preschool Trehaus to open first international branch in Jakarta in 2024
summary: Trehaus, a Singapore-based education technology company, is set to open its first international branch in Jakarta, Indonesia, by the second quarter of 2024. The pre-school, which offers a Silicon Valley-inspired curriculum, has already seen overwhelming response with a waitlist at capacity. The Jakarta centre will cater to up to 100 students aged 6 months to 6 years, with fees ranging from SGD 2,400 to SGD 3,000 per month. This marks Trehaus' expansion into Southeast Asia, following its success in Singapore, where it has worked with education experts from top US institutions to design its unique curriculum.

images.alt_text: From left: Chin Kai Lun, COO of ProfilePrint; Craig Goonting, COO of Troopers; Raghav Narayan, CEO of Aprisium; Tan Swee Yen, co-founder and CEO of CoNex Healthcare; Didi Gan, founder and CEO of N&E Innovations; Steven Fong, co-founder and CEO of Flex Fuel Hydrogen Development; Kang Jen Wee, founder and CEO of Redex Group; and Bryan Oh, CEO of Neu Battery Materials.
Music has been part of the group’s DNA since it was founded in 2005 at The Substation Garden, said Timbre Group founder and chief executive officer Danny Loong.

site_title: Insurers heavily exposed to climate change, global watchdog says
summary: The International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) has warned that insurers are heavily exposed to climate change due to investments in fossil fuels and energy-intensive industries, as well as underwriting natural catastrophe risk. This exposure could negatively impact insurers' profitability and capital buffers. The IAIS also noted that aggregate scores measuring systemic risk in the insurance sector declined slightly in 2022, but insurers are "significantly" less risky than banks. The watchdog plans to conduct more frequent checks on insurers due to the risk of sudden cash withdrawals.

images.alt_text: In the near term, AIA Group aims to achieve a 46.2 per cent reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2030.

site_title: Banks mask lending to polluters with PR greenwash: ECB blog
summary: A new blog post by the European Central Bank's economists argues that EU banks claiming to be environmentally conscious actually lend more to polluting industries. The mismatch between public statements and actual lending data reveals that banks prioritize protecting client relationships over reducing climate risk. This perpetuates the pollution and supports dirty industries, creating a loop where polluters are kept alive by banks seeking to protect earnings.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign outside the European Central Bank building in Frankfurt, Germany October 27, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
The survey of Iosco members to coincide with the COP28 UN climate summit in Dubai shows most jurisdictions do not specifically define greenwashing in legally binding provisions.
Process, people and technology have to be aligned for organisations to fully harness the potential of automation for ESG reporting and compliance.
“This rule allows us to challenge firms if we consider they are making misleading claims about their products or services and, if appropriate, take further action,” the FCA says.
Many product claims in the report stated they were made of recycled materials without specifying how much of it is recycled content.
A standardised data framework supported by advanced technology solutions can provide clear data backed by robust controls.
In the handful of years that they have existed, sustainability-linked loans have mushroomed into a US$1.5 trillion market.

site_title: BOJ deputy chief hints that negative rate end may be closer
summary: Deputy Governor Ryozo Himino of the Bank of Japan hinted that the central bank may end its negative interest rate regime sooner than expected, suggesting that the transition could be less harmful than feared. Himino stated that households would likely benefit from improved net income if rates moved to positive territory, while the corporate sector would experience limited impact. The BOJ will carefully assess economic conditions before embarking on the exit, with expectations that the policy may end by mid-2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese national flag is hoisted atop the headquarters of Bank of Japan in Tokyo, Japan September 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: World animal health body warns of swine fever vaccine risks as Vietnam readies exports
summary: The World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH) is warning that more testing of African swine fever vaccines is needed due to concerns over Vietnam's plans to export doses. The vaccines, developed by AVAC Vietnam, have not shared sufficient data with international researchers, prompting WOAH to urge countries to conduct their own trials. If a vaccine is deemed sub-standard, it could lead to trade restrictions against pork-exporting countries, affecting the global pork market worth around $250 billion in 2022.

images.alt_text: The approval of the vaccines could pave the way for possible sales abroad, a major breakthrough to tackle the deadly animal disease that regularly ravages pig farms worldwide.
This is the first time we have detected this virus in humans in the UK, though it is very similar to viruses that have been detected in pigs,” says UKHSA incident director Meera Chand.
The Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) says it plans to cull around 1,900 pigs from one herd on Nov 25 after the virus was discovered at a local pig farm.
African swine fever has plagued China for years, with an initial wave during 2018 and 2019 killing millions of pigs and leading to a dramatic decline in meat output that roiled global markets.

site_title: Traders see ECB cutting rates by 150 basis points through 2024
summary: Traders expect the European Central Bank to cut interest rates by 150 basis points through 2024, with the first quarter-point cut possible as early as March. This follows policymakers' acknowledgment that further rate hikes above 4% may not be needed to bring inflation back to target. Euro area inflation has dropped to 2.4% in November, the lowest in three months, and some members, such as Francois Villeroy de Galhau, have suggested rate hikes are over.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The European Central Bank (ECB) logo in Frankfurt, Germany, January 23, 2020. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski

site_title: China blue-chip stocks hit 5-year lows, yuan eases after Moody's move
summary: China's blue-chip stocks hit 5-year lows amid growing economic worries, with the CSI300 Index falling to its lowest level since February 2019. Moody's downgrade warning on China's credit rating and its negative outlook on 18 Chinese corporates weighed on the market. The yuan currency also eased, despite efforts by major state-owned banks to stabilize it. Despite this, foreign capital poured into Chinese markets, and analysts expect the index to rebound soon. Moody's decision has added to concerns about China's economic recovery, which has shown signs of losing steam quickly.

images.alt_text: The weak earnings momentum may give investors more reasons to sell Chinese equities after the CSI 300 benchmark for mainland shares tumbled to its lowest since 2019 this week.

site_title: ByteDance offers investors share buyback, valued at US$268 billion: sources
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, is offering to buy back around $5 billion worth of shares from investors at $160 each, valuing the company at $268 billion. This is 10% lower than its value a year ago. The same price was offered to employees last month, and the move is seen as a strategic decision to reduce its valuation.

site_title: Nissan, Mitsubishi confirm investment plans in Renault EV unit
summary: Nissan and Mitsubishi have confirmed plans to invest up to 600 million euros and 200 million euros, respectively, in Renault's electric vehicle unit Ampere. The investment will be used to develop electric vehicles for the European market, including a compact Nissan Micra and a medium-sized electric SUV for Mitsubishi. Ampere is set to list on the market next year and will cut production costs for the Micra by 50%. The alliance also plans joint projects in Latin America and India, marking a more pragmatic and regional cooperation between the three automakers.

images.alt_text: Renault chief executive officer Luca de Meo is pitching Ampere as a European response to competition from US rival Tesla and Chinese EV manufacturers.
Alpine’s search for new investors will probably start at the end of next year or in early 2025.
Renault plans to use proceeds from Nissan stake sales to continue investing in its electric vehicle and software business Ampere, its sports-car division Alpine and its recycling unit.
Mitsubishi says it seeks to improve its EV development technology and expand its lineup of battery-powered vehicles with the investment in the Renault EV unit, named Ampere.
Renault and Nissan finalised at the end of July the terms of a restructured alliance after months of negotiations.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB slashes Sea target to US$42, downgrades to ‘hold’
summary: CGS-CIMB has cut Sea's target price to US$42 from US$61, downgrading the Internet company to "hold" from "buy" due to heightened competition in Indonesia's e-commerce sector. The analysts cited a potential return of rival TikTok's live-commerce into the market, following an informal agreement with Indonesian technology company GoTo's Tokopedia. The current share price implies a 0.5 multiple to forecast FY2024 sales of Shopee.

images.alt_text: Chinese ice cream and bubble tea chain Mixue opened its 1,000th store in Vietnam this June via its fast-growing franchise model
Sea's results miss an analyst consensus of US$102 million in profit and came as the company shifted its focus to growth for its e-commerce business.
The growth of Sea's e-commerce arm, Shopee, will be key in achieving long-term profitability says Forrest Li, chairman and chief executive at Sea.
Workers sorting packages for delivery after the Singles’ Day shopping festival at a logistics center in Hunan, China.

site_title: Malaysia beats target with RM225 billion of approved investments in first 9 months
summary: Malaysia has exceeded its annual investment target, attracting RM225 billion of approved investments in the first 9 months of 2023, a 6.6% rise from last year. This is expected to create nearly 90,000 new job opportunities, the country's best achievement in the corresponding period over the past decade. The majority of investments came from the services sector, with foreign direct investment from top investors including the Netherlands, Singapore, and the US.

site_title: Wanda’s billionaire founder sells film unit as debt pressure builds
summary: Wanda Group's billionaire founder Wang Jianlin plans to sell the film unit as the company faces increasing debt repayment pressure. He will transfer his 51% stake in Beijing Wanda Investment to a subsidiary of China Ruyi Holdings, giving Ruyi full ownership after a 49% stake purchase for $432 million in July. The sale marks the end of Wang's ambitions to rival Walt Disney, as Wanda's business has declined since a 2015 stock-market bubble burst and China's economic slowdown worsened.

images.alt_text: Wanda Properties International wants to push back the maturity on the 7.25 per cent note by almost a year to Dec 29, 2024, according to a statement to the Hong Kong stock exchange.
Wanda is considering offering compensation to pre-IPO investors of Zhuhai Wanda Commercial Management Group as an alternative to immediate repayment.

site_title: Prada aims to double business in China in medium term: CEO
summary: Prada CEO Gianfranco D'Attis aims to double the company's business in China over the medium term, requiring increased investments. To achieve this, Prada plans to expand its store presence, introduce more local products, and host more events in the country. This strategic move is seen as a response to China's growing luxury market, where Prada seeks to strengthen its presence despite potential tariffs.

site_title: PBOC steps up yuan support via fixing after Moody’s outlook cut
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) strengthened the yuan via the daily reference rate, setting it at 7.1140 per US dollar, amid market concerns triggered by Moody's Investors Service cutting its credit outlook for China to negative. This move follows a weaker yuan in onshore and overseas trading after the credit rating cut. Analysts say the PBOC is boosting efforts to prevent declines in the Chinese currency, but the fixing is not as aggressive as in previous months. The yuan's depreciation pressure is expected to persist in the near term.

site_title: Nvidia CEO hints at new supercomputer in Singapore; meeting PM Lee, EDB to discuss AI plans
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang hinted at a new supercomputer in Singapore during a meeting with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Jacqueline Poh, managing director of the Singapore Economic Development Board. Nvidia aims to make "large investments" in artificial intelligence in Singapore, with plans to work with local industry players, startups, and researchers. The company also discussed potential investment in a significant iconic site for AI and will prioritize Japan for AI processors. This visit comes after Singapore launched a refreshed national AI strategy, dubbed Nais 2.0, and follows Nvidia's existing AI technology centre in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Nvidia will deliver a new set of products for the Chinese market that’s in line with the latest rules coming from Washington, Jensen Huang says.
“The semiconductor industry that Japan is now starting to grow and foster will be able to produce GPUs,” says Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang.

Developed market companies like Nvidia may have dominated the headlines as the first wave of investment opportunity centres around computing power, but there are secondary role opportunities in the wider tech supply chain for EM businesses.
Nvidia executives and directors last month sold or filed paperwork showing they intend to sell roughly 370,000 shares worth about US$180 million.
Nvidia’s graphics chips have become the go-to tool for training AI services.

People walk in front of an electronic board displaying the Nikkei average of the Tokyo Stock Exchange (L) and numbers of the New York Dow (R) along a street in Tokyo on August 25, 2023. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Nvidia has climbed about 22 per cent during the course of this latest rally, adding about US$220 billion in market value.

site_title: South-east Asia banks on aviation boom
summary: South-east Asia banks on an expected aviation boom, driven by Chinese and Indian tourists. Major airport expansion projects are underway in Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam, with new airlines such as Really Cool Airlines set to launch in mid-2024. However, concerns about the impact of travel on climate change and an uncertain economic environment raise doubts about the boom's materialization.

images.alt_text: A man shelters from the rain under an umbrella as he walks past the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on July 27, 2023 ahead of thr ECB's monthly announcement on eurozone monetary policy. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

Borrowers can get better conditions at new types of investment firms that are willing to take the risk that banks are no longer interested in bearing. But these investors require a certain level of control over their creditors.
FILE PHOTO: People walk along a busy shopping street, during the traditional Boxing Day sales in London, Britain, December 26, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo
Amro expects Asean+3 to grow by 4.3 per cent this year and at 4.5 per cent in 2024.
Flood waters submerge parked cars in Hue city in central Vietnam on November 15, 2023.

site_title: UK landlords battered by higher rates are selling their properties
summary: UK landlords are selling more properties than they're buying, with an estimated 27,520 rentals leaving the market in 2023, according to a report by estate agents firm Hamptons. This marks an eighth consecutive year of landlords downsizing their portfolios due to stricter policies and rising costs, including higher mortgage rates. Rent has skyrocketed in London, but landlords are struggling to cover expenses, with the number of landlords with late mortgage payments doubling in the third quarter. The trend is expected to continue, leading to a structural scarcity of rental properties.

images.alt_text: A one-hour walk from Rutland Gate, through Hyde Park and the affluent Marylebone district, leads to The Holme, a 40-room mansion in Regent’s Park.
The ONS household cost index shows the average mortgage borrower having a 9.3 per cent personal rate of inflation, far above the headline 6.7 per cent consumer prices index for September.

site_title: Yellen says economists ‘eating their words’ after predicting high US unemployment
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that economists who predicted high US unemployment to control inflation are "eating their words" as the economy shows little weakness in the labor market and consumer demand with prices moderating. The US Labor Department is set to report October jobs data, which may impact Federal Reserve interest rate decisions. Demand remains adequate to power the economy forward at trend-growth-like rates, according to Yellen.

images.alt_text: Job openings, a measure of labour demand, fall 617,000 to 8.733 million on the last day of October, according to Jolts report.
The Institute for Supply Management says that its non-manufacturing PMI rises to 52.7 in November from 51.8, which was a 5-month low.
Many homeowners are unwilling to sell, in part because that means letting go of the cheap mortgages they locked in during the pandemic.
Worker pay did not keep up with inflation in 2021 and 2022, but workers enjoyed real disposable income gains of 4 per cent in the first three quarters of this year.
Factory orders fall 3.6 per cent after a downwardly revised 2.3 per cent in September.
Homeowners are willing to sell their existing homes and take on higher-interest mortgages if they find a property in a more affordable area or their dream home became available, the survey shows.

site_title: Nvidia sees Huawei as formidable AI chipmaking rival, CEO says
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang views Huawei as a "very formidable" competitor in the AI chip market, joining Intel and other semiconductor startups as a stiff challenge to Nvidia's dominant position. Despite US trade restrictions, Nvidia plans to deliver new products for the Chinese market in line with Washington's rules. China accounts for about 20% of Nvidia's sales, and Huang emphasizes adherence to trade regulations, navigating US-China trade tensions that target Nvidia's AI chips as strategically important.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s graphics chips have become the go-to tool for training AI services.
Nvidia executives and directors last month sold or filed paperwork showing they intend to sell roughly 370,000 shares worth about US$180 million.

site_title: Singapore, China reaffirm close ties, discuss cooperation in emerging areas
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong met with Chinese Premier Li Qiang on Dec 6, reaffirming close ties between the two countries. Over 20 agreements will be signed at the Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation meeting on Thursday, covering cooperation in emerging areas such as the digital economy, renewable energy, and clean energy. The meeting marked the second bilateral meeting between both leaders this year, with China expressing its readiness to work with Singapore to pursue ambitious goals in their bilateral relations.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) said he was happy to see Chinese Premier Li Qiang again, "in a different capacity".
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong addressed a group of 300 overseas Singaporeans at a reception in Beijing.
FILE PHOTO: Chinese Premier Li Qiang speaks during the 26th ASEAN-China Summit at the 43rd ASEAN Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, on September 6, 2023. Yasuyoshi Chiba/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Li Qiang, the former Communist Party chief of Shanghai, China’s largest city, will replace Li Keqiang.

site_title: Twitch to shut down in South Korea due to high costs
summary: Twitch, Amazon's streaming unit, plans to shut down operations in South Korea in February 2024 due to high operating costs and network fees, which are 10 times more expensive than in most other countries. Despite efforts to reduce costs, the company determined that there was no pathway forward for the business to operate sustainably in the country. This decision comes after Twitch laid off over 400 employees in March due to slow user and revenue growth.

site_title: Cultivated meat startup Meatiply secures US$3.8 million seed funding at first close
summary: Singapore-based cultivated meat startup Meatiply has secured US$3.8 million in seed funding at its first close, co-led by Wavemaker Partners and AgFunder. The funding will be used to expand research and development capabilities and scale up production for commercial partnerships. Meatiply aims to launch a product within an unprecedented five-year timeframe, starting with a new facility in 2024, two years ahead of its targeted commercial launch in 2026. The company's advanced cultivated meat technology prototypes have showcased complex, value-added compounds, positioning it for opportunities in the nutraceutical and wellness market.

images.alt_text: Meatiply's cultivated duck with skin, fat, and muscle layers - one of the company's three advanced cultivated meat technology prototypes.
Meatable is looking to sell its cultivated pork products in Singapore by Q2 2024, subject to regulatory approvals.
Neither side of Eat Just’s business makes money, and the company recently has had trouble paying bills.
Alternative proteins are those that do not involve the slaughter of animals; they may be plant-based, fermented using microbes, or cultivated from animal cells.
More cultured meat firms and researchers need to consider regional culinary preferences across Asia, such as fish balls or dumplings.
While succeeding in the general lab-meat market has proven complicated and expensive, some companies have set their sights on pet food, whose consumers are less picky.

site_title: Thai business group keeps 2023 growth forecast at 2.5%-3.0%
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 2.5%-3.0% this year, unchanged from previous forecasts. Tourism revenue is expected to be lower due to a 28 million foreign arrivals, down from an earlier forecast of 30 million. Next year's growth is forecasted to be 2.8%-3.3%, with a potential additional 1.0%-1.5% growth if the government's digital wallet plan is successful. The economy grew 1.5% in the July-September quarter, the slowest this year, due to declining exports and government spending.

site_title: Two of London’s most expensive mansions are struggling to sell
summary: Two of London's most expensive mansions, valued at £475 million, are struggling to sell due to high-interest rates and a tough tax environment. Despite numerous visits from prospective buyers, sellers have yet to receive offers close to the asking price. Luxury homes priced above £15 million are seeing a decline in sales, with buyers seeking discounts. However, ultra-prime sellers remain resilient, with top-end transactions still securing deals, driven by American and Middle Eastern buyers. The market is also seeing a shift towards more realistic pricing, with sellers accepting discounts to secure sales.

images.alt_text: Unauthorised construction has long been an issue in Hong Kong, but successive administrations have done little to tackle the problem.
In Singapore, prime rents are up 14.5 per cent compared to last year.
Russians have traditionally been fans of United Arab Emirates property, but they really flooded into the market in 2022.

site_title: COE premiums dip across the board, except for small cars
summary: COE premiums dipped across most categories in the first round of bidding in December, except for small cars in Category A, which saw a 3.6% increase to S$88,020. Category B COE premiums fell 3.9% to S$130,100, while Category E premiums decreased 1.2% to S$133,388. The market remains weak due to high COE prices, with fewer bids submitted compared to previous tenders, and consumers reluctant to commit to capital purchases.

images.alt_text: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) price for mainstream cars has fallen to lows not seen since January 2023.

site_title: Bitcoin’s ‘jet-fuelled’ 16% six-day jump takes token past US$44,000
summary: Bitcoin surged 16% in six days, reaching over $44,000, driven by speculation of the US allowing its first Bitcoin ETFs, which could attract a wider investor base. The rally is also linked to expectations of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy pivot and the Bitcoin halving next year. Smaller cryptocurrencies like Ether and Dogecoin also advanced. Analysts attribute the surge to a combination of macro and micro factors, with some warning that the rally may be overvalued.

images.alt_text: Crypto companies have spent US$18.96 million in the first three quarters of 2023 on lobbying, compared with US$16.1 million during the same period in 2022.
The crypto industry is awaiting the outcome of applications from the likes of BlackRock to start the first US spot Bitcoin ETFs.

site_title: Gold steady as markets await US jobs data
summary: Gold prices steadied at US$2,020.39 per ounce, trading in a tight range, as the US dollar levelled with bets for a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve in 2024. Spot gold rose 0.1% following a record high on Monday, despite uncertainty over the timing of the monetary policy easing. US job openings fell to a two-and-a-half year low, supporting non-interest-bearing bullion, with traders pricing in a 60% chance of a rate cut by March next year.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-interest-bearing bullion.

site_title: Amazon targets Shein with big fee cuts for cheap apparel sellers
summary: Amazon has cut fees for merchants selling clothing priced below $20, with rates dropping to 5% for products under $15 and 10% for those between $15 and $20. This move is seen as a response to Chinese fast-fashion upstart Shein, which has excelled in offering low-cost apparel. Amazon aims to remain competitive in the low-price apparel category without losing Prime shoppers to Shein, which plans to hold an initial public offering in 2024.

images.alt_text: Convincing regulators that its supply chain is clean will likely be a major regulatory hurdle as Shein works to convince the US Securities and Exchange Commission that its shares should be traded publicly.
Shein has become popular thanks to its trendy clothing at ultra-low prices.
Shein was the world’s third most valuable startup in 2022, when a funding round valued the company at US$100 billion.

site_title: 5 Questions with managing director of Google Cloud’s AI business Caroline Yap
summary: Caroline Yap, managing director of Google Cloud's AI business, recounts her unconventional journey to the top. Born in Malaysia, Yap ran away from home at 18 and secured a job in the UK, where she began her career in IT. She eventually landed at Motorola, where she created a global virtual private network architecture, and later at Google Cloud, where she applied her outside perspective to make AI relevant to everyone. Yap emphasizes that AI is relatable to everyone, and that believing in oneself is empowering. Despite facing setbacks, including underestimation of women in tech, Yap remains optimistic about the future of AI.

site_title: Government boosts private housing supply on confirmed list by 5.6% to 5,450 units in H1 2024
summary: The Singapore government has announced a 5.6% increase in private housing supply on the confirmed list of the Government Land Sales (GLS) programme for the first half of 2024, with 5,450 units to be released. This is the highest supply since 2013, but analysts note that long-stay serviced apartments are excluded from the increase, resulting in a 1% increase.

images.alt_text: “The government will continue to monitor economic and property market conditions and calibrate the supply of future GLS programmes, as necessary, to help meet demand and promote market stability,” MND says.
The Zion Road (parcel A) plot is expected to get a top bid of S$1.47 billion and S$1.66 billion, says PropNex's Wong Siew Ying.

site_title: Malaysians top list of tourists flocking to Thailand as Chinese miss target
summary: Thailand is on track to meet its 28 million foreign tourist arrivals target for the year, driven by a surge in visitors from Malaysia, which has more than doubled to four million. In contrast, Chinese arrivals fell short of the target, with 3.1 million visitors, despite the government's efforts to attract more Chinese tourists. The Tourism Authority of Thailand expects a further recovery to 35 million visitors next year, including 8.2 million from China.

images.alt_text: ildrunk23/ Tourists and locals browse goods and food at a walking street market in Phuket, Thailand, on Sunday, Oct. 2, 2022. Thailand will end a nationwide state of emergency declared in the wake of Covid outbreak after the Southeast Asian nation downgraded the virus from a “dangerous” communicable disease to one that only requires surveillance.

site_title: Trafigura staff tried to hide nickel ‘red flags’, Prateek Gupta says
summary: Trafigura staff allegedly collaborated with alleged fraudster Prateek Gupta to conceal suspicious trading activities from Citigroup, a key lender, in a nickel deal. Messages made public in court show Trafigura employees instructed Gupta to maintain credibility and avoid raising red flags, which Citigroup used to determine the legitimacy of the trades. The communications suggest Trafigura staff worked to juggle trades to ensure cargoes could be repurchased within 180 days, raising questions about the company's processes and its claims of innocence. Trafigura denies any complicity in the alleged fraud.

images.alt_text: Indian businessman Prateek Gupta and his companies, against whom Trafigura secured a US$625 million freezing order this week, have a checkered history in the trading world.

A Sept 2022 file photo of a nickel smelting facility in Konawe, Southeast Sulawesi. Many of the materials critical for the green transition are currently produced in far fewer areas than oil and gas are.

site_title: Asia: Markets on front foot as US jobs data provide new rate cheer
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, with Tokyo and Sydney up over one percent, as data showing a softening US labor market boosted hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in 2024. The below-forecast job openings figure bolstered optimism ahead of the non-farm payrolls report on Friday, which investors expect will confirm the economic slowdown. However, some traders expressed concerns that buying may have been overdone, with the potential risk to the "Santa rally" revolving around the exhaustion of investment flows.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 36,124.56 on Tuesday.
Gainers are on par with losers in early trade at 47 each.

site_title: Japanese buyers snap up New York, London buildings in spending spree
summary: Japanese investors are spending the most in two decades on international real estate, driven by low financing rates and a desire for diversification. They have acquired a Manhattan skyscraper, data centers in Toronto, and office buildings in London, accounting for $7.4 billion of global commercial transactions in 2023. Japanese companies, such as Mori Trust and Mitsui Fudosan, are taking a long-term view, seeing attractive prices in the real estate downturn, despite the yen's weakness. This investment boom is providing relief to the market, which has been frozen due to rising office vacancies and interest rates.

images.alt_text: From January to October 2023, Singapore welcomed approximately 1.13 million visitors from China, according to the Singapore Tourism Board.

site_title: HSBC cuts at least four bank jobs in Hong Kong as deals dry up
summary: HSBC has cut at least four Hong Kong-based bankers as deals slow amid macro-economic concerns and tumultuous markets. The bank reduced staff within its commercial banking origination unit for Greater China. This move follows similar cuts by Goldman Sachs Group and Citigroup in the region. The value of mergers and acquisitions in mainland China and Hong Kong is expected to be the lowest for any year since 2013. Despite the slowdown, HSBC continues to invest in China, including a recent deal to buy Citigroup's retail wealth management portfolio.

images.alt_text: The problems are the result of an “internal system issue,” a HSBC spokesperson says.
FILE Ñ HSBC Bank headquarters in London on Oct. 18, 2022. The bank will acquire Silicon Valley BankÕs British subsidiary. (Sam Bush/The New York Times)

site_title: Europe: German shares hit fresh record high, outpace Europe’s Stoxx 600
summary: German shares reached a fresh record high on Tuesday, driven by strong gains in industrial stocks and insurers, with the DAX index up 0.8% and the Stoxx 600 index up 0.4%. The German index has gained nearly 18.7% this year, outperforming the Stoxx 600 index. Data showed a slower decline in the services sector in November, while European Central Bank conservative Isabel Schnabel stated that further interest hikes are unlikely due to a big fall in inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 36,124.56 on Tuesday.

site_title: Nio rises on cost cuts despite falling behind its sales goals
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, reported a quarterly loss and missed revenue and delivery estimates. Despite cost-cutting measures, including a 10% workforce reduction, the company expects to sell up to 49,000 vehicles in the quarter, below analysts' forecast of 59,426. Nio aims to reduce expenses by around 2 billion yuan in 2024 and will cut or postpone projects that cannot improve its financial performance in three years. The company's shares rose 3.7% after detailing its cost reduction plans.

images.alt_text: **EMBARGO: No electronic distribution, Web posting or street sales before THURSDAY 12:01 A.M. ET, OCT. 5, 2023. No exceptions for any reasons. EMBARGO set by source.** FILE — The NIO booth at the Auto Shanghai 2023 in Shanghai, April 19, 2023. Chinese electric vehicle companies like NIO are pulling ever further ahead, partly through government support but also rapid technological advances. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)
The Chinese EV maker expects revenue of up to 16.7 billion yuan in the three months through December, short of the 21.4 billion yuan average estimate from analysts.

site_title: Members of gig-worker associations injured on the job to get grocery vouchers
summary: A new short-term relief scheme in Singapore provides S$250 in NTUC FairPrice vouchers to ride-hailing, taxi, and freelance delivery workers injured on the job, if they've been members of relevant worker associations for at least three months. The NTUC Care Fund launched the scheme, which has an initial tranche of S$120,000, with NTUC and three associations contributing to the fund. This comes ahead of planned legislative changes expanding basic protections for platform workers.

images.alt_text: NTUC deputy secretary-general Desmond Tan (pictured) at the MOU signing event on Nov 29.

site_title: CPF interest rates for Special, MediSave and Retirement accounts raised to 4.08%
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) has raised interest rates for Special, MediSave, and Retirement accounts to 4.08% from 4.04% starting January 1, 2024, and 4% in 2023. The Ordinary Account interest rate remains unchanged at 2.5%. The increase is due to the 12-month average yield of 10-year Singapore Government Securities exceeding the floor rate of 4%. The Retirement Account interest rate will be computed quarterly, starting from January 1, 2024, to align with the Special and MediSave Accounts.

images.alt_text: The cash payments are part of a suite of measures in the Assurance Package, which cushions the impact of inflation and the goods and services tax increase.
As we live longer and inflation stays high, one may need to work one's CPF savings harder.
CPF Ordinary Account interest rates, tracked from 1955 to 2023.
The extension provides certainty for CPF members amid the uncertain interest rate environment.

site_title: All Blackpink members renew contracts with label YG
summary: Blackpink members Jenny, Lisa, Jisoo, and Rose have renewed their contracts with YG Entertainment for "group activities" following speculation about their future. The renewal, announced on December 6, drove up YG shares by over 20%. The group, one of K-pop's most successful girl groups, plans to release a new album and embark on a world tour with YG's full support. This marks a positive development for the label, which was previously hit by the "Burning Sun" scandal.

images.alt_text: The South Korean sensations Blackpink receive honorary MBEs (Members of the Order of the British Empire) from Britain's King Charles III, for its members’ work as advocates for the COP26 climate summit in 2021.
Each year, some 100 participants join The Academy Australia’s boot camp – spanning eight to 10 days – and receive training in singing, dancing and entertaining.
Photocards are the cornerstone of Kpop merchandise, as collectors' items packaged with other items to increase their sales.
Blackpink members (from left: Jisoo, Jennie, Lisa and Rose) performing at the National Stadium in Singapore in May 2023.
K-pop boy band BTS member Suga will begin his mandatory military service on Sep 22.

site_title: Singapore shares dip at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,074.93. Global equities ended on a positive note, with the Dow Jones down 0.2% and the S&P 500 slipping 0.1%. Local banking stocks were mixed, with DBS rising 0.4% and UOB and OCBC losing 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Gainers and losers were on par in early trade, with 21.2 million securities worth S$33.3 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Shares of Nio closed 1 per cent higher at US$7.19 on Tuesday, before the results announcement.

site_title: CLCT divests CapitaMall Shuangjing in Beijing for 842 million yuan
summary: CLCT divests CapitaMall Shuangjing in Beijing for 842 million yuan, representing an exit yield of 2.8%. The sale is expected to crystallize higher cash value, reduce leverage, and enhance returns for unitholders. The transaction is slated to complete in Q1 2024 and will generate 690.7 million yuan in net proceeds, which may be used to repay debt, undertake a unit buyback, and finance general corporate and working capital requirements.

images.alt_text: One of CapitaLand China Trust's prime logistics assets in Chengdu.
CapitaMall Wangjing, one of CapitaLand China Trust's prime shopping malls. The new offshore bonds will enable the trust to optimise its capital structure.
One of CapitaLand China Trust's (CLCT) prime logistics assets in Chengdu.
Pixgeneric / generic picture taken on 7 Feb 2023 of JCube mall, The 11 year old mall is  to close down on Aug 6, site to make way for 40-storey residential development.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, CapitaLand China Trust, Cordlife, Oiltek International
summary: Nio, an electric vehicle player, reported a net loss of 4.6 billion yuan (S$868.7 million) for the third quarter of FY2023, despite a 75.4% increase in deliveries. CapitaLand China Trust sold its Beijing mall, CapitaMall Shuangjing, for 842 million yuan (S$157.8 million) to enhance returns for its unitholders.

site_title: Unesco to list ceviche, opera as ‘intangible heritage’
summary: Unesco will list dozens of global traditions as "intangible heritage", including the preparation and consumption of ceviche from Peru, Italian opera singing, and the art of painting rickshaws in Bangladesh. Other candidates include Azerbaijani iftar traditions, traditional skills from Ivory Coast, and Cuban bolero. The recognition aims to safeguard disappearing traditions and promote shared cultural heritage.

images.alt_text: More than five years after the blaze, three investigating judges are still looking into what sparked it.
The Si Thep historical site in Phetchabun province, is Thailand’s first cultural site to be recognised by Unesco since 1992.
Launched by Microsoft-backed OpenAI in November, GenAI chatbot ChatGPT has become the world’s fastest growing app to date, and its emergence has prompted the release of rivals, such as Google’s Bard.

site_title: Young Chinese spurn traditional investments in favour of gold
summary: Chinese consumers, primarily those aged 18-40, are increasingly opting for gold investments due to economic uncertainty, with 70% intending to purchase pure gold jewellery. The trend is driven by low bank deposit interest rates, a weakening currency, and a property market downturn. Analysts expect Chinese demand for gold to remain high, with the metal serving as a safe haven in an economy experiencing slower growth. This trend highlights the growing importance of gold in China, the world's top buyer of physical gold.

images.alt_text: China has been ramping up efforts to revive its post-Covid economy with a slew of policy support measures in recent months, although these steps have provided only modest benefits so far.

University graduates attend a job fair in Hefei, Anhui province, China, Sept 4, 2023. On Wednesday, China's statistics bureau is expected to omit for the fourth consecutive month the release of youth unemployment data, suspended in July after reaching a record 21.3 per cent in June, just as 11.6 million fresh graduates were entering the job market.
Bai Yunxi, 33, a full-time astrologer, laughs during an interview with Reuters in Dali, Yunnan province, China, Nov 10, 2023.

While the economy is seen on track to hit the government’s annual growth target of around 5 per cent this year, Moody’s expects China’s annual economic growth to slow to an average 3.8 per cent from 2026 to 2030.
Analysts say the different survey sizes and composition of surveyed companies might explain the discrepancy between the Caixin and official PMI readings.

site_title: Australia’s economy surprisingly slows as rate hikes damp spending
summary: Australia's economy unexpectedly slowed to a 0.2% growth in the September quarter, lower than economists' 0.5% estimate, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The slowdown was driven by decreased household spending and a decline in exports. Annual growth slowed from a decade average of 2.4%, easing concerns about inflation pressures. This data suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia can maintain its current monetary policy stance to assess the economy.

site_title: EU takes tough line to China to level economic playing field
summary: European Union leaders are set to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Qiang on December 7, with trade and economic issues at the forefront. The EU will push for tangible progress on data flows, market access, and countering Russia's use of China as a route to secure banned technologies. China is expected to raise concerns about an EU probe into electric vehicles and the bloc's economic security strategy. The EU is concerned about China's economic recovery and its potential to export more goods, threatening European industries. The summit aims to reassure China's leaders that the EU's "de-risking" plans are about reducing dependencies, but China is unlikely to change its stance on economic policy.

images.alt_text: A Chinese consumer survey released by jewellery firm Chow Tai Fook in late October found 70 per cent of consumers aged between 18 and 40 intend to purchase pure gold jewellery.
From January to October 2023, Singapore welcomed approximately 1.13 million visitors from China, according to the Singapore Tourism Board.
A challenge for European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is the differences in how the 27 European Union member states view Beijing.

site_title: Hong Kong takes on rich-gone-rogue in illegal building crackdown
summary: Hong Kong's government has cracked down on unauthorized construction in the exclusive Redhill Peninsula, where a landslide exposed illegal basements and structures. 48 properties were found to have unapproved structures, with 22 encroaching on city-owned land. Chief Executive John Lee has vowed to prosecute homeowners and bill them for repairs. The issue of unauthorised structures in Hong Kong is widespread, with over 170 luxury houses found to occupy government land without permission. Experts say the problem is exacerbated by lax enforcement and the high price of land, making it difficult for homeowners to expand or add features.

images.alt_text: New World, which has one of the highest debt ratios among its peers after a years-long expansion spree, had US$8.4 billion dollars worth of outstanding bonds before it launched the tender offer for seven of its bonds.
Families with children born on or after Oct 25 this year qualify to apply for Category A tenancy after two years instead of the previous three-year period.

site_title: Oiltek obtains RM52.5 million worth of contracts from Colombia, Malaysia
summary: Oiltek International's wholly-owned subsidiary has secured RM52.5 million worth of contracts from Colombia and Malaysia. The contracts include designing and delivering plants for a new edible oil refinery complex and retrofitting an existing palm oil mill in Malaysia. This brings Oiltek's order book to RM390.6 million, with the projects expected to be fulfilled over 18-24 months. The cumulative value of new contracts won in FY2023 is RM312.5 million, 59.4% higher than FY2022.

images.alt_text: Renewable Energy Credit to Oiltek International Limited
The company said the new contracts are expected to contribute positively to its financial performance in FY2023 ending December.

Following the RM101 million worth of new contracts secured in the first quarter of this year, the cumulative value of new contracts that Oiltek has won in the current year to date amounts to approximately RM157.8 million.
Oiltek, however, said it is unable to provide a definitive assessment on the financial impact of carrying out the rectification works on the group.
Oiltek will assess if the fire incident will have any material financial impact on its results for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023.
Koh Brothers unit, Oiltek, lodges prospectus for Catalist IPO

site_title: Worsening China earnings are giving bears more reasons to sell
summary: China's third-quarter earnings worsened, with 30% of MSCI China Index members reporting earnings below consensus forecasts. Aggregate earnings per share fell 6% from last year, marking a fourth straight quarter of declines. Regulatory uncertainties, a worsening property crisis, and dim income prospects continue to pressure businesses, raising concerns about a stock market rebound. Investors are bracing for more pain as the economic slump is expected to continue, with some sectors needing deflationary pressures to improve margins and earnings.

images.alt_text: A Chinese consumer survey released by jewellery firm Chow Tai Fook in late October found 70 per cent of consumers aged between 18 and 40 intend to purchase pure gold jewellery.

While the economy is seen on track to hit the government’s annual growth target of around 5 per cent this year, Moody’s expects China’s annual economic growth to slow to an average 3.8 per cent from 2026 to 2030.
Analysts say the different survey sizes and composition of surveyed companies might explain the discrepancy between the Caixin and official PMI readings.

site_title: BYD growth status in doubt with US$12 billion sell-off
summary: BYD, the dominant Chinese auto brand, saw a US$12 billion sell-off in November due to doubts over its sales targets and smart-car capabilities. Despite record sales, investors question BYD's ability to meet sales goals, citing a difficult macro outlook, price cuts, and increasing competition from rivals like Huawei and Tesla. BYD's shares have plummeted 12% and its forward earnings multiple has fallen to its lowest in 12 years, raising concerns about further losses and a potential loss of market share.

images.alt_text: Shenzhen-based BYD aims to sell 3 million hybrids and EVs this year, and November’s figure lifts it to 2.67 million so far in 2023.
A cheaper model by Tesla, produced in Germany, may improve the US firm’s competitive edge over Chinese brands as carmakers race to bring down costs and make appealing, affordable EVs.
BYD is responsible for selling roughly one in three new-energy vehicles in China.

site_title: Biden ‘not sure’ he’d be seeking reelection if not for Trump
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed uncertainty about seeking reelection in 2024 if not for Republican rival Donald Trump's bid, citing concerns about Trump's increasingly extreme language and the threat to democracy. Biden praised former Republican lawmaker Liz Cheney's warning about a potential dictatorship if Trump returns. Trump responded with a post on his Truth Social network, calling Biden a "dictator." The 81-year-old Biden has repeatedly portrayed himself as defending American democracy in next year's vote, despite facing criticism over his age.

images.alt_text: An appeals court on November 30, 2023 reimposed a limited gag order on former president Donald Trump intended to protect court staff at his New York civil fraud trial after a flood of online abuse.
US President Joe Biden heads to California on Friday for a two-day stop where he will tap the deep pockets of Hollywood stars like directors Stephen Spielberg and Rob Reiner
“There is no magical pot of funding available to meet this moment, we are out of money – and nearly out of time,” says Shalanda Young, director of Office of Management and Budget.
The decision leaves open the possibility that Trump could still prevail in his immunity claims.
US President Joe Biden has been putting pressure on the Israeli government to delay and moderate its ground invasion of the Gaza Strip.
Many leaders from EU are expected at the COP28 climate summit. The bloc has become a big player in climate negotiations, partly through the power of example.

Republican presidential candidate and former US President Donald Trump faces four criminal cases, including state and federal charges stemming from his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss to Democrat Joe Biden.

site_title: Messi named Time’s ‘Athlete of the Year’
summary: Lionel Messi has been named Time magazine's "Athlete of the Year" for 2023, marking a transformative impact on the American sporting landscape. The 36-year-old Argentine superstar, who made a groundbreaking move to Major League Soccer's Inter Miami, led the team to win the expanded Leagues Cup. Messi's arrival drove a surge in attendances, ticket prices, merchandise sales, and viewership, making him a key figure in turning the US into a soccer country.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - Premier League - Everton v Manchester United - Goodison Park, Liverpool, Britain - November 26, 2023
