Fresh from a highly successful 2023 World Cup in Australia and New Zealand, football’s revenue is expected to reach US$555 million out of a total predicted figure of US$1.28 billion in 2024.

Everton's supporters protest over the club's 10-point deduction for breaching financial regulations, prior to the English Premier League football match between Everton and Manchester United at Goodison Park in Liverpool, north west England on Nov 26, 2023.
Last weekend’s match between Chelsea FC and Liverpool Football Club was watched by a record-breaking 1 million-plus audience on the free-to-air BBC.
Girona's Uruguayan forward Cristhian Stuani is the club's all-time top scorer with 226 goals. Here he is seen celebrating scoring against Almeria on Oct 22, 2023.

site_title: Volkswagen says audit finds no sign of forced labour at Xinjiang site
summary: Volkswagen has released the results of an audit of its Xinjiang site in China, finding no signs of forced labor. The audit, conducted by a German human rights firm, included on-site interviews and inspections of employee contracts. The site, which was reduced from 650 to 197 staff after the pandemic, has just under a quarter Uyghur employees. The audit acknowledged challenges in collecting data in China, but the findings are a relief for the automaker.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen is in the middle of negotiations with its works council over a cost-cutting scheme at its VW brand, the first step in a group-wide drive to boost efficiency in the transition to electric cars.
FILE PHOTO: A Volkswagen logo is seen during the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 5, 2023. REUTERS/David 'Dee' Delgado/File Photo
VW  is looking at localising assembly of battery packs for the under-US$35,000 EV to qualify for additional incentives under the US Inflation Reduction Act.
Cariad CEO Peter Bosch “has been working on a comprehensive transformation plan for the repositioning of Cariad” since the summer, says Volkswagen.

site_title: CBDCs still have not found their raison d’etre
summary: CBDCs, or central bank digital currencies, have yet to find their purpose despite over 130 countries exploring them. Proponents argue they can improve financial inclusion, but countries like India have shown that providing unique digital identifiers, low-cost accounts, and mobile payment systems can achieve the same goals more effectively. The inefficiencies of traditional banking payment systems can be addressed through alternative solutions, rendering CBDCs less necessary.

images.alt_text: The dollar is and will remain for the foreseeable future the main store of value for global investors. Geopolitical tensions favour the greenback as investors search for a haven and further escalations do not necessarily point to an imminent weakening of its dominant position.
Supporters say CBDCs will modernise payments with new functionality and provide an alternative to physical cash, which seems in terminal decline.

epa10570963 IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva participates in a news conference at the IMF headquarters during the 2023 Spring Meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank Group (WBG) in Washington, DC, USA, 13 April 2023. The Spring Meetings run from 10 to 15 April 2023.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS

The development of various digital currencies over the past few years implies a need for digital representations of money, and it is the job of the central banks to meet this need, said Agustin Carstens, general manager of BIS.
It is high time that central banks devote all their energies to fighting inflation. Dabbling in digital technologies should be put on the back burner.

site_title: Elon Musk’s xAI startup seeks to raise US$1 billion in equity
summary: Elon Musk's AI startup xAI is seeking to raise $1 billion in equity funding, with nearly $135 million already raised. The company, created to compete with OpenAI, has debuted a chatbot called Grok, trained on X social network data. Musk has expressed concerns about the technology and has publicly criticized OpenAI, which he believes is "effectively controlled by Microsoft". The funding will be used to further develop the company's products and compete with other AI companies.

images.alt_text: Musk has made a number of previous posts that promoted or amplified antisemitic content.

Elon Musk has faced a torrent of criticism since he on Nov 15 agreed with a user who falsely claimed Jewish people were stoking hatred against white people, saying the user who referenced the “Great Replacement” conspiracy theory was speaking “the actual truth.”

site_title: New leader of GM’s Cruise acknowledges ‘all-time low’ amid safety review
summary: GM's Cruise autonomous vehicle unit has hit an "all-time low" under its new leader, Mo Elshenawy, amid a safety review following a regulatory scrutiny over an October accident. The company paused all US driverless and supervised trips, expanded a safety review, and stepped down its CEO and chief product officer. Elshenawy acknowledged the need to be "significantly better" than human performance and vows to restore trust with regulators and the public. The company faces potential fines and sanctions for its failure to disclose accident details, and has cut spending on Cruise and halted its shares buyback program.

images.alt_text: Some conservative lawmakers have challenged Ford Motor’s plans to license technology from the Chinese battery giant known as CATL for a plant in Marshall, Michigan.
Tesla’s new Cybertruck on display at a Tesla store in San Diego, California, US, Nov 20, 2023.
GM has struggled to boost its stock price as it dealt this year with the UAW strike, problems at its Cruise self-driving vehicle unit and with the rollout of its new electric vehicles.

FILE PHOTO: A self-driving GM Bolt EV is seen during a media event where Cruise, GM's autonomous car unit, showed off its self-driving cars in San Francisco, California, U.S. November 28, 2017. REUTERS/Elijah Nouvelage/File Photo
Its shift in strategy will result in reductions in personnel “primarily in non-engineering roles”, Cruise said, adding that it would provide more details in mid-December.

site_title: Markets turbocharge bets that ECB will lead world on rate cuts
summary: Markets are betting on the European Central Bank (ECB) to cut interest rates in the first quarter of 2024, with a 90% chance of a 150 basis point cut to 2.5%. ECB policymaker Isabel Schnabel described a slowdown in inflation as "encouraging", effectively ruling out further rate hikes. This scenario would make the ECB the first major central bank to cut rates and deliver the most aggressive easing cycle. However, some Wall Street strategists caution that expectations for cuts may be extended, and the Federal Reserve is expected to deliver its first move in May.

images.alt_text: Following ECB official Isabel Schnabel’s comments, Germany’s 10-year bond yield has fallen to its lowest level since June, to 2.279 per cent.
“We need to remain attentive to the different forces affecting inflation and firmly focused on our mandate of price stability,” says ECB president Christine Lagarde.

The ECB has repeatedly warned that lenders aren’t doing enough to prepare for the fallout of extreme weather shocks on asset values, or the risk that clients with big carbon footprints might go out of business.

site_title: US services sector gauge picks up on improved business activity
summary: The Institute for Supply Management's services gauge rose 0.9 points to 52.7 in November, indicating a faster expansion pace as business activity and employment increased. The index has remained above the 50 level since the onset of the pandemic, with only one dip in contraction. However, forecasters expect a slowdown in consumer spending due to rising borrowing costs, price pressures, and reduced hiring and wage gains. The government's jobs report is expected to show a healthy but milder labor market growth.

images.alt_text: Worker pay did not keep up with inflation in 2021 and 2022, but workers enjoyed real disposable income gains of 4 per cent in the first three quarters of this year.
Factory orders fall 3.6 per cent after a downwardly revised 2.3 per cent in September.
Investment in residential construction shot up 1.2 per cent.
It is the 13th consecutive month that the ISM's PMI stayed below 50, which indicates contraction in manufacturing.

site_title: Wall Street CEOs head to Washington with capital-rule concerns
summary: Wall Street CEOs, including Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, James Gorman of Morgan Stanley, and David Solomon of Goldman Sachs, are set to testify before Congress on December 6, arguing that proposed capital rule changes will harm the economy. The rules, unveiled in July, would require big banks to increase their capital cushion by 20% to ensure survival in a crisis. Bankers claim the rules will limit their ability to deploy capital, drive up interest rates for certain borrowers, and push riskier lending into the non-bank sector, potentially leading to financial shocks.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s authorities have accelerated efforts to revive its hub status.

site_title: Hotels eye leisure and ‘bleisure’ as business travel recovery weakens
summary: Hotels globally are refocusing on leisure and "bleisure" travel as corporate travel demand weakens. Business travel demand remains at around 80% of 2019 levels, while leisure travel is "off the charts" compared to 2019. Luxury hotels now prioritize leisure services, and companies are reassessing employee travel due to sustainability concerns. Industry players agree that business travel is shifting, with the rise of "bleisure" trips combining work and leisure. To adapt, hotels are expanding leisure offerings, introducing wellness programs, and increasing focus on extended-stay products.

images.alt_text: Specialised travel itineraries such as wellness tourism, thematic holidays and active tourism are becoming increasingly popular.
Kevin Goh, CEO, The Ascott Limited
Thousands will travel there in early 2024 as British rock band Coldplay and American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift are scheduled to perform, each in a series of six dates at the National Stadium.
Indonesia, China, India, Malaysia and Australia are the top five source countries for visitors to Singapore in October.

site_title: ‘We felt it first’: Climate-threatened islands battle fossil fuels at COP28
summary: Small island states, despite being among the least to blame for global warming, are leading the fight against climate change at the COP28 UN conference in Dubai. They are pushing for the most ambitious temperature targets and a phase-out of fossil fuels, citing devastating storms and rising sea levels. The Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS) is determined to "keep 1.5 alive" and has called for a phase-out of fossil fuels, with some nations proposing alternative solutions like carbon capture and storage. The small islands' "extreme vulnerability" to climate change is driving their efforts to combat global warming.

images.alt_text: Activists participate in a demonstration against fossil fuels, during the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, December 5, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Mukoya

site_title: Binance might be peak for US crypto enforcement cases, says CFTC official
summary: The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) commissioner, Kristin Johnson, stated that the recent $4.3 billion settlement with Binance may have reached its peak for crypto enforcement cases, as the settlement provides a "template" for governing companies. The settlement was for Binance's violations of US anti-money laundering and sanctions laws. The CFTC has brought several cases against crypto firms, establishing "guardrails" to bring "order and structure" to the market.

images.alt_text: Changpeng Zhao (CZ) acquires a majority stake in the company that operates Trust Wallet in 2018.
Internal communications showed Zhao had direct knowledge Binance was violating US laws.
The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) says Binance is not registered in the Philippines and therefore not authorised to sell or offer securities in the country.

Changpeng Zhao, the founder of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, pleaded guilty to failing to implement anti-money laundering policies and US sanctions violations as part of a broad agreement with the US government.

site_title: Disney to release Pixar’s pandemic-era movies in theatres
summary: Disney will release Pixar's pandemic-era movies, Soul, Turning Red, and Luca, in theaters starting next year. The films, which debuted on Disney+, received critical acclaim and will help boost the studio's release schedule. The move aims to restore the profitability of Disney's film business, which has not turned a profit in over a year. The releases will also provide more fare for cinema operators. Inside Out 2, a sequel to the 2015 film Inside Out, will be released in June.

site_title: Oil falls to near 5-month low on Opec+ cut doubts, demand concerns
summary: Oil prices fell to a near five-month low on Tuesday, with Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate crude dropping 1.1% and 1.0% respectively, due to doubts over Opec+ supply cuts and concerns about demand. The Opec+ deal, announced last week, failed to support prices, with traders expressing skepticism about the effectiveness of the cuts. A stronger US dollar and lower interest rates also contributed to the price decline, while demand concerns were fueled by China's economic slowdown and the COP28 climate conference.

images.alt_text: The cuts in Saudi oil prices highlight the heated competition to win Asian customers in an oversupplied market.
FILE PHOTO: A well head and drilling rig in the Yarakta oilfield, owned by Irkutsk Oil Company (INK), in the Irkutsk region, Russia, March 11, 2019. REUTERS/Vasily Fedosenko/File Photo

site_title: As banks retreat from lending, innovative financing models are filling the void
summary: Banks' reduced lending due to high inflation and rising interest rates has led to a funding crisis, forcing businesses to seek alternative financing options. New investment firms, such as private equity and venture capital firms, angel investors, and family offices, have filled the void by taking on riskier projects and offering better conditions to borrowers who require more control over their creditors. These "shadow banks" are acting as an alternative to traditional banking, but their ability to engage in riskier transactions is still limited by regulatory pressure.

images.alt_text: Operational improvements are emerging as an important source of value creation in private equity. Active ownership by a PE fund can  improve underlying companies' value.
One alternative financing option is invoice factoring, in which a factoring company buys another company’s unpaid invoices at a discounted rate.

site_title: German firms diversify in Asia to reduce China risk: survey
summary: German companies are diversifying their supply chains to reduce dependence on China, shifting operations to other Asian markets. A survey of 566 German firms found 83% cited geopolitical tensions as the main reason for their actions, while 45% cited China's economic slowdown and 24% its focus on self-reliance. This trend aims to mitigate risks related to China business, with nearly half of German companies in China taking steps to reduce risk.

images.alt_text: Amro expects Asean+3 to grow by 4.3 per cent this year and at 4.5 per cent in 2024.
A challenge for European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is the differences in how the 27 European Union member states view Beijing.

site_title: Zara expands second-hand platform to 14 European countries
summary: Spanish fashion retailer Zara is expanding its 'Pre-Owned' second-hand platform to 14 European countries, starting Dec 12. The service is currently available in the UK and France and aims to extend the life of customers' Zara clothes, reduce waste, and raw material consumption. The expansion follows similar initiatives by competitors H&M and other fast fashion brands.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shoppers walk past a Zara clothes store, part of the Spanish group Inditex, in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain, December 13, 2022. REUTERS/Borja Suarez/File Photo

site_title: Singapore firms need to start combining climate- and nature-related financial disclosures
summary: Singapore companies must incorporate climate- and nature-related financial disclosures into their reporting, as climate and biodiversity are inextricably linked. The Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) and the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) frameworks provide a basis for transparency and accountability. While TCFD is mandatory for listed companies, TNFD is voluntary, but its framework is being adopted globally. To implement combined disclosures, companies must start small, engage stakeholders, and assess their impact on nature, leveraging existing climate disclosures and resources.

images.alt_text: Climate disclosures were “uneven in terms of quality and depth”, said Tan Boon Gin, chief executive of SGX Regulation.
The Sustainability Reporting Advisory Committee has recommended that non-listed companies with an annual revenue of at least S$1 billion make mandatory climate-related disclosures from FY2027.
An aerial view of forest land being cleared in Indonesia's West Kalimantan. The new framework by TNFD paves the way for a new focus around creating a “nature-positive” economy.

The National Parks Board (NParks) will be announcing plans to restore and enhance the habitats of Labrador Nature Reserve including a new Keppel Coastal Trail, as part of efforts to transform Singapore into a City in Nature, a key pillar of the Singapore Green Plan.
An estimated 63 per cent of Asia Pacific's GDP, US$19 trillion, is at risk from nature loss.

site_title: Cordlife Group’s cellular therapy accreditation suspended indefinitely
summary: Cordlife Group's cellular therapy accreditation has been suspended indefinitely by the Foundation for the Accreditation of Cellular Therapy following an investigation into seven storage tanks kept at temperatures above acceptable limits. The company has received a request to submit reports and corrective plans to restore accreditation. Cordlife Group has been accredited since 2015 and has promised to provide all necessary information to the foundation to resolve the issues. The impact on its business is unclear.

images.alt_text: Cordlife has been barred for six months from collecting, testing, processing and storing new cord-blood or tissue samples, as well as from running new test types for patients.
Cordlife Group said that it will continue to store affected cord blood units for clients, as they “may still be valuable in light of developments in the field of cell and gene therapy.”
The group, as one of the five private cord blood banks in Asia, has been barred from collecting, testing, processing and storing new cord-blood or tissue samples.

site_title: P&G to record up to US$2.5 billion in Gillette writedown, operations rejig
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) plans to record up to $2.5 billion in charges over two fiscal years due to a write-down of its Gillette business and restructuring of markets. The company expects a non-cash impairment charge of $1.3 billion before tax in the current quarter. P&G also expects charges of $1 billion to $1.5 billion after tax related to restructuring in Argentina and Nigeria due to macroeconomic difficulties.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, P&G said the company’s first-quarter global shipment volumes were weighed down by weakness and volatility in China.
P&G’s results underscore shoppers’ willingness to continue spending in the face of persistent inflation and economic uncertainty.
P&G’s overall volumes fall 1 per cent in the fourth quarter and the company flag lower volumes, primarily in Greater China.
“Our volumes are starting to stabilise, which is what we wanted to see,” P&G chief financial officer Andre Schulten said.

site_title: Saudis cut Asia oil prices after Opec+ deepens output curbs
summary: Saudi Arabia cut its official crude oil selling prices to Asia by 50 cents to $3.50 a barrel, amid a supply glut and Opec+ production cuts. The cuts, which are less than estimated, highlight competition to win Asian customers. Opec and its allies agreed to reduce joint supplies by over 2 million barrels a day, with Saudi Arabia contributing half of that. Despite the cuts, oil prices have remained low due to oversupply concerns, with front-month spreads indicating a bearish market.

site_title: Unitholders of Manulife US Reit caught between a rock and a hard place
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (MUST) has received a $235 million funding package from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property and a sponsor-lender loan. The recapitalisation plan provides MUST with a longer timeline to navigate its financial troubles, but unitholders are uncertain about the value that could be realised in the long term. The plan suspends half-yearly distributions until December 2025 and involves selling off less desirable assets in a weak US office market. MUST's weighted average debt maturity is now at 3.7 years, giving it a 19-month runway to execute asset dispositions.

images.alt_text: Part of the deal unveiled last week involves MUST's sponsor taking Park Place off its books for US$98.7 million
Manulife US Reit's Centerpointe property. Its manager has announced plans to raise funds through a mix of asset dispositions and a sponsor-lender loan to remedy the Reit’s financial covenant breach.
The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.

site_title: Singapore, Europe top wish list of Chinese tourists as Thailand and Japan lose some shine
summary: Singapore has become the top destination for Chinese tourists, surpassing Japan and Thailand due to health and safety concerns. According to a quarterly travel sentiment survey, 17.5% of Chinese residents plan to visit Singapore, while 14.3% want to go to Europe, and 11.4% to South Korea. This marks a significant shift in travel preferences, with Singapore's strong tourism infrastructure and safety record likely contributing to its appeal.

images.alt_text: Tourists from mainland China dressed in traditional Thai costumes visit Wat Arun temple in Bangkok, Thailand on January 18, 2023. Despite being the most popular destination among Chinese tourists in Q1 2023, Thailand has lost its appeal due to safety concerns. PHOTO: REUTERS
Indonesia, China, India, Malaysia and Australia are the top five source countries for visitors to Singapore in October.
The reiterated "add" call comes before the Q3 update by Malaysia Airports Holdings (MAHB) on Wednesday.
Attracting Chinese travellers is the key to tourism-reliant Thailand’s ambitious target of luring 40 million visitors next year and generating 3.1 trillion baht (S$117.1 billion) in revenue.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as job market tightens
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.2% to 36,124.56, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% to 4,567.18. A cooling US jobs market, as indicated by a drop of over 600,000 job openings in October, contributed to the mixed performance. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.3% to 14,229.91. Positive economic reports, including a slight rise in the services index of the Institute for Supply Management, countered the negative impact of declining shares from companies such as CVS Health and Procter & Gamble.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 68.79 points, or 0.19 per cent, at the open, to 36,135.65.

site_title: ECB says consumer inflation expectations match 5-month high
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported that consumer inflation expectations for the eurozone remained at 4% in October, matching a 5-month high. This suggests caution from the ECB in the face of mounting bets for interest-rate cuts. For the next three years, the outlook for inflation stayed unchanged at 2.5%. The ECB's survey also showed consumers expecting a 1.3% contraction in the next 12 months, raising concerns of a shallow recession.

images.alt_text: Following ECB official Isabel Schnabel’s comments, Germany’s 10-year bond yield has fallen to its lowest level since June, to 2.279 per cent.

Eurozone inflation tumbled to 2.4 per cent last month, coming well below expectations for the third straight month, fuelling market bets that ECB interest rates will come down much quicker than the bank now guides.

site_title: Climate Impact X to launch new governance body-aligned carbon contract
summary: Climate Impact X (CIX), a Singapore-based carbon exchange, will launch a new set of standardised carbon contracts aligned with the Core Carbon Principles (CCP) credits, expected to come on stream next year. The CCP credits, set by the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM), are a key governance body for high-integrity carbon credits. CIX's new contracts will complement its existing suite, built around forest conservation and cookstove projects, and are expected to trade at a premium. The move aims to support a projected demand for credible credits and promote a transparent, standardised market for carbon credits.

images.alt_text: ICVCM states that forestry projects under Redd+ – a UN framework created to guide activities in the forest sector that reduces emissions from deforestation and forest degradation – must also conform to the Cancun safeguards.
The World Business Council for Sustainable Development's president Peter Bakker is joining Temasek's GenZero as a director of its board.
MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures
The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market's framework has ruled out carbon projects that “lock in fossil fuel emissions or technologies”.

site_title: Chipmakers heading for an epic rebound
summary: Chipmakers are poised for a rebound in semiconductor sales, expected to surge 40% by 2025, driven by the growing demand for AI-powered technology. The industry is currently in a downturn, with sales plummeting 20% year-on-year in Q2 2023, but experts believe the slump will be temporary. The adoption of AI will drive the industry's growth, with chipmakers requiring highly advanced processors to handle complex workloads. Government incentives, such as the US$280 billion Chips and Science Act, will also contribute to higher sales growth.

images.alt_text: The artificial intelligence boom has spurred demand for chips that train large language models.
Biren is considering a listing in Hong Kong as soon as this year, Bloomberg News reported in July.
Taiwan remains a critical player in advanced semiconductor manufacturing. But the US is also trying to diversify semiconductor production out of Taiwan into the US and other close allies.

site_title: Prince Harry challenges 'unfair treatment' over UK security in London court
summary: Prince Harry is challenging the UK government's decision to strip him of police protection when in Britain, claiming it's "unlawful, unfair and unjustifiable". The decision was made in 2020 after he stepped back from royal duties, despite him covering the cost of security himself. Harry's lawyer argues that he should be given state security due to the threats and risks he faces, citing credible threats made against him and his family. The case will be heard in private due to security concerns.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex steps out of a car, outside the Rolls Building of the High Court in London, Britain June 7, 2023. REUTERS/Hannah McKay     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
A man checks his smartphone with the Spotify Technology logo behind him in an arranged photograph in London. MUST CREDIT: Bloomberg photo by Chris Ratcliffe.

site_title: US job openings in October lowest since 2021, well below forecasts
summary: US job openings dropped to 8.733 million in October, the lowest level since early 2021, according to the Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey. This represents a 617,000 decline from September and below economists' forecasts of 9.30 million. The decline suggests the labor market is easing, driven by higher interest rates cooling demand in the economy. This easing has raised optimism that the Federal Reserve is likely done raising interest rates, with some anticipating a rate cut in mid-2024.

site_title: Seatrium appoints Adrian Teng as CFO
summary: Seatrium, an engineering solutions provider to the marine, offshore, and energy sectors, has appointed 52-year-old Adrian Teng Wei Ann as its new Chief Financial Officer, effective January 1, 2024. Teng brings over two decades of experience in finance, restructuring, and corporate management across developed and emerging markets. Prior to this appointment, he held roles as group CFO and COO at Clifford Capital Holdings and group finance director at Jardine Cycle & Carriage.

images.alt_text: Photo of Southeast Asias first floating and stacked Energy Storage System with maximum storage capacity of 75 megawatt hour MWh to power over 600 fourroom HDB house
Seatrium says its new facility is expected to support the group in achieving its ESG targets over time.

site_title: London Stock Exchange suffers third outage in months
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG) suffered its third outage in months, halting trading in about 2,000 smaller shares. The outages follow previous disruptions, including a 40-minute outage in FTSE Russell indexes last month and a halt in hundreds of shares in October. The recent disruptions are embarrassing for LSEG as it seeks to transform itself into a data services giant.

images.alt_text: The combined US dollar-based market capitalisation of primary British listings stands now at US$2.90 trillion versus France’s US$2.93 trillion, according to an index compiled by Bloomberg.
Blockchain is a digital ledger which records and verifies transactions.

site_title: EU approves ban on destruction of unsold clothing
summary: The European Union has approved a law banning the destruction of unsold textiles and footwear, aiming to reduce waste and promote sustainability in the fashion industry. The law, set to take effect in two years, will exempt medium-sized companies for six years and smaller companies entirely. This move is part of the EU's efforts to crack down on fast fashion and encourage the use of products that can be repaired and recycled.

images.alt_text: View of used clothes discarded in the Atacama desert, in Alto Hospicio, Iquique, Chile, on September 26, 2021. - EcoFibra, Ecocitex and Sembra are circular economy projects that have textile waste as their raw material. The textile industry in Chile will be included in the law of Extended Responsibility of the Producer (REP), forcing clothes and textiles importers take charge of the waste they generate. (Photo by MARTIN BERNETTI / AFP)
The rules will include tighter requirements for products to be “more durable, reliable, reusable, upgradable, reparable, recyclable and easier to maintain”, the member states say.
Under the ETS, operators of ships of over 5,000 gross tonnage sailing entirely within the European Union will have to account for all of their emissions.
A challenge for European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is the differences in how the 27 European Union member states view Beijing.

The IPCEI Next Generation Cloud Infrastructure and Services (IPCEI CIS) is jointly notified by seven European Union states, namely: France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, and Spain.

site_title: UK interior minister signs new Rwanda treaty to resurrect asylum plan
summary: British Interior Minister James Cleverly signed a new treaty with Rwanda to revive a plan to transfer asylum seekers to the East African country, following a court decision to block the policy. The treaty addresses concerns over human rights and includes measures such as a monitoring committee and a new appeal body. Deportation flights are expected to resume, despite opposition from lawyers and charities and potential legal challenges. The plan aims to cut migration and deter migrants crossing the Channel from Europe, with Rwanda receiving an initial payment of $180 million.

images.alt_text: While Sunak has said that he wants to get immigration down “over time”, his focus has been on reducing the number of people arriving on Britain’s shores in small boats.

site_title: Inflation in advanced economies is now at its lowest in two years
summary: Inflation in advanced economies has reached its lowest level in two years, according to the OECD. The headline inflation measure dropped to 5.6% in October from 6.2% in September, with 28 countries experiencing a decline in inflation rates. Food-cost pressures have eased rapidly, and energy prices have fallen in most countries. This has led investors to bet that central banks will ease monetary policies sooner than expected, despite core price growth remaining stable at 6.5%.

site_title: Amazon latest to criticise Microsoft in UK cloud market probe
summary: Amazon has accused Microsoft of using business practices that restrict customer choice in the cloud computing market, citing changes to Microsoft's terms of services that make it difficult for customers to switch to alternative providers. This criticism comes as Britain's antitrust authority, the Competition and Markets Authority, launched an investigation into the UK cloud computing industry in October. Amazon's concerns echo those of Google, which also submitted a letter to the watchdog, claiming Microsoft's practices have left its rivals at an unfair disadvantage. Microsoft disputes these claims, stating the market remains competitive.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This illustration photograph taken on October 30, 2023 in Mulhouse, eastern France, shows figurines next to a screen displaying a logo of Google, a US multinational technology company. The Canadian government and Google announced on November 29, 2023 a "historic" deal to support the country's media, heading off an imminent threat by the digital giant to block news on its platform. (Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)

FILE PHOTO: Sundar Pichai, CEO of Google, reacts during a meeting with U.S. President Joe Biden, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and senior officials and CEOs of American and Indian companies in the East Room of the White House in Washington, U.S., June 23, 2023. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein/File Photo
AWS and Microsoft have had a combined 70 per cent to 80 per cent share of Britain’s public cloud infrastructure services market in 2022, Ofcom said.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as focus shifts to jobs data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday as investors awaited the jobs report to gauge potential interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 68.79 points, or 0.19%, to 36,135.65. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 opening 12.53 points, or 0.27%, lower at 4,557.25. The lower opening is attributed to uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's decision, which could impact interest rates and the overall market.

site_title: Sri Lanka to receive about US$600 million ADB funding post-IMF approval
summary: Sri Lanka will receive approximately US$600 million in funding from the Asian Development Bank, on a staggered basis, after the International Monetary Fund (IMF) releases its second tranche of a US$2.9 billion bailout. The funding is part of a four-year programme aimed at stabilizing the country's economy, which has been gradually recovering from its worst financial crisis in decades. The IMF's first review is expected to be approved next week, followed by additional support from the ADB, including US$200 million for power sector reforms and US$100 million for the water sector in 2024.

images.alt_text: People gather around readymade clothing stalls to buy clothes ahead of the Sinhala and Tamil New Year festival, in Colombo, Sri Lanka April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: EU clears up to 1.2 billion euros of state aid for cloud computing
summary: The European Union has approved up to 1.2 billion euros in state aid for the IPCEI Next Generation Cloud Infrastructure and Services project, a joint effort by seven EU countries to boost cloud computing in the region. The project aims to increase EU business involvement in the field, dominated by US companies, and unlock 1.4 billion euros in private investments. The EU has previously approved six IPCEIs in related fields, and the cloud project features 19 companies, including major players like Atos and Deutsche Telekom.

images.alt_text: Eurozone inflation tumbled to 2.4 per cent last month, coming well below expectations for the third straight month, fuelling market bets that ECB interest rates will come down much quicker than the bank now guides.

Two employees of German semiconductor manufacturer Infineon Technologies AG work in a clean room on the production line of 300-millimeter wafers at the company's plant in Dresden, eastern Germany, on April 26, 2023. - German chipmaker Infineon will launch the groundbreaking of a new factory, the Smart Power Fab, in Dresden on May 2, 2023. Supply chain snarls during the Coronavirus pandemic have exposed how over-reliant Europe has become on chip imports from abroad in recent years, disrupting numerous industries that depend on the components. The European Union in 2022 launched a plan known as the "Chips Act", which aims to double Europe's market share in semiconductors by 2030. (Photo by JENS SCHLUETER / AFP)

“Our armed forces must be ready for a much more demanding era,” says EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell, who heads the EDA. “Adjusting to these new realities first and foremost means investing more on defence,” he adds.

site_title: Stock investors watch four key COP28 debates for market impact
summary: Investors closely follow COP28 discussions for potential market impact. Key developments include funding for disaster relief, upgrades to power grids to accommodate renewable energy, and agreements on methane emissions reductions. A pledge to triple renewable energy capacity by 2030 requires significant investment, with suppliers and grid upgrades benefiting. A global carbon market is also expected to shape corporate investments in emissions reduction. While concrete steps are not yet clear, the Dubai gathering's agenda will guide governments' actions, creating opportunities for companies involved in disaster relief, renewable energy, and carbon management.

images.alt_text: Flood waters submerge parked cars in Hue city in central Vietnam on November 15, 2023.
Asia slashed the share of fossil fuels in power generation by 8 percentage points to 68 per cent in 2022 from 2015, abating more gas and coal use than Europe and North America.

site_title: Greenback stands near one-week high; yuan weathers China outlook cut
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.15% near a one-week high, driven by a reversal of recent heavy selling that had stripped 3% off the index in November. The euro fell 0.1% after European Central Bank comments, while the yuan held steady despite Moody's downgrade of China's credit rating. Investors await the US non-farm payrolls report for November and look ahead to monetary policy decisions next year, which could shape currency markets.

site_title: Apple warns India’s EU-style charger rules will hit local production target
summary: Apple has warned India's government that implementing EU-style charger rules, requiring existing iPhones to have universal charging ports, will hit local production targets under the country's production-linked incentive (PLI) scheme. Apple is lobbying for an exemption or delay, citing the design of earlier products cannot be changed. If the rules are implemented on earlier models, Apple may struggle to meet PLI targets, which could impact its growth in the Indian market.

images.alt_text: Foxconn, which employs about 35,000 people at its Tamil Nadu iPhone factory, has yet to decide whether to resume production on Tuesday,

epa10933931 The logo of Foxconn is pictured on a building in Taipei, Taiwan, 23 October 2023. According to state media, Foxconn, a Taiwan-based Apple iPhone manufacturer, has reportedly been subject to a Chinese inquiry regarding tax audits and land use investigations.  EPA-EFE/RITCHIE B. TONGO

site_title: Oil holds losses as Saudi pledge wrestles with bearish outlook
summary: Global oil prices remain bearish, trading near $77 a barrel after dropping over 6% in the previous three sessions. Saudi Arabia's pledge to implement Opec+ supply cuts, totaling 900,000 barrels a day, is seen as insufficient to overcome rising stockpiles. Despite the cuts, production from outside the alliance has consistently surpassed expectations, dampening market bullishness. Analysts predict the cuts will be delivered, but may not be enough to prevent oil prices from dipping further, with some predicting a rally to $100 a barrel in the final month of the year.

images.alt_text: Opec+ announced production cuts that are voluntary in nature, raising doubts about whether or not producers would fully implement them.

site_title: Malaysia property agents expect housing prices, rental rates to increase in 2024: survey
summary: Malaysia's property agents anticipate a bullish outlook for 2024, with 95% expecting housing prices to rise and 97% anticipating rental growth. The average expectation is for a 9.95% increase in residential prices and a 9.57% increase in rents. This optimism is attributed to expected economic trends, investment inflows, and demand and supply dynamics, which may encourage more local and foreign investment and lead to developers launching more projects.

images.alt_text: Kuala Lumpur, Selangor and Johor are the top destinations for investors from China, according to Juwai IQI's report.

site_title: Group files climate complaint against US credit agency over fossil fuel loans
summary: An environmental group, Friends of the Earth, has filed a complaint with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) alleging that the US Export-Import Bank's (EXIM) financing of fossil fuel projects abroad violates the Biden administration's promise to stop international public finance for fossil fuels. EXIM has financed $5.78 billion in fossil fuel projects from 2017 to 2021, while only $120 million went to clean energy. The complaint claims EXIM has not taken sufficient action to reduce its portfolio of greenhouse gas-emitting projects and transactions.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean speaking to media at the sidelines of COP28
Asia slashed the share of fossil fuels in power generation by 8 percentage points to 68 per cent in 2022 from 2015, abating more gas and coal use than Europe and North America.

An oil platform in the North Sea, where the UK government is looking to increase oil and gas extraction. As some governments soften their stance over their net-zero promises, central banks have been slowly emerging as key stakeholders in facilitating the green transition.

site_title: Singapore Technologies Telemedia not redeeming S$350 million, 5% perpetual at first call
summary: Singapore Technologies Telemedia will not redeem its S$350 million, 5% subordinated perpetual securities by January 2024, as initially planned. The distribution rate will also not be reset on the first call date on January 17, 2024. The coupon rate will remain at 5% per annum until January 17, 2029, and reset every 10 years thereafter if not redeemed.

images.alt_text: ST Telemedia logo
Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Singapore leads way as Asia tops world education class
summary: Singapore leads the world in education, topping the OECD's Pisa survey in 2022 with 690,000 students from 81 countries. Asian countries, including Macau, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea, followed closely. However, the report also showed that students in top-performing countries, such as Singapore, were not necessarily happier, with high levels of anxiety and limited engagement in extracurricular activities. The survey revealed a record drop in performance in Europe, with countries like Germany, Iceland, and Norway seeing lower achievements in mathematics.

images.alt_text: A recent survey found that around 60 per cent of Indonesian employees consider digital skills the most important to acquire. But, data from 2020 suggests that less than 1 per cent of the workforce possessed advanced digital skills

site_title: Singaporeans exempt from Malaysia digital arrival card that applies to foreigners
summary: Singaporean citizens traveling to Malaysia will not be required to fill the Malaysia Digital Arrival Card (MDAC), which will be mandatory for foreign travelers starting January 1. Home Minister Saifuddin Nasution Ismail announced the exemption, citing that some Singaporeans enter Malaysia daily and making it "more realistic" to exempt them. The exemption applies to all entry points in Malaysia, not just southern entry points in Johor.

site_title: Silverlake appoints Cassandra Goh as next CEO
summary: Silverlake Axis appoints Cassandra Goh Shiou Ling as its next group CEO, effective January 1, 2025, succeeding Andrew Tan Teik Wei. Goh had previously served as deputy CEO since May 2022 and deputy executive chairman since October 2023. The leadership transition was part of a planned process overseen by the board, with Tan's next role and potential departure from the company not specified.

site_title: Nio sinks deeper into the red, posts 4.6 billion yuan net loss for Q3
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle player, reported a net loss of 4.6 billion yuan (S$868.7 million) for the third quarter of FY2023, down from a 4.1 billion yuan loss in the same period last year. Despite a 75.4% increase in deliveries, the company's revenue rose 46.6% but was outpaced by a 55.7% surge in cost of sales, leading to a gross margin drop to 8%. Nio expects to deliver 47,000 to 49,000 vehicles in Q4 and projects revenue to improve to between 16.1 billion yuan and 16.7 billion yuan.

images.alt_text: The Chinese EV maker expects revenue of up to 16.7 billion yuan in the three months through December, short of the 21.4 billion yuan average estimate from analysts.
Granting Nio a production licence marks a shift for Chinese authorities, who have been cautious about approving new production amid overcapacity, and a deepening price war.

site_title: Fall in eurozone Nov business activity adds to recession expectations: PMI
summary: The eurozone business activity fell in November, but eased from its near three-year low, with the Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 47.6. This still indicates a recession, with the economy contracting 0.1% last quarter and expected to do so again this quarter. The dominant services industry continues to struggle, generating demand. The PMI surpasses the 47.1 preliminary estimate, suggesting a slight improvement in the economic health.

images.alt_text: Following ECB official Isabel Schnabel’s comments, Germany’s 10-year bond yield has fallen to its lowest level since June, to 2.279 per cent.
HCOB’s final eurozone manufacturing PMI, compiled by S&P Global, rises to 44.2 in November from October’s 43.1, above a preliminary estimate of 43.8.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio falls behind on sales with revenue outlook missing estimates
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio reported a quarterly loss of 4.6 billion yuan and missed revenue estimates, falling short of analyst forecasts. The company expects revenue of up to 16.7 billion yuan in the three months through December and plans to sell 47,000 to 49,000 vehicles, down from the forecast 59,426 sales. Nio aims to improve efficiency and reduce costs, but its shares have declined 25% this year, trailing rival Xpeng's 61% gain.

images.alt_text: Granting Nio a production licence marks a shift for Chinese authorities, who have been cautious about approving new production amid overcapacity, and a deepening price war.

The partnership will see Nio and state-owned Changan on building and sharing battery-swapping stations and standardising batteries.

site_title: Biden December fundraising blitz to star James Taylor, Spielberg
summary: US President Joe Biden will embark on a two-month fundraising blitz, starting with a December stop in California where he will attend events hosted by Hollywood stars Stephen Spielberg and Rob Reiner. The campaign aims to raise millions of dollars, with James Taylor set to perform at an evening concert. The fundraising efforts come ahead of the 2024 presidential election, where Biden faces a potential rematch with former President Donald Trump. Despite Republican donors being divided, the Biden campaign has raised significant funds, including $91 million in cash on hand.

images.alt_text: The White House launched its own Threads official account, as well as accounts for President Joe Biden, First Lady Jill Biden, Vice-President Kamala Harris and second gentleman Douglas Emhoff.

Footage of Joe Biden losing his balance on the stairs of Air Force One has gone viral - he now uses a shorter flight of stairs - and he has occasionally given rambling answers during press conferences.

site_title: Anticipating calm in the Middle East
summary: The Middle East conflict between Hamas and Israel has had a muted impact on global markets, with oil prices falling despite the attack. This suggests that the global community does not expect the conflict to expand significantly beyond its current borders. The market's reaction to the conflict is less significant than the impact of the Russian attack on Ukraine in 2022, indicating that the Eastern Caucus region of the former USSR remains more concerning to global markets.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-interest-bearing bullion.
Opec+ announced production cuts that are voluntary in nature, raising doubts about whether or not producers would fully implement them.

site_title: ‘Grand Theft Auto VI’ trailer drops, flagging 2025 release
summary: The trailer for Grand Theft Auto VI has been released, confirming a 2025 release date. The game is set in Vice City, a fictional Miami-like city, and appears to feature a playable female character, a first for the franchise. The trailer showcases the game's themes of crime and violence, but also hints at a more absurd and satirical take on American society. Rockstar Games has promised to push the limits of immersive storytelling in the game.

images.alt_text: ByteDance acquired Moonton in 2021 at a valuation of about US$4 billion.
A man, who said he was jailed for two years for scamming others, speaks during an AFP interview on condition of anonymity at temporary housing for ex-prisoners in Tokyo, Japan, August 27, 2023.

site_title: MAS partners ADB to set up US$2 billion blended-finance fund
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has partnered the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Global Energy Alliance for People and Planet (GEAPP) to set up a blended-finance fund aiming to raise up to US$2 billion to finance energy transition in Asia. The fund will leverage concessional capital and commercial capital to de-risk projects and crowd in private capital. The partnership is part of the Financing Asia's Transition Partnership (Fast-P) initiative, which targets to raise at least US$5 billion, and will focus on accelerating the transition to cleaner energy by financing projects such as the early phase-out of coal-fired power plants.

images.alt_text:
Front (from left to right): Global Energy Alliance for People and Planet's (GEAPP) vice president Kitty Bu, Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) chief sustainability officer Gillian Tan and Asian Development Bank's (ADB) vice president for sectors and themes Fatima Yasmin

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 5)
summary: Singapore retail sales dipped 0.1% in October, reversing a 0.8% growth in September, snapping an eight-month expansion streak. The total retail sales value reached S$4 billion, with online sales accounting for 13.1% of the total. Meanwhile, the Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched over 6,000 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in December. The Asean+3 region's non-financial debt reached 300% of its GDP at the end of 2022, and Singtel is developing sustainable data centers to support AI adoption. Singapore shares fell for the second consecutive day, down 0.2%.

site_title: US crypto industry lobby spending on track for new record in 2023
summary: The US cryptocurrency industry is on track to hit a new record for federal lobbying spending in 2023, with companies spending $18.96 million in the first three quarters, compared to $16.1 million in 2022. The industry has been expanding its lobbying efforts to repair reputations and advance friendly legislation, following scandals such as the collapse of FTX. Companies like Coinbase and Binance are leading the pack, with Coinbase spending $2.16 million and Binance operating Crypto.com, the Blockchain Association, and Foris DAX. The industry is pushing for a spot Bitcoin ETF and friendly legislation to combat growing regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: The crypto industry is awaiting the outcome of applications from the likes of BlackRock to start the first US spot Bitcoin ETFs.
Changpeng Zhao (CZ) acquires a majority stake in the company that operates Trust Wallet in 2018.

site_title: Employers can get staff to start retirement planning early
summary: A survey of 2,000 working adults in Singapore found that 79% either do not have a retirement plan or are not on track with one, a concerning trend in a rapidly aging society. The OCBC Financial Wellness Index 2023 recorded its second consecutive fall to an all-time low of 60, with a notable decline in retirement planning. The average age at which respondents in their 50s plan to start retirement savings is 60, a late start for accumulating a meaningful nest egg, given the current statutory retirement age of 63.

images.alt_text: 公积金局碧山服务中心。CPF Bishan Service Centre.
2023’s Financial Wellness Index score fell to 60 points – the lowest since the inception of the index in 2019, OCBC said.

site_title: India to be world’s third-largest economy by 2030, says S&P Global Ratings
summary: India is expected to become the world's third-largest economy by 2030, driven by its rapid growth rate, with S&P Global Ratings forecasting 6.4% growth this fiscal year and 7% by fiscal 2027. The country's successful transition to a manufacturing-dominated economy will be crucial, with a focus on developing a strong logistics framework and upskilling its workforce. Currently, services account for over half of India's GDP, but the sector is facing risks from weak global demand and elevated interest rates.

images.alt_text: India’s economy expands 7.6 per cent in the September quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong's New World Development to buy back US$610.3 million bonds
summary: Hong Kong's New World Development agreed to repurchase $610.3 million of its dollar bonds to cut debt and borrowing costs. The move comes after the company sold its construction subsidiary, NWS Holdings, for $2.8 billion. New World is buying back seven bonds at set prices between $600 to $910 per $1,000 principal amount, providing liquidity to investors at a premium to market price. The tender offer, which expired on Friday, is expected to be settled on Tuesday. This move is part of the company's efforts to address its high debt ratio following a years-long expansion spree.

images.alt_text: A general view shows residential buildings in Hong Kong on July 8, 2023. (Photo by May JAMES / May James / AFP)

site_title: China-EU summit has low expectations
summary: The EU-China summit, set to take place on December 7-8, has low expectations due to the EU's lack of unity on China policy. Despite efforts by European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and High Representative Josep Borrell to enforce a common bloc-wide stance, differences in outlook between Eastern and Western European nations pose a significant challenge. Beijing has been tailoring its approach to individual EU states, with China favoring states that show support. Western European nations like Germany and France are expected to continue engaging with China, despite the EU's hawkish direction, leading to concerns that the EU's policy towards China may be divided and ineffective.

images.alt_text: The summit follows a series of high-level meetings between the two sides this year on issues including trade and foreign policy. The EU’s top diplomat, Josep Borrell (left, with China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi ) visited Beijing in October.

site_title: Singapore shares decline for second day on regional losses; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% or 6.92 points to 3,077.16 on Tuesday, marking its second consecutive day of losses. The decline follows regional losses, with markets in Malaysia, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea also falling. The top loser on the Singapore bourse was DBS, while Jardine Matheson was the biggest gainer. The decline is attributed to concerns over the pace of Fed rate cuts, pushing Treasury yields higher and equities lower.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks mirror global retreat on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%

site_title: Britain's dominant services sector rebounds, cost burdens persist
summary: Britain's services sector experienced a rebound in November, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK Services PMI rising to 50.9, above the 50 threshold for growth. This follows three months of declines. However, companies reported higher prices charged, a concern for the Bank of England ahead of its interest rates decision next week. The services sector production gauge was the strongest since July, but strong input cost pressures remain a worry. Staffing numbers in the services sector improved, but some businesses have implemented hiring freezes due to rising staff wages and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Inflation expectations in five to 10 years’ time pick up to 3.5 per cent in October from 3.3 per cent in September.
Britain’s economy is still suffering from weak growth.

site_title: EU ports fret they will lose business because of CO2 tax
summary: The European Union's Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) will apply to shipping from January 1, 2024, requiring operators of ships over 5,000 gross tonnage to account for all emissions. European port operators, such as Feport, are concerned that the ETS will lead to cargo diversion to non-EU ports, making their terminals less competitive and potentially harming employment. Seven EU countries have written to the European Commission asking to delay the implementation of the ETS, citing concerns about limited environmental benefits and potential economic losses.

images.alt_text: VCMs cover pollution-reducing projects, such as reforestation, renewable energy, biogas and solar power, that generate carbon credits companies buy to offset their emissions and meet net-zero targets.

site_title: 65 years later, Brenda Lee’s ‘Christmas Tree’ hits No 1
summary: Brenda Lee's 1958 rockabilly holiday song "Rockin' Around the Christmas Tree" has finally reached No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart, 65 years after its initial release, beating Mariah Carey's "All I Want for Christmas Is You" in a close competition. The song, which Lee recorded at 13, has gained a boost from streaming playlists, with 34.9 million streams for the week, surpassing Carey's 32.4 million. This marks Lee's first No. 1 hit since 1960 and the longest stretch for any song to reach the top of the Hot 100.

images.alt_text: After a boom during the pandemic, streaming collections have doubled from their pre-Covid levels and account for 35 per cent of total collections for music creators, surpassing TV and radio.
FILE PHOTO: Taylor Swift performs at the iHeartRadio Wango Tango concert in Carson, California, U.S., June 1, 2019. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni//File Photo

site_title: Tesla strike spreads to Denmark, halting shipments to Sweden
summary: Tesla's labor dispute with Swedish unions is expanding to Denmark, where the 3F union will halt shipments of cars to Sweden in support of striking workers. The Danish union has filed a strike warning notice, but operations in Denmark will remain unaffected. The dispute began in Sweden over a month ago, with Tesla refusing to sign a collective bargaining agreement. The chairman of the 3F union stated that Tesla must comply with labor market agreements in the Nordic region to do business there. A similar blockade in Norway is also being considered.

images.alt_text: The logo of a Tesla electric vehicle is placed on a car outside a dealership in Drogenbos, Belgium November 25, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman

site_title: Asean+3 elevated debt levels reach 300% of region’s GDP at end-2022: report
summary: The Asean+3 region's non-financial debt reached 300% of its GDP at the end of 2022, a significant increase from 230% over the past 15 years. According to Amro, the region is expected to grow by 4.3% this year and 4.5% in 2024. High debt levels pose risks, including inflation and fiscal crises, particularly in emerging markets. To mitigate these risks, authorities should strengthen their defences through a balanced policy mix and close cooperation across jurisdictions. The region's corporate debt-to-GDP ratio stands at 140%, while household debt is lower but has increased significantly in some economies.

images.alt_text: The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro) maintains its 2024 growth forecast for the region at 4.5 per cent.

site_title: The bigger airlines get, the worse they become
summary: JetBlue's potential acquisition of Spirit Airlines would make it the fifth-largest airline in the US, further reducing competition in the industry. The bigger airlines have historically become less competitive, with higher prices, smaller seats, and poorer service. This trend is evident in the mergers of the past 15 years, which have led to the dominance of the "big three" airlines (United, Delta, and American) and the elimination of smaller carriers. The merger would also increase the influence of these major airlines, potentially leading to further consolidation and reduced consumer choice.

images.alt_text: Spirit’s holdings, which JetBlue intends to sell to Frontier Group Holdings, includes six gates at the Marine Air Terminal and 22 takeoff and landing slots.
American is the largest US airline by fleet size and low-cost carrier JetBlue is the sixth-largest.
JetBlue will pay US$33.50 per share for Spirit, or as much as US$34.15 depending on timing.

site_title: SoftBank buys majority stake in Irish car software developer for US$513 million
summary: SoftBank has agreed to purchase a majority stake in Irish software developer Cubic Telecom for approximately US$513 million. The deal will allow SoftBank to enter the connected car and software-defined vehicle market, targeting the growing demand for internet-connected vehicles. Cubic Telecom provides a platform for automakers to update software functions in cars globally and in real time, with agreements in place with over 90 mobile networks and connections to more than 17 million cars in 190 countries.

images.alt_text: Carro has already been audited to the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board level, which makes it ready for an IPO in the US.

site_title: China’s November services activity accelerates on boost from new orders: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity accelerated in November, with the Caixin PMI rising to a three-month high of 51.5, driven by an uptick in new orders and firmer market conditions. The sector's growth, however, remains softer than the long-run series average. The mixed picture contrasts with an official survey showing the sector contracted for the first time since December last year, prompting calls for stimulus measures. Analysts attribute the discrepancy to differences in survey sizes and company compositions.

images.alt_text: People dine at a hotpot restaurant in Beijing, China April 8, 2022. Picture taken April 8, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/Files

site_title: Nikkei posts sharpest drop in about 6 weeks as chip shares slide
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 1.37% to 32,775.82, its largest single-day drop in six weeks, due to a heavy sell-off in chip-related stocks amid rising US Treasury yields. Top losers included Advantest, Tokyo Electron, and Screen Holdings, with most chip stocks declining by 5% or more. US stocks also fell on Monday, with megacaps dipping over 1% due to higher yields.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: HDB launches more than 6,000 BTO flats in December exercise; analysts expect demand to dip
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 6,057 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in December 2023, across eight projects in mature and non-mature estates. The median waiting time for BTO projects launched in 2023 is three years and 10 months, a return to pre-pandemic norms. Demand is expected to dip slightly due to non-selection rules and the holiday season, with four projects offering waiting times of four years or less. The next BTO exercise will take place in February 2024, offering about 4,100 flats.

The community care apartments in Bedok is part of the Chai Chee Green BTO development which will comprise a total of 1,234 units.

site_title: Knowledge, tech more consequential than funding for developing countries in climate action: SM Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean of Singapore emphasized that knowledge and technology sharing with developing countries are more crucial than funding for addressing climate impacts. He stated that Singapore's experience as a developing country shows that sharing technical and systems skills has made the most difference, not just funding. Teo also expressed support for the operationalization of the loss and damage fund, which channels money from developed countries to developing countries affected by climate disasters. He also acknowledged the need for energy, citing Singapore's reliance on natural gas, but emphasized the importance of transitioning to clean energy sources.

images.alt_text: The World Bank will play a more limited role, managing the day-to-day operations of the new climate change fund, president Ajay Banga explains.
The plan for starting up the loss and damage fund is one of three main negotiated outcomes COP28 is working to deliver over the next two weeks.

COP28 will also conclude the first-ever global stocktake - a two-year endeavour to assess the progress governments have made in cutting emissions, and make recommendations on what more needs to be done.

site_title: UK public inflation expectations rise in October: Citi/YouGov
summary: The UK public's inflation expectations for 5-10 years rose to 3.5% in October, a five-month high, from 3.3% in September, according to a Citi/YouGov survey. This increase reflects higher petrol prices and may prompt the Bank of England to remain cautious about price risks. Public inflation expectations for 12 months remained stable at 4.2%. Citi trimmed its growth forecast for Britain due to expected tax cuts, which may delay interest rate cuts by the Bank of England.

images.alt_text: Britain’s economy is still suffering from weak growth.

Dave Ramsden, deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The Bank of England hiked interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis and warned the economy is on course to shrink under pressure from double-digit inflation. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
The Confederation of British Industry’s (CBI) monthly retail sales balance, a gauge of sales over the year to November, picked up to -11 from a very weak -36 in October.
Despite lingering cost-of-living pressures, GfK’s headline consumer confidence index was stronger than anticipated in November, increasing to -24 from October’s three-month low of -30.

site_title: Geopolitics and markets in 2024: Brace for the unpredictable
summary: Geopolitical tensions are expected to play a significant role in 2024, with growing fault lines between the Global South and the West, and nearly half of the world's top 20 largest economies set to experience leadership elections. Investors should prepare for geopolitical-induced volatility, diversifying portfolios and hedging against risks through assets like oil and gold. The US presidential election, Taiwanese presidential election, and cross-strait relations will be closely watched, with potential implications for the global economy and asset prices. Supply-chain diversification is expected to accelerate, driven by globalization and shifting manufacturing activities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company) logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

The conflict escalation can spur higher demand for energy security and crude flows.

site_title: Evergrande creditors regroup as liquidation advocate hesitates
summary: Evergrande creditors have regrouped as a liquidation advocate has hesitated, buying the company more time to hammer out debt restructuring terms. Top Shine Global Limited, one of Evergrande's creditors, unexpectedly dropped its bid to liquidate the company, and an ad hoc group of creditors will likely step in as the petitioner if Top Shine were to walk away. The adjournment has given Evergrande more time to narrow its differences with creditors, who are demanding controlling stakes in the equity of the company and its subsidiaries as part of the debt discussions.

images.alt_text: Evergrande now has eight weeks to agree a deal with offshore bondholders for what would be one of the nation’s biggest restructurings.

site_title: Taxing problems and suboptimal outcomes
summary: Singapore homeowners living in private properties or holding them for investment will face higher property tax rates and elevated property values starting next year. The government's progressive wealth tax, implemented in two stages, will significantly increase property tax payments for investors, raising holding costs and reducing returns. A one-off rebate will be given to homeowners, but those owning properties for rental will receive no rebate. This move is expected to have a substantial impact on the market, with some experts warning of suboptimal outcomes from intergenerational wealth transfer practices.

images.alt_text: One largely unseen component of developers’ costs is the land betterment charge paid to the government in return for enhanced land use in building up a site, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
The residential rental market is cooling its heels after racing up in 2021 and 2022, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Hyperlocal factors helped push sales of the 368-unit J’den project in Jurong, writes deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Lee Yeow Seng, group chief executive of  IOI Properties, has extensive interest in downtown Singapore, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

With higher borrowing costs, widespread inflation, and economic uncertainty, analysts expect buyers to be cautious and new private home sales for 2023 to be below that of 2022, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields drop after ECB’s Schnabel says further rate hikes unlikely
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) official Isabel Schnabel said further interest rate hikes are "rather unlikely" due to a slowdown in inflation, prompting a drop in eurozone bond yields. Germany's 10-year bond yield fell to 2.279%, its lowest since June, while Italy's 10-year bond yield fell to 4.053%. Investors now expect an interest rate cut in April, and ECB policymakers are expected to keep rates on hold when they meet on Dec 13-14. Schnabel cautioned that inflation developments have been encouraging, but prices may still rise due to geopolitical tensions and fiscal measures.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 slipped 0.1 per cent, after touching a fresh four-month high in early trade and posting its third straight weekly gain on Friday.

Eurozone inflation tumbled to 2.4 per cent last month, coming well below expectations for the third straight month, fuelling market bets that ECB interest rates will come down much quicker than the bank now guides.
The ECB raised its deposit rate to a record high 4 per cent via ten straight moves ending in September.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks suffer third successive loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced their third consecutive day of losses, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.91% to 16,327.86. The decline is attributed to cooling investor enthusiasm over expected Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. Other Chinese indices, including the Shanghai Composite and Shenzhen Composite, also fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 1.67% and the Shenzhen Composite Index shedding 1.95%. The losses follow a November rally, indicating a shift in market sentiment.

site_title: Foxconn raises Q4 outlook on strong year-end holiday sales
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, raised its Q4 outlook on strong year-end holiday sales. Revenue in the first two months of the fourth quarter was higher than expected, driven by strong sales in the tech industry's traditional peak season. Foxconn's revenue last month reached NT$650 billion, up 18% year-on-year, and its smart consumer electronics products saw strong growth. The company, a major Apple supplier, does not provide exact numerical guidance for Q4.

images.alt_text: Foxconn, which employs about 35,000 people at its Tamil Nadu iPhone factory, has yet to decide whether to resume production on Tuesday,

site_title: ByteDance strikes deal with GoTo to save Indonesian TikTok shop
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, has struck a deal with Indonesia's GoTo Group to invest in its unit, Tokopedia, and cooperate on an online shopping service. The agreement aims to revive TikTok's online shopping service in Indonesia, which was halted due to government regulations. The partnership is seen as a model for TikTok's expansion in other markets, including Malaysia, where the government has expressed willingness to review its influence. The deal is subject to regulatory approval and may change before its formalization.

site_title: Moody’s cuts China credit outlook to negative, cites lower growth, property risks
summary: Moody's cut its outlook on China's government credit ratings to negative, citing lower growth, property risks, and structurally lower medium-term economic growth. The downgrade reflects growing concerns over surging local government debt and a deepening property crisis. China's annual economic growth is expected to slow to an average 3.8% from 2026 to 2030, and the cost of insuring China's sovereign debt against a default rose to its highest since mid-November. Analysts believe the downgrade is a sign of mounting global concern over China's economic prospects.

images.alt_text: Analysts say the different survey sizes and composition of surveyed companies might explain the discrepancy between the Caixin and official PMI readings.

site_title: Asian power generation gets cleaner, even as coal emissions rise
summary: Asia has accelerated the shift away from fossil fuels, reducing its share of power generation from fossil fuels by 8 percentage points to 68% in 2022, outpacing Europe and North America. Despite this, Asian countries like China and India continue to build new coal-fired power plants to meet growing demand. Asia's clean power output increased by 8 percentage points to 32% between 2015 and 2022, while Europe and North America saw similar increases. The region's reliance on gas is increasing, but at a slower pace, as countries seek to transition away from coal.

site_title: Panel formed by Quarz seeks authorities’ guidance on Sabana internalisation
summary: A committee formed by activist investor Quarz and other unitholders of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has sent an open letter to regulatory authorities seeking guidance on the internalisation of the Reit's manager. The committee questions the trustee's interpretation of the trust deed and whether the sponsor and its concert parties should be barred from voting on a resolution to amend the trust deed due to their potential conflict of interest. Unitholders voted in favour of internalisation on August 7, but the trustee and regulatory authorities have raised concerns over the process's risks and uncertainties.

site_title: Blackstone buys Kyoto Hotel from Goldman in deal worth 8 billion yen
summary: Blackstone acquired the 158-room Moxy Kyoto Nijo hotel from Goldman Sachs Group in a deal worth 8 billion yen (S$72.8 million). The hotel, located near Kyoto's historic Nijo Castle, opened in July 2021. The transaction reflects Japan's rapid tourism rebound, boosting hospitality deals in the country. This is part of Blackstone's expansion in Japan's hotel market, with the company acquiring at least 12 hotels for its portfolio in the past two years.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest alternative asset manager has been active in India, where it recently acquired a stake in two hospital chains.

site_title: France in one-year ‘battle’ to reopen Notre-Dame
summary: France is racing against time to complete the restoration of Notre-Dame cathedral within a year, with workers aiming to reopen the monument on December 8, 2024, for the Paris Olympics. Despite several setbacks, including a delayed decontamination process and high winds, the new spire is nearing completion and expected to be fully finished by the summer. The restoration, which has been entirely funded by $848 million in donations, is being overseen by civil servant Philippe Jost, who is confident in meeting the deadline.
