site_title: How and why China Evergrande crashed
summary: China Evergrande Group, a real estate giant, crashed due to questionable accounting and poor corporate oversight. The company's decline began when it failed to pay US$2 billion, prompting an internal investigation that revealed top executives had engineered a plan to circumvent borrowing restrictions. The company's longtime auditor resigned, and a new audit revealed a combined loss of US$81 billion over two years. Evergrande's founder, Hui Ka Yan, had paid himself over US$7 billion in dividends, and his arrest further destabilized the company. The company remains in default, with its stock trading for pennies a share.

images.alt_text: Evergrande now has eight weeks to agree a deal with offshore bondholders for what would be one of the nation’s biggest restructurings.

site_title: Coffee lovers to endure more pain as Vietnam’s crop set to fall
summary: Vietnam's coffee crop is expected to fall to 1.6-1.7 million tonnes, down from 1.78 million tonnes last year, due to a smaller crop and growing local demand. This could lead to increased prices, with local prices up more than 40% from last year. The country's coffee acreage is shrinking, and yields are dropping, with farmers cutting down coffee trees for more profitable crops. Vietnam's exports may fall 15% in the 2023-24 season, and local consumption of beans may surge to 350,000-400,000 tonnes once instant coffee plants reach full capacity.

site_title: Sats says it remains on track to restoring profitability
summary: SATS remains on track to restore profitability despite filing a notice of three consecutive years of losses. The company cites global travel recovery, new contract wins, operational efficiencies, and synergies from its integration with Worldwide Flight Services as key factors. It also secured a S$3 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme to access global debt markets and reduce borrowing costs. The company's market capitalization remains above the SGX listing rules' threshold, and it continues to generate positive net operating cash flow.

images.alt_text: Sats says that it also has existing uncommitted banking facilities of about S$500 million obtained from various lenders in the past.
Sats said that cashflow would be optimised for 3Rs: repayment of debt, reinvestment (capital expenditure) and resumption of dividend.

site_title: Australia trade drags on Q3 growth, government spending a boost
summary: Australia's economy grew less than expected in the third quarter due to a decline in commodity exports, resulting in a trade deficit of A$158 million. However, strong government spending helped offset the drag, with a 1% rise in spending adding to GDP. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold interest rates steady, awaiting more data on inflation and employment. New vehicle sales surged in November, indicating resilience in domestic demand.

images.alt_text: Job ads fell 4.6 per cent in November from October, the biggest drop since August 2021. according to data from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and employment website Indeed.

site_title: The King’s royal blue tie speaks volumes to Greeks
summary: King Charles III wore a royal blue tie to the COP28 climate conference in Dubai, sparking speculation that he favored repatriation of 2,600-year-old sculptures from the Parthenon in Athens to Greece. The tie's color and pattern, similar to the Greek flag, was seen as a signal to UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who had previously skipped a meeting with Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis over the issue. The move is seen as a subtle expression of the king's personal feelings on the matter, which remains a contentious issue due to British law preventing the return of national heritage items.

images.alt_text: Greece has been fighting to repatriate looted artefacts from museums and private collections around the world.
Greece recovers Picasso stolen in 2012

site_title: Billionaires Island draws super rich to secluded Dubai enclave
summary: Dubai's Billionaires Island, a secluded enclave on Jumeirah Bay Island, has gained popularity among the super rich, with its relaxed vibe and proximity to Dubai's financial center and international airport. Luxury residential property developer Palace Luxury Living, in collaboration with Lebanese developer Wissam Damaa, is launching a collection of 10 mega-mansions valued at over $545 million. The island is already home to several high-profile billionaires, including Saudi's Mohammed Abdul Latif Jameel and Israeli tycoon Teddy Sagi. Despite concerns about a potential slowdown in Dubai's property market, luxury buyers are expected to continue to drive sales, with some brokers suggesting the market may be less affected by economic downturns.

images.alt_text: This image shows high-rise buildings in Dubai, on February 18, 2023. - Home to towering skyscrapers and ultra-luxury villas, Dubai saw record real estate transactions in 2022, largely due to an influx of wealthy investors, especially from Russia. (Photo by Karim SAHIB / AFP)
The joint venture between Dubai Holding and Aldar Properties, Abu Dhabi’s biggest developer, sold out two phases in the “Haven” project on launch day.
The average rental rate climbed 20.6 per cent in the year through September, slightly lower than the 21.7 per cent growth registered a month earlier.

site_title: Bitcoin surges past US$42,000 even as stocks and bonds take a hit
summary: Bitcoin surged past $42,000 for the first time in 19 months, driven by speculation surrounding the approval of US spot Bitcoin ETFs by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The crypto industry awaits the outcome of applications from companies like BlackRock, with Bloomberg Intelligence predicting approval by January. Despite a weak day in traditional markets, Bitcoin's revival has weathered a US crackdown and potential ETFs signal a maturing industry. However, lingering risks include a reset in interest-rate bets and technical indicators suggesting the rally is stretched, with some predicting a potential correction.

images.alt_text: The world’s biggest cryptocurrency hit US$41,522 on Monday (Dec 4), its highest since April 2022 and has seemed to cast off the funk that had settled over crypto markets since the collapse of FTX and other crypto-business failures in 2022.

site_title: RBA holds key rate to assess economy, sending currency lower
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35% in its final meeting of the year, citing a broader downtrend in inflation and a softening labour market. Economists expect the RBA to be done with tightening, with some predicting another hike early in 2024. The decision sent the Australian dollar lower and trimmed bets on future rate hikes. The RBA aims to bring the economy to a soft landing, with data suggesting the economy maintained momentum and inflation slowed in October.

images.alt_text: Markets are pricing in a tiny chance of another rise now, but a 40 per cent probability of a move by March.
Job ads fell 4.6 per cent in November from October, the biggest drop since August 2021. according to data from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and employment website Indeed.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 0.1% in October, undoing September gains
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 0.1% year-over-year in October, reversing a 0.8% growth in September. This comes despite a 13.1% contribution from online sales, with the recreational goods industry experiencing an 8.1% year-on-year contraction. Food and alcohol sales, however, surged 22% year-over-year. Economists attribute the decline to lower demand for sporting goods and higher prices, but expect year-end festive demand and a potential rebound in retail sales. Full-year retail sales growth is forecasted at 3% by UOB, with Maybank predicting single-digit growth in 2024.

images.alt_text: On a month-on-month, seasonally adjusted basis, petrol service stations have recorded the largest increase, with a 4.7% rise.

site_title: Global central banks to study ways to scale up adaptation finance
summary: Central banks are forming a taskforce to study ways to scale up adaptation finance, a critical area for emerging markets and developing economies vulnerable to climate change. The Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) aims to address the lack of private sector financing, which is hindered by unclear metrics for impact and financial return. The current adaptation finance gap is estimated at US$194-366 billion per year, and the taskforce will explore how central banks and supervisors can contribute to scaling up blended finance and improving climate policies and regulatory clarity.

images.alt_text: The report gleaned insights from 24 philanthropies, which granted more than US$3.7 billion last year, including at least US$1.9 billion to climate and nature globally and US$580 million to climate and nature in Asia.

COP28 will also conclude the first-ever global stocktake - a two-year endeavour to assess the progress governments have made in cutting emissions, and make recommendations on what more needs to be done.
World Bank says it will spend US$40 billion on climate-related projects, US$9 billion more than was previously programmed.
The plan for starting up the loss and damage fund is one of three main negotiated outcomes COP28 is working to deliver over the next two weeks.
Growth will ease to 2.7 per cent in 2024 after an already “sub-par” expansion of 3 per cent in 2023, according to the latest OECD forecasts.

site_title: Nvidia plans network of chip plants in Japan to meet AI demand
summary: Nvidia plans to establish a network of chip plants in Japan to meet the growing demand for AI-powered graphics chips. The partnership with Japanese companies will utilize the country's technical expertise and industrial capabilities to foster AI startups. Nvidia's graphics chips are in high demand, with prices surging due to the increasing need for AI development. Japan's government has offered billions of dollars in support for domestic semiconductor production, including investment in local startup Rapidus. The move aims to entice investment in cutting-edge semiconductor production critical to future technologies.

site_title: Consumer is king
summary: Startup businesses in South-east Asia have weakened in their attractiveness to investors, with venture funding for consumer-focused startups falling in the last two years. Despite this, some investors remain bullish on the potential of consumer-focused startups, particularly those offering social value. A US$114 million fourth fund from DSG Consumer Partners is being deployed to support such brands. The demise of a 27-year-old brand, Spinelli, in Singapore highlights the challenges faced by consumer businesses in the region.

images.alt_text: Flash Coffee's Taiwan bankruptcy mirrors the Singapore one, with Flash Coffee’s holding company being the largest creditor, and staff salaries left unpaid, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
Some sectors and regions remain bright spots for investments, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.
The drop in private funding has had an unequal impact across countries, with Indonesia bearing the brunt of the fall, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.

It will be interesting to watch how Kopi Kenangan balances rapid global expansion via a franchise model with maintaining standards and customer stickiness, writes Garage correspondent Sharanya Pillai.
Speculation ran rife in the startup world following the abrupt departure of Grab's CEO Jakob Angele, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as traders temper rate cut bets
summary: Asia markets fell on Tuesday, extending the sell-off seen on Wall Street, after traders scaled back bets on interest rate cuts. Despite a dovish turn by the Federal Reserve, analysts warned that November's rally may have gone too far, leading to near-term volatility in both rates and equities. Key indexes in New York ended in the red, with the S&P 500 coming off a nine-percentage-point November rally, and Asian markets such as Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Sydney also shed more than one percent each.

images.alt_text: Stock markets were mixed on Monday mid day, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Wellington and Taipei in the red, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Manila and Jakarta rose.

site_title: DPM Lawrence Wong on four-day official visit to Beijing, Tianjin
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong arrived in Beijing for a four-day official visit to China, marking the first time the Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation (JCBC) will be co-chaired by Singapore and China in China since the Covid-19 pandemic. Wong will meet with Chinese leaders, including Premier Li Qiang and Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang, and co-chair JCBC and government-to-government projects. His visit comes after Singapore and China upgraded their bilateral relationship in March, and marks a significant milestone in their "all-round, high-quality, future-oriented partnership".

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) said he was happy to see Chinese Premier Li Qiang again, "in a different capacity".

Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling (left) in conversation with CEO Singapore Business Federation Kok Ping Soon. Low shared insights on how Singapore and China can forge stronger economic ties in areas of sustainability, digital economy and e-commerce. PHOTO: SINGAPORE BUSINESS FEDERATION

site_title: Singtel develops sustainable data centres to support AI adoption
summary: Singtel is developing a new generation of sustainable data centers (DCs) with high power density and AI capabilities. The fourth-generation DCs will incorporate efficient cooling solutions, liquid cooling capabilities, and lower carbon embedded materials. The DC Tuas, set to be one of the most efficient in the industry, will have a power usage effectiveness (PUE) ratio of around 1.23 at full load. Singtel aims to transition its data centers to green and renewable energy sources and is also developing projects in Thailand and Indonesia to increase its pipeline capacity beyond 200 MW.

images.alt_text: Singtel's first green loan requires that its two data centres, DC West and DC Kim Chuan, must obtain at least a Green Mark GoldPlus certification from Singapore’s Building and Construction Authority.
Optus's crisis planning did not anticipate and cover worst-case scenarios such as an outage of the scale it had on Nov 8.
SGX Group CEO Loh Boon Chye speaks at an event in Bangkok to celebrate the progress of the Thailand-Singpaore Depository Receipt linkage scheme
The telco said H1 net profit saw a boost from an exceptional gain as a result of regional associate Telkomsel’s integration of IndiHome.
This investment puts the enterprise value of Singtel’s overall RDC business at S$5.5 billion.

site_title: Gold climbs as US dollar, bond yields slip
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $2,037.29 per ounce, driven by a decline in the US dollar and Treasury yields. The US dollar index fell 0.1% and 10-year Treasury yields slipped to 4.2587%. Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-interest-bearing bullion, but traders have lowered rate cut bets to about 60% by March. Gold prices surged earlier this week after Fed chair Jerome Powell's comments on rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Gold struck US$2,135.39 in early Asian trade, topping the previous all-time high set in 2020, during the pandemic.

site_title: China issues safety guidelines for autonomous public transport vehicles
summary: China has issued safety guidelines for autonomous public transport vehicles, covering vehicles of various degrees of automation and mandating at least one driver or security inspector. The guidelines apply to taxis and freight transportation, requiring companies to be qualified and licensed. China aims to formulate a system supporting assisted and autonomous driving functions by 2025 and establish a safety assurance system by 2030, following previous guidelines on intelligent connected vehicles and highway engineering facilities.

site_title: As Ozempic cases mount, consumer lawyers push to consolidate lawsuits
summary: Consumer lawyers are pushing to consolidate lawsuits against pharmaceutical companies Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly over the side effects of weight loss drugs Ozempic and Wegovy. About 20 lawsuits have been filed since August, claiming the companies downplayed or failed to warn consumers about risks such as stomach paralysis and intestinal obstruction. Attorneys are seeking to centralize the litigation in a Louisiana federal court, arguing it would streamline the discovery process and prevent conflicting rulings. The companies have refuted the claims, arguing the side effects are well-known and printed on their labels.

images.alt_text: Kim Gradwell, who has type 2 diabetes, begins the Ozempic injection at her home in Dudley, North Tyneside, Britain, Oct 31, 2023.
Astra is testing a separate experimental compound that’s a long-acting analogue to a hormone called amylin.

site_title: Inflation has depleted pandemic-era savings for many Americans
summary: US inflation has depleted pandemic-era savings for many Americans, eroding consumer spending power. According to Santander US Capital Markets, 40% of Americans have lost their pandemic savings due to inflation. Despite nominal gains in bank deposits and money market balances, inflation has reduced liquid assets by 1% for the bottom 40% of Americans. Economists, including chief US economist Stephen Stanley, attribute the loss to inflation, which has outpaced real disposable income gains. This has led to poor consumer confidence, with spending expected to rise only 1% in 2024 due to inflation and higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: Factory orders fall 3.6 per cent after a downwardly revised 2.3 per cent in September.
“It would be premature to conclude with confidence that we have achieved a sufficiently restrictive stance, or to speculate on when policy might ease,” says Fed char Jerome Powell.
Investment in residential construction shot up 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Wavemaker Impact raises US$60 million for its maiden fund
summary: Wavemaker Impact, a climate-tech venture builder, has raised US$60 million for its maiden fund, exceeding its initial target of US$25 million. The fund will focus on startups supporting decarbonisation efforts in South-east Asia through technology that tackles climate change issues. Limited partners include international development finance institutions and impact investors, and the additional capital will be used to expand the portfolio and make follow-on investments. By 2035, Wavemaker Impact aims to lower the global carbon budget by 10%.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow
Wavemaker Impact founding team comprises (from left to right) Quentin Vaquette, Doug Parker, Marie Cheong, Paul Santos and Steve Melhuish.
L-R: Wavemaker Impact founding members Quentin Vaquette, Doug Parker, Marie Cheong, Paul Santos and Steve Melhuish.
Wavemaker Partners launches climate-tech venture builder, with US$25m target for fund

site_title: UK retailers see weak sales growth in November despite Black Friday deals
summary: UK retailers saw weak sales growth in November, with a 2.7% annual increase in spending, below the 4.2% rise a year ago. The ongoing cost-of-living squeeze prompted shoppers to cut back on non-essential spending, with sales growth driven by budget-friendly items like food and drink, and personal care. The weak sales may lead to retailer collapses, especially online retailers, and consumer spending may not recover until after the holiday period.

images.alt_text: The ONS household cost index shows the average mortgage borrower having a 9.3 per cent personal rate of inflation, far above the headline 6.7 per cent consumer prices index for September.
The final reading of the S&P Global/CIPS manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) improves for a third month in a row to 47.2 in November from 44.8 in October.

Dave Ramsden, deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The Bank of England hiked interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis and warned the economy is on course to shrink under pressure from double-digit inflation. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Inflation in Japan’s capital slows in November
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation in Tokyo slowed to 2.3% in November, down from 2.7% in October, indicating easing cost-push pressure. This data, released before the Bank of Japan's policy meeting on Dec 19, aligns with the BOJ's view that rising wages and service costs will replace cost-push inflation, helping Japan meet its 2% inflation target. Despite this, the BOJ remains a dovish outlier, maintaining ultra-loose policy as major central banks raise interest rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan's Toyoaki Nakamura said Japan’s continued economic recovery, tight labour market and an increasing number of workers switching jobs are heightening the chance that wage growth will eventually exceed the pace of inflation.
Japan's industrial production rose 1.0 per cent in October from the previous month, data from the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry showed.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit’s portfolio valuation falls 9.5% to £412.5 million; gearing climbs to 49.6%
summary: Elite Commercial Reit's portfolio valuation declined 9.5% to £412.5 million as of Dec 1, 2023, with a gearing ratio of 49.6%. This represents a 15.7% drop in adjusted net asset value (NAV) per unit. Despite the decline, the Reit's manager remains positive on the portfolio's relevance and expects leases signed directly with the UK government to provide credit stability and income certainty. The Reit's gearing remains within the Monetary Authority of Singapore's 50% limit.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit is one of the top four performers during the period.
Newport Road, Cardiff, Wales is one of Elite Commercial Reit's properties.
Elite Commercial Reit's chief financial officer Joel Cheah has stepped down, with effect from Nov 6, 2023.

site_title: S$70 million Singapore AI initiative to develop first large language model with South-east Asian context
summary: Singapore has launched a S$70 million initiative to develop the first large language model with a South-east Asian context, aiming to bridge the gap in AI research between Western and regional models. The National Multimodel LLM Programme will be developed in partnership with AI Singapore and A*Star, and will contribute to Singapore's capabilities in AI research and innovation. The model will be built on the existing South-east Asian Languages in One Network (Sea-Lion) model, which was designed to represent regional cultural contexts and linguistic nuances.

images.alt_text: Recent breakthroughs in generative AI have sparked renewed interest about the potential of AI, its risks and its implications for humanity, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the Singapore Conference on AI, which runs from Dec 4 to 6.

Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo (centre) at a demonstration by small business owners on the use of chatbot Bard at the launch of the AI Trailblazers initiative on July 24, 2023.

site_title: Japan’s November service activity grows at slowest pace in a year: PMI
summary: Japan's service sector expanded at the slowest pace in a year in November, with the final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers' index slipping to 50.8 from 51.6 in October. The decline was attributed to accelerating new export decline and softer demand. However, the outlook for the sector remained upbeat, with new business rising and service providers' outlook for the next 12 months hitting a three-month high. The composite PMI, which combines manufacturing and service activity, dropped to 49.6, falling into contraction territory for the first time since December last year.

images.alt_text: The BOJ remains a dovish outlier among global peers, having maintained ultra-loose policy even as major central banks elsewhere raised interest rates aggressively to fight rampant inflation.

Bank of Japan's Toyoaki Nakamura said Japan’s continued economic recovery, tight labour market and an increasing number of workers switching jobs are heightening the chance that wage growth will eventually exceed the pace of inflation.
Japan's industrial production rose 1.0 per cent in October from the previous month, data from the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry showed.

site_title: VTAC to pay redemption price of S$5.01 on Dec 8
summary: Vertex Technology Acquisition Corp (VTAC) will pay S$5.01 per share to shareholders who exercised redemption rights, totaling about S$130.3 million. This comes after 62.5% of its issued share capital of 41.6 million shares were redeemed. The redemption price is derived from the aggregate amount in the escrow account, excluding promote shares held by Venezio and the sponsor Vertex Venture Holdings. The company's business combination with 17Live was passed with a 95.5% vote, and non-redeeming shareholders will receive special bonus shares and additional warrants.

images.alt_text: The Spac’s shareholders are due to meet at 2 pm on Friday to vote on the business combination with e-commerce streaming company 17Live.  If the proposed combination does not pass, the redemption requests will be cancelled.
VTAC, led by non-executive chairman Chua Kee Lock,  has endorsed the merger, citing 17Live’s strong management, the potential for scale, and its alignment with Vertex Holdings’ areas of expertise.
Flash Coffee's Taiwan bankruptcy mirrors the Singapore one, with Flash Coffee’s holding company being the largest creditor, and staff salaries left unpaid, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
Phillip Securities says VTAC shareholders should redeem their shares at the price range of S$5 to S$5.02 apiece.
Phillip Securities says VTAC shareholders should redeem their shares at the price range of S$5 to S$5.02 apiece.
The expected completion of the deal would be on Dec 8, where the Spac will trade under the new name 17LIVE Group, if the transaction is successful.

site_title: Singapore stocks mirror global retreat on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,080.87, with losers outnumbering gainers 64 to 55. The decline followed overnight losses on global markets, including a 0.1% drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS and OCBC gaining, while UOB lost 0.2%. The decline was attributed to weak commodity prices in Europe, which hurt miners and energy stocks.

site_title: Qatar’s wealth fund to sell nearly half its shares in Barclays
summary: Qatar's wealth fund, Qatar Holding, is selling nearly half of its shares in Barclays, a move expected to raise £510 million. The sale comes as the bank's executives prepare a strategic overhaul for early next year. The move, which represents about 2.4% of Barclays' outstanding shares, follows a series of sales by Qatar in the 2008 global financial crisis. The sale's timing has been described as "slightly odd" by analysts, amid Barclays' struggles to boost returns and its underperformance compared to peers.

images.alt_text: Executives are mulling trimming clients that don’t transact with Barclays enough to earn a good return, according to FT report.

(FILES) A couple kiss whilst sitting at a bus stop outside a branch of British bank Barclays, in central London, February 14, 2023. British bank Barclays on October 24, 2023 unveiled a 16-percent drop in net profit for the third quarter on souring loans and rising costs, and flagged more cutbacks ahead. Profit after tax slid to £1.3 billion ($1.73 billion) in the June-September period, down from £1.5 billion in the third quarter last year, Barclays said in a statement. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)
Barclays’ £1 billion cost saving target would represent about 7 per cent of the bank’s underlying annual operating expenses of £15 billion in 2022.

site_title: US slowest housing market in years is weighing on consumer spending
summary: The US housing market is experiencing its slowest pace in years, weighing on consumer spending. Home sales have plummeted, with existing home sales at their lowest level since 2001, and spending on furniture and related items fell nearly 12% from the previous year. The Federal Reserve's rate hikes have contributed to the slowdown, with mortgage rates reaching their highest level since 2000. This has led to a decrease in home purchases, with many homeowners unwilling to sell due to cheap mortgages from the pandemic. The effects are visible across the economy, with retailers feeling the pain, and some firms seeking bankruptcy protection.

images.alt_text: Worker pay did not keep up with inflation in 2021 and 2022, but workers enjoyed real disposable income gains of 4 per cent in the first three quarters of this year.
Factory orders fall 3.6 per cent after a downwardly revised 2.3 per cent in September.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sats, Centurion, Vertex Technology, Elite Commercial Reit, BRC Asia
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies reported updates on Tuesday (Dec 5), including Sats, which cited global travel recovery and new contract wins as factors to restore profitability. Centurion sold two assets in Malaysia for RM227 million, while Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation announced its redemption price for its proposed business combination. Elite Commercial Reit's portfolio value decreased, but its government-backed income stream remains resilient. BRC Asia saved S$25 per tonne by replacing a steel-supply contract. GP Industries received shareholder approval to alter its objects clause and adopt a new constitution.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index fell 0.2 per cent or 6.23 points to close at 3,084.08.

site_title: Starbucks suffers record 11-day rout as sales concerns build
summary: Starbucks shares hit a record 11-day losing streak, with a 1.6% decline on Monday, wiping out nearly $12 billion in market value. The company's sales concerns grew after data showed a "material slowing" in November, with analysts lowering estimates for the first-quarter US comparable sales. The slump follows strong comparable sales growth in the fiscal fourth quarter and a better-than-expected sales outlook for fiscal 2024. Analysts attribute the decline to "still-slow China data" and sales trends amid boycotts and labor strikes.

images.alt_text: The Egyptian McDonald's October and November sales fell by at least 70 per cent compared to the same months last year.
Starbucks plans to boost barista pay to more hours and higher wages.

site_title: Israel investigates possible trading knowledge ahead of October 7 Hamas attack
summary: Israeli authorities are investigating claims that some investors may have anticipated a Hamas attack on October 7 and profited from Israeli securities. Research by law professors found significant short-selling of shares leading up to the attacks, which triggered a war nearly two months old. The study suggests that traders may have used information about the planned attack to profit from Israeli securities, with profits estimated at 3.2 billion shekels (S$1.15 billion) for one bank. The investigation is ongoing, with the Israel Securities Authority confirming that the matter is under investigation.

images.alt_text: Both sides blame each other for breaking the truce.
Israel believes Hamas’ top leadership is hiding in southern Gaza.

Palestinians inspect the destruction following an Israeli strike in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Dec 1, 2023, as fighting resumed shortly after the expiration of a seven-day truce between Israel and Hamas militants.

site_title: South Korea inflation eases in relief to policymakers
summary: South Korea's inflation eased in November, marking the first decline in four months, with the consumer price index rising 3.3% year-over-year and 0.6% month-over-month. The mild slowdown is attributed to easing prices of fresh food and fuel. The Bank of Korea, South Korea's central bank, kept interest rates steady at 3.5% and signaled a possible need to keep rates higher to address persistent inflation risks. Economists expect the bank to start easing policy from the third quarter of next year as cooling inflation becomes difficult to justify.

images.alt_text: South Korea is the seventh country to select the C-390, after Brazil, Portugal, Hungary, the Netherlands, Austria and the Czech Republic, according to Embraer.
South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol does not need parliamentary approval to appoint a new finance minister, who will also be deputy prime minister.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat after November rally
summary: US stocks retreated on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 0.1% to 36,204.44, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes falling 0.5% and 0.8% respectively. The decline came after a strong November, driven by expectations of a potential interest rate pause. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to hold rates steady at its upcoming policy meeting, but a rise in US Treasury yields dampened equity purchases. Notable gains included Hawaiian Holdings, which surged 190% after an acquisition, and Uber Technologies, which rose 2.2% after being added to the S&P 500.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 156.12 points, or 0.43 per cent, at the open, to 36,089.38.

site_title: Hired: Job redesign has made logistics safe and fun (Ep 3)
summary: CWT Integrated's CEO Ricky Loo discusses how job redesign has transformed the logistics sector, making it "safe and fun". The company's experience with job redesign has been successful, with staff embracing the changes. Loo credits mentorship as a key factor in employee buy-in, and notes that job redesign has helped the industry continue to thrive despite the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Job Redesign Centre of Excellence was launched by Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng at the 2023 People Behind People Forum, IHRP’s annual signature event for the human resources industry.
(L-R) Ng Jia Min, Assistant Team Lead SEO, OOm Pte Ltd; Cheow Yu Yuan, CEO, OOm Pte Ltd
Employers must look at jobs and redesign them to get the maximum traction out of them, according to Mark Li from Randstad.
Leaders need to explain to the staff why you have to do this and get their buy-in right from the start, according to Xu Xue Ting of Star International.

site_title: Oil falls on doubts Opec+ will make further cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as traders expressed doubts about Opec+ plans to cut production, citing concerns over the voluntary nature of the cuts and uncertainty about demand. Brent crude futures dropped 1.08% to $78.03 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 1.39% to $73.04. Analysts attributed the decline to market skepticism about the impact of the production cuts and fears of an economic slowdown next year.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were down 0.6 per cent, or 49 cents, to US$78.39 a barrel by 0406 GMT on Monday, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were at US$73.65 a barrel, down 0.6 per cent, or 42 cents.

site_title: AT&T chooses Ericsson over Nokia for new US telecom network
summary: AT&T has chosen Ericsson to build its US telecom network using Open RAN technology, expected to cover 70% of its wireless traffic by 2026. The five-year contract is worth approximately $14 billion, with AT&T's spending on Open RAN equipment approaching $14 billion. Ericsson's deal marks a milestone for the technology, which aims to cut costs by using cloud-based software and gear from multiple suppliers. This win for Ericsson also solidifies its position as the largest supplier to AT&T, potentially taking over Nokia's share.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shoppers walk past an AT&T store at the King of Prussia Mall in King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, U.S. November 22, 2019. REUTERS/Mark Makela/File Photo

site_title: Singapore updates AI strategy with aim to contribute globally valuable breakthroughs
summary: Singapore has updated its national artificial intelligence (AI) strategy, dubbed National AI Strategy 2.0 (Nais 2.0), with the aim of becoming a world leader in AI and contributing to globally valuable breakthroughs. The new strategy involves 15 courses of action over the next three to five years, focusing on talent, capabilities, placemaking, industry, government, research, compute, data, trusted environment, and leader in thought and action. The strategy aims to scale up AI for compelling use cases in various sectors and bring benefits to Singapore and the world.

images.alt_text: Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo (centre) at a demonstration by small business owners on the use of chatbot Bard at the launch of the AI Trailblazers initiative on July 24, 2023.
“There’s absolutely no probability that you’re going to see this so-called AGI, where computers are more powerful than people, in the next 12 months," says Microsoft's president Brad Smith(L).

AI Verify was launched as a minimum viable product for international pilot last year. It has attracted interest from over 50 local and multinational companies including IBM, Dell and Hitachi, IMDA says.

site_title: In South-east Asia, more consumers seeking unique experiences rather than material items
summary: In South-east Asia, consumers are increasingly prioritizing unique experiences over material possessions, with spending on travel, dining, and entertainment rising by over 80% year-on-year, according to UOB's data. The bank is capitalizing on this trend by expanding its entertainment offerings, including exclusive concert tickets and a new 6,000-pax capacity venue in Bangkok. UOB aims to bring in two global entertainment partnerships annually, providing customers with greater access to concerts, festivals, and meet-and-greets.

images.alt_text: From left: Choo Wan Sim, head of UOB TMRW Digital (Singapore) and Jacquelyn Tan, head of group personal financial services showcasing the "scan to pay" feature on UOB TMRW App. UOB customers in Singapore can now use the function to make payments when they travel to Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia. UOB managing director Ian Wong delivers a keynote session on thriving internationally and intentionally at the inaugural Global Leadership Symposium on Oct 19, 2023.
UOB’s deputy chairman and chief executive officer Wee Ee Cheong delivers the opening keynote speech at the Asean Conference 2023.

68 per cent of respondents in Singapore expect to see a recession in the next six to 12 months, compared to 71 per cent in the region.

(From left) Mr Prashant Choudhary, Managing Director and Partner of Boston Consulting Group; Ms Jacquelyn Tan, Head, Group Personal Financial Services, UOB; Mr Tareq Muhmood, Group Country Manager of Visa; Mr He Ruiming, co-founder of The Woke Salaryman

site_title: Getting supply chain resilience right in S-E Asia
summary: South-east Asia has emerged as an attractive location for companies seeking to manage supply costs and mitigate risks. With global geopolitical upheaval accelerating pre-existing production shifts, multinational companies are redesigning their supply footprints, with 90% of global manufacturers planning to do so in the next five years. The region's favorable technology and labor costs, combined with the need for ESG-compliant supply bases, make it an attractive engine of economic growth.

images.alt_text: Maersk intends to scale up its warehousing and distribution in South-east Asia by up to 50 per cent, and expects to add nearly 480,000 square metres of capacity across Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines by 2026.
Given the intersection of trade flows here, Singapore is in a strong position to help drive and promote leading practices in supply chains.

Singapore’s robust legal and regulatory framework can offer businesses much-needed stability, while other countries may contribute through strong manufacturing bases, abundant labour or advanced technologies.

site_title: Corporate culture: The root of good and poor governance
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore managing director Ravi Menon considers introducing a new provision to its corporate governance code to promote good company culture. Corporate culture is seen as the root of good and poor governance, with a strong culture underpinned by ethics key to success, as seen in companies like Tata Group, Ayala Group, and Berkshire Hathaway. A poor culture, however, can lead to scandals and failures, with the UK Financial Reporting Council citing silo thinking, dominant leadership, and short-term focus as common issues. The board's role in setting the tone and ensuring a cascaded culture is crucial, and Singapore's fit-and-proper tests for directors and management are seen as lacking, raising concerns that the new provision could become another box to tick.

images.alt_text: In “The Techno-Optimist Manifesto”, Marc Andreessen outlines a vision of technologists as the authors of a future in which the “techno-capital machine” produces everything that is good in the world.

At the time of their downfall, Kenneth Lay of Enron, Sam Bankman-Fried of FTX and Elizabeth Holmes of Theranos – who was recently sentenced to 11 years in prison for fraud – were all celebrities in their own right.
The queasy 'Enron feeling' directors must never ignore

site_title: Warburg Pincus names new Asia private equity head amid regional reshuffle
summary: Warburg Pincus, a US private equity firm, has appointed Vishal Mahadevia as head of Asia private equity, replacing Frank Wei, amid a regional reshuffle. Mahadevia, a 17-year veteran, will also remain as co-head of financial services. The moves come as Warburg is nearing completion of raising its 3 billion yuan fund focused on the healthcare sector. The firm is also expanding its presence in key markets such as China, India, and Japan, with new leaders appointed for each region.

images.alt_text: Warburg Pincus, through its unit StorHub, bought Storage Plus for an undisclosed amount last month.
A Barclays Plc bank branch in London, UK, on Tuesday, July 25, 2023. Barclays are due to report first-half results on Thursday, July 27. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: ‘Greenhushing’ and ‘green bleaching’ blur sanctions targets: watchdog
summary: A global securities watchdog, Iosco, warns that the lack of a binding legal definition for greenwashing hinders regulators from tackling investment funds that exaggerate their sustainability credentials. Trillions of US dollars flow into funds claiming environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, but Iosco reports that greenwashing is compounded by "malpractices" such as greenhushing and green-bleaching. Most jurisdictions lack specific definitions, and regulators face data gaps and inconsistent labelling, threatening investor protection.

site_title: South Korea selects Embraer’s C-390 Millennium aircraft in first Asian order
summary: South Korea has selected Embraer's C-390 Millennium aircraft for its military, marking the first Asian order for the aircraft. The selection is the seventh for Embraer, following countries in Brazil, Portugal, Hungary, the Netherlands, Austria, and the Czech Republic. Embraer will supply an undisclosed number of aircraft to meet specific requirements for the Korean Air Force, with analysts estimating two to three planes. The value of the contract will be included in Embraer's order book for the fourth quarter of 2023, boosting the company's share price by nearly 2%.

images.alt_text: Brazilian aircraft manufacturer Embraer unveils its new E190-E2 in Sao Jose dos Campos, Brazil, February 25, 2016. REUTERS/Nacho Doce

site_title: Chevron, ExxonMobil opt out of funding COP28 methane-reduction fund
summary: Chevron and ExxonMobil have opted out of funding a global methane-reduction fund, which aims to cut methane intensity by 0.2% and halt routine flaring of natural gas by 2030. The fund, run by the World Bank, secured $255 million from six oil companies, including BP, Eni, Equinor, Occidental Petroleum, Shell, and TotalEnergies. Chevron and ExxonMobil's decision is seen as a setback for the initiative, which aims to reduce the potent greenhouse gas and mitigate climate change.

images.alt_text: MAS MD Ravi Menon, Temasek CEO Dilhan Pillai and GFanz founder Mark Carney speaking at the Singapore pavilion at COP28.

Singapore's Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security Teo Chee Hean and Paraguay president Santiago Pena met on the sidelines of the 28th UN Climate Conference in Dubai on Dec 2, 2023.
MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures
The survey of Iosco members to coincide with the COP28 UN climate summit in Dubai shows most jurisdictions do not specifically define greenwashing in legally binding provisions.
The funds will help the Philippines implement its commitments to climate action under the Paris Agreement, according to ADB.

site_title: US: Wall St retreats as traders await economic data for policy cues
summary: US stocks retreated on Monday as investors awaited economic data this week, which may impact the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut narrative. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 156.12 points, or 0.43%, to 36,089.38, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline follows recent record highs, with traders seeking policy cues from upcoming economic data.

site_title: Twilio to cut about 5% of total workforce
summary: Twilio, a cloud communications platform, plans to lay off approximately 5% of its workforce, or 295 employees, by the first quarter of 2024 to achieve profitable growth. The restructuring is expected to incur costs of $25-$35 million in the last three months of 2023. This move follows previous layoffs in the company, and Twilio has reaffirmed its guidance for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ending December 31, 2023.

site_title: Australian legal opinion on nature risks for directors may ripple to Singapore
summary: Australian legal opinion suggests directors who fail to identify and address nature-related risks may face legal consequences, including breaching their duty of care and diligence. This could have implications for Singapore directors, particularly given the growing scrutiny of forest and biodiversity conservation in South-east Asia. Companies are advised to make nature-based disclosures and engage with guidelines from the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures, as investor expectations and political action move towards addressing nature and biodiversity.

images.alt_text: investment, nature, growth

site_title: Nvidia insiders unload shares after 220% AI rally
summary: Nvidia executives and directors have sold approximately 370,000 shares worth around $180 million, marking the largest monthly disposal by US dollar value in at least six years. The sales come after the company's AI rally, which saw the stock triple in 2023. This is the first time insiders have sold shares since 2020, with no buying activity reported. The majority of the sales are based on pre-set 10b5-1 plans, and the sales are seen as a sign that insiders are locking in gains after the stellar run.

images.alt_text: “The semiconductor industry that Japan is now starting to grow and foster will be able to produce GPUs,” says Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang.
Nvidia's graphics cards (GPUs) are high-performance devices that enable powerful graphics rendering and processing for use in video editing, video gaming and other complex computing operations.

Despite the expanded China chip export curbs, analysts expect Nvidia‘s order books to be full until at least August next year, as demand for its AI chips, especially in the United States, continues to outstrip supply.

SandboxAQ will help expand the capabilities of CUDA, Nvidia’s software platform for developing artificial intelligence applications, to better simulate the quantum mechanics behind chemical, biological and material science.

site_title: Cordlife storage lapses warrant compensation, but class action may be difficult: lawyers
summary: Cordlife, a Singapore-based cord-blood bank, has been barred for six months from collecting, testing, and storing new samples due to storage issues affecting 2,150 clients. Seven storage tanks recorded temperatures above acceptable limits, causing damage to cord-blood units. While customers may have grounds for compensation, mounting a class action lawsuit could be difficult due to Singapore's lack of class action mechanism and representative action laws. Experts say a representative action, where a few claimants bring an action on behalf of a larger group, may be possible but can be complex and expensive.

images.alt_text: Cordlife Group said that it will continue to store affected cord blood units for clients, as they “may still be valuable in light of developments in the field of cell and gene therapy.”
The group, as one of the five private cord blood banks in Asia, has been barred from collecting, testing, processing and storing new cord-blood or tissue samples.
Shares of Cordlife had hit a three-year high to S$0.495 amid heavy trading on Jun 26 after the company said it was aware of a possible transaction for an offer for its shares.

site_title: Intel wins US appeal to overturn US$2.18 billion VLSI patent verdict
summary: The US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has overturned a $2.18 billion patent-infringement award won by VLSI Technology against Intel in a 2021 verdict. The court reversed the jury's decision that Intel infringed one VLSI patent and sent the case back to Texas for a new trial to determine damages for a second patent. This decision reverses one of the largest US patent law verdicts in history, and the outcome of the new trial will determine how much Intel owes for patent infringement.

images.alt_text: Vietnam is keen to position itself as an alternative to China and Taiwan, amid political risks and trade tensions with the United States.
AI-enabled PCs refer to machines that come with advanced chips capable of running large-language models and apps powered by the technology directly on the device, instead of the cloud.
PC sales and manufacturing contracts are increasing after a post-pandemic slump that pushed Intel’s margins to their lowest in a decade.

site_title: ChildAid 2023 raises over S$2 million for charities
summary: The 2023 ChildAid charity fundraiser, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, raised over S$2 million for two charities, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The event featured a musical mystery dinner theatre with 48 kid performers, including a four-course dinner and performances by talented young artists. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat was the guest of honour, praising the event's success and the positive impact on the lives of those in need.

images.alt_text:
(From left to right) Touch Community Services CEO James Tan; Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth & Ministry of Social and Family Development Eric Chua and Singapore Citi Country Officer and Banking Head Tibor Pandi launch Citi’s partnership with Touch Community Services as part of Project V, a national level corporate volunteerism pilot.




Credit : PHOTO: CITI

site_title: A new age of the worker will overturn conventional thinking
summary: A new era of labor is emerging, where wage gaps between white- and blue-collar workers are narrowing. Generative AI may reinforce this trend by providing a productivity boost for lower performers and adding value to tasks that only humans can do. The blue-collar bonanza is driven by factors such as high demand for labor, constrained supply due to demographic shifts, and changes in digitization. This shift challenges conventional thinking about inequality and suggests that governments can promote prosperity without stifling markets. The blue-collar bonanza has the potential to be a golden age for workers, but its longevity depends on factors such as recession and government policies.

images.alt_text: As societies age, labour is becoming scarcer and better rewarded, especially manual activity that is hard to replace with technology.

site_title: The AI revolution – a new era for emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets (EM) are poised to reap the benefits of the AI revolution, leveraging their agility to adapt and innovate. The availability of data and lower computing costs have made AI more accessible and affordable, allowing companies beyond "Big Tech" to adopt the technology. This has created opportunities for EM countries to leapfrog into the AI era, bypassing the need for expensive infrastructure. As AI adoption becomes widespread, EM countries can harness its transformative potential across diverse industries, with unique opportunities and challenges arising.

images.alt_text: AI’s economic benefits are tied to efficiency gains as it helps automate easier but time-consuming tasks, which gives employees more time to do more productive work.
Investing in an emerging markets ex-China index tracker offers a relatively larger exposure to markets like Taiwan, where companies such as TSMC stands to benefit from robust semiconductor demand.
Artificial intelligence, AI, organs, brains, bodies

site_title: US factory orders fall to 3½ year low in October
summary: US factory orders plummeted 3.6% in October, the lowest level since April 2020, due to weakening demand and high interest rates. This decline was more than expected and follows a downwardly revised 2.3% drop in September. Economists attribute the slowdown to the manufacturing sector, which accounts for 11.1% of the economy, feeling the strain of higher interest rates. The sector's decline adds to signs the US economy will slow in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Wanted: A Kissingerian foreign policy
summary: Former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, a key figure in shaping the post-Cold War international system, has passed away at 100. His diplomatic efforts, including the "opening to China" and secret talks that ended the Vietnam War, helped create a new international balance of power. Kissinger's pragmatic approach, focusing on securing power balances between great powers, remains relevant today in addressing global issues such as rising China, the Ukraine conflict, and the Middle East peace process. His legacy serves as a model for resolving international problems through practical solutions.

images.alt_text: Former United States Secretary of State Henry Kissinger died at his home in Connecticut at the age of 100.

Chinese President Xi Jinping and Henry Kissinger, former U.S. secretary of state, attend a meeting at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing, China July 20, 2023. China Daily via REUTERS  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT.

site_title: More US home buyers willing to purchase despite high rates: BOA study
summary: US home buyers are becoming more willing to purchase properties despite high interest rates, according to a Bank of America study. 62% of respondents said they would wait for borrowing costs to fall, down from 85% six months earlier. However, many are willing to take on higher-interest mortgages for a more affordable area or their dream home. The study suggests that Americans' pent-up demand for homes will increase sales, despite a 5.6% drop in new-home sales last month. Experts expect the US economy to continue cooling, potentially leading to lower interest rates.

images.alt_text: For homebuilding stocks, the bulk of the monthly advance was made during the first three sessions of November after the Federal Reserve announced it would hold its benchmark rate steady for a second meeting.

site_title: Central banks ‘not out of the woods’ in inflation battle: BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has eased its stance on inflation, stating that while recent data shows progress in bringing inflation under control, central banks are not out of the woods yet. Global economic data indicates multi-decade highs in inflation are in the rear-view mirror, with money markets pricing in over 100 basis points of rate cuts from the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank in 2024. BIS officials emphasize the need for central banks to be "flexible and nimble" in response to a slowing global economy.

images.alt_text: Despite the relentless rise in rates over the last 18 months, inflation in many top economies remains stubbornly high,

site_title: White House warns Congress nearly ‘out of time’ on Ukraine funds
summary: The US is warning Congress that it will run out of funds to assist Ukraine by the end of the year, with Director of the Office of Management and Budget Shalanda Young stating that "there is no magical pot of funding available to meet this moment." The White House is seeking $61 billion for Ukraine aid as part of a $105 billion package, with a failure to act potentially "kneecapping Ukraine on the battlefield" and increasing the likelihood of Russian military victories. The issue has become a flashpoint on Capitol Hill, with negotiations on a sweeping immigration agreement yet to yield results.

images.alt_text: Russia has periodically over the past two decades barred farm goods from the country lying between Ukraine and Romania.
People fleeing from Ukraine at a border crossing in Hungary in February 2022. As at Nov 14, there are 6.3 million recorded Ukrainian refugees globally.

site_title: Foxconn, Pegatron halt Indian iPhone production due to extreme weather: sources
summary: Taiwanese electronics manufacturers Foxconn and Pegatron have halted production of Apple iPhones at their factories in southern India due to heavy rains and Cyclone Michaung. The factories, which employ about 35,000 people, have yet to decide whether to resume production on Tuesday. This is the second time Pegatron has halted production in recent months, following a factory fire in September. Heavy rains have caused floodwater to sweep away cars and shut the airport in Chennai, a major electronics hub. Apple's iPhone production in India has been expanding rapidly, with over 2.5 million units shipped in the quarter ending September.

images.alt_text: Apple has been touting India as its next big growth driver as it looks to move some production away from China.

epa10933931 The logo of Foxconn is pictured on a building in Taipei, Taiwan, 23 October 2023. According to state media, Foxconn, a Taiwan-based Apple iPhone manufacturer, has reportedly been subject to a Chinese inquiry regarding tax audits and land use investigations.  EPA-EFE/RITCHIE B. TONGO
The number of Apple smartphones sold declined 4 per cent year on year during the two-week sales from Oct 30 to Nov 12.
Apple’s software – famous for its clean interfaces, easy-to-use controls and focus on privacy – is one of its biggest selling points.

site_title: GP Industries gets shareholder approval to undertake any business, activity and transaction
summary: GP Industries secured shareholder approval to alter its objects clause and adopt a new constitution, granting the company full capacity to undertake any business, activity, and transaction. The company also received approval to distribute 483.8 million shares of GP Energy Tech to shareholders on a pro rata basis. This move aims to adapt to the rapidly changing business environment while ensuring compliance with the Companies Act and listing rules.

images.alt_text: GP Industries’ sales of primary batteries and rechargeable batteries have both declined.

site_title: Cautious response expected for Zion Road, Upper Thomson GLS sites
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two government land sales (GLS) sites, including a plot on Zion Road that could fetch up to S$1.66 billion for a 1,170-unit residential project. Another site on Upper Thomson Road will yield 640 units, with analysts expecting a cautious response from developers due to the new long-stay serviced apartment concept and significant risks. Bids for both sites are expected to close in April and June 2024, respectively. The new serviced apartment model requires a minimum stay of three months, reducing operating costs.

images.alt_text: An estimated 680 residential units can be built at the Holland Drive site.
The location plan for the land parcel at Plantation Close in Tengah.

site_title: US dollar claws back some ground; Bitcoin breaches US$42,000
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.23% to 103.36, clawing back some ground after a three-week decline, amid expectations of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Bitcoin breached the $42,000 mark for the first time since 2022, boosted by expectations of a US-registered Bitcoin fund and a potential end to the Fed's rate-hiking cycle. The euro fell 0.2% against the US dollar, while sterling and the Australian dollar also declined.

images.alt_text: Powell says it's clear that US monetary policy was slowing the economy as expected, with a benchmark overnight interest rate “well into restrictive territory”.

site_title: Private credit isn’t as risky as some may believe
summary: Private credit funds, which lend directly to buyout deals and highly indebted companies, have rapidly grown in popularity and assets under management, reaching nearly $1.6 trillion. Despite concerns about systemic risk, experts argue that the structure of private credit funds, which typically fund lending with long-term liabilities, reduces the risk of panics and runs. However, regulators must monitor trends such as insurers' investment styles and the sale of funds to retail investors, which could increase the risk of large-scale runs and damage the financial system.

images.alt_text: US billionaire investor Howard Marks views emerging economies as "teenagers" - full of potential yet also "volatile and tempestuous".

While another bull market or interest-rate cuts could spare private equity firms some blushes, the onus is on them to deliver operational improvements rather than relying on rising valuations to generate profit for their investors.

site_title: BOE bond selling creates arbitrage opportunity for UK banks
summary: The Bank of England's liquidity facility has created an arbitrage opportunity for UK banks, allowing them to profit from the difference in short-term borrowing and lending rates. Banks borrowed £2.46 billion from the facility last week, taking advantage of the widening spread between short-term money market rates and Bank Rate as quantitative tightening gets underway. This arbitrage is seen as a natural consequence of the BOE's efforts to correct the spread and ensure that short-term market rates remain close to Bank Rate.

images.alt_text: The Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, attends a press conference in London, Britain, May 11, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/Pool

site_title: US Strategic Oil Reserve refill is limited despite low prices
summary: The US Strategic Petroleum Reserve is at its lowest level since the 1980s, but refilling it is limited due to physical constraints and maintenance along the US Gulf Coast. The Energy Department can only purchase about 3 million barrels of crude oil per month, according to Deputy Energy Secretary David Turk. Despite low oil prices, the administration is unable to take full advantage of the drop to refill the reserve, with Turk stating that physical constraints are the main limitation.

images.alt_text: With the surge in output, gasoline prices have fallen by close to US$2 a gallon since summer 2022 and are back to levels that prevailed in 2021.
For the week, Brent posts a decline of about 2.1 per cent and WTI records a drop of more than 1.9 per cent.

site_title: UK mortgage borrowers face highest inflation rate: ONS
summary: The UK's Office for National Statistics (ONS) reports that mortgage borrowers face the highest personal rate of inflation, at 9.3%, in the year to September, significantly higher than the 6.7% consumer prices index. This is driven by soaring interest rates, which have increased borrowing costs for households. Private renters and outright owners also experienced significant inflation rates, at 7.2% and 7.4%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore rushes to ink carbon credit deals at COP28
summary: Singapore has concluded preliminary carbon credit deals with Bhutan, Paraguay, Ghana, and Vietnam, paving the way for carbon credit trading aligned with Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. The agreements will enable companies to offset up to 5% of their taxable emissions from 2024. Singapore has also signed memorandums of understanding with Rwanda and Fiji, bringing the total to 13 countries. The government aims to operationalize its new carbon tax regime as scheduled and will unveil a list of eligible host countries by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: GenZero, a Temasek-owned investment platform company, announced on Jun 8, 2023 that it would invest in a restoration project in Ghana aiming to generate carbon credits with corresponding adjustments.
The government will explore working with "high forest, low deforestation" jurisdictions to refine HFLD methodologies and come up with mechanisms that offer incentives to promote conservation.

BYD electric vehicles on display in Singapore. The Singapore government has clarified that credits generated from projects in Singapore, such as those from the Electric Vehicle Accelerator programme, do not fall under the ICC Framework.
Container ships are docked at PSA's Tanjong Pagar terminal in Singapore.
Coal is transported on barges in Samarinda, East Kalimantan in January 11, 2022.
Mizuho will invest in Climate Impact X, joining its founding shareholders DBS Bank, SGX Group, Standard Chartered and GenZero, a decarbonisation investment platform founded by Temasek.

Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security Teo Chee Hean delivering Singapore's national statement at the UN Climate Change Conference at Expo City Dubai on December 2, 2023, in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

site_title: Equities vs ‘guaranteed’ fixed deposits
summary: Global equities have outperformed US Treasury bills by a significant margin in high-interest rate periods, such as 1973-1991, 1995-2000, and 2006-2007, returning 579% compared to 326% for fixed deposits. This phenomenon is due to the equity-risk premium, where investors are willing to take on risk for higher expected returns. Historically, investors with longer time horizons have been rewarded, but require patience, discipline, and the stomach for volatility. Experts recommend using fixed deposits for short-term goals and exploring alternative options, such as money market funds and the Supplementary Retirement Scheme, for long-term savings.

images.alt_text: US 10-year Treasuries currently yield more than 4.6 per cent. Yields of investment-grade corporates are at around 6 per cent, and high-yield bonds at nearly 9 per cent.
dollars, currency, money

site_title: Private clients slow to embrace alternative investments: BlackRock official
summary: Edwin Conway, BlackRock's global head equity private markets, notes that high-net-worth investors allocate between 3-5% to alternative investments, while institutions allocate 25% or more. He expects private wealth allocations to shift towards alternatives, with a balanced portfolio comprising 50% equities, 30% fixed income, and 20% alternatives. Yield and capital appreciation are key considerations for allocations, with risk diversification also playing a significant role. Decarbonization is seen as a key investment theme, with BlackRock launching a partnership focused on next-generation private companies.

images.alt_text: Coal is transported on barges in Samarinda, East Kalimantan in January 11, 2022.
Investors need to be sharp-eyed about what private credit managers are doing with their money.

site_title: 'Rizz' charms Oxford wordsmiths to emerge as word of the year
summary: Oxford University Press has named "rizz" as the 2023 word of the year, a colloquial term defined as style, charm, or attractiveness. The word gained mainstream recognition after an interviewer asked Spider-Man actor Tom Holland about his "rizz," to which he replied he had none. The choice reflects the growing impact of Gen Z on language and the internet's ability to propel fringe language into the mainstream, with over 30,000 word lovers participating in the selection process.

images.alt_text: Hybrid work will reshape cities, careers, family life and free time.

site_title: Toyota eyes Europe production, sees region as reaching EV tipping point in a few years
summary: Toyota plans to offer 15 zero-emission vehicles in Europe by 2026, with over 250,000 battery electric vehicles (BEVs) expected to be delivered by then. The company is considering localizing production due to Europe's growing readiness for EVs, despite still needing to improve its battery supply chain, public charging infrastructure, and used EV market. Toyota's cautious approach suggests the industry is trending in the right direction, with environmentally conscious buyers and policymakers driving growth.

images.alt_text: epa11010407 Visitors inspect Toyota cars displayed at the 40th Thailand International Motor Expo 2023 in Bangkok, Thailand, 04 December 2023. More than 40 leading brands of international automakers attend to exhibit their automotive products and technology including the new electric vehicles in the annual Thailand International Motor Expo automobile showcase. site_title: China to host EU leaders for first in-person summit since 2019
summary: China will host European Union leaders for the first in-person summit since 2019, aimed at easing tensions between the two sides. The summit, set to begin on December 7, will be chaired by Chinese Premier Li Qiang and will include discussions on trade, climate change, and global health. The EU has expressed concerns over China's position on Russia's war in Ukraine and the Middle East, while China has emphasized its "partnership, not rivalry" with the EU. The visit follows a series of high-level meetings this year on trade and foreign policy.

images.alt_text: China has unleashed a flurry of market access concessions in the wake of last month’s leaders’ summit.

site_title: MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has formed a global coalition, the Transition Credits Coalition, to develop a new class of carbon credits aimed at accelerating the closure of coal-fired power plants. The coalition, comprising 27 members, will work to create a market for transition credits to compensate coal plant owners for early retirement. Two pilot projects are underway in the Philippines to test the integrity of the new asset class, with one aiming to bring forward the closure of a 246-megawatt coal plant to as early as 2030. The coalition aims to develop a whole-of-system approach to transition credits over a two-year period, with a focus on mitigating risks and building buyer confidence.

images.alt_text: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020.
