The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market's framework has ruled out carbon projects that “lock in fossil fuel emissions or technologies”.

For investors the risk focus has shifted from the rising cost of capital to refinancing. Some companies are rolling over debt early even at higher rates, to avoid potentially not being able to do so at all later on.

site_title: Asian Development Bank to provide US$10 billion climate finance for Philippines
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has committed to providing the Philippines with $10 billion in climate finance between 2024 and 2029 to support its climate action under the Paris Agreement. The funds will be used to implement projects in low-carbon transport, renewable energy, carbon markets, flood management, and other initiatives. This funding forms part of the ADB's new program aimed at supporting the Philippines' transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 4)
summary: Singapore's managing director of the Monetary Authority of Ravi Menon suggests the country's carbon tax should increase higher than planned to accelerate climate action. Singapore hotels' performance in October fell for the first time in almost three years, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore launched an international coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures. Local business sentiment improved in Q1 2024, and Singapore Exchange Regulation launched new listing requirements for actively managed exchange-traded funds.

site_title: Inflation data is good news but early to declare victory: ECB’s De Guindos
summary: Eurozone inflation fell to 2.4% in the latest month, beating expectations for the third consecutive time, fueling speculation that the European Central Bank (ECB) will lower interest rates sooner than expected. However, ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos cautioned that it's premature to declare victory, citing potential inflationary risks from government measures and wage developments. Decisions on monetary policy will remain data-dependent, and the ECB aims to return to its 2% inflation target in the second half of 2025.

images.alt_text: “We need to remain attentive to the different forces affecting inflation and firmly focused on our mandate of price stability,” says ECB president Christine Lagarde.

site_title: Global banks face negative outlook, property stress in 2024: Moody’s
summary: Global banks face a negative outlook in 2024 due to sluggish global growth, higher risk of borrowers defaulting on loans, and pressure on profitability. Prior rate hikes by central banks and rising unemployment in advanced economies will weaken asset quality, particularly in real estate exposures in the US and Europe. The Asia-Pacific region is also likely to experience pockets of stress in property markets. Moody's Investors Services warns of a growing risk of borrowers defaulting on loans, affecting bank profitability.

images.alt_text: UniCredit has been removed from the list of global systemically important banks, according to The Financial Stability Board (FSB).

site_title: China adds Nio to list of approved vehicle manufacturers
summary: China has approved Nio, an electric vehicle (EV) maker, to produce vehicles in the country after adding it to a list of approved manufacturers. This decision marks a shift for Chinese authorities, who have been cautious about new production amid overcapacity and a deepening price war. Nio, which partnered with Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Group since 2018, currently has no information on when a manufacturing licence was granted. The approval clears uncertainty over Nio's impact from JAC's plans to sell some assets related to the two factories that make Nio EVs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the logo of Chinese automobile manufacturer Geely at a dealership in Moscow, Russia, March 23, 2023. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: BRC Asia claims cost savings over S$2.1 million settlement compensation to supplier
summary: BRC Asia announced a cost-saving measure by replacing a steel-supply contract with a cheaper deal, saving at least S$25 per tonne, despite paying S$2.1 million to compensate the first supplier. The company stated that the compensation to an associate of its controlling shareholder did not prejudice the interests of minority shareholders, describing the settlement as "commercially justifiable". This move aims to mitigate potential financial risks while maintaining the interests of minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: Looking ahead, BRC Asia expects the local construction sector will continue to recover with accelerating site progress and strengthening construction demand.

site_title: All foreigners entering Malaysia from Dec 1 must submit digital arrival card
summary: Malaysia requires all foreigners entering the country from December 1 to submit a digital arrival card, known as the Malaysia Digital Arrival Card (MDAC), at least three days prior to arrival. Exceptions apply to Malaysia's permanent residents, automated clearance system pass holders, and those transiting through Singapore. The Immigration Department of Malaysia has implemented this new rule to enhance border control and immigration management.

images.alt_text: Travellers from China who are symptomatic will be referred to health officials, and will undergo throat swabs as well as RTK-Antigen Covid-19 tests.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund to buy 49% of luxury hotel chain Rocco Forte
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has agreed to buy a 49% stake in luxury hotel chain Rocco Forte Hotels, valuing the company at around £1.4 billion. The deal will support the hotel group's expansion, with founders Rocco Forte and his sister Olga Polizzi retaining majority ownership and control. PIF's investment will help Rocco Forte achieve its long-term vision, with the company currently operating 14 hotels across Italy, Britain, Germany, Belgium, and Russia, and planning to open three new hotels in Italy within the next two years.

images.alt_text: The Hawaii hotel is not the first to ditch the Trump brand.
Investors have announced new hospitality funds in recent months

The Public Investment Fund (PIF) tower, center, in the King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD) in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday, Dec. 6, 2022. The Saudi Arabian tourism ministry is targeting 12 million foreign tourists this year, with tourism on track to contribute about 4% of economic output, Tourism Minister Ahmed Al Khateeb said. Photographer: Maya Siddiqui/Bloomberg
Roshn is building around 400,000 homes across the kingdom, along with about 1,000 schools and entire commercial and entertainment districts.

site_title: Tesla’s China-made electric vehicle sales skid 17.8% on year in November
summary: Tesla's China-made electric vehicle sales dropped 17.8% in November to 82,432 cars, compared to the same period last year. Deliveries of China-made Model 3 and Model Y cars rose 14.3% from October. Chinese rival BYD set a record for passenger vehicle deliveries at 301,378 vehicles, up 31% from a year earlier.

site_title: Maersk to invest more than US$500 million to boost South-east Asia supply chain
summary: Maersk plans to invest over $500 million to boost its supply chain in South-east Asia by 50% by 2026, adding nearly 480,000 square meters of capacity across Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. This three-year investment aims to strengthen supply chain resilience and reduce trade costs, which are typically 2-3 times higher in the region.

site_title: US DFC considers US$500 million loan to Vietnamese EV maker VinFast
summary: The US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) has signed a letter of interest to consider a $500 million loan to Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast for the establishment of lithium-ion battery manufacturing facilities in Vietnam. The loan is subject to a comprehensive review and approval process by the DFC. This move aims to support VinFast's expansion in the region and enhance the country's battery manufacturing capabilities.

images.alt_text: A Vinfast electric vehicle store is shown at one of the company's retail locations in San Diego, California, U.S.,October 20, 2023.     REUTERS/Mike Blake
VinFast has said it aims to deliver up to 50,000 cars globally this year.
The company is constructing a US$2 billion manufacturing complex in North Carolina and plans factories in Indonesia and India.
GSM is Vietnam’s first electric-only taxi company, with its fleet consisting entirely of VinFast EVs.
VinFast says the strategic acquisition of VinES would help it secure the supply of batteries as the EV maker sought to save 5 per cent to 7 per cent on battery costs.
VinFast, which is backed by Vietnam’s largest conglomerate Vingroup, is gearing up to strengthen its foothold overseas.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower on Monday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% on Monday, closing at 3,084.08, with 881.7 million securities worth S$828.8 million changing hands. Sembcorp Industries was the top loser, dropping 6.2%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rose 2.8%. The decline was attributed to various factors, including a Ministry of Health notice to Cordlife Group, which saw a significant increase in its shares after a 32% plunge on Friday. Regional indices also fell, with the exception of the Kospi Composite Index, which rose 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit’s data centre in Northern Virginia. The Reit is one of four truststhat maintained double digit total return gains in the year to date till end November

site_title: Nvidia will try to prioritise Japan for AI processors: CEO
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang announced plans to prioritize Japan for artificial intelligence processors, following the country's significant investment in semiconductor infrastructure. Japan aims to rebuild its semiconductor industry and catch up on AI technology, with high demand for Nvidia's GPUs. Huang promised to do his "very best" to meet Japan's requirements, amid a budget allocation of 2 trillion yen (S$18.2 billion) for chip investment. This move reflects Japan's growing recognition of the need to own its own AI data, build its own AI factories, and produce its own AI intelligence.

images.alt_text: Nvidia's graphics cards (GPUs) are high-performance devices that enable powerful graphics rendering and processing for use in video editing, video gaming and other complex computing operations.

Despite the expanded China chip export curbs, analysts expect Nvidia‘s order books to be full until at least August next year, as demand for its AI chips, especially in the United States, continues to outstrip supply.

SandboxAQ will help expand the capabilities of CUDA, Nvidia’s software platform for developing artificial intelligence applications, to better simulate the quantum mechanics behind chemical, biological and material science.
Investors' buying spree has fuelled an abrupt U-turn in the Nasdaq 100 Stock Index that went from correction territory to a 15-month high in a matter of three weeks

site_title: Singapore’s carbon tax should be higher than planned to speed up action: MAS’ Menon
summary: Singapore's carbon tax needs to be higher than planned to accelerate climate action, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon. The current tax rate of $5 per tonne of emissions will increase to $25 per tonne by 2024 and $45 per tonne between 2026 and 2027, but Menon suggests it should be higher to meet the goal of reducing emissions. Only 30% of global emissions are subject to carbon tax, and blended finance and carbon credits are essential to lower capital costs for energy transition projects in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Blast furnaces of Tata Steel in IJmuiden, the Netherlands. The EU's new carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) complements its EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) designed to reduce emissions from power and industry plants.

site_title: Gautam Adani’s wealth swells by US$10 billion on relief rally
summary: Gautam Adani's net worth has surged by $10 billion, reaching a total of $70.3 billion, following a relief rally in his conglomerate's stocks after India's Supreme Court concluded its hearings on a lawsuit probing allegations of corporate malfeasance. The court's observations, which downplayed scathing media reports, have bolstered investor confidence. Adani's stocks have seen significant gains, with the conglomerate's market value increasing by $12 billion and $8.6 billion last week, respectively. Despite ongoing regulatory probes and a significant wealth loss this year, Adani remains among the world's 20 richest people.

images.alt_text: Adani Group will decide on divesting its stake in Adani Wilmar, its joint venture (JV) with Singapore’s Wilmar International, in the next three months.
Gautam Adani has denied wrongdoing, saying that Indian authorities assessed its coal shipments before releasing them from ports.

The potential capital raising adds to evidence the conglomerate has at least partially rebuilt investor confidence after being thrown into a tailspin by allegations of malpractice by short-seller Hindenburg Research.
Adani Enterprises posts net income of 2.28 billion rupees (US$37.3 million) for the quarter through September.
Adani New Industries, a wholly owned subsidiary of flagship company Adani Enterprises, will take the lead raising the money from domestic and international banks.

site_title: Foreigners flood back to Indonesian bonds on bets Fed is done
summary: Foreign investors have flooded back into Indonesian bonds, buying a net $1.5 billion of rupiah sovereign notes in November, as the interest rate gap with the US widens. The unexpected Bank Indonesia hike in October, ahead of the Fed pause, led to the increase in foreign investment. The yield on Indonesia's benchmark 10-year note has fallen over 60 basis points, driven by market expectations that the Fed will cut rates by mid-2024 and growth is slowing. This marks the first year of foreign inflow in four years for Indonesia.

site_title: German exports unexpectedly drop in October
summary: Germany's exports unexpectedly decreased by 0.2% in October, contrary to a forecast of a 1.1% increase, as demand in the European Union slumped. Exports to EU countries dropped by 2.7%, and imports from the EU also declined by 1.2% for the fifth consecutive month. This marks a stabilization in exports, contrary to expectations, and may raise concerns about the country's economic growth.

site_title: S. Korea's Yoon picks veteran technocrat Choi as finance minister ahead of vote
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol appointed Choi Sang-mok, a veteran technocrat, as the country's next finance minister, replacing Choo Kyung-ho. Choi, who will also serve as deputy prime minister, needs to maintain economic momentum ahead of April 2024 parliamentary elections. The move aims to ensure policy continuity, as Yoon's approval rating has fallen to 32% amid economic challenges, including higher borrowing costs and consumer inflation.

images.alt_text: At the main panel on Friday moderated by former US secretary of state Condoleezza Rice (centre), Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (right) and South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol  stressed the need to cooperate on climate change solutions and quantum computing.
South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol said on Tuesday that the country’s ban on short selling shares would remain in place.
Retail investors in South Korea have called for the ban, arguing that the trade practice gives unfair advantages to institutional and global investors.

site_title: Travellers ready to set sail on cruises at record levels next year
summary: US cruise operators and travel agents report a surge in bookings for 2024, with travellers opting for cruises due to their affordability compared to land-based alternatives. Occupancy levels are nearing pre-pandemic levels, leading to plans to increase prices in the coming months. The top-end luxury cruise market is particularly strong, according to CEO Bob Levinstein of Cruise Compete.

images.alt_text: The Seven Seas Grandeur set off on its maiden voyage on Nov 18.

The Ruby Princess was for a time Australia’s biggest single source of Covid-19 infection after 2,651 passengers, many feeling unwell, were allowed to leave the ship helping spread the virus across the country and internationally.

site_title: CDL secures £200 million sustainability-linked loan from OCBC
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) secured a £200 million (S$338.2 million) three-year sustainability-linked revolving credit facility from OCBC, bringing the group's total sustainable financing to around S$6 billion. This is the first corporate to obtain the OCBC 1.5°C loan, which offers interest rate incentives pegged to annual decarbonisation targets. CDL aims to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 and has set targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 63% and Scope 3 emissions by 41% by 2030.

images.alt_text: City Developments will buy back 33.1 million of its preference shares at S$0.78 apiece on Dec 1.
Since The Myst’s launch in July, the group has sold 169 units at an average selling price of S$2,065 per square foot.
Both MCK and CDI, subsidiaries of CDL, are New Zealand-incorporated companies that are listed on New Zealand's Exchange's mainboard.
Each preference shareholder will be entitled to sell 10 per cent of their entire holdings, the group said.

site_title: Spotify to cut 1,500 employees in third layoff this year
summary: Spotify is laying off approximately 1,500 employees, or 17% of its workforce, in its third layoff this year, following previous cuts in January and June. CEO Daniel Ek attributed the decision to cut costs, citing a gap between the company's financial goals and operational costs. Despite recent positive earnings reports, Ek stated that the reduction will feel large due to its size. Employees will receive severance pay, vacation pay, and healthcare coverage for the severance period.

images.alt_text: From early 2024, Spotify will require a minimum of 1,000 streams over 12 months before paying out royalties.
Spotify is now aiming to use LLMs to replicate that across its non-music content such as podcasts and audiobooks.
After spending more than a billion euros in building up its podcast business, Spotify has been keeping a tight lid on costs.

site_title: Singapore business confidence continues recovery in Q1 2024: SCCB
summary: Singapore's business confidence has continued to recover in Q1 2024, with the Business Optimism Index rising to +4.48 percentage points, up from +4.35 in Q4 2023. This marks the second consecutive quarter of improvement, despite the index still being lower than the +4.73 percentage points in Q1 2023. The recovery is attributed to a rebound in the construction, tourism, and manufacturing sectors.

images.alt_text: Revenues in transportation and storage decline 20.7 per cent year on year and 1.5 per cent quarter on quarter, non-seasonally adjusted. in Q3.
According to SGX data, just 13 out of the 180 Catalist stocks have a market capitalisation of above S$100 million.
The economy has expanded by 1.1 per cent year on year in the third quarter of this year, faster than the 0.5 per cent clocked in Q2.

site_title: Credit Suisse AT1 fallout widens in Japan with more lawsuits
summary: Japanese investors have filed lawsuits against the brokerage arms of SBI Holdings, Rakuten Group, and Monex Group, seeking compensation for losses on Credit Suisse's riskiest debt. The lawsuits claim that the brokerages sold the notes while offering incorrect explanations about them. The debt was written down by Switzerland as part of a merger with UBS Group, resulting in losses for global investors. The Tokyo District Court will consider the claims, which are part of a growing legal fallout over the Credit Suisse AT1 fallout in Japan.

images.alt_text: “In consideration of the product characteristics of AT1 bonds of Credit Suisse Group, we have sold those securities to customers to whom we thought the products would be suited, after having sales staff explain about them in person,” an SBI spokesperson says.

site_title: Swiss inflation unexpectedly slows, backs case for SNB pause
summary: Switzerland's inflation unexpectedly slowed to a two-year low in November, with consumer prices rising 1.4% from last year, lower than predicted economists. The country's strong currency has shielded it from inflationary pressures, with inflation rates within the central bank's target range. The Swiss National Bank may keep borrowing costs steady, as officials stress that more tightening might be required to combat future inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Year on year, the Swiss economy grows 0.9 per cent, stronger than the 0.5 per cent forecast.

site_title: Oil down on persistent uncertainty over Opec+ supply cuts
summary: Oil prices fell 0.6% on Monday, with Brent crude futures at $78.39 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures at $73.65 a barrel, amid uncertainty over Opec+ supply cuts. The Opec+ decision, combined with concerns over global demand growth and the Middle East conflict, contributed to the decline. Investors remain skeptical about the depth of supply cuts and geopolitical tensions, including the Israel-Hamas war, also impacted oil prices.

images.alt_text: For the week, Brent posts a decline of about 2.1 per cent and WTI records a drop of more than 1.9 per cent.

site_title: Beyonce’s Renaissance concert film tops North America box office
summary: Beyoncé's concert film "Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé" topped the North American box office with an estimated $21 million opening weekend, ranking among the top five all-time concert movie openings. The film's success is attributed to positive critics' reviews and audience scores, making it an excellent domestic opening for a concert film. This achievement comes after Taylor Swift's "The Eras Tour" film held the top spot earlier this year with a $92.8 million opening.

images.alt_text: Josh Hutcherson leads the cast as a security guard working nights at an abandoned family entertainment centre, where creepy animatronic characters spring murderously to life after dark.
“This opening is fantastic,” analyst David A Gross said, adding that the film looks likely to rank just behind two Stephen King It movies among domestic horror-film openings.

site_title: Helping your children buy that private property now may not help them in future
summary: Affluent parents in Singapore are advised to refrain from providing financial help for their children to buy private homes, as this could worsen inequality and be financially suboptimal. Buying a private home for a minor via a trust incurs Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) and can lead to complications later, such as selling the property to buy an HDB flat. In contrast, buying a BTO unit can yield a higher profit on purchase price and smaller loan repayments, allowing the couple to invest more. The HDB is ramping up BTO supply, making it a more optimal start for young local couples.

images.alt_text: Stricter rules for the non-selection of a BTO flat has led buyers to look towards the resale market instead, property analysts observe.
Facade of Raffles Town Club, whose lease at Plymouth Avenue will not be renewed, with the site being slated for future housing development.

site_title: Requisition to internalise trustee-manager could delay Dasin Retail Trust’s restructuring, says lender
summary: A group of 15 investors is seeking to replace Dasin Retail Trust's external trustee-manager with an internal one, potentially delaying the trust's debt restructuring efforts. The trustee-manager has received a requisition notice and is considering it, but internalisation could prolong the process. The trust's largest controlling unitholder has agreed to provide pre-approval for the sale of retail malls, and lenders are discussing terms of the proposed restructuring. Units of Dasin Retail Trust rose 12.3% following the update, as the trustee-manager reiterated its commitment to considering the requisition notice.

images.alt_text: Ocean Metro Mall, one of Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio assets. Its unitholders are seeking to hold an extraordinary general meeting to internalise its trustee-manager.
The 400-million-yuan onshore facility is for Dasin Retail Trust's acquisitions of its initial portfolio including Ocean Metro Mall.
The offshore facility in default is used to finance the acquisitions of the trust’s initial portfolio comprising Xiaolan Metro Mall, Ocean Metro Mall, Dasin E-Colour and Shiqi Metro Mall.
This loan facility was to finance the acquisition of Doumen Metro Mall, and was announced by the trust in September and October last year, the trust said in a filing to the bourse.

Dasin Retail Trust’s portfolio includes Ocean Metro Mall in Zhongshan. SGX had queried the trust’s management on Jul 6 after the company announced that talks with a “reputable Chinese entity” for a potential memorandum of understanding (MOU) fell through.
Ocean Metro Mall is one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio. The trust's net loss for the second half ended December 2022 stands at S$221.5 million.

site_title: Japan’s TDK to manufacture iPhone battery cells in India
summary: TDK, a Japanese electronic parts maker, will manufacture lithium-ion battery cells for Apple iPhones in India, creating several thousand new jobs in the northern state of Haryana. This move is part of Apple's strategy to diversify production away from China and tap into India's growing market. TDK's facility will supply cells to Sunwoda Electronics, an Apple-approved battery assembler. The partnership aims to boost Apple's presence in India, which has been a key focus for the company as it seeks to expand its global reach.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Broken Apple iPhones are seen in a repair shop in Vienna, Austria July 4, 2017. REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo

site_title: Islamic State claims responsibility for deadly Philippine bombing
summary: Islamic State militants claimed responsibility for a deadly bombing at a Catholic Mass in the Philippines, killing at least 4 people and injuring 50 others. The attack occurred at Mindanao State University in Marawi, a city in the south of the country besieged by Islamist militants for five months in 2017. Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. condemned the attack, while Pope Francis offered prayers for the victims. Law enforcement operations will continue to bring perpetrators to justice, with "strong indications of a foreign element" in the bombing.

images.alt_text: At least four people were killed and at least 50 injured after a bomb exploded during a morning Catholic Mass in a university gymnasium in Marawi, a city in the south of the country besieged by Islamist militants for five months in 2017.

site_title: Singapore hotel room rates in October down again amid falling tourist arrivals
summary: Singapore hotel room rates declined 14.6% in October from September, marking the first on-year slide since March 2021, amid falling tourist arrivals. Average room rates across all four hotel categories decreased, with the luxury segment seeing a drop of over $100. Total hotel room revenue fell 16.2% to S$413.1 million, and revenue per available room (RevPAR) dropped 19.3% to S$217.05. The decline was attributed to competition from other Asia-Pacific destinations and weaker hotel demand.

images.alt_text: All hotel categories mark increases in average room rates in September.
Indonesia, China, India, Malaysia and Australia are the top five source countries for visitors to Singapore in October.
Corporate travel spending is accelerating and should exceed pre-Covid levels in 2024

site_title: Gold strikes record above US$2,100 as rate cut bets surge
summary: Gold prices reached a record high of US$2,135.39 on Monday, surpassing the 2020 pandemic-era peak of US$2,100. The surge is driven by growing expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in the new year, boosting investor confidence. Traders are betting on a rate cut, which could lead to increased demand for gold as a safe-haven asset. The price increase is a significant milestone, marking a new all-time high for the precious metal.

site_title: Roche enters obesity drug market with US$2.7 billion Carmot deal
summary: Roche has agreed to acquire obesity drug developer Carmot Therapeutics for US$2.7 billion. The deal includes upfront payments of US$2.7 billion and potential additional payments of up to US$400 million based on milestones. Carmot's lead drug candidate, CT-388, is a dual GLP-1/GIP receptor agonist, similar to Eli Lilly's Mounjaro. The drug has shown promising Phase I trial results and is set to be tested on humans in the next trial stage. The acquisition aims to challenge the dominant weight-loss drug makers, Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign at a diagnostics site for Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche is seen as the company said problems at a new warehouse delayed the dispatch of some products, as the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues, in Burgess Hill, Britain, October 7, 2020.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Gold jumps to record on rate cut bets but equities struggle
summary: Gold reached a record high of $2,135 due to growing bets that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates in the new year, despite Jerome Powell's attempts to temper expectations. Markets were mixed, with equities struggling to build on a positive lead from Wall Street. The dollar fell, making gold cheaper for international buyers, and bets on a rate cut have weighed on the dollar. The US jobs figures due at the end of the week will be closely watched.

images.alt_text: Wall Street now expects the Fed will start cutting its key lending rate “in the end of the first quarter” next year.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 91 to 46.

site_title: Australian job advertisements fall 4.6% in November: ANZ-Indeed
summary: Australian job advertisements declined 4.6% in November from October, the largest drop since August 2021, according to data from ANZ and Indeed. This decline, combined with a 16.8% decrease from the previous year, suggests the labour market may be easing as high interest rates cool demand. ANZ economist Madeline Dunk stated that the decline highlights a cooling labour market, potentially leading to an increase in the unemployment rate.

site_title: Bitcoin breaks US$40,000 as momentum builds
summary: Bitcoin broke above $40,000 for the first time this year, reaching a high of $41,522 on December 4, its highest since April 2022. The surge is attributed to broad enthusiasm for US interest rate cuts and anticipation of the approval of US-stockmarket traded Bitcoin funds. A 50% rally since mid-October has marked a decisive shift away from bearishness in 2022 and early 2023, with institutional buying and potential ETF approval driving the momentum.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin, the world’s biggest and best-known cryptocurrency, is up 51.1 per cent from the year’s low of US$26,533 on Oct 11.

site_title: DBS Foundation: Driving holistic support for those in need
summary: DBS Foundation, the philanthropic arm of DBS Bank, is ramping up efforts to support underserved groups in Singapore. The bank has committed $40 million in 2023 to ease cost-of-living pressures on its customers, including low-income families and individuals. DBS has also set up pop-up markets offering a wide range of food and household necessities, giving beneficiaries the freedom to choose what they want and need. The bank's initiatives, including a financial literacy program for children and a volunteer program, aim to empower communities to be more food secure and resilient.

images.alt_text: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (right) at Tuesday's pilot financial literacy workshop by DBS Foundation and SG Enable, where persons with disabilities received guidance from DBS volunteers.

Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Trade and Industry, as well as Minister of State for Culture, Community and Youth, visits Market for Good's booth. The event aims to raise funds for underprivileged children from Singapore Red Cross' Young Hearts programme.

site_title: Evergrande liquidation hearing postponed in surprise to lenders; shares rally
summary: A Hong Kong court has postponed a decision on whether Evergrande Group should be wound up, giving the company eight weeks to agree a deal with offshore bondholders. The decision was pushed back to January 29, 2024, after the original petitioner did not push for immediate liquidation. Evergrande's lawyer said a new proposal was sent to creditors on November 26, and the company is seeking further support and feedback. This development has led to a rally in Evergrande's shares.

images.alt_text: Evergrande, which has liabilities of about US$327 billion, has become the poster child of China’s real estate debt crisis since it defaulted in December 2021.

site_title: SGX ready to list active ETFs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched new listing requirements for actively managed exchange-traded funds (ETFs), allowing for more transparency and investment opportunities to capitalise on market inefficiencies. The new requirements include publishing indicative net asset value daily, disclosing net asset value, and publishing fund performance and portfolio holdings monthly. Industry players expect the introduction of active ETFs to strengthen Singapore's position in the global financial landscape, with assets under management doubling to over S$10 billion and the number of direct retail investors doubling.

images.alt_text: VTAC, led by non-executive chairman Chua Kee Lock,  has endorsed the merger, citing 17Live’s strong management, the potential for scale, and its alignment with Vertex Holdings’ areas of expertise.
As the volume of IPO deals has shrunk, work in the IPO space has become “very cost-competitive”, industry players say.

The fund, which offers dual currency trading in US dollars and Singapore dollars, comprises 1,000 China-listed companies that have a market capitalisation of less than 20 billion yuan (S$3.8 billion).
The fund — which was a collaboration between BlackRock, SGX and the MSCI –  has assets under management of US$426 million.

site_title: GIC acquires two more logistics facilities in Japan
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired two logistics facilities in Japan developed by Daiwa House Industry for an undisclosed amount. The assets, located in Takatsuki city and Tosu city, were completed in 2023 and 2021, respectively. The properties feature modern building specifications and are situated in regional logistics hubs with convenient transportation access.

site_title: Indonesia’s coal love affair still aflame despite pledges
summary: Indonesia, the world's top coal exporter, is expanding its coal-fired power plant despite pledging to move away from the fuel. The Suralaya power plant in Banten province is set to receive two new units, and plans for new plants are underway to power the nickel industry, crucial for the electric vehicle boom. The government's pledge excludes captive coal plants, which account for over 13 gigawatts of existing capacity. Activists and analysts argue that the expansion will hinder Indonesia's efforts to achieve net-zero power sector emissions by 2050 and will have serious health consequences.

images.alt_text: People protest against fossil fuels in Brussels, Belgium, Dec 3, 2023. The protest, coinciding with the COP28 in Dubai, is calling for urgent measures to combat climate change.
Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has announced the multi-billion dollar Resource Mobilisation Plan on the sidelines of the COP28 climate talks.
Coal is transported on barges in Samarinda, East Kalimantan in January 11, 2022.

Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security Teo Chee Hean delivering Singapore's national statement at the UN Climate Change Conference at Expo City Dubai on December 2, 2023, in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.
Among the expected pledges at COP28 are a goal to triple renewable energy capacity and initiatives on methane and coal power.
The announcement was made at the UN’s COP28 climate summit in Dubai.

site_title: Construction platform Gravel raises US$14 million funding round
summary: Gravel, an Indonesian construction startup, has raised a US$14 million funding round led by venture capital firms New Enterprise Associates, SMDV, and East Ventures. The funding will be used to expand the business and broaden its market reach in Indonesia. Gravel's app connects skilled construction workers with contractors and architects, supporting over 6,000 projects across 20 provinces. The startup aims to amplify Indonesia's nationwide growth with its job-matching technology, enabling right worker allocation within minutes.

images.alt_text: Liris Maduningtyas, co-founder and chief executive officer of JALA.
Downturns are the best time to angel invest, some reckon

site_title: Centurion inks RM227 million sale-and-leaseback deal with Malaysian pension fund
summary: Centurion Corp is selling two of its assets in Malaysia, Westlite Bukit Minyak and Westlite Tampoi, to Kumpulan Wang Persaraan (KWAP) for RM227 million, above the properties' collective net tangible asset value of RM224.3 million. The sale-and-leaseback deal will allow Centurion to recycle capital, enlarge its portfolio, and expand revenue streams. The deal is part of the company's strategy to grow its business via asset-light means, with the properties leased back for 15 years.

images.alt_text: Three migrant workers looking out from their windows in their rooms at Westlite Dormitory Woodlands on April 23, 2021.
Centurion will explore different business opportunities, such as the development of deal structure and joint ventures in the region.
Centurion Corporation is confident that it will continue to see positive rental reversions as tight market conditions persist.

site_title: Singapore shares track global rally to rise at Monday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at Monday's open, following a global rally led by Wall Street and European markets. The Straits Times Index reached 3,095.52, with gainers outnumbering losers 91 to 46. Banking stocks led the gains, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising 0.1%, 0.3%, and 0.2% respectively. The rally was driven by comments from Fed chair Jerome Powell that it was premature to speculate on when the central bank would cut interest rates.

images.alt_text: OCBC is claiming at least S$19.7 million from Su Baolin, as well as possession of his mortgage Sentosa Cove villa.

site_title: Thailand’s proposed 100 km land bridge poses little threat to Singapore, Malaysia ports: analysts
summary: Thailand's proposed 100 km land bridge, aimed at bypassing the Strait of Malacca, is unlikely to pose a significant threat to Singapore and Malaysia's ports, experts say. The project could, however, benefit Singapore as an investor by selling excess crane equipment, and potentially benefit Malaysia as well. The land bridge's development is expected to be completed in phases, with the first phase set to be finished in 2030 and the full capacity reached in 2039. Analysts warn that the project's success hinges on the balance between costs and benefits, and that it may not be economically viable.

images.alt_text: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin addresses the 78th United Nations General Assembly at UN headquarters in New York City on September 22, 2023. (Photo by Bryan R. Smith / AFP)
Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin made a pitch to potential investors about the Landbridge project during his recent visit to the US.
Srettha Thavisin became the first leader in some four decades to take on the dual role of finance minister.

site_title: Insurtech Igloo bags US$36 million pre-Series C funding
summary: Insurtech startup Igloo has secured US$36 million in a pre-Series C funding round led by Eurazeo's insurtech fund. Existing investors Openspace Ventures and La Maison also participated. Igloo's post-money valuation now stands at US$210 million, 50% above its previous valuation. The funding will be used to expand the company's reach and product portfolio through mergers and acquisitions, and to hire new staff, with a target of increasing headcount by 20%. Igloo claims to have facilitated over 500 million insurance policies and has over 22,000 insurance agents in Vietnam and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Insurtech startup Igloo raises US$19m in Series B round; names new CEO and co-founder
Igloo CEO Raunak Mehta wants to accelerate regional growth.

site_title: Singtel obtains S$535 million five-year green loan for data centres
summary: Singtel has secured a S$535 million five-year green loan from DBS, OCBC, UOB, and Standard Chartered to support the operations of its two data centres, DC West and DC Kim Chuan. The loan requires these facilities to obtain at least a Green Mark GoldPlus certification. Proceeds will be used for refinancing borrowings and improving efficiency. This marks Singtel's first green loan, and the company plans to explore further green technologies, including liquid cooling and artificial intelligence, to reduce its environmental impact.

images.alt_text: SGX Group CEO Loh Boon Chye speaks at an event in Bangkok to celebrate the progress of the Thailand-Singpaore Depository Receipt linkage scheme
The telco said H1 net profit saw a boost from an exceptional gain as a result of regional associate Telkomsel’s integration of IndiHome.

Pedestrians walk past a security guard standing outside an outlet for the Australian communications company Optus in Sydney on November 9, 2023. Australia's government on November 9 launched an investigation into a nationwide communications outage that crippled phone lines and severed internet access for 10 million customers countrywide. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)
This investment puts the enterprise value of Singtel’s overall RDC business at S$5.5 billion.

site_title: S&P 500 facing headwinds in final month of 2023
summary: The US stock market, particularly the S&P 500, experienced a strong November, with gains of 8.9% in the S&P 500, 8.8% in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, and 10.7% in the Nasdaq. However, investors are now contemplating profit-taking before the year ends, potentially leading to a correction. A potential rate cut by the US Federal Reserve and the traditional "Santa Claus rally" could support the S&P 500's bullish momentum, but a reversal of November's gains is possible if the bearish sentiment intensifies, potentially leading to a decline to the 4,280 area.

images.alt_text: Investors next week will be watching US employment data, due out on Dec 8, to see whether economic growth is continuing to level off.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, OCBC, Uni-Asia, Koh Brothers Eco Engineering
summary: OCBC claims at least S$19.7 million from money-laundering accused Su Baolin, while Singtel secured a S$535 million green loan to refinance borrowings and support operations. Uni-Asia Group won a tender in Japan for S$118 million, while Koh Brothers Eco Engineering reported a cyberattack that has been "contained". Parkson Retail Asia requested a trading halt on Monday morning.

site_title: Almost half of Singapore workers seeking new jobs even as economic outlook weakens
summary: A survey by Ernst & Young (EY) Advisory found that 45% of employees in Singapore are likely to resign from their current workplaces in the next 12 months, with better employee programmes and perks cited as top reasons. The survey also revealed a disconnect between employers and employees on the economic outlook, with 74% of employers believing slower growth will reduce employees' likelihood of quitting, but only 59% of employees agreeing. The survey highlights the need for employers to invest in better employee programmes and address the growing chasm between employers and employees on work-related issues.

site_title: Bank of Singapore shuffles leadership team in Hong Kong
summary: Bank of Singapore has shuffled its leadership team in Hong Kong, with Rickie Chan joining as head of private banking for Greater China, Hong Kong branch, effective February 15, 2024. Chan, former chief executive of Credit Suisse's Hong Kong branch, will report to CEO Jason Moo. Teresa Lee, current head of Greater China, will become vice-chair of Greater China, Hong Kong branch, also effective February 15, 2024. The appointments mark a significant change in leadership for the bank in the region.

site_title: Financing for energy transition in Asean gains momentum at COP28
summary: Indonesia announced the early retirement of its 660-megawatt Cirebon-1 coal plant in December 2035, seven years before its original retirement date, as part of its transition to a low-carbon economy. This deal comes as part of the country's Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) with developed nations and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The move is seen as a step towards clean energy transition in Southeast Asia, with several other Asean countries also announcing initiatives to develop transition finance. However, questions remain on the scalability of such transactions and the need for more private sector capital to close international financing gaps.

site_title: Koh Brothers Eco units face cyberattack, investigation ongoing
summary: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, a sustainable engineering solutions provider, was targeted by a recent cyberattack, resulting in unauthorized access and encryption of its servers. The company is unable to assess the full impact on its operations and has engaged incident response experts and external legal counsel to manage the incident. The group's business continues to operate, and shareholders are advised to exercise caution when dealing with their shares. The incident is currently being investigated, and the company will provide updates on any material developments.

site_title: Hong Kong court adjourns Evergrande winding-up petition to Jan 29
summary: A Hong Kong court has adjourned a winding-up petition for Chinese real estate giant Evergrande to January 29, giving the company until then to submit a restructuring plan. High Court judge Linda Chan advised Evergrande's lawyer to discuss the plan with relevant authorities to confirm its feasibility. The initial deadline was set for December, and the extension provides more time for the company to finalize its proposal.

site_title: In boost for Modi, BJP sweeps polls in three Indian states
summary: India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won regional votes in three major states - Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, and Chhattisgarh - in a boost for Prime Minister Narendra Modi ahead of a national election due by May. The BJP comfortably won Rajasthan and Chhattisgarh, and retained Madhya Pradesh. This victory marks a significant gain for Modi, who is seeking a third term, and sets the stage for the national election.

site_title: Alaska Air to buy Hawaiian Airlines for US$1.9 billion
summary: Alaska Airlines has agreed to acquire Hawaiian Airlines for $1.9 billion, including $900 million in debt. The deal will be finalized at $18 per share in cash, aiming to unlock new destinations and expand access throughout the Pacific and globally. The acquisition is expected to generate high single-digit earnings accretion for Alaska Airlines within the first two years, with minimal impact on its long-term balance sheet metrics.

site_title: Net-zero targets must include fossil fuel ‘phase-out’: monitor
summary: Most countries with net-zero carbon emissions targets haven't announced plans to phase out fossil fuels, putting those pledges at risk. A new report by Net Zero Tracker found 150 countries have committed to net-zero targets, covering 88% of human-driven greenhouse gases, but none have plans to phase out fossil fuels. This could render those pledges ineffective, making them appear as "bumper stickers" rather than meaningful commitments.

site_title: Binance’s VIP traders got sneak peek of record US crypto penalty at posh Singapore club
summary: Binance, the largest crypto exchange, has reached a $4 billion settlement with US authorities, avoiding a potentially record-breaking penalty. Internal communications showed that Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao (CZ) had direct knowledge of the company's US law violations. The settlement was finalized after months of pressure from the US Justice Department, which had pushed for harsher punishment. The deal was previewed to VIP traders at a Binance-hosted dinner in Singapore, where they were told the company would survive its American legal troubles. CZ pleaded guilty to a criminal charge in a Seattle courtroom and will step down, with Richard Teng taking over as CEO.

site_title: PwC to set up blocks preventing exam cheating after US$7 million fine
summary: PwC has blocked technologies that enable employee cheating on internal training exams after a US$7 million fine from the PCAOB for cheating by over 1,000 employees in its China and Hong Kong offices. site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia to hold rates on Dec 5, Aussie home prices to rise 5% in 2024: poll
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to hold interest rates steady at 4.35% on December 5, according to a Reuters poll of 30 economists. Despite a 12-year high, Australian home prices are expected to rise 8% this year and 5% next year, driven by a strong housing market. Consumer price inflation in October slowed to 4.9%, still above the RBA's target range of 2-3%. Only two economists predicted a 25 basis point interest rate hike, with 20 forecasting steady rates until end-March and the rest predicting a quarter percentage point hike.

site_title: New UK Foreign Secretary Cameron to visit Washington
summary: UK Foreign Secretary David Cameron is set to visit Washington from Wednesday to reaffirm the UK's relationship with the US. As the country's top diplomat, Cameron will meet with key members of the Biden Administration, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken, to discuss support for Ukraine in its fight against Russian aggression and de-escalating tensions in the Middle East. This trip comes after Cameron's appointment as Foreign Secretary last month and follows his visit to Ukraine just days after being named to the role.

Real estate investing remains a viable option for building wealth, and experts highlight various opportunities in the market.

site_title: China youths swap city dreams for country living as jobs crisis mounts
summary: China youths are fleeing city life to rural areas as a jobs crisis mounts, with many turning to farming or entrepreneurship. A 30-year-old former finance blogger, Gong Chengqiang, is one such example, who now grows strawberries in rural Zhejiang province. Others, like 33-year-old astrologer Bai Yunxi, are also choosing country living over city dreams. The decision is driven by financial struggles and a desire for a simpler life, with many parents also disappointed by their children's career choices. This trend is a reflection of China's shifting economic landscape and youth aspirations.

site_title: Strategy shifts power Dyna-Mac’s growth
summary: Dyna-Mac, an offshore oil and gas contractor, has seen significant growth under the leadership of CEO Lim Ah Cheng, who shifted the company's strategy from tendering widely to engaging customers early on. This approach has led to a healthy order book and a 46.9% increase in revenue for the first half of FY2023. The company has also expanded its facilities and is exploring opportunities in the green and pharmaceutical spaces. Lim attributes the turnaround to a focus on on-time delivery, cost control, and building relationships with customers.

site_title: Bitcoin hits US$40,000 level for the first time this year
summary: Bitcoin reached a nearly 18-month high of US$40,085 on Sunday, up 51.1% from its year-low of US$26,533 in October. The surge is attributed to bets on US regulator approval of stock-market traded bitcoin funds. Bitcoin has more than doubled in price this year, but remains down from its record high of US$69,000 in November 2021, and has yet to gain mainstream acceptance as an investment.

site_title: Blackstone’s flex offices biggest in London as WeWork retreats
summary: Blackstone's flex office brand, now rebranded as Fora, has surpassed WeWork as the largest flexible office provider in London's central districts, with 61 sites across zones one and two. WeWork, which filed for bankruptcy in the US, has retreated from London's market, with 35 sites listed on its website. Fora's majority owner, Blackstone, acquired The Office Group in 2017 and merged it with Fora last year, valuing the combined business at £1.5 billion.

site_title: MAS, Temasek ink MOU to address region’s sustainable infrastructure financing gap
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Temasek have signed a memorandum of understanding with Allied Climate Partners (ACP) and the World Bank's International Finance Corporation (IFC) to address Asia's sustainable development financing gap. The partnership will deploy blended finance, combining public and private capital, to green and sustainable projects, primarily in South-east Asia. The goal is to meet region's carbon reduction targets, create jobs, and address climate finance gaps. The four parties will identify and develop a pipeline of investments in various sectors, including renewable energy and transportation.

site_title: Why the yen is so weak and what that means for Japan
summary: The yen has fallen to a historic low of 152 against the US dollar in November, mainly due to Japan's central bank keeping interest rates low while other central banks hike rates. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) still believes price growth has yet to be settled, despite inflation being similar to the US. The yen's decline has both helped and harmed the economy, with a weaker currency increasing repatriated overseas profits but making imports more expensive. The BOJ is expected to keep interest rates unchanged for now, but policymakers remain on guard for potential currency intervention to curb the decline.

site_title: World Bank focuses on securitisation to scale climate finance
summary: The World Bank is focusing on securitization to scale climate finance, with the Private Sector Investment Lab (PSIL) working with 15 finance bosses to lower risk and attract private capital for climate deals. The lab aims to create a "securitisable asset class" to mobilize billions from large investors like BlackRock and pension funds. The World Bank's president, Ajay Banga, says the goal is to simplify guarantee products and create more financial firepower to scale financing, as multilateral development banks and governments lack the funds to address climate change.

site_title: With campaigning in full swing, Indonesia’s presidential hopefuls out to court the youth vote
summary: Indonesia's 75-day presidential election campaign period has begun, with a focus on the youth vote aged 17-40, accounting for 52% of the electorate. Candidates are using social media, memes, and wefies to connect with this demographic. Prabowo Subianto's campaign team has been active on social media, promoting his softer side, while other candidates are emphasizing their policies and priorities. Voters are seeking informed decisions, with a recent survey showing that 60% of this age group relies on social media for election updates.

site_title: Proposal to rescue Manulife US Reit falls flat
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (MUST) has proposed a rescue plan to address loan covenant breaches, but its proposal was met with a 42.8% decline in unit price to US$0.052. The plan involves selling assets, taking on a $137 million loan at 10% interest, and waiving loan covenant breaches. MUST's sponsor group should consider repackaging assets into a new fund or trust to unlock value for unitholders and spare the sponsor group the task of rehabilitating MUST's market standing. The deal buys time for MUST until 2025, when the US office property market may recover.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of December 1, 2023, highlights exceptional gains in the capesize market, driven by strong momentum in the Pacific and Atlantic regions. The Pacific market saw a notable uptick, with rates increasing by 20 points, while the Atlantic market remained optimistic despite reduced activity from south Brazil and West Africa. The Panamax market also experienced solid gains, with rates reaching the upper $28,000s in the North Atlantic. In contrast, the Handysize sector saw a calmer feel, with owners' expectations rising and rates increasing in the Atlantic. The report also notes that the LR2 market declined, while the MR and Suezmax markets remained stable.

site_title: Vietnam lays out US$15.5 billion energy transition plan
summary: Vietnam has unveiled a US$15.5 billion plan to transition away from coal power, aiming to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The Resource Mobilisation Plan, announced during COP28 climate talks, includes commitments to open mechanisms, good infrastructure, and smart management. However, environmentalists have expressed concerns, citing the country's intention to use coal-fired plants until their life operations and shrinking civil society space, which could discourage investment in renewables and limit the plan's effectiveness.

site_title: How to survive and succeed in a disrupted world? With sound strategy
summary: A renowned WWII British general, Bernard Montgomery, emphasized the importance of planning and being better equipped than adversaries. In today's disrupted world, sound strategy is crucial for survival and success. Companies like Boeing, Rolls Royce, and Netflix have faced pressure to deliver results quickly, compromising quality and safety. Disruptions require recalibration of strategies, and traditional planning models are inadequate. Strategic thinking, forecasting, and flexibility are essential for navigating uncertainty. A well-crafted strategy guides individuals and organizations through turbulent times, while tactics execute the plan, making informed decisions swiftly and adapting to changing circumstances.

I was 13 when an old Polish soldier, living out the war as a refugee in Britain, taught me how to plough. He showed me that aiming for the “Tree on the other side of the Field” would achieve a straight furrow, and all subsequent furrows would follow the line of the first. Ever since then I have known each morning, when rising from bed, where my Tree is.

People widely have a poor view of planning, especially in times of emergency. This may be partly because they see the process of planning as something you do for a posh wedding, where everything must be tickety-boo and there is no room for mishap.  The point is: How much worse would they have been without planning?

Why do humans blame their work for their misery? Why do many find themselves lacking in confidence, bereft of enthusiasm, tempted to opt out? The answer to this is another question. What do you think is the purpose of your life and the lives of those who work with you?

This return to normalcy is being viewed as a positive development by some, despite pundits warning of potential risks. The article's author, Ken Fisher, notes that the Covid-19 pandemic's lasting impact on spending patterns was overstated, and that economic normalcy is now returning. site_title: Why Elon Musk is accused of antisemitism and what it means for X
summary: Elon Musk has faced accusations of antisemitism after posting on X, the social media platform he owns, that endorsed an antisemitic conspiracy theory and made racist comments. The post, which referred to a conspiracy theory that motivated a 2018 synagogue shooting, prompted advertisers to halt spending on the platform, with major brands such as Apple and Disney suspending their ads. Musk responded to the backlash by criticizing advertisers and accusing the Anti-Defamation League of inspiring the boycott. Musk later apologized for the post, but the incident has led to a significant decline in ad revenue for X, with the platform's ad revenue down 60% and the company struggling to make up for lost revenue.

site_title: Top development banks at COP28 vow to up climate game, but quiet on fossil fuels
summary: Top development banks at COP28 have pledged to step up climate efforts, but failed to address financing for fossil fuel projects. The group, including the World Bank, aims to track and report climate impact, scale up green financing, and coordinate support for countries to develop plans for decarbonization and climate resilience. Despite record extreme weather events, the banks remain a fraction of what is needed to address the climate crisis, with the European Investment Bank being the only signatory to commit to stopping fossil fuel lending.

site_title: Global regulators propose tougher scrutiny of voluntary carbon markets
summary: Global regulators, led by the International Organization of Securities Commissions (Iosco), have proposed 21 safety measures to improve the integrity, transparency, and enforcement of voluntary carbon markets (VCMs). The measures aim to address concerns over the quality and double-counting of credits, and could include requirements for companies to disclose their use of carbon credits and platforms to have better anti-fraud safeguards. The goal is to standardize terminology and practices in VCMs, a sector expected to grow to $250 billion by 2050, to support efforts to fight climate change.

summary: Seoul's high-rise apartment complexes, known as "apatu danji," are a ubiquitous feature of the city's landscape, housing 61% of Koreans as of 2021. Tailored to Korean tastes and customs, they offer a unique blend of international and local design elements.

site_title: Evergrande faces final chance to avoid liquidation by HK court
summary: Evergrande, the world's most indebted developer, faces a final chance to avoid liquidation by a Hong Kong court. The company must present a concrete debt restructuring plan by Monday's hearing, or it will likely be wound up, leading to further chaos in its operations and the housing market. A group of offshore creditors, holding over $6 billion of Evergrande's offshore notes, demands controlling equity stakes in the developer, potentially complicating the restructuring process.

site_title: US dollar dips on dovish remarks by Fed chief
summary: The US dollar fell on December 1, following a two-day gain, after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell made dovish remarks on interest rate moves, signaling the Fed may be done raising rates. Powell stated US monetary policy is slowing the economy as expected, with a benchmark overnight interest rate "well into restrictive territory." This led to a 64% chance of a rate cut by the March meeting, according to US rate futures, as investors priced in expectations of earlier cuts next year.

Without an available or affordable childcare option, it is impossible to find a job, or to keep it, while the country is experiencing a significant shortage of labour. site_title: China frames ‘one province, one policy’ plan for financial risk
summary: China's regulator is framing a "one province, one policy" plan to manage financial risks, according to Li Yunze, head of the National Financial Regulatory Administration. This approach will allow provinces to devise their own policies to handle risks, rather than a one-size-fits-all approach. The move comes as China struggles with debt issues and a property crisis, prompting central and local authorities to provide successive waves of support. The plan aims to prevent major risks, deepen market rectification, and protect consumers' rights.

images.alt_text: People wade through flood waters at the Shenzhen Bus Station in Shenzhen, in China's Guangdong province on Sept 8, 2023, after the city recorded the heaviest rains since records began in 1952.

site_title: Yet another private college in New York is closing
summary: The College of Saint Rose, a private Roman Catholic school in Albany, New York, will close after the current academic year due to financial struggles. The college has $54 million of outstanding municipal-bond debt and will no longer make interest payments to investors. The school's decision comes as multiple colleges in the northeastern US have shut down due to declining enrollment. The closure will leave the 48-acre campus vacant, with options to sell assets being unsuccessful. The school's chairman attributed the closure to the decline in high school graduates and less demand for teaching programs.

images.alt_text: Concern over a potential renewed bout of inflation is likely to keep the Federal Open Market Committee forecasting much higher interest rates in 2024 than the four quarter-point cuts priced in by markets.

New York Fed president John Williams expects inflation to end this year at 3 per cent, and ebb to 2.25 per cent in 2024, as economic growth slows to 1.25 per cent and unemployment rises to 4.25 per cent.

site_title: Heirs beat self-made billionaires for first time: survey
summary: For the first time since 2014, new billionaires have inherited more wealth than self-made billionaires, according to a UBS survey. In 2023, 53 heirs joined the billionaire list, accumulating $150.8 billion, while 84 self-made billionaires had $140.7 billion. This shift is part of a larger trend, with over 1,000 billionaires expected to pass on $5.2 trillion to the next generation over the next 20-30 years.

images.alt_text: Second-generation billionaires want to enable their descendants to benefit from their wealth and grow what their forebears had achieved.
Kirkbi's assets have swelled to about 166 billion kroner, mainly driven by rising profits at Lego, which has grown to become the world’s largest toy company.

site_title: NYC realtors are grappling over who will pay commissions
summary: New York City real estate agents are grappling with a shift in commission structures due to lawsuits challenging the current system. The Real Estate Board of New York (Rebny) has changed its policy, requiring buyer's agents to be compensated directly by sellers or negotiate their pay with buyers. This change comes as the market struggles with high mortgage rates and low inventory, with Manhattan home sales down 23% in the third quarter. Agents face uncertainty and potential turnover as they adjust to the new policy, which could lead to lower commissions in the future.

images.alt_text: The agreement encourages agents to adopt a best practice guide for co-broking commissions from July 1, 2024.

site_title: MAS finalises taxonomy on sustainable and transition financing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a key sustainable finance framework, the Singapore-Asia Taxonomy for Sustainable Finance, which defines eligible economic activities across eight sectors for green and brown-to-green funding. The taxonomy sets criteria for transition activities, including energy, real estate, and transportation, and aims to reduce the risk of green or transition washing. MAS managing director Ravi Menon stated that the taxonomy will help provide clarity on sustainable and transition financing, increasing taxonomy-aligned financing solutions and facilitating sustainable development in markets. The framework is the first in the world to comprehensively define transition activities across eight sectors, and Singapore joins three other countries in South-east Asia in releasing finalised taxonomies for sustainable financing.

site_title: More climate philanthropies considering South-east Asia expansion
summary: Major philanthropies are expanding into South-east Asia, with nearly three-quarters of funders already working on philanthropic public-private partnerships (PPPPs) in the region. The report, launched at COP28, found that Indonesia is the top destination for philanthropies, while the Philippines and Cambodia are growing areas of interest. The sector of food and agriculture decarbonisation is gaining interest, with 14 funders looking to expand into it. The report identified four key characteristics of successful PPPPs, including aligning system-wide strategy and values, building win-win-win collaborations, adopting innovative financing approaches, and prioritizing people-centric capacity building.

images.alt_text: Coal-fired power plants are responsible for nearly 60 per cent of Asia's power generation and the livelihoods of millions. Thus, decarbonising the region needs to be done in a balanced manner to ensure continued energy accessibility and security.
The 2022 GSIA review shows that investors had US$30.3 trillion in sustainable assets, down from US$35.3 trillion in 2020.

site_title: ‘Foreign terrorists’ behind deadly Philippine bombing: officials
summary: A deadly bombing during a Catholic Mass in a university gymnasium in Marawi, Philippines, killed at least four people and injured 50 others. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. blamed "foreign terrorists" for the attack, with Defence Secretary Gilberto Teodoro stating there were "strong indications" of a foreign element. The blast followed a series of military operations against local pro-Islamic State groups in the southern Philippines, and it's possible the attack was retaliatory. The government has strengthened security and launched investigations to bring the perpetrators to justice.

images.alt_text: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) says Binance is not registered in the Philippines and therefore not authorised to sell or offer securities in the country.

site_title: Even Opec output cuts are powerless to stop oil’s 6-week slide
summary: Oil prices dropped for a sixth straight week, with the US benchmark closing 2.5% lower to near $74 a barrel. Opec+ announced 900,000 barrels a day of output cuts, but the move was deemed insufficient to dispel market concerns over swelling global supplies. The alliance's cuts are voluntary, with Angola rejecting its quota, and algorithmic selling played a significant role in the price decline. The US oil rig count increased, signaling a continued increase in US output, and Brazil will join the Opec+ alliance cooperation charter but won't participate in production cuts.

images.alt_text: With the surge in output, gasoline prices have fallen by close to US$2 a gallon since summer 2022 and are back to levels that prevailed in 2021.

site_title: Real estate euphoria highlights trader angst for end to rate hikes
summary: Real estate stocks surged 12% in November, outperforming the S&P 500, as investors bet on potential rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The sector's momentum was fueled by a pullback in Treasury yields and optimism about the end of interest-rate hikes. Despite battered office landlord stocks, the Reit sector is seen as a bright spot, with Bank of America predicting it will be a top performer in 2024, calling it "diamond in the rough."

site_title: At COP28, Al Gore takes aim at host UAE’s emissions
summary: Former US Vice President Al Gore criticized the UAE at COP28 for not disclosing its true emissions, citing data from Climate Trace, a satellite-based emissions tracker. The UAE's greenhouse gas emissions rose 7.5% in 2022, compared to a 1.5% increase globally. Gore singled out the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company for allegedly claiming no emissions from oil and gas transport. Gore praised a pledge by 50 oil and gas companies to reach "near zero" methane emissions, but warned they must comply. To consider COP28 a success, countries must commit to phasing out fossil fuels.

site_title: Consumer-focused startups in South-east Asia need laser-sharp focus to attract funding
summary: Consumer-focused startups in South-east Asia need to prioritize their strategy and marketing to attract funding in a competitive market. With changing consumption habits, companies must consider values like sustainability, affordability, and personalization to resonate with younger consumers. Venture funding for consumer startups has fallen 79.1% in the Asia-Pacific region, mirroring global trends. To compete, brands must tailor their growth strategies to each market segment, consider expanding their "essentials" range, and adopt social and environmental practices. Despite challenges, investors remain optimistic about the opportunities for venture capital in the region, citing its young population and growing discretionary spending.

site_title: Why is it so hard to say ‘I don’t know’ at work?
summary: A workplace fear, saying "I don't know", is rooted in cultural and self-imposed pressures. Product designer Tobias van Schneider found relief in admitting uncertainty, stating it felt "refreshing". Several factors contribute to this fear, including fear of appearing incompetent, pressure to provide solutions, and a culture that values certainty. By examining these factors, it may be possible to create a safe context for employees to express uncertainty, potentially leading to improved collaboration and decision-making.

site_title: Toyota says it halts some Tianjin operations after report of partial suspension
summary: Toyota has halted production on some ageing lines at its joint venture in Tianjin, China, due to weak sales of gasoline-engine cars. The move, which is part of a daily production adjustment, is not a full suspension of operations. The halt affects the joint venture with China's FAW, but normal operations continue. This adjustment follows a report by Japan's Jiji news service that Toyota was suspending production in response to weak sales. The move is part of a larger challenge Toyota faces in China, which accounted for nearly 20% of its worldwide sales in the first 10 months of the year.

site_title: Wall Street week ahead-tax-loss selling, ‘Santa rally’ could sway US stocks after November melt-up
summary: US stocks are poised for a potentially volatile final week of 2023, with investors watching for tax-loss selling and the "Santa Claus rally" that typically occurs in December. The S&P 500 has gained 19.6% year-to-date, but some underperforming stocks may face pressure from tax-loss selling, with analysts recommending buys for certain shares. The Federal Reserve's monetary policy trajectory will also be closely watched, with some speculating a rate cut as early as 2024.

site_title: US Navy, UK, Australia will test AI system to help crews track Chinese submarines in the pacific
summary: The US, UK, and Australia will test an AI system to track Chinese submarines in the Pacific, utilizing sonar data from underwater devices on P-8A Poseidon aircraft. This technology aims to enhance anti-submarine warfare capabilities and counter China's rapid military modernization. The joint test is part of the Aukus Pillar II agreement, focusing on cooperation in eight technological areas, including quantum technologies and advanced cybersecurity. The alliance seeks to bolster its capabilities in the face of China's growing global assertiveness.

site_title: Honduras coffee exports soar 62.7% on shipping commitments
summary: Honduras' coffee exports surged 62.7% in November, reaching 84,650 60-kilo bags, driven by previously agreed shipping commitments. This represents a 17.9% increase from the same period last year. The exports were largely made up of "carry over" coffee from the previous harvest, as the current harvest has been delayed due to rains. Honduras aims to export 4,983,333 60-kilo bags in the 2023-2024 harvest.

site_title: Hong Kong cuts public housing waiting time to boost birth rates
summary: Hong Kong has reduced the waiting time for public housing applicants with newborn babies to two years from three, effective Dec 2, in an effort to support birth rates. Families with children born on or after Oct 25 qualify for Category A tenancy, while the three-year requirement remains unchanged for other applicants. The change aims to promote fertility and create a childbearing environment, helping families with newborns to break away from difficulties and improve their quality of life.

site_title: Charlie Munger and the fading art of the second banana
summary: Charlie Munger, the vice-chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, passed away at 99, and his legacy will be celebrated for his business acumen and aphorisms. However, his role was not that of a traditional "second banana" but rather a strong-willed and independent operating executive who turned down the CEO position to run challenging companies. Munger's hands-on approach and ability to build Berkshire into a successful conglomerate will be remembered as a key factor in his enduring legacy.

site_title: Xi takes flurry of small steps to open China after US trip
summary: China has taken several market access concessions since President Xi Jinping's meeting with US leader Joe Biden, aiming to restore foreign investors' confidence. These include approving a Mastercard joint venture, green lighting a large technology merger, and announcing visa-free access to China for six countries. The moves signal Xi's determination to reinvigorate investor confidence, following a year of efforts to address concerns about policy swings, trade probes, and a national security drive. While small steps may not fully address concerns, they could reassure investors and improve relations with the US and other countries.

site_title: Britain yet to make the case for a digital pound, lawmakers say
summary: UK lawmakers say the Bank of England and Treasury should keep an open mind on introducing a digital pound due to costs involved. A digital pound is unlikely to be available in large sums initially to avoid bank runs. Lawmakers recommend a smaller limit initially to mitigate risks and suggest that any primary legislation introducing a digital pound should not allow authorities to use data for purposes beyond law enforcement. The report highlights concerns over cash and user privacy.

site_title: Singapore will buy credible carbon credits from coal plant closures
summary: Singapore has announced its intention to buy carbon credits from coal plant closures, provided they meet environmental integrity standards. The decision is part of its nationally determined contributions to address climate change, with the goal of accelerating the energy transition while ensuring sustainable socio-economic development. Singapore plans to purchase transition credits to meet its climate targets and companies can also offset up to 5% of taxable emissions beginning 2024.

site_title: Exxon among 50 oil producers in controversial climate pact at COP28
summary: At the COP28 climate summit, 50 oil and gas producers, including Exxon and Saudi Arabia's Aramco, pledged to cut methane emissions to near zero by 2030 and stop routine flaring of natural gas. The deal, known as the Oil and Gas Decarbonisation Charter, is non-binding but requires signatories to submit a plan by 2025. The agreement aims to reduce global oil production emissions and is seen as a step forward by COP president Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber, who believes oil and gas will remain part of the energy system for decades to come. However, many activists criticized the pledge as insufficient and called for a legally binding package to phase out all fossil fuels.
