site_title: Why Trust Wallet, the Binance founder-owned crypto app, is looking to the UAE
summary: Trust Wallet, a cryptocurrency app co-owned by Binance founder Changpeng Zhao (CZ), is shifting its operations to the United Arab Emirates (UAE), citing favorable regulatory conditions. The company has 56 million downloads globally and plans to expand in countries like India, Pakistan, and Southeast Asia. Trust Wallet's CEO, Eowyn Chen, aims to make Asia a high-priority growth market, and the company is basing its operations in Ras Al Khaimah, a free trade zone with flexible corporate treatment for web3 companies. The move is seen as a diversification of risk management for the company amid regulatory challenges in the US.

site_title: S-Reits rebound 7.4 per cent in November, best month in 3 years
summary: The S-Reit Index in Singapore rebounded 7.4% in November, its best month in three years, reversing a 7.0% decline in October. The iEdge S-Reit Index now has a year-to-date decline of 2.2%, with four trusts maintaining double-digit total return gains: Digital Core Reit (19.6%), Frasers Hospitality Trust (19.2%), Aims Apac Reit (10.7%), and Far East Hospitality Trust (10.2%). This rebound is attributed to signals from the US Federal Reserve that rate hikes are likely over, with similar performance seen across major Reit markets.

images.alt_text: ParkwayLife Reit reported that its 9M2023 gross revenue increased 24.6 per cent yoy to S$110.9 million.

site_title: COP28 lines up new climate pledges - but do they work?
summary: At COP28, world leaders have made new climate pledges, including a goal to triple renewable energy capacity and initiatives on methane and coal power. Voluntary side deals, which don't require consensus among nearly 200 countries, have proliferated, with some pledges showing stronger action against climate change. However, experts warn that unfulfilled pledges risk undermining trust in core UN climate negotiations. Examples of successful pledges include the global methane pledge, which has raised the profile of the potent greenhouse gas, and the halt on international fossil fuel finance, which has shifted billions away from fossil fuels toward clean energy.

site_title: Israeli strikes rock Gaza for second day after truce collapse
summary: Israel launched deadly airstrikes in Gaza for a second day after a week-long truce with Hamas collapsed. Nearly 200 people, mostly civilians, have been killed, according to the Hamas-run health ministry. Both sides blame each other for breaking the truce, with Israel claiming Hamas tried to fire a rocket before the truce ended. International leaders, including the UN Secretary General, condemned the return to fighting, calling it a "humanitarian catastrophe." Mediation efforts by Qatar and Egypt are ongoing, and the US is working with regional partners to reach another ceasefire.

site_title: India’s construction sector levels up as housing demand spurs economy
summary: India's construction sector experienced a 13.3% growth in the July to September quarter, its best performance in five quarters, driven by rising incomes and a severe housing shortage. The sector's robust growth contributed to the country's 7.6% expansion, outpacing Western economies and China's struggling property sector. The urban housing shortage is expected to double by 2030, with demand for homes in big cities and smaller towns increasing due to salary hikes and government subsidies.

site_title: Trump denied immunity against US election subversion charges
summary: US District Judge Tanya Chutkan ruled that Donald Trump is not entitled to absolute presidential immunity against criminal charges related to his efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election. The judge rejected Trump's motions to dismiss the case, including claims that he could not be prosecuted for actions taken after the election. Trump's legal team plans to appeal the decision, potentially taking the issue to the US Supreme Court. A trial in the federal election obstruction case against Trump is set to begin on March 4.

images.alt_text: The decision leaves open the possibility that Trump could still prevail in his immunity claims.

A billboard in Helena, Montana, Aug 15, 2023. A federal judge in Montana has blocked a statewide ban of TikTok from taking effect next year, at least temporarily preventing the nation's first such prohibition on the popular video app.
An appeals court on November 30, 2023 reimposed a limited gag order on former president Donald Trump intended to protect court staff at his New York civil fraud trial after a flood of online abuse.

site_title: Investors yank money out of ETFs tracking inflation-protected bonds
summary: Investors have withdrawn $2.2 billion from five major exchange-traded funds tracking US Treasury's inflation-protected securities in November, the largest monthly outflow since October 2022. This comes as inflation pressures moderate in the US, with a recent index showing a 3.5% rise in nominal Treasury bonds, its best since 2008. Softening inflation and a slowing economy have led the bond market to price in Fed easing, with traders expecting a rate cut as early as March.

site_title: Give yourself the gift of selling your losers
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean transportation company, is being considered for sale by its investor due to its poor performance. The author, a long-time bus driver, had initially considered investing in the company but now believes it's time to cut losses. The article suggests that investors should review their portfolios and sell underperforming stocks, such as ComfortDelGro, to reassess their investment goals.

site_title: Indonesia approves delayed Abadi Masela gas revised development plan
summary: Indonesia has approved a revised development plan for the Abadi Masela gas project, a long-delayed project with $20 billion in investment, targeting production to start in 2029. The project, led by Japanese oil and gas company Inpex, has faced years of delay due to changes and changes in contractors. The revised plan includes a carbon capture and storage component, and the project is expected to produce 9.5 million tonnes of LNG per year.

site_title: Vietnam probes central bank’s handling of credit growth: media
summary: Vietnam's government has launched an investigation into the central bank's handling of credit growth in 2022 and 2023, following a request from Deputy Prime Minister Le Minh Khai. The probe aims to improve the State Bank's timely and efficient management of credit growth. As the country seeks to boost its export-dependent economy, Vietnam's loan growth was at 7.39% at the end of October, exceeding the government's 2023 credit growth goal of 14-15%. The investigation will be completed by January.

site_title: Uber to become S&P 500 constituent
summary: Uber Technologies will join the S&P 500, replacing Sealed Air Corp, Alaska Air Group, and SolarEdge Technologies, effective Monday, Dec 4. This marks Uber's entry into the benchmark index, alongside Jabil and Builders FirstSource, which will also join the S&P MidCap 400 index.

site_title: Israel’s next aim is Southern Gaza, US urges restraint
summary: Israel resumes airstrikes in southern Gaza, targeting areas where Hamas' top leadership is believed to be hiding, amid pressure from the US to limit civilian deaths and destruction. The US has urged Israel to consider restricting combat operations to protect civilians, and has proposed creating "deconfliction areas" where Palestinians can shelter. However, Israel has distributed a map of the Al-Mawasi zone, where a proposed "humanitarian zone" was discussed, leaving Palestinians uncertain about where to go. The UN has opposed the idea of a safe zone, citing concerns about civilian safety.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - An International Red Cross vehicle reportedly carrying hostages released by Hamas crosses the Rafah border point in the Gaza Strip towards Egypt from where they would be flown to Israel to be reunited with their families, on November 24, 2023. After 48 days of gunfire and bombardment that claimed thousands of lives, a four-day truce in the Israel-Hamas war began on November 24 with 50 hostages set to be released in exchange for 150 Palestinian prisoners. (Photo by MOHAMMED ABED / AFP)

site_title: Brands are critical in shaping the world’s net-zero journey
summary: A new UN report warns of a 2.5-2.9°C temperature rise this century, with only a 14% chance of limiting warming to 1.5°C. To mitigate this, businesses must adopt circular and regenerative practices, with marketing playing a pivotal role in shifting consumer behavior and lifestyles. A recent study by dentsu and Kantar found that businesses can generate significant positive change by leveraging their influence on consumer motivation and behaviors. However, many companies struggle to justify investment in sustainability efforts, and marketing departments lag behind other divisions in working towards sustainability goals.

images.alt_text: When local bank DBS chose top Indian badminton players to bear its logo, this sparked social media discussions on whether they should have backed Singapore players such as Loh Kean Yew instead.
The Food and Agriculture Organisation's net zero plan for food calls on wealthy nations to eat less meat, while beefing up productivity and sustainability in livestock practices.

The Porsche Design tower; the market for name-brand luxury condominium units is projected to grow 12 per cent each year between now and 2026, according to a report from global real estate consultants Knight Frank

site_title: Climate change drives new cases of Malaria, complicating efforts to fight the disease
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reported an estimated 249 million cases of malaria globally in 2023, a significant increase of 5 million over 2021. Malaria remains a top killer of children, with new cases concentrated in five countries: Pakistan, Nigeria, Uganda, Ethiopia, and Papua-New Guinea. Climate change was a direct contributor in three of these countries, including Pakistan, where massive flooding led to a fivefold increase in malaria transmission after 3.1 million confirmed cases in 2022. The WHO attributes the surge to the rapid multiplication of mosquitoes following the floods.

images.alt_text: A medical laboratory scientist preparing blood samples for the extraction of DNA at Tan Tock Seng Hospital on Aug 15, 2023. ST PHOTO: KEVIN LIM lypharm
The second Sustainable Development Goals summit in New York. Progress on the goals is happening at less than a quarter of the pledged speed.
Bangladeshi boatmen navigate through dense water hyacinths on the Buriganga river in Dhaka. Eastern Africa's Lake Victoria has been similarly infested with this invasive plant species.

site_title: US to limit China’s ability to benefit from electric vehicle industry
summary: The US government has proposed new rules to shift more electric vehicle battery production to the US, limiting Chinese firms' ability to benefit from the industry. The rules, set to kick in in 2024, will restrict companies from sourcing materials from China or Russia for vehicles eligible for federal tax credits. Chinese companies that set up operations outside China will be exempt, as long as the Chinese government is not a significant shareholder. The rules aim to build up a US supply chain, which currently relies heavily on China for materials and components, and could encourage shifts in automotive supply chains.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor Company's electric F-150 Lightning on the production line at their Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan on September 8, 2022. (Photo by JEFF KOWALSKY / AFP) (Photo by JEFF KOWALSKY/AFP via Getty Images)

site_title: Larry Summers says OpenAI technology ‘extraordinarily important’
summary: Larry Summers, former US Treasury Secretary, has joined OpenAI's board, calling the company's work "extraordinarily important" and emphasizing the need for it to operate with "a conscience." He plans to work on regulatory and national security issues, and to cooperate with government officials. Summers, who also predicted AI could replace some white-collar jobs, said he has no immediate plan for governing the company safely, noting he has only been on the job two days.

site_title: Former PM of Congo Henri Lopes, who straddled literature and politics in Africa, dies at 86
summary: Former Prime Minister of the Republic of Congo Henri Lopes, a renowned writer and politician, has died at 86. Lopes' dual career spanned the formative years of African nationhood and the continent's literature, earning him prestigious literary prizes and high positions in politics and diplomacy. He passed away on November 2 in a Paris suburb, according to the Republic of Congo's Embassy in Paris.

images.alt_text: Wild white rhinos are seen at an undisclosed location in the North-West Province of South Africa, on April 2, 2023. - South Africa is home to nearly 80 percent of the world's rhinos, making it a hotspot for poaching driven by demand from Asia, where horns are used in traditional medicine for their supposed therapeutic effect. The government said 448 of the endangered animals were killed across the country last year, only three fewer than in 2021, despite increased protection efforts at national parks, such as the renowned Kruger. (Photo by Luca Sola / AFP)

Last month, Ramaphosa led a seven-country African peace delegation including representatives from the Republic of Congo, Egypt, Senegal and Uganda, in a historic attempt to broker peace between Kyiv and Moscow.
Malaria remains a top killer of children.

site_title: Amazon to hire rival SpaceX to launch internet satellites
summary: Amazon has signed a contract with SpaceX to launch its internet-from-space satellites into orbit, relying on the company's main rival for additional capacity. The deal, set to begin in mid-2025, comes after a series of testing failures and issues with launch partners delayed flights. Amazon's Project Kuiper aims to deliver internet service from low-Earth orbit with a 3,236-satellite constellation, while SpaceX's Starlink already has roughly 5,000 satellites in orbit.

images.alt_text: Meta can rely on thousands of developers across the world to help enhance its AI models by open-source its AI technology.
The 11 tech giants have promised to take tougher action within six months to block and remove scams, such as fake adverts and romance fraud, from their platforms.

(Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)
Costing US$20 monthly per user, Amazon Q will perform a variety of tasks including summarising uploaded documents and answering questions about specific data sitting on a company’s servers.

site_title: A tense climate summit begins against a backdrop of war and record heat
summary: World leaders gathered at the COP28 climate summit in Dubai, urging a rapid transition away from fossil fuels and towards clean energy to combat the effects of climate change. Despite dire warnings, global greenhouse gas emissions and fossil fuel demand continue to rise, putting the planet on track to warm at least 3°C. Key leaders, including US President Joe Biden and China's President Xi Jinping, were absent, but many leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and UN Secretary-General António Guterres, called for an end to coal, oil, and gas. A final agreement must be ratified by every country in attendance, with negotiators working to include language calling for a phase-out of fossil fuels.

World Bank says it will spend US$40 billion on climate-related projects, US$9 billion more than was previously programmed.

site_title: Japan to stop building ‘unabated’ coal plants: PM
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced at the UN's COP28 climate summit in Dubai that the country will stop building new coal-fired power plants without carbon emissions reduction measures, aligning with its goal to become carbon-neutral by 2050. This move aims to secure a stable energy supply while phasing out unabated coal power plants.

site_title: World Bank to operate ‘loss and damage’ climate fund
summary: The World Bank will manage the day-to-day operations of a new "loss and damage" climate fund, but donors and recipients will control how the money is spent. Over $400 million has been pledged initially, falling short of the $100 billion needed by developing nations to meet climate costs, but more pledges are expected. The fund was approved by nations at the UN's COP 28 climate summit in Dubai.

images.alt_text: World Bank says it will spend US$40 billion on climate-related projects, US$9 billion more than was previously programmed.
Dr Steve Howard, Chief Sustainability Officer, Temasek

site_title: Chairpersons of two Zhongzhi-linked listed companies go missing
summary: Two chairpersons of Zhongzhi-linked listed companies, Ma Hongying and Ma Changshui, have gone missing as Chinese authorities widen their investigation into the firm's wealth management units, which have left investors with billions of yuan in losses. Zhongzhi, a privately-owned company, has revealed severe financial difficulties, including a $36.4 billion shortfall, and dozens of suspects are being investigated by the police, including senior managers and core sales personnel. The investigation is related to the firms' money-losing bets, which have been uncovered due to a liquidity crisis.

images.alt_text: The Zhongzhi Enterprise Group office in Beijing. The firm, which has sizeable exposure to China’s real estate sector, is a major player in the country's US$3 trillion shadow banking sector.
During China’s real estate boom, many developers used Zhongzhi to finance their projects.

The Zhongrong International Trust Co. offices in Beijing, China, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. China's banking regulator has set up a taskforce to examine risks at Zhongzhi Enterprise Group Co., one of the nations top private wealth managers, after its unit Zhongrong missed payments on multiple high-yield investment products. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Appeals court rules that Jan 6 suits against Trump can proceed for now
summary: A federal appeals court has ruled that lawsuits seeking to hold former President Donald Trump accountable for the January 6, 2021, Capitol violence can proceed for now, rejecting his claim of immunity. The decision allows the civil cases to move forward, leaving open the possibility that Trump could still prevail in his immunity claims. The court's ruling does not definitively answer whether Trump's speech was an official presidential act or part of his reelection campaign, allowing Trump to present factual evidence to rebut the plaintiffs' claims.

images.alt_text: An appeals court on November 30, 2023 reimposed a limited gag order on former president Donald Trump intended to protect court staff at his New York civil fraud trial after a flood of online abuse.

Republican presidential candidate and former US President Donald Trump faces four criminal cases, including state and federal charges stemming from his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss to Democrat Joe Biden.
Donald Trump has yet to be removed from a single ballot as the political season unfolds in the United States.

site_title: Americans are finally turning frugal after splurging over summer
summary: The US economy has started to slow down, with Americans cutting back on discretionary spending such as cars, furniture, and gym memberships. The slowdown is attributed to high interest rates, dwindling savings, and a weaker consumer. Key data shows a decrease in personal spending, with Black Friday spending down and online purchases made using buy-now-pay-later schemes on Cyber Monday. Economists expect the economy to moderate in the fourth quarter and potentially enter a recession in 2024, with some forecasting 1.1% growth in the fourth quarter and 0.2% in the second quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, increases 0.2 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.7 per cent gain in September.

site_title: Moldova denounces new Russian ban on fruit imports
summary: Moldova has denounced a new Russian ban on imports of its fruit and vegetables, which took effect on Monday, as "groundless" and "contradicting phytosanitary principles." The ban, imposed by Russia's farm goods oversight agency, Rosselkhoznadzor, is the latest in a series of restrictions imposed by Moscow on Moldovan goods. Moldovan authorities claim the ban has nothing to do with the quality of the goods and that laboratory evidence shows no harmful organisms. The move has been seen as a sign of deteriorating relations between Moscow and the pro-European government in Moldova.

site_title: Global equity funds see fourth week of inflows on Fed rate cut hopes
summary: Global equity funds saw their fourth consecutive week of inflows, with a net US$2.25 billion poured in during the week ended Nov 29, according to LSEG data. The inflows were driven by optimism over potential Federal Reserve rate cuts, with Fed governor Christopher Waller stating that rate cuts could begin if inflation eases. However, US and Asian funds suffered outflows, while equity sector funds recorded their first weekly net selling in three. Global bond funds also drew in significant inflows, with US$2.4 billion added to global bond funds.

site_title: Startup raises US$17.5 million to bring AI to holiday shopping logistics
summary: Syrup, a startup using AI to optimize holiday shopping logistics, has raised $17.5 million in funding led by Accel, bringing its valuation close to $100 million. The company aims to reduce retail industry waste, particularly during the holiday season, by helping retailers manage inventory and predict demand. Syrup's software has already shown improvements for clients like Reformation, increasing stock availability from 70% to 90% and reducing inventory waste. The startup plans to hire more staff to expand its team to 70 employees by the end of next year.

site_title: Weight-loss drugs are a gold mine, and just as elusive
summary: Pfizer has dropped development of an experimental weight-loss pill after patients experienced uncomfortable side effects in clinical trials. The pill, which was seen as a potential game-changer in the weight-loss market, was expected to be easier to manufacture and transport than injections. However, its development was hindered by side effects, and shots from other companies, such as Ozempic and Mounjaro, remain highly profitable, projected to reach $100 billion in the next seven years.

site_title: US: Stocks extend recent rally into December trading
summary: US stocks extended their recent rally into December, with the S&P 500 reaching its highest level this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8% and the Nasdaq Composite Index increased 0.6%. Despite Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments that it's premature to speculate on rate cuts, Wall Street expects the Fed to start cutting interest rates in the first quarter of next year, with the S&P 500 now expecting a rate cut. This optimism led to gains in individual stocks such as Paramount and Ulta Beauty.

site_title: Stocks grind higher on interest rate expectations
summary: US and European stocks rose on Friday, December 1, driven by anticipation of lower interest rates as inflation wanes and economies slow. Despite Fed Chair Jerome Powell's caution, investors remain optimistic about rate cuts in 2024. The ongoing weakness in China's economy persists, despite measures to boost growth, and is expected to slow GDP growth. Market expectations remain high, with Citigroup targeting a 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend US$1.2 trillion rally as mining shares soar
summary: European stocks rose 1% on Friday, extending a US$1.2 trillion rally, with mining shares leading gains. The Stoxx 600 index reached a four-month high, driven by comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on interest rate cuts. Optimism around easing inflation and a peak in interest rates fueled the rally, with markets pricing in four quarter-point cuts for 2024. Despite some positive business activity news, strategists remain cautious about the rally extending into the year-end, citing an expected economic slowdown.

site_title: Surging US oil production brings down prices, raises climate fears
summary: US oil production has surged to a record 13.2 million barrels a day, driving down fuel prices and threatening to undercut climate efforts. Gasoline prices have fallen by nearly $2 a gallon since summer 2022, returning to levels in 2021. The increase in production has provided leverage for the Biden administration in dealings with oil-exporting countries, but poses risks of increasing fossil fuel demand and exacerbating climate change. Scientists warn that the world is far from achieving climate goals, and the US oil industry's comeback is seen as a conflicting goal of energy security and reducing emissions.

site_title: Oil prices fall more than 2% as investors wary of Opec+ cuts
summary: Oil prices fell more than 2% on Friday as investors reacted to OPEC+ production cuts, which removed around 2.2 million barrels per day from the global market. Despite the cuts, traders remain skeptical about compliance and the impact on the market, with some analysts warning of a "billowing cloud of confusion." The cuts come as global manufacturing activity remains weak, and oil prices have fallen from about $98 a barrel in late September. The US Federal Reserve also signaled a cautious approach to interest rates, while a truce between Israel and Hamas collapsed, leading to a resumption of the war in Gaza.

site_title:
Water sommeliers: A profession
that’s more than ‘still or sparkling’
summary: A growing number of experts, known as water sommeliers, are perfecting the art of hydration by assessing water's mineral composition, acidity, and other attributes. Certified water sommelier Sam Wu, a Singapore-based mineral water distribution business owner, recommends pairing specific waters with foods like lamb and beef due to their high mineral content. Unlike wine, the taste of water is more limited, relying on the palate rather than smell. Water sommeliers aim to educate consumers about the value of their drinking water, encouraging them to appreciate the nuances of their hydration.

images.alt_text: Sam Wu, a certified water sommelier, pays close attention to the mineral composition of various water brands.

site_title: China Aviation Oil appoints new executive chairman
summary: China Aviation Oil appoints 52-year-old Shi Yanliang as new executive chairman, replacing Gong Feng, who stepped down on Dec 15. Shi, a 52-year-old former chairman of China National Aviation Petrochemicals Pipeline, has also served as general manager at China Aviation Oil Import & Export. The change in leadership aligns with the company's aim of deepening senior management leadership, according to a statement.

site_title: Uni-Asia consortium wins tender to develop, operate Japan public work facilities project
summary: Uni-Asia Group's wholly-owned subsidiary, Uni-Asia Capital (Japan), has won a tender to develop and operate a private finance initiative project in Japan. The project, valued at 13.1 billion yen (S$118 million), will build a public facility using residual heat from a waste treatment plant, featuring a fitness centre, public park, pool, and bathhouse. Development is expected to begin in 2027, with the consortium operating the facility for 20 years. The project aligns with Uni-Asia's commitment to sustainable business practices and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

site_title: In a world of digital natives, businesses need to embrace discontinuous thinking
summary: The rise of digital natives, born after 1980, poses significant challenges for businesses, as they have different expectations and behaviors. With 75% of the global workforce expected to be digital natives within two years, companies must adapt to their new demands for customer service, user experience, and digital word of mouth. However, traditional corporate leaders, often from older generations, may not grasp the need for transformation, increasing the risk of obsolescence and failure. To survive, companies must solve old problems in new ways, embracing discontinuous thinking and innovative leaps in thinking, rather than just putting digital lipstick on an analogue pig.

site_title: US construction spending rises in October
summary: US construction spending rose 0.6% in October, exceeding expectations, driven by a 1.2% increase in residential construction and a 10.7% year-on-year gain. Single-family homebuilding surged 1.1%, ending nine straight quarters of decline. New construction is fueled by a shortage of previously owned homes, but high mortgage rates above 7% pose a challenge. Spending on multi-family housing projects fell 0.2%, while private non-residential structures and public projects saw slight increases.

images.alt_text: Pending home sales are down 6.6 per cent from a year earlier on an unadjusted basis.

site_title: Issue 77: MAS works out cost of a late start; COP28’s wild kick-off
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has analyzed the potential cost of climate transition, finding that a smooth transition scenario could result in credit costs of 1.63% of the banking sector's vulnerable portfolios, while an abrupt transition scenario could lead to 2.43%. The analysis suggests that starting climate action earlier can lower these costs. The MAS also found that banks' market portfolios could lose 2.2% in a smooth transition, and 3.1% in an abrupt transition. The findings highlight the need for swift climate action to mitigate financial sector costs.

site_title: Powell brushes off rate-cut speculation as Fed moves carefully
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed caution against premature interest-rate cuts, stating that the Fed will continue to move cautiously with borrowing costs at a 22-year high. Despite a slowing US economy and falling inflation rate, Powell said it would be premature to speculate on when policy might ease. The Fed is expected to leave interest rates steady at its December meeting, with projections suggesting rates at 5% by the end of next year.

New York Fed president John Williams expects inflation to end this year at 3 per cent, and ebb to 2.25 per cent in 2024, as economic growth slows to 1.25 per cent and unemployment rises to 4.25 per cent.

Federal Reserve President of Cleveland Loretta Mester pointed to cooling price pressures, adding that “there has been discernible progress on inflation even while the overall economy has remained relatively strong.”
Cutting inflation while avoiding a downturn, commonly known as a “soft landing,” is challenging, but the latest update from the US central bank suggests it could be on track.
US Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman said she expects to support additional tightening of monetary policy to return inflation to the central bank’s goal.

site_title: Vietnam launches financing framework for its energy transition
summary: Vietnam has launched a financing framework to support its transition to a low-carbon economy, with a total investment of US$15.8 billion, funded by developed nations and private-sector banks. The framework, known as the Resource Mobilisation Plan, aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 43.5% by 2030 and involves projects such as renewable energy, energy efficiency, and coal power plant transition. Developed nations will contribute US$8.08 billion, with private-sector banks providing US$7.7 billion in loans.

images.alt_text: The US and Vietnam have had a comprehensive strategic partnership – the highest rung in the South-east Asian nation’s diplomatic ladder – since September.

On the banks of the Saigon River, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.  The government's power development roadmap has planned for 39 per cent of the country's electricity to come from renewable sources by 2030, but the figure needs to hit 47 per cent for the country to obtain US$15.5 billion from outside sources.
The Suralaya coal-fired power plant in  Banten, Indonesia, is among the largest of its kind in the country and contributes to the hazardous smog in Jakarta.
A newly built floating solar power plant at Cirata Reservoir, West Java, in Indonesia. Currently, more than 99 per cent of Asean’s potential remains untapped, the report said.

site_title: Malaysia telcos sign deals to take up stakes in state 5G agency
summary: Malaysian telcos have signed deals to take up to 70% equity in state-owned 5G agency Digital Nasional (DNB) for approximately RM233 million each. The move aims to dismantle DNB's monopoly ahead of a planned switch to a dual network model. The government will retain a 30% share in DNB, while telcos will assist in reaching 80% network coverage by the end of the year, with some firms separating to form a second 5G network.

site_title: Myanmar ethnic minority fighters clash with military on major trade route
summary: Myanmar ethnic minority fighters from the Karen National Union clashed with the military on a major trade route to Thailand, blocking traffic and prompting evacuations in the town of Kawkareik in eastern Karen state. The fight occurred at dawn on a key Asia Highway connecting the Myawaddy trade hub to Yangon, the country's largest city. The conflict highlights ongoing tensions between the military and ethnic minority groups in Myanmar, which have battled the military since independence from Britain in 1948.

images.alt_text: A member of the Karenni Army rides a truck with sized weapons during a battle in Loikaw in Kayah State, Myanmar November 12, 2023. REUTERS/Stringer

Members of the ethnic rebel group Ta'ang National Liberation Army (TNLA) taking part in a training exercise in Shan State. An alliance of Myanmar ethnic armed groups is waging a lighting offensive against the military which analysts say is the biggest battlefield challenge to the junta since it seized power. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: Sats bags new uncommitted bilateral facilities worth S$204.5 million to generate cost savings
summary: SATS, an in-flight caterer and ground handler, has secured new uncommitted bilateral facilities worth S$204.5 million to help manage its debt load and generate cost savings. The facilities, totaling 25 million euros (S$36.4 million) and 33 million euros, were granted by ING Bank and MUFG Bank, respectively. SATS also has existing uncommitted banking facilities of about S$500 million. The move comes after the cancellation of an older revolving credit facility and a liability management exercise to refinance certain notes.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of a Singapore Airlines plane at Changi Airport Terminal 3 on July 9, 2022.
Sats said that cashflow would be optimised for 3Rs: repayment of debt, reinvestment (capital expenditure) and resumption of dividend.

The company said that the net proceeds from the programme will be used to refinance existing borrowings, finance potential acquisition and investment opportunities as well as working capital and capital expenditure requirements and other general corporate purposes.
Citi Research and CGS-CIMB have upgraded their recommendations Sats, while Phillip Securities has downgraded its call to "reduce".
Sats' revenue more than tripled to S$2.5 billion for H1 FY2024, up from S$804.5 million in H1 FY2023.

site_title: China AI chipmaker Biren gets 2 billion yuan funding pledge after US sanction: sources
summary: China's AI chipmaker Biren secured a 2 billion yuan funding pledge from Guangzhou government-backed investors after being blacklisted by the US in October. The company is considering a listing in Hong Kong and may establish operations in the territory. This funding comes as Chinese firms seek domestic alternatives to Nvidia's AI chips due to growing US curbs on semiconductor access. Biren is not the only Chinese AI chip startup to secure funding, with Moore Threads Intelligent Technology also raising hundreds of millions in yuan from investors.

images.alt_text: Google says it would now share its data with the research community, in the hopes of accelerating further breakthroughs in material discovery.
Investors see the Taiwanese MediaTek’s Dimensity 9300 chip as a game-changer that will help it to steal a march over Qualcomm.

site_title: Sri Lanka bondholders raise concerns over debt deal transparency
summary: Sri Lanka's bondholder group expressed concerns over the lack of transparency in the country's debt restructuring deal with official creditors, hindering their efforts to strike a compliant agreement. The group welcomes the $5.9 billion deal with creditor nations, but criticizes the lack of visibility on deals struck between the country and private creditors. This lack of transparency makes it difficult for the group to negotiate a "fair and equitable" debt treatment, as required by IMF rules. The group remains committed to reaching an agreement with Sri Lankan authorities.

images.alt_text: People gather around readymade clothing stalls to buy clothes ahead of the Sinhala and Tamil New Year festival, in Colombo, Sri Lanka April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: Eurozone factory downturn eased a touch in November: PMI
summary: The Eurozone manufacturing sector's downturn eased slightly in November, with the final PMI rising to 44.2 from 43.1 in October. The sector remains in contractionary territory, with factories trimming staffing levels for a sixth consecutive month. Output and backlogs of work improved, but demand declined for a 19th month, and employment dropped to a low not seen since August 2020. The slight improvement does not signal an upward trend, and experts warn that the sector's contractionary territory could heighten stability risks from future interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: People pass by the Europa-Center shopping mall, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Berlin, Germany, December 14, 2020. REUTERS/Michele Tantussi/Files

(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: People walk past discount signs on a store's front window in Nice on the eve of the start of summer sales in France, June 27, 2023.    REUTERS/Eric Gaillard/File Photo

“The aggregate fiscal stance for the euro area is projected to be contractionary in 2024 on the back of an almost complete phase out of the remaining energy-related measures,” the European Commission says.

site_title: High-net-worth individuals leave their wealth at risk without succession planning
summary: High-net-worth individuals and families are increasingly prioritizing succession planning to protect their wealth for future generations. Despite 70% of families in the Asia-Pacific region having some form of a succession plan, many remain informally agreed upon or unwritten. Proactive planning with expert guidance can help achieve legacy goals, safeguard assets, and ensure the financial well-being of families. A thoughtful legacy plan goes beyond passing wealth to create an opportunity to pass on family values, traditions, and aspirations, bringing assurance and meaning to the wealth and assets individuals intend to pass on.

images.alt_text: The transfer of wealth for Asia's UHNW families is a precursor to a paradigm shift for the region's wealth management industry.
Lack of legacy and succession planning can hurt businesses, family harmony
Creating a legacy for loved ones in an unpredictable market

site_title: Meta says there’s been no downside to sharing AI technology
summary: Meta Platforms executives stated that sharing its AI technology has no major drawbacks, despite peers' cautious approach. The company has released open-source versions of its large language models, allowing thousands of developers worldwide to enhance its AI models, potentially leading to faster improvements. This approach contrasts with companies like OpenAI and Google's DeepMind, which keep their models closed. Meta plans to charge select companies for using its models, but CEO Mark Zuckerberg expects limited revenue in the near term.

images.alt_text: BEUC says it is likely that Meta users’ data would continue to be collected and used for other purposes even if they select the new service.
Meta will take a bigger share of device sales, while Tencent will get more of the content and service revenue.
The rules will require advertisers to disclose when AI or other digital tools are used in Facebook or Instagram ads on social issues, elections or politics.

site_title: India’s Adani Group plans 7 trillion rupees infra spend over next decade
summary: India's Adani Group plans to spend 7 trillion rupees (S$112.4 billion) over the next decade on infrastructure projects, according to chief financial officer Jugeshinder Singh. The conglomerate, led by billionaire Gautam Adani, will also consider divesting its 44% stake in Adani Wilmar, a joint venture with Singapore's Wilmar International, within the next three months. The company's cost of funds remains stable despite recent allegations of debt levels and tax haven use, with a weighted average cost of capital between 9.25-9.50%.

images.alt_text: Gautam Adani has denied wrongdoing, saying that Indian authorities assessed its coal shipments before releasing them from ports.
Colombo’s port is one of the busiest in the Indian Ocean, given its proximity to the international shipping routes.

The potential capital raising adds to evidence the conglomerate has at least partially rebuilt investor confidence after being thrown into a tailspin by allegations of malpractice by short-seller Hindenburg Research.
Adani Enterprises posts net income of 2.28 billion rupees (US$37.3 million) for the quarter through September.
Adani New Industries, a wholly owned subsidiary of flagship company Adani Enterprises, will take the lead raising the money from domestic and international banks.

site_title: New Silkroutes former directors, executives found to have helped company sidestep rules: SGX RegCo
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has found that New Silkroutes' former directors and executives helped the company circumvent listing rules. An independent reviewer, KPMG, reported that certain transactions were not in compliance with the rules. The findings are a result of KPMG's review of the company's financial statements for 2020. SGX RegCo does not condone these actions and has taken a regulatory stance against the circumvention of rules. This marks a significant development for the company, which has faced regulatory scrutiny in the past.

images.alt_text: New Silkroutes places two of its units into creditors' voluntary liquidation.
Goh Jin Hian, the former chief executive officer of New Silkroutes Group, is charged for false trading.
New Silkroutes Group says its proposed investment is an opportunity to enter China's transportation industry.

site_title: Google pushes for antitrust action against Microsoft in UK cloud market
summary: Google has called on Britain's antitrust regulator to take action against Microsoft, alleging its licensing practices unfairly discouraged customers from using competitor services in the UK cloud market. Microsoft's licensing restrictions limited customers' ability to use rival cloud services, even as a secondary provider, with Google claiming it left UK customers with no economically reasonable alternative but to use Azure. Google made six recommendations to the CMA, including forcing Microsoft to improve interoperability and banning it from withholding security updates from those that switch.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sundar Pichai, CEO of Google, reacts during a meeting with U.S. President Joe Biden, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and senior officials and CEOs of American and Indian companies in the East Room of the White House in Washington, U.S., June 23, 2023. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein/File Photo

site_title: British property prices rise unexpectedly for a third month
summary: British property prices rose 0.2% in November, marking a third consecutive month of gains, with the average home value increasing to $326,870. Economists had expected a 0.4% drop, but a decrease in borrowing costs is believed to have revived housing market activity. The housing market defies forecasts for a correction, with prices now 5.6% below the August 2022 peak. This suggests confidence in the market that interest rates won't exceed 6%, supporting modest rises in activity in the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: epa10695346 A picture taken with a drone shows houses in east London, Britain, 16 June 2023. House prices across the UK fell by 1 percent on average, first annual decline since December 2012, according to Halifax Mortgages. UK mortgage rates are heading up towards 6 percent interest rates and higher borrowing costs are adding to the burden on homeowners with the biggest mortgage squeeze since 1991.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN

Terraced residential housing in Sheffield, UK, on Friday, May 19, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK CPI Inflation data on Wednesday. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: Record high gold prices add to post-festival lull in India demand
summary: Indian gold dealers offered discounts of up to $9 an ounce due to a post-festival slowdown in demand, with record high prices reaching 62,675 rupees per 10 grams. This has led to a slowdown in other Asian hubs, with China, Hong Kong, and Singapore seeing increased premiums. However, some analysts believe a positive trend for gold premiums is expected in the coming year due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory and escalating geopolitical and economic risks.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.2 per cent at US$2,039.63 per ounce by 0301 GMT on Friday, after marking an over US$60 rise in November - its second straight monthly rise.
Spot gold rose 0.2 per cent to US$2,044.53 per ounce by 0453 GMT after hitting its highest since May 5.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 1)
summary: Temasek, Singapore's state investor, will divest from carbon-intensive portfolio companies if it can't see a viable way to reduce emissions. OCBC has filed a claim against money laundering accused Su Baolin for a mortgaged Sentosa Cove villa. Frasers Property plans to tear down Bedok Point mall after 11 years, replacing it with a 17-storey residential-commercial hybrid. GXBank has launched as Malaysia's first digital bank, while VTAC shareholders will redeem nearly all capital ahead of a combination with 17Live. Singapore stocks ended 0.6% higher amid mixed regional trading.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower ahead of Powell’s remarks
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday ahead of Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's remarks, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 36.44 points, or 0.10%, to 35,914.45. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, opening 8.37 and 44.86 points lower, respectively. Investors are awaiting Powell's comments on interest rates, which may provide insight into the central bank's path.

site_title: US manufacturing stays depressed in November: ISM
summary: US manufacturing remained depressed in November, with the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) manufacturing PMI staying below 50 for the 13th consecutive month, indicating a contraction in manufacturing. The PMI reading of 46.7 was unchanged from the previous month, and economists had forecast a slight increase to 47.6. The contraction in manufacturing is a concern, as it suggests the overall economy continues to expand at a 5.2% annualized rate, but the ISM's definition of a contraction (PMI below 48.7) has not been met.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers marry the body structure with the battery pack and the front and rear sub frames as they assemble electric vehicles at the Lucid Motors plant in Casa Grande, Arizona, U.S. September 28, 2021.  REUTERS/Caitlin O'Hara

site_title: World Bank to boost climate financing share to 45%, broaden climate debt clauses
summary: The World Bank has announced plans to boost its climate financing share to 45% by 2025, up from 35%, with a focus on climate-related projects worth US$40 billion annually. World Bank President Ajay Banga also extended debt repayment pauses for climate-disaster affected countries, covering principal and interest payments, and broadened climate debt clauses to cover all existing loans to the most vulnerable countries. This move aims to better respond to climate change and other global crises.

images.alt_text: The plan for starting up the loss and damage fund is one of three main negotiated outcomes COP28 is working to deliver over the next two weeks.

Attendees outside the entrance to the Blue Zone ahead of the COP28 climate conference at Expo City in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Nov 29, 2023. More than 70,000 politicians, diplomats, campaigners, financiers and business leaders are in  Dubai to talk about arresting the world's slide toward environmental catastrophe.
Singapore’s banking sector could incur credit costs that are about 50 per cent higher if the world’s climate transition is an abrupt instead of smooth one, says the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

Coal-fired power plants are responsible for nearly 60 per cent of Asia's power generation and the livelihoods of millions. Thus, decarbonising the region needs to be done in a balanced manner to ensure continued energy accessibility and security.

site_title: Grab shares dodge bullet after Meituan says it’s not keen on foodpanda: DBS
summary: Grab shares have corrected about 10% following the confirmation by Meituan that it is not interested in acquiring foodpanda, removing a key overhang from the Singapore-based super-app operator's stock price. DBS Group Research maintained a "buy" call and target price of US$4.26 for Grab, citing that the delivery-only business, excluding Indonesia and Vietnam, is a sub-scale business comprising 5-6% of China's delivery market. This news removes concerns about Meituan's potential acquisition, allowing Grab's stock to potentially rally.

images.alt_text: Meituan reports June-September revenue of 76.47 billion yuan (S$14.3 billion), versus 62.62 billion yuan in the same period a year earlier.

Jack Ma’s whereabouts and activities have been the topic of intense discussion since 2020, when he stepped away from the limelight after Beijing clamped down on his twin companies — Alibaba and Ant Group.
Maa wants to spend more time with his family.
Founded in 2010, Meituan has become the largest food delivery platform in China.
Grab remains a substantial business with about 35 million monthly users.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher amid mixed regional trading; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,090.31. Gainers outnumbered losers 300 to 273, driven by Venture Corp's 3.9% gain. The tech manufacturer plans to buy up to 10 million shares under its share-buyback plan. The STI was down 0.2% for the week. Regional indices showed mixed trading, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index falling, while the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index gained 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers slightly 56 to 53.
Venture’s board said the purchase of its shares, under the share buyback plan, will only be made in circumstances where it is considered to be in the best interests of the company.
Stocks on the reserve list will replace any constituents that become ineligible as a result of corporate actions before the next review.
The group, as one of the five private cord blood banks in Asia, has been barred from collecting, testing, processing and storing new cord-blood or tissue samples.

site_title: US to limit Chinese firms, battery parts from winning EV tax credits
summary: The US Treasury has issued guidance limiting Chinese content in batteries eligible for electric vehicle tax credits starting next year. The rules, required under an August 2022 law, aim to reduce US dependence on Chinese battery supplies. The US will temporarily exempt some critical minerals from new strict rules, allowing automakers to continue sourcing materials from countries deemed a "Foreign Entity of Concern." This move is seen as a win for automakers making investment decisions on producing batteries for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: As part of the partnership, Stellantis and CATL plan to build an LFP battery factory in Europe.
Across the six Gulf states, including oil majors Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, electric cars account for just 0.4 per cent of the passenger-vehicle market.

site_title: Beijing Capital hires Citi to sell Singapore waste company ECO in up to S$535 million deal: sources
summary: China's state-owned Beijing Capital Group hires Citigroup to sell its Singapore waste management company ECO in a deal that could fetch S$401 million to S$535 million. ECO, founded in 1997, provides waste management services in Singapore with a fleet of over 40 vehicles. The sale process is in its early stages, with potential buyers including private equity funds and companies in similar industries. This sale comes amid increasing investor interest in South-east Asia's waste management sector, driven by population growth and a shift towards greener energy and environment.

images.alt_text: The investment would be in the form of convertible dividend preference shares priced at 85,000 dong each.

site_title: GXBank launches as Malaysia’s first digital bank, offers debit card
summary: GXBank, Malaysia's first digital bank, has launched its app nationwide, offering a savings account and debit card. The bank, backed by Singapore's GXS Bank, commenced beta operations in September and is now open to the public. Despite regulatory limitations, GXBank faces a tough battle ahead, with only 5% of Malaysia's population expected to remain unbanked by 2020. Fitch Ratings estimates digital banks will not become major competitors to traditional banks within the next five years.

images.alt_text: GXBank is a subsidiary of GXS Bank – the digital bank joint venture between Grab and Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel), as well as a consortium of other Malaysian investors including Kuok Group.
Kearney Singapore's head of digital banking Nisha Paramjothi (third from left) said digital banks have a major role to play in promoting financial inclusion.
Customers of participating financial institutions in Singapore and Indonesia will now be able to make cross-border retail payments when making purchases.

site_title: Independent VTAC shareholders redeem nearly all capital, approve 17Live combination
summary: Independent shareholders of Vertex Technology Acquisition Corp (VTAC) have redeemed nearly 62.5% of the company's issued share capital, with 26 million shares exercised. The redemption rate, excluding two non-redeeming shareholders, would be 87.9%. The business combination with e-commerce streaming company 17Live was approved at an extraordinary general meeting with 95.5% in favor. This leaves 15.6 million shares remaining, which will be entitled to additional warrants.

images.alt_text: VTAC, led by non-executive chairman Chua Kee Lock,  has endorsed the merger, citing 17Live’s strong management, the potential for scale, and its alignment with Vertex Holdings’ areas of expertise.
The acquisition of 17Live by VTAC could be one of the most important new listings to hit the Singapore market in a long while
Phillip Securities says VTAC shareholders should redeem their shares at the price range of S$5 to S$5.02 apiece.
Phillip Securities says VTAC shareholders should redeem their shares at the price range of S$5 to S$5.02 apiece.
The expected completion of the deal would be on Dec 8, where the Spac will trade under the new name 17LIVE Group, if the transaction is successful.
It would be the first merger by a Singapore’s special purpose acquisition company.

site_title: Soaring Canadian housing costs power a population boom in Alberta
summary: Canada's housing costs are driving a population boom in Alberta, with the province's population surging 4.1% in the 12 months through June. Many residents, including Kealy, a teacher, are moving from British Columbia and Ontario due to affordable housing options, with international immigrants accounting for over 60% of the population increase. The influx is welcomed by businesses, which see it as insurance against labor shortages, and is driven by cheap housing, remote work, and the diversification of the economy. However, the surge is putting pressure on the healthcare system and driving up home prices in Calgary.

site_title: Apple, Paramount discuss bundling their streaming services: WSJ
summary: Apple and Paramount Global are reportedly discussing a bundled streaming service offering that would cost less than subscribing to both Paramount+ and Apple TV+ separately. The combined service would likely include both Paramount+ and Apple TV+ content. Shares of Paramount Global rose 3% in premarket trading following the news. No further details on the proposed pricing or launch timeline have been disclosed.

site_title: BYD has Tesla in its sights as EV and hybrid sales hit record
summary: BYD, a Chinese auto manufacturer, reported record electric and plug-in hybrid vehicle sales in November, reaching 301,378 units. The company aims to sell 3 million hybrids and EVs this year, surpassing its previous target. BYD's sales increased 31% from the same period last year, while Tesla, which doesn't release monthly numbers, sold 435,059 EVs in the July-September quarter. BYD's total EV sales for the first two months of the quarter are 335,655, positioning the company to potentially surpass Tesla in worldwide quarterly deliveries.

site_title: Maybank Singapore extends US$100 million sustainability-linked Islamic facility to AET
summary: Maybank Singapore has extended a US$100 million sustainability-linked Islamic revolving credit facility to AET, the owner and operator of maritime transportation assets and specialized services. This marks the first sustainability-linked Islamic facility in South-east Asia's shipping industry. The loan supports AET's initiatives to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions intensity by 40% by 2030 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The facility provides a fixed ceiling rate and no compounding of charges in the event of late payments, offering certainty to AET in a volatile environment.

images.alt_text: UOB Kay Hian expects Maybank to report RM2.7 billion in fourth-quarter net profit.
Maybank targets to achieve a return on equity of between 10.5 per cent and 11 per cent for FY2023.

“We have chosen Singapore as our offshore hub for our Islamic wealth management given the position of Singapore as a wealth management player not just in the region but also globally,” says John Chong, Maybank’s Group CEO of Community Financial Services.

site_title: Swiss GDP grows by 0.3% in third quarter
summary: Switzerland's economy grew 0.3% in the third quarter, beating the forecast of 0.1%. The growth was driven by the service sector, which offset stagnant manufacturing growth. Year-on-year, the economy grew 0.9%, stronger than the 0.5% forecast. Despite this, the manufacturing sector remains weak, with production continuing to contract. The Swiss government expects the economy to grow 1.3% this year and 1.2% in 2024, slower than the country's long-term average growth rate.

images.alt_text: In recent years, the price growth of condominiums was slightly less pronounced than that of single-family homes.

The Swiss Bankers Association (SBA), which represents lenders like UBS and Julius Baer as well as the country’s smaller banks, wants to continue with self-regulation rather than be subject to tighter government rules.
The decision by Swiss National Bank (SNB), which unveils announcements only once a quarter, widens the gap in rates with its peers.

site_title: Malaysia central bank chief sees ringgit reprieve as rates peak
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour, believes the country's interest rate of 3% is slightly accommodative and suitable for the economy. The ringgit is expected to recover with other emerging-market currencies once developed economies finish raising interest rates. Despite the currency weakening this year, policymakers will focus on domestic considerations, such as inflation and growth, when deciding on borrowing costs. The ringgit has fallen 6% against the US dollar this year, but Ghaffour sees no need for a key rate hike to boost the currency.

images.alt_text: (From left to right) GXS chairman Hsieh Fu Hua, Datuk Johan Merican, GXBank CEO Pei Si Lai and Datuk Zaiton Hassan, chairperson of GXBank, at the public launch of GXBank.

The raids are conducted on certain entities suspected of operating money services businesses without a valid licence from the central bank as well as potentially engaging in money laundering activities, BNM says.
Bank Negara Malaysia governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour says that resilient domestic spending, underpinned by improved employment and rising tourism activities, bolstered Q3 growth.
BNM is under pressure to raise borrowing costs as the ringgit lingers near the weakest level since 1998, and as regional peers turn hawkish to back their currencies

site_title: UK factory downturn shows more signs of easing:  PMI
summary: The UK manufacturing sector showed signs of easing its downturn for the third consecutive month, with the S&P Global/CIPS manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) improving to 47.2 in November from 44.8 in October. However, companies remained cautious, with ongoing market uncertainty and cost control measures leading to job losses and lower purchasing. Input costs fell, but manufacturers increased selling prices for the second time in six months to repair profit margins. The Bank of England continues to monitor price pressures and interest rates remain at a 15-year high.

images.alt_text: Dave Ramsden, deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, U.K., on Thursday, May 5, 2022. The Bank of England hiked interest rates to their highest level since the financial crisis and warned the economy is on course to shrink under pressure from double-digit inflation. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
The Confederation of British Industry’s (CBI) monthly retail sales balance, a gauge of sales over the year to November, picked up to -11 from a very weak -36 in October.
Despite lingering cost-of-living pressures, GfK’s headline consumer confidence index was stronger than anticipated in November, increasing to -24 from October’s three-month low of -30.
With factories feeling the impact of higher borrowing costs the CBI says its monthly industrial orders balance dropped to -35 in November – the lowest since January 2021.

site_title: Kiwi house prices to rise modestly next year on high interest rates
summary: New Zealand's average house prices are forecast to rise 4% next year and 5% in 2025, according to a Reuters poll of 11 property analysts. Despite high interest rates, prices are expected to increase at a more subdued pace than the recent past. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand may still raise borrowing costs before cutting them, and the market is expected to be undersupplied, with affordable housing not increasing enough to balance demand. Experts warn that households may struggle to service mortgages, potentially presenting downside risks to the economy.

images.alt_text: House prices in New Zealand are recovering after a prolonged slump that coincided with a steep rise in mortgage interest rates.
The RBNZ has signalled it is done raising rates after rapidly lifting its benchmark to 5.5 per cent.
The national average house price was NZ$905,445 in September, the lowest since May 2021.

site_title: Oil prices stabilise after slump on underwhelming Opec+ cuts
summary: Opec+ producers agreed to remove 2.2 million barrels per day of oil from the global market in the first quarter of next year, including Saudi Arabia and Russia's voluntary cuts. Oil prices remained steady, with Brent Crude futures rising 0.27% to $81.08 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 0.41% to $76.27. The market appeared unconvinced that the production cuts would lift prices out of their recent slump, despite the agreement.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for January settled 27 cents, or 0.3 per cent, lower to expire at US$82.83 a barrel, and a 5.2 per cent loss for the month.

site_title: Yen’s plunge is a blessing and a curse for people in South Korea
summary: The yen has dropped to its lowest level against the won since 2008, reaching a 15-year low on November 16. This has led to increased travel to Japan and purchases of Japanese goods by South Koreans. However, some individuals, like Park Hanul, who invested in the yen, have seen their investment decline in value, as the yen is still down 9% this year. The yen's decline has mixed effects on the South Korean economy, with both positive and negative consequences.

images.alt_text: CEO Kentaro Okuda is trying to revitalise Nomura after profit fell in his first three years in office, weighed by overseas losses.

A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. site_title: China's weak economy spurs furious demand for bond funds
summary: China's struggling economy has fueled a surge in demand for bond funds, with over 50 bond-focused mutual funds launched in November, raising $14.71 billion. Existing bond products have also seen significant inflows, forcing mutual funds to limit subscriptions. Analysts expect interest rates to trend lower, benefiting bonds, which move inversely with rates. China's economic restructuring requires lower risk-free interest rates, pushing up bond prices. Experts say it's a good time to buy bonds, driven by expectations of a post-Covid recovery and potential interest rate cuts in 2024.

images.alt_text: None of survey by 22 funds by OMFIF,  reports a positive outlook for China’s economy, citing the regulatory environment and geopolitics among primary factors dissuading them from investing.

site_title: OCBC seeks at least S$19.7 million, mortgaged Sentosa Cove villa from money laundering accused Su Baolin
summary: OCBC bank has filed a claim in Singapore's High Court, seeking at least S$19.7 million from money-laundering accused Su Baolin, who mortgaged his Sentosa Cove villa. Su, one of 10 individuals accused of a S$2.8 billion money laundering case, faces charges related to forging bank documents. The claim was filed on Oct 25 and is scheduled for a hearing on Jan 5, 2024.

images.alt_text: Eight Sentosa Cove landed homes were amongst the 152 properties issued with prohibition of disposal orders

site_title: War resumes in Gaza after truce collapses
summary: War resumes in Gaza after a seven-day truce between Israel and Hamas militants collapsed, with Israeli warplanes pounding Gaza, sending scores wounded and dead to hospitals. At least 54 people were killed and dozens wounded in air strikes targeting homes, with Gaza health officials reporting the most intensive bombing in Khan Younis and Rafah. The truce had allowed for daily exchanges of Israeli hostages for Palestinian detainees, but negotiations failed to find a formula to release more hostages, including Israeli men.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres talks to the media during a press conference on sidelines of the 43rd Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023. Indonesia hosts the 43rd ASEAN Summit and related summits from 05 to 07 September
US President Joe Biden has been putting pressure on the Israeli government to delay and moderate its ground invasion of the Gaza Strip.

site_title: DBS customers face mobile app delays on Friday
summary: DBS customers faced delays in logging in to the bank's mobile app on Friday due to high traffic from customers checking their balances at the start of the month. The issue was attributed to a large number of concurrent logins. Customers can access their accounts through the bank's website. This incident follows a series of digital disruptions for DBS customers this year, which the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has been monitoring and addressing.

images.alt_text: DBS has seen a number of disruptions over the last two years.
DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta may be in the hot seat now, following the resignation of Optus' CEO.

site_title: Tearing down Singapore’s love of brand-new buildings
summary: Singapore's developers are demolishing and rebuilding buildings at an alarming rate, generating significant waste and emissions. The country's commercial buildings are relatively young, with a median age of under 20 years, making adaptive reuse a more sustainable option. However, developers prioritize profits over sustainability, with many opting for demolition and rebuilding due to rezone announcements and increased plot ratio changes. Adaptive reuse, which involves repurposing existing buildings, can save developers money and time, but requires more justifications and analysis to ensure structural integrity. The industry's focus on financial returns rather than environmental impact is driven by land economics policies, which prioritize land value and financial gain over sustainability.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Development is looking to minimise the environmental toll of the JCube redevelopment, by retaining existing building structures and incorporating them into the new building design “as much as possible”.

Environmental engineer Patrick Bellew pointed out that Singapore loves a good transfer structure to get buildings to look like they defy gravity. But such structures are "hugely carbon intensive", he said.
The leisure and edutainment mall is located opposite Jurong East MRT interchange station and bus interchange.
Forum The Shopping Mall may be redeveloped as part of a mixed redevelopment by Hotel Properties Limited

Schroders takes into account the investments needed to transition its assets to net-zero, and factors the cost of the impacts they have on the environment in its net cash flows today, says its global head of Real Estate, Sophie van Oosterom. PHOTO: SCHRODERS
Singapore buildings to have to meet higher standards to be certified green

site_title: Lexus LBX review: The first Cat A Lexus
summary: The Lexus LBX, a compact luxury crossover, is the first Cat A model from Lexus, eligible for a cheaper Certificate of entitlement (COE). Inspired by Toyota Chairman Akio Toyoda's favorite shoes, the LBX aims to offer a premium, yet casual driving experience. With a hybrid powertrain detuned to 130 horsepower, it boasts a luxurious interior, digital driver displays, and a 9.8-inch touchscreen. The LBX is priced around S$230,000 and targets a wider market, breaking into a new segment for Lexus. Its debut at the Singapore Motorshow in January 2024 could boost sales and establish the brand as a luxury option for casual driving.
