site_title: Temasek portfolio companies may divest its ‘dirty’ assets to provide clarity on net-zero plans
summary: Temasek, Singapore's state investor, has stated that while it prefers to work with carbon-intensive portfolio companies to reduce emissions, it may divest assets if a clear signal on future net-zero direction is needed. This was highlighted by Steve Howard, vice-chairman of sustainability at Temasek, after Sembcorp Industries sold its coal power business in India. Temasek is prioritizing long-term partnerships and sustainable investments, with a focus on emerging markets and low-carbon opportunities. The company is also investing in sustainable aviation fuels and green hydrogen to power aircraft.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The new investment will focus on green solutions such as rooftop solar.
Temasek Trust and the Earthshot Prize will work to raise awareness about the fight against climate change in the region.
SIA and Scoot say sustainable fuels are critical to the group’s goals of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.
Part of the funds from Changi Carbon Offsets will be channelled into developing wind-power generation facilities in Koppal in India.
On an operational aspect, the pilot validated the chain to bring Saf into Changi Airport.

Temasek Trust's Desmond Kuek says PAA "will harness the strengths, ideas and best practices of members and partners to jointly pioneer philanthropic innovations, to realise our bold ambitions as an alliance to prime Asia as a force for good".

Unlike other carbon-intensive sectors, which may have various avenues to decarbonise, the only way SIA is able to reduce its carbon emissions is by switching its fuel, which are currently fossil fuel-based, to sustainable aviation fuel, said Dilhan Pillay, chief executive officer of Temasek.

site_title: From Singapore to San Francisco Bay Area – Innovation across borders
summary: The San Francisco Bay Area maintains its top spot as a global innovation hub, driven by its long history, established research institutions, and strong networks. The area continues to attract top talent, investment, and innovation talent, with the US and Singapore maintaining close economic ties. Despite the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, VC funding in the Bay Area remains strong, and startups like OpenAI and Resilience have secured significant funding. The US and Singapore see the Bay Area as a key innovation partner, with Singapore companies exploring growth opportunities and establishing a presence in the area.

images.alt_text: The opening of the new office marks a new chapter for BLOCK71, says Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong at its opening ceremony.
The launch of Enterprise Singapore's San Francisco Overseas Centre marks a step-up in Singapore's engagement on the West Coast, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.
Setting up a lab in San Francisco has enabled Engine Biosciences to tap the deal flow among pharmaceutical giants in the US.

site_title: China, Vietnam consider rail link through rare earths heartland
summary: China and Vietnam are discussing a possible upgrade of their rail link, which would boost trade and connectivity between the two countries, particularly in Vietnam's rare-earths heartland. The talks, led by Chinese diplomat Wang Yi and Vietnamese Deputy Prime Minister Tran Luu Quang, come ahead of a potential visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping. The upgraded railway would improve interoperability and increase capacity, potentially boosting Vietnam's exports to China and integrating the two countries' manufacturing industries.

images.alt_text: A general view shows Vietnam's parliament, the National Assembly, as it opens its autumn session in Hanoi on October 20, 2022. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP)
“We are willing to build closer production and industrial supply chain partnerships with all countries,” says Chinese Premier Li Qiang.
A general view shows Vietnam's parliament, the National Assembly, as it opens its autumn session in Hanoi on October 20, 2022. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP)

China's manufacturing sector is struggling to recover with the official purchasing managers’ index (PMI) falling for the second month on Thursday, despite China’s better-than-expected economic growth in the third quarter.
The value of new home sales among the 100 biggest real estate companies falls 29.6 per cent from a year earlier to 390.19 billion yuan (S$73.3 billion).

site_title: BOJ survey highlights sharp bond market strains from ultra-easy policy
summary: The Bank of Japan's survey reveals sharp bond market strains resulting from its prolonged ultra-easy monetary policy. The BOJ's asset-buying scheme, introduced in 2013, led to a deterioration in bond market function, which worsened after the adoption of yield curve control in 2016. A diffusion index measuring market participant views on bond market functioning declined sharply to 5, indicating significant strains. The findings could impact the BOJ's decision on reversing ultra-low interest rates, which may be reversed next year due to inflation exceeding 2% for over a year.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan's Toyoaki Nakamura said Japan’s continued economic recovery, tight labour market and an increasing number of workers switching jobs are heightening the chance that wage growth will eventually exceed the pace of inflation.

site_title: Bitcoin brings US$40,000 into view after more than doubling in a chaotic year
summary: Bitcoin has rebounded about 130% over the past 11 months, surpassing investments like stocks or gold, and is now within reach of $40,000. The token's price surge is attributed to hopes for Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts and the potential approval of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds. Analysts predict a batch of ETFs will win SEC approval by January, boosting sentiment. Some, like Michael Novogratz, expect Bitcoin to reach its 2021 peak of $69,000 by the end of 2024.

site_title: Do 70,000 people really need to be at a climate confab?
summary: The United Nations' COP28 climate conference in Dubai is expected to draw a record 70,000 attendees, sparking concerns about the meeting's purpose being overshadowed by celebrity-studded gatherings. While the event aims to hammer out a global climate agreement, progress is uncertain, and critics argue that the large number of attendees is a sign of "bloat" that naturally accumulates around gatherings of influential people. The conference's carbon footprint is also a concern, with many attendees expected to fly private jets, generating significantly more pollution than commercial flights.

images.alt_text: The allegations against Sultan Al Jaber, who is also CEO of UAE’s oil giant Adnoc, have fanned long-running suspicions over the wisdom of a petrostate hosting the COP28 talks.
The plan for starting up the loss and damage fund is one of three main negotiated outcomes COP28 is working to deliver over the next two weeks.
Oil and gas use would fall by 75 per cent by 2050 if governments successfully pursued the 1.5 deg C target and emissions from the energy sector reached net zero by then.
Global temperatures were around 1.4 deg Celsius above the pre-industrial average for the first 10 months of the year, prompting the WMO to declared it the warmest ever recorded.

site_title: Gold poised for third weekly gain as cooler data cements Fed cut bets
summary: Gold prices are poised for a third straight weekly gain as cooling inflation data cements bets for a US Federal Reserve rate cut. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $2,039.63 per ounce, while US gold futures for February delivery rose 0.1% to $2,059.30. The data showed moderate US consumer spending and the smallest annual inflation increase in over 2-1/2 years, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest-bearing bullion and supporting gold prices.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.2 per cent to US$2,044.53 per ounce by 0453 GMT after hitting its highest since May 5.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials shift tone but remain wary of markets’ aggressive rate cut bets
summary: Federal Reserve officials have signaled a potential shift in tone, inching closer to discussing interest rate cuts, but remain cautious due to concerns over potential renewed inflation. Despite downward trends in inflation and data showing a slowing economy, officials are unlikely to cut rates immediately, with projections suggesting higher interest rates in 2024 than currently priced in by markets. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is expected to reiterate caution, while some Wall Street predictions suggest the central bank may begin cutting rates as early as the first quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: New York Fed president John Williams expects inflation to end this year at 3 per cent, and ebb to 2.25 per cent in 2024, as economic growth slows to 1.25 per cent and unemployment rises to 4.25 per cent.
Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, increases 0.2 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.7 per cent gain in September.

Federal Reserve President of Cleveland Loretta Mester pointed to cooling price pressures, adding that “there has been discernible progress on inflation even while the overall economy has remained relatively strong.”
Cutting inflation while avoiding a downturn, commonly known as a “soft landing,” is challenging, but the latest update from the US central bank suggests it could be on track.
US GDP rises at an upwardly revised 5.2 per cent annualised pace in the third quarter, the fastest in nearly two years.

site_title: From Ronaldo to Rooney, the greatest overhead kicks of all time
summary: Manchester United's Alejandro Garnacho scored a stunning overhead kick against Everton, sending the ball flying into the back of the net past goalkeeper Jordan Pickford. The goal, scored in the third minute of the match, is a leading contender for the EPL's Goal of the Season prize. Garnacho's impressive strike joins a list of other breathtaking overhead goals, including Rivaldo's 2001 goal for Barcelona, Wayne Rooney's 2011 goal for Manchester United, Zlatan Ibrahimovic's 2012 goal for Sweden, Gareth Bale's 2018 goal for Real Madrid, and Cristiano Ronaldo's 2018 goal for Real Madrid.

(From left) Trifecta's co-founders Daphne Goh, Alex Hsu and Terry Tan. They are also from The Ride Side, which organises skiing and snowboarding trips.
Argentina captain Lionel Messi with the World Cup trophy in December 2022. Argentina will host one of the 2030 World Cup's opening matches.

site_title: Malaysia invites China's Xi to visit, ramps up tourism target
summary: Malaysia has invited China's President Xi Jinping to visit, following a surge in Chinese tourists, with 498,540 visiting the country in the six months to June, a third of pre-pandemic levels. The country aims to boost Chinese tourism to five million a year, driving economic growth. Malaysia also recently introduced visa-free travel for Chinese tourists for 30 days, mirroring Thailand. The goal is not considered far-fetched, with the country expecting to meet its 4% economic growth target this year, driven in part by stronger tourism.

images.alt_text: The reiterated "add" call comes before the Q3 update by Malaysia Airports Holdings (MAHB) on Wednesday.

site_title: Top Abu Dhabi developer buys London Square for US$291 million
summary: Aldar Properties, Abu Dhabi's top real estate developer, has acquired London Square for $291.4 million, its first acquisition outside the Middle East. The deal is expected to boost sales due to cross-selling opportunities between the two companies. London Square, known for its Nine Elms development, will leverage Aldar's expertise and balance sheet to acquire prime central London sites. The acquisition is part of a strategy by Gulf states to transform local companies into regional and global players.

images.alt_text: This image shows high-rise buildings in Dubai, on February 18, 2023. - Home to towering skyscrapers and ultra-luxury villas, Dubai saw record real estate transactions in 2022, largely due to an influx of wealthy investors, especially from Russia. (Photo by Karim SAHIB / AFP)
The joint venture between Dubai Holding and Aldar Properties, Abu Dhabi’s biggest developer, sold out two phases in the “Haven” project on launch day.

site_title: Keppel’s acquisition of Aermont to deliver growth and diversification benefits: analysts
summary: Keppel has agreed to acquire European real estate manager Aermont Capital for up to $1.4 billion. Analysts from Macquarie and UOBKH view the deal as strategic, boosting Keppel's funds under management and driving growth. Macquarie rates Keppel "outperform" with a price target of $7.88, while UOBKH maintains a "buy" call with a target of $9.09. The deal is expected to add at least 8% to Keppel's fair value, with analysts forecasting a significant earnings upside if the company co-invests in new funds.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Christina Tan, CEO, Fund Management and CIO of Keppel Corporation; Léon Bressler, Chairman of Aermont Capital; Loh Chin Hua, CEO of Keppel Corporation; and Paul Golding, Managing Partner of Aermont Capital.

The six shortlisted entities have been shortlisted from 26 proposals received by the government in an expression of interest launched in December 2022.
Any pipeline to be established by City Energy and Gentari will supply hydrogen into the former’s Senoko Gasworks plant.

site_title: Wealth and pension funds prefer India over China, study shows
summary: Global pension and sovereign wealth managers are favoring India over China, with 40% of investors selecting India as the most attractive emerging market, while less than 25% chose China. The shift is attributed to growing global optimism over India's strong growth, demographics, and diversification of global supply chains, as well as Beijing's rising tensions with the West and policy mishaps. In contrast, there is hesitation on China, with no surveyed fund having a positive outlook for its economy or expecting higher returns from Chinese assets, citing regulation and geopolitics as major barriers.

images.alt_text: More than two-thirds of China-focused hedge funds lost money in 2022, while 36 per cent were down a fifth or more.
China’s pledge this week to step up stimulus measures to shore up the economy provides some hope for investors, but it’s too early to say what impact it could have on foreign money inflows.

site_title:
Evergrande creditors demand controlling stakes in 
new restructuring proposal
summary: Evergrande Group's creditors are demanding controlling stakes in the company and its two Hong Kong subsidiaries as part of a revised restructuring proposal. The proposal, set to be presented in court on Dec 4, initially offered 17.8% of the parent company and 30% of each subsidiary. Creditors are seeking to swap debt for equity, citing the need for more control and stability. The move comes as the company faces the risk of liquidation unless it submits a convincing restructuring plan.

images.alt_text: Evergrande has until a Hong Kong court hearing on Monday (Dec 4) to present a “concrete” revised debt restructuring proposal for offshore creditors.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle even as US data fuels rate cut talk
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, despite US data suggesting the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates in 2024, as inflation slows and consumer spending weakens. Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, and Jakarta fell, while Singapore, Manila, and Wellington rose. Analysts expect the Fed to continue its rate-cutting cycle without tipping the economy into recession. The ongoing weakness in China's economy remains a concern, and investors remain cautious amid geopolitical risks and uncertainties.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a new high for the year and finished up 1.5 per cent at 35,950.89, while the broad-based S&P 500 rose by 0.4 per cent to 4,567.80 on Thursday.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers slightly 56 to 53.

site_title: Asia factory activity weakens, uncertainty on China clouds outlook
summary: Asia's factory activity remained weak in November due to sluggish global demand, with export-reliant Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan experiencing stagnant manufacturing activity. China's private Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI unexpectedly rose to 50.7 in November, surpassing analysts' forecasts, but official surveys showed a contraction in both manufacturers' and non-manufacturers' activity. This mixed data clouded the outlook for the region's fragile recovery, with economists warning of a slow recovery in Asia, citing a lack of a key driver of growth in the global economy.

images.alt_text: The au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing PMI slipped to 48.1 in November from 48.7 in October. The index has remained below the 50.0 threshold that separates contraction from expansion since June.

China's manufacturing sector is struggling to recover with the official purchasing managers’ index (PMI) falling for the second month on Thursday, despite China’s better-than-expected economic growth in the third quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: The Singapore Exchange opened with a 0.3% gain, lifting the Straits Times Index (STI) to 3,080.52. Despite the positive start, losers outnumbered gainers 56 to 53, with 54.7 million securities changing hands. The most active counter was Seatrium, holding steady at S$0.105 with 21.6 million shares traded. The gains were largely attributed to overnight market performances in the US and Europe, which ended mostly higher.

site_title: Goldman Sachs now expects ECB’s first rate cut in Q2 2024
summary: Goldman Sachs now expects the European Central Bank (ECB) to deliver its first interest rate cut in the second quarter of 2024, reversing its earlier forecast of a cut in the third quarter of next year. The ECB raised its deposit rate to a record high 4% via ten straight moves ending in September, with inflation expected to inch up in the coming months before returning to its target in the second half of 2025.

site_title: US judge blocks Montana from banning TikTok use in state
summary: A US federal judge blocked Montana's ban on TikTok from taking effect, citing a violation of the free speech rights of users. The ban, which would have prohibited the use of the popular video-sharing app in the state, was blocked by US District Judge Donald Molloy. TikTok argued that the ban was unconstitutional and would not share user data with the Chinese government, which was a concern raised by Montana's state legislature. The ruling is a temporary reprieve for TikTok users in Montana, who will be able to continue using the app until the case is resolved.

images.alt_text: The 11 tech giants have promised to take tougher action within six months to block and remove scams, such as fake adverts and romance fraud, from their platforms.

ByteDance has recently started to allow some content creators with more than 100,000 followers to put part of their videos behind a paywall on Douyin, TikTok’s sister app in China.
TikTok says it is a challenger, not an incumbent, in digital advertising and no market investigation was conducted in relation to its designation by the European Commission.

site_title: China factory activity surprisingly expands in November: Caixin PMI
summary: China's manufacturing sector unexpectedly expanded in November, with the Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI rising to 50.7 from 49.5 in October. This marked the fastest expansion in three months and surpassed analysts' forecasts. The sector is struggling to recover due to sluggish external demand, but factory owners expanded production and purchasing activity in November. Economists expect the policy stance to remain proactive, supporting overall growth momentum into the coming quarters.

ETFs, which are funds that typically track an index, have garnered more than 400 billion yuan (S$74.5 billion) this year in what would be record annual net inflows, according to mutual fund house China Asset Management Co.
The value of new home sales among the 100 biggest real estate companies falls 29.6 per cent from a year earlier to 390.19 billion yuan (S$73.3 billion).
Australian wineries will likely benefit from the removal of tariffs, although it will take time to rebuild market share after almost two years shut out of China.

site_title: Japan aircon king Daikin looks to custom chips for energy savings
summary: Japan's Daikin, a leading air conditioner manufacturer, is partnering with a Japanese design company to create custom logic chips for its inverters, which adjust the speed of air conditioners to save energy. The custom chips, made by Taiwan's TSMC, are expected to offer better energy efficiency and improve performance. Daikin plans to start introducing the chips in high-end air conditioners from 2025 and aims to use them in about a fifth of its units by the end of the decade. The move aims to enhance energy efficiency and stay competitive in a market where the number of air conditioners globally is expected to triple by 2050.

images.alt_text: Daikin, the world’s largest manufacturer of air conditioning equipment, says UK PM Sunak’s decisions would make it harder to hit Britain’s target to become a net zero carbon economy by 2050.
Daikin, the top provider of heat-pump systems in Europe since 2019, is betting on new European regulations spurring their use.

Air-conditioner maker Daikin readies billions to expand in warmer world

site_title: Shen Yao independent director charged by CPIB, quits citing health reasons
summary: Independent director Pek Choon Lee of Shen Yao has resigned due to "health reasons", just a month into his role. He faces three charges under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act, related to providing false information regarding employment, and could face a fine of up to S$15,000 or imprisonment for up to 12 months. The charges are unrelated to Shen Yao's operations and the company's shares have been suspended from trading since March. Pek was also managing director at One World Business Advisory and has other business roles.

images.alt_text: Shen Yao said several parts of the article by the Australian Financial Review are “misleading”.
Shen Yao to buy up to 20.25% stake in loss-making Real Estate Analytics

site_title: South Korea’s chips exports rise for first time in more than a year
summary: South Korea's chip exports rose 12.9% in November, snapping a 15-month decline, and exports overall gained 7.8% year-over-year to $55.80 billion, beating economist forecasts. The recovery in chip demand and strong car sales are expected to boost overall exports, with economists predicting an 8% growth next year. However, policymakers are cautious, citing downside risks from China's tepid recovery and persistent inflation risks.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea held its key policy rate at 3.50 per cent at a policy review meeting in Seoul, as expected by all 36 economists polled by Reuters.
South Korea's industrial output index fell 3.5 per cent in October from a month earlier on a seasonally adjusted basis, according to Statistics Korea.
A rocket carrying a spy satellite Malligyong-1 is launched, North Gyeongsang Province, North Korea, Nov 21, 2023.
Japanese Foreign Minister Yoko Kamikawa, South Korean Foreign Minister Park Jin, and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi at the 10th trilateral foreign ministers' meeting in Busan on Nov 26.

site_title: The Charlie Munger principles to invest and live by
summary: Charlie Munger, Berkshire Hathaway vice-chair and renowned investor, died at 99 on November 28. His investment philosophy, as outlined in speeches and interviews, emphasizes a multidisciplinary approach to investing and living. Key principles include: being "educated" beyond finance, taking a long-term view, and focusing on "what can you control." Munger also stressed the importance of being " observant" and "uncomfortable" with uncertainty. His approach, shaped by his partnership with Warren Buffett, has guided investors and inspired a new generation of investors with his trademark bluntness and humor.

images.alt_text: Berkshire Hathaway said Charlie Munger died peacefully at a hospital in California, where he lived. No cause was given.

Berkshire's Munger says now 'even crazier' than dotcom bust

site_title: Porsche’s 911 Dakar and 911 Sport Classic offer a fast line to heritage
summary: Porsche unveiled the 911 Sport Classic and 911 Dakar, two limited-edition cars celebrating the brand's heritage. The Sport Classic, a 7-speed manual model, pays homage to the original 911 from 1964 and the Carrera RS 2.7, a racing legend. It features a wide body, carbon fiber roof and hood, and a retro interior. The 911 Dakar, an off-road-ready 911, was inspired by Porsche's 1984 Paris-Dakar Rally win and features a jacked-up ride height, all-wheel drive system, and dedicated driving modes. Both cars offer a unique driving experience and a nod to Porsche's rich motoring history.

The Series 5's base model is practically ubiquitous in Singapore.

site_title: SEA AiR: Passages of discovery through the arts
summary: The European Union's Studio Residencies for Southeast Asian Artists in the EU (SEA AiR) has launched its second cycle, featuring three artists from Southeast Asia - Priyageetha Dia from Singapore, Ngoc Nau from Vietnam, and Saroot Supasuthivech from Thailand - who have spent three months in European art institutions. The residency programme aims to promote dialogue and exchange between European art institutions and Southeast Asian artists, and is part of the EU's Global Gateway initiative. The second cycle exhibition, "Passages," opened on November 28 and runs until January 28, 2024, at NTU CCA Gillman Barracks in Singapore.

site_title: Olivier Lim to succeed Chaly Mah as STB chairman
summary: Singapore Tourism Board chairman Chaly Mah is stepping down after seven years, succeeded by Olivier Lim, who was appointed deputy chairman in 2023. Mah led initiatives such as the SingapoRediscovers campaign and SingapoReimagine, contributing to Singapore's strong tourism performance pre-pandemic. Lim, a seasoned director and lead independent director at DBS, is expected to guide STB towards its next phase of growth. The changes will take effect from January 1, 2024.

images.alt_text: The 6.8 hectare site is adjacent to the new Science Centre and Jurong Lake Gardens.
Chaly Mah to succeed Surbana Jurong's Liew Mun Leong
DBS names Olivier Lim new lead independent director

site_title: Xi urges Chinese envoys to create 'diplomatic iron army'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged Chinese envoys to create a "diplomatic iron army" loyal to the Communist Party, emphasizing the need to increase China's international influence to combat Western attempts to contain and suppress the country. Xi's remarks revived the "Wolf Warrior" rhetoric and urged envoys to adhere to Party discipline, repeating the word "strict" seven times. This comes amid a renewed disciplinary push in China's diplomatic corps and amid diplomatic disputes with the US, Philippines, and Japan.

images.alt_text: Xi has spent his first decade-plus in office consolidating power to levels unseen since Mao.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH Healthcare, Venture, Starhill Global Reit, Cordlife
summary: IHH Healthcare reported higher earnings for Q3, with revenue across all markets contributing to the increase. Venture Corporation is purchasing up to 10 million of its ordinary shares, while Starhill Global Reit renewed its master lease with Takashimaya manager Toshin Development Singapore. Cordlife Group was issued a notice to stop collecting new cord blood and human tissue for six months due to temperature issues. Golden Agri-Resources was added to the Straits Times Index reserve list following a quarterly review.

site_title: Billionaire heirs have a how-to-spend-it problem
summary: For the first time, UBS' annual study of billionaires reveals that new billionaires accumulated more wealth through inheritance than entrepreneurship, with $151 billion inherited by 53 heirs in 2022. Second-generation billionaires aim to enable their descendants to benefit from their wealth and continue their family's legacy, but often prioritize financial growth over philanthropy, with only 16% citing "enabling or supporting others" as their main objective. This trend raises concerns about the responsible management of inherited wealth and the need for these heirs to develop a sense of social responsibility.

images.alt_text: Young Jin Yee, co-head of UBS Global Wealth Management for Apac, says the region continues to have the highest number of billionaires and the highest proportion of self-made billionaires in the world.
Among the 137 new billionaires, a total of US$150.8 billion is inherited by 53 heirs over the last year, exceeding the 84 new self-made billionaires’ total of US$140.7 billion, according to UBS.

site_title: Indonesia agritech startup helps ageing rice farmers improve yields
summary: Indonesia's agritech startup, Agri Sparta, is helping ageing rice farmers improve yields through the use of drone-mounted cameras, AI, and data analysis. The company aims to raise rice production by 25% and farmers' income by 30% by 2025. With the country's population projected to reach 330 million by 2050, increasing rice production is critical for food security. Agri Sparta currently manages 200 hectares of rice fields, producing 3,500-4,000 tonnes of rice annually, and is exploring additional funding to achieve profitability.

images.alt_text: Thai white rice 5 per cent broken – an Asian benchmark – climbed for a third straight week to reach US$659 a ton on Wednesday (Dec 27), according to the Thai Rice Exporters Association.

A farmer carries a sack of green beans during a harvest session at a field in Darul Kamal, Aceh province, July 28, 2023. Changes in land use, fossil-fuel-heavy energy production, and growing consumption mean Indonesia is now the fourth-largest annual emitter of greenhouse gasses.

site_title: Bangladesh's 'tiny houses' tackle giant flood challenge
summary: Bangladesh's architect Marina Tabassum has developed "Khudi Bari" or "tiny houses" made from locally available materials like bamboo poles and metal sheeting to combat the country's frequent flooding. The two-floor homes can be easily assembled and disassembled, costing around $450 to build, and can be moved to safer locations when needed. The design has been successful in helping 40-year-old farmer Abu Sayeed weather the 2023 monsoon floodwaters, and Tabassum plans to build over 100 such homes across the country, offering hope to millions at risk from climate change.

images.alt_text: In this photograph taken on September 3, 2023, a child climbs a ladder inside a mobile modular shelter "Khudi Bari" or "tiny house" in Char Shildaha. An award-winning architect in Bangladesh, one of the nations most at risk from flooding driven by climate change, has developed an ingenious two-story housing solution to help people survive what scientists warn is a growing threat. The "Khudi Bari" or "tiny house" -- resilient homes made on bamboo stilts rising out of the floodwaters that are also easy to move to safer locations when needed -- offer hope to millions. (Photo by Munir UZ ZAMAN / AFP)

site_title: Issue 81: Assessing renewable energy costs; weak demand for ESG funds
summary: Renewable energy costs in South-east Asia are higher than globally, with the benchmark levelised cost of electricity (LCOE) for solar PV being between $0.05 and $0.075 per kilowatt-hour, compared to the global weighted average of $0.048/kWh. High local content requirements, inflexible power purchase agreements, and lack of an integrated policy approach contribute to elevated costs. As a result, many renewable projects in the region are only marginally bankable and unable to attract sufficient private-sector investment. Efforts to reduce costs include new initiatives announced at the United Nations climate change conference in Dubai, including a $5 billion blended finance initiative and transition credits.

images.alt_text: ESG index constituents such as Keppel Corp have stepped up their renewable energy footprints this year.
Seatrium's floating and stacked energy storage system. The group's S$400 million loan facility from DBS includes a sustainability-linked conversion option.
Kelvin Wong, chief executive officer of the Building and Construction Authority.
FILE PHOTO: A general view shows the central Swiss Alps and the town of Zug, Switzerland March 28, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
The Galaxy Leader cargo ship was seized by the Houthis in the Red Sea in early December. Such attacks forced shipping companies to change their routes.

site_title: Restaurants poised to lower prices, widen options as industry adjusts to smaller dining wallets in 2024
summary: Restaurants in Singapore are expected to lower prices and widen their options in 2024 as the F&B industry adjusts to smaller dining wallets. Despite a 10-30% drop in revenue, some high-end eateries have bucked the trend with record-breaking sales, while others have introduced a la carte menus to attract price-conscious diners. New restaurants are also set to open, including celebrity chef tie-ups and local ventures, offering more dining options for consumers. Experts predict a shift towards more affordable and flexible dining experiences, with lower prices and shorter menus becoming more prevalent.

images.alt_text: One Michelin-starred Basque Kitchen by Aitor closed its premises on May 28.

site_title: China appoints Dong Jun as new defence minister
summary: China has appointed Dong Jun as its new defence minister, replacing Li Shangfu who had not been seen in public since August. Dong, 62, was the People's Liberation Army Navy chief and faces no US sanctions, allowing him to engage with the US military. This move is part of President Xi Jinping's push to make China a dominant world power, amid concerns from neighbours. Dong will be the public face of the People's Liberation Army, but the ministry has little say in defence policy, which is overseen by the Central Military Commission led by Xi.

images.alt_text: China's Defence Minister Li Shangfu at the 20th Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on June 2, 2023. General Li, who has been absent from public view for two months, was dismissed as defence minister and state councillor.

site_title: Hot stock: Cordlife Group drops 32% after it is found to have damaged cord  blood units of customers
summary: Cordlife Group, a private cord-blood bank in Asia, has been barred from collecting, testing, and storing new cord-blood or tissue samples for six months after the Ministry of Health found seven storage tanks kept at temperatures above acceptable limits. The company's shares plummeted 42.9% in early trading, nearing its lowest level since 2012. Customers who stored their cord-blood units with the company are concerned about the viability of their stem cells and the company's handling of the situation.

images.alt_text: The new Mount Elizabeth Novena hospital is owned by Parkway Holdings, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Malaysian-controlled IHH Healthcare, which reports promising earnings for Q3.
Cordlife Group said that it will continue to store affected cord blood units for clients, as they “may still be valuable in light of developments in the field of cell and gene therapy.”
Shares of Cordlife had hit a three-year high to S$0.495 amid heavy trading on Jun 26 after the company said it was aware of a possible transaction for an offer for its shares.
Shares of Cordlife Group hit a three-year high amid heavy trading on Monday (Jun 26) after the company said it was aware of a possible transaction for an offer for its shares.

site_title: Europe: Shares ends 2023 up 12.6% on rate cut optimism, Italy best performer
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 closed 2023 with an annual gain of 12.6% on hopes of softer monetary policy from major central banks in 2024. The index posted its seventh straight weekly gain and best December performance since 2021. Rate-sensitive technology stocks led gains, while Italian shares rose almost 30% this year. The European Central Bank has yet to indicate potential rate cuts, but money markets suggest an 80% chance of a first cut in March.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 slipped 0.1 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Gold set for best year in three as Fed rate cut bets boost appeal
summary: Gold prices are set for their best year in three, rising 14% in 2023, driven by bets on US interest rate cuts and easing inflation. The US dollar index is poised for its worst yearly performance in three years, boosting gold's appeal. Cooler inflation data has strengthened interest rate cut expectations, making gold more attractive as a non-yielding asset.

images.alt_text: A Bloomberg gauge of the greenback is down nearly 3 per cent since January in the steepest annual drop for the US currency since 2020.

(FILES) Gold bullion bars are pictured after being inspected and polished at the ABC Refinery in Sydney on August 5, 2020. Gold prices soared to a record high above USD 2,100 on December 4, 2023 as traders grow increasingly confident the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates in the new year. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)
The price of gold in Vietnam has skyrocketed this month, reaching a peak of 80 million dong per ounce on Tuesday.

site_title: Three myths about investing for retirement
summary: Retirement planning is more challenging than initially thought, with uncertainty surrounding market fluctuations, income, health, and longevity. Common misconceptions about investing for retirement include thinking that a fixed rate of return is necessary, believing that inflation is always a bad thing, and assuming that saving enough is the only concern. However, experts emphasize the importance of focusing on long-term wealth creation and making the most of available resources, rather than relying on unrealistic assumptions.

images.alt_text: To fully expoit the returns from the stock market, it is important to start investing as early as possible.
A survey of 2,000 working adults in Singapore has found that the proportion who either do not have a retirement plan or are not on track with any is a worrying 79 per cent.
Those who do find it tough to keep investing in volatile times can consider taking advantage of the higher interest rates the government pays on Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies.

site_title: Indonesia’s bumper IPO harvest to continue as Asean middle class fuels growth
summary: Indonesia's initial public offerings (IPOs) are expected to continue driving growth in the Asean region in 2024, with the country raising $3.6 billion across 80 listings in 2023. The Asean region as a whole raised $5.7 billion in IPOs, down from $7.9 billion in 2022 due to macroeconomic challenges. Despite this, investors are optimistic about the market, citing a growing middle-class population, improved accessibility, and rising financial literacy. Other countries, such as Thailand and Malaysia, are also expected to see increased IPO activity, driven by consumer sectors and companies seeking capital.

images.alt_text: market watchers are mixed on whether the local bourse will see new listings of business trusts, a key yield product of the Singapore Exchange (SGX).
Plaza Senayan XXI in Jakarta, Indonesia. Cinema XXI has It 1,230 screens in 228 cinema locations across 55 Indonesian cities, as at the end of the first quarter of 2023.
Leaders of the US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity members at the Apec Summit in San Francisco.

site_title: China is softening stance on gaming after US$80 billion rout
summary: China approved 105 domestic games on December 25, a move seen as a softening of its stance on gaming after the US$80 billion industry rout caused by tightened industry restrictions. The approvals include games operated by Tencent Holdings and NetEase, China's leading game publishers. Chinese officials will listen to feedback from stakeholders to improve the rules, which include restrictions on spending by adult players and content that violates national security. The move aims to support the development of online gaming and promote fair practices.

images.alt_text: The administration is seeking public comment on the rules by Jan 22, 2024.

site_title: Turkish airport operator and Malaysia Airports seek deal on Istanbul airport: sources
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan inaugurated the Sabiha Gokcen airport's second runway, costing approximately US$970 million. IC Holding, a Turkish infrastructure company, is in talks with Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd about a collaboration deal for the Istanbul Sabiha Gokcen airport, potentially leading to an acquisition of a stake by IC Holding. The airport has seen a 21% increase in passengers between January and November, making it the third-busiest airport in the country.

images.alt_text: Work stoppage is delaying flights during the busy Christmas rush.
Indonesian President Joko Widodo has pledged to boost GDP growth to 5.2 per cent in 2024.
The Royal Schiphol Group says it could only meet demand for 483,000 flights if airlines would commit to altering schedules.

site_title: Seafarers’ safety must be top priority in Red Sea crisis
summary: The international crew of the vehicle carrier Galaxy Leader is being held in Yemen by Houthi rebels, sparking concerns for seafarers' safety. The International Bargaining Forum (IBF) has designated the southern Red Sea and Bab el-Mandeb strait as a High Risk Area, requiring vessels to follow enhanced security measures and double pay for those in the area. The designation aims to safeguard the globally important trade route and ensure the health and safety of seafarers, but critics argue that double pay is not enough to alleviate concerns.

images.alt_text: Maersk was preparing to allow for vessels both eastbound and westbound to resume transit through the Red Sea, under the protection from the multi-national security coalition.
Cargo ship Galaxy Leader has been anchored off a Yemeni port controlled by Houthi rebels since it was seized by armed men in November.

site_title: Police investigating alleged misappropriation at Kim Heng; unit’s GM sacked
summary: Police are investigating alleged misappropriation and suspicious purchases at Kim Heng's subsidiary, Zale Offshore, with estimated losses of S$160,000 (1.8% of 2022 net profit). The case involves inflated transactions and fixed asset misappropriation, linked to the unit's former general manager, who was sacked last month. The police are now handling the case, and Kim Heng is cooperating with the authorities. The incident is considered "gross misconduct" and is not expected to impact the company's audited financial statements.

images.alt_text: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine incorporates JV company and branch in Taiwan
Kim Heng Offshore & Marine secures fabrication jobs totalling S$7m

site_title: JD.com preps big pay hikes even as Chinese consumption gyrates
summary: JD.com plans to nearly double fixed salaries for procurement, sales, and other front-line staff, and offer 20% plus pay hikes for retail staff starting January 1. The move comes as the e-commerce company faces intense competition and uncertain Chinese consumption in 2024. JD.com's revenue rose 1.7% last quarter, but growth remains anaemic. The company has been adopting discounts and lower prices to entice consumers during the economic recovery. JD.com's human resource costs totaled 25.9 billion yuan (S$4.8 billion) last quarter.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week in the black amid festive cheer; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.9% on Friday, December 22, amid festive cheer, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 27.82 points to 3,140.32. Local banks OCBC, DBS, and UOB were top gainers, while Singtel rose 1.3%. The broader market saw 311 gainers and 248 losers, with 1.2 billion securities worth S$810 million changing hands. Analysts attribute the improvement to stable economic conditions and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Advisory fees from completed mergers and acquisitions are down 41 per cent year on year to US$205.2 million.
Fed chair Jerome Powell and his colleagues are now set to cut interest rates “earlier and faster,” beginning in March.

site_title: Top Chinese solar firm Tongwei plans 28 billion yuan factory as consolidation looms
summary: China's top solar firm, Tongwei, plans to build a 28 billion yuan ($5.2 billion) factory in northern China to produce 500,000 tonnes of industrial silicon and 400,000 tonnes of polysilicon annually. The expansion comes as the industry struggles with falling profitability due to a price war and looming consolidation. The factory will start production in 2026, after the sector recovers from the current round of consolidation. This move aims to benefit from low raw material costs, with the first phase delivering half of its planned capacity by 2025.

images.alt_text: The predicted shake-out is happening even as installations continue to pick up pace with 142.6 gigawatts has been added in China in the first 10 months of the year.

site_title: Tesla buys land for Shanghai Megapack battery factory
summary: Tesla has acquired land to build its Shanghai Megapack factory, which will have a capacity to produce 10,000 battery packs per year. The factory, set to start construction in the third quarter of this year, will primarily export megapacks, following the Lathrop plant in California. The acquisition is part of Tesla's growing energy generation business, which recorded $1.6 billion in revenue in the third quarter, driven by Megapack sales.

site_title: Vietnam 2023 trade surplus seen tripling to US$30 billion
summary: Vietnam is expected to record a trade surplus of US$30 billion in 2023, tripling last year's surplus. The country's exports are expected to be worth US$354.5 billion, down 4.6% annually, due to weak global demand. This would be the eighth consecutive year of a trade surplus, helping strengthen foreign exchange reserves and stabilize the currency. The ministry attributes the decrease to weak global demand, while retail sales are expected to rise 9.6% this year.

site_title: A retrospective perspective: how the global economy has changed in 35 years
summary: The global economy over the past 35 years has been shaped by three dominant themes: the great disinflation, the rise of China, and the rise of government debt. The great disinflation, which began in the late 1980s, saw inflation steadily fall year after year, leading to asset bubbles and market volatility. The rise of China, starting in the early 2000s, has been a significant economic force, increasing global trade and supply, but also leading to job losses and widening income inequality in Western countries. The rise of government debt has become a major concern, with many economists warning of a potential debt crisis. These three themes will likely continue to shape the global economy and markets in the decades ahead, with China's influence expected to remain a key factor.

Sri Lankan protesters in 2022, calling for the president to resign over the economic crisis. Sri Lanka has faced long delays in receiving debt relief, because their Chinese creditors refuse to agree to the debt-restructuring terms agreed in the Paris Club.

site_title: The coming debt crisis
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that a rising share of countries, 56% of low-income nations and 25% of emerging markets, are in or at high levels of debt distress. A developing-world debt crisis is looming due to unsustainable debt levels, with creditors refusing to roll over claims or extend new loans with high interest rates. To address this, an international agreement is needed to establish procedures for supporting debt-distressed sovereigns, enabling the IMF to deliver loans faster. Debt relief must be conditioned on sound, realistic, and business-friendly economic policies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The World Bank logo is seen at the 2023 Spring Meetings of the World Bank Group and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: We’ll be home for Christmas: warm thoughts for the holiday season
summary: Two prominent business personalities, Rachel Lim and Loh Lik Peng, share their thoughts on the holiday season, Christmas, and personal growth. Rachel Lim, co-founder of Love, Bonito, reflects on her transformative year, which included expanding her brand, launching a podcast, and welcoming her second child. She values Christmas as a time for reflection, connection, and family. Loh Lik Peng, a hotelier and restaurateur, prioritizes family time and celebrates Christmas at home, where he enjoys traditional meals and values the importance of connection. Both emphasize the importance of simplicity, kindness, and introspection during the holiday season.

images.alt_text: Moleskine's Precious and Ethical Collection is a special holiday collection featuring a tactile vegan cover.

site_title: Coming home for Christmas
summary: Several Singaporeans will spend Christmas abroad, but some business personalities have chosen to stay in the country. In an interview, four individuals - Rachel Lim, Loh Lik Peng, Linus Lim, and Choe Peng Sum - shared their Christmas plans, despite hectic travel schedules. They reflected on the past year and emphasized the importance of being with loved ones locally. The article also highlights eco-conscious gift ideas and recommends a new fine-dining eatery, Imbue, on Keong Saik Road.

site_title: Asia: Markets track another Wall Street record on rate hopes
summary: Asian stocks rose over 1% on Wednesday, following another record performance on Wall Street, as traders bet on the US Federal Reserve slashing interest rates several times in 2024. Despite central bank officials pushing back against expectations, markets are optimistic about a healthy end-of-year rally. The next key event will be the release of the US personal consumption expenditures price index, which has fallen in recent months and is seen as a key indicator of inflation.

images.alt_text: Eyes are now on the Bank of Japan as it concludes a two-day meeting.

site_title: China EV maker Nio wins US$2.2 billion Abu Dhabi cash boost
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio has secured a US$2.2 billion investment from Abu Dhabi-backed fund CYVN Holdings, which will own a 20.1% stake in the company. The investment, part of a larger cash injection, comes after Nio's sales and revenue fell short of targets, with the company posting losses and considering further job cuts. Nio's stock jumped 9.5% in premarket trading following the announcement, as CYVN chairman Jassem Al Zaabi expressed confidence in Nio's competitiveness in the global EV market.

images.alt_text: Nio, which currently competes with EVs offered by premium carmakers like BMW, and Mercedes-Benz at a price point above US$42,000 in China, is facing expanding losses as a price war started by Tesla weighed on its profitability.

site_title: Nightmares before Christmas 3
summary: The article discusses various topics, including a comic strip about "Nightmares Before Christmas 3", rising COE premiums, a money laundering case involving the President's Challenge, and assets seized in an anti-money laundering probe. Additionally, two individuals, Iswaran and Ong Beng Seng, were arrested and released on bail in a CPIB probe. The article also touches on various business and economic topics, including Good Class Bungalow prices, the challenges faced by fresh grads in Singapore, and the startup ecosystem in South-east Asia.

site_title: OpenAI outlines AI safety plan, allowing board to reverse decisions
summary: OpenAI has outlined a safety plan for its most advanced models, allowing the board to reverse decisions if deemed necessary. The company will only deploy its latest technology in areas such as cybersecurity and nuclear threats if deemed safe. An advisory group will review safety reports, with the board having the authority to override executive decisions. This plan comes amid growing concerns over AI's potential dangers, with a Reuters/Ipsos poll finding 61% of Americans believe AI could threaten civilization.

site_title: Lenovo’s 60% rally may extend as AI adds to optimism
summary: Lenovo's stock has surged 60% this year, driven by optimism over global demand recovery for PCs and enthusiasm for its AI products. The company, which generates 75% of its revenue overseas, is less exposed to China's slowing economy. Analysts predict Lenovo's strong performance will continue, with Goldman Sachs setting a price target of HK$11.79, implying a 15% upside. The company aims to report PC revenue growth this quarter, and investors are expressing bullishness in the options market, with the right to buy Lenovo shares in three months trading at a premium.

images.alt_text: Intel’s pitch to consumers and businesses comes as it is fighting its way out of a post-pandemic PC slump where buyers who upgraded to work from home in 2020 have seen little reason to buy new equipment.
The Chinese company buys advanced processors from American chip suppliers such as Advanced Micro Devices to Nvidia for its consumer and enterprise products.

site_title: China’s weak property sector, retail sales keep stimulus calls alive
summary: China's retail sales rose 10.1% in November, but the country's property sector worsened, with new home prices falling for the fifth straight month and property investment declining 9.4% year-on-year. Industrial output grew 6.6% in November, beating expectations, but retail sales missed forecasts, and fixed asset investment expanded only 2.9% year-on-year. Analysts say different parts of the economy are running at different speeds, and long-standing issues persist, prompting calls for further stimulus to support an annual economic growth target of around 5%.

images.alt_text: The central bank cut policy rates twice this year to support the economy.
Aggregate financing is 2.45 trillion yuan (S$461 billion), the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) says.

Fitch forecast mainland China’s gross domestic product (GDP) growth would moderate to 4.6 per cent from just over 5 per cent in 2023, adding it “forecast growth to be broadly stable and generally at levels above those of rating peers.”

site_title: Japan to use more tax incentives to encourage wage increases
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party has agreed to offer more tax incentives to companies that administer large wage increases, potentially boosting the nation's chances of achieving the virtuous cycle of pay gains and inflation. The plan extends tax incentives to companies raising wages by 7% or more, with up to 35% of the value deductible from corporate taxes. This move aims to support sustainable wage growth, a key concern for the Bank of Japan, which has been monitoring the strength of overall demand and whether wage gains will support prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker checks machinery at a factory in Higashiosaka, Japan June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Sakura Murakami/File Photo

site_title: Grape expectations adapt to climate change
summary: Climate change is affecting the global wine industry, particularly in temperate regions, causing production problems and disruptions in supply chains. Rising temperatures are altering grape quality and leading to changes in the wine's taste, with some wine varieties becoming unrecognizable. Importers and distributors in Singapore are facing challenges, including a smaller allocation of vintage wines, rising costs, and logistical issues. The impact is expected to grow as the wine industry expands in Singapore, with the market projected to increase by 3-4% annually. Wine businesses are adapting by diversifying supply, sourcing wines from new regions, and being more forward-looking in their planning.

images.alt_text: Wine losing favour among French younger generations who prefer beer and spirits over traditional wine culture.
Based on the chemical composition of wines made in Bordeaux, France, a new computer model can determine which estate each bottle was made in.
Sam Wu, a certified water sommelier, pays close attention to the mineral composition of various water brands.

site_title: Thailand to roll out relief measures for household debt
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has announced debt relief measures to help 10.3 million people struggling to service debt, with measures including lowering interest rates and debt suspensions. The country's household debt is 16 trillion baht (S$603.3 billion) and stands at 90.7% of the country's gross domestic product. The measures will cover teachers, civil servants, and farmers, with additional programs to improve financial management and savings. The goal is to reduce risk across the financial system and improve credit and risk assessment of institutions.

images.alt_text: The value of Thai investments in foreign capital markets reached US$106 billion in 2022, according to Bank of Thailand statistics.
An employee counts Thai one-thousand baht banknotes at a bank in Bangkok, Thailand.Photographer: Luke Duggleby/Bloomberg

An investor monitors electronic stock boards at a brokerage in Bangkok, Thailand, on Monday, May 24, 2010. The consumer index of the University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce increased to 60.9 in November from 60.2 in the previous month.
The economy is expected to grow 2.8 per cent to 3.3 per cent next year.

site_title: Dive into authentic Sri Lankan cooking at Kunthaville
summary: Kunthaville, a homespun Sri Lankan eatery in Singapore's Little India, offers authentic and delicious dishes. The restaurant features light and fluffy coconut rice, tangy appam with caramelized onions, and crispy deep-fried patties of mashed beetroot. Kunthaville's cozy atmosphere is reminiscent of a neighbor's home, inviting customers to indulge in their culinary offerings. With its unique flavors and welcoming ambiance, Kunthaville is a must-visit destination for food enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: Donabe of Japanese rice, herbs and char-grilled tilefish.

site_title: Tencent turns to ByteDance in gaming showdown with NetEase
summary: Tencent, China's largest gaming firm, has partnered with rival ByteDance to promote its new game, DreamStar, on ByteDance's platforms despite a history of competition. About 38% of DreamStar ads were placed on ByteDance's Pangolin ad service, a significant departure from Tencent's own ad network. The move is part of Tencent's $1.4 billion investment to build out DreamStar's ecosystem. This thaw in relations comes as ByteDance winds down its gaming business to focus on core operations, amid China's gaming industry returning to growth after a two-year crackdown.

images.alt_text: NetEase is still up 43 per cent this year, far outpacing Tencent as well as Chinese technology and global game peers.

site_title: Lava fountains gush as volcanic eruption rocks Iceland
summary: A volcanic eruption has begun in southwest Iceland, sending lava fountains hundreds of feet into the sky. The eruption, which started on Monday, is located near the Reykjanes Peninsula and poses a risk to nearby infrastructure, including a fishing town, a power plant, and the Blue Lagoon spa. Flights are operating at the main international airport, Keflavik, with no or minor ash emission. Authorities are monitoring the situation, with geophysicist Freysteinn Sigmundsson stating that the eruption's vigour is declining and it is likely to follow a typical pattern of initial power and rapid decline.

images.alt_text: Epicentre is about 100 kilometres southwest of Gansu province’s capital, Lanzhou.
Total economic losses from natural catastrophes, including those that are not insured, are an estimated US$260 billion in 2023.
Students evacuate from their school building in Manila on Oct 13, 2023, after a magnitude 5.2 earthquake struck about 100 km south of the Philippine capital.

site_title: Global rate-cut standoff looms in 2023 policy finale
summary: Central bankers are set to gather for their final policy meetings of the year, with the US Federal Reserve expected to keep interest rates on hold. The global inflation cycle is causing unease, with investors betting on rate cuts in the first half of 2024. The Bank of England is also expected to keep rates on hold, despite the UK economy facing stagnation next year. The European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank are also expected to maintain current rates, with the ECB potentially tempering market expectations of a rate cut in April.

images.alt_text: Flood waters submerge parked cars in Hue city in central Vietnam on November 15, 2023.
Global economic data has begun to show a clear trend that multi-decade highs in inflation – caused by the rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic and spike in energy prices – are in the rear-view mirror.

site_title: Addvalue, Renaissance United, Telechoice and Tiong Seng on SGX watch list
summary: Four Singapore Exchange-listed companies, Addvalue Technologies, Renaissance United, Telechoice International, and Tiong Seng, have been placed on a watch list due to consecutive pre-tax losses and failing to maintain a minimum market cap of S$40 million over six months. Renaissance United attributed its losses to the Covid-19 pandemic, while Addvalue expressed confidence in its business momentum despite the watch-list status. The companies face risk of delisting or share trading suspension if they fail to improve their financial position and market valuation.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Tay Peck Gek
Jadason Enterprises will have to meet requirements under Rule 1314(1) of the Listing Manual to be removed from the watch-list within 36 months from Jun 6.

In its clarification, the group cites factors including the global travel recovery, new contract wins, operational efficiencies and synergies achieved through the integration with World Flight Services.

site_title: Europe: Shares take a breather after sharp rally last week
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index slipped 0.1% on Monday after touching a four-month high, despite a third straight weekly gain. Miners and energy stocks fell due to weak commodity prices, while investors await data on eurozone PMI, producer prices, and gross domestic product to gauge inflation and economic outlook. The index has risen nearly 10% year-to-date, underperforming the US S&P 500's near-20% jump, with analysts predicting interest rate cuts in Europe sooner than the US.

images.alt_text: Germany’s DAX Index gained 1.1 per cent to end the week just shy of a record.

site_title: SpaceX carries South Korea’s first spy satellite to orbit
summary: South Korea successfully launched its first domestically made spy satellite into orbit using a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, following North Korea's similar move last month. The satellite has a telescope with electro-optical/infrared sensors, capable of identifying objects as small as 30 centimeters, and is expected to provide South Korea with independent space surveillance and reconnaissance capabilities. The launch is part of a broader effort to develop South Korea's space program, with plans to put five spy satellites in orbit by 2025.

Elon Musk’s visit coincides with a four-day truce in an Israeli war with Palestinian Hamas militants in Gaza during which 40 of the 240 hostages Israel says have been held by Hamas have returned to Israel.

SpaceX's Starship mega rocket, which launched from a base in Boca Chica, Texas, on Nov 18, briefly reached space for the first time before both the ship and its main booster were lost minutes into the flight.

site_title: COP28 head presses nations to reach climate ‘compromise’
summary: COP28 president Sultan Al Jaber urged nearly 200 nations to work towards a "historic" deal by early next week, with a goal of having a draft agreement by 11 am on Tuesday. The conference has been unable to produce an updated draft agreement due to disagreements over the fate of fossil fuels, with some nations backing phasing them out and others opposing it. Scientists warn that greenhouse gas emissions must fall by 43% by 2030 to limit warming to 1.5 deg C, and climate campaigners have expressed skepticism about Al Jaber's efforts to ease concerns about his position as head of UAE national oil firm ADNOC.

images.alt_text: The extraordinary global November temperatures, including two days warmer than 2 deg C above pre-industrial, mean that 2023 is the warmest year in recorded history,” deputy director of C3S Samantha Burgess said in a statement.

site_title: New Zealand to ban mobile phones in schools
summary: New Zealand's Prime Minister Christopher Luxon has announced a plan to ban mobile phones in schools within his first 100 days in office, aiming to improve literacy rates and reduce disruptive behavior. The move follows a "literacy crisis" in 2022, where over one-third of 15-year-olds could barely read or write. The ban is part of a broader effort to address declining literacy rates and is inspired by similar policies in the US, UK, and France.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank’s Monetary Policy Committee held the Official Cash Rate at 5.5 per cent on Wednesday in Wellington, as expected by all 23 economists surveyed
The Aussie is now up 5.2 per cent for November at US$0.6669.

New Zealand's new Prime Minister Christopher Luxon (C) takes an oath before New Zealand's Governor General Dame Cindy Kiro (R) during the swearing-in of the new government at Government House in Wellington on November 27, 2023. Former airline boss Christopher Luxon formally took office as New Zealand's prime minister on November 27, vowing to tame inflation and bring down interest rates. (Photo by Marty MELVILLE / AFP)
New Zealand's National Party leader Christopher Luxon is credited with boosting National’s popularity ahead of the Oct 14 general election following a crushing loss three years earlier.

site_title: HK's Swire Pacific approves US$768 million share buyback programme
summary: Swire Pacific, a Hong Kong-based conglomerate, has approved a US$768 million share buyback program that will begin on December 6 and conclude in May 2025. The program is funded by existing capital and cash reserves, and comes as the company reported a 120% jump in profit for the first six months of the year. This is the second share buyback program announced by Swire Pacific, following a successful HK$4 billion (S$684.9 million) program earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Swire Pacific, one of the city’s largest developers and owner of Cathay Pacific Airways, profits had already taken a hit after strict pandemic measures effectively shut down travel and tourism in the financial hub.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei posts first weekly drop in five as tech drags
summary: Japan's Nikkei index ended the day 0.17% lower at 33,431.51, marking its first weekly drop in five, as tech shares declined due to elevated bond yields. The Nikkei fell 0.58% for the week, while the Topix rose 0.32% but slumped 0.35% for the week. The tech sector was the only decline, with tech-heavy companies such as SoftBank Group and Tokyo Electron experiencing significant losses.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei ended the day up 0.5 per cent at 33,486.89, extending the benchmark index’s gain for the month to 8.52 per cent, the most since November 2020.

site_title: Mod-Sin cooking izakaya style at Focal
summary: Singaporean chefs Marcus Leow and Jonathan Gan have transformed the former Magic Square space into Focal, a casual izakaya-style restaurant. The menu features a mix of Asian-inspired dishes, including parsnip bingka ubi with peanut butter ice cream, char-grilled frog's legs with laksa leaf pesto, and donabe of Japanese rice, herbs, and char-grilled tilefish. Leow's cooking style is described as a freestyle riff on ingredients, cooking styles, and Asian inspirations, with a focus on casual comfort food. Focal is open for dinner Tuesdays to Saturdays and lunch on Fridays to Saturdays, with a rating of 6.5.

images.alt_text: Bacata's decor is a riot of colour.

site_title: Innovation wins at World Architecture Festival 2023
summary: The World Architecture Festival 2023, held in Singapore, recognized 495 projects from over 800 entries in its 16th year. The festival focused on "Catalyst" theme, driving positive change through architecture and design. Winners included Huizhen High School, a Chinese school that incorporates nature into its design, and 19 Waterloo Street, a small Australian house that creatively uses space. Other winners included The Probiotic Tower, a repurposed water tower system for cities, and Benjakitti Forest Park, a Bangkok park transformed into a living ecosystem. The festival's programme director noted that the winning projects showcased how design can be a catalyst for positive change, and many of the projects were replicable and modular.

site_title: Gear from The Big Lebowski to go under the hammer
summary: The brown robe worn by Jeff Bridges in the 1998 film The Big Lebowski is set to be auctioned off in California, with an estimated value of up to $50,000. The robe, one of several items from the film, will be sold as part of a four-day "Hollywood Legends" auction, alongside other memorabilia such as E.T.'s animatronic head and Princess Diana's engagement blouse, which could fetch up to $100,000.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, Keppel Corp, Genting Singapore, Keppel DC Reit
summary: Key companies to watch: CapitaLand Investment faces significant net profit reduction due to a weakening macro environment. Keppel Corp partners with Greenko to explore biogenic carbon-based sustainable fuels. Genting Singapore fined S$2.25 million for lapses in customer due diligence. Keppel DC Reit issues S$90 million of floating rate notes. Banyan Tree decouples from joint ventures with China's China Vanke.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand logo on the facade of the Funan mall on Jan 6, 2023.

site_title: JPMorgan to outsource US$500 billion custody business in Hong Kong, Taiwan: sources
summary: JPMorgan Chase is set to outsource its local custody business in Hong Kong and Taiwan to another bank, with Citigroup, HSBC, and Standard Chartered in the running. The US bank has around $520 billion worth of client assets under local custody in the two markets. The move, expected to be completed by the end of next year, will mark JPMorgan's exit from the local custodian business in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign outside the headquarters of JPMorgan Chase & Co in New York, September 19, 2013. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Bordeaux wine snobs have a point, says this computer model
summary: A new computer model can determine the Bordeaux estate of each bottle based on its chemical composition, challenging the notion of terroir as a mysterious and exclusive factor. The model, developed by a computational neuroscientist, achieved 50% accuracy in predicting the vintage of the wine. This breakthrough could potentially verify the authenticity of expensive Bordeaux wines, which often rely on traditional methods and soil characteristics to justify their high prices. The model's findings may also shed light on the complex chemical processes involved in wine production.

images.alt_text: This photograph taken on November 9, 2023 shows a scientist analysing experimental Chateau La Tour Carnet wine at the Institut des Sciences de la Vigne et du Vin (Wine Science Institute) in Villenave-d'Ornon, outside Bordeaux, southwestern France. When it comes to research, the Chateau de la Tour Carnet is a step ahead. Since 2013, this property of wine emperor Bernard Magrez has launched a study into the effects of global warming by 2050, planting a collection of 96 grape varieties alongside the traditional Bordeaux signatures of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc. (Photo by Christophe ARCHAMBAULT / AFP)

site_title: Tiny electric vehicles pack a bigger climate punch than cars
summary: Tiny electric vehicles, such as motorcycles and three-wheeled cars, are significantly reducing global oil demand and greenhouse gas emissions. According to BloombergNEF, two and three-wheelers account for 60% of the 1.8 million barrels of oil reduced daily. Electric vehicles are also reducing air pollution, linked to an estimated 7 million premature deaths annually. In Asia and Africa, startups and established manufacturers are promoting electric mobility, with China dominating the market. However, government policy remains a significant obstacle, with countries like Mexico subsidizing oil rather than batteries.

images.alt_text: An electric rickshaw driver charges up at a Mahindra showroom in Darbhanga, India on Nov. 19, 2023. Of all the changes the world is making to slow global warming, electric vehicle sales are the only category on track to meet climate goals. Few in the west appreciate that the bulk of gains so far have come not from cars, but the electrified two- and three-wheeled vehicles now common in Asia and Africa. (Rebecca Conway/The New York Times)
Wind turbines in South Sulawesi. The interest to invest in technologies that address carbon emissions and the impacts of climate change has been growing over the past five years.

Senior Minister of State Dr Amy Khor trying out the EV charging app at the launch of the largest e-roaming service across both sides of the Causeway   regulates the supply, installation, certification, registration, use, and maintenance of chargers for the green vehicles in Singapore.
Some conservative lawmakers have challenged Ford Motor’s plans to license technology from the Chinese battery giant known as CATL for a plant in Marshall, Michigan.

site_title: He ain’t heavy, he’s my father
summary: Eurokars Group, owned by 75-year-old entrepreneur Karsono Kwee, has officially opened its new headquarters, a $106 million complex housing two luxury car showrooms, one for Rolls-Royce and the other for BMW. Kwee is stepping back, handing over to his children, Charmain and Herbert, who will oversee the 15,000-car empire. CEO Ong Lay Ling will guide them, providing a neutral presence. The younger Kwees acknowledge that succession is challenging, but Charmain emphasizes the importance of finding a passion for the business and learning from experience.

images.alt_text: (L-R) Charmain Kwee, executive director, Eurokars Group; Karsono Kwee, Executive Chairman, Eurokars Group

site_title: The Japanese ‘weirdo’ who built a cool toaster and changed the way we heat bread
summary: Japanese product designer Gen Terao, founder of Balmuda Design, has gained a cult following for his high-end home appliances, particularly the Balmuda toaster, which uses steam technology to create the perfect slice of toast. The company's flagship products, sold at its Singapore store, have become a status symbol among design-conscious homeowners. Despite Japan's emphasis on conformity, Terao's unconventional approach has led to his success, making him a notable example of innovation in the country's product design scene.

site_title: Another cocktail festival, but a different continent – Africa
summary: Ajabu, Africa's first international spirits and cocktail festival, is set to take place in South Africa from March 10 to 13, followed by events in Cape Town and later in 2024. The festival aims to celebrate Africa's unique contributions to the global cocktail scene, bringing together bartenders from across the continent and internationally renowned bars. Mark Talbot Holmes and Colin Asare-Appiah, co-founders of the event, aim to showcase Africa's emerging hotspots in the drinks industry and promote cultural exchange.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A barman stirs a cocktail based on the Chinese spirit baijiu at the Capital Spirits Baijiu Bar in Beijing, China June 22, 2017. Picture taken June 22, 2017.  REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Doritos Nacho Cheese-flavoured booze has just become a reality
summary: Doritos has partnered with Empirical Spirits to launch a limited-edition, 42% ABV Nacho Cheese-flavored booze. The beverage, available in the US for $65 per 750ml bottle, is inspired by the popular snack's flavor and features a similar taste profile. The collaboration is a result of an accidental experiment by Empirical's founders, who infused Doritos Nacho Cheese flavor into a spirit in 2017. The product will be available at select locations in New York and California, and may be extended if demand is high, with potential plans for a line of Doritos-meets-booze products.
